 Hello  to  your  gardeners.  I  know  right 
 now  um  you  are  seeing  such  devastation 
 in  your  gardens.  Um  this  last  week's 
 freeze  was  just  catastrophic.  It  was  was

 um  to  really  kind  of  get  that  that  um 
 get  it  into  a  safe  spot.  The  one  thing  I 
 don't  know  if  I  stressed  enough  in  this 
 video  is  do  not  trim  anything.  Do  do 
 nothing  when  it  comes  to  trimming  at 
 this  point.  Um  you  are  not  going  to  want 
 to  trim  until  we're  absolutely  certain 
 that  there  is  no  cold  snaps  going  to 
 happen.  So,  mid-March,  you  definitely 
 want  to  trim.  And  what  you  want  to  do 
 when  you're  doing  it  with  palm  frrons, 
 it's  pretty  easy  to  see,  right?  You  can 
 trim  off  anything  that's  brown.  But  when 
 it  comes  to  plants,  plants  are  going  to 
 be  sometimes  brown  from  the  top  all  the 
 way  to  the  bottom.  So,  what  you  want  to 
 do  is  you  want  to  really  kind  of  see 
 like  scrape  it  off  with  your  nails.  See 
 where  the  green  stem  it  where  it  stops 
 being  green  and  goes  to  brown.  That's 
 your  line.  The  top  section  of  that 
 plant.  If  you  scrape  it  at  the  top 
 section,  it's  going  to  be  all  brown, 
 brown,  brown,  brown.  Once  it  gets  to 
 that  green  section,  that's  the  area 
 where  new  growth  happens.  So,  you  trim 
 right  there.  You  use  your  hand  clippers. 
 This  is  the  time  where  it's  really 
 important  to  use  hand  clippers  because 
 you  want  to  make  sure  you're  a  surgeon 
 right  now.  You're  you're  just  cutting 
 away  the  dead.  So,  you  want  to  take  this 
 time  and  make  sure  that  you  get  off  as 
 much  of  that  old  growth  as  possible 
 because  what'll  happen  right  where  the 
 new  growth  starts  to  grow  in,  it'll  kind 
 of  flush  back  out  and  it'll  be  beautiful 
 so  much  faster.  I've  seen  where  people 
 take  it  all  the  way  down  to  the  bottom 
 or  don't  take  enough  of  it  and  do  small 
 sections  and  then  you've  got  brown  and 
 then  you've  got,  you  know,  bushes 
 growing  out  on  the  sides  because  they 
 can't  grow  out  on  the  top.  they're  not 
 kind  of  there  yet.  So,  really  pay 
 attention  as  you're  as  you're  looking 
 through  that.  If  it's  a  big  area,  just 
 clip  clip  clip  till  you  start  seeing  the 
 green.  Once  you  see  the  green  on  the 
 inside  of  the  stem,  then  you  know  that 
 that's  all  live  material.  And  then 
 that's  now  that's  your  new  that's  your 
 new  base.  That's  where  you  kind  of 
 everything's  going  to  flush  back  from 
 that  point.  So,  I'm  trying  to  think  if 
 there's  anything  else  that  I  can  tell 
 you  guys  that  might  be  helpful  at  this 
 point.  Um, 
 you  know,  I  guess  the  next  thing  would 
 just  be  don't  just  don't  be  discouraged. 
 I  mean,  I  know  that  this  has  happened

 time  and  effort  into  our  our  beautiful 
 gardens  and  creating  our  beautiful 
 spaces.  Um,  and  don't  let  these  little 
 freak  temperatures,  you  know,  stop  you

---

 Thank  you  so  much  for  joining  me  today. 
 We  are  in  a  fun  tropical  backyard  that 
 we  designed  and  installed  a  couple 
 months  ago.  So,  I  thought  I  would  bring 
 you  along  and  share  with  you  the  plants 
 and  the  trees  that  we  chose  for  the 
 area.  Now,  if  you  guys  are  thinking  of  a 
 no  grass  backyard  or  little  grass 
 backyard,  then  this  video  might  just 
 really  be  up  your  alley  because  we  took 
 out  all  the  grass  and  we  made  more  of  a 
 garden  setting  for  my  clients  back  here. 
 It's  more  of  a  tropical  garden  with  a 
 little  walkway  and  just  kind  of  enjoying 
 the  whole  space  without  any  maintenance 
 of  grass  back  here.  All right,  so  we  are 
 over  here  right  at  the  front.  So,  just 
 to  give  you  guys  kind  of  a  point  of 
 reference,  right  here,  of  course,  is  the 
 back  side  of  the  house.  This  long 
 walkway  of  grass  is  going  to  go  into 
 next  phase.  So,  my  clients  are  planning 
 on  that  being  a  lovely  walkway  just  like 
 their  backyard  spaces  surrounded  by 
 gardens  on  both  sides,  but  that's  to 
 come.  Right  now,  this  is  the  start  of 
 the  back  garden  here  and  we  have  a 
 collection  of  pink  hibiscus  as  the 
 backdrop  here.  Of  course,  we're  in 
 December,  so  they're  not  really  in

 large  8-ft  wall.  We  have  a  lovely

 we  have  three  single  trees  here.  And  I

 they're  very  hard  to  find.  But  these 
 were  existing  here.  They  were  one  solid 
 tree.  Like  they  allowed  them  to  become  a 
 wall  here.  And  so  when  we  came  in,  we 
 divide  them  and  they're  really  starting 
 to  flush  back  out  and  come  together. 
 They're  a  nice  slow  growing  tree,  a  nice 
 slow  growing  hardwood.  You  can  see  these 
 berries  here.  So  they  do  produce  some 
 droppings.  So  that  is  something  to 
 consider  if  you're  planning  on  using

 The  shininess  to  it.  It  reminds  me  a

 use  instead.  Now,  we  have  the  Kucia  as 
 the  backdrop.  You  can  tell  this  area 
 doesn't  get  a  lot  of  sun  because  Kousas 
 thin  out  a  little  bit  when  they  don't 
 have  a  lot  of  sun  exposure,  and  this  was 
 also  existing  here,  so  we  just  worked 
 with  it.  So,  if  you  do  have  that 
 particular  area,  you  might  have  to 
 fertilize  your  Kucia  more  in  the  shade 
 than  you  would  in  the  sun  because  they 
 do  just  need  that  extra  bit  of  nutrients 
 to  kind  of  help  keep  them  nice  and  thick 
 and  dense  and  producing.  At  the  corner, 
 we  have  a  triple  spindle  palm.  Kind  of 
 gives  you  just  a  nice  soft  airy  look  to 
 it.  It's  doing  really,  really  well.  It 
 was  existing  here,  so  we  were  able  to 
 keep  it.  Had  some  deficiencies,  but  I 
 can  see  all  the  new  growth  now  after  the 
 new  fertilizing  the  Palm  Saber  we  put  on 
 it.  is  just  flushing  out  so  lovely.  And 
 then  if  you  guys  are  looking  for  a 
 bedding  plant  and  you  don't  want  a 
 hedge,  try  these  burl  marks.  These 
 little  burly  marks  are  just  the  coolest 
 little  plant.  They're  a  filerendrian. 
 They  kind  of  cascade  over  and  cluster 
 together.  Now,  they're  definitely  not 
 one  you  want  to  try  on  single  like  a 
 like  one  over  there  and  then  plant 
 grouping.  They  do  need  kind  of  a 
 connection  of  their  brothers  with  them. 
 So,  if  you  do  want  kind  of  a  sea  of 
 green,  they  do  a  nice  job  of  that.  and 
 they  have  a  such  a  glossy  leaf  that  I 
 think  it's  just  such  a  lovely  bedding  to 
 any  kind  of  plant  grouping.  So,  if  you 
 kind  of  want  a  jungle  floor  plant  in  the 
 shade  with  a  lot  of  acidity  from  leaves, 
 this  is  a  fantastic  bedding  plant  to 
 work  with.  And  this  is  about  the  size 
 that  it  gets  and  stays.  So,  you  can 
 easily  keep  it  around  2  and  1/2  3t  tall, 
 no  problem.  Grows  super  slow.  Before  we 
 move  on,  I  guess  I  should  mention  this 
 cool  pathway  in  the  middle  of  the 
 gardens.  We  have  a  garden  on  one  side 
 and  a  garden  on  the  opposite  side.  And 
 we  decided  to  take  out  the  old  ugly  sod 
 that  would  not  just  live.  The  grass  just 
 does  not  like  being  underneath  of  these 
 trees.  Most  of  you  guys  are  probably 
 well  aware  of  that  and  fighting  that 
 same  battle.  If  that  is  you,  then  I 
 completely  get  it  because  grass  is  is 
 difficult.  It  was  always  muddy  and  mucky 
 here.  So,  when  we  were  creating  the 
 design,  I  was  walking  through  with  my 
 client  and  they  love  the  idea  of  just 
 having  a  soft  gravel,  more  organic 
 walkway  here.  We  have  a  gray  granite 
 stone.  It  is  the  smallest  variety,  the 
 half  inch.  So,  it's  kind  of  it  just 
 chunks  right  on  your  feet.  Really  easy 
 to  walk  on.  I  can  have  flip-flops  on  and 
 it's  just  so  easy  to  walk  on.  So,  this 
 is  the  perfect  perfect  little  thing  to 
 do.  Of  course,  you  guys  know  I  like  the 
 Tahesian  gray  granite,  too.  This  just 
 happened  to  be  the  gray  granite  that  was 
 in  stock.  So  either  one  of  them  works 
 super  super  well  and  it  kind  of  does  the 
 job  back  here.  We  didn't  want  anything 
 too  polished  because  this  is  a  soft 
 tropical  planting.  They  have  the 
 polished  look  all  by  the  pool  and  the 
 seating  section  and  all  that  that's 
 going  on  there  which  is  absolutely 
 lovely.  And  then  as  you  step  further 
 back  into  the  garden,  you  get  more  of 
 that  just  that  tropical  feel  that  more 
 like  grab  a  glass  of  wine  and  walk 
 through  the  garden  through  the  pathway. 
 And  that's  that's  what  they  wanted  and 
 that's  what  we  created  for  them.  And 
 it's  starting  to  come  together  really 
 lovely.  We'll  continue  to  watch  it 
 unfold  over  the  next  few  months.  Those 
 of  you  guys  who  have  not  subscribed, 
 please  subscribe.  We  post  every  single 
 weekend  and  we  would  love  to  see  you 
 every  Saturday.  Hit  that  notification 
 bell  and  you  will  know  that  we  have  a 
 video  coming  out  every  Saturday.  All 
 right,  so  now  we're  back  here  kind  of  at 
 the  beginning.  So  from  the  main  housing 
 area,  right  from  the  main  seating 
 section,  which  is  always  important  for 
 me  to  see,  is  to  have  good  balance  on 
 both  sides.  So  you  guys,  if  you  have  two 
 corner  areas  and  you're  able  to  balance 
 those  two  corner  sections  out  and  mimic 
 each  other,  that's  a  great  great  thing 
 to  do  because  when  you're  looking  at  it 
 from  one  central  location,  whether  it's 
 the  kitchen  window  or  the  back  patio 
 doors  or  the  pool  area,  whatever  that 
 might  be,  having  two  anchored  areas  is 
 perfect.  Now,  we  didn't  have  a  lot  of 
 sun  to  work  with.  So,  I  ended  up 
 choosing  a  clustering  of  antiloo  here 
 and  a  clustering  of  antiloo  back  in  that 
 rear  corner.  And  those  both  served  well 
 for  both  of  those  locations.  And  they're 
 really  drawing  the  eye  of  a  nice 
 contrasting  coloration  to  the  rest  of 
 the  plants  in  the  garden.  So,  we  have  a 
 nice  dark  green  and  yellow  and  these 
 Brazilian  red  cloaks.  With  the  greens, 
 we  needed  something  with  kind  of  a  year 
 round  color,  which  is  ideal.  Those 
 antiloo  will  do  a  nice  job  of  that.  So,

 Brazilian  red  cloaks.  This  little

 leaf  that's  here  with  the  green.  This 
 msianda  is  absolutely  stunning.  They're 
 very,  very  nice.  Now,  there  this  is 
 their  coldest  location.  And  then  they 
 can't  get  you  want  to  plant  them  in 
 nothing  colder  than  zone  10A  because 
 they  can  get  a  little  bit  delicate  when 
 it  comes  to  the  cold.  But  they're  so 
 worth  it  cuz  their  blooming  cycle  is 
 stunning.  You  get  8  to  10  months  of 
 blooms  from  them  every  year.  They're 
 just  such  a  delicate  like  little  look. 
 Now  I  don't  like  to  use  a  lot  of  them.  I 
 just  use  like  a  little  touch  of  those 
 for  a  variation  in  color.  Then  just  down

 gorgeous  white  clustering  flower.  I'm 
 really  been  a  big  fan  of  them  because

 light.  Those  are  its  two  favorites. 
 These  are  great.  You  can  keep  them  this

 leaves  are  just  stunning.  That's  from

 weather,  they  go  dark  like  that.  And 
 then  during  the  summer,  you'll  have  more 
 kind  of  light  bright  coloration  to  them. 
 So,  I  love  them  in  both  seasons.  We  had

 popping  back.  They're  so  just  they're 
 just  so  tough.  So,  don't  be  afraid.

 leaves  and  limbs  are  going  to  fall  and

 right,  so  as  we  move  on  to  this  corner, 
 you  can  see  these  Brazilian  red  cloaks 
 are  starting  to  really  take  off  in 
 bloom.  We've  got  new  blooms  and  new 
 color  coming  from  everywhere  on  those. 
 So,  in  answer  to  your  question  that  you 
 probably  have,  will  these  bloom  in  the 
 shade?  I  know  I  mention  this  all  the 
 time.  They  will  bloom  in  the  shade.  So, 
 they  can  handle  filtered  light,  they  can 
 handle  full  sun,  and  they  can  handle 
 good  shade.  They  do  prefer  filtered 
 light.  That's  their  ideal  plant.  If  you 
 put  them  in  full  sun,  make  sure  that  you 
 add  a  little  bit  of  a  water  or  soaker 
 hose  to  it.  So,  that  way  it  gets  a 
 little  bit  extra  irrigation.  So,  a 
 little  extra  bubbler  to  your  collection 
 of  your  Brazilian  red  cloaks  will  make 
 them  bloom  10  times  more.  They  really  do 
 get  that  good  energy  from  that  water 
 source.  So  don't  be  afraid  to  add  a 
 little  extra  water  to  this  particular 
 plant  for  some  happy  blooms.  So  as  we 
 make  our  way  back  up  to  the  walkway,  let

 does  not  get  this  big  claim  to  fame 
 because  it  is  just  a  little  tiny  grass. 
 You  know,  you  want  to  edge  any  kind  of 
 walkway  with  a  really  nice  edge  line.

 really  a  cool  kind  of  different  take  on

 think  the  combination  of  this  is  going

 something  a  little  bit  wild  and  crazy. 
 And  it's  just  something  so  simple. 
 There's  not  a  lot  of  room  here.  So  you 
 can  see  we  don't  have  many  layers  going 
 on  in  this  particular  bed,  but 
 considering  we  have  all  that  going  on 
 back  there,  I  love  to  keep  the  sides 
 simple.  If  you  guys  have  oak  trees,  you 
 may  have  the  same  problem  here.  We've 
 got  oak  trees  with  a  tree  well  here  and 
 tons  and  tons  of  roots.  So  when  you  have 
 that,  you  need  to  bring  in  plant 
 material  that  has  a  small  root  system  or 
 something  that  when  you're  planting  it, 
 you  can  cut  half  of  that  root  ball  off 
 and  plant  that  plant.  And  that's  exactly 
 what  we  did  here.  So  these  right  here, 
 this  is  silver  odora  burmilad.  And  when 
 you  plant  these  guys,  this  was  a 
 15gallon  plant,  which  means  that  the 
 plant  root  ball  is  about  this  big  and 
 about  this  big,  which  is  pretty 
 significant.  But  this  is  a  big  canopy, 
 so  that's  what  you  want  to  start  with. 
 But  because  of  all  the  roots  in  here,  we 
 cut  that  down  to  where  it's  just  a  few 
 inches  of  the  root  ball  because  it 
 doesn't  rely  on  that.  So,  we  were  able 
 to  really  plant  a  big  plant  in  here  with 
 very  little  root  ball.  So,  that's  when 
 you're  dealing  with  plants,  agave  are 
 perfect  for  that.  You  can  cut  that  root 
 ball  almost  entirely  off.  Bmilads  are 
 that  way.  You  can  cut  that  root  ball 
 almost  entirely  off.  It's  ideal  to  work 
 with  because  they're  not  really  having 
 to  fight  that  root  system. 
 And  then  we  have  a  grouping  right  here 
 is  a  Johannis  burmilad.  I  commonly  get 
 the  question  which  bmilad  can  handle  the 
 sun.  These  can  handle  the  sun  like  a 
 champ.  They're  ideal  for  this  type  of 
 situation.  They  can  handle  the 
 bounceback  heat  from  the  pavers.  But 
 these  Johannes  permilad  have  that 
 beautiful  flamboyant  green  and  yellow 
 with  tips  of  pink  on  them.  I  just  think 
 they're  gorgeous,  especially  when 
 they're  paired  with  plants  like  these 
 guys,  which  are  the  Margaret  Burmilads 
 or  some  people  know  them  as  margaritas. 
 They're  a  dark  dark  tone  and  they  can 
 also  they  handle  they're  both  in  the  Neo 
 family,  but  they're  very  very  tough 
 sun-loving  plants  and  they're  not  that 
 orange  flame  variety,  which  is  what  what 
 I  like.  They  kind  of  hold  that  pink 
 coloring  real  well.  Then  we  have  some 
 beonia  odoratas  underneath  the  oak  tree. 
 And  then  those  icone  croins  that  you 
 guys  may  have  seen  in  the  front  yard. 
 And  I  just  love  how  compact  these  guys 
 are.  Now  these  are  the  seven  gallon  size 
 here.  So  you  can  see  they're  more 
 rounded,  more  dense.  Those  are  the  three 
 gallon  size  down  below.  You  can  tell 
 they're  much  younger  plant,  but  they 
 will  eventually  get  into  a  chunkier 
 version.  But  not  much  bigger  than  what 
 you  see  here.  They  will  chunk  out  a 
 little  bit  more,  but  they're  easy  to 
 keep  at  a  small  height.  And  that's  what 
 we  wanted  here.  We  kind  of  wanted  a 
 little  bit  of  a  wall,  but  nothing  that 
 was  going  to  be  up  here.  She  always 
 wanted  to  be  able  to  see  what  was  going 
 on  behind  this  area.  You  guys  will  have 
 to  tell  me,  would  you  miss  the  grass? 
 Would  would  something  like  this  work  for 
 your  garden?  Do  you  like  the  idea  of 
 grabbing  a,  you  know,  a  cup  of  coffee 
 and  walking  through  the  backyard  space 
 like  you're  walking  through  a  botanical

 Well,  hello  true  [music]  gardeners. 
 Welcome  back.  So,  today's  video  is  all 
 about  going  vertical.  [music]  I  wanted 
 to  share  with  you  a  way  to  take  your 
 garden  from  pretty  cool,  pretty 
 tropical,  pretty  awesome  to  going 
 straight  up  with  very  little  square 
 footage,  [music]  but  making  it  from  good 
 to  great.  Sometimes  we're  finished  with 
 the  landscaping  and  the  layers  are  in, 
 the  tropics  are  in,  and  everybody's 
 like,  "Oh  my  god,  I  absolutely  love  the 
 way  this  is  turning  out.  I  love  the  way 
 this  is  looking."  But  [music]  as  those 
 things  are  growing  in  and  establishing, 
 I  get  the  question  like  how  to  make  it 
 your  own,  how  to  make  those  standout 
 features.  Now,  [music]  you  guys  have 
 seen  where  I  put  pots  and  interesting 
 accents  and  statues  into  the  garden  and 
 obviously  that's  a  great  way  to  do  it, 
 but  I  want  to  add  one  more  thing  to  that 
 list  and  it's  a  wowza  kind  of  thing.  I 
 absolutely  love  the  way  it  looks  when 
 burmilads  are  mounted  to  trees.  I  think 
 that  that's  just  a  [music]  fantastic 
 look.  If  you  guys  saw  the  video  last 
 week  at  McKe  Gardens,  you  saw  several

 accents  [music]

 You,  me,  and  Bryce.  Woo!

 create  this  gorgeous,  [music] 
 gorgeous  accent  feature  in  your  own 
 garden.  But  you  guys,  let's  just  jump 
 right  in.  I  cannot  wait  to  get  this 
 started.  So  you  guys,  we  have  all  of  our 
 equipment  here.  I'm  going  to  kind  of 
 show  you  each  one.  [music]  And  this  is 
 simple  stuff.  This  is  stuff  that  you  can 
 pick  up  pretty  relatively  easy.  We've 
 got  three  different  sizes  of  zip  ties. 
 So  depending  on  what  you're  looking  for 
 for  the  space,  if  you're  going  to  use 
 nails,  you  want  the  small  zip  ties.  If 
 you're  going  to  wrap  around  the  whole 
 tree,  you're  going  to  want  these  large 
 zip  ties.  If  you're  going  to  need  a 
 little  bit  in  between,  you've  got  these 
 zip  ties.  So  these  guys  are  a  great  way 
 to  go.  You  can  use  wire.  It's  not  my 
 preferred  method  because  it  doesn't 
 stretch  really  well.  And  I  never  never 
 use  fish  and  line  because  that  is  it's 
 kind  of  tough.  It  doesn't  disintegrate. 
 So  really,  you  got  to  go  in  and  make 
 sure  that  you  remember  to  cut  every 
 single  piece.  What  I  really  enjoy  using 
 are  these  staples  here.  uh  especially  if 
 you're  working  with  a  tree  that  is  not 
 alive.  And  if  there  is  a  tree  that  you 
 absolutely  have  to  use  and  it  is  alive, 
 I'm  going  to  show  you  a  secondary 
 option.  And  then  there's  another  option 
 here  [music]  and  you  could  just  use  the 
 nails.  So  you're  going to  see  how  we're 
 going  to  kind  of  do  this.  We're  just 
 going  to  nail  this  section  into  the  tree 
 and  then  use  the  zip  tie  to  attach  the 
 actual  [music]  vermilad.  We're  going  to 
 start  with  these  potted  plants  because 
 gosh,  they  need  to  get  out  and  be  free. 
 And  so  I'm  going  to  show  you  exactly  how 
 I  go  about  cutting  them,  cleaning  them, 
 and  then  the  next  step  to  applying  them 
 to  [music]  a  tree.  All right,  you  guys. 
 So,  as  you  can  see,  these  pots  have  seen 
 better  days.  So,  there's  no  better  time 
 than  um  right  now  to  get  these  guys  out 
 of  the  pot.  So,  what  we're  looking  for 
 when  you're  when  you  have  burmiladas, 
 especially  even  whether  in  a  pot  or  on 
 the  ground,  you're  looking  for  this  stem 
 right  here.  So,  you  want  to  kind  of  take 
 it 
 and  clear  off  as  much  of  these  old  pups 
 as  possible 
 and  then  take  out  this.  Now,  I  know  this 
 seems  heartless,  but  really  they  don't 
 mind.  These  are  roots  that  can  really  be 
 pulled  away  and  you're  not  hurting  the 
 plant.  They're  really  getting  their 
 nutrients  from  [music]  these  cones  right 
 here.  This  is  where  they  hold  water. 
 This  is  where  they  receive  their 
 nutrients. 
 >> [music] 
 >> And  this  little  root  system  is  how  they 
 support  themselves.  So  all  it  really 
 does  is  attach  themselves  to  [music] 
 a  a  location,  whether  it's  a  pot  or  a 
 tree.  So  it's  more  of  a  supporting 
 factor.  You  probably  know  this  already, 
 but  each  vermilad  will  produce  a  pup. 
 And  so  that's  what  you're  [music]  seeing 
 here.  There's  going  to  be  a  mother  plant 
 and  then  off  of  that  mother  plant,  it 
 produces  a  stem  [music]  and  then  another 
 vermilad.  So  more  than  likely,  this 
 section  right  here  was  the  mother  plant 
 that  died  off.  And  then  these  are  the 
 pups  from  that  mother  [music]  plant. 
 This  is  probably  a  pup  from  this  plant 
 here.  So  you're  going  to  see  that  as  you 
 put  it  onto  the  tree,  it's  going  to 
 multiply  and  [music]  multiply  and 
 multiply  just  like  that.  And  they  really 
 do  offer  a  lot  of  pups.  So  you're  really 
 getting  the  benefit  of  a  lot  of  plants 
 with  just  one  plant.  I'm  going  to  just 
 kind  of  clear  this  off.  Now,  you  want  to 
 do  this  at  the  time  of  the  transplant 
 because  you  can  do  it  when  the  tree  when 
 it's  up  in  the  tree,  but  I'm  telling 
 you,  this  is  a  really  good  time  while 
 you  can  get  in  here  and  clean  all  these 
 old  leaves  off  and  no  one's  the  wiser.  I 
 like  kitchen  shears  for  things  like  this 
 because  you  can  [music]  sharpen  them. 
 I'll  use  my  Felcos  for  things  like  the 
 stems  and  and  cleaning  things  off,  but 
 to  me,  this  is  pretty  easy  to  get  into. 
 My  skin  is  super  sensitive  to  these 
 little  leaves.  These  little  leaves,  even 
 though  they  don't  have  teeth  [music]  on 
 the  end,  like  a  lot  of  burmiladas,  I'm 
 still  just  right  the  touch  of  this  or 
 the  rubbing  of  this,  [music]  it  seems  to 
 irritate  my  skin.  Some  people  have  no 
 problems  with  it,  but  I  am  one  of  those 
 people  who  [music]  just  dread  it.  So, 
 I'm  not  doing  it  today  because  we're 
 filming,  but  a  lot  of  times  when  I'm 
 dealing  with  vermilast,  if  you  ever  saw 
 me  [music]  on  some  of  the  shorts,  I 
 literally  have  socks.  I  use  tube  socks. 
 I  have  socks  up  to  here  and  then  I  put 
 my  gloves  on  and  it  does  the  job  of  just 
 protecting.  [music]  I  know  you  can  do 
 rose  gloves  with  it  because  they're 
 really  dense  and  really  thick,  but  I 
 really  like  these  gloves  that  have  a 
 little  bit  of  treading  like  this  and 
 then  are  really  tight  on  my  hands.  So 
 that  way  I  feel  like  I  can  feel 
 everything.  I  can  trim  and  I'm  not 
 actually  making  any  cuts  on  my  hands  or 
 anything  like  that.  Then  voila,  we  have 
 a  beautiful  little  section  right  here. 
 And  this  is  going  to  do  a  nice  job  of 
 being  a  nice  grouping  on  top  of  our 
 coconut  palm.  So,  we  have  just  enough 
 roots  here  where  it  can  actually  start 
 to  grab  too.  You  want  to  make  sure  that 
 you  put  this  right  on  the  tree.  And  then 
 we're  going  to  attach  right  here.  This 
 is  super  super  easy  to  do  when  it's  like 
 this.  I  am  going  to  show  you  the  next 
 step  when  you  don't  have  so  much  stem, 
 but  this  is  by  far  the  easiest.  So,  if 
 those  of  you  guys  who've  got  burmilads 
 on  the  ground  and  they're  [music]  just 
 growing  and  trailing  and  you're  like 
 kind  of  not  loving  them,  pop  them  up 
 because  at  that  point  they  have  all 
 these  stems  and  now  they  become 
 sculptures  in  [music]  the  garden  because 
 you  can  literally  put  them  on  anything. 
 All  right,  you  guys.  So,  look  at  how 
 tightly  these  are  wound  right  here.  You 
 can  actually  pull  these  roots  just 
 aside.  I  mean,  I  [music]  do  pull  gently. 
 I  don't  like  tug  and  tug  and  tug. 
 Sometimes  I'll  use  uh  water  to  kind  of 
 spray  [music]  the  soil  off  of  these,  but 
 these  weren't  too  bad,  so  I  didn't  have 
 to.  You'll  notice  I'm  going  to  do  that 
 with  the  other  ones.  All  right,  you 
 guys.  So,  if  you  see  this  happening, 
 this  was  the  original  mother  plant.  This 
 is  mama.  And  then  these  are  the  pups  off 
 of  her.  So,  [music]  it  is  absolutely 
 okay  to  cut  her  out.  It  is  okay  to  get 
 rid  of  anything  dead  because  she  has 
 already  given  life  and  given  birth  to 
 these  two  [music]  guys.  And  how  cool  are 
 they  going  to  look  in  the  garden?  So, 
 this  bmilad  is  called  Margaret.  This 
 particular  plant  does  not  attach  as 
 well.  So  if  you  have  this  and  you  love 
 this  coloring  and  to  me  this  coloring  is 
 fabulous.  What  I  like  about  this 
 particular  burmilad  is  it  can  handle  sun

 really  really  well  and  keep  that  dynamic

 >> [music] 
 >> Don't  want  to  put  this  plant  directly  on 
 a  vertical  place  because  it's  going  to 
 take  a  very  long  time  for  it  to  attach. 
 However,  these  plants  right  here, 
 because  of  the  way  they  pup,  these  are 
 ideal.  These  are  fireball  neo  fireballs. 
 And  because  of  the  way  they  pup,  you  can 
 put  this  like  this  and  another  one  will 
 pup  [music]  this  way  and  pup  that  way 
 and  pup  this  way  and  every  which  way. 
 So,  these  are  fabulous  [music]  for  that. 
 But,  let  me  show  you  how  you're  going  to 
 do  that.  If  you  just  bought  a  bunch  of 
 bermilads,  say  you  went  to  the  bermilad 
 place  and  you  fell  in  love  and  you're 
 like,  "Will  these  climb?"  And  they  say

 do  it  because  they're  in  pots?"  We're 
 going  to  get  to  that  right  now.  So,  when

 want  to  incorporate  it  and  mount  it  to  a

 out  of  the  pot.  Look  at  all  those 
 luscious  roots  right  there. 
 Well,  don't  get  so  attached  because  we 
 are  going  to  remove  some  of  them.  But  I 
 just  remove  the  soil  like  so  all  the  way 
 around. 
 Now  I'll  repurpose  this  soil  into  a  pot 
 and  use  it  for  other  things  because 
 usually  any  [music]  kind  of  planting 
 soil  is,  you  know,  worth  its  weight  and 
 gold.  You  want  to  make  sure  that  this  is 
 nice  and  light  [music]  and  easily 
 supported  by  whatever  it  is  that  you're 
 going  to  brace  to  that  tree  because  the 
 goal  is  to  allow  it  to  get  the  nutrients 
 from  this  area  and  the  water  from  this 
 area.  It  [music]  doesn't  need  that.  As 
 long  as  it  gets  enough  here,  it  these 
 roots  that  you're  going  to  see  here  are 
 going  to  attach  the  tree.  [music] 
 Burmilads  are  epipites,  so  they're  not 
 taking  any  kind  of  nutrients  away  from 
 the  tree.  All  they're  doing  is  [music] 
 supporting  themselves  that  way.  We're 
 going  to  do  the  exact  same  thing  with 
 that  one  plant  grouping  that  I  took 
 [music]  out.  Now,  this  guy  didn't

 unfortunately,  do  not  do  that  on  their

 loose  or  to  drop  too  much  because  if  you

 cool full  corner  lot  front  yard.  [music]

 just  joking.  Then  down  below,  it's  gonna 
 [music]  soften  it  with  some  sloppy 
 painters  at  the  base  to  really  engulf 
 the  base  of  that  European  [music]  fan 
 palm.  Now,  a  lot  of  us  love  those  fronds 
 on  the  European  fan  palm,  but  not  so 
 crazy  about  the  trunks  [music]  on  them. 
 So,  I  think  that's  going  to  do  a  nice 
 job  of  softening  those  trunks  without 
 losing  the  look  of  this  upper  canopy  of 
 the  frond.  [music]  Then  we  chose  to 
 bring  in  a  decent  sized  boulder  here  in

 burmilads.  These  are  Johannis  burmilads

 vermilads  along  the  front  with  a  touch

 this  little  centerpiece  a  little  bit  of 
 a  an  interest.  Now  you'll  notice  that

 smaller.  Everything  to  the  back  is  going

 kind  of  the  goal.  You  want  to  make  sure 
 your  rear  material  is  your  big  material

 these  are  never  going  to  compete  with 
 what  is  behind  it.  And  then  we  have  a

 carissa  [music]  boxwood.  And  those  are

 mam  croins  to  the  front.  A  [music]  nice

 cover  formation  where  it's  more  rounded, 
 more  clumped,  more  individual  instead  of

 All  right,  so  if  you  guys  have  problem 
 areas  in  your  yard,  no  matter  where  they 
 are,  we  all  know  we  all  have  them  and  we 
 are  looking  for  remedies  for  them. 
 [music]  So,  if  your  problem  area  is  like 
 Scott's  problem  area,  which  was  right  by 
 the  front  door  where  [music]  everybody 
 saw  this  was  a  this  was  a  nuisance 
 space.  This  area  had  been  planted 
 multiple  multiple  times  and  things  just 
 kept  dying  off.  There  was  just  too  much 
 moisture  in  this  area.  You  can  see  this 
 is  a  pretty  large  roof  here  and  all  the 
 water  collects  and  even  with  gutters,  it 
 just  pours  into  this  particular  spot.  So 
 when  we  had  mulch  and  when  there  was 
 plants  here,  it  just  it  just  always 
 looked  bad.  It  always  needed  fungus 
 treatment.  We  couldn't  plant  much  in  the 
 soil  and  it  was  really  hard  to  kind  of 
 make  a  squared  off  area  look  organic. 
 So,  what  we  chose  to  do  is  bring  in 
 three  coina  boulders  like  you  see  here 
 and  then  three  pots.  And  you  can  see 
 that  they're  both  sharing  the  same 
 angle.  A  triangular  formation  going 
 forward  with  this  being  the  centerpiece 
 and  a  triangular  formation  going  forward 
 with  being  this  being  the  [music] 
 centerpiece.  We  took  most  of  the  plant 
 material  and  framed  it  around  the 
 middle.  So,  we  have  some  variations, 
 some  [music]  different  elements  in  the 
 garden.  And  then  we  took  and  put  a  dune 
 palm  as  a  centerpiece,  some  imperialis 
 vermilads  around  the  corners  and  letting 
 these  little  margaret  burmilads  at  the 
 bottom  that  are  going  to  drape  [music] 
 down.  This  pot  was  huge  getting  in  here. 
 It  was  it  was  no  easy  feat,  [music] 
 but  my  goodness,  it  needed  to  be 
 something  substantial.  I  couldn't  put  a 
 little  pot  in  this  area  and  [music]  be 
 like,  "Well,  it's  all  done."  I  needed 
 two  of  the  pots  in  the  back  to  support

 with  those  [music]  two  Song  of  India 
 towards  the  back  really  help  frame  this 
 wide  and  chunky  pot.  We  topped  it  off 
 with  some  Tahesian  gray  granite  at  the 
 base.  And  actually,  believe  it  or  not, 
 these  vermilads  right  here  are  planted 
 [music]  in  a  larger  pot.  So  that  way 
 they're  protected  from  a  little  bit  of 
 that  moisture.  And  you  can  do  that 
 without  having  any  problems  cuz  they're 
 getting  their  nutrients  from  the  top, 
 not  [music]  from  the  roots.  But  they 
 will  die  from  root  rot  if  they're 
 sitting  in  water.  So,  if  you've  got  a 
 wet  area  and  you  want  to  protect  them, 
 put  them  in  a  larger  pot  and  then  put 
 them  in  the  ground.  However,  to  the 
 back,  I  wanted  something  a  little  wild 
 and  crazy.  So,  we  went  with  some  giant 
 aposle  iris  because,  as  you  guys 
 probably  know,  I  have  these  in  my  pond. 
 These  can  grow  straight  in  the  water. 
 They  can  be  drought  tolerant.  So,  don't 
 be  afraid  to  use  them.

 kind  of  go  right  along  this  end  [music]

 Well,  hello  there  gardeners.  [music] 
 So,  today's  video  is  all  about  small 
 spaces  in  a  yard  that  make  huge,  [music] 
 huge  impacts.  So,  today  we  are  going  to 
 tour  this  sideyard  garden.  Yes,  [music] 
 I  said  it.  Sideyard  garden.  You  know, 
 those  spaces  that  are  usually  neglected 
 or  overlooked  or  where  you  store  trash 
 cans  and  whatnot.  Those  little  areas, 
 those  [music]  little  little  slices  of 
 land  that  we  have  on  either  side  of  our 
 houses  that  are  relatively  wasted  space, 
 you  know,  a  patch  of  grass.  In  this 
 particular  area,  there  was  [music] 
 nothing  but  dying  grass,  thin  grass  that 
 really  just  didn't  appeal  to  my  clients. 
 So,  what  we  did  is  we  created  a  side 
 buffer  from  the  neighbors  and  then 
 layered  in  a  landscape.  Now,  this  was  a 
 two-stage  landscape  because  we  had  to 
 let  things  grow  up  before  we  patched 
 [music]  in.  So,  you  guys  might  remember 
 this  video  from  before  when  we  initially 
 put  a  lot  of  this  tree  material  in,  but 
 now  that  tree  material  has  really  grown 
 up,  leaving  us  room  to  put  in  a 
 secondary  tier  underneath.  And  I  think 
 it's  really  come  together  so  [music] 
 nicely.  So,  let's  check  out  this  private 
 garden.  This  is  the  sideyard.  And  just

 of  [music]  reference,  we  are  in,  of 
 course,  the  backyard  on  this  side  of  the 
 yard.  This  is  closest  to  the  neighbor 
 side  here.  And  from  the  screen  room  to

 And  that  is  the  widest  section  of  the 
 yard.  And  then  it  starts  to  narrow  as  we 
 get  further  to  the  backyard  section.  Not 
 a  lot  of  room  like  I  mentioned,  right? 
 So,  a  lot  of  the  plants  and  the  trees

 kind  of  grow  nice  and  tall,  allowing  you

 this  pygmy  [music]  8  palm.  We've  got  a

 corner  of  the  house.  Looking  from  the

 secret  garden  type  of  feel.  I  just  love

 soft.  And  I  wanted  to  make  sure 
 something  that  didn't  grow  over  the  roof 
 in  this  particular  spot  because  I  wanted 
 something  pretty  big  and  pretty  [music] 
 significant  on  this  blank  wall  and  to 
 support  hiding  this  fence,  but  also  not 
 [music]  be  too  too  tall  for  this  area. 
 However,  on  the  opposite  side,  as  we  get

 weight.  I  wanted  heaviness.  That's  the 
 the  neighbor's  house.  They've  got  a 
 white  house.  I  wanted  to  soften  that.  I 
 wanted  you  to  feel  like  you're  outside

 clumping  and  becoming  a  25  30  foot 
 clustered  palm  tree  in  this  particular 
 area.  And  absolutely  stunning.  [music] 
 And  these  individual  leaves  like  this,  I 
 don't  know  if  they'll  capture,  but  if

 so,  for  the  second  space,  right,  coming

 green  light  to  go  jungle  crazy.  That

 attention  to  [music]

 things  because  you  don't  want  to  do  tons

 slowly.  Wouldn't  overtake  and  get  into 
 this  area  and  get  into  this  area  over 
 here  and  you  needed  something  [music] 
 that  was  going  to  stay  nice  and  compact. 
 Gold  dust  croins  do  a  great  job  of  that.

 layered  landscaping.  But  if  you've  got

 the  space.  If  this  was  just  a  garden  and 
 then  this  was  just  mulch,  it  would  look

 nice  established  pathway  gives  you  that 
 secret  garden  feel.  You  want  to  set  your 
 landscaping  up.  Make  sure  you're  really 
 happy  with  your  layers,  your  spacing. 
 You  kind  of  want  all  that  in  place.  And 
 then  set  your  walkway  where  it's  going 
 to  fit  into  that  particular  space. 
 Anytime  you  have  growth  on  both  sides, 
 if  you  can  kind  of  have  it  just  canopy 
 over  top  of  you,  like  this  guy  is  doing

 you  use  to  make  the  best  pathway?  And 
 you  guys  know  I  love  the  Tahesian  gray 
 granite,  but  [music]  you  can  use  any 
 kind  of  stone  that  has  jagged  pieces 
 that  have  multiple  different  sizes  in 
 them.  So  you  can  go  from  the  half  inch 
 to  inch  and  a  half.  That's  my  favorite

 between  the  inch  and  an  inch  and  a  half 
 pieces.  You  kind  of  see  that  right  here. 
 It's  a  nice  solid  sturdy  base.  It's  not 
 going  anywhere.  Where  if  you  have  a 
 round  stone  that  has  similar  sizes,  they 
 roll  all  over  the  place.  I  mean,  you're 
 kind  of  just  skating  on  them.  Those  are 
 perfect  for  landscape  beds,  but  not  for 
 walkways.  And  of  course,  you  want  to 
 edge  it.  Whatever  type  of  edging  that 
 you  work  with,  you're  comfortable  with. 
 I  love  the  aluminum  alloy  edging.  When 
 you  put  this  stone  in,  you  tamp  it  down. 
 You  make  it  a  nice  solid  space.  And  you 
 want  to  make  sure  that  it  is  kind  of 
 controlled  on  both  sections.  It's  not 
 running.  It's  not  rolling.  It's  not 
 moving  into  the  next  section  of  the  bed. 
 It's  staying  where  you  put  it  long  term. 
 Weed  berry  goes  underneath.  [music] 
 Edging  goes  on  either  side.  and  then

 And  then  it's  going  to  be  a  really, 
 really  nice  feature.  We  have  it  on  both 
 sides  of  the  wall  there.  And  yes,  you 
 can  get  songs  of  India  on  a  trellis  and 
 make  them  into  little  trees.  And  when 
 they  do  get  there,  they're  [music]  just 
 stunning.  We've  got  bird's  nest  ferns,  a 
 sea  of  them,  and  just  let  them  kind  of 
 come  in  and  fill  [music]  this  whole 
 bedding.  Now,  this  will  not  be  the  end 
 of  the  bird's  nest  ferns.  If  you  guys 
 know,  these  are  also  epipites.  So,  as 
 they  grow  in,  as  they  kind  of  start  to 
 widen  [music]  and  spread  out  and  get 
 nice  and  big,  they're  not  going  to  grow 
 into  this  walkway.  No,  they're  going  to 
 grow  up.  They're  going  to  grow  up  those 
 trees,  kind  of  attach  to  the  tree 
 [music]  lines  and  work  their  way  up.  So,

 bit  of  room.  So,  I  clustered  [music]  in 
 a  nice  tight  grouping  of  antiloo,  kind

 know  that  I  like  when  you're  walking 
 down  a  pathway  having  some  interruption.

 search  for  the  sun.  So,  anytime  you

 we  are  going  to  look  at  [music]  a 
 beautiful  front  yard  garden  that  we  did 
 about  a  month  ago.  But  I  really  want  to 
 share  [music]  with  you  guys  this 
 particular  space  because  I  think  the 
 combination  of  plants  is  fantastic.  So, 
 if  you  guys  are  along  the  treasure  or 
 the  space  [music]  coast  and  you're 
 looking  for  some  plant  ideas  that  are 
 going  to  really  work  harmoniously 
 together,  pull  out  your  pad  because  I 
 think  these  are  just  doing  super  super 
 well  [music]  in  the  space  and  it  might 
 be  something  that  you  can  just  exactly 
 replicate.  This  front  yard  is  not  very 
 big  as  you  can  see,  but  you  can  tell 
 there  are  three  distinct  sections.  We've 
 got  full  sun  in  one  area,  part  sun  in 
 another  area,  and  nearly  full  [music] 
 shade  in  the  third  section.  I  thought 
 this  would  kind  of  pertain  to  a  lot  of 
 you  guys.  You  DIYers  out  there  that  are 
 looking  to  kind  of  create  your  perfect 
 little  front  yard  garden.  Please 
 subscribe  and  let's  jump  into  this 
 video.  Come  on.  I  think  we're  going  to 
 start  over  here.  Actually,  I  want  to 
 start  with  the  area  that  everybody  sees 
 from  the  road  first.  Now,  [music]  this 
 was  a  troubled  area.  It  was  kind  of  a 
 really  troubled  spot.  When  you  have  this 
 much  leaf  coverage  and  leaf  foliage, 
 there's  a  lot  of  acidity  in  the  ground 
 and  a  lot  of  mess.  So,  it's  very  hard  to 
 keep  a  garden  looking  pristine.  So  if 
 that's  the  case,  you  kind  of  got  to  work 
 with  it,  you  know,  work  with  mother 
 nature  when  it  happens  like  that.  And 
 that's  what  we  did  in  this  particular 
 space.  So  as  the  backdrop  for  our  height 
 for  our  impact,  we  have  two  triple  pygmy 
 eight  palms.  These  guys  are  full  grown 
 now.  So  this  is  what  they  look  like  when 
 they're  full  grown.  If  they  were  being 
 used  in  a  buffer  area,  they  would  be 
 fuller,  thicker.  But  because  I  want  to 
 see  the  house,  I  just  kind  of  needed  a 
 little  bit  of  softness  with  some  height 
 here.  And  these  are  perfect.  [music] 
 They're  doing  just  that.  They're  kind  of 
 giving  just  a  little  bit  of  a  whimsy 
 feel  on  either  side  of  the  front  without 
 hiding  the  front.  And  of  course,  we've 
 got  these  big  mama  jama  oak  trees  up 
 here.  So,  we  could  not  put  anything  too 
 tall.  Kind  of  using  this  as  our  anchor 
 pieces  because  of  that  reason.  If  I 
 didn't  have  the  complexity  of  this 
 [music]  particular  space  of  shade  and 
 the  oak  tree  canopy,  I  might  put 
 something  more  vertical  here,  like,  you 
 know,  maybe  two  double  foxtail  [music] 
 palms  or  two  single  foxtail  palms, 
 something  with  a  little  bit  more  ump 
 like  you  guys  see  in  a  lot  [music]  of  my 
 videos.  These  are  really  giving  a  nice 
 bit  of  punctuation  on  either  side 
 without  kind  of,  you  know,  getting  into 
 the  canopy  of  the  trees.  We've  got  a  lot 
 of  leaf  foliage  here.  So,  [music]  the 
 best  thing  to  do  when  you  have  that  is 
 find  some  things  that  are  going  to  cover 
 that  ground.  So,  [music]  these  big 
 alocacas,  these  are  the  dwarf  alicacas, 
 believe  it  or  not.  They're  going  to  do 
 that.  They're  going  to  paddle  all  the 
 way  around.  This  everything's  been 
 recently  trimmed,  but  prior  to  trimming, 
 they  kind  of  engulfed  the  base  of  this 
 tree  all  the  way  around  it.  And  of 
 course,  three  times  a  year,  you  want  to 
 trim  those  back  so  that  you  get  nice 
 fullness  of  those  allocations  at  the 
 bottom.  But  right  now,  they're  kind  of 
 open  and  clean.  Over  time,  over  the  next 
 3  months,  they're  going  to  engulf  that 
 tree  base  again  and  really  kind  of  give 
 you  some  camouflage  to  that  bottom.  So, 
 if  you  guys  have  a  lot  of  leaves,  those 
 big  giant  paddle  leaves  of  alicacas  will 
 give  you  almost  like  a  blanket  along 
 that  base.  And  then  another  option  would 
 be  something  like  aimas.  They  have  that 
 big  giant  leaf.  the  leaf  falls  down 
 below  it  because  the  leaf  just  flutters 
 down  and  then  those  big  giant  [music] 
 leaves  cover  it.  You  can  also  use 
 something  as  simple  as  variegated 
 arbakas.  The  leaves  aren't  so  big  but 
 they're  so  dense  that  the  leaves  go 
 underneath  of  them  and  it  gives  [music] 
 you  again  a  blanket  along  the  ground. 
 And  so  those  will  fall  in  line  with  that 
 same  type  of  planting  where  we  have 
 filtered  [music]  light  more  of  a  shady 
 area  here.  Our  next  standard  focal 
 points  are  going  to  be  these  silver 
 odoras.  They  are  so  cool  when  I  have  a 
 bit  of  darkness  in  the  garden.  I  hope 
 this  comes  across  on  camera.  I  know  it

 such  a  bright  spot  in  a  garden.  And  I 
 just  love  that  when  you  need  something 
 to  kind  of  really  bounce  some  light  off

 families  or  something  in  the  silver

 little  sun  here,  you  guys.  And  look  at 
 how  much  beautiful  growth  they're  giving

 you  know,  we're  in  December  and  they're

 some  beautiful  color  still.  And  then  as

 their  seasons  for  sure,  but  they  really 
 those  seasons  [music]  last  super  super 
 long.  We  might  get  a  month  or  two  where

 planning  of  this  kind  of  landscape

 really  branch  out.  So  if  you're  going  to 
 use  things  like  [music]  dwarf  alicacas

 distance.  So  our  croin  our  alicacas  are

 these  are  dwarfed  croins  are  two  foot 
 off  the  house  line.  That  gives  it  a

 more  depth  in  your  garden,  you  could

 throughout  the  day.  I  don't  know if  I

 design  that  we  created  and  installed. 
 And  we  do  that  here  in  Vero  Beach, 
 Florida  along  the  Vero  and  the  Space 
 Coast  area.  We  do  a  landscape  design  and 
 installation.  So,  we  kind  of  see  you

 hope  I  put  enough  information  in  to

 Landscaping  is  tricky,  especially 
 [music]  in  our  area.  So,  these  are 
 processes  and  these  are  groupings  that 
 work  well  together.  So,  if  you  like 
 them,  work  with  them.  I  promise  you'll 
 be  happy  with  them.  Okay,  so  right  here 
 we  have  a  very  young  fall  agave  and  then 
 we've  got  some  bugan  villas  and  then 
 draped  right  along  the  front  and  kind  of 
 like  a  nice  little  surfed  curve.  Keep  in 
 mind  you  guys,  every  time  you  have  a 
 accent  feature,  make  sure  to  just  dial 
 it  in  with  a  ground  cover  or  something 
 to  curve  around  the  base  of  [music]  it 
 just  to  kind  of  give  it  like  a  little 
 bit  of  a  support  system.  So,  normally  if 
 this  tree  wasn't  here,  this  bugan  villia 
 would  curve  to  the  back  around  the  rear 
 side  of  this,  kind  of  curving  this  way 
 with  some  height.  And  this  ground  cover 
 would  curve  the  opposite  way  and  really 
 kind  of  frame  the  accent  feature.  So,  if 
 you  guys  don't  have  something  like  a 
 palm  tree  in  the  way  of  that,  that  is  a 
 great  way  to  frame  a  feel  and  give  you 
 that  layered  feel  without  much  work  at 
 all.  Blew  my  minds  are  so  easy  to  work 
 with.  You  can  also  use  something  like 
 Mexican  heather.  Those  work  well  as  a 
 ground  cover.  Of  course,  laria  like  we 
 have  over  there  work  well  as  a  ground 
 cover.  But  what  you  want  to  make  sure  to 
 do  is  don't  put  [music]  anything  that's 
 going  to  compete  with  the  size  of  this 
 plant.  Keeping  these  guys  around  3  to 
 four  foot  is  going  to  be  nice  in  this 
 particular  [music]  space  because  that's 
 going  to  give  us  our  layers  that  we  need 
 in  this  little  island.  We  have  a 
 centerpiece  tree  of  an  existing  pygmy 
 ape  palm  that  was  here  that  we  worked 
 with.  And  then  of  [music]  course  then  we 
 kind  of  a  rinse  and  repeat.  We  have  a 
 nice  grouping  of  bugan  villia  with  a 
 little  dollop  of  foxtail  ferns  that 
 again  curve  come  straight  and  then  curve 
 their  way  up.  Anytime  you  guys  can  do 
 that  you  can  have  one  curving  this  way, 
 one  curving  that  way.  It  makes  for 
 [music]  an  interesting  plant,  especially 
 as  things  mature.  This  is  a  young 
 landscaping,  but  it's  really  on  its  way. 
 So,  I  think  it's  going  to  come  together 
 very  nicely  over  a  short  period  of  time. 
 And  one  of  the  things  that  I  don't 
 really  talk  about  very  often,  but  I  do 
 think  it  adds  a  little  ambiance  to  a 
 garden  is  landscape  lighting.  So,  those 
 of  you  guys  who  are  doing  it  yourself, 
 [music]  it  is  definitely  a  doable 
 project.  You  know,  make  sure  that  you  do 
 a  layered  lighting  effect.  So,  this 
 particular  house  we  didn't  do  the 
 lighting  on,  but  it  just  it  prompted  my 
 mind  when  I  saw  the  the  spotlights  out 
 here.  If  you  got  something  like  the  size 
 of  what  a  pygmy  date  palm  is,  you  know, 
 it's  going  to  be  around  five  or  six  foot 
 when  you  plant  it,  but  it's  going  to 
 turn  into  around  something  around  10  10 
 to  11  foot,  you  want  something  along  the 
 lines  of  a  four  to  five  watt.  That 
 wattage  is  ideal.  You  don't  want  to  go 
 any  stronger  than  that  because  that'll 
 just  blast  out  the  tree  and  all  you're 
 really  trying  to  create  is  a  shadow 
 [music]  effect.  However,  if  you  got 
 something  like  a  foxtail  palm  or  royal 
 palm  or  something  that's  really  going  to 
 get  some  really  good  size,  then  you 
 [music]  want  to  go  with  nothing  lower 
 than  a  seven  watt  bulb.  that  is 
 fantastic  to  really  work  with  and  light 
 up  that  trunk  line  and  get  all  the  way 
 up  into  that  canopy  of  that  tree.  Even 
 if  your  foxtail  palm  is  only  10  foot 
 tall,  maybe  it's  only  a  30-  gallallon 
 that  you  put  [music]  in.  Plan  for  it  to 
 be  a  big  boy  and  put  a  seven  watt  bulb 
 in  there  and  shine  it  right  up  into  that 
 tree.  And  [music]  that's  going to  be  an 
 ideal  way  to  make  make  sure  when  you're 
 looking  at  things  to  have  a  layered 
 light.  That  goes  the  same  for  things 
 like  these  fals  agave.  I  love  putting 
 lights  on  the  falsabes  because  again 
 they  give  you  that  fantastic  shadow 
 [music]  effect.  However,  I  don't  usually 
 use  a  spotlight  for  those.  You  want  to 
 get  kind  of  the  wide  lens  light  for 
 that.  They  call  them  wall  lights,  and 
 you  normally  you'll  see  them  on  walls  of 
 houses,  but  they  have  a  diffuser  in  them 
 that  kind  of  softens.  It'll  kind  of  give 
 just  a  diffused  look  to  that  whole 
 agave.  So,  you  get  a  really  beautiful 
 shadow  effect,  and  you  want  something 
 like  a  two  W  bulb  on  that.  Let's  jump 
 into  the  to  the  last  bed  in  this  front 
 yard.  So,  we  are  in  the  front  [music] 
 bed  section.  This  is  right  by  coming  up 
 to  the  front  door  area.  And  this  also 
 framed  by  the  big  driveway  that's  here. 
 So,  we  chose  to  go  with  stone  here 
 because  there  was  constant  runoff  of 
 mulch  going  into  this  driveway  [music] 
 that  pitches  down  towards  the  road.  So, 
 the  rock  really  did  a  fantastic  job  of 
 [music]  solving  that  problem.  Before  you 
 could  see  the  mulch  tidbits  all  the  way 
 down  the  driveway.  So,  this  is  working 
 out  perfectly,  which  is  great.  So,  we 
 have  1  to  3  [music]  in  rainbow  river 
 rock  here,  which  is  a  round  rock.  It's 
 rock  that  I  like  to  use  in  the  landscape 
 beds.  Definitely  not  one  that  I  would 
 want  to  walk  on  or  have  traffic  on,  but 
 it's  perfect  for  landscaping  beds.  So, 
 it's  a  nice  decorative  light  colored 
 stone.  I  [music]  think  it  does  a  nice 
 job  of  highlighting  the  ground.  And  then 
 the  next  big  item  in  this  guy  is  [music] 
 a  Montgomery  triple.  Look  how  gorgeous 
 this  big  boy  is.  Just  kind  of  framing 
 the  left  side  of  this  house.  You  can 
 kind  of  see  where  this  is  where  the 
 house  dips  down  and  then  the  roof  line 
 is  nice  and  peaked  on  the  opposite  side. 
 So,  we  did  need  something  big,  something 
 pretty  dramatic  to  really  kind  of  help 
 balance  out  this  side  of  the  house.  And 
 I  think  that  this  Montgomery  palm  is 
 doing  a  lovely  job  of  that.  Just  to 
 soften  the  two  sides  and  to  give  the 
 Montgomery  palm  a  little  bit  of  backing 
 on  this  blank  wall,  we  have  two  rafus 
 palms  or  lady  palms,  whatever  you  like 
 to  call  them.  They  are  being  kept  as 
 like  a  bunched  planting.  Now,  these  guys 
 can  spread.  They  can  get  big  and  long 
 and  run  if  you  let  them.  But  if  you  stay 
 on  top  of  it,  they're  very  easy  to  keep 
 clipped  and  [music]  keep  bunched  the  way 
 you  want.  So,  they're  one  of  those  trees 
 that  you  do  have  to  maintain.  And  it's 
 not  super  crazy  maintenance.  I  mean, 
 every  3  months,  if  you  came  out  [music] 
 and  just  did  some  clipping  on  them, 
 you're  done.  That's  what  it  takes.  If 
 that's  not  you,  and  you  really  kind  of 
 want  the  look  without  the  worry,  [music] 
 then  find  a  nice  big  lowbelly  pot, 
 something  that's  kind  of  short  and 
 stacked,  but  big  and  round.  They  grow 
 really  well  in  a  shallow  pot,  but  they 
 do  need  some  width,  some  size  to  it  to 
 really  keep  that  big  umbrella  look  to 
 them.  Put  [music]  that  in  a  pot  right 
 there.  Put  a  little  pot  mister  in  there 
 and  you're  golden  because  it's  going  to 
 be  so  nice  [music]  to  kind  of  give  you 
 some  chunkiness  to  that  side.  And  then 
 of  course  in  the  pot,  they're  not  going 
 to  outrow  that  space  because  they'll  be 
 contained.  So  you  want  to  know 
 generally,  is  this  an  area  that  you  want 
 to  block  some  view  line  from?  Do  you 
 want  something  bigger  like  a  pygmy  palm? 
 something  with  more  foliage  here  to  kind 
 of  give  you  some  privacy  in  these 
 windows  or  do  you  want  to  have  free 
 ownership  of  this  outdoor  space  and  have 
 all  the  light  that  pops  in  through  there 
 and  keep  something  more  dramatic, 
 something  that's  going  to  stay  rather 
 small  in  this  area.  Those  are  questions 
 to  really  know  before  you  meet  with  your 
 contractor  or  when  you're  planning  out 
 your  own  landscaping.  So,  in  this 
 particular  case,  these  windows  were 
 lovely.  This  wasn't  a  huge  space, 
 [music]  so  I  definitely  wanted  to  keep 
 it  open.  I  put  the  chunkier  material  on 
 the  sides  along  the  wall.  Letting  them 
 get  a  [music]  couple  foot  taller  is 
 going  to  be  perfect.  And  then  having 
 this  guy  in  here  was  going  to  give  you 
 some  substance  which  fals  agave  do  so  so 
 [music]  well.  It's  going  to  get  around 
 that  4  and  1/2,  5t  tall,  but  it's  going 
 to  be  a  4  and  1/2  ft  tall  like  this. 
 We're  going  to  see  [music]  right  through 
 it.  So  give  you  impact  without  the 
 coverage  and  take  away  absolutely  no 
 light  from  those  [music]  windows.  Right 
 to  the  back.  We  wanted  to  keep  this 
 super  super  clean,  super  simple.  So,  we 
 have  dwarf  kousias  right  to  the  back  and 
 they  do  a  nice  job  of  really  giving  you 
 a  clean  kind  of  rounded  shaped  [music] 
 little  plant.  I  know  most  of  you  guys, 
 everybody  loves  the  regular  kousias, 
 those  big  giant  succulent  looking 
 leaves.  These  are  the  same  leaves. 
 They're  just  itty  bitty  little  tiny 
 guys.  And  they're  super  easy  to  keep.  So 
 nice  and  rounded.  I  love  love love  the 
 texture  to  them.  And  I  love  the  shine. 
 Another  plant  that  kind  of  gives  you  a 
 similar  look  is  a  green  island  ficcus. 
 It  grows  a  little  bit  more  aggressive. 
 So,  and  it  grows  a  little  faster,  but  it 
 is  quite  a  nice  dense  plant.  So,  this 
 one's  a  little  easier  to  work  with,  but 
 doesn't  grow  quite  as  dense  as  the  Green 
 Island  fus.  So,  those  are  two  really, 
 really  good  alternatives.  Another  thing 
 if  you  wanted  to  use  in  this  back 
 section  and  you  were  in  full  sun  would 
 be  Pringles  Podarpus.  It's  a  completely 
 different  texture,  [music]  but  it's  dark 
 dark  green  and  it  really  is  easy  to 
 maintain  a  small  planting.  So,  it's  not 
 getting  in  this  height  line,  not  turning 
 to  a  hedge  like  an  arbocaola.  It's  gonna 
 always  stay  in  [music]  this  range  and  no 
 bigger,  which  is  really,  really  perfect 
 for  here.  It's  almost  like  you  want  a 
 hint  of  a  barrier,  but  not  a  wall.  Then 
 right  here,  we  got  a  little  wild  and 
 crazy  because  we  needed  some  brightness. 
 We've  got  green  and  we've  got  green  and 
 we  got  green.  So,  we  needed  something  a 
 little  more  fun  like  the  song  of  India 
 that  we  have  here.  So,  we  have  a  kind  of 
 a  halo  effect  around  the  rear  side  of 
 the  false  agave  with  the  song  of  India. 
 Now,  these  guys  are  ready  to  be  trimmed. 
 The  [music]  best  way  to  keep  them  nice 
 and  full  is  to  trim  these  tops  right 
 here.  So,  you  can  nip  all  of  those  tops 
 and  they'll  push  out  growth  from  the 
 middle.  And  what  you  want  to  do  is  keep 
 encouraging  that  growth.  [music]  If  you 
 let  this  guy,  he  will  kind  of  push  out 
 this  limb  all  the  way  up  to  here.  And 
 that's  not  what  you  want.  We  we  want  a 
 hedge  grouping  of  a  little  [music]  wild 
 and  crazy  leaves.  And  that's  what  you're 
 going to  get  here.  If  you  just  nip  off 
 those  tops,  it'll  [music]  push  out 
 energy  down  below.  So,  that's  the  goal 
 with  these  guys.  So,  they'll  make  a  nice 
 little  halo  [music]  to  the  back  as  they 
 chunk  out.  And  then  right  below  where 
 Bryce  is  standing 
 is  a  nice  collection  of  Helen  Johnson 
 buganvilia.  Just  a  nice  overall  cool 
 plant.  They  can  handle  dry  temperatures 
 and  these  can  handle  a  little  bit  more 
 water  than  your  typical  buganvilia.  And 
 you  [music]  can  see  they  can  be 
 maintained  very  very  clean  line  or  they 
 can  be  left  more  casual.  One  of  the 
 questions  I  commonly  get  is  rock  really 
 unhealthy  for  your  plants.  Yes  and  no. 
 You  know  your  rock  can  really  um  heat  up 
 the  ground.  So  during  our  summer  months, 
 our  June,  July,  August,  you  guys  know 
 they're  brutal.  Those  of  you  guys  who 
 don't  go  up  north  and  you  you're  here 
 during  those  times,  you  you  know  what 
 I'm  talking  about.  It's  pretty  brutal. 
 They  will  create  a  [music]  just  hot 
 pocket  in  the  garden.  So  what  you  want 
 to  make  sure  if  you're  planting  in  rock, 
 use  rock,  lovable  material,  things  that 
 do  not  mind  getting  hot.  Dwarf  Buggan 
 blew  my  minds,  song  of  India,  [music] 
 dwarf  Kucia,  and  so  on.  All right,  you 
 guys.  So  that  does  it  for  our  front  yard

 like  a  peekab-oo  plant.  So,  how  I  would

 backdrop,  give  myself  plenty  of  room  to

 them  climb  the  tree.  Is  a  kabato  palm. 
 It  is.  It's  probably  one  of  the  tallest 
 ones  I've  [music]  ever  seen.  Now,  a  lot 
 of  people  confuse  those  with  a  RA  palms, 
 but  they  are  not.  As  those  chunks  get 
 bigger,  um,  they  have  a  [music]  nice 
 white  ring  around  them.  That  nice 
 whitening  to  the  ring.  And  this  one's  a 
 little  darker  than  normal,  probably 
 because  it's  in  the  direct  shade.  But 
 this  tree  is  stunning.  And  surprise, 
 surprise,  [music]  I  just  got  one.  I  have

 So,  it's  getting  cold,  you  guys.  And  if 
 you're  getting  cold  here  in  Florida, 
 imagine  what  your  poor  poor  plants  are 
 going  to  do.  So,  today's  video  [music] 
 is  all  about  five  tips  on  how  to  keep 
 your  garden,  your  tropicals  super  safe 
 [music]  this  cold  season.  We  put  a  great 
 deal  of  effort  into  these  videos  and  try 
 to  find  some  things  that  you  guys  really 
 enjoy  watching  [music]  as  well  as  making 
 it  as  educational  as  possible.  So,  we 
 really  appreciate  your  support  [music] 
 and  subscribing  and  checking  out  our 
 channel.  Well,  it  really  helps  to  give 
 us  that  pat  on  the  back  that  we  are 
 doing  something  right  and  also  puts  us 
 in  your  [music]  feed  if  this  is  the  kind 
 of  stuff  that  you  like  to  see  every 
 single  week.  So,  the  very  first  tip 
 [music]  is  an  easy  one.  Now,  we  know 
 when  these  cold  fronts  hit,  the  news 
 goes  crazy.  Everybody  goes  nuts  and 
 winter  is  coming.  So,  we  know  when  a 
 cold  front  is  happening  here  in  Florida. 
 [music]  So,  when  that  does  happen,  a 
 couple  days  in  advance,  make  sure  to  up 
 that  water.  If  you've  got  an  irrigation 
 system,  make  sure  to  double  the  time 
 that  you  currently  have.  If  you  have  it 
 on  for  20  minutes,  those  [music]  two 
 days  prior  to  a  freeze,  hit  it  for 
 double  that  amount  of  time.  Make  sure 
 that  everything's  a  little  bit  soggy, 
 really,  really,  really  hydrated  because 
 they're  going  to  need  that  that  little 
 bit  of  protection  from  the  very 
 beginning.  And  then  the  day  of  the 
 freeze,  cut  that  water  off.  Cut  [music] 
 it  completely  off.  You  want  to  let  prior 
 to  covering  or  doing  your  next  step,  you 
 want  to  make  sure  that  that  water  is 
 there  to  set  and  settle  and  be  warm  in 
 the  earth  because  that  that  water  turns 
 into  like  an  an  insulation  around  the 
 root  system.  Think  of  it  as  a  hot  water 
 bottle  cozing  you  up  during  those  cold 
 cold  nights  and  that's  exactly  what  it 
 does.  That  heat  during  the  day  of  our 
 Florida  heat  warms  that  ground.  That 
 water  stays  nice  and  toasty.  Now,  I  know 
 you  guys  I  know  it  sounds  like  it  should 
 be  the  opposite.  Like  don't  water  your 
 plants.  You  don't  want  them  to  freeze, 
 especially  the  water  that's  left  on  the 
 leaves.  That's  the  reason  why  you  stop 
 watering  that  day  prior.  Leading  up  to 
 it,  hit  water  as  much  as  you  can.  But 
 the  day  of  the  freeze,  the  evening  of 
 the  freeze,  make  sure  there  is  no  water 
 on  there  because  you  don't  want  water 
 actually  on  the  [music]  leaves.  The 
 whole  purpose  to  have  the  water  is  to 
 insulate  the  ground,  to  insulate  the 
 root  system  [music]  because  our  ground 
 here  in  Florida  is  pretty  toasty.  So, 
 you  want  to  let  that  water  warm  up  all 
 the  way  around  the  roots  and  that's 
 [music]  what  helps  insulate  it  over 
 time.  So  2  days  prior,  even  the  morning 
 of  [music]  you  can  water  as  long  as  we 
 have  good  sun  out.  But  by  that 
 afternoon,  by  that  evening,  cut  that 
 water  way  off  because  we  don't  want  to 
 take  the  chance  of  burning  any  of  the 
 leaves.  The  whole  goal  of  keeping 
 [music]  the  plants  happy  is  really 
 trying  to  really  protect  the  root 
 system.  If  you  get  a  little  cold  damage 
 on  plants,  as  you  know,  if  you're  from 
 Florida,  you  know  that's  going  to 
 happen.  A  little  frostburn  in  [music] 
 the  spring.  You're  going  to  cut  that 
 back  anyway  and  you're  going to  get  all 
 new  growth.  But  what  we're  trying  to  do 
 is  protect  [music]  the  roots  so  that  way 
 you  get  new  growth  every  single  spring. 
 All right,  you  guys.  For  the  next  tip,  I 
 know  this  is  going  to  come  off  as  just 
 common  sense,  but  the  plant  blanket,  the 
 blankets,  they  work  so  so  well  for 
 covering.  I  mentioned  this  because  I  had 
 a  client  mention  to  me  that  she  used  it 
 and  it  didn't  help  at  all.  And  a  lot  of 
 time,  you  can  toss  it  up  to  more  human 
 error.  There  is  a  proper  way  to  do  plant 
 blankets.  And  I  think  a  lot  of  us  don't 
 realize  this.  this.  I  almost  want  to 
 knock  on  people's  doors  as  I  drive  by 
 and  see  the  plant  blankets  just  kind  of 
 covering  the  top  of  the  blanket.  So, 
 when  you're  using  your  plant  blankets, 
 you  either  use  the  jacket  with  the 
 drawstring  or  you  can  use  the  full  plant 
 blanket.  I  prefer  the  full  plant  blanket 
 probably  because  I  have  tons  and  tons  of 
 plants  and  they  come  in  nice  long  rows. 
 And  the  best  thing  that  you're  going to 
 want  to  do  is  you're  going  to  want  to 
 treat  it  like  a  hot  air  balloon.  And 
 I'll  give  you  an  example  here.  Like  if 
 this  croin  is  [music]  here  and  I  want  to 
 protect  it,  you  want  to  go  around  this 
 croin  all  the  way  [music]  to  the  stem, 
 all  the  way  to  the  ground  here.  I  use 
 weed  barrier  stakes  and  I  put  those  in, 
 but  you  can  use  stones,  you  can  use 
 rocks,  you  can  use  whatever.  You  can  use 
 a  shovel,  whatever  you  have  on  hand.  You 
 want  to  kind  of  mushroom  all  the  way 
 around  here.  And  make  sure  the  plant 
 blanket  is  [music]  tucked  right  along 
 the  base  here  and  into  the  ground.  So 
 that  way  that  hot  air  from  the  the 
 ground  starts  [music]  to  push  up  during 
 that  cold  snap  that  we  have  starts  to 
 release  into  this  plant  blanket.  Because 
 unlike  us  where  we're,  you  know,  have  an 
 internal  [music]  temperature  that  keeps 
 us  warm,  these  guys  don't.  So  having 
 that  plant  blanket  in  there,  you  [music] 
 really  want  to  make  sure  that  you're 
 utilizing  the  the  water  that  you  kind  of 
 helps  keep  warm  in  there  and  then  that 
 once  that  starts  to  release,  that  really 
 does  help  protect  the  plant  itself.  A 
 common  misconception,  it's  kind  of  what 
 I  see  a  lot.  I  I'll  see  it  where  they'll 
 just  kind  of  drape  it  over  top  and  just 
 kind  of  let  it  hang  here  or  maybe  even 
 tie  it  up  to  the  plant  here.  However, 
 unfortunately,  you're  not  focusing  on 
 the  most  important  part.  The  thing  that 
 needs  to  be  done  is  for  this  plant  to  be 
 completely  covered  all  the  way  to  the 
 base  to  [music]  protect  the  root  system. 
 That's  the  thing  that  you  want  to 
 protect  because  in  the  future,  of 
 course,  you  can  cut  some  of  these  old 
 leaves  off  if  they  get  windburnt,  but 
 those  roots,  they  have  to  be  strong 
 enough  to  push  out  new  energy  to  give 
 you  all  that  new  growth  back.  So  the 
 whole  plant  all  the  way  to  the  bottom 
 wants  [music]  to  be  covered.  And  if  you 
 have  the  bonus  of  having  like  a  boulder 
 or  any  kind  of  stones  or  rocks,  cover 
 that  [music]  tube  because  during  the 
 day,  during  the  sunny  part  of  the  day, 
 that  boulder  heats  up  and  it's  again 
 like  a  hot  water  bottle  in  there  and 
 it's  going  to  allow  some  of  that  heat 
 [music]  to  generate  for  inside  of  this 
 plant.  So  anything  like  that  that  you 
 might  have,  totally  cover  it.  If  you 
 have  concrete  edging,  cover  that 
 concrete  edging  with  your  plant  [music] 
 because  that's  going  to  allow  that  heat 
 to  kind  of  penetrate  towards  the  plant. 
 So,  anything  you  can  do  to  help  warm 
 [music]  up  those  little  guys  during 
 those  cold  snaps  going  to  it's  going  to 
 just  pay  off  tremendously.  So,  the  next 
 tip  [music]  is  some  Christmas  lights. 
 So,  I  know  that  you  guys  have  probably 
 heard  this.  Don't  use  your  LED  lights. 
 Use  incandescent  [music] 
 outdoor  rated  lights.  I  like  the  C9 
 variety.  I'll  put  them  in  my  storefront 
 down  below.  They're  fantastic  to  use. 
 You  want  the  big  bulbs  because  they 
 really  do  give  off  the  [music]  most 
 heat.  And  when  they're  outdoor  rated, 
 you  don't  have  to  worry  about  fires.  You 
 don't  have  to  worry  about  any  kind  of 
 issues.  And  they're  kind  of  cool.  I 
 mean,  just  to  have  little  key  areas  that 
 you're  going  to  do  wrap  your  trees  with 
 them.  Now,  I  only  wrap  Christmas  lights 
 around  my  specialty  palms.  my  palms.  I 
 want  to  make  sure  I  don't  lose  any  kind 
 of  height  from  them  or  lose  too  many 
 fronds  from  them  because,  you  know,  it 
 takes  so  long  for  some  of  these 
 specialty  palms  to  get  any  kind  of  real 
 size  to  them  like  my  penga  coronada  here 
 or  like  my  Laquala  palms  that  you  guys 
 see.  So,  this  palm  tree  is  one  that  I 
 will  be  wrapping  this  year.  I  think  it 
 also  look  pretty  in  the  garden  just  to 
 have  some  Christmas  lights  in  here.  But 
 what  you  want  to  make  sure  to  do  is  you 
 [music]  want  to  start  at  the  bottom,  of 
 course,  work  your  way  through  all  of  the 
 stems  that  you  can.  So  you're  going to 
 work  your  way  through  the  stems,  but 
 each  one  of  these  stems,  there's  a  heart 
 in  this  tree.  [music] 
 And  you  want  to  make  sure  that  you  get 
 into  the  heart.  So  into  the  main  trunk. 
 So  when  I'm  wrapping  the  Christmas 
 lights  through  here,  I'm  wrapping  them 
 through  that  center  stem.  [music] 
 This  one  here  would  be  right  here.  This 
 is  where  that  center  stem  would  be.  I 
 can  go  to  the  laquala  and  show  you  the 
 same  thing  with  the  laquala.  So  in 
 wrapping  this  guy  here,  I  would  make 
 sure  to  wrap  all  the  way  from  the  bottom 
 and  then  hit  all  [music]  of  this 
 interior  section  here.  This  is  the  area 
 that  protects  it.  This  is  the  heart  of 
 the  tree.  A  lot  of  people  concentrate 
 down  by  the  roots,  but  if  you  can  really 
 kind  of  get  in  here,  [music]  that's 
 going  to  protect  you  losing  any  of  these 
 fronds  during  a  frost.  And  then,  of 
 course,  finalize  it  by  wrapping  that 
 tree.  That's  going  to  hold  that  heat  in. 
 That's  going  to  give  you  [music]  like  an 
 internal  heater  for  any  of  your 
 specialty  palms  or  specialty  accents.  If 
 there's  anything  in  your  garden  that  is 
 just  kind  of  on  the  border  and  you're 
 like,  gosh,  I  just  don't  want  to  [music] 
 wait  a  whole  season  for  this  thing  to 
 bounce  back.  cover  it  and  add  some 
 Christmas  lights  to  it.  It's  that  time 
 of  the  year  anyway.  Why  not  add  a  little 
 dazzle?  All right,  you  guys.  For  the 
 fourth  tip,  fungicide.  Liquid  copper 
 fungicide  is  an  ideal  thing  to  do.  If 
 you've  covered,  uncovered,  it's  gotten 
 warm,  it's  gotten  cold,  it's  gotten 
 warm,  it's  gotten  cold,  your  plants,  no 
 doubt,  are  going  to  get  a  fungus  or  be 
 on  the  verge  of  getting  a  fungus.  So,  if 
 you  can  spray  everything  with  a  copper 
 fungicide,  then  you're  going  to  be  super 
 super  happy,  especially  your  palms.  And 
 if  you  do  your  palms,  again,  keep  in 
 mind  the  crown,  the  heart  of  the  palm  is 
 the  most  important  part.  So,  focus  in  on 
 getting  that  fungicide  right  into  the 
 crowns  and  the  hearts  of  the  tree 
 [music]  because  that's  going  to  make  all 
 the  difference.  You  spray  that  into  the 
 canopies.  That  is  the  time  of  the  year 
 that  that  kind  of  thing  happens.  And  if 
 you  can  nip  that  in  the  bud  right  away, 
 then  voila,  you  have  a  beautiful  garden 
 that  did  not  [music]  miss  a  beat.  And 
 for  the  last  tip,  this  is  the  time  of 
 the  year  we're  having  festivities  and 
 everybody  is  traveling.  This  is  a  great 
 time  to  touch  [music]  up  your  area  with 
 mulch.  Now,  it's  going  to  protect  your 
 plants.  It's  going  to  protect  that  root 
 system.  It's  also  going  to  help  kind  of 
 hold  that  moisture  in  the  ground.  So, 
 this  is  a  great  time  as  we  also  cut  back 
 on  water.  It's  going  to  be  a  great  time 
 to  kind  of  help  keep  [music]  things 
 hydrated  when  they  need  to  be.  So, 
 adding  a  nice  layer  of  mulch  is  an  ideal 
 thing  to  do  this  time  of  the  year.  And 
 if  you  have  a  garden  kind  of  like  my 
 garden  where  mulch  is  not  kind  of  an 
 option,  you  kind  of  see  I  kind  of  have  a 
 jungle  floor  of  plants.  So  I  don't 
 really  have  mulch  at  all  in  this 
 particular  section  of  my  garden.  I've 
 allowed  the  plants  to  kind  of  be  its  own 
 ground  cover  like  kind  of  like  nature 
 intends.  So  I  have  a  jungle  floor  and  a 
 lot  of  my  plants  I  don't  have  to  worry 
 about  covering  them  at  all.  even  if  the 
 temperatures  I  know  are  going  to  get 
 into  32,  there's  some  specific  things

 overall  I  cover  very  little  of  it  um

 wrists  are  not  super  strong  and  you 
 know,  just  if  unless  you're  digging  in 
 some  really  nice  kind  of  garden  soil,  it 
 was  just  too  much.  It  torqued  it  too 
 much.  I  like  this  two  handheld  option. 
 And  then  now  we'll  move  on  to  my  final 
 and  probably  the  most  practical  tool 
 that  every  gardener  should  have  in  their 
 garden.  It's  over  here  on  the  side. 
 Excuse  us,  Red. 
 So,  for  my  final  tool  is  my  handy  dandy, 
 heavily  used  wheelbarrow.  Now,  this  is  a 
 twowheel  wheelbarrel,  and  it  sits  nice 
 and  level.  I  like  that  it's  the  hard 
 plastic,  the  Rubbermaid  variety.  So  easy 
 to  work  with.  I  like  that  this  is  big 
 and  bulky  like  this  because  I've  got  to 
 go  through  pavers  on  some  end,  so  it's 
 nice  smooth  sailing,  and  then  rock  on 
 the  other.  And  those  hard  wheels  just 
 work  right  over  top  of  both  like 
 nobody's  business.  So,  I  use  this  for 
 just  pretty  much  everything.  Everybody 
 needs  a  wheelbarrow.  Whether  you're 
 bringing  plants  to  your  back  from  your 
 back  of  your  truck  like  I  am  or  a  soil, 
 mulch.  This  is  just  an  ideal  thing.  This 
 is  the  perfect  size  for  me  because  I 
 don't  have  a  lot  of  space  back  there.  I 
 had  a  giant  I've  had  several  different 
 wheelbarls,  but  they're  just  so  big  and 
 so  bulky  or  they  tip  too  easy.  I  like 
 that  this  is  kind  of  a  secured  one.  You 
 know,  I  like  things  really  easy  in  the 
 garden.  So,  so  although  this  is  kind  of 
 a,  you  know,  a  cheapy  kind  of  overall, 
 you  know,  easy  to  use  wool  barrel,  it's 
 the  perfect  thing.  I  found  it  on  Amazon 
 100  years  ago.  I  will  put  the  link  in 
 the  description,  but  it  is  a  great  one 
 to  use.  And  when  this  one  finally  wears 
 out,  I'm  going  to  get  another  one 
 exactly  like  it.  All right,  you  guys. 
 So,  that  does  it.  Those  are  the  tools 
 that  make  the  magic  happen.  That's  kind 
 of  what  helps  create  this  garden  and 
 keeps  it  all  nice  and  pristine.  So  you

 skirt  plantings.  [music]  Anytime  I  know

 with  some  legggininess  at  the  base,  you

 those.  You  guys,  I  if  you  had  raphus 
 palms  or  lady  palms  in  the  past,  you 
 know  what  they'll  naturally  do  is 
 they'll  naturally  spread.  They  kind  of 
 clump  at  the  base  here,  open  up,  and 
 then  they'll  provide  little  pups  at  the 
 bottom.  If  you  want  to  keep  those  under

 every  3  to  four  months,  just  go  in  and 
 remove  any  of  those  lower  clumping.  That

 nice  clumping,  more  like  a  bouquet  style

 wider.  But  that  starts  from  the 
 beginning.  That  starts  from,  you  know, 
 the  first  few  months  in.  If  you  see  any, 
 kind  of  clip  it,  clip  it.  And  that  way 
 it  forces  [music]  that  tree  to  stay  kind

 definitely  doable.  It's  [music] 
 definitely  worth  having  because  what  an 
 interesting  leaf  those  guys  offer. 
 They're  just  so  cool  [music]  because  we 
 have  so  much  green  and  light  colorations 
 on  the  sides.  The  center  area  is  going 
 to  give  you  a  real  dark  contrast  against 
 [music]  the  blue  of  the  house.  I  love 
 the  love  the  antiloo  collections  right 
 there.  You  [music]  guys  know  what  I  like 
 to  do  with  antiloo's  I'll  connect  them 
 into  one  hole.  So  we'll  [music]  have 
 like  two  or  three  antiloos  in  one  hole
