 each  other  and  become  a  nice  thick 
 grouping  versus  an  individual  plant  like 
 this.  We  kind  of  want  to  take,  you 
 [music]  know,  two  or  three  depending  on 
 the  size  of  them,  put  them  together,  dig 
 a  much  larger  hole  and  plant  them  as 
 one.  And  then  they'll  push  against  each 
 other  again  giving  you  that  bouquet  kind 
 of  feel  where  they  really  widen  out  nice 
 and  chunky.  So,  they're  going to  do  that 
 and  really  fill  in  that  gap  back  there 
 on  [music]  either  side.  I  love  these 
 burl  marks.  Oh  my  gosh,  the  shiny  leaves 
 of  these  little  plants.  Now,  these  guys, 
 you  can  easily  keep  them  around  two, 
 three  foot  tall.  They're  a  nice  slow 
 grower.  They  really  will  kind  of  drift 
 where  you  want  them  to  go,  and  I  just 
 kind  of  love  the  way  that  they  kind  of 
 give  you  a  nice  anchor  point.  An 
 alternative  to  burl  marks  if  you  guys 
 want  something  that's  a  little  bit  more 
 controlled,  a  little  bit  more  compact 
 would  be  Xanadoo.  Dwarf  Xanadoo  is  an 
 ideal  little  kind  of  ground  space.  Both 
 of  them  require  medium  light  to  filter 
 light  to  full  [music]  shade.  So  those 
 are  if  you  get  into  the  sun,  they  can 
 really  burn  on  those.  But  if  that's  your 
 environment,  then  those  are  two  great 
 choices.  And  then  to  brighten  it  up 
 against  cuz  we  had  the  Java  whites  on 
 the  corner.  So  we  want  now  we  went  to 
 dark  green  and  the  dark  green  of  the 
 rafus.  Now  to  bring  a  little  bit  of 
 brightness  and  to  highlight  these 
 antiloos,  we've  [music]  got  song  of 
 India  at  the  bottom.  You  guys,  these 
 Song  of  India  are  easy  to  keep  chunky. 
 All  you  do  is  just  take  off  that  little 
 nip,  [music]  that  little  top.  That  way, 
 it  forces  the  plant  to  go  and  connect 
 together  and  not  shoot  straight  up.  This 
 plant  can  be  this  size  its  whole  life  if 
 you  nip  [music]  it.  I  think  that's  a 
 misconception.  A  lot  of  people  think 
 they  can  get  they  have  to  get  real 
 large,  and  they  can,  [music]  but  they 
 can  easily  be  kept  in  a  kind  of  a  bushy 
 style.  So  you  can  put  four  or  five 
 together  in  one  bush  and  just  clip  those 
 tops  off.  So  that  way  they  knit  and 
 connect  together  because  they're  they're 
 looking  for  a  supporting  partner  there. 
 So  I  mean  aren't  we  all  that  that  way 
 they  really  become  a  nice  full  little 
 cluster  and  the  brightness  [music]  they 
 give  you  in  a  darker  space  is  ideal. 
 Song  of  India  are  versatile.  They  can 
 live  in  shade.  They  can  live  in  filtered 
 light.  They  can  live  in  full  sun.  So  you 
 know  when  you  have a  plant  like  that  you 
 kind  of  want  to  find  good  uses  for  it. 
 So  I  use  it  to  brighten  up  a  dark  spot. 
 So  we  have  the  burl  marks  next  to  it,  a 
 bright  spot  here,  and  then  really  give 
 you  a  nice  dark  hit  with  the  antiloo's 
 there,  and  then  a  nice  kind  of 
 complimentary  color  with  the  dwarf 
 pentas.  And  when  I  use  pentas,  I  kind  of 
 used  to  use  them  in  dabs.  I  don't 
 usually  use  big  sweeps  of  them.  I  like 
 like  a  little  clustering  of  five  or  six 
 in  a  group,  then  I  break  it  with  a 
 another  non-blooming  plant  so  we  always 
 get  color.  These  pentas  will  bloom  all 
 spring,  [music]  all  summer,  and 
 apparently  in  the  fall.  So,  they  do 
 bloom  quite  quite  [music]  often.  The 
 thing  with  pentas  that  do  get  missed  is 
 that  everybody  thinks  because  they're 
 blooming  and  they're  gorgeous  that 
 [music]  you  don't  trim  them.  But  you  do 
 absolutely  trim  these  plants.  And  when 
 you  trim  them,  you  give  them  a  hard  cut 
 [music]  back.  So,  you're  going  to  want 
 to  take  these  guys.  See,  this  size  is 
 perfect.  This  guy's  kind  of  getting  a 
 little  bit  wild  and  a  little  bit  crazy. 
 So,  in  the  next  month,  I  would  say  I 
 would  come  in  and  trim  them  back  down  to 
 a  little  smaller  [music]  than  this  size 
 here.  So,  I  take  all  the  tops  of  them 
 off.  And  anytime  you  trim  a  plant, 
 especially  a  blooming  plant,  you  kind  of 
 want  to  go  mushroom  style.  Leave  a 
 little  bit  of  height  in  the  middle  and 
 then  round  it  off  at  the  bottom.  So 
 that's  exactly  what  you  would  do  here. 
 You  would  trim  it  a  little  tight  on  the 
 sides,  leave  it  a  little  bit  taller  in 
 the  middle.  That  way  when  it  mounds  out, 
 it  kind  of  mounds  out  to  that  that  type 
 of  that  type  of  look.  And  then  you've 
 got  a  gorgeous  grouping.  I  want  these  to 
 fully  connect.  So  this  is  one  solid 
 [music]  swath.  That  way  there's  no  mulch 
 seen  at  all  as  they  grow  in.  This  is 
 going  to  be  the  ground  cover  of  the 
 plants.  And  in  general,  if  you  notice  in 
 my  designs,  that's  exactly  what  I  like 
 to  do  with  all  my  plants  where  mulch  is 
 kind  of  only  seen  along  the  edges  or 
 along  the  rear  side  of  the  bed.  That 
 way,  everything  is  kind  of  a  sea  of  this 
 and  then  it  breaks  and  then  a  sea  of 
 this  and  then  it  breaks.  So,  that's  kind 
 of  the  goal  there.  And  then  you  guys,  we 
 have  a  rinse  and  repeat  pattern.  We've 
 got  the  burl  marks  here  with  the  song  of 
 India  and  then  we're  hitting  it  again 
 with  the  Java  white  copper  leaf.  said 
 the  java  white  copper  leaves.  We  have  a 
 sea  of  those,  a  cluster  here  with  a 
 break  of  the  false  agave  and  this  cool 
 coina  boulder.  And  then  again,  we've  got 
 a  little  touch  of  the  java  whites  on  the 
 corner  with  a  [music]  dark  sea  of  this 
 red  copper  leaf.  That's  the  Louisiana 
 red  copper  leaf.  I  get  this  question  a 
 lot.  Instead  of  using  the  same  type 
 [music]  of  plants  over  and  over  again, 
 sometimes  it's  just  best  to  use  the  same 
 variations  [music]  of  color.  So  that's 
 what  you're  going  to  see  here.  So,  back 
 to  the  back  here.  I  could  have  used 
 antiloo  like  I  have  over  there,  but  I

 contrasting  color  [music]  that  simulates

 antiloo  offers.  So,  the  copper  leaves  to 
 the  back  do  that.  [music]  Then,  we've 
 got  a  bright  tone  because  if  you  got 
 dark,  you  want  to  bring  in  something 
 bright.  So,  we  got  the  brightness  of  the 
 Java  whites  on  the  corner  and  then  of 
 [music]  course  the  dark  greens  here.  And

 song  of  India  like  we  have  in  the  Java 
 whites.  Then  we  have  the  pink  tones  that 
 complement  the  antiloo.  So  you  kind  of 
 see  how  we  go  from  light,  [music]  dark, 
 light,  dark,  and  then  it  just  kind  of  a 
 rinse  and  repeat.  What  a  great  companion

 cloaks  with  their  pink  tones.  So,  it's 
 like  almost  every  plant  in  here  has  a 
 color  partner,  you  know?  So,  that  way

 whole  island  [music]  and  kind  of  give

 more  height  to  this  side  of  it  to  kind

 have  here  is  our  main  centerpiece  area

 kind  of  threw  off  the  bed  shape.  So  we 
 had  to  kind  of  create  our  own  center, 
 our  own  bit  of  weight  here.  [music]  So 
 what  we  did  is  we  we  chose  the  dune  palm 
 and  then  tiered  it  down  to  another 
 accent  with  this  imperialis  [music] 
 bmilad  and  then  tied  in  some  boulders 
 just  to  give  us  a  different  texture  in 
 [music]  the  space.  When  you  can't  go 
 symmetrical,  you  want  to  make  sure  that 
 you  just  can  balance  it  out  with  weight. 
 So  [music]  because  we  have  two  large 
 trees  on  this  side,  I  didn't  want  to  do 
 super  large  trees  on  this  side,  but  I 
 know  we  needed  some  additional  weight. 
 So,  the  pygmy  8  palm  with  its  chunky  and 
 fatness  and  what  that's  going  to  create 
 over  time  is  going  to  offer  balance  and 
 weight  there.  Then  we've  got  the  double 
 foxtail  palm  here.  Then  we've  got 
 [music]  the  two  upright  accents  here  and 
 then  of  course  the  boulders  tucked  in  so 
 that  way  it  feels  like  it  has  a  little 
 bit  a  little  bit  more  ump  on  this  side 
 of  the  bed  to  match  that  side  of  the 
 bed.  And  then  on  both  sides  we  balanced 
 it  out  with  big  clusters  of  Sanchezia.  I 
 have  a  grouping  there  and  a  grouping 
 here.  I  love  the  pop  of  color  in  these 
 leaves.  You  see  them  a  little  bit  now, 
 but  over  time  as  the  Kucia  grow  in, 
 you're  really  going  to  see  that 
 variegation  in  [music]  color.  So,  you 
 guys  may  be  wondering  why  the  ruby  reds 
 are  in  prison  here.  They're  they're 
 completely  in  timeout  over  here  in  these 
 cages.  [music]  These  are  rabbit  cages. 
 Most  of  you  guys  probably  are  familiar 
 with  how  that  works.  Young  plantings, 
 tender  plantings  like  ruby  reds,  like 
 blew  my  [music]  minds,  like  so  many 
 other  tender  ground  covers  that  are  low 
 to  the  ground.  If  you  have  rabbits  that 
 live  in  the  area,  they  can  nibble  and 
 really  kind  of  get  a  hold  of  those 
 smaller  [music]  plants.  What  they  do 
 need  ruby  reds  need  to  be  trimmed 
 several  times  to  get  to  that  [music] 
 hardened  stem  and  then  the  rabbits 
 really  kind  of  lose  interest  in  them. 
 But  it  does  take  some  time  for  that  to 
 happen.  So  you  can  either  use  a 
 pesticide  treatment  or  do  what  my 
 clients  are  doing  here,  which  is  caging 
 the  ruby  reds.  some  of  the  other  plants 
 that  we  have  within  this  bed.  We've  got 
 some  pie  crust  croins  [music]  to  the 
 back  there  and  then  a  little  touch  a 
 little  swath  of  icone  croins  to  the 
 front  of  the  dune  palm.  And  the  main 
 reason  for  the  two  different  types  of 
 croins  there  is  the  pie  crust  croins 
 grow  fat  and  chunky  and  tall.  So  I 
 [music]  have  three  and  three  on  either 
 side  of  the  the  palm  tree.  So  during  the 
 summer  months  and  that's  obviously  when 
 croins  really  do  their  thing  because 
 their  color  is  so  profound  during  that 
 time  of  the  year.  But  we'll  have  four  or 
 five  foot  of  big  clusters  of  high pieces 
 on  either  side  of  the  upright  dune  palm. 
 And  then  down  below  we'll  have  the  ice 
 tones  that  are  more  compact  and  small 
 and  lower  to  the  ground  and  nowhere 
 nearly  as  aggressive.  So  still  going  to 
 offer  color,  still  going  to  give  a  sweep 
 of  something,  but  it's  going  to  be  a 
 more  controlled  plant.  [music]  So  those 
 of  you  guys  who  need  to  change  that  up 
 for  not  putting  something  too  high  in 
 front  of  something  else,  that's  a  great 
 way  to  do  it.  Keep  the  height  to  the 
 sides  or  of  course  to  the  [music]  back, 
 but  then  take  that  front  and  find 
 something  with  a  similar  pattern  or  a 
 fully  contrasted  color  pattern,  but  make 
 sure  that  that  [music]  is  smaller  to  the

 false  agave  or  imperialism,  anything

 here,  we  have  three  Caribbean  agave.  I 
 love  these  little  agave.  They're  they're 
 small  and  cute  now,  but  over  time  they 
 get  gorgeous  and  rounded.  So,  they're 
 almost  like  spherical.  So,  they'll  kind

 the  garden.  They  tend  [music]  to  stay 
 nice  and  small.  They  do  grow  super  slow. 
 So,  if  you  do  want  them  to  have  that 
 gorgeous  look  right  away,  you  might  have

 But,  this  was  I  think  a  5gallon  size

 already  starting  to  pop  out  with  some 
 interest.  But  over  time,  awesome.  What

 boulder  that  we  have  here.  And  we  just

 All  right,  you  guys.  So,  now  we're  at 
 the  driveway.  Now,  I  think  this  turned 
 out  so  cool.  We  don't  have  a  lot  of 
 space  because,  of  course,  we  want  to 
 keep  this  area  open  back  here.  And  when 
 you  don't  have  a  lot  of  space,  I  know  a 
 lot  of  clients,  a  lot  of  my  customers 
 always  ask  me,  could  we  just  do  a  row  of 
 something?  Could  we  just  do  a  row  of 
 trees?  And  you  absolutely  can.  I  love  an 
 avenue  of  palm  [music]  trees.  But  if  you 
 want  something  to  look  a  little  bit 
 grander  and  you  don't  have  a  lot  of 
 depth  in  my  case  and  in  this  situation, 
 what  we  chose  to  do  is  use  foxtail  palms 
 because  they're  a  beefier  [music]  tree 
 with  a  feathery  canopy  and  they're 
 naturally  taller  than  the  kentopsis 
 [music]  palm.  So  they're  always  going  to 
 give  a  height  variation.  But  if  you 
 start  out  with  a  smaller  palm,  different 
 contrasting  leaf,  then  you  go  with  a 
 foxtail  palm  and  then  another  kentopsis 
 palm  for  again  a  lowered  height  [music] 
 back  up  to  a  foxtail.  I  guess  you  got  it 
 right.  You  can  really  see  that  it 
 [music]  adds  more  impact  than  if  I  were 
 to  just  put  a  row  of  foxtails  into  this 
 space.  [music]  Anytime  you  guys  can  do 
 that  up  and  down  motion,  up  and  down 
 motion,  you're  really  able  to  fit  a  lot 
 more  material  into  that  space.  And  then 
 if  I  were  to  put  foxtails  as  close 
 [music]  together  as  I've  got  the  kiopsis 
 and  this  foxtail  together,  they  would  be 
 competing  at  the  canopies.  And  that's 
 kind  of  what  we  want  to  avoid.  We  want 
 this  low  and  high,  low  and  high  kind  of 
 look.  So  that  way  each  tree  can  do  its 
 own  statement.  And  that  was  the  goal 
 here.  So  cuz  we  didn't  have  a  lot  of 
 room  to  work  with.  And  I  think  that  that 
 kind  of  maximized  it  for  the  space.  And

 house.  And  not  having  that  weight  on

 look.  So  being  able  to  create  this 
 linear  kind  of  grouping  with  these  palm 
 trees  gave  that  to  us  from  the  road.  Now

 balance.  And  I  think  that's  [music]  the

 mule  palm.  It  grows  so  very  slow.  It's

 because  they  can  be  really  cool  or  not 
 so  cool.  So,  this  is  a  lovely  one.  We 
 just  went  through  some  summer  storms,

 minutes  ago.  The  difference  of  the  leaf 
 is  enormous.  I  mean,  look  at  the  size  of 
 this  leaf.  I  just  love  this  is  like  a 
 seymour  leaf.  This  is  like  giant  giant. 
 [music]  Now,  when  they're  in  the  shade, 
 they're  not  getting  the  harshness  of  the 
 sun,  so  they're  trying  to  find  more 
 exposure.  So,  they're  growing  those 
 leaves  like  big  giant  lily  pads.  So  that 
 way  they  get  a  little  bit  more  sunlight. 
 They  still  offer  the  beautiful  variation 
 in  color.  And  if  they  get  a  little  less 
 sun,  you'll  [music]  notice  they'll  go 
 even  they'll  take  it  from  yellow  to  a 
 little  bit  more  white  tones.  So  it's 
 it's  still  it's  a  beautiful  plant 
 whether  it's  in  the  sun  or  [music]  it's 
 in  the  shade.  But  just  know  if  you're 
 planning  on  putting  it  more  in  the 
 shade,  it's  going  to  stretch  more.  It's 
 going  to  try  to  reach  out  and  get  more 
 exposure.  [music]  So  filtered  light  is 
 an  ideal  space  for  this  or  full  sun. 
 Full  full  shade.  I  would  probably  stick 
 with  something  more  like  a  Sanchezia 
 [music]  instead,  but  this  is  kind  of  a 
 nice  middle  option.  This  gets  a  couple 
 afternoon  hours  and  then  that's  about

 cloaks  to  the  back.  They're  going  to

 pops  of  beautiful  [music]  pink.  All

 That  makes  it  so  nice  to  be  able  to  walk

 whole  view  of  the  garden.  And  [music] 
 what  these  Kucia  offer  is  no  openings. 
 They  have  condensed  privacy.  And  you  can 
 see  kind  of  the  height  of  where  these 
 Kucia  are  just  at  my  headline  here.  So 
 this  is  the  perfect  height.  They  could 
 be  taller  if  they  wanted,  but  all  she 
 really  wanted  was  a  medium-sized  wall. 
 And  then  she  used  the  accents  on  both

 thrielis,  some  lower  plantings  down

 Brazilian  red  cloaks  on  that  side  there. 
 And  this  wall  kind  of  comes  through 
 here,  curves  in,  and  then  back  down. 
 [music]  So,  it  becomes  kind  of  like  a 
 moving  waving  wall.  But  more 
 importantly,  it  becomes  the  privacy  that 
 she's  looking  for  for  what  she  was 
 looking  for.  And  that's  kind  of  what  I 
 mean  when  I  ask  my  clients,  kind  of  live 
 in  the  [music]  space  with  me.  Tell  me 
 how  you're  going  to  use  it.  Tell  me  what 
 you  need  it  for.  Do  we  need  it  to  do

 do  that?  And  in  her  situation,  she's

 don't  want  to  have  to  worry  about  it.  I 
 want  to  have  a  cup  of  coffee.  I  want  to 
 enjoy  my  space.  [music]  This  is  a  crazy 
 busy  road  right  here.  I  just  want  to  be

 coming  in  and  out."  And  that's  exactly 
 what  this  does  to  you.  I  feel  like  this 
 is  a  very  private  space.  It's  almost 
 like  a  semi  kind  of  courtyard  along  her 
 walkway  space  on  the  sideyard.  And 
 anytime  that  you  can  do  that,  you've 
 [music]  just  extended  your  living  space 
 and  she  gets  to  incorporate  her  garden 
 along  with  that.  So,  Kucia  do  a  great 
 job.  Whether  you're  keeping  them  at 
 [music]  4T,  6T,  8T,  they  become  a  dense 
 wall  from  the  bottom  all  the  way  to  the 
 top.  Now,  they  are  fast  growers,  so  you 
 have  to  keep  that  in  mind.  Your  trimming 
 is  trimming  along  the  top  and  trimming 
 along  the  sides  to  keep  those  all  in 
 place.  And  that  has  to  happen  every  3 
 months.  That's  kind  of  my  general  rule 
 for  Kucia.  I  do  love  the  look  of  Kucia 
 because  I  love  that  big  succulent  leaf 
 on  there.  Funny  enough,  if  you  guys 
 travel  to  the  Keys,  you'll  see  Kucia 
 everywhere  and  people  will  put  their 
 little  initials  or  their  names  or  just 
 married  or  whatnot  on  those  leaves 
 because  the  leaves  last  [music]  so  long 
 on  the  plant.  And  that's  why  they're 
 almost  always  on  my  list  when  it  comes 
 to  [music]  creating  privacy.  They  can  be 
 kept  neat,  super  clean,  like  a  courtyard 
 feel,  or  they  can  be  a  little  bit  wild, 
 a  little  bit  crazy,  a  little  bit 
 tropical.  So,  they  really  fit  into  both 
 environments.  So,  if  you  guys  enjoyed

 just  get  pllopped  in  anywhere  and 
 everywhere.  That's  because  [music] 
 they're  tough.  They're  a  plant  that  does 
 not  grow  super  fast,  can  be  easily 
 maintained.  Trim  this  about  every  three 
 months.  You  know,  whether  you  trim  it 
 like  a  hedge  or  you  mound  it  or  you 
 shape  it,  you  can  pretty  much  do  what 
 you  like  with  it.  It  doesn't  require  a 
 ton  of  water.  It's  about  as  [music] 
 close  to  a  native  that's  not  native. 
 It's  a  very  Florida  friendly  plant 
 because  of  that  reason.  And  you  can  keep 
 it  solid  from  the  bottom  all  the  way  to 
 the  top.  [music]  So,  it  can  be  a  skirt 
 planting  or  it  can  be  your  taller 
 planting,  but  it's  kind  of  a  nice 
 middleman  that  doesn't  really  grow  super 
 [music]  crazy.  So  if  you  need  some

 kind  of  front  yard,  sideyard  buffer  type

 very  appealing  cuz  my  clients  wanted  a 
 wall.  They  wanted  something  that  was 
 going  to  create  some  pretty  good 
 coverage  just  from  the  neighboring 
 house,  but  they  also  wanted  it  to  look 
 good  from  [music]  passer  buyers.  And  we 
 all  have  that,  especially  those  of  you 
 guys  who  are  on  corner  lots.  I  know  that

 is  technically  just  an  extension  of  your 
 front  yard.  And  so  we  kind  of  wanted  to 
 do  the  same  thing  with  this.  We  wanted

 pretty  visual  and  it's  going  to  grow  in 
 with  layers  and  colors  along  this  side

 just  put  up  a  wall  to  kind  of  block  off 
 the  neighboring  house.  And  it  also 
 doesn't  make  them  feel  closed  in.  If  we 
 put  up  a  row  of  RA  palms,  which  nothing 
 bad  about  that,  but  if  you  do  that, 
 sometimes  it  has  a  tendency  to  close  the 
 area  in  even  more.  And  we  want  to  try  to 
 avoid  that  if  we  at  all  possibly  can 
 because  that's  what  gives  you  that  kind 
 of  garden  feel.  Gardens  are  meant  to 
 draw  you  through  to  take  you  through 
 this  expanse.  [music]  That  being  said,

 this  because  what'll  happen  in  that  same

 push  against  each  other  for  future

 gorgeous  bouquet  longterm  year  after

 Very,  very  good  information.  And  Bryce 
 also  mentioned  one  other  thing  off 
 camerara  is  all  of  these  plants,  not 
 only  do  they  work  together  as  a  good 
 combination,  but  they're  also  going  to 
 be  in  the  same  watering  pattern.  So, 
 this  is  not  going  to  be  something  where 
 you  have  to  water  this  one  a  different 
 way  versus  this  one.  All  of  these  are 
 going  to  be  able  to  maintain  and  live 
 off  the  same  watering  [music]  cycle.  And 
 I  think  that's  a  that's  a  big  important 
 thing  to  stress  because  so  many 
 different  tropical  plants  really  require 
 like  a  whole  a  whole  multitude  of 
 watering  options.  [music]  So,  when 
 you're  picking  material,  try  to  do  that. 
 That's  one  more  thing  that  I  did  mention 
 in  the  book.  I  know  I  keep  plugging  the 
 book,  you  guys.  It's  a  shameless  plug 
 [music]  because  I'm  so  very  excited  that 
 it's  out.  But  [laughter]  so,  but 
 definitely  when  you're  pulling  things 
 together,  I  [music]  try  to  mention  what 
 works  together  in  there,  but  I  I  don't 
 always  talk  about  watering.  So,  I'm  so 
 glad  that  he  brought  that  up,  especially 
 in  our  summer  months  here.  What  we  have 
 here  is  a  small  collection.  I  don't  want 
 any  of  this  material  to  overtake  the 
 falsab.  The  falsabave  is  meant  to  be  the 
 star  [music]  of  the  show.  So,  all  of 
 these  to  the  bottom  are  supposed  to 
 crown  around  it.  So  the  little  ruby 
 reds,  the  gold  mound,  the  little  touch 
 of  the  fire  orange  lantana.  I  just  love 
 these  compact  versions  of  Lantana.  These 
 Lantana  are  the  sterile  variety,  not  the 
 ones  that  travel  or  become  invasive.  So 
 if  you  guys  are  looking  in  the 
 nurseries,  try  to  find  those.  Lantana 
 has  a  tendency  to  kind  of  want  to  climb 
 and  and  creep  and  and  do  its  thing. 
 [music]  I  know  that's  the  native  variety 
 versus  the  the  maidana.  However,  what  I 
 do  like  about  these  is  they  just  kind  of 
 stay  put  where  you  want  them  and  they 
 don't  kind  of  travel.  And  considering 
 they  are  kind  of  a  little  toxic  to 
 animals,  especially  cows  and  fields  and 
 things  like  that,  we  want  to  try  to  keep 
 them  where  we're  using  the  sterile 
 variety  if  at  all  possible.  But  I  love 
 the  color  combination  they  offer.  They 
 offer  orange,  pinks,  reds,  yellows,  like 
 things  you  think  that  gosh,  is  that  just 
 too  much?  It's  not  not  going  to  go  well 
 together.  Well,  they  do.  Wait  till  they 
 get  big.  Right  now,  they're  babies.  But 
 when  they  get  big  and  poof  out,  all  of 
 that  color  comes  to  town.  And  then  it 
 pulls  together  other  color  groupings 
 that  you  have  in  the  garden.  I  mean,  we 
 have  the  touch  of  the  purples  and  the 
 burgundies.  [music] 
 We  got  the  touch  of  the  yellows  here.  We 
 got  touches  of  reds  in  the  back.  So,  you 
 know,  anything  that's  going  to  kind  of 
 continue  to  pull  those  colors  together. 
 Pop  in  some  of  that  variegation  there. 
 So,  when  you're  looking  at  this 
 particular  plant  because  this  is  a  new 
 landscape  and  you  might  be  like,  well, 
 these  gold  mount  are  going  to  outgrow 
 these  guys.  Not  the  case.  These  grow 
 gold  mount  are  going  to  be  kept  as  the 
 ground  cover  they're  meant  to  be  kept, 
 which  is  going  to  be  right  into  this 
 range  [music]  here.  And  then  these  guys 
 are  going  to  pop  up  behind  here  and  give 
 you  that  shine  of  color.  So  that's  why 
 we  only  have  three.  You  [music]  guys 
 know  if  there's  room  in  a  garden,  I'm  a 
 plant  filler.  I'll  pop  something  in 
 there  any  chance  I  get.  But  I  have  to 
 restrain  myself  cuz  I  do  know  in  the 
 future  it's  going  to  overgrow  the  space 
 [music]  if  we  put  too  many.  So  three  is 
 all  we  could  do  here  in  a  triangle

 at  once.  They're  very,  very  opposed  to 
 it.  So,  they  dropped  90%  of  their  leaves

 But  I  see  new  growth  coming  everywhere. 
 It's  going  to  pop  back  and  be  gorgeous. 
 This  is  a  tree  combination  that's  been 
 grafted  where  we  have  multiple  colors  in

 another  plumeriia  tree  grouping  here  to 
 the  back  because  one  thing,  the  sun. 
 We've  got  these  oak  trees  to  contend 
 with  unfortunately.  Just  a  little  bit 
 more  shade  than  what  a  plumeriia  really 
 likes.  Plumerias  for  them  to  really

 love  love  love  the  sun.  What  can  handle

 going  to  be  these  bottle  brush  trees. 
 This  is  the  standard  variety,  the 
 lollipop  shape,  the  ones  that  you  can 
 keep  nice  and  rounded  just  like  a 
 lollipop.  So,  I've  chose  three  of  these

 different  view  line.  It  is  something 
 that  we  were  able  to  get  just  have  a 
 little  bit  more  interest  in.  [music]  So 
 instead  of  thinking  of  it  as  one  solid 
 structure  or  one  solid  island,  kind  of 
 think  about  the  purpose  and  the  reason 
 for  it.  This  up  here  obviously  is 
 [music]  for  the  road.  It's  for  the  view 
 line.  It's  for  the  front  door.  It's  for

 is  what  they're  going  to  see.  So  that  is

 have  a  nice  layered  look.  However, 
 [music]  that  doesn't  mean  that  we  can't 
 get  taller.  So  this  is  going  to  be 
 taller  than  that  chunky  plumeriia  in  the 
 back.  You're  going  to  see  this  from  the 
 road,  but  you're  also  going  to  see  this 
 [music]  as  coverage.  These  three  trees 
 are  in  a  triangle  formation.  They're 
 going  to  almost  grow  together.  They  will 
 turn  out  to  be  five  to  six  foot  of 
 circular  heads  at  the  top.  So,  you'll 
 have  6  foot  wide  lollipops  here  [music] 
 as  a  beautiful  green  coloration,  nice 
 texture  of  leaf  with  beautiful  red  red 
 blooms.  So,  those  bottle  brush  blooms 
 are  stunning.  Now,  we're  missing  them 
 right  here  in  fall.  They  do  bloom  all 
 spring,  actually  late  winter,  all 
 spring,  and  in  all  summer  long.  So, 
 we're  just  out  of  the  blooming  cycle 
 now,  but  oh  my  goodness,  during  the  most 
 of  the  year,  they're  absolute  stunners. 
 And  they  take  no  room  in  the  garden.  You 
 kind  of  see  because  they're  the  compact 
 variety,  I'm  not  worried  about  them 
 spilling  out  way  over  here  where  they're 
 [music]  touching  the  house.  No,  they're 
 going  to  kind  of  come  around  here  and 
 give  us  a  nice  rounded  feel.  Very  easy 
 to  [music]  maintain  these  guys.  So,  if 
 you  like  this  kind  of  leaf  structure  and 
 you  got  other  contrasting  leaves,  then 
 don't  sleep  on  the  bottle  brush.  I  just 
 love  them.  If  you  have  a  little  bit  more 
 room  and  want  a  little  bit  more  pizzazz, 
 then  hit  the  weeping  ones.  They  kind  of 
 give  you  a  little  bit  of  a  weeping 
 willow  kind  of  feel.  So,  it's  a  little 
 dreamier,  but  you  definitely  need  more 
 room  for  that  particular  tree.  In 
 standard,  these  are  30-gallon  trees,  and 
 I  usually  put  them  anywhere  between  7 
 and  10t  apart,  just  depending  on  how  big 
 that  tree  canopy  is.  If  it's  a  weeping, 
 definitely  10  foot  apart.  If  it's  a 
 standard  like  this,  it  can  go  as  close 
 as  7  foot  apart.  However,  there's  a 
 caveat  with  that.  Underground  utilities, 
 irrigation  lines,  or  big  mama  oak  trees. 
 Those  roots  on  those  trees  were  no  joke. 
 This  is  the  neighbors  yard.  So, there's 
 nothing  we  can  do  about  the  overhang  of 
 the  trees  here.  So,  what  we've  got  is 
 we've  got  a  couple  trees  a  little  offc 
 center  just  because  we  had  to  work  with 
 what  we're  working  with.  So,  right  here 
 I  have  a  little  collection  of  three 
 thrielis.  Now,  thrielis  are  going  to  do 
 what?  hibiscus  do.  They're  going  to  kind 
 of  come  up.  They're  going  to  give  you  a 
 little  bit  of  a  woody  bottom,  but  the 
 top  of  these  yellow  blooms,  the  top  of 
 those  leaves  are  going  to  [music]  be 
 stunners.  If  you  only  have  room  for  one 
 row  of  something,  don't  use  thrielis. 
 [music]  Thrielis  are  too  woody  at  the 
 bottom  because  that's  all  you'll  see  is 
 the  wood  at  the  base.  If  you  have  room 
 for  a  skirt  to  go  underneath  of  it, 
 thrielis  all  day  long.  They're  gorgeous. 
 They're  easy  to  care  for.  They  bloom  all 
 year  long.  I  mean,  even  in  the  fall, 
 they  bloom.  summer,  fall,  spring. 
 They're  really  fabulous  to  work  with. 
 They  need  filtered  light  to  full  sun. 
 That's  their  favorite  option.  But  they 
 can  handle  all  of  the  acid  dropping  from 
 these  [music]  oak  tree  leaves.  So, 
 they're  going  to  do  perfectly  fine  in 
 this  environment.  Keep  in  mind,  right 
 now,  everything  is  layered  perfectly. 
 But  when  these  get  to  the  back,  get  to 
 be  6t  or  so,  then  we're  going  to  have 
 lower  plantings.  You're  really  going  to 
 see  that  variation  come  to  life  when  the 
 kucia  connect  and  become  the  wall.  And 
 that's  one  of the  best  parts  about  using 
 a  hedge  like  a  kousia,  like  a  green 
 buttonwood,  like  a  podocarpus,  is  you 
 can  manipulate  your  wall,  your  green 
 wall  space  into  whatever  size  you  want 
 it  to  be.  Unlike  a  palm  tree  where 
 you're  kind  of  just  going  to  have  to 
 wait  and  it's  going to  grow  and  do  its 
 thing,  a  wall,  a  rear  wall  of  a  hedge 
 planting,  you  can  maintain  it  whatever 
 size  it's  going  to  suit  your  particular 
 island.  So,  I  love  Kucia  for  that 
 because  they  they  really  let  you  play 
 around  and  and  work  in  your  space 
 instead  of  you  having  to  work  with 
 theirs.  And  then  all  you  have  to  worry 
 about  doing  is  making  sure  that  you 
 dress  up  [music]  in  front  of  the  green 
 wall.  So  your  green  screen  is  there. 
 Layer  in  some  variations  of  colors  or 
 different  textures.  If  you  like  multi 
 greens,  go  with  multi  greens.  Use 
 foxtail  ferns  for  that  chartreuse 
 [music] 
 green.  Use  something  like  Xanadoo  for  a 
 different  kind  of  shaped  green.  Use 
 something  like  this  kind  of  leaf  that 
 really  gives  you  more  of  a  northern  type 
 of  needle  feel  of  of  that  kind  of  green

 These  dwarf  alamandas  are  just  stunners. 
 I  love  love  love  them  in  a  garden.  They 
 can  handle  filter  light.  They  can  handle 
 full  sun.  They  don't  like  shade,  so  you 
 want  to  kind  of  stay  away  from  that.  But 
 they  can  handle  the  acid  from  leaves, 
 pine  needles,  anything  like  that.  They 
 can  be  in  an  acidic  environment  and 
 [music]  be  super  super  happy.  So,  I  just 
 have  a  little  bit  of  grouping,  just  kind

 all  the  way  down  to  the  end  of  the  bed.

 you  can  end  that  back  with  something

 light  tone,  then  there's  something  that

 [music]  Well,  hello  gardeners.  Welcome 
 back.  So,  you  guys  are  getting  ready  to 
 start  your  garden  and  you're  wondering 
 what  to  do  first.  Well,  today's  video  is 
 about  five  [music]  key  essential  things 
 that  I  do  when  I'm  looking  at  a  new 
 space  for  a  new  garden.  Doing  these  five 
 things  before  you  start  putting  that 
 first  plant  in  the  tree  in  the  ground, 
 before  you  go  to  that  nursery  and  get 
 all  the  fun  stuff  done.  These  things  are 
 going  to  save  you  time,  money,  [music] 
 and  quite  a  bit  of  a  headache.  I've  been 
 doing  this  for  well  over  25  years  now.  I 
 am  a  landscape  designer,  and  I  do  this 
 for  my  clients  every  single  week.  We 
 transform  outdoor  spaces,  front  yards, 
 backyards,  landscape  design  and 
 installation.  So,  these  are  things  that 
 I  run  across  so  very  often.  And  what  I 
 notice  is  a  lot  of  times  the  original 
 landscape  on  a  home  maybe  wasn't  set  up 
 so  bad,  but  because  of  some  of these 
 things  that  got  missed  in  the  landscape, 
 it  really  caused  harm.  and  things  had  to 
 be  ripped  out  and  removed  and  changed 
 just  because  these  few  things  haven't 
 been  done.  So,  I  thought  it  was 
 important  enough  [music]  to  make  a  video 
 today  to  share  those  key  things  that  I 
 keep  seeing  over  and  over  and  over  again 
 in  [music]  hopes  that  this  is  going  to 
 help  you  guys  help  you  DIYers  out  there 
 to  kind  of  get  this  handled  right  off 
 the  bat.  [music]  So,  let's  jump  right 
 in.  All  right,  for  the  first  tip  and  the 
 first  thing  to  consider  in  your  garden 
 is  if  you've  decided  where  you're  going 
 to  have  your  landscape  beds  and  it  might 
 interfere  with  some  drainage  issues.  you 
 know,  say  it's  your  gutter  line  or  the 
 corner  of  your  house,  water  kind  of 
 really  kind  of  cascades  over  in  this 
 area,  you  definitely  want  to  consider 
 what  you're  going  to  use  in  that 
 particular  spot.  Make  sure  it  is  a  tough 
 plant.  But  most  importantly,  if  you  can, 
 if  it's  in  your  budget  or  if  it's 
 something  that  you  want  to  do  prior  to  a 
 landscape  company  coming  out,  attach 
 just  like  we  did  here,  attach  a  pipe  to 
 the  gutter  itself  [music] 
 and  then  bring  it  right  out  into  the 
 lowest  section  of  the  yard.  This  is  a 
 pretty  good  example  here  cuz  you  guys 
 can  really  see  the  elevation  pitch.  Not 
 always  do  we  have  this  much  [music]  an 
 extreme  pitch,  but  it  is  ideal  to  make 
 sure  that  you  can  take  that  line  all  the 
 way  out  into  [music]  the  lowest  section 
 of  the  garden  because  now  this  is  the 
 area  that  water  is  going  to  gravitate 
 to.  This  is  the  area  that  is  going  to 
 overflow  [music]  with  water.  We  use  an 
 emitter  at  the  very  end  of  our  pipe. 
 It's  kind  of like  a  sprinkler  [music] 
 head.  It  pops  up  um  when  water  pressure 
 is  inside  and  then  just  releases.  It's 
 an  [music]  ideal  thing  to  know  that  when 
 we  get  those  heavy  cascading  rains  and 
 I've  got  a  metal  roof,  that  water  really 
 just  comes  off  of  that  like  crazy  that  I 
 know  that  this  is  going  to  be  outside 
 not  only  my  pavers,  [music]  but  it's 
 going  to  be  outside  my  landscape  bed 
 into  the  grass  line.  So,  when  you're 
 planning  for  your  garden,  you  don't  have 
 to  worry  about  raising  your  landscape 
 bed  up  too  high  because  there's  already 
 kind  of  a  water  level  here.  What's  ideal 
 about  that  is  that  you  can  make  sure 
 that  your  landscaping  is  has  dry  feet. 
 Sorry,  Red  says  hello  you  guys.  The  your 
 landscaping  itself  has  dry  feet  because 
 all  the  water  is  now  going  to  go  exactly 
 where  you  tell  it  to  go.  It's  going  to 
 go  exactly  to  that  spot,  that  lowest 
 section  of  the  yard.  If  you  guys  can  do 
 that  before  your  landscaper  is  there, 
 great.  If  you,  you  know,  if  it's  not  in 
 your  wheelhouse,  then  and  you  have  the 
 budget  for  it,  then  definitely  make  that 
 a  part  of  your  landscape  package  because 
 that's  an  ideal  thing  to  do  just  to  make 
 sure  all  the  way  around  your  house, 
 you've  collected  that  water  and  gotten 
 it  outside  those  beds  before  the  first 
 plant  or  tree  ever  goes  into  the  ground. 
 For  the  second  [music]  tip,  edging.  Will 
 you  be  needing  landscaping  edging  as 
 part  of  your  project?  [music]  Now,  I 
 have  met  with  a  lot  of  clients.  I  get 
 this  question  all  the  time.  Depending  on 
 the  type  of  landscape  style,  [music] 
 there  are  three  kind  of  reasons  why  you 
 would  be  needing  landscape  edging  in  and 
 you  want  to  kind  of  keep  that  in 
 consideration  [music]  because  it  is 
 going  to  be  part  of  your  budget.  So,  the 
 first  reason  that  I  would  say  if  we're 
 going  to  do  a  landscape  bed  for  you  and 
 we  are  going  to  install  stone,  then  you 
 absolutely  want  some  type  of  edging.  I 
 have  edging  defining  different  types  of 
 [music]  stone  that  we're  working  with. 
 So,  if  you're  going  to  divide  rock  from 
 mulch  or  rock  from  grass,  you  definitely 
 want  a  nice  defined  edge  border  that's 
 really  going  to  hold  everything  into 
 place.  It  is  super  important  to  kind  of 
 have  a  good  edging  for  that.  When  your 
 landscaping  ground  cover  is  stone,  then 
 you're  really  going  to  need  to  have 
 something  that's  going  to  define  and 
 kind  of  give  yourself  a  barrier  for  when 
 your  maintenance  guy  or  [music]  maybe 
 you  do  it  yourself  come  along  through 
 and  edge  that  area.  Because  if  he  tries 
 to  edge  it  without  an  edger  in  place, 
 that's  when  that  rock  goes  everywhere. 
 So  having  that  defining  line  really 
 makes  sure  that  heat  edges  along  the 
 edging,  not  necessarily  [music]  the 
 stone  itself.  The  second  time  to  be 
 using  edging  is  if  you're  having  a  mulch 
 bed.  [music]  Say  we're  doing  a 
 landscaping  and  you're  going  to  do  a 
 mulch  ground  cover.  You  don't  always 
 need  edging  for  that,  but  a  lot  of  times 
 what  I  found  is  it's  [music]  a  great  way 
 to  kind  of  keep  the  bed  from  expanding 
 over  time.  Now,  you  guys  have  seen  lawn 
 maintenance  guys  do  this  where,  you 
 know,  you'll  have  a  maybe  a  six-foot 
 [music] 
 little  area,  a  looped  bed  planting,  and 
 then  over  the  year  because  you  can't 
 kind  of  find  the  line  that's  defined, 
 [music]  the  line  gets  bigger  and  bigger 
 and  bigger,  and  that  six  foot  turns  into 
 15t  over  a  year,  and  you're  like,  "Huh, 
 that  bed  really  grew  on  its  own."  That's 
 exactly  how  it  happens.  So,  having  a  a 
 defined  edge  line  doesn't  mean  that  the 
 guy's  not  going  to  edge  or  you're  not 
 going to  edge  over  time.  It  just  gives 
 you  that  fine  line  to  edge  along.  So 
 that  way  you  always  have  a  nice  form 
 fitting  bed,  you  know,  the  outline  of 
 it.  So  having  a  nice  defined  edging  for 
 that  is  is  ideal.  And  for  the  last 
 reason,  it's  strictly  aesthetic  appeal. 
 Let  me  kind  of  show  you  what  I  mean  on 
 that  one.  So  as  you  guys  saw  that  I  have 
 the  aluminum  alloy  edging  separating  the 
 rock  patterns  here.  But  as  we  get  into 
 this,  I  love  the  rustic  charm  of  a 
 boulder  edge.  Now  this  is  a  small 
 handheld  boulder  edge  that  we've  leveled 
 out  because  I  needed  to  have  a  little 
 bit  of  a  rise.  is  this  everything  in 
 this  particular  bed  needs  additional 
 drainage.  So,  I  needed  a  little  bit  of  a 
 a  height  line  here.  So,  we  kind  of 
 created  [music]  a  retaining  wall.  Now, 
 you  can  do  this  with  boulders,  you  can 
 do  this  with  coina,  you  can  do  this  with 
 stack  stone.  There's  so  many  different 
 ways.  Whatever  your  aesthetic  is,  it's 
 an  ideal  thing  to  do  just  to  kind  of 
 give  you  a  different  little  bit  of 
 elevation  in  the  garden.  [music] 
 And  then,  of  course,  my  other  edging  is 
 the  Buda  edging.  I  love  how  I  have  so 
 many  different  varieties  of  edgings  in 
 the  garden  because  I  feel  like  that 
 contrast  [music]  makes  for  an 
 interesting  space.  It's  like,  oh,  what's 
 going  on  here?  And  just  when  you  think 
 you  got  it  figured  out,  now  you've  got  a 
 kind  of  a  a  different  look.  You  might 
 have  one  more  more  seamless,  one  more 
 clean  lines,  one  [music]  more  rustic. 
 And  having  that  kind  of  all  pulled 
 together,  I  think  is  ideal  in  any  type 
 of  gardening  space.  I  [music]  think  it 
 adds  to  that  look  with  something  that 
 doesn't  require  any  maintenance.  So 
 [music]  something  that's  actually  doing 
 the  job  for  you  in  the  garden.  Edging  is 
 definitely  something  to  consider  because 
 it  is  something  that's  going  to  be  part 
 of  your  price  point  [music]  and  it's  a 
 forever  piece.  It's  a  piece  that  once 
 it's  in,  once  it's  done,  that  is  now  a 
 part  of  your  gardens.  Definitely 
 consider  that  when  you're  putting 
 together  kind  of  your  garden  plans  and 
 especially  if  you're  thinking  about  some 
 different  elevations. 
 All  right,  for  the  third  tip  today  is 
 eradicating  those  weeds  in  the  garden 
 while  there  is  nothing  there.  So,  if  you 
 guys  haven't  started  your  garden  yet, 
 this  is  the  ideal  time  to  kind  of  get  to 
 a  fresh  start,  [music]  a  blank  slate  as 
 you  have  it.  If  you  have  weeds  in  your 
 garden  and  they're  an  aggressive  weed, 
 [music]  definitely  eliminate  them  right 
 off  the  bat.  Give  yourself  time.  Don't 
 rush  the  new  planting.  Make  sure  that 
 you  treat  the  weeds.  Whatever  your 
 method  is,  whether  you  use  a  natural 
 product  or  you  use  a  herbicide,  you  want 
 to  make  sure  that  you've  eliminated 
 those  pockets  of  weeds  through  that 
 space.  And  then  you  want  to  give  it  a 
 little  bit  more  time.  So  each  weed  seed 
 going  [music]  from  a  seed  itself  to  a 
 new  weed  is  about  15  days.  So  maybe 
 every  10  days  to  2  weeks,  it's  a  really 
 good  idea  just  to  kind  of  come  through 
 and  either  pick  or  pull  or  spray  [music] 
 those  weeds  until  you've  got  a  nice 
 clean  bed.  Because  if  you  do  that  now, 
 then  now  when  your  new  plantings  come 
 in,  you're  not  fighting  that.  You're  not 
 having  the  headache  of  trying  to  pull 
 those  weeds  in  between  all  your  new 
 plantings  because  you've  got  now  a  clean 
 soil,  a  clean  base  to  work  with.  So,  I'm 
 actually  facing  that  with  a  client  right 
 now  where  his  existing  landscape  has 
 just  kind  of  been  taken  over  with  a 
 really  aggressive  [music]  weeds  and  he 
 wants  to  go  back  in  with  a  clean  line 
 landscape  and  I  think  that  it's  going  to 
 be  absolutely  stunning  for  his  property. 
 But  I  told  him  if  he's  not  in  too  big  of 
 a  hurry,  let's  do  [music]  it  this  way 
 first.  Even  though  I  had  a  booking 
 availability  in  three  weeks,  we  pushed 
 [music]  him  out  to  six  weeks.  So  that 
 way  we  can  treat  the  area,  get  it  real 
 good  and  free  [music]  of  weeds.  And  that 
 way,  whatever  he's  dealing  with  in  the 
 future  into  those  beds,  it's  just  what's 
 been  dropped  from  seedlings.  It's  not 
 something  that's  already  in  the  ground, 
 something  that's  going  to  be  tilled  and 
 turned  and  and  new  weeds  popping  up 
 through  the  garden  because  that  is  a 
 giant  headache,  especially  when  you  have 
 new  plantings  that  are  just  starting  to 
 grow  in.  You  don't  want  to  have  weeds 
 that  are  growing  in  just  as  fast  because 
 think  of  this.  Now  that  this  area  is  now 
 going  to  be  planted,  it's  got  good  new 
 soil  put  in.  It's  been  fertilized.  It's 
 getting  adequate  water.  So,  think  about 
 what's  going  to  grow  faster,  your  weeds 
 or  your  landscaping.  So,  if  you  can 
 eradicate  them  right  off  the  bat,  just 
 just  [music]  get  them  out  and  over  with, 
 right?  [laughter]  Sorry,  Red  Red  really 
 wants  to  be  in  today's  video,  you  guys. 
 That  is  something  super  [music]  super 
 important.  So,  kind  of  get  that  right 
 off  the  bat.  And  then  you're  going  to  be 
 so  happy  with  just  maintaining  your 
 garden  over  the  long  term  [music] 
 because  you  have  made  it  a  weed-free 
 zone.  Or  you  can  do  it  what  I've  done 
 here  where  I've  done  a  compilation 
 [music]  of  plant  groupings  where  it's  a 
 big  thick  layered  layout.  So  although  I 
 did  have  to  battle  the  weeds  initially 
 [music]  when  we  first  came  into  the 
 garden,  now  that  everything's 
 established,  everything's  grown  in,  all 
 the  ground  cover  is  in,  there's  no  light 
 underneath.  You  know,  it's  kind  of  like

 have  anything  exposed.  [music]  So,

 >> so  guys,  I  will  be  taking  over  tip  four. 
 And  tip  four  is  knowing  your  soil  and 
 knowing  your  plant  pallet.  Now,  knowing 
 your  soil  is  important  because  it  lets 
 you  know  what  your  garden  is  deficient 
 in.  All  you  need  to  do  is  get  a  soil 
 sample  and  send  that  to  your  local 
 extension  office  or  I  believe  the 
 University  of  Florida  does  it  as  well. 
 You  can  just  send  it  in.  They  give  you 
 the  results  back  of  what  your  yard  is 
 deficient  in.  Or  an  alternative  option 
 is  driving  through  your  neighborhood  and 
 seeing  what  does  well  in  other  people's 
 yards.  A  lot  of  the  times  neighborhoods 
 share  similar  soil  backfield  from  when 
 the  neighborhood  was  first  created. 
 That's  one  of  the  first  things  that  I  do 
 when  I  meet  with  somebody  for  a  design 
 is  I  take  a  quick  10-minute  trip  around 
 the  neighborhood  and  I  mark  out  what 
 does  well  [music]  in  the  neighboring 
 houses.  So,  whenever  I'm  meeting  with 
 them,  I'm  saying,  "Oh,  I've  seen  this 
 [music]  flourish.  This  one  does  really 
 well.  It  grows  very  tall,  very  strong." 
 And  for  those  of  you  guys  who  are  also 
 new  to  Florida,  this  is  a  great  tip. 
 Maybe  you're  not  familiar  with  the  USDA 
 zones.  What  can  survive  here?  What 
 cannot?  [music]  You're  seeing  this 
 video.  this  is  in  10  A  and  you're  in 
 zone  9b.  The  best  way  I  could  say  figure 
 [music]  out  what  works  well  in  your  area 
 is  to  drive  around,  see  what's 
 flourishing,  and  then  just  and  add  that 
 to  your  plant  pallet,  your  shopping  list 
 for  your  future  garden.  And  by  seeing 
 what's  doing  well  and  what's 
 flourishing,  [music]

 does  well  in  the  same  soil  type.  Or 
 shameful  plug,  by  the  way,  you  can  just

 All  right,  you  guys.  Hello,  true 
 gardener.  So,  it's  time.  You  are  ready 
 to  get  rid  of  what's  in  the  front  yard 
 or  jazz  it  up,  make  it  more  interesting, 
 whatever  the  case  may  be,  but  you're 
 looking  to  create  a  lowmaintenance  front 
 yard  garden.  Well,  today's  video  is  all 
 about  that.  It  is  all  about 
 lowmaintenance,  easy  care,  but 
 interesting  features.  Because 
 lowmaintenance  should  not  mean  boring, 
 should  not  mean  no  color,  no  impact.  I 
 think  it  it  should  be  the  exact 
 opposite.  I  think  you  should  have 
 interesting  features,  but  just  kind  of 
 bring  some  material  in,  combinations 
 that  are  going  to  work  really  well 
 together  and  live  together  long  term  and 
 things  that  you  can  maintain  on  a 
 quarterly  basis  and  be  super  super  happy 
 with  a  small  front  garden.  This  front  of 
 the  house  is  not  very  deep.  This  yard  is 
 your  typical,  I  would  say,  suburban 
 sized  yard.  So,  this  is  a  fairly  small 
 front  yard.  This  wall  that  we're  working 
 with,  you  can  see  all  of  the  weight  is 
 to  my  left  side  over  here  of  the  house. 
 And  then  this  area  of  the  front  of  the 
 house  is  quite  small.  So,  we  don't  want 
 to  take  and  overcrowd  the  space  with  a 
 bunch  of  height  and  a  bunch  of  lushness 
 and  a  bunch  of  tropical  material.  We 
 really  want  to  be  careful  of  what  you're 
 going  to  use  there.  that  it's  going to 
 look  good  now  and  it's  going  to  look 
 good  years  from  now  because  we  didn't 
 use  material  that  is  just  going  to,  you 
 know,  just  not  fit  the  space  long  term. 
 And  that's  what  lowmaintenance  means. 
 Why  lowmaintenance,  you  might  ask?  It's 
 different  for  every  single  person.  As  a 
 landscape  designer,  I  get  to  meet  with 
 so  many  different  people.  Some  people 
 are  just  not  weekend  warriors.  They 
 don't  want  to  be out  in  the  garden.  They 
 don't  want  to  be  trimming  shape  and 
 cleaning,  you  know,  putting  on  their 
 gardening  gloves  every  time  they  turn 
 around.  So,  obviously,  low  maintenance 
 gardening  is  for  you.  And  then  for  my 
 customers,  Mike  and  Mary  here,  they 
 travel  throughout  parts  of  the  year.  So, 
 they  want  to  be  able  to  be  in  tune  with 
 their  garden.  You  know,  have  somebody 
 come  and  maintain  it  over  the  time  that 
 they're  gone  and  then  do  some  light  work 
 when  they're  here.  So,  it's  important 
 just  to  kind  of  know  what  you're  up  for 
 in  the  garden.  So,  not  only  do  you  want 
 it  to  fit  your  space,  but  you  also  want 
 it  to  fit  your  lifestyle.  Is  this  you? 
 Then  go  this  route.  Those  of  you  guys 
 who  need  more  than  DIY  action,  you  just 
 need  it  to  be  done,  finished,  beautiful, 
 and  polished  for  you.  Give  us  a  shout. 
 We  are  a  landscape  design  and 
 installation  company.  So,  from  concept 
 of  creating  the  design  to  the  final 
 touches  of  the  mulch,  the  finished 
 product.  So,  if  that's  what  you're 
 looking  for,  please  contact  us.  I'll  put 
 all  of  our  contact  information  down  in 
 the  show  notes  down  below.  For  now, 
 let's  jump  into  some  of  the  key  things 
 in  this  garden  that  really  kind  of  help 
 bring  in  that  lowmaintenance  but 
 colorful,  tropical  fun  to  a  front  yard 
 space.  All right,  you  guys.  So,  just 
 like  I  normally  do,  I  like  to  start  from 
 the  back  and  work  my  way  forward.  So, 
 the  corner  pieces,  the  things  that  I 
 chose  to  really  kind  of  add  some  impact, 
 we  only  had  the  room  in  this  garden  to 
 add  one  big  tree.  We  had  plans  in  the 
 original  plan  to  add  two  trees  in  this 
 front  yard  space,  but  easements  and 
 whatnot  with  the  HOA,  it  didn't  work 
 out.  So,  we  only  had  room  for  one.  So, 
 if  you  got  to  do  one,  why  not  do  a  big 
 mama  jama  double  like  this  guy?  So,  this 
 is  a  double  foxtail  palm  that  anchors 
 this  corner  of  the  house.  You'll  notice 
 that  I  like  to  push  my  trees  out  as  far 
 to  the  edge  of  the  property  line  as  I 
 can  without  getting  into  property 
 easements,  of  course.  So,  this  guy  is 
 over  to  the  side.  I  didn't  want  him  in 
 front  of  the  window.  I  kind  of  wanted 
 him  kind  of  more  in  where  this  blank 
 wall  is  and  pushed  him  out  to  the 
 corner.  That  does  a  great  job  of  framing 
 the  front  entrance  of  the  house.  In  a 
 moment,  you'll  see  on  the  opposite  side 
 how  we  have  a  big  giant  fat  fox  tail  on 
 that  side  to  kind  of  give  us  that  same 
 framework  that  we  have  working  on  either 
 side  of  this  big  driveway  that  we've 
 got.  So,  if  you  got  to  do  one  tree,  do  a 
 double  or  a  triple.  That'll  give  you 
 some  substance,  some  impact,  and  really 
 kind  of,  you  know,  nail  that  in.  That's 
 an  anchor  tree.  You  guys  are  probably 
 wondering  why  I  use  foxtails  so  often. 
 It's  because  I  like  self-cleaning  trees. 
 I  like  trees  that  you  don't  have  to  kind 
 of  go  in  there  and  trim  or  pay  somebody 
 a  couple  times  a  year  to  go  in  there  and 
 really  give  it  a  good  haircut.  So,  if 
 it's  at  all  possible  and  you're  looking 
 for  a  lowmaintenance  tree,  a 
 self-shedding  or  self-cleaning  tree  is 
 an  ideal  tree  to  work  with.  And  I  just 
 kind  of  like  how  cool  and  slick  this 
 trunk  line  is.  It  just  really  kind  of 
 gives  me  that  clean  feel  that  I  wanted 
 in  this  front  garden.  This  foxtail  palm 
 is  8  nt  off  of  the  house  here  and  it's 
 pushed  kind  of  out  this  way.  So,  it's 
 really  kind  of  doing  a  good  job  of 
 really  giving  us  an  entranceway  feel. 
 It's  kind  of  just  across  from  the 
 entrance  way  of  the  walkway.  So,  I 
 really  like  the  location  that  it's 
 sitting.  I  think  it's  doing  a  nice  job 
 of  becoming  an  anchor  in  this  space.  And 
 because  I  don't  want  it  to  get  lost.  I 
 don't  want  this  to  be  all  trunk  when 
 it's  27  30  foot  tall.  I  want  it  to  be 
 have  some  kind  of  backing  to  it.  So,  you 
 guys  know  I  love  to  put  pygmy  palms  as  a 
 backdrop.  It's  kind  of  a  fluffy  kind  of 
 soft  backing.  And  you  only  trim  this  guy 
 one  to  two  times  a  year.  It  really 
 depends  on  your  level  of  how  upright  you 
 want  to  keep  these  fronds.  If  you  like 
 this  bushy  kind  of  thick  feel,  you  might 
 only  trim  this  once  a  year.  It  does  have 
 thorns,  so  that  can  make  it  a  little  bit 
 angry  if  you,  you  know,  when  you're 
 trimming.  So,  wear  your  gardening  gloves 
 and  your  long  snippers  and  snip  it  as 
 close  to  the  trunk  line  as  possible.  But 
 again,  at  a  once  a  year  trim  offers  such 
 a  big  impact  in  a  garden  for  such  little 
 care  in  the  garden.  So  definitely  worth 
 a  tree  to  incorporate  as  your  either 
 centerpieces  or  corner  pieces  or 
 backdrops  to  big  trees  to  give  it  depth, 
 to  give  it  that  tearing  effect.  So  now 
 we're  going to  move  over  to  the  next 
 tree  in  this  grouping  here.  This  is  a 
 European  fan  palm.  This  is  such  a  little 
 beauty,  you  guys.  I  know  some  people 
 love  them,  some  people  hate  them.  I 
 don't  understand  it  because  when  I'm 
 thinking  about  low  maintenance,  I  am 
 thinking  about  trimming.  I'm  thinking 
 about  care.  I'm  thinking  about  overall 
 pest  issues  and  things  like  that.  This 
 guy  gives  you  no  problem.  Stays  put. 
 Grows  5  to  6  in  a  year.  That's  how  slow 
 this  tree  grows.  Has  a  beautiful  rounded 
 kind  of  feel.  Now,  when  picking  a 
 European  fan  palm,  you  can  find  them 
 very  small.  If  they  have  this  nice 
 rounded  feel  where  they  kind  of  have 
 trunks  everywhere,  that's  the  tree  that 
 you're  going  to  want  to  find.  whether 
 it's  a  small  little  guy  or  a  big  tree 
 because  they're  so  easy  to  care  for  in 
 nurseries.  A  lot  of  times  they  get 
 forgotten  about  which  means  that  you  get 
 a  tree  that  is  not  super  healthy  or  does 
 not  full  or  doesn't  have  everything  that 
 you  want  it  to  have.  And  for  a  tree  to 
 have  such  a  big  presence  in  a  garden,  it 
 has  to  be  a  real  attractive  European  fan 
 palm.  You  can  see  how  big  this  window  is 
 and  how  little  a  space  we  have  on  either 
 side  of  the  window.  So,  I  didn't  want 
 anything,  you  know,  just  clogging  up 
 this  wall,  making  this  wall  even  more 
 and  more  narrow.  So,  I  wanted  to  open 
 it,  broaden  it  up.  So,  in  order  to  do 
 that,  you  want  a  focal  point  here,  and 
 then  if  at  all  possible,  grow  into  the 
 next  two  focal  points  that  jet  out  on 
 either  side  of  it.  So,  it's  like  a  kind 
 of  like  an  offset  triangle  here.  This  is 
 our  centerpiece.  Now,  we're  coming  out 
 to  our  next  centerpieces,  which  are  the 
 false  agave.  This  guy  right  here  on  this 
 corner  really  gives  you  a  cool  fun  pop 
 of  like  a  statuesque  type  of  look.  And 
 then  right  at  the  entrance  way  does  the 
 same  thing.  And  then  we  sandwiched  the 
 European  fan  palm  right  in  the  middle. 
 So  just  to  reiterate  and  when  you're 
 picking  out  your  plants  and  your  trees, 
 your  tall  stuff,  the  things  that  are 
 hard  to  get  to,  if  you  can  make  them 
 self-shedding,  self-cleaning,  that's 
 you're  not  up  in  a  ladder  having  to  do 
 all  that  work.  When  it  comes  to  your 
 small  stuff,  it's  okay  to  do  the 
 trimming  as  long  as  it  doesn't  grow 
 super  fast.  If  you're  doing  trimming  on 
 this  tree,  maybe  once  a  year,  and  I  mean 
 maybe  once  a  year,  and  it  might  be  just 
 a  limb  or  two  that  maybe  turn  brown  from 
 a  storm  or  whatnot,  you  would  trim  that 
 once  a  year  in  here.  These  two  guys,  now 
 they're  lowmaintenance.  They  do  grow 
 about  a  foot  a  year.  So,  you'll  get  some 
 size,  some  more  size  out  of  this  all  the 
 way  to  here.  But,  it  is  super  easy  to 
 trim.  I  know  it  seems  intimidating. 
 Please  do  not  be  intimidated  by  these 
 guys.  I  don't  have  any  low  ones  that  I 
 can  demonstrate  for  you,  but  what 
 happens  is  the  growth  comes  from  the 
 middle  and  pushes  the  other  leaves  out. 
 So,  it'll  cause  this  leaf  in  the  future 
 to  kind  of  come  down  a  little  bit  more 
 than  you  may  want.  So,  all  you  do  is  you 
 take  and  you  put  your  foot  down  on  that 
 leaf,  take  a  bread  knife,  a  serrated 
 knife,  a  steak  knife,  or  a  garden  knife. 
 I  have  my  Horhi  garden  knife  that  I 
 love.  It's  super  sharp,  has  those 
 serrated  edges,  and  all  I  do  is  slice  it 
 as  close  to  the  trunk.  I'm  going  to  just 
 bend  down  here  and  that's  it.  It's  just 
 as  easy  as  that.  And  I  might  do  that 
 twice  a  year.  The  next  thing  you're 
 going to  do  are  the  fillers.  So,  you've 
 got  the  thrillers,  you've  got  the  tall 
 accents,  you  got  the  anchors,  but  you 
 don't  want  big  bushy  sanchchesia  or 
 copper  leaves  or  anything  that's  going 
 to  really  outgrow  that  space.  Unless 
 you're  a  weekend  warrior.  You  guys  are 
 out  there  and  you're  doing  it.  But  those 
 of  you  guys  who  don't  want  that  kind  of 
 work,  then  pick  mixes  of  ground  cover 
 and  low  shrub  material.  compact  shrub 
 material  along  this  back  wall.  We  get 
 great  sun  in  this  front  yard.  That  is 
 one  of the  things  that  we  do  have.  So, 
 we  could  bring  in  some  blooming  power. 
 So,  we've  got  a  clustering  of  Helen 
 Johnson  dwarf  buganilia.  Now,  those  of 
 you  guys  who  are  like,  "What?  Buggania? 
 They're  high  maintenance."  I  know.  I 
 feel  you.  They  are  high  maintenance.  But 
 dwarf  buganilia  can  be  and  love  to  be 
 kept  compact  and  small.  So,  every  couple 
 months  you  come  in  and  you  just  nip 
 these  together.  You  want  to  let  them 
 control  and  be  one  solid  grouping.  They 
 bloom  so  so  nicely  and  they  can  handle 
 that  direct  sun.  So  they  can  handle  any 
 kind  of  heat  off  the  pavers.  They  can 
 handle  tough  tough  places  and  we  kind  of 
 wanted  a  little  bit  of  pop  of  color  in 
 this  back  side.  So  that's  kind  of  where 
 we  started  with  the  Helen  Johnson 
 boogan.  They'll  get  3x3  so  they'll  be  a 
 nice  kind  of  backdrop  without  getting 
 too  tall  in  front  of  this  window.  It's 
 going  to  be  an  ideal  backdrop  for  my 
 client.  She  was  a  big  fan  of  that 
 coloration.  So  that's  the  direction  we 
 chose  to  go.  Now  we  get  to  this  plant 
 here,  this  tree  here.  Now  this  tree  of 
 course,  as  I  mentioned  earlier,  only 
 gets  five  to  six  inches  a  year.  So  what 
 I  couldn't  put  the  Helen  Johnson's  all 
 the  way  up  to  it  because  I  didn't  want 
 them  to  encroach  in  this  tree.  Now 
 you're  trying  to  keep  the  Helen 
 Johnson's  and  these  separated  to  be 
 happy  neighbors.  So  I  found  a  defining 
 line.  So  these  Indian  hawthorns  right 
 here,  they  curve  like  this,  kind  of  like 
 a  frame  around  the  European  fan  palm.  So 
 they  start  here,  curve  back,  and  then 
 kind  of  curve  forward.  These  guys  are 
 going  to  be  almost  like  a  border.  Like, 
 do  not  touch,  please.  They're  very 
 controlled,  very  confined.  Get  two  foot 
 tall.  Really  stay  nice  and  controlled. 
 You  can  let  them  get  three  if  you  like. 
 They're  very,  very  easy  to  work  with. 
 They  don't  grow  unless  you  say,  "Would 
 you  grow,  please?"  I  mean,  that's  really 
 how  they  work.  They're  such  a  slow 
 growing.  They  do  bloom  a  white  flower, 
 but  it's  really  the  texture  and  the  look 
 of  the  leaf  and  the  compactness  of  it 
 that  is  its  real  beauty.  So,  that's 
 where  this  defining  line  is  to  keep 
 everything  off  of  the  European  fan  palm. 
 This  is  where  it  gets  tricky.  So,  I  need 
 a  little  bit  of  height  on  the  corner  of 
 the  European  fan  palm  because  I  don't 
 want  this  all  to  be  one  level.  We've  got 
 the  three  foot  of  the  uh  buganilia  in 
 the  back  drops  down  to  the  twoft  around 
 guarding  the  European  fan  palm.  But 
 right  here,  I  didn't  want  a  whole  row  of 
 something  4  foot  or  anything  too  big. 
 So,  what  I  chose  is  a  dwarf  alamanda  and 
 only  three  of  them.  These  three  plants 
 right  here  will  become  one  bush.  That's 
 their  goal.  They're  going  to  meld 
 together  and  become  a  bouquet  of  just 
 dwarf  alamanda  right  here.  And  they're 
 going to  be  a  perfect  little  spot  of  2 
 and  1/2  three  foot  tall  right  here  in 
 this  little  mounding.  Then  it  drops  down 
 over  by  the  walkway  with  blue  my  minds 
 wrapping  the  opposite  direction.  Then  we 
 start  with  the  next  tier  which  is  a 
 backdrop  of  foxtail  ferns  as  you're 
 grouping.  Now  this  gives  a  different 
 kind  of  contrast.  We  go  from  leaf  color 
 to  very  vertical  kind  of  soft  flowy,  you 
 know,  look  of  the  foxtail  ferns,  which 
 you  guys  know  I  love.  Then  we  draw  back 
 in  with  a  sea  little  red  rubies.  This 
 time  of  the  year,  they're  more  purple. 
 During  the  summer  months,  they'll  have 
 more  of  a  a  burgundy  reddish  tone.  So, 
 both  colors  are  going  to  be  gorgeous  in 
 this  particular  sea  of  color  cuz  we've 
 got  the  yellow  and  the  chartreuse 
 coloring  of  this  leaf  foxtail  fern 
 completely  contrasting  texture.  And  then 
 we've  got  the  shiny  little  leaves  of  the 
 little  rubies.  And  then  to  kind  of  like 
 completely  go  crazy  and  contrast  a  whole 
 another  look,  we  have  a  similar  leaf 
 structure  as  the  little  rubies,  but  a 
 bright  tone  coloring  of  the  golden  dues 
 or  gold  mounds  right  here.  And  of 
 course,  they  just  do  enough,  a  little 
 swath  just  to  break  up  the  color.  And 
 then  finished  it  off  with  flora  boxwood 
 right  at  the  bottom.  These  are  just 
 almost  like  a  very  low  controlled  foot, 
 foot  foot  and  a  half  ground  cover  that 
 is  really  going  to  kind  of  keep  us 
 almost  like  a  a  defined  edge  border. 
 These  get  a  little  bit  taller.  These  get 
 a  little  bit  taller.  These  get  a  little 
 bit  taller.  And  then  it  drops  back  down. 
 So  you  can  really  see  it  from  both 
 sides,  from  the  road  and  from  people 
 coming  up  the  walkway.  You  kind  of  see 
 how  easy  that  is.  The  borders  are  going 
 to  be  very  easy  to  keep  clean.  You  can 
 see  I've  planted  things  in  groups  of 
 each  other.  Hot  pink  pentas.  Right  now 
 we've  got  five  here,  but  they're  going 
 to  be  one.  I  just  want  this  to  be  a 
 clustering  of  these.  No  space  in 
 between.  They're  going  to  connect  to 
 each  other,  become  one  solid  group  of  a 
 little  bit  of  height.  Then  it's  going  to 
 drop  over  here  to  the  golden  deuce  and 
 be  one  height  along  through  here.  This 
 is  formal.  This  is  soft.  This  is  soft  to 
 the  back.  This  is  formal.  You  kind  of 
 see  the  contrast.  If  you  can't  do  that 
 with  multi  level  of  heights,  you  can 
 definitely  do  it  with  textures  of  leaf 
 and  color  changes.  And  that's  kind  of 
 what  I  mean  about  a  lowmaintenance 
 garden.  It  doesn't  have  to  all  be  one 
 green  hedge,  one  green  hedge,  one  green 
 hedge,  or  just  a  row  of  croins  to  give 
 you  color.  It  can  be  this  variation 
 because  these  are  all  smaller,  compact 
 ground  covers  that  love  the  same 
 situation.  They're  more  in  the  drought 
 tolerant  family.  They're  tough.  They're 
 just  something  that  you  can  really  work 
 with  all  year  long  and  not  have  to  worry 
 or  fuss  too  much  with  them.  Everything 
 kind  of  has  its  own  place.  It  has  its 
 own  job  in  the  garden.  And  this  is  not 
 much  room.  This  is  a  small  pocket  of  a 
 front  yard.  And  I  feel  like  we  got  as 
 much  impact  as  we  possibly  could.  The 
 only  thing  that  if  you're  able  to  do  or 
 you  have  a  little  bit  more  room,  having 
 a  single  foxtail  in  this  particular  spot 
 right  here  would  have  been  a  beautiful 
 feature  to  incorporate  right  here 
 because  we  have  one  on  that  side  of  the 
 driveway  there.  It  would  have  been 
 lovely  to  have  one  on  each  side  of  the 
 driveway.  You  guys  know  how  I  love 
 framing  any  kind  of  project.  There's 
 always  going  to  be  some  makeshift. 
 There's  always  going  to  be  some  things 
 that  I'd  love  to  do  this,  but  it's  not 
 possible.  whether  it's  budget  or  it's 
 HOA  requirements  or  it's  county  easement 
 lines,  whatever  it  is,  you're  going  to 
 just  have  to  work  with  it  and  make  the 
 best  of  the  situation.  So,  that's  why 
 it's  really  good  to  have  a  good  plan  in 
 place  before  you  get  started.  I  hope 
 this  video  helps.  I'm  sorry  it's  such  a 
 short  video  today,  but  I  definitely 
 wanted  to  just  showcase  this  front  yard 
 garden  because  I  think  that  a  lot  of  us 
 are  struggling  with  some  of  the  same 
 problems.  Those  of  you  guys  know  that  we 
 have  a  book  out  we  are  very,  very 
 excited  about.  Please  check  it  out.  It 
 is  going  to  be  the  first  link  in  the 
 description  down  below.  It  is  on  Amazon. 
 It  is  a  book  that  Bryce  and  I  created

 So,  we  are  very  pleased  with  it.  Talks 
 about  the  toughest  of  toughest  tropical

 single  day  as  a  landscape  designer.  Some

 plants.  There  are  the  plants  that  I  use 
 to  pull  all  of  these  designs  that  you 
 guys  see  so  much  on  YouTube  together. 
 And  they're  companion  plants  that  grow 
 super  super  well  with  them.  So,  it  kind 
 of  gives  a  lot  of  information  about  them

 created  all  along  this  treasure  and 
 space  coast.  So,  thank  you  guys  so  much

 plantings  [music]  though,  our  book  is

 [music]  well.  Tough,  hearty  plants  of

 further  by  putting  combination  plant 
 groupings,  things  that  are  going  to  play 
 well  together.  So  that  way  you  guys  can

 plant  groupings  together."  So  you  kind

 over  a  period  of  time  and  grow 
 seamlessly  in  your  garden  with  as  little 
 care  as  possible  that  can  handle  our 
 tough  Florida  environment.  More  on  that 
 later.  I  will  put  it  in  the  description 
 down  below.  and  let's  [music]  get  this 
 party  started  and  uh  show  you  guys 
 around.  So,  starting  this  section  off, 
 the  biggest  issue  [music]  with  most 
 Florida  homes,  especially  ones  that  have 
 these  fantastic  pool  areas,  is  it  leaves 
 little  sideyard  slips  [music]  that  you 
 don't  really  know  what  to  do  with? 
 Should  you  just  put  a  row  of  palm  trees 
 in?  Should  you  just  put  some  ora  palms 
 in?  [music]  I  mean,  there's  just  so  many 
 different  options  that  you  can  do  and 
 you  kind  of  don't  maybe  want  to  be  fully 
 enclosed.  You  want  some  interest.  You 
 want  some  color.  You  want  some 
 character.  You  want  some  levels  and 
 layers.  That's  [music]  exactly  what  I 
 feel  we  accomplished  in  this  space.  So, 
 just  to  give  you  guys  kind  of  a  point  of 
 reference  on  [music]  the  size  that  we're 
 looking  at,  from  the  first  section  of 
 the  bed,  from  the  corner  of  the  house 
 here  to  the  end  of  the  bed  there  is  37 
 [music]  ft  long.  Normally  in  a  normal 
 backyard,  what  you'd  be  seeing  is  the 
 neighbor's  backyard  pool  area,  the 
 neighbor's  backyard  space,  where  they 
 entertain  and  where  you  entertain.  So, 
 of  course,  privacy  is  key  if  you  can 
 create  something  that  divides  those  two 
 areas  from  the  foundation  of  the  screen 
 area  here  out  to  the  property  line  is 
 exactly  10t.  Now,  although  we  had  10t  of 
 space  to  work  with,  if  you  guys  want  to 
 keep  your  neighbors  happy  and  you  don't 
 want  to  be  in  that  low  spot  of  your 
 yard,  you  kind  of  still  want  to  be  on 
 the  high  spot  for  your  rear  tier.  And 
 that's  exactly  what  happened.  The 
 further  back  we  got,  the  further  the 
 slant  started  to  get.  So,  we  chose  to 
 bring  it  up  2  foot  in.  So  this  whole  bed 
 space  from  here  to  the  end  of  the 
 [music]  bed  is  8t  deep,  which  is  a  good 
 amount  of  space  to  kind  of  maintain  to 
 the  backside.  This  way  you  can  maintain 
 from  the  rear  side  of  the  planting  bed 
 and  not  be  on  your  neighbor's  property. 
 And  that's  incredibly  helpful  to  keep 
 happy  neighbors.  We  chose  [music]  to 
 stay  within  that  8ft  guideline,  which 
 really  did  squish  things  up.  So  when 
 you're  breaking  down  how  many  layers  you 
 can  get  into  an  8-ft  [music]  space,  you 
 really  have  to  start  looking  at  your 
 ground  covers,  your  accents,  your  trees, 
 and  then  your  privacy  hedge.  So  you  have 
 to  make  sure  that  there's  going to  be 
 enough  room  to  do  that  so  you  can 
 allocate  [music]  enough  room  for  things 
 to  grow  in,  to  fill  out,  to  lush  out.  So 
 that's  exactly  what  we  did  here.  So,  as 
 you're  looking  at  your  space,  just  kind 
 of  imagine  with  me  if  you  have  a  very 
 similar  layout  as  this  and  it's  8  foot 
 long,  you're  going  to  want  to  make  sure 
 that  you're  leaving  enough  room  for  each 
 layer  to  really  fully  grow  in.  But  just 
 to  give  you  guys  an  example,  I  am  going 
 to  get  Bryce  in  front  of  this  camera. 
 I'm  going  to  walk  this  off  so  that  way 
 you  guys  get  it  really  sets  in  just  kind 
 of  exactly  how  these  layers  are  set  up 
 so  you  really  feel  comfortable  with  kind 
 of  doing  this  on  your  own.  So,  I'm  going 
 to  get  Bryce  right  out  of  his  comfort 
 zone,  away  from  the  rear  side  of  the 
 camera  to  in  front  of  the  camera. 
 >> Hey  guys,  don't  you  love  it  when  your 
 mom  ropes  you  into  things?  I'm  not  used

 give  you  my  best  shot  with  this.  Let  me 
 try  to  explain  this  the  best  way  I  can. 
 One  thing  that's  really  important  is  to 
 make  sure  that  you're  on  center  of  all 
 [music]  of  these  plants.  So,  going  off 
 the  screen  room,  you're  going  to  go  1T 
 [music]  to  the  middle  of  the  plant. 
 That's  your  ground  cover.  That's  one 
 layer  right  there.  That's  your  first 
 [music]  one.  Going  to  the  next  layer, 
 you're  going  one  foot,  two  feet  right 
 here.  That's  your  next  layer  of  the 
 croins  and  the  alamanda  right  here.  Next

 foxtail.  Going  to  one,  two  feet  right

 can  see  [music]  2  4  6  you're  at  three 
 layers.  The  final  layer  is  going  to  be 
 this  Kucia  hedge  right  here.  That's 
 going  to  be  one  2  feet.  So  now  you're  at 
 8  ft  of  space  and  then  you  have  another 
 2T  for  your  maintenance  path  back  here. 
 So,  we  like  to  say  that  they  can  range 
 from  two  to  three  feet  depending  on  the 
 layer,  especially  when  you're  in  a 
 condensed  space  right  here.  You're  going

 little  bit  more  than  you  normally  would. 
 Kusia  would  normally  want  around  3  ft  of 
 space,  but  when  you're  trying  to  fill  it
