 trimmed  up  to  about  2  ft  [music]  of 
 space  so  you  can  fit  your  bigger 
 material  like  your  foxtails.  And  then 
 your  gold  mound,  your  blue  my  mind 
 mines,  they  can  vary  from  that  1  to  2  ft 
 of  space  rather  than  that  big  three  it 
 normally  would  take  to  fill  that  space. 
 Hope  that  explains  it  pretty  well  for 
 you  guys.  And  let's  get  back  into  it. 
 >> So  in  this  particular  [music]  case, 
 because  of  what  we  had  to  work  with,  I 
 knew  that  we  could  do  four  layers  into 
 [music]  this  particular  spot.  And  then 
 now  it's  time  to  decide  what  layers  and 
 why.  So  we're  going  to  get  into  that 
 now.  Obviously,  we  have  [music]  the 
 Kucia.  That's  our  backdrop,  our  wall.  If 
 you're  not  a  Kucia  fan  and  maybe  your 
 space  is  even  tighter  than  this  and  you 
 need  to  keep  this  that  rear  wall  a  foot 
 wide,  you  might  be  better  off  going  with 
 something  like  podocarvis  [music] 
 that'll  kind  of  give  you  a  long  linear 
 type  of  look.  It  will  take  longer  to 
 grow  in  these  kucia  within  6  months  will 
 [music]  be  a  nice  solid  wall.  So  that's 
 so  great.  You'll  be  a  good  year  to  year 
 and  a  half  before  it  really  [music] 
 connects.  So  that's  kind  of  the  reason 
 why  I  lean  more  towards  the  the  Kucia. 
 is  also  going  to  not  only  give  you 
 privacy,  but  it's  going  to  let  what  we 
 chose  to  the  front  of  it  really  pop  with 
 color  because  anytime  you  put  a  green 
 screen  next  to  anything,  well,  you  guys 
 know  it  by  now  if  you  watch  this 
 channel,  it  brings  out  the  color  of 
 everything  else.  It  takes  it  and  really 
 just  kind  of  controls  your  environment, 
 creates  more  of  a  garden  setting,  more 
 of  a  courtyard  kind  of  feel.  And  that's 
 what  I  love  about  these  kind  of  walls  in 
 a  landscape.  So,  that's  why  it  was  one 
 of  the  most  important  things  to  get  in 
 at  a  good  size.  These  are  10gallon 
 Kucia.  They  came  in  about  4t  tall,  so 
 they're  really  starting  off  to  a  great 
 start.  Going  to  create  a  perfect  6-ft 
 wall  along  this  area.  And  then  the  next 
 thing  to  do  is  [music]  decide  on  your 
 trees.  What  trees  are  you  going  to  work 
 with?  Do  you  want  layers  of  big  and 
 [music]  tall  and  short  and  cool  trees? 
 Yes.  However,  when  you're  working  with  a 
 narrow  [music]  space,  you  have  to  make 
 sure  that  your  trees  not  only  vary  in 
 size,  but  won't  compete  with  each  other. 
 Because  I  can't  take  these  trees  like  I 
 did  in  my  very  own  house  where  my  buffer 
 was  [music]  16  to  18t  deep.  I  can't  take 
 them  and  put  my  taller  trees  back  here, 
 my  shorter  trees  here,  and  so  on  and 
 layer  like  this.  This  is  a  row.  All  of 
 these  [music]  trees  are  6t  off  of  the 
 screen  room  just  to  kind  of  keep  them 
 off  of  the  screen  room  to  keep  these 
 fronds  away.  So,  I  had  to  strategically 
 plan  on  what  trees  I  can  use,  where,  and 
 how.  King  Alexander  are  some  of  my 
 favorite  trees  to  work  with.  I  think 
 they're  an  ideal  beautiful  centerpiece. 
 Big  crown.  Nice  cool  sturdy  trunk.  Love 
 this  ringed  kind  of  cane  look  to  it. 
 Just  so  cool  and  green  and  a  very 
 substantial  tree  for  an  area.  I  think 
 it's  a  nice  dynamic  look.  And  so  I 
 started  it  with  the  King  Alexander.  Now 
 the  King  Alexander  growth  rate  grows 
 slower  than  the  tree  right  next  to 
 [music]  it.  However,  I  did  not  want  to 
 rely  solely  on  the  growth  rates  on 
 things.  So,  [music]  I  was  able  to  bring 
 this  tree  in  at  a  15t  size  where  the 
 King  Alexander  is  at  an  11  ft  size. 
 [music] 
 So,  if  that  is  you  guys,  no  matter  what 
 size  you're  working  with,  make  sure  that 
 whatever  tree  you're  starting  with  is 
 either  taller  or  shorter.  It  doesn't 
 matter.  Whatever  your  viewpoint  is, 
 [music]  make  sure  it  starts  out  at  a 
 different  height  as  the  neighboring 
 tree.  That  way  you  can  layer  [music] 
 this  way  up  and  down,  up  and  down 
 instead  of  having  to  layer  staggered 
 forward  because  you  just  don't  have  that 
 kind  of  room.  Right.  These  two  trees 
 right  here  are  about  9  ft  apart.  So 
 they're  about  9  ft  on  center  here  to 
 [music]  give  us  plenty  of  room.  So  that 
 way  they  cascade  but  they  don't 
 interfere  with  each  other.  And  because 
 the  levels  are  different,  they're  not 
 going  to  combine  like  this  or  clash. 
 They're  going  to  give  you  that  different 
 feel,  that  more  opening  kind  of  a  look 
 with  a  shorter  tree  and  a  taller  tree. 
 This  tree  will  grow  faster  than  this 
 tree.  So  that  way  there's  always  going 
 to  be  a  height  difference  no matter  how 
 many  [music]  years  down  the  road  this 
 goes.  And  that's  just  how  you  get  that 
 tropical  feel  where  you  get  that  trunk 
 on  trunk  kind  of  look  mixed  in  with  all 
 your  plant  groupings.  You  just  got  to 
 make  sure  that  you're  you're  really 
 allowing  for  proper  space  and  proper 
 height  so  things  don't  clash  so  things 
 really  kind  of  draw  you  in  like  this 
 when  you're  looking  through  the  garden. 
 And  that's  exactly  what  we  continued  on 
 right  over  here.  So  now  we  drop  down  to 
 the  pygmy  palm.  So,  I've  [music]  got  two 
 trees  on  either  side,  but  we  needed 
 still  coverage,  long-term  coverage.  So, 
 you  guys  know  how  I  feel  about  my 
 pygmies.  Beautiful  little  tree  in  the 
 beginning,  and  then  as  they  grow  into 
 their  full  maturity,  they're  the  perfect 
 [music] 
 blocking  tree  for  a  long-term  success 
 without  the  maintenance  of  having  to  do 
 a  hedge  of  any  [music]  kind.  So,  this  is 
 a  great  kind  of  little  focal  point,  and 
 it's  soft  little  frond.  We  go  up  from 
 the  15t  down  to  the  5  [music]  foot  of 
 the  piggy  palm.  This  is  a  triple  piggy 
 palm.  Right  next  to  it  is  another  King 
 Alexander  palm.  So  you  see  we  [music] 
 started  with  the  King  Alexander  double 
 foxtail  pygmy  eight  palm  back  up  [music] 
 to  the  King  Alexander  and  then  back  down 
 to  another  pygmy  eight  palm.  This  is 
 another  triple.  So  we've  dropped  it  back 
 down  again  only  to  go  back  right  back  up 
 again.  It's  like  a  roller  coaster  ride. 
 This  is  like  a  great  roller  coaster 
 ride.  I  just  love  that.  So,  [laughter] 
 we're  back  up  to  the  double  foxtail  yet 
 again.  And  then  we've  completely  brought 
 in  another  pygmy  right  anchoring  this 
 corner.  Now,  this  pygmy  when  it  matures 
 and  grows  in,  it's  going  to  completely 
 wrap  around  this  corner,  giving  them 
 that  really  soft  buffering  feel  because 
 I  didn't  want  them  to  see  the  end  of  the 
 Kucia  [music]  hedge,  the  end  of  the 
 wall.  I  wanted  to  soften  it,  to  curve 
 it,  to  kind  of  make  this  not  feel  so 
 tight  and  [music]  constricted.  So,  the 
 best  way  to  do  that  is  to  layer  your 
 plants  to  the  front  of  that  hedge.  You 
 don't  know  how  many  times  I've  [music] 
 had  clients  say,  "I  want  privacy,  but  I 
 don't  want  a  wall  or  I  don't  want  a 
 hedge."  And  I'm  like,  "Well,  [music] 
 okay.  So,  we  can  do,  you  know,  other 
 types  of  trees  for  that."  But  that 
 wasn't  the  look  either.  They  kind  of 
 wanted  the  clean  line  of  a  hedge,  but 
 not  feeling  like  it's  just  a  big  tall 
 wall.  This  is  how  you  do  that.  You  layer 
 to  the  front  of  it,  create  pockets, 
 [music]  create  grooves,  create  interest, 
 let  that  wall  do  its  job,  and  then  make 
 it  pretty.  Just  put  pretty  things  in 
 front  of  it.  So,  [laughter] 
 that's  the  that's  the  secret  to 
 landscape  [music]  designing.  Um,  so  now 
 we're  working  our  way  around  and  now 
 we've  chosen  a  different  tree  right 
 here.  This  is  a  regular  Alexander  about 
 12  and  1/2t  tall.  [music]  So,  this 
 Alexander  I  love  this  is  one  of  Bryce's

 [music]  plant.  This  is  a  no  fuss  plant. 
 It  loves  loves  loves.  It  can  handle 
 morning  midday  sun.  Try  to  keep  it  at

 kind  of  doing  this  [music]  to  give  it

 silver.  [music] 
 So  what  I  did  is  a  contrast  of  color.  So 
 this  could  be  anything.  Could  be  in  your 
 garden  a  falsab.  It  could  be  a  bird  of 
 paradise.  It  could  [music]  be  a  king 
 seo.  It  could  be  a  dune  palm.  Could  be 
 anything  that  draws  your  eye.  But  if  at 
 all  possible  and  you've  got  this  much 
 green,  this  much  yellow,  this  much  red, 
 why  not  do  silver?  [music] 
 Silver,  I  think,  is  a  gorgeous  touch, 
 especially  when  the  garden  is  a  little 
 shaded  because  it's  like  a  little 
 highlight,  a  little  pop  of  color,  a 
 little  pop  of  a  spotlight  in  the  garden. 
 And  that's  exactly  what  this  guy  is 
 going  to  do  is  create  that  spotlight 
 [music] 
 as  the  centerpiece.  So,  what  we  did  is 
 we  took  the  centerpiece  in  and  framed  it 
 with  the  two  pymedate  palms.  That  goes 
 for  both  sides  of  the  bed.  So,  that  way 
 we've  wrapped  it  around.  We've  got  our 
 thriller  in  the  middle,  foxtail  palm,

 don't know  if  they  call  it  the  spillers, 
 [music] 
 where  they  kind  of  come  around  and  kind 
 of  wrap  around.  And  then  we've  got  a 
 centerpiece  area  that  really  just  kind 
 of  crowns  out  and  draws  your  eyes.  That 
 doesn't  mean  you  can't  jazz  up  other 
 sections  of  the  garden.  Right  on  each 
 corner,  there's  not  a  lot  of  room  to  do 
 much  of  anything  else,  but  I  wanted 
 [music]  something  with  some  brightness, 
 something  with  a  contrast,  color,  and 
 height  that  the  rest  of  the  bed  doesn't 
 have.  So,  I  [music]  chose  to  bring  in 
 some  antiloo.  So  we  have  a  nice 
 collection  [music]  of  antiloo's  here. 
 Now  you  can  bring  in  a  15gallon  if  you 
 like  and  just  do  one  nice  [music] 
 cluster.  I  like  to  bring  in  some  nice 
 five  gallons  and  cluster  them  together

 This  will  get  8  foot  tall  right  here  and 
 really  kind  of  become  just  such  a  nice

 landscaping  that  it  draws  your  eye

 anchored  here  and  then  in  another  what  I

 we  have  three  clusters  of  what  I  would 
 consider  dead  areas.  Areas  that's  kind 
 of  hard  to  do  something  really  cool.  I 
 knew  that  this  was  going  to  be  a  tight 
 spot  because  the  walkway  is  right  here.

 silver  odor,  or  put  another  little 
 accent  or  an  agave  or  anything  here 
 because  it's  going to  be  right  in  the 
 way  of  the  walkway.  But  having  something 
 vertical  here  with  some  sanchchesia  and 
 gold  mound  around  them,  it  is  another 
 type  of  spotlight.  We  go  from  a  bright 
 spotlight  to  a  dark  contrasting  leaf 
 [music]  spotlight.  So,  these  key 
 clusters  are  really  going  to  allow  you

 eye  from  green,  green,  green  to  silver, 
 green,  green,  green  to  red  throughout 
 the  bed.  I  hope  that  comes  across.  I 
 hope  that  makes  sense.  [music]  All 
 right,  so  now  for  some  of  my  favorite 
 parts,  the  ground  covers,  the  shrub 
 material,  the  small  things  that  pull  it 
 all  together.  Now,  they  are  kind  of 
 [music]  the  unsung  heroes  of  the  garden. 
 All  of  this  other  fun  stuff  is 
 definitely  great.  Great  [music]  look, 
 great  energy,  really,  you  know,  takes 
 the  garden  to  another  level.  But  you 
 pull  it  all  together  with  the  edges, 
 with  the  borders,  with  the  small  stuff. 
 And  that's  what  we're  going  to  talk 
 about  here.  Right  behind  this  beautiful 
 cluster  of  antiloo,  I  [music]  put  in  two 
 sanchchesia.  Why  two?  Because  only  two 
 will  fit  there  and  grow  in  super  well

 [music]  these  two.  This  is  going  to  be  a 
 shaded  spot  between  these  two  areas 
 because  these  fishtail  palms  will  do 
 what  fishtail  palms  do.  We  chose  two 
 fishtail  pumps  for  this  particular  space 
 just  to  [music]  kind  of  help  soften  the 
 neighbors  back  patio  space.  It  really 
 does  a  good  job  of  giving  my  [music] 
 clients  a  pretty  instantaneous  privacy 
 buffer  and  then  as  it  matures,  it's 
 going  to  even  do  the  job  and  create  a 
 gorgeous  tropical  wall  right  here.  But 
 Sanchezia  are  going  to  do  a  great  job 
 when  these  guys  get  6  to  8t  tall.

 those  [music]  trunks,  giving  it  kind  of 
 a  a  really  cool  variegated  leaf  kind  of 
 look.  A  little  bit  wild,  a  little  bit 
 crazy.  And  I  could  have  continued  them 
 on  to  [music]  the  front,  but  s  cheesy 
 are  one  of  those  plants  that  don't  like

 little  loosey  goosey  and  kind  of  crazy. 
 So,  you  want  to  let  them  get  beefy.  You 
 want  to  let  them  spread  out.  They  like

 plant  groupings  and  be  lush  and 
 tropical.  Not  so  much  to  the  front. 
 [music]  To  the  front,  we  would  have  had 
 to  trim  them  so  much  that  they  were  not 
 attractive  from  the  screen  room.  So,

 cluster  of  them.  I  didn't  go  crazy.  I 
 just  have  a  little  bit  of  highlight  with 
 those  to  the  front.  [music]  The  next 
 plant  grouping  I  chose,  the  ground  cover 
 is  the  pentas,  the  dark  hot  pink  pentas, 
 because  if  you  got  yellow,  why  not  bring 
 in  the  pinks?  This  is  my  favorite 
 variety.  And  these  pentas  bloom  in  the 
 shade,  which  is  hard  to  [music]  find.  So 
 that's  why  I  chose  them  for  this 
 particular  spot.  I  didn't  use  something 
 that  really  is  going  to  need  a  lot  of

 stay  around  2  and  1/2,  3t  tall.  Now

 mounded  and  kept  small  for  buganilia. 
 They're  fabulous.  Put  them  in  an 
 environment  like  this.  They'll  [music]

 not  [music]  going to  be  gorgeous.

 color  if  any,  and  just  be  little  green

 going  to  offer  that  color. 
 >> [music] 
 >> So  definitely  work  with  your  space.  If

 pink  pentas,  these  guys  get  cut  back. 
 Usually  I  do  it  in  the  spring.  I'll  cut 
 them  really  low  down  to  the  ground  and 
 let  them  flush  out  with  all  new  growth 
 every  single  year.  Some  people  do  it 
 every  3  years,  and  if  that  works  for 
 you,  that's  perfectly  fine.  I  like  to  do 
 mine  once  a  year.  I'll  cut  it  all  the 
 way  back  down,  leave  about  this  much  of 
 it  left.  It  flushes  out  with  new  growth 
 every  year  and  and  just  comes  back 
 beautifully,  beautifully.  And  it  happens

 draws  your  eye  right  to  that  space. 
 [music]  It  instantly  gives  it  impact. 
 And  I  think  that's  what  these  trees  are 
 doing  for  us  right  here.  They're  about 
 14t  tall.  They  have  beautiful  trunk  base 
 to  them.  [music]  I  just  absolutely  love 
 them.  I  love  them  patterned  like  this  in 
 a  Vshape.  If  these  were  to  be  put  on  a 
 corner  area,  I  would  take  them  from  like 
 this  space  like  [music]  this  flat 
 against  the  road  to  a  corner  area  right 
 on  the  corner.  So,  just  kind  of  angle 
 them  versus  straight  [music]  on.  But  in 
 this  particular  format,  I  love  them 
 straight  on  as  a  nice  Vshape.  And  then 
 when  I  have  a  foxtail  palm  or  when  I 
 have  something  that  has  a  clean  trunk  to 
 it,  I  kind  of  plan  for  the  future. 
 That's  what  these  piggy  date  palms  are 
 doing.  So,  these  pygmy  palms  are  going 
 to  be  our  green  screen  behind  them.  You 
 don't  know  how  often  I  see  in  landscapes 
 where  I'll  see  a  tree  here  and  then  I'll 
 see  a  pigment  8  palm  in  front  of  it 
 because  it  makes  sense,  right?  It's  a 
 smaller  tree.  It  should  be  to  the  front. 
 However,  that  does  nothing  to  me.  It 
 kind  of  hides  the  whole  impact  of  the 
 space.  I  like  a  backdrop  of  something 
 soft  and  fluffy.  It  gives  you  kind  of  an 
 underplanting  kind  of  feel.  So  having  a 
 pygmy  8  palm  wrap  around  the  rear  side 
 of  it,  kind  of  nestle  it  in,  it  makes  it 
 so  where  this  tree  when  it  becomes  30 
 foot  tall,  this  tree  no  longer 
 disappears  because  this  tree,  which  is 
 going  to  be  9  to  10t  tall,  is  going  to 
 frame  and  wrap  all  the  way  around  it, 
 kind  [music]  of  giving  it  an  under 
 canopy  type  of  substance.  So  that's  kind 
 of  why  I  like  to  pair  these  two  together 
 in  this  particular  spot.  If  you're  going 
 to  do  a  foxtail  palm,  it's  ideal  to  do 
 it  about  7  to  8t  off  the  house.  This 
 tree  here  is  8t  off  of  the  house.  That 
 way  it  gives  you  plenty  of  room  to  kind 
 of  be  away  from  the  canopy  or  the  corner 
 pieces  [music]  of  the  roof  line.  And 
 with  the  pigmentate  palm,  four  to  five 
 foot  off  the  house  is  ideal  because 
 these  are  such  soft  fronds.  This  [music] 
 is  not  going  to  do  anything  to  hurt  the 
 walls.  You  kind  of  want  this  almost  to 
 soften  your  corner  area.  So  I  commonly 
 will  [music]  put  them  close  enough  to 
 the  house  and  they're  perfectly  fine. 
 They're  going  to  naturally  want  to  go 
 towards  the  sun.  [music]  So,  this  tree, 
 even  though  it's  positioned  right  here, 
 is  going  to  end  up  more  in  line  here  and 
 going  to  hug  this  tree  and  come  around 
 this  way  to  really  kind  of  give  us  that 
 that  folding  feel  that  we're  looking  for 
 in  the  landscape,  but  it's  going to  be 
 looking  for  the  sun.  So,  it's  really 
 going  to  give  you  kind  of  a  a  nice 
 [music]  softness  and  pull  away  from  the 
 house  line  even  more.  And  you'll  get  to 
 see  that  we  just  did  that  in  two  other 
 areas.  So,  this  palm  right  here  was  part 
 of  the  original  landscape.  It  was  just 
 far  [music]  too  close  to  the  house,  so 
 we  pulled  it  out.  Now,  because  the 
 corner  beds  are  not  the  front  beds,  we 
 had  more  room  to  work  with  here.  I 
 pulled  this  tree  out  [music]  and  then 
 pushed  this  pydate  palm,  which  was  part 
 of  the  original  builder's  package. 
 Relocated  it  back  here  and  shifted  it  to 
 the  right  of  the  tree  a  little  bit  just 
 to  kind  of  give  us  kind  of  more  of  an 
 anchor  feel  because  we  had  plenty  of 
 room  to  work  with  there.  And  I  did  the 
 exact  same  thing  on  the  opposite  side, 
 the  far  right.  And  I  love  how  each 
 corner  matches  itself  and  then  the  two 
 front  entrance  matches  itself.  So,  it 
 gives  it  kind  of  a  streamline  feel  and 
 then  it's  a  way  to  take  your  space  when 
 you're  on  the  far  corners  of  your 
 property  of  extending  it  out  as  far  as 
 absolutely  possible.  So,  if  you  could 
 take  and  wrap  those  [music]  trees  in 
 those  and  your  accents,  whatever  they 
 might  be,  further  out  on  the  corners  and 
 then  really  layer  down  from  there,  then 
 you're  going to  make  your  house  feel 
 like  you're  framing  it,  not  your  not 
 that  you're  hiding  it.  So,  [music] 
 you'll  notice  when  I  put  material  to  the 
 front  of  a  house,  it's  usually  tall, 
 linear,  long.  [music] 
 The  only  areas  that  I'm  trying  to  keep  a 
 little  bit  of  substance  or  thickness  is 
 just  kind  of  to  give  that  area  a  little 
 bit  of  a  backdrop,  but  other  than  that, 
 everything  near  the  house  [music]  is 
 kind  of  big  and  open.  One  design  element 
 that  I  really  want  to  make  sure  to 
 stress  [music]  to  get  across.  One  thing 
 that  I  use  on  every  single  project  is  I 
 definitely  definitely  work  with  the 
 layers.  As  you  guys  know,  I  love  the 
 strategy  of  having  frame  trees,  having 
 backdrop  trees,  but  bringing  in  the 
 depth.  To  me,  that  is  one  of  the  biggest 
 things  that  get  missed  on  your 
 traditional  builder's  package.  They'll 
 bring  in  big  trees  because  you  have  to 
 have  a  certain  amount  of  those,  right? 
 They'll  bring  in  um  some  rows  of  bushes 
 because  you  have  to  have  a  certain 
 amount  of  those,  but  nobody  calls  for 
 depth.  You  really  need  that  layered 
 feel.  You  need  your  larger,  your  stature 
 trees,  but  then  you  need  that  backdrop, 
 that  intermediate  mix,  those  layers  that 
 really  kind  of  add  a  little  bit,  just 
 kind  of  really  draw  your  eye  from  the 
 bottom  all  the  way  up  instead  of  from 
 the  bottom  to  [music]  the  top  and  then 
 you  lose  out  in  between.  And  because  we 
 don't  have  big  lots  here  in  Florida, 
 it's  hard  to  do  that  because  there's  not 
 a  lot  of  space.  So,  you  got  to  make  sure 
 that  you  really  hit  key  areas  to  do  that 
 in.  And  that's  kind  of  why  when  I'm 
 focusing  on  a  design,  that's  the  one  of 
 the  first  things  I'm  looking  for. 
 Obviously,  where  the  big  trees  are  going 
 to  go  next,  where's  the  depth  going  to 
 go  that's  not  going  to  cover  critical 
 areas.  You  don't  want  to  put  your  depths 
 right  in  front  of  that  that  doorway  or 
 right  in  front  of  that  main  window  that 
 you  want  to  see.  You  want  to  put  it  in 
 key  areas,  but  you  want  the  whole 
 landscape  to  come  together.  So,  I  feel 
 like  this  house  did  that  pretty  [music] 
 well.  I  feel  like  we  have  open  areas 
 where  we  need  them.  We  have  depth  where 
 we  need  them.  And  we  have  the  [music] 
 color,  the  impact,  the  layers,  you  know, 
 some  cool  accent  features.  We  have  all 
 those  things  [music]  where  you  need 
 them.  So,  I  felt  like  this  design  came 
 together.  Now,  this  is  a  really  young 
 design,  so  kind  of  keep  that  in  mind 
 [music]  as  it  matures.  It's  really  going 
 to  grow  into  seeing  those  drifts  and  big 
 groups  of  color  and  all  those  those 
 things  come  together  in  a  matter  of  six 
 to  eight  months.  That's  all  going  to 
 come  together.  But  I  want  to  show  you 
 guys  this  because  this  is  the  time  that 
 everybody's  out  in  their  garden 
 planting.  This  is  the  time  to  really  get 
 out  there  and  enjoy  it  in  Florida 
 because  the  next  few  months  are  going  to 
 be  gorgeous.  They're  going  to  be  perfect 
 to  be  outside  drawing  some  ideas,  kind 
 of  putting  this  together,  put  this  on 
 paper  for  your  own  particular  house.  And 
 hopefully  that'll  help  you.  And  then  if 
 you  need  more  than  that,  give  us  a  shout 
 because  we  would  love  to  help  you  with 
 your  own  design.  But  let's  jump  into 
 this  front  section  of  the  garden  and  how 
 I  created  the  depth  here.  And  then  we'll 
 work  into  the  next  section  of  the  bed 
 and  where  that  depth  lies  [music]  there. 
 In  this  particular  area,  we  have  several 
 different  varieties,  different  heights 
 of  trees.  And  that's  kind  of  what  where 
 your  eye  kind  of  rest  right  right  at  the 
 intermediate  trees,  that  5  to  6  ft 
 range.  So  if  you're  looking  at  this 
 space  here,  there  is  not  a  lot  of  room 
 here.  This  is  pretty  much  an  easement 
 just  past  this  5ft  mark  at  the  edge  of 
 this  bed.  So  we're  having  to  fit  a  lot 
 of  material  into  that  space  or  a  lot  of 
 impact  [music]  into  that  space.  So  we've 
 got,  you  know,  the  depth  here  with  the 
 pygmy  8  palm,  something  around  that  five 
 foot  range  right  here  of  height.  We 
 [music]  go  up  to  the  foxtail  palm.  So 
 you  can  see  we're  doing  this  with 
 different  heights  of  the  varieties  of 
 trees.  Then  it  drops  back  down  to  this 
 double  Christmas  palm, 
 then  back  [music]  down  to  this  pygmy  8 
 palm,  and  then  back  up  to  the  foxtail 
 palm.  [music]  Next  thing  it's  going  to 
 go  into  is  the  agave  in  that  list.  Then 
 it  goes  into  your  intermediate  bush 
 plantings  like  the  Croins  or  the 
 variegated  arbicas.  Then  it  goes  into 
 your  foxtail  ferns  for  the  lower.  Then 
 it  goes  into  your  ground  cover  like  the 
 blew  my  mind.  So  you  kind  of  see  that 
 you  take  those  levels  and  those  layers 
 from  your  smallest  plant  of  your  ground 
 cover  all  the  way  to  your  biggest 
 [music]  tree.  And  that's  that  waterfall 
 effect.  That's  what  when  it  comes 
 together  and  you're  like,  I  kind  of 
 don't  know  why  I  like  that  landscaping 
 over  maybe  that  landscaping,  but  it  just 
 works  because  that's  exactly  what  you 
 want  to  do.  You  want  to  layer  it  on  your 
 house.  hit  the  hot  spots  of  your  house, 
 but  bring  in  those  layers  to  give  you 
 that  height,  [music]  that  intermediate 
 depth,  that  lower  depth,  and  then  again 
 the  layering  effect  with  your  plants. 
 And  then  then  you're  golden. 
 All right,  so  next  we  are  working  on  the 
 accents.  [music]  Now  it's  time  for  the

 do  that  so  well.  Just  just  about

 layers  around  those  features.  So  right

 Mammy  Croins.  They  could  stay  that  size

 leave  them  just  like  this.  They  can  let

 I  do  with  this?"  So,  this  is  a  giant

 for  it.  So  this  whole  purpose  of  this  is

 feature  is  meant  to  do.  Now,  this  is 
 really  going  to  come  together  as  this 
 landscape  grows  in.  It's  very  young,  but 
 you  guys  [music]  can  see  the  potential. 
 You  can  see  the  possibility  of  how  cool 
 this  is  going  to  be.  We  took  this 
 boulder,  we  angled  it  up.  So,  all  you  do

 earth.  Like,  it's  really  just  naturally

 whatever  plants  of  choice.  You  guys  know 
 I  love  the  foxtail  ferns  when  it  comes 
 to  boulders.  I  love  the  blue  flame  agave

 agave.  I  just  think  they're  so  cool.

 thornless.  These  guys  have  a  little

 almost  like  a  succulent  type  of  feel. 
 Those  [music]  have  absolutely  no  thorns. 
 Easy  to  work  with.  And  when  they 
 reproduce,  they  like  crown  out.  They 
 rotta  out  a  lot  like  a  succulent  does,

 wait  to  see  it  all  [music]  come 
 together.  I  can't  wait  to  see  it  in  a 
 good  year.  It's  really  going  to  have  a 
 lot  of  different  levels  for  the  amount 
 of  space  that  we're  working  with.  So  you 
 [music]  guys  get  it.  You  get  the  point 
 on  this  side  of  the  garden.  Now,  this 
 side  over  here,  because  it's  laid  out 
 differently,  I  wanted  this  to  have  a 
 different  [music]  type  of  feel.  It 
 doesn't  need  as  much  impact  as  that  side 
 did  because  we  don't  have  any  blank 
 walls  that  we're  looking  with.  We  don't 
 have  a  flat  surface  that  we're  working 
 on.  We  have  an  elongated  area.  We  have 
 where  the  driveway  goes  up,  squares 
 [music]  off  right  here.  It's  a  whole 
 different  feel,  whole  different  look. 
 So,  we  started  out  with  a  familiar  feel 
 as  what  we  have  over  there  to  this  front 
 because  they're  going  to  match  when 
 you're  looking  from  the  road.  They're 
 going  to  give  you  the  same  type  of  look. 
 you  kind  of  want  that  to  continue.  And 
 then  all  we  did  was  we  kept  the  same 
 color  palette  as  we  moved  to  the  back. 
 So  we  had  the  same  yellows,  the  same 
 reds,  the  same  blues,  but  it  is  a 
 different  plant  grouping  all  together 
 because  it  is  a  different  space  there. 
 And  when  you're  doing  your  planting, 
 just  kind  of  keep  this  in  mind.  It's  not 
 always  just  about  the  texture  changes  or 
 the  leaf  changes.  It's  about  the  color. 
 You  want  to  go  dark,  [music]  light, 
 dark.  Replicate  that.  You'll  notice  that 
 I  do  that  through  all  of  my  landscapes. 
 Everything's  all  grown  in  together. 
 There's  no  space  in  between.  The  mulch 
 is  fully  covered.  That  dark  [music] 
 light  dark  light,  that's  like,  wow,  that 
 I  just  I  don't  know.  It  feels  like  we 
 have  a  lot  of  color  there.  But  in 
 reality,  you  only  have  a  handful  of 
 colors.  It's  [music]  just  because  the 
 contrast  is  so  sharp.  And  where  there's 
 not  a  sharp  contrast,  there's  a  sharp 
 leaf  contrast.  A  sharp  type  of  where 
 this  is  a  fuzzy  leaf  or  this  is  an 
 upright  leaf  where  this  is  a  rounded  or 
 shiny  leaf.  If  you  can  do  that,  that'll 
 take  you  from  your  basic  landscape  to 
 more  of  your  complexity  to  more  of  that, 
 wow,  that  that's  that  was  designed  by  a 
 true  designer.  That  was  really  well 
 done.  And  that's  kind  of  what  I  hope  to 
 get  across  in  these  videos.  There  is  a 
 rhyme  and  a  reason  to  this  type  of 
 landscaping.  So,  if  you're  researching, 
 [music]  which  you  guys  are,  cuz  that's 
 why  you're  watching.  If  you're  gardeners 
 and  you  enjoy  this  kind  of  content,  then 
 you're  you're  learning  as  you  go,  which 
 is  awesome.  If  you  follow  kind  of  just 
 these  guidelines,  these  steps,  then  just 
 replicate  those  steps  [music]  and  you're

 probably  because  some  of  those  steps  got

 [music]

 double  foxtail  palm  here  with  a  pygmy

 see  that  [music]  often  where  they're  not

 kind  of  want  to  visually  make  sure  that 
 your  landscaping  [music]

 particular  area.  You  guys  will  have  to

 small  little  section  over  here.  Now, 
 this  was  was  a  little  bit  of  a  tough 
 one.  This  is  an  easy  area,  you  guys,  to 
 over  [music]  landscape.  I  see  it  all  the 
 time.  There'll  be  three  or  four  tiers 
 here  and  it'll  go  to  town.  I  have 
 [music]  been  guilty  of  that  myself 
 because  I  have  a  hard  time.  If  there's 
 room,  plant  it.  That's  kind  of  my  my  my 
 thought  process  on  things,  but  that's 
 not  always  the  case.  Sometimes  you  got

 [music]  it  and  then  let  this  be  an  easy 
 care  situation  because  that's  exactly 
 what  this  will  turn  into.  This  was  their 
 trouble  problem  from  the  beginning.  You 
 can  probably  tell  why  because  I  can 
 barely  see  [music]  because  I'm  standing 
 right  in  the  sun.  This  is  full  sun 
 morning  to  night.  This  area  gets  crazy 
 sun,  crazy  hot.  You  get  the  heat  from 
 the  wall,  you  get  the  heat  from  the 
 papers.  It  bounces  into  this  area  and 
 there's  very  little  soil  in  this 
 planting  bed.  So,  it's  like  fries.  So, 
 one  of  the  things  that  I  love  to  work 
 with  in  these  areas  is  either  like  a 
 foxtail  fur,  a  carissa  boxwood,  or  if  we 
 need  something  more  dressy,  a  little  bit 
 more  color,  the  dwarf  alamandas.  They 
 get  bushy.  They  get  3x3.  So,  they  go  out 
 this  way  and  come  up  to  3t  tall.  You  do 
 have  to  leave  room  for  them  to  do  that. 
 And  that's  exactly  why  we  have  nothing 
 else  in  this  bed.  They'll  bush  out  and 
 become  just  a  nice  clustering  of  yellow 
 and  greens  right  here.  These  bloom  10 
 months  out  of  the  year,  so  you  get  tons 
 and  tons  of  that  tulipy  [music]  kind  of 
 color.  Great  little  plant.  And  they 
 don't  get  the  legggininess  that  you  have 
 to  worry  about  with  the  regular 
 alamandas.  If  I  put  the  regular 
 alamandas  here,  they  would  get  a  little 
 bit  taller.  However,  you'd  have  to  put  a 
 skirt  at  the  [music]  bottom.  And  I  just 
 didn't  feel  like  there  was  enough  room 
 for  both  of  these  in  this  particular 
 environment.  [music] 
 I  did  have  a  little  bit  more  room  in  the 
 opposite  side.  So,  I  did  do  that  here

 width  here.  I  was  able  to  put  Cararissa

 was  tough,  had  a  strong  [music]  root 
 base  that  could  really  handle  this  type

 bright  yellow  tones  of  the  flowers

 compliment,  a  nice  a  [music]  nice  bit  of

 be  a  nice  lowmaintenance  area  for  them

 setbacks.  We  have  two  blueberry  trees 
 really  fit  in  this  spot  nicely. 
 Blueberry  trees,  for  those  of  you  guys 
 who  are  not  familiar  with  them,  can  stay 
 this  size  forever.  You  can  keep  them 
 this  height  by  just  trimming  these  tops 
 off  and  then  kind  of  just  softly  pruning 
 along  this  side  as  needed.  You  can  let 
 them  get  six  to  eight  foot  tall.  I've 
 seen  them  25  foot  tall  or  you  can  keep 
 them  six  foot  tall  forever  and  ever  and 
 ever.  They're  a  great  choice  if  you  guys 
 have  just  that  perfect  little  nook  that 
 you're  trying  to  frame  the  architecture 
 of  a  house.  I  think  they  do  a  nice  job 
 of  insetting  and  they  just  [music]  don't 
 get  too  crazy  on  you.  All right,  you

 All  right,  you  guys.  We  are  going  native 
 today.  Well,  native  and  Florida 
 friendly.  So,  today's  garden  tour  is  in 
 Melbourne,  Florida.  This  is  a  70% 
 allnative  garden  and  the  remaining  is 
 Florida  friendly.  This  is  an  HOA 
 requirement  for  this  particular 
 community.  So,  it  really  put  me  to  the 
 test,  but  more  importantly,  it's  going 
 to  answer  that  question.  Can  native 
 plants,  can  a  native  entire  yard  really 
 look  beautiful  long  term?  I  get  this 
 question  often.  and  why  don't  you  use 
 more  native  material  within  your 
 gardens?  And  I  do  some.  However,  in  most 
 cases  of  my  professional  landscape 
 career,  native  material  has  a  tendency 
 to  really  get  overrun.  And  a  lot  of  my 
 designs  are  full  and  lush.  So, 
 incorporating  something  like  that  can  be 
 a  little  bit  challenging,  but  life 
 happens.  And  in  this  particular 
 community,  they  were  like,  hey,  it's  got 
 to  be  done.  So,  my  particular  clients 
 that  I'm  working  with  on  this  project,  I 
 worked  with  them  on  a  previous  project 
 of  their  home,  and  they  like  very  clean 
 lines.  Very  tropical,  lush,  but  clean 
 lines.  So,  I  am  really  happy  with  how 
 this  has  turned  out.  Let's  start  off 
 with  the  island  directly  behind  me.  We 
 really  wanted  to  anchor  this  large  house 
 with  some  big  trees.  Now,  these  right 
 here  are  Florida  royals,  and  I  think 
 they're  absolutely  stunning  for  this 
 front.  They're  really  going  to  give  us 
 that  kind  of  height  quickly.  And  of 
 course,  as  you  guys  know,  they  grow 
 quite  tall  up  into  that  40  foot  range. 
 So,  they're  really  going  to  take  off  and 
 kind  of  really  frame  the  corners  of 
 this,  you  know,  quite  large  house.  So, 
 if  you  have  a  twotory,  royal  palms  are 
 ideal.  If  you  have  a  single  story  and 
 it's  kind  of  on  the  smaller  side,  I  tend 
 to  go  more  with  foxtails  or  King 
 Alexander  or  regular  Alexanders  for 
 that.  But  because  we  had  so  much 
 grandness  with  this  particular  house  and 
 all  of  this  PA  and  hardscape,  Florida 
 royals  were  ideal  because  they're  really 
 going  to  be  able  to  handle  that  cold 
 temper  just  a  little  bit  better.  this 
 little  guy  right  here,  which  I  think  is 
 super  cute,  super  compact.  This  is  an 
 aricuri  palm.  So,  it  is  a  Florida 
 friendly  palm.  Very,  very  drought 
 tolerant,  very,  very  tough  for  a  little 
 tree  and  maxes  out  around  15  to  16t 
 tall.  So,  it  doesn't  get  quite  large. 
 This  is  always  going  to  be  a  nice 
 understory  tree.  As  you  walk  your  way  up 
 to  the  landscape,  it's  going  to  be  a 
 nice  intermediate  kind  of  feel  with  its 
 kind  of  cascading  umbrella  feel.  So,  I 
 think  that's  really  cool.  But  as  for 
 some  of  the  smaller  native  plants  in 
 this  little  bed,  we've  got  right  from 
 this  beginning  here,  these  have  become  a 
 fan  favorite  for  me  just  because  of  this 
 gorgeous  white  flower  on  it.  These  are 
 viburnum.  They're  called  Mrs.  Schillers. 
 They're  the  dwarf  variety  and  they  offer 
 this  real  compact  shape.  And  what's 
 great  about  these,  if  you  don't  get  in 
 here  to  trim  heavily,  that's  okay 
 because  these  guys  stay  small,  they  stay 
 compact,  really,  really  easy  to  care 
 for.  And  I  like  anything  that  stays 
 chunky  and  where  you  put  it  for  any 
 period  of  time  without  you  having  to  do 
 that  for  it.  So  I  think  they're  ideal. 
 I've  really  used  them  as  a  great  framing 
 tool.  So  I've  used  them  as  my  kind  of  my 
 border.  They're  going  to  be  a  dark  green 
 border.  They  bloom  all  spring,  all 
 summer,  and  it  looks  like  pretty  much 
 into  fall  depending  on  your  area  of 
 Florida  that  you're  in.  But  they  can 
 handle  temps  well  below  freezing.  They 
 can  go  all  the  way  to  that  Jacksonville 
 area.  So,  those  of  you  guys  who  are 
 looking  for  a  nice  clean  native  compact 
 group  planting,  these  are  going  to  be 
 ideal.  Coming  in  about  this  size,  really 
 chunking  out  to  about  this  size  and 
 becoming  a  nice  swath  of  a  very 
 controlled  almost  like  a  a  natural  soft 
 boxwood  type  of  look.  I've  got  a  break 
 with  the  boulder  and  then  I  have  them 
 kind  of  curving  up  into  the  bed  there. 
 So,  we  keep  that  kind  of  dark  line.  And 
 you'll  notice  anywhere  I  put  a  dark 
 line,  if  I  can't  do  something  bright,  I 
 find  something  with  a  little  bit  of 
 color.  So,  these  are  native  purse  lanes. 
 They're  the  pink  variety,  and  they're 
 going  to  kind  of  give  us  a  break  in  this 
 darkness  here,  kind  of  framing  this 
 boulder  and  giving  us  a  little  bit  of 
 interest.  And  then  we've  continued  on 
 with  the  Mrs.  Schiller's  viburnum  right 
 here, 
 which  you  guys  are  probably  quickly 
 guessing  is  one  of my  new  favorite 
 accents.  This  is  the  yucka  restrada.  It 
 is  a  Florida  friendly  plant.  Beautiful 
 drought  tolerant  accent.  can  handle 
 those  cold  temperatures  all  the  way  up 
 north  into  Jacksonville.  This  little 
 tree  can  do  really,  really  well.  Once  it 
 matures  out,  it  grows  into  a  really  cool 
 stem.  This  is  perfect  if  you  guys  want 
 to  keep  it  something  really  interesting 
 and  uniformed  in  a  pot.  I've  had  designs 
 where  I  have  a  long  narrow  space  and  a 
 client  wants  something  pretty  dynamic  on 
 a  wall  and  I  put  these  tall  tubular  pots 
 and  framing  them  with  three  of  these 
 kind  of  coming  up  the  walkway. 
 absolutely  gorgeous  because  it's  very 
 easy  to  get  these  to  match  one  another 
 where  other  agaveies  it  can  be  really 
 hard  to  get  them  to  grow  in  a  pattern. 
 So  these  guys  are  just  a  great  punch  of 
 color.  I  love  their  silver  tone  to  them. 
 Just  kind  of  looks  really  really  unique 
 and  I  think  it's  going  to  fit  in  so 
 well.  I  have  one  on  this  side  of  the 
 driveway  and  we'll  get  to  that  in  a 
 minute,  but  I  have  one  on  the  opposite 
 side  of  the  driveway.  So  it  looks  like 
 as  these  guys  grow  in  together  they'll 
 frame  each  end  of  the  driveway  really 
 really  nice.  To  the  back  I  have  some 
 Wuigilia  or  daisy  carpet  flowers.  These 
 are  very  aggressive  growers.  They're 
 going  to  really  kind  of  give  us  a  swath 
 of  about  a  foot  and  a  half  to  two  foot 
 of  ground  cover.  Beautiful  coloring. 
 These  bloom  that  yellow  daisy  like  look. 
 Really,  really  tough.  Can  handle.  If  you 
 guys  have  rabbit  problems,  the  rabbits 
 tend  to  leave  these  guys  alone.  They're 
 really  a  perfect  ground  cover.  They  do 
 need  room  to  spread.  So,  I  wouldn't  put 
 like  two  and  then  a  bunch  of  plants  near 
 them  and  then,  you  know,  two  and  a  bunch 
 of  plants  near  them.  I  would  give  them 
 their  own  space.  So  I  usually  create 
 like  a  little  swath  with  those.  I  want 
 them  to  be  a  backdrop  of  yellow  here, 
 pink  up  here,  and  then  framing  the  sides 
 over  here  with  the  greens.  So  that  way 
 we  have  a  really  good  sandwich  effect  of 
 like  a  pop  of  color  when  everything 
 matures  and  grows  slowly.  I  think  I 
 mentioned  you  guys  that  this  is  a  very 
 young  landscape.  We  literally  just 
 finished  yesterday.  Back  here  is  a 
 native  silver  buttonwood.  And  you'll 
 notice  that  anytime  I  bring  in  one 
 silver  thing,  especially  if  I  have  a  lot 
 of  greens,  silver  can  be  a  color  that 
 can  really  contrast  against  those 
 greens.  We're  doing  greens,  reds, 
 silvers,  and  yellows  because  it  really 
 just  kind  of  blends  in  so  nicely  with 
 lights  and  darks.  So,  this  is  going  to 
 kind  of  create  a  hedge  along  this  curved 
 walkway  path  here.  Really  giving  us  a 
 bright  spot.  As  when  you're  looking  from 
 the  road,  you  get  the  reds  of  the  dwarf 
 exoras  and  the  dark  greens  and  white 
 tones  of  the  Mrs.  Shillers,  viburnum, 
 and  then  it  and  of  course  the  yellows 
 and  the  pinks.  I  think  it's  just  all 
 going  to  really  really  come  together 
 really  nice.  So,  this  is  going  to  be  a 
 fantastic  little  grouping  for  some 
 pollinators,  especially  when  you 
 consider  these  dwarf  little  psycho 
 coffee  plants.  So,  these  are  more  the 
 compact  version.  A  lot  of  times  you'll 
 see  this  variety  big  and  wild  and  crazy. 
 Those  bloom  a  beautiful  big  cherry  kind 
 of  berry.  This  is  one  of  my  favorites 
 because  this  can  stay  compact.  It  can 
 stay  lush.  It  can  stay  thick.  And  I  tend 
 to  use  this  underneath  a  tree  planting 
 just  like  you  see  here.  They  do  need  a 
 little  protection  from  the  sun.  However, 
 when  they're  in  this  grouping,  they're 
 just  going  to  fluff  out  like  this  and 
 like  this  and  become  a  nice  4ft 
 backdrop,  almost  like  a  circular  light 
 coloration  of  green.  And  we've  got  the 
 dark  greens  here  that  are  going to  be 
 real  dark.  We've  got  a  little  bit  of 
 that  chartreuse  green  in  these  guys.  And 
 then  of  course  we  have  the  dark  green 
 and  orange  to  the  front  of  the  dwarf 
 exoris.  So  that's  going  to  be  the 
 framework  for  our  silver  bismark  as 
 everything  really  grows  in.  So  I  hope 
 that  comes  together.  And  you  guys  will 
 notice  when  I'm  kind  of  creating  these 
 plans  to  put  them  together,  anytime  that 
 I'm  working  with  a  tall  grouping  of  palm 
 trees,  I  really  want  to  make  sure  to 
 stagger  them.  Look,  we  have  like  a 
 triangular  formation  of  these  royals 
 here.  And  then  of  course  it  leaves  us 
 open  for  a  centerpiece.  So  this 
 centerpiece  can  be  a  blooming  tree.  This 
 can  be  a  statement  palm.  It  can  be 
 anything  along  those  lines.  My  client 
 had  a  beautiful  large  bismar  in  his 
 backyard  from  his  previous  house  that  we 
 did.  And  so  he  wanted  to  replicate  that 
 with  another  bismar  but  in  the  front 
 yard  this  time.  So  we  found  the  perfect 
 spot  for  a  bismar  as  the  centerpiece 
 amongst  these  royals.  You  do  want  to 
 make  sure  though  if  you're  going  to 
 choose  a  bismar,  you  don't  want  your 
 larger  trees  to  be  something  like  King 
 Alexander's  or  something  that's  going  to 
 stop  growing  at  a  small  rate  because 
 these  royal  palms  get  so  big.  It  really 
 opened  up  the  gate  to  whatever  kind  of 
 centerpiece  tree  that  I  wanted  to  use. 
 This  tree  can  get  30  foot  tall  and 
 always  still  the  be  the  understory  tree 
 to  these  big  palms.  If  you  want 
 something  that's  going  to  be  like  a 
 bottle  brush  or  something  that's  going 
 to  only  grow  to  10  to  12  foot,  then  you 
 could  use  King  Alexander  as  your  frame 
 trees  or  foxtail  palms  or  anything  along 
 those  lines  because  you  don't  have  to 
 worry  about  that  kind  of  height 
 competing  with  each  other.  This  will 
 always  be  a  layered  effect.  These  guys 
 will  get  tall.  This  will  get  less  tall 
 and  that  little  guy  up  front  there  will 
 get  less  tall  lesser  lesser  tall.  So  So 
 it  becomes  kind  of  that  that  waterfall 
 pattern  that  you're  looking  for.  Over 
 here  we  have  a  nice  kind  of  small 
 planting  bed,  but  still  a  little  bit  of 
 power  going  on  here.  We're  working  with 
 silvers.  We're  working  with  natives.  And

 wish  you  guys  can  feel  it's  like  a

 You  can  keep  it  sheared  almost  like  a

 are  Japanese  blueberries.  They're  not 
 edible  blueberries.  This  is  a  Florida 
 friendly  plant,  not  necessarily  a 
 native,  but  it  is  great  for  the  birds. 
 They  nest  in  here  commonly.  Half  the 
 time  when  I'm  picking  them  up  from  the 
 nursery,  they  have  an  old  nest  in  there. 
 So,  they  nest  in  these  guys  quite  early, 
 but  they  become  such  a  cool  look.  They 
 get  a  little  bit  of  red  tips  to  the  end

 do  like  about  them  is  you  can  keep  them 
 this  size  forever  for  their  whole 
 lifespan  if  that's  what  you  choose.  You 
 can  keep  them  whatever  size  that  really 
 fits  your  space.  So,  if  your  walls  a 
 little  bit  shorter,  a  lot  of  us  have 
 these  little  nooks  on  the  insets  near 
 our  front  doors.  If  you  got  that  going

 vertical.  They  can  handle  our  heat.  They 
 can  handle  our  cold.  What  they  don't 
 like  is  full  shade.  So,  anything  besides 
 full  shade,  they  can  handle  sun,  partial 
 sun,  baking  right  off  of  the  concrete. 
 They're  champs.  So,  Japanese  blueberry

 I  know  the  edging  doesn't  show  up  great 
 without  grass  in  it.  But  this  beauty 
 edging,  I  feel  like  it  fits  in  so  well 
 with  this  house.  This  is  the  first  time 
 I've  used  the  charcoal  other  than  a  spot 
 in  my  own  garden  where  I  had  the 
 charcoal  as  kind  of  like  a  test.  I 
 wanted  to  see  how  it  looked.  I  love  the 
 way  it  looks  with  all  the  black  and  dark 
 trim  that  the  house  has.  I  think  it  ties 
 in  so  perfectly.  And  then  the  dark  kind 
 of  trim  that  they  have  on  the  pavers 
 really  kind  of  comes  together.  And  then 
 I  know  that  it's  going  to  do  what  it 
 needs  to  do.  These  mowers  in  this 
 community  are  like  all  other  mowers 
 where  they  come  in  quickly,  run  through, 
 weed  eaters  hit  these  guys.  So,  I  know 
 that  not  only  is  my  landscaping  going  to 
 be  sustainable,  but  this  beauty  edging 
 is  going  to  hold  up  to  that  kind  of 
 traffic  that  those  big  tires  running 
 over  top  of  it,  those  weed  eaters 
 slapping  and  hitting  it,  and  this  is  not 
 going  to  scuff  at  all.  This  is  going to 
 be  a  perfect  nice  little  edge  line.  Says 
 that  you  do  not  have  to  dig  these  in  at 
 all,  and  you  don't.  You  can  literally 
 set  the  edging  on  top  of  the  grass  and 
 hammer  the  nail  in  and  it's  perfectly 
 fine.  It's  perfectly  stable  at  that 
 point.  I  like  personally  the  way  it 
 looks.  If  you  can  take  a  little  bit  of  a 
 a  shovel  and  dig  a  couple  inches  out,  it 
 doesn't  have  to  be  anything  major,  but  a 
 couple  inches  out.  The  best  shovel  to 
 use  for  that  is  a  sprinkler  shovel  cuz 
 it's  long  and  narrow.  And  you  can 
 literally  after  your  line  is  drawn,  you 
 can  just  go  through  and  dig  2  in  out, 
 set  this  edging  in,  and  voila,  it  looks 
 like  it's  inset  into  the  ground.  I  even 
 do  that  with  my  boulders.  I  inset  the 
 edges  of  my  boulders  into  the  ground 
 because  I  like  that  look.  It  doesn't 
 look  like  something  set  on  top  of 
 anything.  I  like  that  everything  to  be 
 inset  and  really  have  a  place  in  the 
 gardens.  Just  a  little bit  of  tidbit  on 
 that.  Let's  continue  on  with  the  tour. 
 These  back  here  are  native  fire  bush. 
 Now,  a  lot  of  my  videos  showcase  regular 
 dwarf  fire  bush.  They  will  get  big,  but 
 you  can  keep  them  smaller.  These  guys 
 have  a  mind  of  their  own.  They  are  not 
 going  to  stay  the  size  that  you  want 
 them  to  stay  just  because  you  know  you 
 want  them  to  stay  there.  These  guys  are 
 going  to  naturally  get  six  to  seven  foot 
 tall  as  this  backdrop.  Now,  my  clients 
 are  aware  of  this.  This  is the  main 
 reason  why  I  don't  always  use  the  native 
 variety.  However,  if  you're  going  to  use 
 it,  use  it  as  the  wall  of  your 
 landscape.  Use  it  as  the  backdrop.  So, 
 we  have  got  in  this  bed,  we've  got 
 yellow  blooming  flowers.  We've  got 
 yellow  golden  dew.  We've  got  the  dark 
 coloring  of  the  chartreuse  coffee 
 plants.  We've  got  the  dwarf  exoras  to 
 the  front.  That's  all  beautiful  right 
 now.  But  once  we  can  hem  this  in  where 
 everything's  grown  in  together,  these 
 are  going  to  be  a  wall  of  these 
 beautiful  blooms  that  bloom  almost  all 
 year  long  because  they're  native.  You're 
 going  to  have  this  gorgeous  backdrop  of 
 a  6ft  wall  of  this  kind  of  coloring 
 that's  going  to  really  kind  of  bring  all 
 of  those  colors  out  in  the  front.  So,  if 
 you  have  to  use  these  guys  somewhere  or 
 you  want  to  use  these  guys  somewhere 
 because  they  really  bring  in  the 
 hummingbirds.  They  really  bring  in  all 
 the  birds.  If  you're  wanting 
 butterflies,  these  guys  are  going  to  be 
 your  go-to.  Just  make  sure  that  they're 
 not  in  the  front  of  your  garden.  They're 
 in  an  area  that  you're  prepared  for  them 
 to  get  bushy  and  full  and  tall.  So, 
 let's  move  on  to  the  side  here.  There 
 was  some  challenges  with  this  particular 
 side.  Those  of  you  guys  who  are  live  in 
 close  neighborhoods,  you're  probably 
 facing  some  of  those  same  challenges, 
 which  is  property  in  this  particular 
 house.  Even  though  that  it  feels  like 
 this  yard  has  some  expanse  to  it,  it  has 
 some  size  to  it.  We  had  restrictions  of 
 staying  10t  off  of  the  property  line 
 along  the  side  of  the  yard.  Really 
 really  had  to  be  cautious  about  really 
 spreading  gardens  out.  I  really  do  like 
 to  create  big  wavy  gardens.  That  way, 
 you  know,  you  can  really  kind  of  allow 
 things  to  fill  out.  You  have  plenty  of 
 room  for  it.  But  in  this  particular 
 garden,  every  part  of  it  was  compact. 
 However,  I  know  my  clients,  which  are 
 are  also  my  friends,  they  want  big 
 impacts.  It  was  a  challenge  to  make  sure 
 that  we  had  both.  So,  if  you  guys  are  in 
 that  boat,  then  you  know  what  HOAs  how 
 they  can  restrict  you.  So,  we  really  had 
 to  tighten  some  things  up  and  really 
 push  some  things  close  to  the  house  on 
 this  like  this  powderpuff  tree.  This 
 powderpuff  tree,  personally,  I  would 
 love  to  see  it  out  here  more  as  a 
 backdrop,  but  it  does  allow  us  to  see  it 
 as  part  of  the  front  bed  from  the  road. 
 So,  it  does  work  well.  They're  just 
 going  to  have  to  keep  it  maintained 
 because  if  you  guys  know  about 
 powderpuff  trees,  almost  give  you  that 
 Asian  style,  which  is  ideal  because 
 they'll  flatten  out  at  the  bottom, 
 really  push  out  on  the  ends  and  kind  of 
 give  you  kind  of a  mushroom  effect  to 
 the  top.  So,  they're  a  gorgeous  tree  to 
 work  with.  This  one  maybe  has  a  bloom  or 
 two  left  from  transplants,  but  not  a 
 whole  lot.  It's  going  to  really  flush 
 out.  Gives  you  all  summer  color  and 
 beautiful  for  the  birds.  So,  a  very 
 Florida  friendly  tree  can  handle  so  many 
 different  climates  and  it's  just  it's 
 just  going  to  really  take  over  this 
 side.  Hence  why  we  don't  have  anything 
 else  around  it.  It's  a  tree  that's 
 really  going  to  do  its  own  job.  We  again 
 we  have  the  Ocala  anise  on  either  side. 
 These  we're  going  to  allow  to  grow  into 
 little  trees  on  this  side.  Maybe  clean 
 up  the  trunk  a  little  bit  and  let  them 
 fill  in  above  the  wall  line.  And  then  of 
 course  the  silver  buttonwood  tree  is 
 also  another  Florida  native.  And  just  a 
 little  dash  of  the  Walters  Viburnum  Mrs. 
 Schillers  at  the  bottom.  Now,  this 
 particular  side,  we  were  limited  to 
 being  a  6ft  bed.  If  you  guys  can  see 
 over  to  the  side  here,  what  the  view 
 line  is  that  my  clients  are  dealing 
 with.  We'll  walk  inside  and  really  let 
 you  see  that.  But  really,  as  soon  as 
 this  house  was  built,  I  mean,  it 
 literally  looks  like  it  was  a  heart  of 
 this  house.  It's  that  close.  So,  we  came 
 in  with  some  45gallon  fishtail  palms, 
 and  we  had  to  put  them  close  to  the 
 house.  So,  these  fishtail  palms  are 
 about  10t  tall.  They're  really  going  to 
 fill  in  this  space.  Yes.  When  you  put 
 fishtail  palm  6  foot  off  the  house,  you 
 are  going  to  have  to  trim  those  trunks 
 closest  to  the  house  because  you're 
 going  to  want  to  make  sure  that  they 
 kind  of  grow  out  more  towards  the  rear 
 end  of  the  property  versus  along  the 
 house.  But  it's  a  totally  doable  thing. 
 I've  seen  fishtail  palms  put  in  pool 
 planters  that  are  3  foot  wide  and 
 produce  beautifully.  So,  you  can 
 absolutely  do  it  if  that's  a  question  on 
 your  mind  right  now.  These  are  going  to 
 become  a  great  wall  as  the  pool  backdrop 
 here,  which  is  also  going  to  do  a  great 
 job  of  getting  rid  of  this  giant  giant 
 second  story  right  next  to  them  within 
 feet  of  their  biggest  entertaining  space 
 that  they  have.  So,  they're  going  to 
 create  a  great  wall  there.  So,  they've 
 got  room  to  grow  in  and  just  a  little 
 bit  of  maintenance  for  my  clients  to 
 really  get  in  there  and  and  do  that 
 trimming.  Now,  that  is  absolutely 
 doable.  They're  going  to  grow  about  2  to 
 three  foot  per  year  and  really  kind  of 
 give  them  some  size.  So  they  want  to 
 feel  like  when  they  do  walk  back  here, 
 what  they  see  are  two  things.  They  want 
 to  see  a  beautiful  garden,  bronze  galore 
 over  on  one  side  and  feel  like  they're 
 not  in  a  neighborhood  and  the  next  thing 
 they  want  to  see  is  this  remainder  of 
 this  beautiful  little  lake  that  they're 
 sitting  on.  So  that  way  they  can  enjoy 
 it  fully  and  not  have  to  worry  about, 
 you  know,  feeling  like,  you  know, 
 they're  up  close  and  personal  with  with 
 any  neighbors.  So  that's  going  to  be  a 
 um  one  of  the  better  parts  of  this 
 natural  landscape.  Right  here  we  have  a 
 15gallon  gorgeous  false  agave  that  we 
 brought  in.  We  put  it  on  a  little  bit  of 
 a  hill.  Kind  of  looks  crazy  here,  but 
 from  inside  I  wanted  you  to  be  able  to 
 see  not  only  the  false  agave,  but  the 
 boulders.  So  we  raised  this  area  up  a 
 little  bit  so  that  way  you  can  see  that. 
 And  then  did  some  beautiful  little 
 yellow  lantana  carpet  flowers  for  this 
 bottom.  This  is  the  chunkier  variety. 
 The  ones  in  the  front  are  one  of  the 
 ones  that  are  more  natural,  more 
 widespread.  These  kind  of  mound  out. 
 These  are  kind  of  one  of  my  favorites. 
 They're  in  the  anmarie  family.  So,  but 
 instead  of  the  pink  tones  to  it,  it  has 
 the  yellow  and  a  little  bit  of  the  white 
 tones  in  it.  And  I  think  it's  just  a 
 gorgeous  little  carpet  flower.  Got  to 
 find  a  spot  in  my  garden  for  them  cuz  I 
 think  they're  gorgeous  and  they're  going 
 to  really  do  a  nice  contrast  against 
 this  rock.  So,  this  is  great.  These  are 
 Florida  friendly.  They're  non-native 
 species,  but  they  are  Florida  friendly 
 plant  because  they  do  so  well  here  in 
 Florida.  So,  if  you  guys  have  a 
 challenging  situation  like  this  and  you 
 are  at  with  end  with  whether  it's  your 
 HOA  or  maybe  it's  just  a  desire  that  you 
 have  to  have  more  of  a  sustainable 
 landscape,  something  that  can  withstand 
 things  and  be  more  on  the  water  saver 
 side  and  not  have  to  worry  about 
 fertilizing  quite  as  much,  a  little  less 
 care  in  the  garden  and  not  have  to  worry 
 about  some  of  the  other  things  that  us 
 tropical  gardeners  have  to  worry  about. 
 So,  if  you're  looking  for  a  little  bit 
 of  help  with  that,  and  if  you're  along 
 the  Florida  area  and  you're,  you  know, 
 maybe  a  little  bit  further  outside  of 
 our  installation  zone,  then  we  do  have 
 virtual  consults.  It's  a  one-on-one  with 
 me.  It's  a  1-hour  session.  It's 
 something  that  we  look  at,  walk  through 
 your  property  virtually,  and  then 
 discuss  some  options  as  I  put  things 
 down  on  on  the  computer  for  us  to  kind 
 of  visualize  and  see.  And  then  there  is 
 the  next  step  where  we  have  the  CAD  plan 
 service.  So,  if  you're  looking  for  just 
 a  master  plan,  a  full  design  service,  we 
 have  that  as  well.  That  is  also  a 
 one-on-one  with  Bryce  and  myself  and  we 
 kind  of  work  together  to  create 
 renderings  and  landscape  CAD.  So  that 
 way  that  could  be  something  that  you  can 
 hand  over  to  a  landscape  contractor  or 
 nursery  to  help  you  source  and  get  your 
 materials  and  it's  it's  pretty  much  a 
 roadmap  for  that.  So  if  you  guys  are 
 looking  for  either  one  of  those  things 
 and  kind  of  some  of  the  styles  that  you 
 see  here  on  YouTube,  if  that's  your 
 thing,  then  reach  out  to  us.  We'd  be 
 happy  to  work  with  you  and  kind  of  see 
 if  we  can  help  you  with  your  space.

 below.  So,  thank  you  so  much  for  joining

 backyard  garden  tour.  It  was  a  fun

 jungle  inspired  backyard.  So,  I  hope  you

---

 Well,  hello  gardeners.  Welcome  back.  We 
 are  in  Melbourne,  Florida,  zone  10A 
 today.  This  video  is  something  I've  been 
 excited  to  do  for  you  guys  because  this 
 is  a  tiny,  tiny  backyard  that  my  clients 
 wanted  to  create  a  resort  in.  Now,  they 
 are  responsible  for  bringing  in  this 
 gorgeous,  gorgeous  pool.  But  today,  we 
 are  going  to  talk  about  how  to  maximize 
 a  small  space  by  creating  kind  of  a 
 staggered  grouping,  a  staggered 
 footprint  of  different  types  of  palms 
 and  trees  to  create  that  resort-like 
 look,  kind  of  nestling  in  this  whole 
 pool.  If  this  is  the  kind  of  look  you're 
 going  for,  you  kind  of  want  a 
 lowmaintenance  tropical  feel,  then  this 
 video  is  going  to  be  for  you.  Eugene  and 
 Nicole  contacted  us  a  few  months  ago. 
 They  wanted  to  create  a  resort  within  a 
 tiny  tiny  footprint.  I  mean,  we  are 
 talking  about  this  side  over  here  right 
 behind  me,  less  than  five  foot  deep 
 here.  This  area  from  the  pool  area  to 
 the  back  of  the  fence  is  9  and  1/2t 
 deep.  And  then,  of  course,  we  have  about 
 a  4ft  section  on  the  opposite  side.  So, 
 we're  really  just  pretty  much  looking  at 
 a  rectangular  area.  We  prepared  a 
 rendering  and  a  full  master  plan  for 
 them,  a  full  CAD  plan  for  their  backyard 
 and  their  front  yard.  And  then  they  had 
 us  come  back  and  put  in  all  the  big 
 material.  That's  a  great  way  to  do  it  if 
 you're  going  to  do  things  within  a 
 budget.  Having  a  master  plan  really  does 
 a  great  job  of  taking  out  the  guesswork. 
 Now,  a  lot  of  our  clients  will  call  us 
 and  we'll  come  in  and  do  the  whole  thing 
 from  start  to  finish  and  that's  an  ideal 
 way  to  do  it.  But  if  you're  doing  this 
 on  a  budget,  having  the  heavy  lifting 
 done  initially  is  ideal  and  then  come  in 
 with  all  the  fun  stuff.  You  know,  if  it 
 were  in  the  similar  situation,  so  even 
 if  you  didn't  have  a  pool  like  this  and 
 you  had  this  was  your  back  patio,  I  love 
 to  do  a  landscaping  that  pretty  much 
 nestles  everything  around.  also  going  to 
 talk  about  how  to  put  things  in  a  zigzag 
 pattern.  So  that  way  you  maximize  the 
 amount  of  material  that  you  can  use  in  a 
 small  space.  If  you  put  everything  in  a 
 row  and  a  row  and  a  row,  you're  really 
 limiting  off  to  what  you  can  do.  And 
 then  it  also  kind  of  has  more  of  that 
 boring  look  and  almost  like  a  hedge  and 
 a  hedge  and  a  hedge  of  material.  So  when 
 you're  working  with  smaller  spaces,  it's 
 really  important  to  zigzag  that  pattern 
 of  trees.  As  an  example,  I'm  going  to 
 show  you  this  corner  here.  I  always  like 
 to  start  from  the  back.  My  back  area  is 
 always  going  to  be  my  taller  trees.  This 
 coconut  palm  serves  as  kind  of  like  a 
 roof  line  above  this  palm  planting.  Now, 
 if  I  had  a  smaller  tree  right  here  and 
 it  was  kind  of  more  in  my  face  here, 
 that  would  not  leave  room  for  me  to 
 stagger  in  a  grouping  of  pygmyate  palms 
 and  cat  palms.  And  that's  exactly  what 
 we  were  able  to  do  here.  By  having  a 
 taller  tree  in  this  corner  area  that 
 kind  of  brings  us  up  a  canopy,  something 
 that's  going  to  grow  relatively  fast. 
 This  is  an  ideal  thing  to  do  because  we 
 have  more  like  three  foot  to  four  foot 
 of  trunk.  You're  really  not  covering 
 anything  but  the  trunk  line  and  then 
 you've  got  the  canopy  above  you  which 
 instantly  gives  you  that  at  least  that 
 first  tier  in  a  landscape.  Those  of  you 
 guys  who  are  not  able  to  have  a 
 landscaper  come  in  and  put  big  trees  or 
 you  don't  have  the  capacity  to  put  a  big 
 tree  but  you  do  like  this  type  of  look, 
 go  ahead  and  stick  your  coconut  palm  in. 
 They  grow  3  to  4  foot  a  year  so  they 
 grow  super  super  fast.  And  maybe  give 
 yourself  that  time.  Give  yourself  that 
 year  before  you  get  the  next  phase  in. 
 Instead  of  trying  to  fill  this  in  with  a 
 bunch  of  plant  material,  if  you  like 
 this  frond  on  frond  kind  of  look,  get 
 that  going.  Give  it  a  year.  Now  you  have 
 room  for  that  next  small  planting.  And 
 then  you  can  do  something  like  this 
 pymid  8  palm.  This  was  a  25gallon 
 pigment  8  palm  that  we  put  in.  They  come 
 in  about  5  to  6t  tall  when  they're  that 
 size  and  they  mature  out  between  10  and 
 12.  They  mature  out  to  what's  relatively 
 a  good  size  when  you're  looking  for 
 coverage  above  a  fence  line.  So  at  10  to 
 12t  tall,  they're  going  to  be  the 
 perfect  height  to  kind  of  camouflage 
 what's  going  on  back  behind  the  fence 
 and  leaving  you  enough  room  for  maybe 
 some  color  at  that  point  down  below.  So 
 they're  going  to  let  this  guy  get  a 
 little  bit  taller  and  then  they're  going 
 to  stick  some  blooming  power  of  some 
 color  underneath  as  he  matures  and  get 
 some  height  to  him.  So  when  you  have  a 
 rectangular  area  like  this,  the  corners 
 you're  going to  find  usually  a  little 
 bit  of  room  and  that's  the  area  that  you 
 want  to  make  sure  these  corners, 
 whatever  you  put  landscape  wise  really 
 softens  the  corner.  Whether  it's  the 
 corner  of  a  screen  roof,  corner  of  a 
 patio,  corner  of  a  pool  area,  this 
 beautiful  wall  that  we  have  here,  we 
 really  wanted  to  soften  and  let  the 
 fronds  come  up  over  top  of  it.  Because 
 we  had  the  height  of  this  coconut  palm, 
 it  allowed  us  to  put  a  pygmy  date  palm 
 and  a  pygmy  eight  palm  on  each  corner 
 and  then  fill  in  the  bottom  of  this  tree 
 with  cat  palms.  Cuz  you  guys  know  palms 
 get  9  to  10t  tall.  So  this  area  as  this 
 tree  becomes  nothing  but  trunk  and  the 
 canopy  is  well  above  us.  These  cateria 
 palms  are  going  to  fill  in  this  base. 
 Gorgeous.  And  then  these  with  this  more 
 of  a  weepy  fr  that  the  pygmy  8  palms 
 offer  are  going  to  do  a  great  job  of 
 folding  over  top  of  the  wall  corners. 
 Really  giving  you  that  almost  that 
 cascade  that  waterfall  kind  of  look  from 
 this  trunk.  And  then  of  course  you'll 
 always  have  the  dynamic  look  of  this  big 
 coconut  palm  kind  of  really  becoming  the 
 umbrella  of  the  whole  space.  This  is 
 kind  of  going  to  be  our  roof  line.  This 
 is  what  that's  going  to  do.  And  then 
 every  other  tree  along  this  side  we  did 
 the  opposite  with.  So  you'll  notice  this 
 tree  right  here,  the  triangle  palm,  the 
 traveler's  palm,  the  king  Alexander 
 palm.  These  palms  that  we  had,  we  did 
 find  a  formation  that  we  liked  on  those, 
 but  they're  all  have  one  thing  in 
 common.  They're  all  vertical  trees.  So, 
 they're  not  something  like  the  pygmyate 
 palm  that's  squat  and  and  kind  of  fat 
 and  chunky  and  weepy.  We  wanted 
 something  that's  going  to  have  a  good 
 trunk  base,  but  very,  very  flat.  So,  we 
 can  fit  many  trees  into  this  space. 
 Normally,  you  wouldn't  be  able  to  fit 
 this  many  trees  in  one  area.  Because 
 that  traveler's  palm  does  this,  which  is 
 nice  and  vertical,  nice  and  upright. 
 It's  going  to  kind  of  give  us  almost 
 like  a  wall  effect.  And  then  we're  going 
 to  have  the  silver  tone  against  that 
 wall  effect  with  a  triangle  fan  palm 
 that  does  the  same  thing.  So,  it's 
 really  going  to  be  like  wild  and  crazy 
 and  chunky  on  the  corners  and  then  very 
 vertical  everywhere  else.  I  love  love 
 love  what  King  Allaranders  do  in  a 
 garden.  I  just  think  that  they're  just 
 such  a  fantastic,  very  dynamic  frond  to 
 this  tree.  They  offer  a  very  little 
 footprint  because  the  trunks  themselves, 
 I  think  they're  substantial,  but  they're 
 not  huge.  They're  just  kind  of  a  nice 
 clean  green  trunk,  and  that's  going  to 
 offer  quite  a  bit  of  look.  In  a  lot  of 
 cases,  I'll  do  a  triple,  but  I  did  not 
 want  something  coming  over  the  front.  I 
 wanted  something  V-shaped.  I  wanted  this 
 whole  back  to  not  kind  of  encroach  on 
 the  pool  area.  I  wanted  the  corners  to 
 do  that,  but  I  wanted  the  backs  to  be 
 almost  just  dynamic,  just  very  vertical. 
 Everything  is  almost  like  a  a  tropical 
 wall  here  that  didn't  come  this  way,  but 
 the  corners  came  this  way  to  kind  of 
 soften  a  rectangular  area.  I  find  it 
 that's  the  best  way  to  do  it  when  I'm 
 working  in  my  designs  because  that's  a 
 way  to  add  curvature.  That's  a  way  to 
 add  softness  with  your  landscaping, 
 especially  when  the  biggest  thing  in 
 this  whole  area  is  the  pool.  So,  I'm 
 like,  okay,  so  we  need  to  bring  some 
 dynamics  in  here  to  really  soften  that 
 look.  Know  that  this  is  really  going  to 
 take  hold  as  these  guys  go  straight  up 
 and  these  guys  unfold  even  a  little  bit 
 more.  So,  I  think  it's  going  to  be 
 absolutely  stunning.  Right  here  to  the 
 back,  this  was  part  of  the  plan  that  we 
 proposed.  They  have  started  their 
 landscaping.  They've  already  put  in  some 
 antiloo  as  a  backdrop  and  a  little 
 clustering  of  Rojo  Congos  on  the  corner. 
 Next,  they're  going  to  bring  in  some 
 silver  odoras  and  really  kind  of  dazzle 
 this  up  with  some  pretty  colored 
 burmilads.  That's  going  to  be  a  stunner 
 in  this  area.  And  you  know,  with  a 
 landscaping  like  this,  you  kind  of  want 
 to  keep  this  base  a  little  bit  simple 
 because  you  really  do  get  a  lot  of  girth 
 with  just  the  palm  trees.  And  that's 
 kind  of  the  goal  here.  You'll  notice  we 
 have  a  gap  of  space  here.  And  I  know 
 they're  going  to  get  started  with  those 
 croins  on  this  corner  and  some  elephant 
 ears.  And  that's  just  going  to  be  a  nice 
 soft  touch  here.  But  then  we  get  back 
 over  to  this  side  here  and  we've  pretty 
 much  replicated  the  side.  I  mean,  I'm 
 sitting  here  and  I  feel  like  I'm 
 engulfed  in  this  whole  corner.  And 
 that's  the  part  of  being  in  a  resort. 
 That's  the  part  of  being  in  a  tropical 
 landscape.  And  that's  what  they  wanted. 
 They  wanted  a  tiny  resort  in  their 
 space.  And  they  started  off  with  a 
 fabulous  pool  and  then  we  got  to  come  in 
 and  really  soften  all  this  hardscape 
 with  a  lot  of  this  tropical  look.  So 
 we've  got  the  coconut  palm  as  the 
 centerpiece.  We've  wrapped  cat  palms  all 
 the  way  around.  These  are  15gallon  cat 
 palms.  And  then  on  either  side  are  two 
 pigmentate  palms.  So,  the  exact  replica, 
 the  exact  mirror  effect  of  what  we  have 
 on  that  corner,  we  recreated  on  this 
 corner.  And  you  notice  that  as  far  as 
 the  landscaping  goes,  if  you're  looking 
 kind  of  how  I'm  looking  down  this  way, 
 you'll  see  that  it's  the  corners  that 
 encroach  in  the  backside.  Everything, 
 even  the  plant  material,  stays  more 
 vertical,  more  compact.  And  I  think  that 
 that's  going  to  give  them  kind  of  really 
 long-term  success.  As  this  planting  is  a 
 month  old,  when  it's  10  years  old,  it's 
 just  going  to  be  stunning.  The  only 
 difference  is  when  it's  10  years  old, 
 you'll  have  more  trunk  line.  So  you  can 
 decide  at  that  point  you'll  have  a 
 little  bit  more  shade  so  they  can  put  in 
 some  of  those  key  features  trees  that 
 they  want  that  needed  a  little  bit  of 
 protection  from  some  of  this  aggressive 
 sun  they've  got  going  on  back  here.  This 
 is  our  ending  points  at  the  edges  of  the 
 this  narrow  space  of  4t.  I  think  it's  4 
 and  1/2t  is  what  we  had  to  work  with 
 here.  We  chose  a  kiopsis  palm  to  fit  in 
 this  particular  spot  because  its  trunk 
 is  going  to  be  so  beautiful.  Why  not 
 have  it  forefront  in  the  landscape?  So, 
 this  trunk  is  going  to  get  super  sized 
 and  then  this  tree  stays  so  nice  and 
 vertical  and  it  has  such  a  unique  frond, 
 especially  when  you're  comparing  it  to 
 the  softness  of  the  other  fronds.  That 
 contrast  is  super  important  when  you 
 only  have  the  option  of  using  one  tree. 
 One  tree  that  has  a  completely  different 
 frond  and  then  mix  it  with  the  trees 
 that  have  completely  different  fronds 
 and  then  that  contrast  makes  it  look 
 like  you  have  just  multiple  things  going 
 on  when  you're  really  only  maybe  looking 
 at  three  or  four  trees.  So,  right  next 
 to  the  Kentopsis  there,  we  have  a  King 
 Kong  fishtail  palm,  which  is  such  an 
 unusual  tree.  I  think  that's  going  to  be 
 a  fun,  interesting  tree  as  it  comes  in. 
 And  then  we  mimicked  it.  Everything's 
 squared  off.  And  you  kind  of  want  to  do 
 a  rinse  and  repeat.  This  is  a  very 
 contemporary  pattern  that  we're  trying 
 to  soften  with  a  tropical  landscape.  But 
 we're  going  to  follow  the  rules  by 
 making  sure  that  we  do  kind  of 
 complement  the  sides  by  having  some 
 symmetry  here,  having  some  symmetry  on 
 the  corners,  and  then  making  more  of  a 
 dynamic  centerpiece  area  by  kind  of 
 creating  the  middle  as  its  very  own 
 space  and  kind  of  using  the  sides  to 
 frame.  I  find  that  seems  to  be  the  best 
 thing  to  do  when  you  have  a  small  space 
 to  work  with.  It  takes  away  that  feel  of 
 things  being  too  cluttered  and  it  kind 
 of  makes  it  more  streamlined.  Now,  I 
 know  if  you  guys  seen  my  videos,  you 
 know  that  I  love  the  clustered  fishtail 
 palms  for  privacy.  This  was  the  client's 
 idea.  I  think  it  was  Universal  Studios 
 he  told  me  that  he  saw  these  in  and  they 
 were  stunners  in  the  garden  there.  And 
 so  he's  like,  I  just  love  this  big  giant 
 leaf.  And  I  can  see  why  because  I've 
 become  a  fan  myself  now.  I  love  this 
 kind  of  cascading  look  when  there's 
 multiple  ones  with  the  big  fishtail 
 palms,  but  seeing  them  in  a  tree  form,  I 
 don't  know.  I  think  I  might  have  to 
 experiment  with  it  because  I  am  really 
 liking  this  kind  of  graceful  just  kind 
 of  whimsy  type  of  look.  I  mean,  I  feel 
 like  I  could  just  stand  right  under  it. 
 is  this  is  like  the  perfect  thing  for 
 pictures  as  this  really  unfolds. 
 Fishtail  palms  are  one  of  my  favorites 
 and  now  I  think  King  Kongs.  I'm  going  to 
 keep  a  close  eye  on  how  these  do  in  this 
 environment  and  then  maybe  start  to  use 
 them  in  other  gardens.  Then  we  have 
 another  Kentopsis.  Eugene  and  Nikki  have 
 already  started  to  put  in  some  plants. 
 So  they've  gotten  perilis  vermilads  per 
 the  plan  that  we  designed  for  them. 
 They're  going  to  do  a  little  bit  of 
 boulders  and  then  bring  in  a  little  bit 
 of  stone  as  they  can  to  make  this  little 
 spot  a  little  interesting  right  here. 
 and  then  come  in  with  some  small 
 plantings  because  again  we're  only  4  and 
 1/2t  of  space  to  work  with  here.  This 
 garden  really  really  came  together  for 
 the  space  that  we  had  to  work  with.  And 
 I  wanted  you  to  see  the  possibilities 
 what  you  can  create  in  such  a  small 
 space  because  I  know  a  lot  of  us  think 
 that  gosh  if  I  had  that  much  room  I  can 
 create  that  kind  of  garden  too  but  you 
 do  not  need  much  room  to  really  fit  in  a 
 good  amount  of  tree  material.  This  looks 
 great  now,  but  in  five,  six  years,  in  10 
 years,  it's  really  going  to  come 
 together,  really  give  them  that  dynamic 
 tropical  look.  When  you  open  that  back 
 gate,  when  you  come  through  this  back 
 area,  they're  going  to  see  these 
 different  varieties  of  flat  trees  mixed 
 in  with  these  corner  trees  come 
 together,  and  it  is  going  to  feel  like 
 the  garden  of  their  dreams.  And  I  cannot 
 wait.  I'm  hoping  they'll  invite  us  back 
 to  do  a  video  on  that  because  I  think 
 that  would  just  be  so  stunning.  I  hope 
 you  got  a  little  bit  information  about 
 some  of  these  plants  and  trees.  As  you 
 guys  know,  we  have  a  book  coming  out 
 very,  very  soon.  It  is  finished.  It's  50 
 of  the  heartiest  plants  and  trees  in 
 South  Florida.  It  is  my  favorite 
 material  that  I  love  to  use  that  I've 
 used  for  25  plus  years  in  the  landscapes 
 for  my  garden  and  many,  many,  many  other 
 gardens  throughout  our  areas  of  Florida. 
 We're  super  proud  of  it.  As  soon  as  it's 
 ready,  it'll  be  in  the  show  notes  of  our 
 latest  video.  So,  please  check  it  out. 
 It'll  be  on  Amazon.  We're  very,  very 
 thrilled  about  it.  It  goes  into  not  only 
 depths  of  each  and  every  one  of  those 
 plants,  but  it  also  talks  about 
 companion  plants,  what  they  like,  areas 
 of  the  garden  they  like  to  be  in,  and 
 kind  of  just  how  to  work  them  into  a 
 landscaping.  So,  we  wanted  each  plant 
 and  tree  to  have  enough  information 
 there.  That  way,  you  guys  can  see  if 
 this  is  going  to  be  something  that's 
 going  to  fit  for  your  space.  So,  this  is 
 going  to  be  something  that  when  once 
 we're  done  talking  about  and  explaining

 paired  with,  the  type  of  environment

 go-to  plant  for  this  particular  location

 page  and  find  another  plant.  We  enjoy

 projects  are  projects  that  we've  either

 we  are in  my  backyard  yet  again,  Vero 
 Beach,  Florida,  zone  10A.  And  if  you 
 guys  were  around  a  couple  weekends  ago,

 my  garden  that  we're  going  to  do  a  part 
 two  for  the  other  side  of  the  walkway 
 because  if  you  guys  are  new  to  Florida

 what  I  have  going  on  back  here,  I  wanted 
 you  to  have  enough  information  to  where

 work  in  my  space."  Whether  it  gets  sun, 
 little  sun,  whether  it  needs  a  good 
 amount  of  water,  you  can  take  it  from  a 
 landscape  designer.  I've  been  doing  this 
 for  over  25  years.  This  is  my  space. 
 This  is  my  jam.  This  is  my  personal 
 garden.  I  know  it  might  not  appeal  to 
 everybody,  but  I  like  the  tropical 
 style.  I  like  that  jungle  style.  I  like 
 being  involved  in  almost  like  a 
 resort-like  garden,  even  though  I  live 
 on  a  teeny  tiny  slice  of  land  here  in 
 Vero  Beach,  Florida.  So,  I've  tried  to 
 make  my  space  feel  more  like  a  resort. 
 This  is  a  very  lowmaintenance  section  of 
 my  garden.  So,  come  on,  you  guys.  Let's 
 jump  right  in.  All right,  you  guys.  So, 
 right  where  we  left  off,  this  is  the 
 rear  corner  of  my  property.  This  is  my 
 whole  backyard  space,  you  guys.  I  have 
 like  a  drainage  easement  down  the  middle
