 pretty  much  plants  on  both  sides  of  that 
 drainage  easement.  So,  Bryce,  pan  over  a 
 little  bit  to  my  neighbor's  yard.  This 
 is  my  neighbor  Don's  yard.  She  is  the 
 sweetest  neighbor  I  have.  I  just 
 absolutely  love  her.  She's  kept  her  yard 
 pretty  natural,  and  that's  pretty  much 
 what  my  garden  looked  like  when  I  first 
 moved  in.  So,  right  here  on  the  very 
 corner,  we  have  the  red  cone  ginger. 
 This  is  the  red  variety.  Even  though  it 
 has  more  of  a  a  pink  tone  to  it,  it  is  a 
 beautiful  striking  red  as  it  matures. 
 You  can  kind  of  see  it  and  they  really 
 open  up  to  a  nice  tall  bloom.  Now,  these 
 blooms  last  for  months  and  months.  So, 
 it  is  really  striking  when  the  whole 
 thing  really  starts  to  come  together. 
 Blooms  all  summer  long.  Unfortunately, 
 this  particular  variety  really  does  need 
 to  be  in  warm  climate.  And  once  it  hits 
 that  30  32  range,  really  does  not  like 
 it.  you're  going  to  have  to  cut  it  back 
 and  then  let  it  flush  back  out.  You  want 
 to  do  filtered  light  when  it's  in  a  pot 
 because  it  can't  take  too  much  of  that 
 harsh  rays  cuz  it  can  really  burn.  Make 
 sure  it  gets  good  water  and  then  it  will 
 kind  of  flush  out  and  be  gorgeous  and 
 beautiful  and  then  during  those  cool 
 nights  that  you  have,  pop  it  into  the 
 garage  and,  you  know,  put  it  into  safety 
 and  then,  you  know,  pop  it  back  out 
 through  the  rest  of  the  year  and  it  does 
 fabulous.  So,  if  you  guys  have  a  cluster 
 in  the  garden,  especially  around  a 
 corner  or  maybe  a  backdrop  around  behind 
 a  pool  area  or  a  water  feature,  red  cone 
 ginger  is  ideal.  I  love  it  when  it's  hot 
 pink  and  really  goes  to  town  and  fills 
 in  this  whole  corner  area.  So,  right 
 down  here,  I  have  a  little  collection  of 
 some  Tennessee  boulders.  I  absolutely 
 love  putting  them  on  corner  areas, 
 especially  when  I'm  trying  to  soften 
 something.  So,  it  also  disguises  the 
 connection  of  two  edgings.  So  I  have  but 
 edging  right  along  this  edge  and  then  I 
 have  the  aluminum  alloy  edging  right 
 across  this  edge.  Edging  is  important  on 
 my  garden  because  both  sides  slant 
 pretty  aggressively  and  I  really  want  a 
 nice  tight  path.  I  want  a  tight  area  of 
 mulch  and  plantings  then  a  tight  area  of 
 stone  and  edging  does  a  good  job  of 
 controlling  those  two  things.  We  kind  of 
 have  a  little  forefront  with  the 
 boulders  here.  Right  where  I'm  standing 
 is  a  great  look  for  a  really  cool  either 
 statue  or  a  pot  with  something  popping 
 out  of  the  middle  of  it  to  kind  of  give 
 us  a  secondary  tier.  That's  a  perfect 
 way  to  offer  some  different  kind  of 
 layering  in  the  garden  and  making  it 
 interesting  and  then  also  soften  the  two 
 connections  of  the  different  types  of 
 edging  for  this  particular  space.  All 
 right  guys,  so  coming  around  the  corner 
 is  Song  of  India.  Now  we  just  have  a 
 little  clustering.  There's  not  much 
 going  on.  There  are  exactly  three  song 
 of  India  in  this  little  grouping  and 
 that's  all  it  takes.  And  what  I  wanted 
 was  we  have  the  darkness  of  the  ginger. 
 We  have  the  darkness  of  the  ic  tee 
 croins  as  a  backdrop.  So  having 
 something  with  a  little  bit  of 
 brightness  in  a  dark  spot  is  always  my 
 goal.  So  I'm  always  looking  for  light 
 and  dark  combinations  in  the  garden  and 
 song  of  India  do  that.  They  have  that 
 beautiful  yellow  and  green  tone  and  then 
 when  it  gets  more  shade  it's  more  of  a 
 white  and  green  kind  of  tone.  So  that 
 combination  really  really  speaks  to  me. 
 But  you  can  keep  them  a  bush  forever. 
 They  do  not  need  to  be  that  tall.  You 
 can  keep  them  chunky.  You  can  keep  them 
 full.  Every  time  you  trim  one  of  these 
 individual  limbs,  it  produces  two  new 
 heads.  And  I'm  going  to  continue  to  do 
 that.  So,  that's  an  easy  way  to  keep 
 this  a  long-term  colorful  bush.  If  I 
 wanted  one  to  kind  of  come  right  through 
 here  and  kind  of  be  nice  and  tall  in  the 
 midst  of  all  of  these  guys,  that's  an 
 absolute  possibility.  You  could  totally 
 train  it  to  be  a  tree  as  a  centerpiece 
 in  that  group.  And  it's  kind  of  like  a 
 wonky  kind  of  cousin  it  type  of  tree, 
 which  I  love.  They  can  handle  full  sun. 
 They  can  handle  filtered  light.  They  can 
 handle  almost  all  shades.  So,  a  plant 
 that's  that  versatile,  I  find  a  lot  of 
 uses  for  it  in  the  garden.  And  I  think 
 it  does  a  great  job  of  kind  of  capturing 
 kind  of  taking  your  eye  and  zooming 
 right  in  that  particular  spot.  It  can  be 
 kept  like  this  forever  if  that's  your 
 choice.  So,  directly  behind  the  song  of 
 India  are  a  little  clustering  of  four  of 
 the  icon  croins.  Now,  these  icone 
 croins,  they're  a  little  bit  darker  than 
 they  are  in  the  sunny  areas.  This  is  a 
 little  bit  of  a  filtered  light,  more  of

 tree  has  really  come  into  this  area  and 
 the  gingers  are  kind  of  unfolding  over 
 top  of  it.  This  spot  gets  a  little  bit 
 more  shade  and  then  it  allows  my  icon 
 croins  to  have  a  little  bit  of  a  deeper 
 tone.  Icone  croins  in  general  are  a 
 chunkier  croin.  They're  going  to  really 
 kind  of  stay  easy  care,  lowmaintenance. 
 I  haven't  trimmed  these  guys  since  I  put 
 them  in  about  8  months  ago.  They  can 
 really  really  live  in  a  space  for  a  long 
 period  of  time  and  stay  chunky  and  more

 look  like  more  in  the  sun.  Early  morning 
 sun  to  midday  sun,  they  have  more  of 
 those  pink  tones,  more  vibrant 
 colorations.  This  is  my  weight.  This  is 
 my  thickness  here.  But  the  focal  point 
 in  my  garden  is  the  triple  bottle  palm. 
 You  guys  know  how  much  I  love  the  bottle 
 palms.  And  if  you  love  a  single,  you're 
 going  to  love  a  triple.  This  is  going to 
 be  an  absolute  stunner.  I  have  one  in  my 
 front  yard  that  I'm  in  love  with.  This 
 one  is  fairly  young.  It's  been  in  the 
 garden  for  about  a  year.  Kind  of 
 starting  to  open  up.  They're  more 
 compact  when  they're  newly  planted.  As 
 they  grow  and  search  for  the  sun,  they 
 really  widen  out.  So,  they  become  a  cool 
 sculpture  in  the  garden.  They  have  that 
 big  bulbous  base.  If  they're  fairly 
 young  tree,  they  don't  want  to  be  in  the 
 full  sun.  They  like  filtered  light 
 protection.  They  can  handle  all  morning 
 sun  that  you  want,  but  towards  that 
 afternoon  sun,  they  can  really  brown  out 
 on  you.  If  you  have  an  area  that  has 
 maybe  some  canopy  coverage  where  you 
 have  a  palm  tree  over  top  of  it  or  you 
 have  an  oak  tree  over  top  of  it, 
 anything  like  that,  it  is  a  perfect 
 place  to  kind  of  pop  a  bottle  palm 
 underneath  of  there.  Now,  what's  great 
 about  the  bottle  palm  is  it  does  not  get 
 enormous.  So,  a  bottle  palm  on  average 
 is  going  to  get  around  14t  tall  and  then 
 stop  growing.  So,  there's  not  many 
 Florida  trees  that  are  going  to  offer 
 you  that  kind  of  look,  especially  with  a 
 clean,  cool  trunk  as  the  bottle  palm. 
 And  I've  got  a  couple  singles  right 
 behind  me  that  have  been  full  grown  for 
 a  good  10  years.  And  that  is  as  a  big  as 
 they're  going  to  get.  And  I  just  think 
 they're  absolute  stunners  in  the  garden 
 with  this  big  bulbous  base.  I  wrap 
 myself  around  it.  It  is  just  huge.  This 
 tree  has  been  like  this  forever.  They're 
 a  fabulous,  fabulous  tree  to  work  with 
 in  the  garden.  Great  understory  tree 
 amongst  all  of  the  other  big  canopy 
 trees.  Deserves  its  place  in  the  garden, 
 especially  a  Florida  garden.  Oh,  you

 getting  more  sun  than  the  one  on  the 
 left.  You  can  really  tell  the  difference 
 in  what  they're  offering.  But  I  still 
 love  them  as  a  backdrop  plant.  They're 
 going  to  get  some  size  to  them.  About 
 five  or  six  foot  tall.  I  can  trim  them. 
 I  can  keep  them  a  little  bit  lower  than

 along  my  black  fence  there.  The  aglion 
 have  a  tendency  to  get  wider  and 
 chunkier.  And  so  that's  why  it's  the 
 centerpiece  in  that  spot.  It's  really 
 going  to  open  up  and  kind  of  give  us  a 
 bright  spot.  Anything  to  the  back  of  a 
 garden,  I  love  sticking  things  in  that 
 have  a  lot  of  light  coloring  to  them 
 that  just  draws  your  eye  and  it  makes 
 the  bed  look  like  it  has  more  depth.  So 
 down  below  you  guys,  we  have  three  dwarf 
 exoras  because  sometimes  three  is  all  it 
 takes.  Those  guys  are  doing  super  well. 
 I  didn't  want  something  that  was  going 
 to  compete  or  overgrow  the  bottle  palm. 
 And  dwarf  exoras  do  a  great  job  of 
 staying  compact  and  small  with  little 
 leaves.  Now  this  area  only  gets  morning 
 sun.  So  right  now  we  don't  have  a  lot  of 
 blooms  on  them,  but  in  average  I  have 
 five  to  six  blooms  during  the  summer 
 months.  This  is  a  full  sun  plant.  It  can 
 handle  filtered  light,  can  handle 
 morning  sun.  This  area  only  gets  early 
 morning  sun  and  then  it  kind  of  stops 
 from  there.  So  for  me,  what  was  really 
 important  was  to  not  have  too  much 
 maintenance  around  the  base  of  this  tree 
 because  I  do  love  to  see  the  base  of 
 this  tree,  especially  as  it  gets  a 
 little  bit  larger.  When  I  start  taking 
 off  these  sheds  here  because  once  that 
 comes  off,  then  you  really  see  the 
 bulbous  base.  It's  just  still  a  little 
 young  of  a  tree.  So,  I  definitely  want 
 to  keep  a  little  skirt  planting  here 
 that  was  just  not  too  much  work  or  not 
 too  cluttered  in  this  particular  spot 
 because  it's  generally  a  small  spot.  All 
 right,  so  as  we  move  just  past  that 
 section,  this  is  one  of  my  favorite 
 little  areas.  You  know,  this  was  kind  of 
 a  nice  surprise  and  why  I  love  love  love 
 pots  in  the  garden.  When  you  have  spots 
 in  your  garden,  wait  for  that  perfect 
 pot  that  you  find  on  marketplace  or  a 
 pottery  shop  because  I  love  this  pot  in 
 the  garden.  It's  the  perfect  size.  I 
 waited  until  I  found  this  dune  palm  that 
 I  love  in  the  garden.  I  wanted  something 
 that  I  knew  would  either  be  vertical, 
 like  a  cleared  trunk  with  a  canopy  to 
 it,  or  something  vertical  like  a 
 sculpture  like  this  dune  palm.  And  I 
 think  that  this  dune  palm  really  did  the 
 trick.  I  think  that  was  the  perfect  fit 
 for  this  spot.  What  I  have  is  excellence 
 croins  that  wrap  around  it.  These  croins 
 are  very  old.  They're  a  good  12  years 
 old.  I  wanted  something  here  where  I  can 
 let  these  guys  get  some  size,  but  I 
 needed  something  to  pop  out  of  the 
 middle  of  it  without  it  getting  too  too 
 tall.  So,  when  you  have  a  pot,  you  can 
 really  control  what  you  want  to  use  in 
 it.  So,  a  dune  palm  is  an  ideal  plant  to 
 use  because  it  needs  little  water. 
 Overall,  tough  when  it  comes  to  pests 
 and  and  other  issues,  and  it's  kind  of 
 up  and  out  of  the  way.  Anytime  I  do  need 
 to  trim  a  frond,  it's  like  right  in  my 
 face,  so  it's  super  easy  to  get  to.  It's 
 become  a  perfect  lowmaintenance  feature. 
 It's  going  to  get  about  2  foot  taller 
 than  it  currently  is.  And  that's  it. 
 It's  not  going  to  outgrow  the  spot 
 forever  and  ever  and  ever.  And  it's 
 going  to  become  a  big  kind  of  crown  in 
 this  particular  spot.  Pop  to  boulder 
 right  in  front  of  it.  And  then  voila,  we 
 have  a  little  feature  grouping  here.  I 
 have  some  dreads  croins  down  below.  It 
 is  a  kind  of  curly  leafed  kind  of  crazy 
 croten.  I've  had  them  for  about  a  year 
 now  and  I  love  them  in  down  south 
 gardens,  but  I've  had  pest  problems  with 
 them.  I've  had  issues  with  them  in  my 
 garden  and  I'm  not  super  happy  with  them 
 in  my  particular  space.  So,  I'm  going  to 
 give  them  another  6  months.  If  they're 
 not  going  to  work  in  the  garden  and 
 they're  just  really  not  going  to  really 
 pop  out  and  give  me  some  of  that  good 
 color  that  I  was  really  hoping  from 
 them,  I  might  switch  them  out  to 
 something  else  that  kind  of  fits  this 
 spot  a  little  bit  better.  That  is  my 
 honest  review  on  these  particular 
 croins.  A  lot  of  my  garden  is  kind  of  in 
 the  filtered  light,  more  protected  with 
 the  palm  trees.  This  particular  spot 
 right  here  is  full  full  sun.  Now,  when 
 you  have  that  going  on  in  your  space  and 
 you're  not  able  to  remodify  all  your 
 irrigation  to  fit  sun,  no  sun,  the  best 
 thing  that  you  can  do  is  really  modify 
 your  plants  and  trees  to  fit  the 
 irrigation  that  you  currently  have. 
 Irrigation  is  a  big  part  of  keeping  your 
 plants  super  happy  and  healthy.  But  I 
 can't  run  separate  zones  for  this 
 section  versus  that  section.  So  I  went 
 with  more  of  a  drought  tolerant  plant 
 material  in  this  particular  spot.  These 
 are  some  tried  andrue  tough  plants  that 
 really  work  in  this  kind  of  environment. 
 So  right  here,  right  off  the  bat,  this 
 is  a  dwarf  jasmine  tree.  Just  look  at 
 the  movement  in  this  particular  tree. 
 She  blooms  a  beautiful  white  flower  that 
 offers  a  lovely  fragrance.  Hence  why  I 
 have  her  right  here  on  the  corner  near 
 my  seating  section.  Anytime  I  have  a 
 seating  section  that  I  spend  time  in,  I 
 do  try  to  stick  something  in  with  some 
 fragrance.  My  back  arbor  has  a 
 variegated  confederate  jasmine  that  just 
 lights  up  the  backyard  with  fragrance 
 because  it  blooms  all  summer  long.  I 
 just  get  that  soft,  subtle  fragrance.  It 
 has  like  a  citrusy  smell  to  it.  And  I 
 just  love  how  plants  and  trees  will  do 
 that  to  you.  Just  extra  bonus  in  life.  I 
 wanted  a  little  bit  of  a  raised  area 
 here,  a  little  bit  of  impact  here.  So, 
 we  have  the  Tennessee  boulders  that  I've 
 used  as  an  edging  along  this  area.  And 
 it  wasn't  just  for  the  purpose  of  the 
 beauty  of  this  edging.  I  needed  this 
 landscaping  to  not  sit  low  at  all 
 because  when  you  have  drought  tolerant 
 plants,  what  do  you  need  most?  You  need 
 drainage  in  a  garden.  So,  everything 
 here  is  planted  about  5  in  above  grade. 
 So,  it's  slightly  birmed  up  along  this 
 area.  So,  that  way  I  don't  have  any 
 trouble  with  this  being  underwater 
 during  our  heavy  storm.  So  this  is  a 
 subtle  retaining  wall.  And  I  think  that 
 that  just  kind  of  adds  more  charm  and 
 more  interest  to  the  garden.  Right  in 
 the  center  I  have  a  false  agave.  This  is 
 the  dark  green  variety  with  the  yellow 
 center  or  sometimes  of  the  year  it's 
 more  of  a  white  center.  It's  going  to  be 
 a  gorgeous  tall  feature.  Now  this  is  the 
 taller  of  the  fals  agave.  I  wanted 
 something  that's  going  to  get  about  3 
 foot  taller  than  what  it  currently  is. 
 And  it's  really  going  to  do  that  and 
 become  that  centerpiece  coming  over  top 
 of  the  deck.  Directly  behind  it  is  my 
 foxtail  ferns.  and  I  just  have  a  curved 
 swath  of  foxtail  ferns.  When  you  have 
 something  that's  more  of  a  a  sharp  tone, 
 something  more  of  like  the  bold  and  and 
 crazy.  Having  something  like  this  that's 
 soft  and  just  a  perfect  kind  of  bedding 
 plant,  it  creates  such  a  great  contrast. 
 It  just  makes  you  want  to  bend  over  and 
 touch  it  just  like  this.  So,  I  love 
 using  these  guys  for  that.  Now,  they're 
 fairly  young.  This  is  their  first  year 
 in  the  garden,  but  I'll  get  Bryce  to 
 slide  in  a  um  picture  of  what  they  look 
 like  after  a  few  trimming  cycles.  When 
 you  trim  these  guys,  you  pretty  much 
 handle  them  just  kind  of  like  a  a 
 ponytail  here  and  you  trim  all  along  the 
 bottom  of  it.  So  that  way  you  keep  that 
 vertical  aspect  after  a  good  year.  They 
 really  do  show  off  almost  that  vertical 
 and  chunky  look  of  them.  Kind  of  gives 
 you  an  architectural  detail  in  the 
 garden.  I  just  I  love  the  way  that 
 looks.  These  three  here  are  flame  agave. 
 This  here  is  a  foxtail  agave.  No  thorns 
 to  it.  Very  soft.  Such  a  beautiful 
 plant.  This  one  has  a  little  bit  of 
 thorns  right  along  this  edge  here.  Not 
 crazy,  not  terrible.  They  still  kind  of 
 give  you  that  succulent  kind  of  look. 
 Gorgeous  together  as  a  grouping.  They 
 really  kind  of  pop  out  and  lean  against 
 each  other  and  really  give  you  that  kind 
 of  tropical  lily  pad  kind  of  leaf.  And  I 
 love  the  way  they  look  as  a  backdrop. 
 And  through  the  cracks,  I  often  use 
 pelane  or  perchilaka.  That's  a  great 
 summer  annual.  These  all  cut  back. 
 They'll  flush  back  out  in  the  spring, 
 but  they're  a  gorgeous  little  plant  that 
 blooms  consistently  other  than  when  I 
 seem  to  be  filming  because  they're  never 
 in  bloom,  but  they  do  bloom.  A  gorgeous 
 pink  vibrant  pink pink  flower.  I  know 
 it's  kind  of  hard  to  see  here.  I'll  try 
 to  get  Bryce  to  pop  in  a  picture  of  what 
 they  look  like  when  they're  in  full 
 bloom.  Down  below,  I  have  mam  croins. 
 So,  I  have  three  on  this  side  wrapping 
 around  the  front  of  this  banana  leaf 
 croin.  I  love  the  mammy  croins.  there. 
 Make  like  a  fireball  display.  Really, 
 really  bright  and  contrasting  color. 
 Super  easy  to  stay  this  size.  This  is 
 about  the  height  that  I  want  to  let  them 
 get.  Maybe  a  tad  bit  taller,  but  then 
 they  can  be  that  way  forever,  you  guys. 
 You  can  keep  them  chunky.  You  can  keep 
 them  small  and  they'll  widen  out  at  the 
 base.  They  can  take  the  heat  of  full  sun 
 or  bounce  back  heat  from  a  walkway  or  a 
 pool  deck.  They'll  handle  that  like  a 
 champ.  and  they'll  give  you  that  giant 
 fireball  kind  of  red  look  to  it  and 
 really  give  you  a  good  bit  of 
 concealment  from,  you  know,  whatever 
 you're  trying  to  hide  behind  it.  So, 
 that's  kind  of  how  I  use  mammy  croins. 
 I'll  cluster  them  in  a  big  grouping  to 
 the  front  of  something  like  this. 
 Something  that  really  does  have  a  lot  of 
 stem  work  at  the  bottom  where  I  love 
 this  top  beauty  but  not  so  much  at  the 
 base.  And  that's  exactly  what  they're 
 doing  for  my  girls  here.  I  have  two 
 banana  leaf  croins.  I  brought  these  guys 
 in  at  15gallon  size.  They  are  one  of  my 
 favorite  croins  and  I  don't  get  to  use 
 them  very  often  and  I'll  tell  you  why. 
 They're  like  a  terrible  adolescence. 
 They  have  a  bunch  of  attitude  right  in 
 the  beginning.  They  might  drop  their 
 leaves.  They  might  not  really  flush  out 
 for  a  good  four  to  five  months,  maybe 
 even  6  months  because  this  one  took  a 
 while  and  then  all  of  a  sudden  they  take 
 hold  and  then  they're  beautiful  non-stop 
 from  there.  Like  they  just  flush  out  and 
 then  they  just  have  all  of  this  gorgeous 
 foliage  to  it.  I  hope  it  comes  across  on 
 camera,  but  I  see  this  through  almost 
 every  back  window  of  my  house.  It's 
 absolutely  a  stunner  in  my  space.  And 
 then  when  I  come  out  to  walk  along  this 
 walkway  path,  I  see  them  against  these 
 mammy  croins  and  just  makes  me  smile 
 because  talk  about  your  dark  tones  mixed 
 with  your  light  tones.  These  can  handle 
 two  day  a  week  watering  cycles,  so  they 
 do  not  need  tons  of  water.  This  is  right 
 in  my  particular  spot  of  my  drought 
 tolerant  environment.  Now,  if  you  give 
 them  a  little  bit  more  water,  they  might 
 not  stress  as  much  as  mine  did.  So,  next 
 is  the  Madagascar  palm.  There's  a  love 
 and  hate  relationship  on  YouTube  with 
 this  particular  palm.  I  love  it.  I  know 
 that  there's  a  lot  of  drama  with  all 
 these  spikes.  I  know  it  doesn't  look 
 super  friendly,  but  to  me,  I  like  unique 
 things.  I  like  sculptures  in  the  garden, 
 and  that's  what  this  palm  does  for  me. 
 And  then  it  offers  these  beautiful 
 blooms  after  all  of  the  harshness  of 
 these  thorns.  You're  thinking,  what's  it 
 going  to  do?  And  then  it  pops  out  all 
 summer  long.  Pretty  much  deciduous,  very 
 similar  to  like  the  plumeriia  tree  where 
 a  lot  of  those  leaves  will  fall  and  then 
 all  summer  long.  About  10  months  out  of 
 the  year  here  in  Florida,  we  will  have 
 leaf  cover  and  we  will  have  beautiful 
 blooms.  During  the  rest  of  the  year, 
 we're  going  to  have  a  lot  less  leaves 
 and  then  obviously  no  blooms,  but  we 
 will  have  still  the  sculpture  in  the 
 garden.  And  that's  kind  of  what  I 
 wanted.  I  love  these  octopus  arms  and 
 then  it  offers  those  little  palm  heads 
 to  them  cuz  this  is  not  actually  a  palm 
 tree.  You  know,  I  think  it  deserves  a 
 spot  in  a  tropical  garden.  Even  as  a 
 landscape  designer,  I  try  never  to  put 
 too  many  limitations.  Obviously,  I  want 
 you  guys  to  have  a  symmetrical  planting 
 and  things  to  make  sense,  but  if  there 
 is  something  that  calls  to  my  clients,  I 
 I  fit  that  in  because  that's  what  it 
 means  to  have  your  own  space.  When  I 
 walk  through  here  and  I  see  those  crazy 
 blooms  and  it's  absolutely  gorgeous  and 
 everybody's  like,  "Oh  my  god,  what  is 
 that?"  that  I  know  I  put  the  right  tree 
 in  the  right  spot.  She  will  continue  to 
 grow.  If  you  chop  off  a  head,  she  may 
 produce  another  head  just  right  next  to 
 it.  I'm  so  glad  to  have  my  very  own  in 
 my  own  space.  So,  in  this  next  section, 
 you  guys,  this  is  kind  of  like  the 
 purpose  for  everything  else.  Pulls  all 
 the  other  reasoning  together.  You  know, 
 this  is  the  entrance  way  to  my  garden 
 space.  This  is  the  entrance  way  to  my 
 waterfall  area.  We  are  walking  through 
 my  drainage  easement,  which  is  pretty 
 much  Tahesian  gray  granite  stone.  And 
 then  I  set  some  flag  stone  into  place  to 
 kind  of,  you  know,  meander  through  my 
 garden.  But  you  do  not  need  a  big  lot  to 
 create  that  kind  of  space  for  yourself. 
 The  best  thing  that  you  can  do  is  create 
 a  master  plan  that's  going  to  kind  of 
 get  you  there  and  do  little  pockets  of 
 that  over  the  years.  And  then  if  you're 
 like  me  and  you're  10,  15,  20  years 
 later,  you  know,  however  long  you're  in 
 that  house  and  then  by  the  end  of  that, 
 you  created  a  garden  that  you  can  now 
 not  leave  that  house.  Like  I  could  not 
 leave  this  house  now  because  I 
 absolutely  love  what  we  created.  It's 
 not  the  bedrooms.  It's  not  the  walls. 
 It's  not  the  fans.  It's  not  everything 
 that  I  have  inside.  It's  the  outdoor 
 space  that  went  from  this  big  to  this 
 whole  space  like  this.  This  year,  spend 
 that  on  creating  the  backdrops.  Next 
 year,  create  this  section.  Next  year, 
 create  that  section.  And  so  on.  And  then 
 you  get  what  you  want  at  the  end  of  the 
 day.  Because,  you  know,  landscaping  is 
 expensive.  But  what's  great  about  it, 
 it's  not  like  buying  a  house  all  at 
 once.  It's  you  get  to  see  it  all  grow 
 in.  I  will  never  drive  a  Porsche,  but  I 
 will  have  a  beautiful  backyard  space. 
 So,  all  right.  So,  we're  going to  move 
 on  to  this  little  area  right  here.  Now, 
 this  is  centered  on  my  doorway.  I  knew 
 as  soon  as  I  walked  out  from  my  back 
 door,  I  not  only  wanted  to  see  gardens 
 on  either  side  of  my  seating  sections,  I 
 wanted  to  see  right  off  the  bat  my  water 
 feature  that  is  inset  into  the  backyard 
 slope  that's  in  set  into  the  garden.  I 
 want  it  to  feel  like  it's  all  enveloped. 
 So,  what  I  did  is  make  sure  to  leave  out 
 there's  no  planting  in  this  area  other 
 than  my  two  imperialis  vermilads,  which 
 are  going  to  stay  kind  of  compact  and 
 small  in  this  particular  spot.  And  then 
 a  step  down  boulders  that  have  been 
 sectioned  out  for  steps  and  then  they 
 step  down  into  the  garden  that  allow  me 
 to  walk  this  way  or  that  way  or  allow  me 
 to  see  without  any  type  of  interruption 
 my  backyard  waterfall  which  is  the  focal 
 point  of  my  backyard  space.  It  is  the 
 area  that  I  see  the  most  out  of  every 
 single  seating  section.  And  I  do  this 
 with  all  my  clients.  Whether  it's  a 
 water  feature  or  it's  a  fountain  or  it's 
 a  pergola  or  it's  a  specimen  palm  tree 
 that  you've  always  wanted.  I  put  that 
 right  in  the  forefront.  That  becomes  our 
 focal  point  and  then  we  work  the  garden 
 off  of  that  because  anything  will  get 
 you  to  grab  that  glass  of  wine  at  the 
 end  of  your  day  or  whatever  your 
 beverage  of  choice  is  and  take  that  walk 
 through  your  garden  because  that  is  the 
 thing  that's  going  to  take  and 
 decompress  you.  That's  the  thing  that's 
 going  to  take  and  make  you  say,  "Oh,  I 
 don't  know  why  I'm  in  here.  Let  me  walk 
 out  here."  And  then  just  kind  of  kind  of 
 come  out  here  and  sit  and  relax.  Well, 
 you  guys,  thank  you  so  much  for  joining 
 us  in  today's  garden  tour.  If  you 
 enjoyed  this  one,  then  check  out  last 
 week's  garden  tour  of  the  other  side  of 
 my  space.  And  please  list  your  favorite 
 plant  or  tree  that  we  discussed  today. 
 And  I  would  love  to  know  what  struck 
 just  struck  a  chord  with  you  in  our 
 particular  backyard.  Thank  you  guys  so 
 much.  Take  care.  See  you  next  week.

 it's  a  pretty  good  choice  if  you  have 
 kind  of  a  narrow  area  that  you  want  to 
 get  some  really  good  coverage  in.  So, 
 I'm  going  to  let  Matt  explain  it  to  you 
 guys. 
 >> That's  clumping  bamboo. 
 Clumping.  But  the  ones  back  here  are  the 
 easiest  ones  to  look  at.  Clumping  bamboo 
 will  stay  real  tight  together  like  this. 
 Or  running  bamboo,  if  you  plant  it  here, 
 it  might  pop  up  on  the  other  side  of 
 your  driveway  or  the  sidewalk.  Trimming 
 bamboo  is  really  nice,  too.  These 
 bamboos,  like  this  one  here  in 
 particular,  this  bamboo  gets  15  ft  tall. 
 We  keep  it  at  this  nice  hedge  right  here 
 at  well,  this  one's  about  2  ft.  This  one 
 back  here,  this  is  25,  30  foot  bamboos. 
 Back  at  our  office,  we  keep  them  about 
 12  ft.  some  of  them  six  feet.  You  got  to 
 trim  them  a  little  more  often  in  the 
 summer,  very  little  in  the  winter.  Once 
 you  cut  bamboo,  it  stops  growing  up  and 
 starts  pushing  out  laterally.  So,  the 
 more  you  trim  it,  the  more  you're  going 
 to  get  thicker.  You're  just  going  to 
 have  a  nice  almost  a  zero  lot  line  with 
 this  stuff.  It's  fantastic.  Stay  away 
 from  the  running  bamboo,  though, 
 especially  in  Florida  cuz  it  just  grows 
 and  grows  and  grows.  Might  even  be 
 illegal  in  Florida.  Fact  check  me  on 
 that  one.  But  nonetheless,  the  bigger 
 the  coms  though,  the  further  they're 
 going  to  spread  out,  but  they're  going 
 to  stay  tight  together.  This  is  my 
 favorite.  This  is  dwarf  Buddha  belly 
 bamboo.  Gets  about  15  feet  tall.  I  think 
 it  has  a  great  Dr.  Seuss  look  to  it. 
 Putting  it  up  against  the  wall.  This 
 bamboo  is  usually  open  at  the  bottom 
 like  this.  When  it's  younger,  it'll  be 
 full,  but  eventually  get  naturally  like 
 this.  We  didn't  do  this.  Golden  goddess. 
 It's  a  multiplex.  Gets  real  thick.  You 
 can  see  all  the  coms  in  here.  Golden 
 gods  bamboo.  This  one  back  here  by  far 
 the  most  common  one  we  sell  popular. 
 This  is  graceful  bamboo  or  texiles 
 graasilus.  Fantastic.  Another  one  of  my 
 favorites,  Asian  lemon  bamboo.  This 
 golden  butterly  uh  coms  with  these  green 
 highlights  in  them.  That's  why  we 
 trimmed  it  up  like  this  about  2  to  3  ft. 
 So  you  can  see  this  again  against  a  wall 
 or  a  fence.  Fantastic. 
 >> Beautiful. 
 >> Yeah.  I  love  it.  And  then  the  new 
 growth.  This  one  right  here.  It  looks

 >> It  sure  does. 
 >> Yeah.  Yeah.

 This  dark  green  is  one  of  those  things 
 that  are  hard  to  keep  when  you  have  a 
 ramp.  So,  that's  why  the  good  soil  is  so 
 important  for  these  particular  trees 
 because  they  can  really  be  deficient  in

 turn  a  little  bit  golden,  especially  if 
 they're  in  the  sun.  All right,  you  guys. 
 So,  we  popped  in  real  quick  to  Epic 
 Stone  Works.  This  is  a  super  cool 
 product  that  is  actually  native  to 
 Florida  that's  made  here  that  these  guys 
 are  harvesting  and  creating  these 
 beautiful  displays.  And  Michael  here  is 
 going  to  tell  us  a  little  bit  about  it. 
 >> This  is  a  a  local  material  that  we're 
 producing  down  in  our  mine  in  Florida 
 City.  This  comes  anywhere  between  30  ft 
 to  70  ft  below  the  surface.  When  you 
 start  to  get  to  those  depths,  the 
 compaction,  the  heat,  and  the  actual 
 composition  of  the  material  changes.  So 
 we  switch  from  a  porous  material  like 
 you  see  here  with  the  Oolite.  This  is  a 
 topical  material,  very  soft.  It's  right 
 there  at  the  surface.  And  then  when  you 
 go  down  to  the  depths  of  what  we're 
 talking  about  with  the  Hemingway,  you 
 switch  over  to  a  more  shell  riddled 
 material.  It's  got  quartz  side.  It 
 shines  and  it's  very  white.  So  it's  a 
 very  dense  material  as  well. 
 >> These  are  cut  not  to  a  specific  pattern 
 or  they're 
 >> This  is  what  we  call  our  flagstone 
 format.  So  it's  very  natural.  We 
 basically  slice  the  boulders  like  a  loaf 
 of  bread.  And  these  are  2-in  slices. 
 That's  what  gives  us  the  natural  shape 
 of  that  material. 
 >> How  cool. 
 >> So,  this  is  the  most  natural  planter 
 that  we  offer.  We  call  it  our  boulder 
 planter.  Um,  so  what  we've  done 
 basically  is  taken  a  natural  boulder  out 
 of  the  ground  and  cut  the  flat  top  and 
 bottom.  And  after  we  do  that,  we  come 
 back  and  t  it  into  the  actual  trough 
 that  you  see  there.  This  is  actually  a

 [Music] 
 So,  I  know  oftent  times  you  guys  when 
 we're  putting  together  designs  or  when 
 you  guys  are  calling  in  and  you're 
 shopping  at  nurseries,  you're  looking  at 
 the  difference  of  field  grown  material 
 over  potted  material.  Most  nurseries 
 carry  mostly  potted  material,  but  in 
 some  cases,  if  you're  working  with  a 
 landscape  company  and  they  have  the 
 machinery  to  move  it,  you  can  really 
 tell  the  difference  with  fieldgrown 
 material.  Well,  this  is  called  ENB  and 
 it's  burlap  wrapped  and  this  is  what  a 
 lot  of  landscapers  choose.  Obviously, 
 the  effort  of  the  installation  is 
 involved.  You  could  install  a  tree  that 
 is  more  established,  that's  more  dense, 
 that's  really  just  an  overall  chunkier, 
 fuller  caliber  kind  of  tree  over  a 
 potted  tree  that  might  be  the  same  size, 
 but  you  can  really  see  the  significant 
 difference.  These  are  all  field  grown 
 trees,  and  you  really  feel  like  these 
 guys  have  had  some  growth.  Now,  if  this 
 tree  were  in  a  pot,  it  would  be  in  a 
 65gallon  pot  and  it  would  be  about  half 
 the  size,  half  of  the  thickness  that  you 
 see  in  this  trunk.  It  would  be  much  much 
 more  narrow  and  the  canopy  because  it's 
 in  a  smaller  pot.  The  canopy  itself 
 would  be  more  condensed.  They  wouldn't 
 be  as  aggressive.  They  would  be  more 
 like  in  line  with  this  and  more 
 vertical.  So,  if  you  have  the  option,  if 
 there's  choice  involved  and  you  can  go 
 with  field  grow  material,  always  go  that 
 way  because  I  try  to  go  that  way  when  I 
 can.  All right,  you  guys.  So,  you  know 
 that  I'm  always  stressing  about  really 
 taking  good  care  of  your  plants  and  your 
 trees.  That's  the  best  way  to  protect 
 your  investment,  everything  that  you  put 
 into  it.  So,  I'm  here  with  Gary  at 
 Perfect  Palm  and  he's  going  to  just  kind 
 of  explain  a  little  bit  about  his 
 product. 
 >> So,  Perfect  Palm  was  developed  through 
 decades  of  actually  using  other  products 
 and  finding  the  shortcomings  and 
 pitfalls  of  those  that  just  didn't  work 
 across  everything  in  the  industry  for 
 containers,  in  ground,  and  fertilizer 
 that  can  be  used  at  the  time  of 
 planting.  And  as  growers  ourselves,  we 
 needed  something  that  would  work  across 
 the  board  on  everything  instead  of 
 having  to  blend  over  and  over  again  for 
 ourselves  or  customers.  So  through  years 
 of  research  and  trying  different 
 products  and  methods  and  feeding 
 techniques,  we  came  up  with  perfect  palm 
 fertilizer  years  ago  and  then 
 incorporated  the  newest  coatings,  XCU 
 coatings,  and  made  a  new  feeding  method 
 of  smaller  spoon  feeding  methods  to 
 where  you  use  light  feeding  more  often. 
 So  it  reduces  the  chance  of  leeching, 
 runoff,  and  harmful  environmental  uh 
 factors  that  outdated  fertilizers  did 
 that  only  fed  a  few  times  a  year  doing 
 much  heavier  feedings.  So  this  is  much 
 more  ecologically  friendly.  You  can 
 reuse  the  pales.  It's  got  the  scoopers 
 in  there,  which  the  customers  are 
 finding  easy  to  use.  And  it  has  dual 
 forms  of  ingredients,  which  a  lot  of the 
 other  fertilizers  don't.  Uh  if  your  pH 
 is  neutral,  sometimes  iron  or  magnesium 
 doesn't  uptake.  So  we  included  two  forms 
 of  that  as  well.  and  very  high  levels  of 
 nutrients.  So,  it's  not  a  lot  of 
 fillers.  So,  without  the  fillers,  it 
 allows  us  to  use  smaller  amounts  more 
 often  and  even  get  better  results.  You 
 can  use  it  year  round  and  even  if  you're 
 in  northern  Florida  or  areas  of  cold,  it 
 can  even  increase  their  cold  tolerance 
 and  boost  their  resilience  after  the 
 freeze  because  you  can  get  freeze 
 induced  deficiencies  of  boron  and 
 manganesees. 
 So,  a  lot  of  this  has  been  backed  by 
 studies  of  the  University  of  Florida  and 
 the  potassium  levels,  the  uptake  in 
 those  actually  increase  their  hardiness 
 for  freeze  prior  to  the  freeze  as  well. 
 So,  it's  one  of  the  few  products  that's 
 out  right  now  that  you  can  use  um  for 
 inground  and  container  material  and  even 
 at  the  time  of  install.  So,  it's  great 
 for  installs  um  follow-up  care, 
 maintenance,  and  use  on  all  different 
 palms. 
 >> As  soon  as  I  was  talking  to  Gary,  I  was

 Well,  hello  gardeners.  Welcome  to  my 
 backyard.  Today  we  are  going  to  do  an 
 in-depth  garden  tour  of  my  backyard 
 space.  I  think  it's  going  to  allow  you 
 to  choose  a  lot  of  different  species  and 
 varieties  throughout  our  Florida 
 tropical  gardens.  So,  for  those  of  you 
 guys  who  are  new  to  this  channel,  my 
 name  is  Jennifer  Beaven.  I  am  a 
 landscape  designer  here  in  Vero  Beach, 
 Florida,  zone  10A.  We  service  along  the 
 Treasure  and  Space  Coast,  and  we  also  do 
 designs  throughout  the  state  of  Florida 
 and  virtual  consults.  So  check  us  out  if 
 this  is  the  kind  of  style  you're  looking 
 for.  But  for  now,  let's  just  talk  about 
 plants  and  trees  because  I  am  a 
 landscape  designer  and  have  been  for  a 
 long,  long  time.  But  I'm  a  gardener 
 first.  I  love  working  in  my  garden.  I 
 love  creating  new  fields  and  new  spaces. 
 However,  I'm  not  the  biggest  fan  of 
 maintenance.  So  you're  going to  notice 
 in  my  particular  garden,  I  designed  it 
 to  help  me  minimize  the  amount  of 
 maintenance  involved  with  a  Florida 
 gardens.  I'll  kind  of  explain  why  as  we 
 go  into  certain  plants  and  trees  and 
 what  they  offer  in  the  gardens.  So,  I'm 
 going  to  get  Bryce  to  kind  of  turn 
 around  and  you  guys  will  see  my 
 neighbor's  backyard  where  they've  kind 
 of  allowed  it  just  to  be  a  full  backyard 
 with  very  little  landscaping.  They've 
 just  kept  more  open  space. 
 We're  on  about  a  quarter  of  an  acre. 
 Now,  they  actually  have  more  backyard 
 space  than  we  have.  So,  we  have  pretty 
 much  about  right  off  the  foundation  of 
 our  house  line.  We've  got  a  12t  patio 
 that  runs  along  the  length  of  my  house. 
 Then  we've  got  this  little  9  to  10  foot 
 walkway  space  which  is  pretty  much  a 
 drainage  easement  here  right  through  the 
 middle.  And  this  has  become  our  walkway 
 area  because  we  just  could  not  get  grass 
 to  grow.  And  then  we  took  the  remainder 
 of  the  property  line  which  is  about  16 
 to  18t  deep  and  it  goes  up  at  kind  of a 
 slant  like  you  saw  my  neighbors  did.  And 
 we've  created  a  layered  backyard 
 landscape. 
 All  right.  So,  we  are  here  at  the  edge 
 of  my  property  line.  I  pretty  much 
 landscape  from  one  end  of  the  property 
 line  to  the  other.  This  is  my  finishing 
 point.  Right  on  the  other  side  of  this 
 hedge  here  is  my  neighbor's  property. 
 So,  we  wanted  to  make  sure  that  we 
 started  with  something  that  was  an 
 aggressive  grower,  something  that  was  a 
 good  dense  grower,  kind  of  a  sound 
 barrier,  a  tall  plant  that  we  could  work 
 with.  So,  we  have  the  Kucia  hedge  that 
 runs  the  length  from  the  corner  of  this 
 drainage  easement  all  the  way  up  to  the 
 edge  of  my  rear  property  line  back 
 there.  I  have  a  love  affair  with  this 
 plant  because  of  its  durability,  its 
 versatility,  and  just  overall  toughness 
 of  Florida  environment.  So,  it  is  a 
 fantastic  plant  to  use.  Can  be  a  little 
 cold  sensitive  in  the  northern  areas  of 
 Florida.  So,  anything  I  would  say  above 
 Satellite  Beach,  I'd  probably  steer  away 
 from  it.  A  little  too  burnt,  too 
 aggressive.  However,  it  they  are  such 
 such  an  aggressive  grower  that  you  know 
 if  you  do  get  some  burn  back,  you  trim 
 it  and  then  let  it  flush  back  out.  So, 
 it  is  just  such  a  great  grower.  Um,  they 
 do  like  proper  drainage.  So,  you  want  to 
 make  sure  you  plant  them  a  little  bit 
 high  if  they're  going  to  be  in  a  low 
 area.  You'll  notice  that  because  my 
 landscaping  really  likes  a  lot  of  water, 
 I  have  it  set  on  that  slope  and 
 everything  drains  straight  down.  So,  it 
 really,  really  works  really  well  as  the 
 water  drains  all  this  way  and  this  way. 
 So,  that's  a  great  environment  for  it. 
 If  you're  on  flat  land,  just  plant  the 
 Kooi  a  tad  bit  high  to  make  sure  that 
 water  doesn't  sit  on  those  roots.  There 
 are  roof  lines  and  houses  pretty  much 
 everywhere.  We  are  in  a  a  typical 
 suburban  neighborhood,  houses  on  the 
 side,  roof  lines  to  the  back,  big 
 community,  and  a  big  clubhouse  area  over 
 in  that  rear  side.  So,  this  is  something 
 that  I  knew  I  wanted  to  make  sure  that 
 became  very  private  over  time.  And  it 
 really  has.  I  really  feel  like  we  are 
 nice  and  secluded  and  tucked  into  this 
 space,  which  was  the  goal,  you  guys. 
 Now,  this  was  kind  of  a  little 
 makeshift.  This  is  a  drainage  easement. 
 I  still  wanted  coverage  here.  I  feel 
 like  I'm  getting  coverage  from 
 everywhere  from  all  my  neighbors.  I 
 couldn't  plant  right  in  the  center  of 
 this  drainage  easement  because  in 
 terrible  storms,  this  area  right  here 
 will  fill  up  with  water.  So,  what  I 
 tried  to  do  was  take  plants  or  trees 
 that  are  going  to  kind  of  grow  up  and 
 out  and  over  top  of  this  area.  So,  these 
 guys  are  going  to  search  for  the  sun. 
 And  these  are  plumeriia.  These  are  pink, 
 yellow,  and  white  blooms  on  the 
 plumeriia.  Unfortunately,  nobody's 
 blooming  today.  But  these  giant  leaves 
 offer  kind  of  just  that  bit  of 
 concealment,  that  bit  of  tropical 
 thickness  or  fullness  and  what  would 
 naturally  be  a  very  open  area.  So,  if 
 you  guys  have  a  similar  situation  and 
 you're  trying  to  get  something  to  branch 
 over  into  that  area,  a  great  branching 
 plant  is  plumeriia.  They'll  do  a 
 fantastic  job  of  following  the  sun.  So 
 they'll  come  in  this  way,  cross  each 
 other,  really  find  little  interesting 
 grape  viny  trunks.  I'm  hoping  in  time  as 
 these  guys  get  bigger  and  come  over 
 here,  I'll  hang  different  types  of 
 birdhouses  or  bird  feeders  or  something 
 underneath  of  those  trunks,  utilizing 
 that  kind  of  cool  look  and  then  kind  of 
 also  filling  this  space  as  these  guys 
 get  tall.  The  next  tree  that  I  chose 
 that  I  planted  kind  of  at  an  angle  is 
 this  double  bottle  palm.  Now,  I  planted 
 him,  he  was  very  young  and  small  when  I 
 put  him  in.  It's  really  starting  to  take 
 off  and  grow  in  our  Florida  summer  this 
 year,  but  it  is  going  to  naturally  come 
 over  and  completely  conceal  this  corner. 
 So,  this  frond  that's  here  when  it's 
 full  grown  is  going  to  be  14t  wide  and 
 they're  going  to  come  out  just  like  this 
 and  fill  this  whole  space.  No  opening 
 here  between  this  guy  and  the 
 neighboring  plantings  next  to  us.  This 
 is  going  to  be  a  very  full  ending  to  my 
 landscape.  and  that's  what  I  wanted  all 
 the  way  around  concealment,  but  I  had  to 
 deal  with  a  drainage  easement  that 
 wouldn't  allow  me  to  have  plantings  all 
 the  way  through.  So,  this  is  the  best  I 
 could  do  with  that  spot.  We  have  a 
 flagstone  walkway  that  leads  through  the 
 drainage  easement.  This  is  fairly  new.  I 
 am  in  love  with  it.  Creating  little 
 walkway  space,  little  open  areas  that 
 lead  out  to  an  area  that  you  can  drop 
 some  debris  behind  your  planting  is 
 go-to.  I  have  them  in  several  areas  of 
 my  garden.  That's  an  easy  way  to 
 maintain  your  garden  because  there's 
 always  going  to  be  that  in  Florida. 
 Sometimes  it's  just  as  easy  as  walking 
 through  your  garden  for  five  or  6 
 minutes  and  clip  something  that's  just  a 
 little  unsightly  and  stick  it  back  there 
 or  grab  a  frond  that's  kind  of  fallen 
 and  put  it  back  there.  And  voila,  you're 
 not  working  in  the  garden.  You're  not 
 distracted.  You're  back  up  there  having 
 that  cup  of  coffee  or  that  glass  of  wine 
 and  spending  more  time  up  there  than  in 
 your  garden.  The  showstopper  right  here 
 that's  the  only  one  that's  in  bloom 
 right  now  is  the  pigota.  The  pigota  is  a 
 beautiful  summertime  bloomer  with  that 
 orange  flame.  Oh  my  goodness.  I  just 
 cannot  think  of  of  a  plant  that  really 
 shows  off  more  than  this  plant  and 
 blooms  so  often.  Sometimes  I  get  blooms 
 even  in  the  winter.  You  do  have  to 
 really  stick  with  the  maintenance  on 
 this.  When  I  talked  about  some  of  the 
 plants  in  my  garden  being 
 lowmaintenance,  I  would  say  a  good  90% 
 of  them  are.  This  gal  is  not.  She  does 
 need  to  be  cut  in  the  winter.  She  can 
 get  a  little  bit  thin,  not  as 
 attractive,  but  all  summer  long  she 
 blooms.  She  has  these  big  giant  leaves 
 and  it  just  has  an  interesting  look.  But 
 what  she  does  do  is  she  invites  her 
 friends  and  her  family  and  you  know 
 and  offers  little  popups  of  new  pagotas 
 everywhere.  If  you  like  this  plant,  make 
 sure  that  you  really  like  it  and  you 
 leave  a  spot  out  for  her  invite  her 
 friends  because  that's  exactly  what'll 
 happen.  And  the  good  thing  about  it  is 
 it's  very  easy  to  pop  up  and  propagate 
 if  you  want  to  move  it  or  gift  it  to  a 
 neighbor  or  a  friend  or  a  family.  So,  I 
 do  that  about  twice  a  year  where  I'll 
 select  the  ones  that  I  don't  want  and 
 pop  them  up  and  get  rid  of  them.  To  the 
 back  of  her,  um,  these  guys  are  not 
 right  now  in  bloom,  but  this  beautiful 
 collection  of  my  buffer  here  is  the 
 Brazilian  red  cloaks.  Oh  my  goodness. 
 Same  big  giant  leaf  does  not  spread  like 
 the  pigota  does  or  offer  little  runners 
 or  pups  that  go  everywhere.  It  is  a 
 plant  that  absolutely  loves  to  connect 
 together,  becomes  a  solid  wall,  and 
 really  just  does  a  gorgeous  job  of 
 becoming  a  red  showstopper  when  it's  in 
 bloom.  It  does  bloom  most  summers.  It 
 does  bloom  in  filtered  light,  full  sun. 
 It  can  get  a  little  thirsty.  So,  if  you 
 guys  are  going  to  put  it  in  full  sun, 
 make  sure  that  you  have  an  irrigation 
 head  nearby  that  does  spray  and  hit  all 
 of  the  roots  of  these  guys  because  they 
 can  get  a  little  bit  little  bit  thirsty 
 in  that  heat.  But,  they  will  bloom  more 
 in  the  full  sun.  So,  it's  definitely 
 worth  having  a  little  extra  water.  This 
 area  is  more  shady,  but  it  does  bloom 
 pretty  often  here  as  well.  Down  below, 
 I've  had  these  guys  for  ages.  This  is 
 the  gold  dust  croin.  One  of  my  favorite 
 croins  to  use.  Beautiful  leaflet 
 coloring  variegation  in  here.  Just  a 
 nice  compact  chunky  little  collection.  I 
 love  to  pair  these  with  a  dark  green. 
 So,  if  you  have  something  like  this  and 
 then  you  have  something  dark  green 
 behind  it,  it's  just  such  a  gorgeous 
 combination.  I  think  that  they  work 
 really,  really  well  together.  So,  it's 
 just  a  collection  of  three  of  those.  I 
 brought  them  in  at  seven  gallon  size  and 
 then  I  have  one  anchor  in  the  other  side 
 of  the  walkway.  And  just  what  a  nice 
 little  grouping  of  Croin  that  can  handle 
 filtered  light.  Now,  this  Croin  variety, 
 you  can  tell  right  here,  this  particular 
 one  over  on  this  side  and  that  middle 
 get  more  sun  than  the  other  Croins.  You 
 can  see  the  difference  what  you're  going 
 to  get  in  a  full  sun  environment.  This 
 is  what  the  leaf  coloring  is  going  to 
 look  like  for  this  particular  gold  dust 
 croin.  And  then  in  the  shade  leaflet 
 coloring  is  going  to  look  like  in  the 
 same  variety  of  croin.  And  I  don't know, 
 you  pick.  But  I  think  they're  both  very 
 pretty.  Now,  this  down  here  is  um  a 
 landscaper  mistake.  So,  even  doing  this 
 for  as  long  as  I'm  doing  this,  I  still 
 make  my  mistakes.  this  little  area.  I 
 thought  I  had  enough  shade  coverage 
 between  this  grouping  here  and  thinking 
 that  this  bottle  palm  was  going  to  get 
 big  enough  to  shade  this  little 
 collection  of  ground  orchids.  Trying 
 them,  giving  a  little  bit  more  time.  But 
 you  can  see  the  sunburn  on  these  guys. 
 These  bloom  a  beautiful  pink  flower. 
 Believe  it  or  not,  I  have  some  that  get 
 afternoon  sun,  but  they  only  get  it  for 
 about  2  hours,  and  they're  doing 
 beautifully.  They're  blooming  more. 
 They're  very  happy.  It's  such  a  balance 
 of  where  to  place  your  plants  that  it 
 really  matters.  So  over  here  I  have  a 
 large  ora  palm.  Now  I  have  trimmed  and 
 trimmed  on  her.  She's  got  multiple 
 stocks.  She's  recently  been  trimmed  so 
 she's  a  little  bit  more  narrow  than  she 
 normally  is.  Normally  I  let  her  become 
 nice  and  full  and  thick  so  that  way  I 
 can't  really  see  to  the  back  of  her. 
 This  tree  for  the  longest  time, 
 literally  for  10  years,  has  been  my 
 blockage  from  the  house  directly  behind 
 me,  from  the  pool  screen  directly  behind 
 me.  This  tree  was  a  tree  that  blocked  it 
 all.  So  now  that  the  other  trees  have 
 grown  in  and  the  Kucia  have  grown  in, 
 I've  cut  this  tree  back  because  I  don't 
 necessarily  need  that  much  density  in 
 this  spot  and  I  wanted  to  see  a  little 
 bit  more  to  the  backside  of  it.  So  you 
 know,  it's  amazing  how  landscapes  can  do 
 that.  They  really  can  solve  a  problem 
 right  off  the  bat  for  four  or  five,  six 
 years  and  then  as  your  other  landscapes 
 caught  up  then  now  you  might  not  need 
 that  for  that.  So  you  can  address  and 
 adjust  based  on  what  your  needs  are.  I 
 hear  people  say,  "Well,  I  don't  want  a 
 tree  that's  going  to  get  too  tall  and 
 out  of  sight."  Well,  I  I  get  that,  but 
 they  need  immediate  coverage.  Sometimes 
 it's  good  to  go  with  something  like  that 
 that  grows  fast,  that's  going  to  give 
 you  almost  immediate  coverage  and  then 
 plant  on  the  next  phase  of  your 
 landscaping  to  catch  up  with  that.  So, 
 when  that  tree  does  become  too  large, 
 you  know,  maybe  10  years  later,  then  it 
 might  be  time  to  either  remove  the  tree 
 or  cut  it  back.  So,  the  tree  is  no 
 longer  the  focal  point,  but  all  the 
 landscaping  around  it  has  grown  in  and 
 kind  of  taken  over  the  job.  It's  like 
 they've  stepped  into  the  shadow  of  that 
 tree  and  now  become  the  focal  point 
 themselves.  So,  I  think  that  that's 
 great.  So,  think  of  your  landscaping  as 
 an  evolving  situation  because  that's 
 what  gardens  do.  That's  why  gardens 
 become  such  a  big  part  of  us.  They  take 
 on  a  life  of  their  own  and  you  find 
 yourself  walking  through  them.  I  don't 
 know,  maybe  I'm  crazy.  Maybe  I'm  the 
 only  one  that  does  that.  But  you  find 
 yourself  walking  through  them  going, 
 "Oh,  hello.  Look  at  you.  You're 
 blooming.  Look  at  you.  You're  happy. 
 Look  at  you.  You're  not.  What's  going 
 on?"  That's  why  gardens  are  so  pleasant. 
 So  right  here  we  have  a  Malayan  coconut 
 palm.  Now  they're  more  in  the  dwarf 
 varieties  of  coconut  palms.  They  have  a 
 nice  chunky  trunk.  Takes  them  a  while  to 
 really  get  some  good  size  to  them.  They 
 still  produce  coconuts  like  crazy.  This 
 guy  has  been  in  the  ground  for  10  years. 
 So  really  established,  but  I  hear  all 
 the  time  where  people  put  a  coconut  palm 
 in  at  6t  tall  and  then  2  years  later 
 it's  20  foot  tall.  It's  not  usually  the 
 case.  But  with  Malayans,  it's  really  not 
 the  case.  Malayans  grow  slower.  They're 
 more  of  a  compact  canopy  to  them.  They 
 have  a  little  bit  of  a  chunkier  base  and 
 they  just  take  a  little  bit  more  time  to 
 get  to  that  size.  So,  if  you  want 
 something  that  sticks  around  in  the 
 garden  a  little  bit  longer,  your 
 Malayans  are  the  way  to  go.  To  the  back 
 is  a  spindle  palm  that  is  struggling 
 because  it's  not  getting  tons  of  light. 
 To  the  right  over  there  is  another 
 Malayan.  You  guys  know  the  queen  of  my 
 heart  is  the  Queen  Emma.  This  is  the 
 perfect  environment  for  a  Queen  Emma.  If 
 you  guys  have  a  queen  Emma  and  you  have 
 a  little  protection  from  whatever  tree, 
 it  could  be  an  oak  tree,  it  could  be  any 
 kind  of  hardwood  tree,  it  could  be  a 
 palm  tree,  they  love  a  little  bit  of 
 filter  light  where  their  leaves  are 
 getting  sunlight  through  them,  but 
 they're  not  getting  the  harsh  direct 
 rays.  When  that  happens,  they  get  this 
 beautiful  purple  tones  to  the  leaves. 
 So,  you  get  this  gorgeous  all  the  new 
 growth  has  more  purple  in  it  and  then 
 you  have  that  striking  green  to  the 
 center  and  then  of  course  this  beautiful 
 fragrant  bloom  that  they  offer.  is  such 
 a  stunner.  That  bloom  will  last  for  a 
 good  month.  Sometimes  I'll  get  multiple 
 ones  at  a  time.  It  seems  like  it's 
 always  blooming  all  summer  long.  They 
 start  early  spring  and  bloom  all  summer. 
 I  even  had  a  couple  this  winter.  So,  as 
 long  as  they're  happy,  I  find  that  they 
 bloom  pretty  much  that  they  show  their 
 appreciation  by  blooming  and  I 
 appreciate  their  appreciation.  So,  I 
 think  it's  great.  Down  below  are  my 
 sanchesia.  I  love  love love  Sancheesia. 
 They're  a  soft  plant.  They  do  need  some 
 filtered  protection.  They  can  handle 
 full  sun,  but  they  will  bleach  out  a 
 little  bit  and  they  will  need  a  little 
 extra  water  if  you're  planning  on 
 putting  them  in  the  full  sun.  But  some 
 filtered  light  like  we  have  here,  they 
 do  great.  Now,  along  this  edge  gets  more 
 sun  than  inside,  and  the  leaf  color  will 
 change.  They'll  be  a  little  bit  brighter 
 on  the  edges  where  you  get  sun,  where 
 you  get  more  shade,  they'll  be  a  little 
 bit  more  of  that  darker,  and  the  yellow 
 will  go  almost  white  versus  yellow.  But 
 the  reason  why  I  have  them  here  is 
 because  the  Queen  Emma  is  gorgeous  as  it 
 pops  up  like  out  of  a  birthday  cake 
 here.  But  the  bottom  stock,  it's 
 something  that  I  like  to  hide.  So  I 
 usually  when  I  have  a  tree  like  that, 
 I'll  put  a  skirt  planting,  something 
 chunky  and  full  and  lower  and  compact 
 that  will  really  fill  up  the  base  of 
 this  planting.  So  that  way  you  go  from  a 
 sea  of  these  to  that  upright  look  of 
 this  guy  popping  out  of  the  middle  of 
 it.  And  that's  what  these  are  great  for. 
 I  could  have  continued  on  with  the 
 sloppy  painters.  Those  would  have 
 worked.  Or  a  different  Croin  variety. 
 Those  would  have  worked  too.  But  what  I 
 do  like  about  Sanchezia  is  they  stay 
 chunky.  They  stay  full.  See,  they  kind 
 of  move  like  this.  They'll  move  in  the 
 wind.  And  that's  what  I  love  about  them. 
 They're  just  not  a  harsh  hedge  in  any 
 sort  of  the  way.  That  also  means  if  you 
 only  have  two  of  these  guys,  there's  not 
 a  lot  of  support  system  for  them.  They 
 do  like  to  be  planted  in  a  drift  like 
 this.  They  really  really  will  connect 
 together,  become  just  a  little  sturdier. 
 They  just  do  so  well  like  that.  But  I  I 
 love  the  way  they  look.  I  love  their 
 tender,  soft,  big  giant  leaf.  And  I 
 think  that  they're  just  so  tropical.  I 
 will  put  them  and  let  them  just  kind  of 
 fall  over  top  of  my  beauty  edging.  I'm 
 not  a  big  fan  of  big  heavy  edge  lines. 
 So,  I  love  the  Beauty  Edging  for  what  it 
 does.  It's  definitely  a  fantastic 
 product.  That  composite  edging,  I  know 
 it's  here  to  stay,  but  I  also  like  it 
 interrupted  a  little bit.  I  like  more  of 
 that  natural  look.  You'll  see  all  the 
 way  through  my  walkway  space,  I've  done 
 the  same  thing  where  I've  taken  spots 
 where  you  can  distinctly  see  the  edging 
 and  it's  nice  and  clean  line.  And  then 
 I'll  blur  it  a  little  bit  with  the 
 plants,  letting  them  overhang  like  my 
 burl  marks  or  my  St.  Cheese  ear  or 
 whatnot  as  we  walk  through  the  garden 
 cuz  I  like  that  organic  mix.  On  this 
 side  of  the  garden  here,  I  have  a 
 gardinia  tree.  Of  course,  she's  done  her 
 blooming  cycles  during  Mother's  Day,  but 
 she's  still  got  some  green  on  her.  I 
 only  plant  Gardinia  trees  when  I  know 
 the  soil  is  really  good.  Her  pH  levels 
 are  a  little  bit  finicky  here  in 
 Florida.  She's  happy  here,  and  she  is 
 right  on  this  corner.  And  when  she's  in 
 bloom,  it's  like,  oo,  it  just  smells  so 
 good  out  here.  It's  a  perfect  fragrance 
 to  have  near  a  seeding  section.  So,  if 
 you're  going  to  try  one,  put  them  near 
 anywhere  the  seeding  section.  If  you 
 can't  control  the  pH  or,  you  know,  you 
 struggle  with,  you  know,  good  soil  in 
 your  area,  get  a  nice  big  low  belly  pot. 
 Something  that's  kind  of  really  wide  and 
 chunky.  It  doesn't  have  to  be  deep. 
 They're  not  deep  rooers,  but  nice  and 
 broad  and  wide,  like  a  big  bowl.  Put 
 that  girl  in  there,  and  then  make  sure 
 that  she's  got  really  good  soil  for  a 
 gardinia.  And  then  you're  going  to  have 
 a  fantastic  blooming  tree  that's  going 
 to  be  near  your  seeding  section  that  you 
 get  to  really  enjoy.  I  have  another 
 pathway  that  leaves  as  like  a  little 
 maintenance  pathway.  And  then  I  have  a 
 little  Laquala  palm.  That  Laquala  palm  I 
 have  been  babying  for  years.  They  are 
 slow  growers.  They  do  like  shade.  She 
 kind  of  can  be  a  bit  of a  diva.  They 
 can't  handle  anything  below  32.  They 
 will  really  be  upset  with  you  if  that's 
 the  case.  So  you  want  to  cover  them  or 
 put  them  in  a  pot  in  the  garden  and 
 bring  them  in  during  your  cold  snaps. 
 We've  gotten  a  little  bit  below  32.  I've 
 not  had  to  cover  because  of  all  the 
 exterior  foliage  that  I  have.  This 
 microclimate  has  done  its  own  job  of 
 really  creating  kind  of  a  cove  for  my 
 landscaping.  I  get  very,  very  little,  if 
 any,  lost  from  freezes  here  because  of 
 that.  Because  they  do  have  these  giant 
 paddle  leaves,  they  don't  like  a  lot  of 
 wind.  So,  if  you've  got  a  courtyard  or  a 
 walled  area  or,  you  know,  a  sideyard 
 where  there's  some  additional  palm  trees 
 that  are  netted  real  close.  I'll  get 
 Bryce  to  pop  in  a  picture  of  the  little 
 quala  palm  that  we  have  further  down. 
 That's  kind  of  in  a  cove  area  of  palms

 fronds  are  bigger.  They  don't  have  so 
 many  rips  in  them.  It's  just  a  happier, 
 happier  tree.  So,  these  guys  are 
 fantastic  to  work  with,  but  when  they're

 showstoppers.  They're  the  things  that

 because  that  is  exactly  where  they  need 
 to  go.  Right  here,  I  have  the  silver  bay

 lowlight  plant  grouping.  Excellent  to

 These  guys  only  need  3  hours  of  sun  to

 little  spot  because  they  get  this  angled

 corner  area  here.  So,  this  is  a  spot

 these  guys  were  okay  because  they  were 
 protected  here.  So,  I  needed  something 
 with  some  color  here.  That's  what's

 requires  a  whole  different  look  because 
 the  amount  of  sun  that  it's  getting.  So, 
 this  is  a  pop  of  color  right  here  just

 All  this  craziness  that  you  see  here  is 
 creeping  fig.  If  you  guys  are  trying  to 
 naturalize  some  rocks  or  an  old  wall  or 
 even  make  a  green  wall  space,  uh 
 creeping  fig  is  perfect  for  that  because 
 it  will  stick  to  hard  surface  and  climb 
 its  way  up.  I've  got  a  mix  of  burmilads 
 here.  I've  got  some  Johannes  bmilads 
 here,  a  little  Don  Juan  burmilad  down

 is  in  the  shade  underneath  this 
 Laquala's  big  fronds  here.  and  it's  in 
 bloom.  I  have  a  foxtail  agave  just  kind 
 of  popping  out  there.  If  you  guys  have 
 some  boulders,  use  foxtail  agave.  They 
 have  a  little  trunk  to  them  as  they  get 
 older  and  they'll  fold  over  top  of 
 boulders  and  really  kind  of  give  you 
 that  interactive  look  like  they're  just 
 coming  out  to  say  hello.  Very,  very 
 interesting.  And  they  also  once  they  get 
 that  trunk  to  them,  they  offer  uh  pups. 
 It  takes  a  while.  They  don't  pop  out 
 babies  fast,  but  once  they  do  get  that 
 trunk  to  them,  now  they  start  popping 
 out  other  babies.  And  you  can  take 
 literally  peel  those  babies  off  and 
 start  popping  them  in  between  other 
 boulders  and  really  decorating  with 
 those  guys.  They  are  the  perfect  slow 
 growing  agave.  Thornless,  very  easy  to 
 work  with  and  can  handle  more  water  than 
 most  agave.  Can  handle  sun  and  can 
 handle  shade.  They're  definitely  a  go-to 
 plant  for  me.  The  backdrop  that  I  have 
 along  my  water  feature  there,  those  are 
 all  cat  palms.  Now,  cat  palms  mature  out 
 to  around  9t  tall.  So,  they're  super 
 slow  growers,  but  they  really  I  mean,

 other  neighboring  development. 
 [Music] 
 My  favorite  palm  tree  in  my  whole 
 backyard  space,  the  Carpoxalon  palms. 
 They're  dynamic.  They're  stately. 
 They're  gorgeous.  They  are  super  slow 
 growers.  So  much  so,  apparently  I  forget 
 about  them  in  the  yard.  But  their  crown 
 shaft  is  absolutely  a  stunner.  I  hope 
 you  guys  can  see  that  on  camera.  But  if 
 you're  looking  for  one  of  those  palms, 
 maybe  an  entrance  palm  on  either  side  of 
 a  walkway  or  a  corner  of  a  house  or  a 
 feature  palm  somewhere,  they're  a  bit 
 pricey,  I  will  tell  you,  but  they  are 
 worth  their  weight  in  gold  because 
 they're  just  so  beautiful.  And  then  as 
 they  mature,  even  more  beautiful.  I 
 brought  these  guys  in  around  9  to  10 
 foot  tall.  They've  been  in  the  ground 
 for  I  would  say  about  eight  or  nine 
 years.  And  they're  really  really  just 
 taking  off.  And  I  would  say  it's  the 
 last  2  years  they've  really  shown  off 
 what  they  can  do.  Initially  they're  more 
 compact  because  they're  not  one  of  your 
 fast  growing  wild  palms.  They're  more 
 controlled.  The  canopies  are  more  tight. 
 They're  very  vertical  and  then  they  just 
 do  a  slight  bend  at  the  edge  of  the  leaf 
 like  a  curtsy.  So  I  just  think  they're 
 just  such  dulls  in  the  garden.  So,  I 
 have  two  of  them  here  and  one  at  the 
 rear  corner  of  my  garden.  I  know  that 
 this  is  not  to  everyone's  taste.  I  like 
 a  jungle  inspired  garden.  I  really  like 
 that  wild  thing,  you  know,  plant  on 
 plant.  I  do  like  a  collection  of  plants, 
 not  one  of  these  and  two  of  these  or, 
 you  know,  I  do  like  a  little  bit  more 
 dense  planting,  but  I  do  know  that  this 
 part  might  just  be  a  little  bit  too  wild 
 for  most,  but  this  is  my  jam  and  this 
 this  is  why  I  wanted  to  share  it  with 
 you.  This  is  my  personal  garden.  I've 
 got  some  sloppy  painters  mixed  into  the 
 back  there  because  sloppy  painters  need 
 no  light.  You  guys  have  a  no  light 
 situation,  but  you  need  a  little  bright 
 spot  in  the  garden.  Pick  a  sloppy 
 painter.  There's  no  light  back  there. 
 And  those  guys  pop  around  the  corner  and 
 really  spit  out  with  some  beautiful 
 bright  yellow  coloring.  Right  down 
 below,  I  have  a  row  of  aglioneas,  the 
 silver  bays  to  match  these  here.  Well, 
 the  elephant  ears  are  not  supposed  to  be 
 there.  I  planted  them  initially  before  I 
 put  the  agleneemas  in  there  and  then  I 
 was  trying  out  to  see  if  I  could  put 
 algeneemas  in  more  of  a  shade 
 environment  with  no  light.  So  that  was  a 
 test  trial  and  they're  doing  perfectly 
 fine  but  but  I  cannot  get  rid  of  the 
 dwarf  alicacia.  So  that  is  a  disclaimer 
 when  it  comes  to  dwarf  alicasia.  You  can 
 put  it  somewhere  and  then  decide  to  take 
 it  out  later  and  it's  going  to  come 
 back.  So  they  have  little  bulbs  under 
 the  ground.  They'll  pop  back  up  over 
 time  and  you'll  have  to  kind  of  relocate 
 them.  What  is  great  about  that 
 particular  plant,  if  it  happens  to  pop 
 up  again,  you  can  literally  cut  it  off 
 right  at  the  trunk  base  and  put  it 
 anywhere  else  in  your  garden  and  it'll 
 rroot  and  grow  in.  You  can  put  it  in  a 
 fountain  of  water  in  the  center  and  then 
 it'll  live  perfectly  that  way  as  well. 
 It  It'll  live  in  so  many  different 
 environments.  It's  fantastic.  It  does 
 like  filtered  light,  so  it's  going  to 
 need  some  protection  from  the  harshest 
 days  of  the  sun.  Can  handle  all  morning 
 sun,  though,  and  it's  just  a  fabulous 
 plant  to  work  with.  Unless  you're  trying 
 to  get  rid  of  it  permanently  in  a  spot, 
 cuz  that  doesn't  go  so  well.  As  you  can 
 probably  see,  I  put  elephant  ears  in 
 this  area.  Sometimes  I'll  fill  up  this 
 whole  corner  and  this  whole  corner  with 
 elephant  ears  and  let  them  live  in  the 
 water.  And  to  me,  that's  so  much  fun. 
 Just  when  I  pop  out  pups,  I  just  place 
 them  everywhere.  So,  very,  very  easy  to 
 work  with.  The  great  thing  about  having 
 a  water  feature  like  this  in  the  garden, 
 all  the  plants  in  this  environment  love 
 that  humidity,  that  constant  feed  of 
 water  that's  in  this  particular  area. 
 So,  if  you  have  a  water  feature,  put 
 some  hanging  orchids  near  it.  Really  let 
 and  unfold  your  plants  around  it.  Nestle 
 that  water  feature  because  they're  going 
 to  love  where  they  live.  This  water 
 feature  circulates  over  time.  So,  it 
 pockets  this  water  here  for  a  short 
 period  of  time.  There  is  a  big  giant 
 basin  underneath  here  that  holds  500 
 gallons  of  water  that  recirculates,  goes 
 back  up  the  pipe  and  out.  So,  this  is 
 not  a  sitting  water  situation.  It's 
 always  moving.  goes  down  into  the  basin, 
 back  up  the  pipe,  so  we  don't  have  to 
 worry  about  mosquitoes  or  any  kind  of 
 problems.  One  of  those  features  that 
 really  give  you  that  great  bit  of  sound 
 in  the  garden,  especially  if  you're 
 needing  a  little  bit  more  sound  from  a 
 very  busy  neighborhood  like  we  have. 
 Right  here,  we've  anchored  a  triple 
 spindle  palm.  Happy,  happy,  happy.  Here 
 it  is  really  unfolding.  I  was  hoping 
 that  it  would  really  go  all  the  way  over 
 the  water  feature  on  that  side  with  that 
 trunk.  Not  quite  there  yet.  They  mature 
 out  to  around  14  to  16T.  So  they  kind  of 
 overall  stay  a  smaller  palm  tree.  That's 
 why  I  wanted  it  so  close.  I  always  kind

 And  this  girl  is  doing  it.  She  provides 
 great  shade  for  this  collection  of

 Still  not  loving  this  location.  You  can

 just  all  play  so  well  together.  Right 
 here  I  have  a  giant's  bird's  nest  fern 
 and  it  was  so  little  when  I  put  him  in, 
 but  look  how  big  he's  gotten.  He's 
 really  become  such  a  stunner.  So  much  so 
 that  he  is  kind  of  attaching  to  the 
 trunk  of  this  tree  and  I'm  wondering  how 
 as  this  tree  grows  will  he  become,  you 
 know,  up  here  as  this  tree  gets  to  be  14 
 foot.  That's  going  to  be  an  exciting 
 thing  to  see.  I  have  a  Rojo  Congo  that 
 has  done  that  and  I  just  think  that's 
 just  such  a  cool  thing.  As  the  tree  is 
 grown,  so  is  the  plant  grown  up  it.  So 
 bird's  nest  ferns  are  epipy,  so  they  can 
 absolutely  grow  on  tree  trunks  or  pretty 
 much  on  anything.  They  they  can  you  can 
 attach  them  in  wall  settings  and  they 
 will  root  in  and  grow  there.  They're 
 competing  a  little  bit,  but  I  really 
 think  they  have  a  happy  marriage  because 
 they're  kind  of  really  growing  in 
 together.  Right  down  below  here,  this  is 
 a  collection  of  those  foxtail  agave. 
 Little  pups  that  I've  taken  from  my 
 bigger  versions  of  the  other  foxtail 
 agave.  And  you  can  really  see  just  how 
 when  you  bunch  them  up  together,  what  a 
 cool  little  grouping  they  meet.  It's 
 like  a  big  succulent  grouping.  Right 
 here  is  a  flame  agave.  I  have  one  in  the 
 front  yard.  I'll  get  Bryce  to  pop  up  a 
 picture  of  it.  It's  gorgeous  and  big. 
 Absolutely  stunners.  Now,  the  only 
 negative  with  the  flame  agave  is  that  it 
 does  have  the  thorns  at  the  end  and  you 
 can  clip  these  guys.  You  can  clip  those 
 thorns  right  off.  You  see,  I've  done 
 that  on  some  of  the  older  ones,  but  the 
 newer  ones  will  always  come  up  with 
 thorns  where  these  guys  are  super  soft. 
 This  has  a  little  bit  of  a  silver  tone 
 to  it  where  these  guys  have  more  of  a 
 lime  chartreuse  green  to  them.  So,  a 
 nice  contrast  with  each  other.  Same  with 
 the  Imperialis  Bmilad.  Now,  this  guy  is 
 getting  baked  gorgeous  and  beautiful  the 
 most  of  the  year,  but  July  and  August, 
 those  are  the  months  of  the  year  that 
 it's  just  not  super  happy  in  the  garden 
 because  we  get  that  intense  intense 
 heat.  I  don't know  if  you  guys  can  feel 
 or  see  the  radiated  heat  coming  off  of 
 me  right  now,  but  it's  like  150  out 
 here.  It's  crazy  hot.  You  might  have  to 
 sacrifice  a  month  or  two,  but  after 
 that,  they'll  pop  back  and  be  their 
 beautiful  selves  the  rest  of  the  year. 
 So,  it  might  be  worth  it  to  you.  So,  as 
 we  get  further  and  deeper  into  this 
 section  here,  this  is  going  to  be  more 
 of  of  a  shade  garden  along  this  backside 
 and  then  more  of  a  little  bit  more  sun 
 as  we  get  to  the  middle  section.  Now,  I 
 like  to  think  of  my  backyard  garden 
 because  it  is  a  flat  space.  I  separated 
 things  like  I'd  like  to  see  them.  So, 
 over  there,  that  is  a  big  flat  front 
 face  of  the  garden  as  I'm  sitting  in  my 
 seating  section  as  my  family  and  us  are 
 enjoying  our  our  dining  over  there.  That 
 area  is  more  of  like  you  can  kind  of  see 
 everything  all  at  once  in  that 
 particular  spot.  And  then  of  course 
 around  the  water  feature,  that's  its  own 
 kind  of  garden.  That's  it.  It's  wild. 
 That's  like  like  the  jungle  just  kind  of 
 came  in  and  went  a  little  crazy  around 
 the  water  feature.  Now  this  area,  this 
 area  is  is  where  I  wanted  that  whole 
 botanical  garden  vibe  to  come  in.  I 
 wanted  as  I  walked  through  it  was  more 
 interactive.  Like  I  saw  a  lot  of 
 different  layers  in  here,  sun  and  shade 
 material,  and  that's  kind  of  what  I 
 wanted  to  see  in  this  particular  spot. 
 Back  here  we  have  some  very  old  cat 
 palms.  These  guys  were  probably  one  of 
 the  first  things  that  I  planted  back 
 here  after  my  Eureka  palms  and  coconut 
 palms.  Now,  when  you  guys  want  to  do  a 
 garden  that  is  somewhat  shaded,  but  you 
 are  on  the  east  side  of  the  property  and 
 it  gets  pretty  decent  sun  over  here,  in 
 order  to  create  that  kind  of 
 microclimate,  you're  going  to  have  to 
 create  different  layers  of  canopy  trees 
 to  offer  that  kind  of  shade  and 
 protection.  So,  it's  almost  like  you're 
 bringing  in  the  umbrellas  to  really 
 protect  your  new  plantings  from  the 
 harshness  of  the  sun.  So,  everything  on 
 the  inside  of  this  burm  area  is  going  to 
 be  more  of  a  dense  shade  planting. 
 That's  what  it's  allowed  to  go  into 
 there.  And  so,  that's  kind  of  what  we 
 have.  So,  we  have  cat  palms  in  this  area 
 to  kind  of  give  us  a  leaf  on  leaf  kind 
 of  jungle  vibe  back  there.  And  then  I 
 have  aimas,  the  silver  bays  right  here. 
 A  little  collection  of  quarter  lines. 
 These  are  the  shade  variety  of  quarter 
 lines.  There's  an  exotica  here,  a  marie 
 there,  an  exotica  to  the  back.  It  was 
 probably  a  little  bit  hard  to  see  there. 
 These  right  here,  I've  got  three  dwarf 
 ferns.  I  believe  they're  called  silver 
 ladies.  They're  kind  of  a  test  trial, 
 but  I  love  their  upright  look.  They  kind 
 of  have  that  dune  palm  look  where 
 they're  very  vertical.  They're  very  slow 
 growing,  grow  into  that  3  to  4  foot 
 range,  so  I  don't  have  to  worry  about 
 them  getting  bigger.  I  have  them  planted 
 up  and  out  this  way.  That's  why  there's 
 a  gap  here  because  I  kind  of  want  them 
 to  fall  forward.  So,  when  I'm  looking  at 
 them  from  my  seating  section,  I'm  not

 spring.  They're  a  gorgeous  plant  to  work 
 with.  And  then  right  here,  I  have  a 
 single  bottle  palm.  This  single  bottle 
 palm,  because  of  the  coconut  palm  and

 forward  to  find  the  sun.  Of  course,  it's 
 like  it's  like  a  bright  spot.  So,  I
