 top.  So,  it's  almost  like  having  an 
 arbor  in  the  garden.  So,  I  have  those. 
 But  what  became  in  the  first  thing  that 
 I  planted  here  were  the  triangle  fan 
 palms  that  you  see  behind  us.  We  have 
 three  triangle  fan  palms.  It  is  amazing. 
 I  planted  them  all  flat,  but  you  can  see 
 how  they've  turned  towards  the  sun. 
 Those  angles.  Triangle  fan  palms.  If 
 you're  not  familiar  with  them,  they  have 
 a  silvery  green  tone  to  the  leaf.  More 
 silver  than  anything,  which  is  fabulous 
 because  they  really  just  give  you  a 
 completely  different  contrasting  look  to 
 the  other  palms.  This  one  has  three  flat 
 sides,  so  you're  able  to  have  a  fan  on 
 one  side,  or  you  can  turn  it  the  other 
 way,  have  a  fan  this  way,  and  a  tail 
 this  way.  Because  of  how  they  are,  you 
 can  really  position  them  the  way  that 
 you  want  them  to,  unless  you're  like 
 mine,  which  have  decided  just  to  do  what 
 they  want  to  do  because  they're  looking 
 for  a  specific  thing  for  themselves.  But 
 I  love  them.  They  are  old  and  they  are 
 beautiful  and  they  are  one  of the  first 
 things  that  I  would  always  see  when  I 
 come  out  in  the  garden.  Now  that  they're 
 understory  trees,  the  bottle  palms,  the 
 spindle  palms,  you  know,  all  the  new 
 palms  that  I've  put  in  has  started  to 
 grow  up,  it's  funny  how  they  become  now 
 the  backdrop  to  those  trees  and  the  new 
 landscaping  is  kind  of  coming  in  to  take 
 over  and  and  that's  what  gardens  do.  Um, 
 I  get  this  question  often,  how  close  can 
 you  plant  palm  trees  to  one  another?  And 
 you  can  absolutely  plant  them  as  close 
 as  the  fronds  will  allow  you  to  plant 
 them.  If  you're  in  good  fertile  soil, 
 you  can  see  that  I've  got  a  triangle  fan 
 palm  right  here.  And  then  two  bottle 
 palms  right  next  to  it.  And  then  I've 
 got  a  triangle  fan  palm  probably  about 
 about  9  to  10  foot  from  the  other  one  on 
 the  other  side.  So  a  center  piece,  a  9 
 to  10  foot  that  way,  9  to  10  foot  that 
 way.  And  then  you've  got  trees  that 
 close  together.  And  you'll  see  that  I 
 have  right  on  that  last  end  triangle 
 palm,  I've  got  that  triple  spindle  palm. 
 That  triple  spinnel  palm  came  in  years 
 and  years  and  years  later  because  it 
 came  in  when  the  fronds  were  below  this 
 trunk  line  and  now  it's  starting  to 
 catch  up  and  grow  up  the  tree.  But 
 literally  can  put  I  don't  know  if  Bryce 
 is  able  to  capture  that  on  camera,  but 
 we're  like  three  foot  off  of  that  tree 
 right  there.  So  you  can  see  that  this 
 tree  is  a  big  mama  jama  back  there.  It 
 is  not  affected  by  its  neighboring  tree. 
 It,  you  know,  they're  going  to  share  the 
 same  root  system.  They're  going  to  be 
 very,  very  happy.  They're  going  to  be 
 very  strong.  When  I  get  a  lot  of  clients 
 who  ask  me,  we  don't  want  anything  too 
 manicured.  We  want  that  jungle  vibe.  We 
 having  a  tree  here  and  a  tree  here  and  a 
 tree  here  and  a  little  bit  more  hairy 
 carry,  more  organic.  I  get  that  and  I 
 can  landscape  that  way.  However,  I 
 prefer  to  landscape  where  the  trees  have 
 all  structure.  This  is  your  anchor 
 trees.  These  are  your  centerpiece  trees. 
 These  are  your  smaller  dwarf  trees.  You 
 know,  like  I  have  there's  there's  like  a 
 systematic  placement  for  those  type  of 
 things.  then  you  can  get  all  crazy  and  a 
 little  bit  wild  kind  of  like  I  have  here 
 with  all  your  underplanting  trees  and  it 
 still  makes  sense.  But  if  you  have  one 
 tree  out  growing  another  tree  and  it's 
 all  wishy-washy,  it  has  a  tendency  to 
 really  get  away  from  you  because  you're 
 like,  gosh,  I  I  kind  of  feel  like 
 there's  just  a  lot  going  on  back  there. 
 But  nothing  has  more  of  that  unanimous 
 feel.  kind  of  want  your  wall  to  be  your 
 solid,  your  roof  line  to  be  nice  and 
 solid,  then  get  a  little  dicey  with  your 
 plants.  If  you  want  that  jungle  vibe, 
 you  know,  and  then  even  more  so  if  you 
 want  that  real  clean  line  vibe,  you  can 
 make  a  beautiful  thick,  dense  tree 
 canopy  and  stagger  things  like  this  and 
 then  do  more  of  the  same  type  of  plant 
 grouping  that  goes  from  one  and  then 
 another  plant  grouping  that  goes  another 
 way  that's  very  clean  line.  It  doesn't 
 have  to  be  big  leafed  and  and  jungle 
 inspired.  You  can  really  really  play 
 with  it.  But  in  both  of  those  scenarios, 
 it's  always  best  to  start  out  with  a 
 really  well-designed  tree  installation 
 first.  And  that's  what  a  landscape 
 designer  does  for  you  or  a  landscape 
 contractor  will  come  in  and  they'll  look 
 at  the  whole  space  and  say,  "Okay,  let's 
 do  the  sense  work  first,  then  bring  in 
 the  then  bring  in  the  fun,  bring  in  the 
 party.  Now,  look  at  this  little  laquala. 
 This  little  guy  I  brought  in  at  a  3 
 gallon  size,  a  teeny  tiny  little  thing. 
 And  as  you  guys  probably  know,  they're  a 
 bit  pricey,  these  little  trees.  So,  you 
 really  have  to  find  find  out  where  you 
 want  to  use  them.  Tuck  this  bad  boy 
 right  in  here.  He's  getting  very  little 
 airflow.  He's  really,  really  happy.  And 
 out  of  all  of  my  Laqualas,  and  I  have 
 four  of  them,  he's  grown  the  fastest.  He 
 was  like  this.  I  put  him  in.  I  woke  up 
 the  next  day,  and  I  mean,  literally,  it 
 was  almost  like  that.  It  was  amazing. 
 He's  outgrown  the  aglanimas  underneath. 
 He's  really,  really  happy  in  that 
 particular  spot.  I  cannot  wait  till  he 
 gets  his  9  10  foot  tall  in  this  spot  and 
 becomes  the  showstopper.  He's  also  going 
 to  lean  towards  a  little  bit  of  the  sun. 
 So,  he's  going  to  do  what  these  trees 
 are  doing,  which  is  leaning  out  this 
 way,  which  is  what  I  prefer  and  when  I'm 
 working  with  a  flat  garden.  All right, 
 so  moving  on  to  this  palm  tree.  This  is 
 a  penanga  coronada.  This  is  a  cool  new 
 palm  species  that  I  put  in  the  ground. 
 It's  been  in  the  ground  maybe  close  to  a 
 year.  It  really  taking  off  because 
 they're  supposed  to  be  slow  growers,  but 
 I  think  I've  gotten  a  good  two  foot  out 
 of  it,  which  is  very  unlikely,  but  but  I 
 did  use  a  really  good  back  fill  with 
 soil  on  this  one  cuz  I  wanted  to  make 
 sure  it  took  off.  very  very  upright, 
 very  compact.  So,  it  has  individual 
 trunks.  I  know  it's  probably  hard  to 
 see,  but  it's  almost  like  they  bouquet 
 right  in  the  middle.  And  these  fronds 
 stay  real  close  together  and  kind  of  do 
 this,  which  is  exactly  what  I  wanted.  I 
 didn't  have  all  the  room  in  the  world 
 for  fronds  to  get  like  this  cuz  I 
 already  got  that  going  on.  So,  I  wanted 
 something  that  was  a  different  a 
 contrasting  leaf.  And  when  you  guys  are 
 looking  for  your  plantings,  don't  be 
 afraid  to  do  that.  If  you've  got  one 
 leaf  that's  big  like  the  laquala,  then 
 choose  another  leaf  that's  more  linear, 
 more  more  arrowshaped,  just  jazz  it  up 
 with  different  fronds.  It  feels  like,  oh 
 my  gosh,  there's  a  lot  of  different 
 textures  laying  on  top  of  one  another, 
 which  is  what  makes  it  really  cool  and 
 interesting.  Botanical  gardens  when 
 they're  designing  for  that  space,  and 
 resorts  do  that  to  a  tea.  You'll  see 
 them  use  different  fronds  on  top  of 
 fronds  and  it'll  feel  like  there's  a  lot 
 going  on  when  there  really  isn't.  So, 
 perfect  for  courtyard  palms  or  a  small 
 planter  along  a  wall.  A  lot  of you  guys 
 will  have  those  walled  areas  where  you 
 have  like  a  3-FFT  planter.  Put  this  bad 
 boy  in  there.  They  can  handle  that  just 
 fine.  They  do  need  a  little  bit  of 
 protection  from  the  sun.  So  they,  you 
 know,  they  kind  of  want  morning  sun 
 environment  into  full  shade.  They  can 
 handle  full  shade.  This  is  a  cousin  to 
 the  lipstick  palm.  The  lipstick  palm  of 
 course  has  that  beautiful  red  stemming. 
 I  would  kill  for  a  lipstick  palm.  I 
 mean,  not  really  because  I'm  a  pacifist, 
 but  I  would  love  to  have  a  lipstick  palm 
 in  my  garden,  but  I'm  a  little  bit 
 worried  about  how  cold  we  get.  I  mean, 
 they're  they're  really  really  cold 
 sensitive  and  I  don't  have  many  more 
 room  for  pots  out  in  my  shade  gardens  to 
 the  backside.  Again,  filling  her  up  with 
 some  aglioneas.  Really  giving  her  that 
 leaf  look,  that  light  coloring.  Anytime 
 you  have  a  dark  spot  and  you  can  bring 
 in  light  green  or  a  light  variegation  in 
 tone,  it  really  shows  off  so  much  nicer. 
 And  then  I  have  the  large  leaf  chiffera. 
 This  is  the  dwarf  variety,  but  it  does 
 mound  out.  So,  normal  variegated 
 chifilera  is  more  hedgike.  This  is 
 softer,  more  flowy.  It  doesn't  It's  not 
 as  hard  stemi.  I  really  like  I  just  have 
 a  little  drift  of  those  wrapping  around 
 the  base  of  this  tree.  I  think  that'll 
 be  gorgeous  at  four  or  5t  tall.  Once 
 this  tree  gets  a  little  bit  bigger, 
 it'll  be  my  ground  planting.  This  area 
 gets  more  sun,  so  I  needed  something 
 that  could  tolerate  that.  These  guys  can 
 handle  full  sun.  Not  as  well  as  a 
 variegated  arvocaola  because  that's  a 
 tougher  plant.  But  this  has  a  similar 
 look  to  it.  A  bigger  leaf,  more 
 floppier,  but  it  can  handle  shade, 
 filtered  light,  and  full  sun  once  it's 
 adapted  with  a  little  bit  of  a  little 
 bit  of  time.  These  are  the  pink  pentas. 
 They  can  handle  some  filtered  light  and 
 some  sun.  Will  bloom  in  both  spots, 
 which  is  fabulous  for  those  little  guys. 
 These  guys  look  great  for  about  2  or  3 
 years.  Then  you  really  do  need  to  cut 
 the  pentas  back.  So  they're  in  that 
 family  line  where  they're  a  little  bit 
 longer  lived.  You're  in  your  typical  uh 
 small  flowering  perennial,  but  I  think 
 they're  worth  it.  And  then  if  it's  a 
 smaller  spot,  you  can  always  pull  them 
 out  and  replant  five  or  six  more.  So 
 moving  on,  we  have  the  quarter  lines 
 grouping.  So  we  had  one  at  the  very 
 start  on on  the  other  bottle  palm.  Now 
 we've  got  it  at  the  ending  of  this 
 bottle  palm.  And  it  is  just  a  collection 
 of  quarter  lines.  These  guys,  I  cut  back 
 the  tallest  one  every  year.  It  flushes 
 out  with  a  new  head  every  single  year  or 
 two.  So,  I'm  constantly  getting  new 
 quarter  lines  and  I'm  taking  the  old 
 ones  and  putting  them  back  in  this  sea 
 of  quarterline  collection.  And  then 
 that's  exactly  what  they  do.  They  just  I 
 cut  them,  they  keep  growing  and  they 
 produce  more  and  then  I  put  them  in 
 there.  So,  in  5  years  when  we  do  this 
 tour,  you  guys,  we're  going  to  have  like 
 a  sea  of  quarter  lines  where  I  give  them 
 away  all  the  time,  too.  So,  this  is  a 
 spot  where  I  like  it  to  get  a  little  bit 
 more  organic.  It's  feeding  over  into  the 
 walkway  right  here,  right  over  top  of  my 
 edge  lines.  So,  I  feel  like  it's  coming 
 out  into  the  walkway.  And  I'll  do  that 
 often,  especially  in  my  designs  where 
 I'll  narrow  a  space  just  to  kind  of  open 
 it  up  later  to  kind  of  give  you  not  just 
 curves  in  the  garden,  but  to  give  you 
 interest,  to  kind  of  give  you  a 
 tightening  up  and  then  opening  to  okay, 
 now  you're  seeing  it  all  and  then  you're 
 not  seeing  anything  and  then  you're 
 seeing  it  all  and  it's  whole  experience. 
 So  that's  what  these  guys  do.  So  moving 
 on,  as  we  get  further  down,  we  get  a 
 little  bit  more  light  in  this  particular 
 spot.  So  it  really  allowed  me  to  open  it 
 up  and  use.  Now,  I  could  have  used 
 something  blooming  here,  but  I  love 
 croins.  I  like  that  variegation  and 
 look,  especially  when  I  only  have  a  very 
 small  section  of  the  garden  that  I  need 
 a  almost  like  a  wow  factor.  I  need  some 
 punch.  I  need  some  I  I  need  some  impact. 
 So,  I  use  the  magnificent  Croins  here 
 for  their  variation  in  color.  Now, 
 during  the  winter  months,  they  get  more 
 burgundy  tones  to  them  with  the  yellow 
 and  the  greens.  During  the  summer 
 months,  they'll  bleach  out  a  little  bit 
 and  get  more  of  the  yellow  and  the  green 
 tones.  That's  a  fabulous  kind  of 
 combination  that  they  offer.  Down  below, 
 you'll  notice  I'll  have  a  red  sister 
 quarterline  that's  popped  out  amongst 
 the  back  side  of  the  tree.  It's  kind  of 
 carried  over  and  then  an  ginger  plant. 
 And  then  over  there  to  the  back,  we  have 
 another  Queen  Emma  with  a  bedding  of 
 aglioneas  at  the  bottom.  And  that  Rojo 
 Congo  that's  climbing  up  the  triangle 
 palm.  That's  what  I  was  meaning  earlier 
 when  I  said  some  of  these  plants  will 
 climb  right  up  the  tree.  So,  it  has 
 grown  up,  grown  with  the  tree.  As  the 
 tree  continues  to  grow,  the  Congo  is 
 growing  up  with  it,  which  is  so  funny 
 because  it  was  originally  in  the  direct 
 shade.  Now,  it's  getting  more  and  more 
 sun  as  the  tree  continues  to  grow.  So, 
 we'll  see  how  that  works  out  as  it  uh  as 
 it  continues  to  get  taller.  We  have  a 
 traveler's  palm  back  there  and  an  ora 
 palm  back  there,  as  well  as  a  coconut 
 palm  as  our  backdrop.  So  you  can  really 
 see  that  we've  got  some  good  coverage  at 
 that  back  section  of  the  garden.  And 
 then  that  leads  us  to  the  Laquala  palm. 
 Now  this  Laquala  palm  is  the  biggest  one 
 I  have  in  my  whole  garden.  It's  actually 
 in  the  perfect  spot.  It  gets  a  little 
 bit  of  wind  to  the  back  section,  but  you 
 can  really  see  it's  tucked  into  this 
 burm  into  this  buffer.  So  it  is  almost 
 like  the  little  inset  little  jewel  in 
 the  garden.  It  is  the  thing  that  I  see 
 when  I  walk  around  this  corner  the  most. 
 I  love  these  big  paddle  fronds.  See, 
 we've  got  a  nice  bedding  of  forest 
 plants  down  below.  Those  are  bird's  nest 
 ferns  and  rojo  congos  down  at  the 
 bottom.  And  I  love  that,  you  guys, 
 because  I  I  don't  want  to  see  mulch  at 
 the  bottom.  I  don't  want  to  remulch.  I 
 never  remulch  this  area.  My  ground  cover 
 now  is  the  ground  forest,  the  ground 
 floor  is  all  planting.  So,  that's 
 exactly  what  happens.  I  did  forget  about 
 my  white  lady  here.  I  don't  know  how  I 
 forgot  about  her.  She  literally  glows  at 
 night  in  the  garden.  I  love  her  right 
 here.  Here  I  see  her  from  my  seating 
 section.  She's  absolutely  stunning.  It 
 was  a  marketplace  find.  Just  she's 
 nestled  in  the  forest  plants  here.  One 
 heart-shaped  ficus  to  see  how  well  it 
 does  in  this  this  type  of  lighting 
 situation.  It's  doing  fantastic.  It's 
 growing  super  super  slow.  So,  if  you  get 
 that  collection,  make  sure  that  you  have 
 plenty  of  time  for  it  to  mature  out. 
 They're  such  a  unique  look  in  the 
 garden.  They  can  handle  really  deep 
 shade  and  keep  that  white  and  green 
 leaf.  So,  if  you  need  like  a  blast  of 
 something,  don't  do  one  like  I  did.  Do 
 make  sure  you  do  eight  or  nine  and  one 
 collection  and  that  you're  going  to  get 
 that  nice  dollop  of  color,  then  you  can 
 do  some  greens  around  it  to  really 
 showcase  that  white  and  green  of  those 
 guys.  Speaking  of  showcasing,  this 
 dumpane  plant  is  fabulous  right  here.  It 
 has  been  such  a  stunner.  It's  getting  a 
 little  bit  too  big  for  this  spot.  This 
 is  meant  to  be  as  a  backdrop  planting.  I 
 wanted  to  see  if  it  could  take  more  sun 
 and  this  is  the  spot  that  it  seemed  to 
 really  like  so  I'm  probably  going  to 
 keep  it  here.  Next  year  I  might  relocate 
 it.  So  far  it's  done  well.  It's  had  a 
 lot  of  water.  It's  had  a  little  bit  of 
 water.  I've  had  water  2  days  a  week  and 
 it's  had  water  4  days  4  to  5  days  a  week 
 and  it's  done  well  in  both  situations. 
 It's  a  very  very  tough  plant  overall. 
 Great  for  pots.  They  don't  like  full 
 full  sun.  So  they  like  this  kind  of 
 environment  where  they'll  get  few  hours 
 of  afternoon  sun  and  then  that's  that. 
 right  here  as  our  backdrop.  These  are 
 old  mama  jama  Europeans.  The  double 
 European  fan  palm.  I  brought  it  in  years 
 ago.  It  has  grown  exceptionally  slow, 
 maybe  5,  6  in  a  year  at  most.  I  just 
 love  that  it  is  a  completely  different 
 texture  of  frond  than  every  other  frond 
 that  I  have  in  the  garden.  It's  very 
 weepy,  very  lacy,  great  movement.  And 
 it's  not  very  stiff  in  the  garden.  When 
 we  get  storms,  rains  out  here  and  we're 
 we  sit  out  a  lot  when  it's  nice  and 
 breezy  like  that.  It's  like  it's  got 
 loose  hair  flowing  in  the  garden.  It's 
 just  fabulous.  So,  European  fan  palms  I 
 know  get  sometimes  a  bad  rap  of  being 
 just  a  a  very  slow  growing  small  tree 
 and  and  that  they  are  that  does  take 
 them  a  long  time  to  get  any  size.  That 
 can  be  a  pro  and  it  can  be  a  con,  but 
 for  me  it  can  be  a  pro  because  it  means 
 it  can  fit  in  a  tight  spot  for  a  very 
 long  period  of  time.  I'm  I'm  talking  20 
 years  into  a  small  space  before  it  gets 
 oversized  for  that  particular  area. 
 They're  also  great  because  they're  going 
 to  really  protect  what's  underneath  of 
 it.  Like  these  Lady  Claire  Croins,  they 
 do  not  like  full  sun,  but  you  can  see 
 the  ones  that  get  more  sun  have  that 
 brighter  tone  and  leaf  color.  The  ones 
 to  the  back  that  are  down  there  filling 
 up  the  bottom  base  of  that  European  fan 
 palm  have  the  darker  green  leaf  and  a 
 little  speckled  bit  of  color.  And  then 
 during  the  winter,  that  yellow  turns 
 more  white.  So  you  get  that  white  and 
 green  back  here,  which  is  exactly  what 
 I'm  looking  for  when  I  have  a  big 
 balance  of  something  like  this  where  I 
 have  the  burl  marks  where  these  burl 
 marks  just  drape  over  this  edge.  I  just 
 think  that  it's  just  such  a  little 
 masterpiece  when  I'm  looking  down  the 
 garden  like  this.  Having  them  kind  of 
 flow  over,  it's  just  so  so  super 
 stunning.  Put  them  in  a  little 
 collection  like  a  little  swath.  Now,  you 
 can  pretty  much  draw  with  these  guys. 
 You  can  curve  them  this  way  in  a  garden. 
 You  can  just  do  a  little  a  little 
 collection  of  maybe  five  or  six  kind  of 
 framing  something.  They're  great  for 
 that.  This  shiny  kind  of  arrowhead  leaf 
 is  such  a  slow  growing  plant.  It  will  if 
 you  have  time  and  you  train  it  up  a 
 tree,  if  you  like  that  kind  of  look 
 where  it'll  go  straight  up  a  tree,  it 
 absolutely  will.  However,  it  won't 
 naturally  want  to  do  that  unless  it's 
 incredibly  old.  So,  it's  just  one  of 
 those  things  you'll  have  to  train  it  if 
 you  want  it  to  do  that.  But  I  do  like 
 them  here  like  a  skirt  planting  because 
 you  can  easily  keep  them  around  this 
 twoft  height  to  threeft  height.  And  then 
 I  have  one  carpaloxin  palm  right  here.  I 
 squeezed  him  in  here.  It  was  had  no 
 sense  of  being  in  this  particular  spot, 
 but  there  was  one  left  in  a  in  at  the 
 nursery  and  so  I  wanted  one  more  and 
 popped  him  in  here.  So  he  is  fighting 
 off  some  of  the  other  trees,  but 
 definitely  a  tree  that  I  love  so  much  I 
 wanted  to  find  a  spot  for.  Right  here  we 
 have  a  double  trunked  hurricane  palm. 
 And  I'm  sure  you  guys  by  now  can  guess 
 why  I  put  him  on  the  corner  just  like 
 the  other  double  bottle  palm.  Just 
 because  these  fronds  are  going  to  hang 
 over  here  as  I  sit  here  in  my  chair, 
 have  my  coffee.  This  is  just  such  a 
 great  spot.  This  is  the  shady  spot  in 
 the  garden.  This  is  the  coolest  spot  in 
 the  garden.  We  get  this  breeze  that 
 comes  this  way.  And  I  know  that  people 
 are  like,  "Do  you  ever  sit  there?"  I  can 
 promise  you  I  sit  here.  My  husband  sits 
 here.  I'm  working  out  in  the  garden. 
 This  is  the  place  that  I  sit  to  collect 
 my  thoughts  or  find  whatever  podcast  I 
 want  to  listen  to  on  my  phone  before  I 
 get  started  back  out  in  the  garden.  I 
 thought,  honestly,  I  would  only  sit  here 
 when  this  variegated  jasmine  behind  me 
 would  go  into  bloom,  but  I  find  myself 
 sitting  here  even  in  the  hottest  times 
 of  the  year.  So,  I  think  that  when  that 
 goes  into  bloom,  it's  going  to  be  just  a 
 bonus.  I'll  just  be  getting  that  great 
 fragrance.  And  just  like  I  mentioned 
 with  the  Gardinia,  anytime  that  you  have 
 a  seating  section,  if  you  can  pop 
 something  in  there  that's  going  to  give 
 you  that  fragrance  to  dial  up  your 
 senses,  it's  almost  like  you've 
 transported  yourself  out  of  a  suburban 
 yard,  out  of  a  neighborhood,  out  of  busy 
 lawnmowers  and  all  the  things  that  go 
 on,  pool  guys  and  all  that  stuff  that 
 are  popping  around  your  neighborhood, 
 but  into  your  own  private  resort. 
 Something  that  you've  been  a  part  of 
 creating,  something  you've  been  a  part 
 of  maintaining,  something  that  you've 
 seen  kind  of  unfold  and  grow  up.  That's 
 the  magic  of  gardening  and  that's  the 
 bug  that  is  scary  to  get.  So  be  careful 
 because  it's  just  the  beginning.  And  if 
 this  is  your  vibe,  if  this  is  your 
 thing,  then  you  guys,  I  am  so  proud.  I'm 
 going  to  proud  mom.  Bryce  did  a  video 
 that  kind  of  shares  with  you  guys  how  to 
 set  up  a  backyard  garden  space.  It's

 shows  how  to  create  a  private  backyard.

 you  true  gardeners,  if  you  wouldn't  mind

 Wow,  awesome  landscape. 
 >> Well,  yeah.  10  palm  trees  in  a  small 
 front  yard.  It's  amazing  how  many 
 different  varieties  that  you  can  get 
 into  an  average  typical  suburban  front 
 yard  to  make  it  super  super  interesting. 
 Why  go  with  the  same  palm  tree  on  every 
 corner  of  the  house  and  to  the  front 
 along  the  driveway  when  you  can  do  10 
 different  varieties?  I  don't  mean  just 
 10  palm  trees.  I  mean  10  different 
 varieties  to  really  give  you  that 
 tropical  look.  Come  on  you  guys,  we're 
 going to  take  a  quick  tour. 
 So,  the  first  showpiece  tree  is  the 
 Kentopsis.  So,  if  you  guys  are  new  to 
 Florida,  you  may  have  not  seen  this 
 palm.  It  is  getting  big  in  popularity 
 right  now.  I'm  seeing  it  more  and  more 
 on  different  projects,  different 
 construction  entrances  because  of  the 
 showpiece  that  it  is.  This  is  a 
 beautiful  palm.  Has  a  gorgeous  upright 
 frrawn.  I  mean,  look  at  this  frond 
 compared  to  me.  I  mean,  it  is  just  so 
 wide,  so  broad,  so  dynamic,  and  gives 
 you  such  a  vertical  pop  in  the  garden. 
 This  tree  has  a  very  small  base  and 
 that's  what's  great  about  it.  Kind  of 
 gives  you  a  lot  of  bang  for  your  buck 
 when  it  comes  to  this  kind  of  tree 
 because  you  get  so  much  coverage,  so 
 much  impact  with  a  fairly  small  tree. 
 Does  grow  super  slow.  So,  this  tree  will 
 be  like  a  foxtail  palm.  It  will  grow 
 into  about  the  20  to  24  foot  range, 
 somewhere  in  that  range  depending  on 
 your  soil  types.  But,  it  will  do  that  at 
 a  very  slow  rate.  So,  if  you've  got  a 
 spot  that  you  don't  want  a  tree  to  get 
 too  big  or  you  have  a  long  time  for  it 
 to  get  some  size  to  it,  a  kentopsis  is  a 
 great  anchoring  palm  tree.  You  can  use 
 it  as  a  centerpiece.  You  can  use  it  as  a 
 corner  anchor.  Both  of  those  are  great 
 ways.  We've  also  used  it  over  here.  If 
 you  show  everybody,  Bryce,  right  along 
 the  driveway.  I  mean,  just  look  how 
 gorgeous  and  vertical  they  look  against 
 your  typical  foxtail  palm  there.  I  love 
 palm  alleys.  If  you  can  and  it  works 
 well  with  your  type  of  landscape  and  you 
 guys  like  the  look  of  flanking  your 
 driveway  with  palms,  ideal.  I  even  like 
 it  more  when  you  only  do  one  side  of  the 
 driveway  that  way.  We  needed  some  weight 
 over  on  that  side.  We  have a  septic  tank 
 on  the  opposite  side  over  there.  So,  we 
 need  to  kind  of  stay  nice  and  close  to 
 the  driveway.  But,  when  looking  at  this 
 house  from  the  road,  it  it's  so 
 lopsided.  There's  a  lot  of  heavy  weight 
 over  on  this  side  of  the  yard  and 
 nothing  really  going  on  on  that  side  of 
 the  yard.  So,  what  we  wanted  to  do  was 
 kind  of  create  some  visual  weight  by 
 kind  of  creating  a  palm  alley.  We  have 
 three  kentopsis  palms,  nice  and 
 vertical,  starting  with  small,  then  a 
 tall  fox  tail,  small  kiosis,  tall 
 foxtail,  small.  Well,  you  get  the  point, 
 right?  It  really  is  going  to  do  a  nice 
 job  of  giving  them  a  really  vertical 
 layered  feel,  almost  kind  of  giving  you 
 that  grand  entrance  kind  of  style.  So, 
 don't  be  afraid  to  mix  them  with  foxtail 
 palms,  with  royal  palms,  with  anything 
 that's  vertical  and  upright  because 
 they're  never  going  to  compete  with 
 that.  They're  never  going  to  go  the  same 
 size.  They're  really  going  to  go  above 
 here  with  the  foxtail  and  the  kentopsis 
 is  going to  be  a  different  type  of 
 vertical  palm.  When  it  gets  large,  those 
 two  canopies  themselves  won't  compete 
 with  each  other  because  the  kiopsis 
 frond  is  so  different  than  the  foxtail 
 that  it's  going  to  be  even  more 
 beautiful  as  it  gets  large.  It's  not 
 going  to  be  like  a  row,  row,  row,  row 
 kind  of  a  boring  look  for  palm  trees. 
 It's  always  going  to  remain  a  vertical 
 palm  with  a  very  fuzzy  fluffy  foxtail 
 kind  of  top.  And  then  the  Kentopsis  is 
 going  to  have  that  dynamic  that  really 
 like  aggressive  kind  of  frrawn  like 
 this.  So  no  matter  what  size  or  what  age 
 they're  going  to  be,  they're  always 
 going  to  be  stunners  in  the  front.  So 
 the  Kentopsis  is  the  first  palm  on 
 today's  list.  You  guys  know  how  much  I 
 love  the  foxtail  palms.  I  just  think 
 that  beefy  big  trunk  on  them  is  going  to 
 be  stunners  no matter  where  you  have 
 them.  We  have  a  single  foxtail  here  and 
 we  also  right  behind  you  Bryce  have  a 
 double  foxtail  in  the  front  island 
 there.  So,  that  is  going  to  be  gorgeous 
 as  it  opens  up  and  becomes  a  bigger, 
 wider  tree  there. 
 So,  as  for  our  third  palm  on  the  list, 
 Bryce,  if  you  back  up  a  little  bit,  then 
 you'll  get  this  whole  big  old  mama  jama 
 in  here.  This  is  the  triple  Christmas 
 palm.  Now,  we  inherited  this  palm.  It 
 came  with  the  landscaping,  but  it  is 
 going  to  look  completely  different  with 
 the  new  garden  style.  So,  it  is 
 obviously  the  centerpiece.  I  love  the 
 way  Christmas  palms  offer  you  a  lot  of 
 trunks,  so  they  don't  really  take  up  a 
 lot  of  weight  in  the  front  of  the  house. 
 This  tree  will  stop  growing  just  as  it 
 gets  to  the  gutter  line.  So,  that's 
 what's  great.  It's  going  to  have  nothing 
 but  long  legs  and  then  right  at  the  top 
 of  the  roof  line,  right  when  you  get  to 
 that  gutter  line  and  roof  line,  it's 
 going  to  do  that  crowning  shape.  So,  it 
 is  going  to  be  that  tree  that's  going  to 
 stop  growing  exactly  where  it  was 
 supposed  to  stop  growing,  which  is  nice 
 when  they're  they  do  what  they're  told. 
 So,  as  for  our  fourth  palm  today,  now 
 these  guys  are  babies,  so  they're  not  as 
 big  as  the  other  guys,  but  we  have  got 
 the  rafus  palms,  the  lady  palms.  These 
 girls  just,  you  guys,  look  at  these 
 fronds  on  these  things.  I  just  love 
 these  multi-fingered  fronds  like  this. 
 They  have  a  lot  of  movement  in  the 
 garden.  My  client's  going  to  let  them 
 get  around  the  sixoot  height,  so  they're 
 going  to  have  a  kind  of  an  anchor  point 
 on  either  side  of  this  Christmas  palm. 
 And  I  really  love  that  the  Christmas 
 palm  allowed  us  to  put  some  weighted 
 palm  trees  on  either  side  of  it  because 
 what  happens  when  you  have  tall,  long 
 legs  of  a  tree,  you  have  all  that 
 opening,  all  of  that  airy  open  feel, 
 which  allows  you  to  put  something  chunky 
 and  fat  on  either  sides  to  almost  like 
 frame  it.  And  that's  exactly  what  these 
 two  rafus  palms  are  going  to  do.  Now, 
 raphus  palms  are  going to  come  with  a 
 disclaimer.  They  are  fabulous  little 
 chunky  trees.  They  really  are  easy  to 
 stay  compact.  However,  twice  a  year, 
 they're  going  to  want  to  pop  up  little 
 pups  to  widen  out  to  get  a  little  bit 
 bigger  because  that's  how  they  travel. 
 You're  going to  want  to  come  out  and 
 just  kind  of  clip  off  the  ones  that  you 
 don't  want.  So,  any  pups  that  might  kind 
 of  come  outside  that  little  center 
 bouquet  of  the  rais  palm,  you're  going 
 to  just  want  to  clip  that  out.  And  you 
 can  either  hit  it  with  the  shovel  and 
 pop  it  out  or  you  can  clip  it  out.  There 
 is  a  little  maintenance  required  on 
 those,  but  it's  so  hard  to  find  a 
 perfect  dwarfed  palm  tree  to  do  kind  of 
 the  job  that  they  do.  So,  I  think  that 
 that's  worth  the  effort.  And  for  our 
 fifth  tree  today  is  the  Sylvester  Palm. 
 Oh  my  goodness,  you  guys.  This  Sylvester 
 palm,  another  tree  we  inherited,  but  fit 
 super  well  into  this  landscape.  Now, 
 when  I  first  got  here,  it  was  the 
 biggest  thing  in  the  in  the  yard.  It  was 
 like,  wow.  There  was  a  bunch  of  smaller 
 intermediate  plants  going  on,  but  there 
 was  nothing  to  kind  of  give  us  some 
 balance.  And  I  think  bringing  in  the 
 other  palms,  bringing  in  the  accents, 
 bringing  in  the  intermediate  levels  is 
 going  to  offer  it  the  perfect  bit  of 
 balance.  So,  we  brought  in  some  big  bush 
 plantings  to  go  around  it  to  kind  of 
 engulf  the  base  of  that  trunk  of  that 
 existing  old  tree.  And  then  you're  going 
 to  really  get  to  show  off  that  canopy. 
 Now,  Sylvester  Palms,  they  come  with  a 
 bit  of  disclaimer.  They  are  absolutely 
 gorgeous,  but  there  is  a  disease  going 
 around,  so  you're  going  to  want  to  get 
 with  a  proper  pest  control  company  to 
 treat  it.  You  know,  usually  a  couple 
 times  a  year  and  make  sure  that  it  stays 
 nice  and  healthy.  It  is  not  one  that  I 
 am  currently  planting,  but  it  is  a  fan 
 favorite  of  a  lot  of  people's  just 
 because  of  there's  not  many  trees. 
 There's  not  many  one  tree  that  offers  as 
 much  punch  as  a  Sylvester  palm.  So,  I 
 think  that  it's  definitely  worth 
 mentioning  as  one  of  our  10  palms  here 
 today,  even  though  that  we  inherited  it 
 in  the  landscape.  So,  we're  going  to 
 work  with  that  bad  boy  and  get  it  to 
 become  a  nestled  part  of  this  new 
 landscaping  here.  All right,  you  guys. 
 So,  for  number  six  on  our  favorite  palm 
 list  is  the  King  Alexander.  Some  would 
 say  the  king  of  palms.  Maybe  I  say  that 
 because  I  love  the  King  Alexander.  Now, 
 this  guy  was  just  planted  a  few  days 
 ago.  We  have  had  extraordinary  heat.  So, 
 all  of  these  palms  are  showing  a  little 
 bit  of  stress.  And  maybe  that's 
 something  I  should  put  in  as  a  secondary 
 or  third  disclaimer  in  today's  video  is 
 that  if  you  guys  can  avoid  planting  in 
 the  month  of  July,  early  August,  that  is 
 a  tough  time  to  keep  things  watered.  We 
 are  trying  our  hardest  to  keep  the 
 plantings  watered.  But  it's,  you  know, 
 it's  a  tough  time.  So  if  you  guys  want 
 to  make  it  a  little  easier  on 
 yourselves,  then  hit  late  September, 
 early  October,  ideal  times  to  plant.  The 
 benefit  of  planting  right  now  is  when  we 
 get  those  rainstorms.  It  is  it  is  just  a 
 masterpiece.  It  is  exactly  what  these 
 plants  and  trees  will  need.  And  I  know 
 Florida  plants  and  trees,  they're  going 
 to  bounce  back  even  after  the  stress  of 
 the  heat.  Kind  of  look  past  some  of  the 
 browning  of  the  fronds.  This  girl  will 
 throw  out  new  fronds  in  a  matter  of 
 days.  She's  really  already  got  some  new 
 fronds  coming  in.  And  absolutely  a 
 stunner.  You  really  get  a  beautiful  tree 
 when  it  comes  to  a  King  Alexander.  They 
 come  in  singles,  doubles,  triples, 
 quads.  My  favorite  favorite  of  all  is 
 the  double  because  you  can  pretty  much 
 put  it  on  any  flat  surface.  I  love

 like  this  because  they  have  that 
 gorgeous  Vshape  and  really  kind  of  give 
 you  that  dynamic  frond.  They  have  a 
 super  long  frond  as  they  get  older.  This 
 tree  is  still  somewhat  young,  but  as 
 this  frond  gets  older,  it's  going  to 
 come  over  into  this  range,  you  guys.  So, 
 it  is  going  to  be  like  a  why  welcome 
 kind  of  palm  at  your  front  entrance.  And 
 you  know,  I  just  think  there's  such  a 
 clean  palm.  This  is  a  self-cleaning 
 palm.  So,  when  a  new  frond  comes  out, 
 the  canopy  gets  full,  it'll  drop  its  old 
 frond.  So,  no  work  when  it  comes  to  the 
 King  Alexanders,  which  is  nice. 
 Absolutely  love  to  use  these  palms  in  my 
 design  as  kind  of  intermediate  trees. 
 They're  not  as  big  and  beefy  as  a

 canopy.  All right,  for  our  next  palm 
 grouping  is  going  to  be  the  mule  palm. 
 So  this  is  a  young  mule  palm.  Absolutely 
 a  perfect  tree  for  this  spot.  Now,  a 
 mule  palm,  for  those  of  you  guys,  this 
 may  be  a  new  palm  for  you,  is  a 
 mishmash.  It's  a  pairing  of  a  pendo  palm 
 and  a  queen  palm.  So,  for  those  of  you 
 guys  who  are  up  north  a  bit  into  the 
 Orlando,  Jacksonville  area,  this  palm  is

 guy  is  fairly  new.  I'll  get  Bryce  to  pop

 interesting  those  fronds,  how  upright 
 those  fronds  are.  It  grows  super  slow. 
 So,  this  would  be  like  an  intermediate 
 tree  or  an  island  tree.  So,  if  you  had 
 somewhere  out  in  the  yard  and  you  needed 
 kind  of  like  a  centerpiece,  kind  of  like 
 a  fountain  popping  up  out  of  the  middle

 use.  You  can  bring  it  in  at  7  gallon 
 size,  15  gallon  size.  You  can  really 
 work  with  it  in  any  size,  which  is  ideal 
 for  these  guys.  As  long  as  you  have  time 
 for  it  to  grow,  it  does  take  some  time. 
 It's  a  slow  growing  palm.  You're  maybe 
 going  to  get  a  foot  a  year  out  of  it  at 
 best,  especially  because  a  lot  of  times 
 these  these  palms  are  planted  in  the 
 northern  climates.  And  in  the  northern 
 climates,  things  grow  just  a  tad  bit 
 slower  than  they  grow  on  our  Treasure 
 Coast  or  Space  Coast  area.  So,  this  is  a 
 great  palm  to  work  with.  If  you  guys 
 love  that  kind  of  dynamic  upright  frond 
 look  that  kind  of  weeps  down,  that 
 really  kind  of  folds  down.  It's  a  great

 palm  that's  going  to  grow  a  little  bit

 not  faster,  then  the  Malayan  might  be 
 the  coconut  palm  for  you.  The  trunk 
 stays  a  little  bit  chunky,  cut  a  little 
 bit  smaller.  The  canopy  obviously 
 overall  a  little  bit  smaller,  but  it 
 does  really  kind  of  really  kind  of  hold 
 their  size.  But  overall,  the  Malayan  is

 >> there  we  go.  So,  for  the  next  palm  on

 She's  still  tied  up  because  if  you  guys 
 know  of  a  pygmy  date  palm,  you  know  that 
 they  have  these  beautiful  trunks,  nice 
 feathery  fronds,  but  the  worst  manners 
 when  it  comes  to  these  thorns.  These 
 thorns  are  nobody's  business.  So,  my 
 guys  leave  them  tied  up  until  all  the 
 mulching,  all  the  trim  work,  everything 
 is  done  around  them.  And  then  they  cut 
 these  bad  boys  loose  and  let  them  fold

 little  bush  palm  and  they  turn  into  a 
 big  kind  of  frond  bush  palm.  And  that's

 compact.  They  grow  fairly  slow.  They're 
 definitely  your  understoried  palm  tree.

 think  they  definitely  have  their  place. 
 I'm  sorry  that  she's  she's  a  little 
 underdressed  for  this  video  today,  but  I 
 know  you  guys  would  understand  your 
 gardeners,  but  this  is  a  great  palm  tree 
 to  use,  and  you  can  almost  sneak  them  in 
 just  about  anywhere,  no matter  how  small 
 your  yard  is.  They  grow  to  10  to  12t. 
 The  trunks  stay  nice  and  chunky  and 
 broad  and  widen  out.  What's  great  about 
 these  palms,  if  you're  looking  for  a 
 little  bit  of  buffering,  they're  an 
 ideal  palm  to  use.  So,  if  you  need  to 
 use  them  in  a  straight  line  along  the 
 side  of  your  house,  they'll  give  you 
 about  6  foot  of  frrawn  coverage  and  then 
 you'll  have  about  3  or  4  foot  at  the 
 bottom  depending  on  the  size  of  your 
 palm  tree  of  clear  trunk.  That's  the 
 perfect  place  to  layer  in  front  of  them 
 with  some  beautiful  plants.  And  then 
 you've  got  a  beautiful  plant  grouping 
 and  then  a  frond  a  solid  frond  canopy. 
 And  that  frond  canopy  is  going  to  be 
 great  because  you  only  trim  them  about 
 two  times  a  year,  unlike  a  hedge  where 
 you  have  to  trim  and  maintain  that  hedge 
 consistently  throughout  the  year. 
 They're  kind  of  more  in  that  low 
 maintenance  if  you  don't  mind  those 
 little  thorns  there.  So,  I  definitely 
 think  they're  a  go-to  palm  for  your 
 Florida  palm  plantings.  Now,  off  to  the

 Well,  hello  true  gardeners.  Welcome 
 back.  Today  we  are  touring  a  garden  in 
 Fort  Pierce,  Florida.  I  wanted  to  bring 
 you  guys  along  on  this  specific  spot 
 because  it  is  a  lowmaintenance  front 
 yard  planting.  And  you  know,  I  think  the 
 right  plant  for  the  right  place  was  so 
 important  to  kind  of  stress  in  this 
 garden.  We're  going  to  do  what  we 
 normally  do.  We're  going  to  walk  through 
 plants  and  trees,  talk  about  why  we  put 
 what,  where,  and  list  on  the  screen  the 
 plants  and  trees  that  we  chose  for  the 
 area.  But  before  we  get  into  it,  I  kind 
 of  want  to  give  you  a  little  bit  of  the 
 backstory  on  this  particular  spot.  I'm 
 going to  get  Bryce  to  pop  in  the  before 
 pictures  and  that  way  you  guys  can  kind 
 of  a  general  feel,  general  vibe  for  this 
 particular  garden.  And  I  say  this 
 because  there  was  really  not  a  whole  lot 
 wrong  with  it,  you  know,  other  than  it 
 was  just  the  wrong  plants  for  the  yard. 
 My  clients  are  travelers.  They're 
 retired  now.  They  want  to  be  out  and 
 about  and  enjoy  retirement.  So,  they're 
 hoping  to  be  out  in  the  garden  only 
 every  couple  months  and  then  travel 
 every  other  time  between  then  and  come 
 home  to  a  well-maintained,  beautiful, 
 lowmaintenance  garden.  This  was  done 
 just  a  few  months  ago,  so  it's  still 
 fairly  new  in  the  planting  stages,  but  I 
 think  that  if  you  guys  are  looking  for 
 something  in  the  low  care  realm  and  you 
 still  want  that  splash  of  tropics,  then 
 stick  around  because  I  think  this  video 
 is  going  to  be  right  up  your  alley.  I  do 
 these  kind  of  projects  every  single 
 week.  We  design,  we  install,  we  design 
 only,  and  we  do  virtual  consults.  So, 
 those  of  you  guys  who  are  needing  some 
 more  than  inspiration  than  what  you're 
 seeing  here,  then  reach  out  to  us  and 
 see  if  we  might  be  a  good  fit  for  what 
 you  guys  are  looking  for.  But  right  now, 
 let's  jump  right  into  this  garden.  Okay. 
 So,  you  guys,  starting  in  this  front  bed 
 that  we  have  here,  starting  with  the 
 lowest  maintenance  thing  in  this  whole 
 front  bed, 
 boulders.  You  guys,  do  not  be  afraid  to 
 incorporate  some  boulders  into  your 
 garden.  They  add  a  change  of  texture, 
 add  a  little  bit  of  ump.  Your 
 landscape's  going  to  grow  around  them. 
 All  you  do  is  trim  around  the  boulders 
 so  that  way  it's  always  seen  in  the 
 garden  and  it  just  becomes  a  place  to 
 rest  your  eye  as  you're  looking  through 
 the  whole  space.  Having  some  impact 
 boulders,  they  don't  have  to  be  crazy 
 expensive  boulders.  I  love  the  coina 
 boulders.  I  love  what  they  offer.  Some 
 of  them  have  the  holes  in  them  where  you 
 can  pop  a  bmilad  or  an  interesting 
 succulent  into  it.  It's  just  kind  of  a 
 little  bit  of  a  little  bit  of 
 personality  in  the  garden  and  it  changes 
 up  that  texture  with,  let's  all  say  it, 
 lowmaintenance,  no  maintenance,  which  is 
 ideal  in  the  garden.  The  next  thing  that 
 we  did  is  you  guys  probably  remember  the 
 giant  fire  bush  clustering  that  was 
 here.  I  don't  know  if  it  came  across  in 
 the  picture  or  not,  but  it  was  taller 
 than  me  and  had  gaps  all  through  the 
 bottom  because  it  was  trimmed  and 
 trimmed  and  trimmed  to  try  to  maintain  a 
 lower  type  of  planting.  But  it  ended  up 
 turning  into  a  wall  which  pretty  much 
 walled  off  the  whole  front  of  the  house 
 here.  It  was  just  complete  cover.  So 
 that  was  the  first  thing  that  we  did. 
 completely  removed,  cleared  out 
 everything  in  this  bed  and  went  back 
 with  a  layering  effect  that  the  client 
 can  still  see  the  home  on.  Starting  with 
 our  low  material.  So  you  guys  know  I 
 love  my  blue  my  minds.  I  just  did  a 
 little  touch  of  those  right  on  the 
 corner  so  that  way  you  get  that  pop  of 
 color.  Now  you  see  we  started  with  the 
 lowest  tier.  So  this  is  kind  of  an  easy 
 thing  to  build  on.  When  you  have  blue  my 
 minds  it  means  what  you  have  in  the  back 
 doesn't  have  to  be  huge.  So  we've  got  a 
 little  clustering  of  foxtail  ferns. 
 Almost  every  time  I  do  a  unique  boulder 
 in  a  landscape,  I'll  put  some  foxtail 
 ferns  or  some  agave  or  some  vermilads, 
 whatever  the  budget  allows  to  kind  of 
 frame  that  boulder  to  kind  of  give  it  a 
 little  bit  of  a  I  don't  know,  a  little 
 bit  of  a  highlight.  So,  having  a  little 
 bit  of  a  halo  of  these  guys,  I  think 
 really  added  some  interest  here.  And 
 they're  not  too  big,  so  they're  not 
 going  to  cover  what  we  have  behind  them. 
 So,  right  behind  them,  we've  got  a  nice 
 grouping  of  King  Seos.  Now,  king  seos 
 grow  exceptionally  slow.  So,  they  kind 
 of  require  once  a  year  trimming.  So, 
 I've  got  them  dazzled  in  a  little 
 cluster  here,  pulled  forward,  back, 
 forward.  And  that's  kind  of my  style. 
 I'm  a  zigzagger  kind  of  landscapers.  And 
 then  I  chose  a  bedding  plant  to  go 
 around  them.  So,  they're  going  to  be 
 really  highlighted  by  these  golden  dues 
 or  gold  mounds  down  below.  When  those 
 are  trimmed  to  kind  of  curve  all  the  way 
 through  this  bed,  they're  clustered 
 together  here  and  they  curve  up 
 through  here  and  then  back  this  way.  It 
 looks  nice  now,  but  when  it  grows  in, 
 it's  going  to  be  like  a  sea  of  this 
 beautiful  lime  kind  of  coloring  and 
 yellow  during  the  summer.  Now,  those  are 
 probably  going  to  be  on  the  higher 
 maintenance  of  everything  in  this  whole 
 garden  because  every  other  month  those 
 are  going  to  need  trimming.  But  most 
 people  have  lawn  maintenance  companies. 
 And  the  one  thing  that  lawn  maintenance 
 companies  do  really  well  is  hedge  trim. 
 So  when  you  have  a  hedge  planting 
 amongst  all  your  sea  of  your  tropical 
 plantings,  you  don't  necessarily  have  to 
 worry  about  how  they're  going  to  trim 
 it.  They're  not  going  to  scalp  it  or  cut 
 it  too  tight  or  cut  it  too  short.  A 
 hedge  of  golden  mound  is  pretty  easy  to 
 kind  of  figure  out  how  you  want  that. 
 So,  this  is  going  to  be  a  nice  dwarfed 
 twoft  sea  of  light  lime  green  during  the 
 times  of  the  year  and  yellow  during  the 
 summer  times  of  the  year.  Then,  we  go 
 into  a  collection  of  these  Carissa 
 boxwood,  which  are  like  a  Florida 
 boxwood.  They're  very  formal,  very,  very 
 tight,  but  I  love  their  round  leaf. 
 They're  very  controlled,  a  great  little 
 planting,  and  they're  just  going  to  kind 
 of  give  us  a  break  between  the  colors, 
 and  that  nothing  shows  off  a  color  more 
 than  when  you  add  green  to  it.  This  pop 
 of  green  between  the  blue,  between  the 
 yellow,  and  again  the  blue  is  really 
 going  to  show  off  so  much  because  of 
 those  little  green  guys.  Kind  of 
 visualize  with  me.  Everything  from  the 
 front  stays  low,  works  its  way  up 
 higher.  Accents  pop  out  of  the  twoft 
 plant  bedding  here.  So,  this  is  going  to 
 be  overall  a  very  clean  design  that 
 really  just  has  some  some  vertical 
 interest,  but  not  overdone  because 
 that's  exactly  what  he  was  getting  away 
 from.  He  did  not  want  it  to  be  overdone. 
 You  didn't  want  to  come  back  and  it'd  be 
 10t  tall  in  this  area  or  even  have 
 things  like  that  in  the  spot.  Now,  I 
 will  say  we  hit  it  out  of  the  park  with 
 this  house  because  they  already  had  a 
 beautiful  collection  of  trees.  We  have 
 two  gorgeous  Christmas  palms  here.  We 
 have  two  stately  foxtail  palms  right  at 
 the  edge  of  the  driveway.  We  have  a 
 beautiful  triple  foxtail  palm  on  the 
 opposite  side  of  the  house  that  is 
 really  grown  in.  Is  just  a  stunner.  on 
 that  corner.  Originally,  there  was  a 
 tree  here,  a  diseased  magnolia  that  just 
 been  struggling  and  it  was  so  close  to 
 everything  else  and  it  was  about,  I 
 would  say,  18t  tall.  It  was  pretty 
 enormous.  It  just  pretty  much  took  up 
 this  whole  space  and  it  was  never  really 
 happy  here.  So,  my  client  was  open  to 
 just  taking  that  out  and  really  opening 
 up  this  bed.  Now,  they  have  concrete 
 curving.  Not  my  favorite,  but  it's 
 working  in  the  space.  If  it  were  edging, 
 I  may  have  changed  the  bed  a  little  bit. 
 just  tweaked  it  a  little  bit  because  you 
 can  pop  that  up  and  add  to  it.  But 
 unfortunately,  the  concrete  edging  is 
 here  to  stay  and  not  you  can't  really 
 manipulate  it  much.  So,  we  worked  with 
 what  was  there,  but  you  know,  sometimes 
 that's  exactly  what  you  have  to  do  in 
 the  landscape  world.  Now,  we  have  two 
 bare  spots  on  the  walls.  So,  originally 
 they  had  a  lot  of  foliage  right  up 
 against  the  house  line  on  the  walls,  but 
 having  some  impact  that's  controlled 
 here,  I  think  is  going  to  be  so  cool. 
 having  that  lime  green  color,  the  blues, 
 the  greens,  the  greens  from  the  King 
 Seos,  and  then  there's  a  big  break  with 
 the  quarter  lines.  I  just  think  that's 
 such  a  cool,  it's  going  to  be  such  a 
 cool  look.  Letting  these  guys  get  to 
 about  my  height  is  going  to  be  gorgeous 
 right  here.  This  just  big  pop  of  color. 
 This  is  a  nice  protected  area,  so 
 they're  going  to  have  a  deeper  tone  than 
 normal.  Now,  you  guys,  when  you  plant 
 your  quarter  lines,  I  know  a  lot  of 
 people  plant  them  at  a  good  distance 
 apart  because  they  worry  about  those 
 roots  connecting  to  the  other  plants  and 
 maybe  starving  them  out.  That  is  not  the 
 case  with  quarter  lines.  You  could 
 actually  pile  these  guys  up  together  and 
 plant  them  in  almost  like  a  bouquet 
 fashion  because  you're  going  to  modify 
 that  soil.  I  mean,  look  how  close  these 
 guys  are  planted  together.  It  allows  it 
 to  be  so  dense  and  full  and  such  a 
 gorgeous  collection.  I  get  so  many 
 questions  on  how  do  you  keep  your 
 quarterline  so  thick  and  luscious  and 
 big.  That's  exactly  how  you  do  it. 
 They'll  naturally  grow  out  like  a  lily 
 versus  growing  straight  up.  So,  they'll 
 kind  of  push  against  each  other  and  do 
 that.  And  as  long  as  your  soil  is  good 
 and  fertile,  as  long  as  you  fertilize, 
 they're  not  going  to  have  any  issues 
 because  they're  going  to  join  roots  and 
 it's  almost  like  you  potted  them  up  from 
 a  small  pot  to  a  bigger  pot  and  they're 
 very,  very  happy.  All right,  so  moving 
 on  to  the  next  area.  So  we  have  some 
 dwarf  kousia.  These  guys  do  not  do  what 
 your  regular  kousia  do.  They  have  a  much 
 smaller  leaf.  They're  the  minis.  They're 
 called  nanas,  and  they  really  stay 
 compact.  You  really  have  to  trim  them 
 very  little,  but  they  have  that  same 
 cool  succulent  leaf.  These  guys  just  had 
 a  real  harsh  trim  back.  So,  you  can 
 really  see  that  they're  a  little  stemi 
 right  now,  but  normally  they're  full  and 
 thick  and  just  such  a  beautiful  tropical 
 little  plant.  A  lot  of  people  say  they 
 look  like  little  mini  sea  grapes,  but 
 they're  just  such  a  cool  little  compact 
 plant.  Easy  to  keep.  They're  just  a  step 
 up  in  size  from  these  carissa  boxwood. 
 So,  they're  going  to  play  so  well 
 together.  And  then  because  we  have  what 
 all  the  paired  backness  to  the  front,  we 
 get  to  get  a  little  wild  and  crazy  to 
 the  back.  So,  we  have  the  song  of  India. 
 I  just  love  how  they're  going  to 
 encompass  this  Queen  Emma.  When  this 
 Queen  Emma  gets  bigger,  you  won't  see 
 this  base  at  all  because  between  these 
 guys  when  they  get  two  foot  and  those 
 guys  when  they  get  4  foot,  you're  really 
 going  to  have  a  sea  of  variegation  and 
 color  right  there.  And  then  that  Queen 
 Emma  is  going  to  pop  out  like,  you  know, 
 somebody  popping  out  of  a  birthday  cake. 
 It's  going  to  be  so  gorgeous  as  that 
 center  firework  in  the  garden.  And  what 
 you'll  notice  that  one  of  the  things 
 that  I  really  liked  about  this  house  is 
 probably  what  you  guys  are  liking,  which 
 is  the  stone  work.  I  think  that  it's  so 
 cool  and  great  feature  on  the  what  it's 
 a  relatively  small  wall.  So  I  took  the 
 blank  walls  and  dialed  them  way  up  with 
 some  color.  And  then  I  took  the  center 
 of  the  window  and  kind  of  gave  something 
 more  vertical  that's  going  to  be  more  of 
 an  impact  vertically  here  that  is  almost 
 going  to  bring  your  attention  to  the 
 wall  instead  of  hiding  it.  So  we've  got 
 chunky  and  fat  vertical  on  the  sides  and 
 then  something  like  a  firework  fountain 
 like  in  the  middle.  And  I  think  that's 
 just  going  to  be  a  nice  combination  in 
 this  front  area.  And  keep  in  mind  this 
 bed  is  not  huge  if  you  guys  are  looking 
 at  this  space.  So  we  really  don't  have  a 
 lot  of  space  to  work  with  in  the  yard  in 
 this  whole  front  yard  space.  This  is 
 outside  the  house  line  right  to  the 
 edge.  And  right  now  all  there  is  is 
 palmettos  and  some  invasive  vines  to 
 that  back.  So  I  chose  Brazilian  red 
 cloaks.  I  really  want  them  to  kind  of 
 engulf  the  whole  base  of  this  tree.  So 
 they  kind  of  go  all  the  way  around  this 
 beautiful  triple  palm  tree.  you  get 
 these  beautiful  big  giant  blooms  that 
 are going  to  come  about  6  to  8  foot  tall 
 and  this  will  be  the  highest  part  of  the 
 landscape.  This  will  be  the  ending 
 point.  It'll  be  almost  like  you  have  now 
 reached  the  finish  line  to  this  bed  and 
 that's  exactly  what  these  guys  are  going 
 to  do.  They're  going  to  really  blanket 
 and  I  think  that's  going  to  be  a  stunner 
 as  a  nice  backdrop  and  it  also  helps 
 kind  of  give  a  little  bit  of  softness  to 
 all  the  pomemettos  behind  it.  We  have  a 
 little  clustering  to  the  front  of  the 
 Songs  of  India  just  to  tie  in  with  that 
 middle  area.  And  then  of  course,  we 
 finished  them  off  with  the  Carissa 
 boxwood.  Now,  if  this  is  y'all's  style 
 and  you  like  this  kind  of  look  for  this 
 particular  bed,  see  how  I  have  a  Carissa 
 boxwood?  I  don't  have  a  whole  row  of 
 them.  I  like  to  keep  it  a  little 
 interesting.  We've  got  the  Carissa 
 boxwood,  a  grouping  of  three,  then 
 there's  a  boulder  and  a  break.  Again, 
 it's  a  rinse  and  repeat.  It's  following 
 a  rhythm.  It's  finding  a  pattern, 
 working  that  pattern  through  the  whole 
 bed.  I  know  that  this  bed  size  is 
 different  than  the  opposite  bed  size, 
 but  you  still  have  to  find  similarities. 
 You'll  notice  that  the  landscape  bed 
 just  comes  together  so  nicely  because 
 there's  a  flow  to  it.  There's  just  a 
 nice  natural  flow  to  that  whole  bed  when 
 that's  done.  So,  find  what  you  like, 
 take  that,  and  then  do  a  break.  Find  a 
 centerpiece  and  then  do  that  again.  Find 
 your  centerpieces  over  here,  but 
 continue  with  that  pattern.  And  if  you 
 can  follow  through  with  that  pattern, 
 then  now  everything  looks  seamless.  And 
 better  than  that,  everything  is  super 
 lowmaintenance.  So,  let's  pop  over  here 
 to  the  next  bed.  But  before  we  do  that, 
 if  this  is  the  kind  of  content  that  you 
 guys  like,  please  do  not  forget  to  like, 
 subscribe,  and  hit  that  little 
 notification  bell.  We  post  every  single 
 weekend,  kind  of  tours  like  this, 
 talking  about  plants  and  trees.  All 
 right,  you  guys.  So,  we're  going  to  work 
 our  way  into  the  next  section  of  the 
 garden.  This  is  coming  right  up  the 
 driveway.  Now,  these  were  not  my  doing. 
 This  was  already  here.  They  had  two 
 beautiful  foxtail  palms  here  surrounded 
 by  some  foxtail  ferns.  A  lot  of  people 
 have  a  very  similar  situation.  They'll 
 have  us  come  in  and  do  like  big  nice  big 
 looped  curved  beds  in  the  front  or  the 
 backyard,  but  then  they've  got  those 
 certain  areas  of  their  previous 
 landscape  and  they're  like,  should  we 
 tie  in  that  to  your  landscape  or  should 
 we  keep  it  separate?  And  a  lot  of  cases 
 I  do  tie  it  in  together.  However,  in 
 this  particular  case,  because  of  the 
 concrete  curbing,  I  opted  to  leave  it 
 individual.  And  I'm  not  hating  it.  I 
 really  do  like  it.  This  side  was  an  easy 
 like  no-brainer.  Obviously,  there's 
 plenty  of  separation,  but  this  side  over 
 here,  I  had  some  concerns  about  because 
 this  area  there  was  a  little  bit  of  a 
 gap  between  here  and  a  little  bit  of a 
 gap  between  there.  And  I  know  low 
 maintenance  was  our  thing.  So,  I'm 
 always  thinking  about  what  is  the  lowest 
 maintenance.  However,  my  client  was 
 perfectly  fine  with  keeping  these  two 
 islands  separated.  I  think  it  added  just 
 a  little  bit  of  that  natural  feel  to  a 
 more  manicured  landscape  that  we  have  to 
 the  back.  And  then  I  also  noticed  that 
 they  took  that  same  kind  of  stonework 
 and  kept  it  in  the  front  sections  right 
 by  the  front  area  of  the  bed.  So  it  kind 
 of  tied  the  two  areas  together.  And  I 
 guess  you  guys  can  see  a  theme  in  the 
 way  that  I  think.  As  long  as  you  have 
 something  that  makes  sense.  As  long  as 
 there's  a  theme  that  starts  here  and 
 wherever  it  ends,  you  continue 
 throughout  those  key  areas  with  that 
 same  theme,  then  you're  going  to  have  a 
 successful  landscape.  It's  going  to  be 
 beautiful  and  it's  going  to  work.  It's 
 going  to  work  low  maintenance-wise  for 
 you.  And  if  this  is  something  that  you 
 guys  are  thinking  about  doing  and  you 
 have  a  similar  situation,  then  just  tie 
 in  whatever  underplanting  maybe.  So 
 maybe  you've  got  a  tree  out  there,  maybe 
 it's  a  holly,  maybe  it's  a  palm  tree, 
 maybe  it's  whatever  it  might  be.  Take 
 whatever  plant  grouping  that  you  have 
 somewhere  else  in  the  bed  and  tie  that 
 in.  Because  you  can  see  underneath  here, 
 we've  got  foxtail  ferns  here  and  it  ties 
 in  with  the  other  foxtail  ferns  that 
 we've  just  kind  of  spotted  around  those 
 boulders,  but  this  could  have  been  the 
 same  type  of  lower  ground  cover  that  we 
 have  in  other  areas  and  worked  just  the 
 same.  So,  we  are  now  at  the  last  bed  in 
 this  front  yard  design,  and  I  think  it's 
 a  beautiful  bed.  I  think  it's  got  a  lot 
 of  variegation  of  color.  I  think  it's 
 really  going  to  bring  a  lot  of  pop.  Now, 
 this  is  the  bed  that's  seen  when  people 
 pull  up  the  driveway,  they  park  here, 
 they  get  out,  they  go  to  the  front  door. 
 So,  this  is  the  area  when  my  client  when 
 Tom  is  pulling  out  and  coming  around 
 this  way,  he  gets  this  right  in  his  face 
 every  single  morning.  And  I  think,  what 
 a  better  way  to  wake  up  than  this.  I 
 think  is  going  to  turn  out  so 
 beautifully  as  it  matures.  These  three 
 palm  trees  we  were  lucky  enough  to 
 inherit.  They  were  here.  So,  we  worked 
 with  what  was  here.  Again,  when  you're 
 doing  lowmaintenance  material,  you  want 
 to  kind  of  uh  work  with  things  that  are 
 more  ordinary,  things  that  are  that  have 
 been  around  the  bin  a  while,  and  that 
 means  mam  croins  and  variegated 
 arbicola.  Are  they  always  showstoppers 
 in  everybody's  garden?  No.  In  some  case, 
 they're  a  supporting  plant  that  just 
 offers  you  exactly  what  you  need.  But 
 sometimes  if  you  take  those  particular 
 plants,  granted  they  have  to  be  a  good 
 quality  of  that  type  of  plant,  but  you 
 take  those  common  plants  and  then  you 
 introduce  something  really  cool  and 
 exotic  near  it,  then  it  allowed  for  you 
 to  have  both  by  choosing  a  more 
 simplistic  plant.  Because  if  you're 
 trying  to  keep  a  low  maintenance  garden, 
 you  got  to  kind  of  be  careful  about  the 
 drama  queens  that  you  pick  in  the 
 garden.  I'm  going  to  balance  it  out  with 
 things  like  this  that  are  more  common 
 that  are  easy  to  care  for  and  not  going 
 to  get  away  from  me.  Mam  Croins  do  a 
 great  job  of  that.  They  really  round 
 out.  They  stay  nice  and  compact.  You  can 
 keep  these  guys  2  foot,  3  foot,  4  foot, 
 whatever  your  collection  of  height  that 
 you're  looking  for  in  this  area  because 
 they  grow  so  slow  and  you  have  to  trim 
 them  so  little.  You  can  keep  them  at  a 
 desired  height  as  small  as  2  foot,  which 
 is  ideal.  These  to  the  back  are  the 
 variegated  arbicas.  And  having  them 
 right  in  this  range,  having  them  around 
 4t  is  going  to  make  this  color  pop  out. 
 Right  now,  you  see  right  through  to  the 
 back  because  these  aren't  tall  enough. 
 But  once  they  get  into  this  height,  have 
 a  little  yellow  and  green  to  the  back  of 
 your  red  and  yellows  and  oranges,  and 
 you  will  see  those  red,  yellows,  and 
 oranges  pop  like  crazy  because  of  what 
 these  guys  are  doing  as  a  backdrop  to 
 force  that  color  forward.  So,  these  are 
 going to  be  a  great  yellow  and  green 
 green  screen  for  this  color  on  this 
 corner.  And  then  we  had  two  kind  of  big 
 gaps.  We  have  a  tree  in  the  middle  with 
 kind  of  no  real  center  pieces.  So,  I 
 opted  to  do  two  cateria  palms.  They're 
 only  going  to  get  9  to  10  foot  in  this 
 particular  spot.  They're  kind  of  nice 
 and  compact  at  the  bottom.  Opens  up  like 
 a  bouquet  towards  the  middle  and  kind  of 
 softens  this  back  area.  He  didn't  want 
 anything  like  kousi  here  or  anything 
 like  too  much  of  a  barrier  here.  More  of 
 a  natural  screening  because  there's  no 
 grass  behind  there.  That's  kind  of  just 
 a  a  natural  walkway  to  get  back  to  the 
 preserve.  So,  he  wanted  a  soft  screening 
 but  not  complete  coverage.  And  that's 
 exactly  what  this  is  going  to  do.  Now 
 just  to  either  side  of  the  variegated 
 arbicas,  we  have  the  Pinocchio  Croins. 
 These  Croins  have  stolen  my  heart.  I  am 
 using  them  everywhere.  I  love  the  way 
 they  look.  I  started  using  them  about  3 
 years  ago,  but  now  I'm  seeing  them  more 
 readily  available  and  thank  goodness  for 
 it  because  they  can  grow  in  the  sun. 
 They  can  grow  in  the  shade  and  I  mean 
 sun,  I  mean  sun,  sun,  sun.  They  can  grow 
 out  in  the  full  sun  and  really  keep  that 
 spotted  variegated  color.  It's  kind  of  a 
 combination  of  different  leaves.  I  mean, 
 look  at  this  leaf  color  here  with  some 
 of  that  orange  to  some  of  this  leaf 
 color.  I  don't know  if  you  can  see  it, 
 but  down  here  with  just  that  kind  of 
 variegation  of  what  almost  like  a  sloppy 
 painter  does.  It's  got  like  a 
 combination  of  several  different 
 varieties  of  croins  all  in  one.  But  what 
 I  do  like  about  them  is  they  will  get 
 big.  So  these  guys  could  get  five,  six, 
 seven  foot  tall  back  here  and  stay  full 
 from  the  top  to  the  bottom,  which  is  a 
 unique  trait  when  it  comes  to  croins. 
 That  is  not  something  that  you  commonly 
 get.  You  always  have  to  have  a  skirt 
 planting  mostly  with  croins.  These  guys 
 will  stay  full  top  to  bottom  become  a 
 nice  colorful  wall  back  here  and  they're 
 going to  have  the  variegation  of  the 
 light  and  greens  on  either  side.  So  that 
 variegation  of  the  arbicas  down  to  these 
 is  just  going  to  be  a  pop  of  color.  And 
 just  in  case  that  wasn't  enough  color, 
 we've  spotted  the  songs  of  India  to  the 
 front  of  those.  Oh  my  goodness.  Right 
 around  that  boulder.  They're  all  hairy 
 carry.  They're  all  a  little  wild. 
 They're  right  after  my  own  heart.  I  just 
 love  how  they're  going  to  connect 
 together.  And  you  guys,  we  do  not  have 
 tons  of  these.  We  have  six.  Three  and 
 three  in  a  triangle  formation.  Two  to 
 the  back,  one  pulled  forward.  Here  we 
 have  two  to  the  front,  one  pulled  back. 
 I  love  that  zigzag  pattern  because  my 
 whole  goal  is  to  make  six  plants  look 
 like  one  plant.  You  want  a  kind  of  a 
 connection.  That's  what  keeps  things  low 
 maintenance.  It  helps  with  weed  control, 
 making  this  your  ground  cover  by  itself. 
 Once  these  connect,  you're  not  mulching 
 in  this  bed.  You're  only  mulching  along 
 the  tips  or  along  the  edges  of  the 
 garden.  This  is  all  concealed.  This  is 
 all  dense.  This  is  all  full.  And  it  goes 
 from  this  height  of  4  foot  to  what's 
 hopefully  get  to  about  6T  and  then  we've 
 got  4T  on  the  corners  with  the 
 variegated  aricas  down  to  2  foot  with 
 the  mammy  croins  in  the  front.  So  you 
 can  kind  of  see  how  this  layering  is 
 going  to  come  in.  And  I  mean  it's  going 
 to  go  boom  boom  back  down  to  the  foxtail 
 ferns  up  to  the  variegated  arbicas  up  to 
 the  tallest  version  of  these  pinocchio 
 croins  and  then  down  to  the  song  of 
 India  and  then  all  the  way  down  to  the 
 la  at  the  end.  So  when  this  bed  comes 
 together  it's  going  to  be  just  like  a 
 sequence  of  movement.  It's  not  a  huge 
 bed  to  do  that.  This  can  be  any  island 
 somewhere  or  any  front  yard  anywhere. 
 This  doesn't  have  to  be  at  the  edge  of  a 
 driveway.  I  think  you  can  replicate  this 
 just  about  anywhere  that  you  get  a 
 little  bit  of  filter  protection.  You  do 
 need  some  sun  protection  to  create  an 
 island  like  this,  but  overall  it's  going 
 to  be  an  easy  care  island.  And  then  we 
 have  a  centerpiece  of  the  boulder  and  we 
 flanked  an  agave  on  either  side  of  those 
 boulders.  And  then  yet  again,  a  little 
 clustering  of  three  foxtail  ferns  to 
 kind  of  give  it  a  little  bit  of  impact 
 and  to  kind  of  tie  it  in  with  the  rest 
 of the  landscape.  In  this  particular 
 spot,  we  don't  have,  believe  it  or  not, 
 as  much  sun  as  we  have  in  the  front.  So, 
 I  use  Lauria,  evergreen  laapy.  That's 
 going  to  stay  nice  and  compact  and  low 
 and  just  kind  of  give  this  bed  a  little 
 bit  of  a  softening.  So,  it's  going  to  do 
 a  great  job.  If  they  didn't  have 
 curbing,  that  would  help  that  mulch  flow 
 in.  So,  if  you  guys  do  not  have  edging 
 between  your  pavers  and  your 
 landscaping,  use  green  la.  They'll  do  a 
 fantastic  job.  Just  stagger  them  in  and 
 they'll  kind  of  knit  together  and  hold 
 in  that  ground  cover.  And  then  as  that 
 grows  in  a  year,  year  and  a  half  later, 
 you  won't  have  to  mulch  those  edgings  at 
 all  because  that  laria  pee  will  now 
 become  your  ground  cover.  So  it's  an 
 ideal  thing  to  incorporate.  All  right, 
 you  guys.  We  have  reached  the  end  of  the 
 bed.  This  right  here  is  a  transplanted 
 bird  of  paradise.  We  inherited  it.  It's 
 going  through  a  little  bit  of  a  shock, 
 but  it'll  bounce  back.  We  had  this 
 little  corner  area,  so  I  chose  to 
 relocate  it  back  into  this  spot.  And 
 then  we  ended  it  with  the  Brazilian  red 
 cloaks,  just  like  we  have  on  the 
 opposite  corner  of  the  garden.  the  whole 
 other  side  of  the  yard.  But  when  you're 
 looking  from  the  street  and  these  guys 
 are  6  7  foot  tall  and  those  guys  are  6  7 
 foot  tall  over  there,  blooming  with 
 color,  it'll  feel  like  the  perfect 
 sandwich.  The  house  is  just  sandwiched 
 in  between  them.  So  ending  it  where  you 
 started  is  ideal  if  you  can  do  that.  The 
 rest  of  the  garden,  as  you  can  see,  is  a 
 complete  repeat  of  what  we  have  on  the 
 opposite  side.  And  that  is  the  goal 
 there.  We're  going  to  get  out  of  here 
 before  we  continue  to  melt.  As  you  can 
 see,  Bryce  and  I  are  both  melting.  So, 
 if  you  guys  enjoyed  today's  garden  tour, 
 then  you  really  might  enjoy  last  week's 
 garden  tour,  which  is  instant  privacy. 
 This  is  going  to  be  give  you  exactly 
 what  you're  looking  for  if  you  want  to 
 get  rid  of  some  nosy  neighbors.  So, 
 thank  you  guys  so  much.  Take  care.  See 
 you  next  weekend.

---

 Well,  hey  gardeners.  I  hear  you  guys  are 
 looking  for  some  potted  plants  to  liven 
 up  just  that  perfect  spot  in  your  own 
 backyard  or  front  yard  space.  Well, 
 today  I  want  to  share  with  you  some  of 
 my  favorite,  five  in  particular,  of  my 
 favorite  potted  plants  that  I  have  here 
 in  my  very  own  garden.  However,  this 
 isn't  just  about  looks.  These  potted 
 plants  are  in  here  for  a  specific 
 reason.  They're  helping  me  solve  a 
 problem  in  my  space.  then  sharing  those 
 plants  and  that  reason  really  might  help 
 you  find  the  perfect  spot  and  fix  a 
 problem  in  your  own  space.  So  you  guys 
 remember  if  this  is  the  kind  of  content 
 that  you  guys  like  to  see,  please  like, 
 subscribe,  hit  that  little  notification 
 bell,  but  we're  going  to  jump  right  into 
 the  very  first  plant.  So  for  starters  is 
 my  dune  palm.  Oh  my  goodness,  what  a 
 fabulous  palm  this  guy  is.  I  absolutely 
 love  this  vertical  look  that  it  offers. 
 I  plant  them  all  the  time  in  the  ground. 
 However,  in  this  particular  spot,  I  had 
 these  old  croins.  These  are  excellence 
 croins  that  I  had  to  cut  back  when  we 
 installed  our  pool,  and  I  wanted  them  to 
 get  big.  I  love  the  way  they  look  when 
 they  really  grow  into  this  space,  but  I 
 still  wanted  something  to  bounce  off 
 this  fence  line.  So,  I  wanted  something 
 real  vertical,  something  that  would  give 
 us  a  nice  almost  like  a  sculpture  in  the 
 garden.  That's  exactly  what  a  potted 
 plant  offers  you  is  it  gives  you  a 
 little  raise,  gets  it  into  the  garden, 
 gives  you  a  little  bit  of  feature  at  the 
 bottom  with  some  color  and  then  you  can 
 put  something  vertical  and  set  it  right 
 into  the  garden.  Now,  this  particular 
 spot  right  here  has  a  stump  underneath. 
 So,  it  was  one  of  those  that  was  kind  of 
 challenging.  I  couldn't  put  a  tree  here 
 if  I  wanted  to,  but  I  absolutely  love 
 that,  you  know,  30-in  rise  that  it  gave 
 me  by  putting  a  pot  in  this  spot  and 
 then  allowing  this  guy  to  get.  you  know, 
 he'll  get  about  2  foot  taller  and  stop 
 and  then  these  guys  will  engulf  the  base 
 and  it'll  just  look  like  he's  tucked 
 right  into  this  nook.  So,  a  dune  palm  is 
 ideal  for  a  pot  and  can  live  in  it  for  a 
 long,  long  time.  They  don't  have  a  huge 
 root  system,  so  they  can  really 
 withstand  sitting  in  a  pot  for  a  good 
 period  of  time.  And  then  they  can  also 
 dry  out  really  well.  So,  if  I  forget 
 this  little  area  for  any  length  of  time 
 or  I  don't  have a  pot  mister  or  don't 
 have  irrigation,  this  is  a  drought 
 tolerant  tree.  It  can  really  really  do 
 well  here  in  kind  of  a  forget  me  spot. 
 It  does  like  a  little  bit  of  protection. 
 Can  handle  early  morning,  midday,  early 
 afternoon  sun,  but  that  late  afternoon 
 sun  kind  of  where  we  are  now,  that's  the 
 perfect  time  for  it  to  get  some  shade. 
 It'll  be  a  super  super  happy  tree  in  any 
 of  those  conditions.  And  I  just  I  love 
 what  it  does  here.  However,  for  another 
 plus  of  why  it's  in  the  pot  is  this  tree 
 would  never  get  to  the  stature  that  it's 
 in  without  this  kind  of  height  that  the 
 pot  is  offering.  And  without  that  kind 
 of  height,  it  would  get  engulfed  and 
 just  kind  of  get  lost  into  this  space 
 because  these  guys  I'm  going  to  let  be 
 around  that  5  foot  range  and  really 
 engulf  the  base  of  it.  Having  it  in  the 
 pot  allows  me  to  give  that  rise  and  it's 
 not  going  to  get  lost  in  this  planting. 
 So  that  can  happen  a  lot.  Like  the 
 laqualas  for  instance,  every  time  I  put 
 a  laquala  in,  clients  are  always 
 concerned  it's  going  to  get  lost  in  the 
 rest  of the  foliage.  And  it  absolutely 
 can.  So  if  that's  you,  then  put  that 
 laquala  in  a  30  in  or  24in  pot.  I  give 
 it  a  little bit  of  rise.  Stick  that  guy 
 into  the  garden  and  let  him  just  kind  of 
 just  have  his  own  space  popped  up, 
 elevated.  And  they're  they're  fabulous 
 for  that.  And  then  even  maybe  stick  a 
 little  plant  stand  underneath  of  it  and 
 add  a  little  bit  of  light  and  it'll 
 shine  glow  underneath.  I  just  love  what 
 you  can  do  with  pots.  And  that's  the 
 thing  to  kind  of  keep  in  mind,  you  know, 
 don't  just  rush  to  go  put  the  first 
 thing  into  that  pot.  Set  that  pot  there 
 for  a  little  while.  Really  get  an  idea 
 of  what  you're  wanting  to  achieve  with 
 the  space.  I  knew  in  this  spot  I  wanted 
 to  soften  that  hard  fence  that  you  see 
 in  the  garden.  And  I  love  the  idea  of 
 having  another  palm  tree  here  even 
 though  I  couldn't.  So  the  pot  allowed  me 
 to  do  that  because  it  gave  me  the  rays, 
 got  me  up  out  of  this  color  here,  and 
 then  it's  going  to  allow  this  to  really 
 become  almost  like  a  crowning  effect 
 over  top  of  this  spot.  So  a  pot  in  the 
 garden,  ideal  thing  to  do.  Dune  palms 
 are  fabulous  for  that.  So  give  them  a 
 try.  And  now  for  my  second  favorite 
 potted  plant.  Now,  you  guys,  I'm  sure, 
 have  seen  this  in  the  background  of  a 
 lot  of  videos.  She  is  not  into  her  full 
 bloom  right  now.  She  just  went  through  a 
 blooming  cycle  and  was  just  covered  with 
 these  beautiful  pink  blooms.  It  is  the 
 famous  desert  rose.  Now,  I  see  these 
 guys  in  nurseries  all  the  time.  They're 
 in  pots  this  big  and  you  put  them  in  the 
 ground  and  they  just  don't  do  super 
 well.  A  lot  of  people  will  have  them  in 
 small  pots,  but  you  guys  consider 
 putting  them  into  a  larger  pot.  Give 
 them  some  room  to  grow.  Give  them  time 
 to  become  that  statement  piece  and  you 
 will  not  regret  it.  I  have  had  her  here 
 for  years  and  years  and  years.  She's 
 developed  all  of  these  cool  trunks.  I 
 cut  her  back  every  single  year  and  then 
 just  kind  of  give  it  a  nice  rounded 
 little  haircut  here  and  then  it  just 
 blossoms  all  the  way  around  and  offers 
 just  a  little  bit  of  softness  to  the 
 edge  of  my  decking.  Now  I  have  my  fence 
 here  and  I  kind  of  just,  you  know,  I 
 kind  of  wanted  something  with  some 
 beauty  right  up  against  the  patio.  a  lot 
 of  harshness  that  I  have  here  with  the 
 hardcaping.  And  I  think  the  pot  did  a 
 fabulous  job  of  doing  that.  And  the 
 desert  rose  is  one  of  those  kind  of 
 forget  me  knots.  You  know,  you  don't 
 have  to  water  it.  It's  watered  by  the 
 rain.  It  you  really  don't  have  to  do  a 
 whole  lot  to  it.  Wants  a  little  bit  of 
 fertilizer  every  once  in  a  while,  but 
 that's  it.  Overall,  I  do  very  little  to 
 nothing  other  than  maybe  a  once  a  year 
 trimming  on  it.  And  it  just  shows  off 
 all  summer  long.  10  months  out  of  the 
 year,  fabulous  with  color.  And  then  you 
 get  those  couple  months  where  it's 
 pretty  much  bald.  But,  you  know,  you  got 
 to  you  got  to  be  patient  with  her.  But 
 you  may  ask,  why  is  it  in  a  pot  and  not 
 into  the  garden?  Why  don't  I  have  tons 
 of  these  in  the  garden  if  they're  so  low 
 maintenance?  Well,  because  I  love  a 
 tropical  garden,  as  you  guys  can  see.  I 
 love  a  lush  tropical,  heavily  foliageed 
 garden  with  colors  and  layers.  And  this 
 girl  just  cannot  handle  it.  She  cannot 
 handle  all  that  water.  So,  if  I  put  her 
 into  the  ground,  then  she  will  get  root 
 rot.  and  you  know  that  will  be  the  end 
 of  her.  So  a  pot  is  an  ideal  situation. 
 Having  them  in  a  nice  big  pot  with  a 
 little  bit  of  stone  on  the  bottom  raised 
 up  with  these  pot  feet  that  I  have  here 
 will  allow  every  single  time  it  rains 
 the  water  to  drain  and  drain  out  and 
 release.  So  it's  never  going  to  get 
 water  logged  in  this  pot.  I  will  have 
 this  desert  rose  for  so  many  more  years 
 because  of  it  the  situation  that  it's 
 in.  It  gets  great  full  sun,  blooms  all 
 the  time,  and  then  I  don't  have  to  worry 
 about  watering  it  at  all.  So,  give  the 
 desert  rose  a  try.  If  you  guys  have  a 
 similar  situation,  if  you  got  a  pool 
 patio  or  if  you  got,  you  know,  a  hard 
 spot  like  this  that  gets  just  really 
 heavy  full  sun,  but  you  want  some  pops 
 of  color,  you  want  some  interest,  and 
 you've  got  maybe  some  cool  pots  you  want 
 to  showcase  something  in,  then  desert 
 roses  are  ideal  for  things  like  that. 
 So,  give  them  a  go.  All right,  you  guys. 
 So,  we  are  on  to  our  next  potted  plant. 
 Now,  if  you  guys  have  a  little  bit  of  a 
 shade  area,  this  is  a  perfect  little 
 tree  to  incorporate  into  your  garden. 
 Now,  you  can  put  it  on  a  patio  deck,  you 
 can  put  it  inside  a  pool,  inside  a  pool 
 cage,  you  can  put  it  inside  your  indoor 
 screen  area,  you  can  pretty  much  put  it 
 anywhere  where  it  gets  a  little  bit  of 
 protection  from  the  sun.  But  the  rafus 
 palm  or  aka  lady  palm  is  an  ideal  little
