 palm  tree  to  incorporate  into  a  space. 
 Now,  I  say  little  because  it  has  the 
 same  problem  that  the  dune  palm  had 
 where  it  was  just  a  tad  bit  small  to 
 incorporate  into  a  real  lush  garden.  So, 
 I  raised  it  and  put  it  into  this  planter 
 and  then  incorporated  it  back  into  the 
 garden  just  to  give  it  a  little  bit  of  a 
 different  texture.  Right  now,  we  have 
 some  very  newly  trimmed  kucia  as  our 
 backdrop  and  then  some  agave  down  below. 
 So,  we  have  a  lot  of  different  kind  of 
 foliage  here  and  that's  the  best  part 
 about  landscaping  is  you're  not  just 
 landscaping  with  plants  and  trees, 
 you're  landscaping  with  all  these 
 different  textures.  So  incorporating 
 things  like  these  little  fingered  fronds 
 here  is  a  whole  different  look  amongst 
 uh  layers  of  different  kind  of  flowy 
 natural  weeping  kind  of  fronds.  So  I 
 love  the  what  they  offer  in  the  garden. 
 However,  what  I  don't  love  is  the  level 
 of  maintenance  involved  when  they  go 
 into  the  ground.  Now  they  do  have  these 
 individual  stocks  here  that  are  runners. 
 So  those  guys  will  reproduce  and  pop  up 
 little  pups  in  other  places.  Now,  a  lot 
 of  people  have  no  trouble  cutting  them 
 out,  removing  them,  and  then  working 
 with  them.  However,  I  just  don't  I  don't 
 have  that  kind  of  time.  So,  I  really 
 love  the  idea  of  putting  them  into  a 
 pot.  So,  I  kind  of  keep  them  almost  like 
 a  bouquet  here.  And  I  grow  them  kind  of 
 like  I  farm  them.  So,  I  love  this  frond 
 so  much.  It  looks  so  fabulous  inside  my 
 house  as  little  cutings.  You  just  take 
 off  of  one  of  these  little  trunks  here. 
 You  take  three  or  four  little  fronds 
 here  and  then  put  it  into  the  smallest 
 of  voses  and  it  just  adds  a  little  bit 
 of  a  a  crazy  whimsy  kind  of  look.  So  I 
 think  they're  fabulous  for  indoor  vases. 
 So  this  is  such  a  slow  growing  little 
 tree.  It's  ideal  for  a  pot.  She's  been 
 in  this  pretty  small  chunky  pot  for 
 about  four  years  and  loving  it.  Still 
 producing,  still  doing  great.  So  I  would 
 say  this  is  a  fantastic  long-term  pot 
 tree  to  work  with.  But  now  let's  jump 
 over  to  the  next  tree.  All  right.  So  the 
 buganvilia,  oh  my  gosh,  if  you  are  in 
 Florida,  you  have  seen  buganvilia  here, 
 you've  seen  buganvilia  there.  They  are  a 
 fabulous,  fabulous  tree  or  bush  to  work 
 with  until  you  have  to  trim  them  and 
 then  you  have  to  trim  them  a  lot.  So  the 
 reason  why  I  put  my  buganilla  in  these 
 pots  here  in  my  front  entrance  for  two 
 good  reasons.  The  first  being  well 
 because  I  absolutely  love  them.  I  love 
 seeing  them  peek  out  into  having  these 
 blooms  and  this  kind  of  clustering  as 
 soon  as  I  walk  through  my  gate.  My 
 Bugenville  trees  have  two  to  three 
 different  colors  in  each  tree.  So,  when 
 they're  going  to  town,  they  are 
 absolutely  just  like  showstoppers  in  the 
 garden.  However,  they  are  very  similar 
 to  how  the  desert  rose  works.  They 
 really  just  do  not  like  that  much  water. 
 So,  the  more  stress  they  have,  the  lack 
 of  water,  all  that  heat  that  they  get 
 with  very  little  water  makes  them  bloom 
 like  crazy.  It's  like  they  show  up  in 
 tough  conditions.  They're  like  the 
 marines  of  the  garden.  These  guys  are 
 fantastic.  And  those  of  you  guys  who've 
 had  to  trim  them  in  the  past  know  that 
 they're  no  easy  walk  in  the  park  to 
 trim.  So  being  able  to  contain  them  in  a 
 pot  slows  the  growth  way  down.  So  you 
 can  really  kind  of  keep  these  in  nice 
 little  tree  forms  for  years  and  years 
 and  years  in  a  potted  area  and  put  them 
 out  into  your  sunny  spots.  Maybe  it's 
 those  spots  that  gosh  everything  fries 
 out  there.  Nothing  does  well.  Well,  try 
 Bugganville  because  they  love  it  out  in 
 this  particular  area.  They  do  like  to  be 
 fed,  so  fertilizing  is  a  part  of  their 
 maintenance.  However,  it  is  worth  it 
 when  you  fertilize  out  there  and  you 
 come  out  2  to  3  days  later  and  it's  like 
 with  all  this  color.  So,  so  worth  it. 
 So,  I  have  boogan  billas  coming  up 
 through  my  front.  Now,  another  reason 
 why  I  have  them  here  is  because  I  have  a 
 septic  tank  here  and  I  didn't  want  them 
 to  kind  of  crawl  and  go  all  through 
 this.  I've  really  tried  to  keep  my 
 landscaping  bare  in  this  particular 
 area.  And  by  putting  them  in  pots  here, 
 it  controls  any  kind  of  roots  or 
 anything  like  that  from  going  into  that 
 septic  system.  And  I  just  love  the  what 
 pots  offer  in  a  garden.  It's  a  little 
 bit  of  that  rustic  charm  in  the 
 landscape.  But  you  guys  will  have  to  let 
 me  know  what  you  think. 
 Wow.  Right  at  the  corner  of  my  property, 
 right  where  she  belongs,  this  is  the 
 variegated  tapioca  plant.  Now,  when  I 
 planted  this  girl,  she  was  not  very  big 
 at  all.  about  two  foot  tall  and  you  know 
 pretty  narrow  and  pretty  skinny.  And 
 that  is  the  reason  why  I  planted  her  in 
 a  pot  because  I  love  this  plant.  I  had  a 
 hard  time  figuring  out  how  best  to  use 
 it  in  a  garden.  And  when  that  happens,  I 
 really  don't  know  how  to  incorporate  it 
 in  other  people's  garden.  So,  I  wanted 
 to  make  sure  that  I  was  happy  with  the 
 growth  rate,  what  it  did,  if  it's 
 something  that  I  can  control  or  if  it's 
 something  that's  going  to  be  forever  in 
 a  potted  plant  location.  It's  perfect 
 for  those  cool  planters  that  you  want 
 something  interesting,  something  a 
 little  bit  crazy  to  work  with.  It's 
 ideal  for  that  situation.  Probably  not 
 something  that  I  would  put  into  an  open 
 planting  area  just  because  it  has  a 
 tendency  to  really  create  these  stocks, 
 really  kind  of  really  pop  out  and  create 
 beautiful  growth  at  the  top,  but  it's 
 going  to  follow  the  sun.  So,  wherever 
 the  sun  is,  that  might  not  be  where  you 
 want  it  to  go,  but  that's  where  it's 
 going  to  go.  So,  you  want  to  make  sure 
 to  kind  of  control  it  into  that  way. 
 Now,  I  am  allowing  it  to  continue 
 flowing  out  this  way  because  I  love 
 curves.  I  mean,  you  guys  have  been  on 
 this  channel,  you  know  how  much  I  love 
 curves.  So,  the  mere  fact  that  it's  kind 
 of  doing  this  whole  thing  is  totally  up 
 my  alley.  The  fact  that  it's  on  the 
 corner  of  my  walkway  as  you're  coming 
 around  the  corner  leading  into  the 
 backyard  setting.  I  think  that  it  kind 
 of  adds  a  little  bit  of  ump  like,  oh, 
 you  have  entered  the  garden.  So,  I  think 
 it's  just  ideal  for  that  kind  of  spot. 
 But  the  variegated  tapioca  has  these 
 gorgeous  leaves,  just  a  splash  of  bright 
 color.  And  then  all  the  stemming  has  a 
 little  bit  of  that  pinkish  reddish  tone 
 to  it.  And  then  of  course  the  individual 
 trunks  have  more  of  a  yellow  kind  of 
 framing  to  it.  What  a  beautiful 
 framework  it  has.  I  just  absolutely 
 think  it  is  a  gorgeous  plant  to  work 
 with.  Would  I  put  it  in  the  garden?  No. 
 It's  just  a  little  bit  too  wild,  too 
 crazy  even  for  me.  But  in  a  pot,  don't 
 hesitate.  put  in  a  small  planter  or  near 
 a  waterfall  area.  Some  of  the  pockets  of 
 the  waterfall,  this  is  an  ideal  plant  to 
 work  with.  You  can  get  them  in  three 
 gallon  size,  you  can  get  them  in  seven 
 gallon  size.  I've  seen  them  all  the  way 
 up  into  the  25gallon  size.  Make  sure  the 
 pot  is  big  enough  kind  of  like  this  big 
 clay  pot  that  we  have  here  where  it  is 
 heavy  enough,  has  enough  weight  to  it, 
 so  when  it  does  start  to  do  this,  you're 
 not  constantly  propping  or  or  fixing 
 this  pot.  I  have  to  do  nothing  with  this 
 area.  I  occasionally  trim  this  guy,  but 
 you  know,  overall  it's  been  a  sturdy  pot 
 in  a  sturdy  spot  for  this  particular 
 plant  in  the  garden,  but  variegated 
 tapioca  definitely  want  to  brighten  up  a 
 spot.  They  can  handle  filtered  light. 
 They  can  handle  medium  light.  They  like 
 obviously  the  sun,  so  they  can  handle 
 all  midday  sun.  Towards  the  afternoon 
 sun,  I've  seen  where  some  of  the  leaves 
 have  dried,  so  it  got  kind  of  got  a 
 little  bit  of  sunburnt  spot.  So  pay  kind 
 of  attention  to  where  you're  going  to 
 plant  it  in  the  garden.  And  then  make 
 sure  the  pot  is  big  enough  where  it  can 
 hold  some  moisture.  When  I'm  trying  to 
 put  in  a  big  plant  or  a  big  focal  point, 
 you're  definitely  going  to  want  a  pot 
 that's  at  least  20  24  in  tall  and  as 
 much  of  a  wide  mouth  as  you  can  possibly 
 get  because  that's  what's  going  to  give 
 the  plant  the  root  ball  the  size  to 
 really  expand.  It  doesn't  matter  if  you 
 don't  absolutely  love  the  coloring  cuz 
 you  can  always  do  something  kind  of  like 
 this  where  you  can  drape  something  over 
 top  of  it.  You  can  even  pop  some  cool 
 plants  to  the  front  of  it.  You  don't 
 necessarily  need  to  see  the  pot,  but 
 it's  definitely  a  great  feature.  I  love 
 the  terracotta  or  the  clay  pots.  They 
 don't  allow  the  root  ball  to  get  so 
 soggy.  They  really  do  a  great  job  of 
 drying  out  fast,  and  I  just  think  that 
 they're  a  great  potted  material  to  work 
 with  in  the  garden.  So,  if  you  have  an 
 area  there  that  where  you  have 
 irrigation,  you  can  add  a  little  pot 
 mister  to  that  with  no  problem.  Then,  it 
 is  going  to  grow  and  grow  and  jack  and 
 the  beantock  kind  of  grow.  So  allow  for 
 that  and  it'll  be  the  perfect  feature 
 for  that  perfect  spot  in  your  garden.  So 
 there  you  have  it  gardeners,  five  potted 
 plants  that  can  liven  up  your  space  and 
 the  reasons  why  some  really  good  reasons 
 why  to  maybe  incorporate  them  in  your 
 very  own.  So  if  you  guys  enjoyed  today's 
 video,  then  hopefully  you'll  enjoy  a 
 recent  video  that  we  did  of  a  cutting 
 garden  on  some  of  those  exact  plants 
 that  we  were  just  talking  about  how  we 
 incorporated  them  and  brought  them 
 indoors,  bringing  the  jungle  inside.  So 
 you  guys  check  that  video  out.  Thank  you 
 so  much.  Take  care  and  I  will  see  you 
 guys  next  weekend.

---

 All  right,  welcome  back  gardeners.  So 
 today's  video  is  all  about  how  to  start 
 the  process,  how  to  get  this  whole 
 project  going.  We  are  going  to  discuss 
 several  steps  on  how  to  kind  of  start 
 from  a  blank  slate  to  visualizing  the 
 very  next  step  to  the  installation  to 
 soil  amendments,  talking  about  root 
 barriers.  Um,  just  kind  of  giving  you  a 
 very  good  feel  for  how  to  start  this 
 project  to  the  final  ending.  That  way 
 you  have  a  great  game  plan  before  the 
 first  shovel  hits  the  ground. 
 [Music] 
 Oh,  I  think  it's  cooler  up  here. 
 All right,  you  guys.  So,  if  you  are 
 working  on  a  budget  and  you're  kind  of 
 figuring  out,  you  know,  what  to  start 
 with.  So,  you  always  want  to  start  with 
 manipulating  your  gallon  size.  If  you 
 can  start  with  your  big  material  first, 
 then  come  in  with  your  layered  material, 
 especially  if  you're  going  to  do  what 
 Eugene  and  Nikki  are  doing  here,  which 
 is  they're  going  to  do  things  in  phases. 
 So,  we're  getting  all  the  tree  material 
 in  for  them.  Next,  they're  going to  come 
 in  and  do  the  accent  material  and  the 
 bush  planting.  So,  if  I  were  setting  it 
 up  or  giving  you  some  advice  like  I  am 
 today  to  how  to  start  that  process,  it 
 would  be  to  be  sure  to  take  your  rear 
 plantings,  the  backdrop  of  everything. 
 Make  sure  that  is  your  tallest  material. 
 Those  are  kind  of  your  roof  lines  of  the 
 planting.  In  this  particular  project, 
 it's  the  coconut  palms  and  the 
 traveler's  palms.  If  you're  doing  it 
 yourself  and  you  can  handle  a  30-gallon 
 size,  those  would  be  your  30-gallon 
 plants.  Everything  in  your  backdrop 
 would  be  your  big  stuff.  And  then  you 
 can  come  in  with  your  next  tier.  What's 
 going  to  be  in  front  of  that?  Come  in 
 with  now  15  gallon  and  then  below  seven 
 gallon,  three  gallon,  one  gallon.  And 
 that's  a  great  way  to  make  sure  that  you 
 know  you're  working  in  layers.  And  it's 
 also  for  Nikki  and  Eugene,  it's  going  to 
 give  them  foliage  from  the  ground  up.  So 
 as  they're  waiting  for  budgets  to  allow 
 for  the  next  phase,  they're  going  to 
 have  some  fullness  down  below.  So,  as 
 everything  layers  into  place,  they're 
 going  to  still  feel  like  they  have  a 
 great  waterfall  effect  leading  down  to 
 the  pool  area.  I  get  this  question  so 
 often.  How  close  can  I  plant  these  trees 
 together?  Well,  that  all  depends  on  the 
 size  that  you  start  with.  If  you  can 
 start  with  a  nice  tall  tree  that  has  a 
 great  roof  line  and  a  bit  of  a  trunk. 
 Now,  you  can  put  that  other  tree  right 
 to  the  front  of  it.  Keep  in  mind,  you've 
 already  amended  the  soil.  You're  going 
 to  make  sure  everything  gets  good 
 fertilization.  These  things  are  not 
 going  to  compete  with  each  other. 
 They're  going  to  be  in  the  same  soil 
 line  as  each  other.  Hopefully  that 
 doesn't  concern  you  too  much  about  that. 
 So  go  ahead  and  put  your  coconut  palm 
 there.  Then  come  in  with  your  your 
 triangle  palm.  That's  25  gallon.  That's 
 going  to  be  about  half  the  size.  Then 
 come  in  with  your  pigment  a  palm.  That's 
 going  to  be  about  half  the  size  of  that. 
 And  then  tear  down.  That  way  when  you're 
 looking  at  it,  you  have  this  great 
 waterfall  effect  all  the  way  to  the 
 space.  That's  what's  going  to  give  you 
 the  walls  around  the  patio  or  the  pool 
 area.  It's  going  to  give  you  that 
 structure.  It's  going  to  envelop  you. 
 So,  it's  really  important  to  kind  of 
 start  that  way,  especially  if  you're 
 starting  on  a  budget,  because  that's 
 going  to  do  a  great  job  of  giving  you 
 that  instantaneous  fullness.  And  then, 
 of  course,  as  things  grow  up,  then  now 
 you  can  start  popping  new  material  in 
 down  below.  And  that's  what's  great 
 about  landscaping  and  why  why  you're 
 never  done.  So,  once  you've  kind  of 
 mapped  out  the  plant  sizes  and  what 
 you're  going  to  do  there,  the  next  thing 
 to  do  is  to  start  visualizing  the  space. 
 So,  what  I  like  to  do  for  my  clients  is 
 we  create  a  full  rendering  for  them.  So, 
 it  shows  a  before  picture  and  then  kind 
 of  what  we're  thinking  about  for  the 
 space.  Now,  I  know  most  of  you  guys 
 don't  have  the  option  of  doing  a 
 rendering.  But  what  I  also  do,  even 
 though  I  have  a  rendering  in  place,  and 
 even  after  all  of  these  years  in 
 business,  I  make  sure  to  lay  everything 
 out  with  my  stakes.  If  you  guys  saw  a 
 life  in  the  day  of  last  week's  video, 
 you  know  that  I  come  out  and  mark 
 everything  with  stakes.  And  that  pretty 
 much  represents  the  trees  that  I'm  going 
 to  use  in  the  space.  That's  where  I  play 
 and  adjust.  I  make  sure  that  those 
 stakes  represent  exactly  the  locations 
 of  where  I  want  those  trees  to  go  within 
 inches.  And  I  kind  of  base  it  on  the 
 seating  sections,  the  the  front  door 
 outdoor  outside  the  kitchen  window,  the 
 main  areas  that  you're  going  to  seat  and 
 relax  to  make  sure  that  I'm  using  the 
 budget  wisely.  You  guys  want  to  make 
 sure  that  if  you're  investing  in  these 
 trees  and  these  plants  that  gosh,  you're 
 getting  the  best  view  from  the  areas 
 that  are  used  the  most.  And  that's  why 
 symmetry  is  so  important  or  in  some 
 cases  lack  thereof  of  symmetry.  Like  for 
 instance,  in  this  backyard  pool  area,  we 
 have  a  very  defined  pool  space,  a  very 
 rectangular  pool  space,  and  then  we  have 
 a  pretty  narrow  planting  bed  all  the  way 
 around  it.  So,  we  really  needed  to  be 
 careful  of  how  we  were  going  to  use  that 
 space.  You  want  symmetry  because  you 
 want  to  make  sure  that  the  features,  the 
 wall,  the  structures  alone,  all  the  big 
 material  kind  of  has  really  good  balance 
 and  flow  all  the  way  through.  And  I  know 
 those  of  you  guys  who  are  thinking, 
 gosh,  I  want  that  jungle.  I  want  it 
 layer  on  layer  and  I  want,  you  know,  I 
 want  it  to  feel  more  flowy.  I  want  it  to 
 feel  more  organic.  I  promise  you,  you 
 can  do  that  after  this  step.  This  step 
 to  me  is  one  of  the  most  important  steps 
 because  once  you  get  these  key  things  in 
 place,  then  you  can  have  different 
 layouts,  you  can  have  different  accents, 
 different  features  that  are  going  to 
 kind  of  give  you  more  of  that  jungle 
 vibe,  but  keeping  the  walls  and 
 everything  together.  So,  in  this 
 particular  area,  we  have  a  very  clean 
 line  pool  design,  which  I  am  in  love 
 with.  I  absolutely  love  Eugene  and 
 Nikki's  pool.  This  is  just  such  a  great 
 use  of  space  back  here.  However,  if  I'm 
 creating  symmetry  where  I  have  a  tree  in 
 this  corner  and  a  tree  in  this  corner, 
 trees  this  way,  and  everything  lines  up 
 this  way.  And  know  the  challenge  can 
 come  in  where  the  pool  is  not  exactly 
 symmetrical,  where  we  have  a  lift  on  one 
 side  of  it  and  it  kind  of  tears  down  on 
 another  side  of  it.  Usually  hot  tubs 
 have  a  rise  in  elevation,  which  is 
 fabulous,  but  when  that  happens,  you 
 want  to  make  sure  that  that  area  has  a 
 little  bit  more  lushness.  That  area  has 
 a  little  bit  more  nestling.  You  kind  of 
 want  to  take  that  and  lift  the  space  and 
 kind  of  work  with  it.  Go  with  it.  Yes, 
 you  want  symmetry  there,  but  you  also 
 want  to  work  with  what  the  elevations 
 give  you.  So,  when  an  elevation  pops  up, 
 so  does  your  landscaping.  You  want  to 
 engulf  that.  You  want  to  kind  of  nestle 
 that,  create  kind  of  more  of  an  intimate 
 spot.  And  I  tend  to  always  do  that  when 
 it  comes  to  hot  tubs  or  or  jacuzzi  areas 
 because  or  waterfall  sections,  anything 
 with  a  rise  like  that.  I  kind  of  want  to 
 envelop  it  because  that's  what  gives  you 
 that  resort-like  feel.  And  that's  what  I 
 love  that  the  resorts  do  so  so  well. 
 They  really  make  sure  to  capitalize  on 
 all  the  money  that  was  spent  on  whatever 
 feature  they  have.  If  they  put  in  a 
 waterfall,  you  can  guarantee  that  bad 
 boy  is  enveloped  by  beautiful  palm 
 frrons  that  are  overhanging  it  to  give 
 it  that  natural  look.  If  they've  got  a 
 very  contemporary  pool  feel  like  this, 
 you  can  guarantee  that  they  put  the  more 
 expensive  item.  Maybe  it's  that  cool  red 
 cone  ginger.  They  nestled  it  into  the 
 corner  and  pul  put  some  palm  trees 
 around  it.  You  know,  those  are  the  areas 
 that  you  pay  a  little  closer  attention 
 to  because  that's  where  you're  going  to 
 get  the  biggest  bang  for  the  buck.  So, 
 you  want  to  make  sure  to  be  intentional 
 about  the  space.  You  can  take  a  piece  of 
 paper  and  you  can  take  a  CAD  plan  and 
 you  can  put  a  tree  here,  here,  here, 
 here,  and  make  it  all  make  sense  on  the 
 picture.  But  when  you're  working  with  a 
 space,  when  you're  working  with  roof 
 lines  for  a  front  yard,  when  you're 
 working  with  waterfalls  or  you're 
 working  with  hot  tubs  for  backyard  pool 
 areas,  you  want  to  be  intentional.  Work 
 with  what  that  space  is  giving  you.  And 
 then  take  it  a  whole  another  level.  Just 
 really  bring  in  the  big  mama  jamas  for 
 those  particular  areas  cuz  again,  that's 
 where  you're  going to  get  the  biggest 
 bang.  That  is  where  it's  really 
 important  and  that's  what  people 
 remember.  That's  what  kind  of  gives  you 
 that  atmosphere  takes  you  from  a  nice 
 landscaping  to  a  resort  landscaping.  But 
 now  on  to  the  next  tip.  But  before  we  go 
 any  further,  before  you  plant  anything 
 here,  it's  an  ideal  time  to  go  ahead  and 
 put  your  root  barrier  in.  If  you're 
 starting  with  a  blank  canvas,  it's  easy 
 to  access  the  ground.  Go  ahead  and  put 
 your  root  barrier  in.  There's  so  many 
 different  varieties  available  on  the 
 market.  I'll  be  sure  to  list  some  of  my 
 favorites  on  the  screen.  You  want  to 
 make  sure  that  you  have  some  access  to 
 it  because  so  many  times  those  root 
 barriers  are  20,  24  in  deep.  So  having 
 protection  along  a  foundation  of  a  pool 
 area  is  a  great  thing  to  do.  Some  of 
 these  palm  trees,  especially  if  you're 
 really  going  to  give  you  that  jungle 
 vibe,  are  going  to  have  big  canopies, 
 which  means  big  roots.  So,  to  prevent, 
 you  know,  anything  cracking  pipes  and 
 whatnot,  you  kind  of  want  to  do  a  root 
 barrier  along  the  foundation  of  those 
 trees  or  right  along  the  foundation  of 
 the  pool  wall  itself.  But  now,  let's 
 talk  about  what's  going  into  the  ground. 
 Now,  you're  getting  ready  to  put  your 
 trees  in.  You're  digging  your  holes.  How 
 to  prep  that  for  best  success.  So,  you 
 guys  know  that  I  I  am  a  big  fan  of 
 making  sure  that  the  ground  has  really 
 good  soil  to  work  with.  In  Florida,  we 
 have  a  mixture  of  whether  it's  silver 
 sandy  soil  or  it's  clay  and  marl  that 
 we're  dealing  with.  You  kind  of  have  to 
 modify  it  no matter  what  soil  conditions 
 that  you  have  when  you're  in  Florida. 
 Just  to  kind  of  give  you  a  visual  on 
 this,  my  key  mix  is  50%  black  cow.  So, 
 that's  about  a  middle  of  your  bucket 
 line  here.  Then,  I  use  25%  Pete  Moss  and 
 then  25%  pine  bark  nuggets.  Mix  it  all 
 together.  The  hole  is  dug  and  ready. 
 It's  a  little  bit  deeper  than  what  I 
 need  in  reality.  So,  I'll  dig  the  hole  a 
 little  deeper  and  quite  a  bit  wider.  And 
 all  I  do  is  make  sure  that  that  tree 
 brute  ball  fits  sticks  up  about  3  in  out 
 of  the  ground.  I  take  that  soil  mixture 
 and  I  mix  it  all  the  way  around  back 
 filling  with  as  much  of  that  soil  that  I 
 need  depending  on  the  size  of  the  plant 
 or  the  tree  or  the  root  ball  if  it's  a 
 big  giant  tree.  That  is  a  huge  huge  huge 
 thing  to  do.  I  also  will  mix  in  palm 
 tone.  This  is  one  of  my  favorite  things 
 to  work  with,  something  that  does  not 
 burn  your  roots.  You  can  kind  of  take 
 that  and  just  dabble  that  all  down  below 
 in  the  hole  and  then  back  fill.  You're 
 going  to  use  that  soil  and  the  soil 
 that's  remaining  to  fill  around  those 
 edges.  That's  the  reason  why  you  want 
 your  tree  to  stick  up  about  3  in  above 
 ground  because  that  soil  that  we  use, 
 that  mixture  that  we  use  will  kind  of 
 compact  over  time  and  you  definitely 
 don't  want  a  tree  to  have  any  kind  of 
 divots.  So,  give  yourself  some  breathing 
 room.  Plant  your  trees  a  little  bit 
 high.  It's  a  little  bit  less  digging 
 that  you  have  to  do.  So,  why  not  plant 
 them  a  little  bit  higher?  But,  as  I 
 always  say,  you've  heard  this  phrase  if 
 you're  a  gardener  so  many  times,  put  a 
 $5  tree  into  a  $20  hole  and  you  will 
 have  success.  I  know  it  sounds  like  an 
 expensive  landscaping,  but  that  is  the 
 way  to  do  it.  That's  the  ratio.  Put  a 
 smaller  tree  in,  but  definitely  work 
 with  good  soil  mixture.  And  then  you're 
 probably  wondering,  you  know,  now  that 
 you  kind  of  have  these  steps  and  you 
 kind  of  have  some  ideas  of  when  is  the 
 best  time  to  start  here  in  Florida.  I 
 would  say  there's  not  really  the  perfect 
 time  to  start.  You  know,  if  you  could 
 plant  within  the  rainy  season,  then 
 that's  really  going  to  be  great  for  your 
 plants.  It's  really  going  to  get 
 everything  off  to  a  fabulous  start. 
 However,  if  you're  planting  in  the 
 winter,  then  that's  not  a  bad  time 
 either  because  that's  that  gives  your 
 plants  and  trees  a  little  bit  of  a  rest, 
 a  little  bit  of  rest  bit  where  you're 
 not  constantly  having  to  water  things  in 
 to  kind  of  get  established.  And  then  if 
 you're  planting  in  the  summer,  then  you 
 know,  our  thunderstorms,  our  afternoon 
 thunderstorms  are  going  to  be  an  ideal 
 time  frame.  So  what  I  would  say  is  try 
 to  avoid  if  you  can  where  the  heat  index 
 shoots  straight  up.  Even  the  end  of 
 July,  August,  September,  that  can  be  a 
 little  bit  of  a  tough  time  period.  If 
 you  are  weekend  warriors  out  there  and 
 you  don't  mind  hand  watering  and  doing  a 
 little  bit  extra  care,  then  it's  never  a 
 bad  time  to  plant  in  Florida  because  we 
 are  in  such  a  great  growing  season. 
 That's  a  perfect  time  to  get  things 
 going  and  really  taking  off.  So  I  hope 
 in  today's  video  it  helps  give  you  guys 
 that  one  step  closer,  one  foot  forward 
 of  like,  hey,  I  can  do  this.  I  can  take 
 it  now  from  the  blank  slate  that  I'm 
 seeing  from  and  start  playing  with  those 
 poles.  Kind  of  get  them  envisioning  what 
 you're  looking  at.  Put  those  guys  out 
 there.  Go  inside  your  house.  Look  at  it 
 different  times  of  the  day.  Just  make 
 sure  that  you're  really  happy  with  the 
 layout  that  you're  coming  from.  And  then 
 find  the  symmetry  off  that.  So  once  you 
 say,  "Okay,  this  is  my  focal  point.  This 
 is  my  focal  point.  Now  bring  those  two 
 things  together."  That's  what's  really 
 going  to  be  your  everlasting  part  of 
 your  design.  That's  what's  really  going 
 to  bring  it  all  together.  Trust  me,  you 
 can  get  jazzy.  You  can  get  creative.  You 
 can  bring  in  drifts  of  this  and  drifts 
 of  that  to  kind  of  give  you  more  of  that 
 wild  feel,  but  definitely  get  that 
 structure  in  place.  So,  I  hope  I  stress 
 that  enough.  That's  kind  of  why  I  wanted 
 to  mention  it  again  because  to  me,  that 
 is  such  an  important  part  of  getting  the 
 proper  design  for  the  right  space.  It's 
 that's  what  I  love  about  our  design 
 process  because  we  want  to  make  sure  to 
 customize  it  to  your  location.  It's  got 
 to  hit  the  corners  perfectly.  It's  got 
 to  be  the  focal  point  on  the  jacuzzi 
 area,  maybe  the  entrance  to  the  back 
 patio  area.  I  want  to  bring  focus  to  it, 
 bring  attention  to  it.  Those  are 
 important  things  to  kind  of  make  sure  to 
 incorporate  when  you're  thinking  about 
 your  outdoor  space.  And  that'll  make  it 
 an  area  that  you  just  want  to  live  in. 
 And  that's  the  goal,  right?  Make  it  your 
 resort.  Make  your  outdoor  space  your  own 
 private  oasis.  That  way,  you're 
 vacationing  out  here.  You're 
 entertaining  out  here.  You're  proud  to 
 be  out  here  with  friends  and  family  and 
 enjoy  that  area.  That's  the  gold  I  think 
 that  we're  all  trying  to  create  is  our 
 own  bit  of  ambiance  because,  you  know, 
 we're  all  busy.  We  all  work  like  crazy. 
 And  I  think  having  that  space  that's 
 your  own,  it's  the  jewel.  It's  the  icing 
 on  the  cake.  So,  I  hope  this  video 
 helps.  Anything  that  you  guys  have 
 question  wise  about  this  type  of  design 
 process,  please  leave  it  in  the  comments 
 down  below.  Those  of  you  guys  who  need 
 more  than  this  kind  of  inspiration,  then 
 hit  us  up  because  we  do  landscape  design 
 installation,  landscape  design  only,  and 
 virtual  consults  and  we'd  be  happy  to 
 meet  with  you.  So,  I'll  put  all  that 
 information  down  below  and  flash  it  up 
 here  on  the  screen  for  a  screenshot.  All 
 right,  you  guys.  If  you  enjoyed  today's 
 video,  then  you  will  enjoy  last  week's 
 video,  which  is  ultimate  privacy  in  a 
 backyard.  Typical  suburban  backyard 
 turned  out  gorgeous.  Thank  you  guys  so 
 much.  See  you  next  weekend.  Take  care.

---

 Well,  hello  gardeners.  Welcome  back. 
 Today  is  all  about  maintenance  or  lack 
 thereof  maintenance.  So,  we're  in  my 
 backyard  space.  And  the  reason  why  I'm 
 doing  today's  video  is  because  I  had 
 somebody  come  over  yesterday  picking 
 something  up  from  marketplace,  of 
 course,  and  they  said,  "Oh  my  god,  who 
 would  have  thought  this  backyard  was 
 back  here  in  this  typical  subdivision, 
 right?  You  must  spend  every  single 
 weekend  in  your  backyard  nipping  and 
 clipping  and  trimming  and  doing  all  the 
 things  that  need  to  be  done  to  maintain 
 a  yard  like  this."  And  I  thought,  let  me 
 share  with  you  guys  what's  involved  with 
 the  maintenance  on  this  kind  of 
 planting,  this  kind  of  garden,  this  kind 
 of  tropical  forest.  Some  of  these  tips 
 and  tricks  can  help  you  kind  of  create 
 more  of  a  cove  field,  create  more  of 
 like  a  jungle  field  that  is  going  to 
 give  you  a  lot  lot  less  work.  And  I'm 
 just  going  to  tell  you  my  techniques  and 
 why  that  is.  Grab  your  cup  of  coffee  or 
 your  glass  of  wine,  depending  on  the 
 time  of  the  day  it  is  for  you,  and  we 
 are  going  to  jump  right  into  this  video. 
 Let's  get  started  with  the  roof  line, 
 the  upper  area.  Now,  by  creating  shade 
 in  your  garden,  whatever  you  choose  to 
 use,  whether  it's  a  canopy  tree,  a 
 hardwood  tree,  or  what  I've  done  here 
 with  palm  trees,  that  is  going  to  be  the 
 very  first  thing  to  do  to  change  the 
 microclimates.  And  why  that's  so 
 important  is  because  the  less  sunlight 
 on  the  inside  of  your  garden,  the  more 
 you're  able  to  create  that  thick,  dense 
 plant  grouping,  that  thick,  dense  jungle 
 floor  down  below  that's  going  to  give 
 you  that  jungle  inspired  vibe.  I  love 
 palm  trees.  I  love  fast  growing  palm 
 trees  like  coconut  palms,  like  a  palms, 
 triangle  palms.  Those  are  a  few  of  the 
 palms  that  I  have  that  are  my  upper 
 canopy  palm  trees.  Those  are  the  things 
 that  are  going  to  allow  me  to  bring  in 
 my  shorter  palms,  my  more  exotic  palms. 
 when  you're  thinking  about  hedge 
 trimming  and  gardening  and  shaping  and 
 clipping  and  and  everything  that  needs 
 to  be  done  with  that,  that  is  a  lot  less 
 time  involved  in  doing  those  kind  of 
 things  versus  the  continuation  of 
 monthly  garden  service.  And  what  those 
 canopy  trees  offer  you  is  the  allowance 
 to  put  in  a  lush,  thick  network  of  plant 
 groupings  or  plant  combinations  that  are 
 going  to  give  you  an  abundance  of  color, 
 an  abundance  of  that  tropical  feel  with 
 very,  very  little  work.  Like  for 
 instance,  look  what  we  have  here.  I  love 
 this  is  the  end  of  my  garden  right  here. 
 A  nice  bright  spot  of  color  with  the 
 Sesia.  Now  Sesia  are  notorious  for 
 fillers.  They're  big  growers.  So  why  is 
 that  so  low  maintenance  in  my  garden?  Is 
 because  it  is  the  perfect  braided 
 combination  of  plants.  This  area  I  put 
 in  a  little  swath  of  this  and  it  fills 
 all  the  gaps.  So  it  really  gives  you 
 almost  like  a  forest  floor  of  thickness 
 and  denseness.  And  what  that  does  is  it 
 eliminates  the  chance  of  weeds  coming 
 in.  Anything  else  kind  of  coming  through 
 them.  It  becomes  a  sea  of  just  one  thing 
 in  this  grouping.  And  all  I  have  to  do 
 is  just  make  sure  that  one  limb  here  and 
 there  is  just  not  going  to  grow  into 
 another  one.  Like  you  know,  I  like  that 
 this  is  an  ending  point  right  here 
 before  you  get  into  my  farfugeiums.  So 
 if  I  had  a  limb  that  came  over  here,  I 
 would  just  simply  clip  that  limb.  And 
 you  can  kind  of  do  do  what  you  like  with 
 these  guys.  You  can  really  give  them  any 
 kind  of  haircut.  They're  such  a  simple 
 little  plant  to  work  with,  but  because 
 they're  in  a  such  a  nice  collection,  a 
 nice  tight  grouping,  it  really  gives  you 
 that  tropical  vibe  and  covers  all  of 
 that  groundwork.  So  any  leaves  or  limbs 
 or  anything  that  falls  just  below  this 
 big  giant  leaf  on  this,  you  don't  see. 
 You  don't  you  don't  have  to  constantly 
 rake.  You  don't  have  to  constantly  just 
 kind  of  make  sure  everything  is 
 manicured  and  pruned.  It  really  gives 
 you  a  just  nice  cover  of  tropical 
 foliage.  And  I  have  a  lot  of  areas  in  my 
 garden  that  are  just  like  that  because 
 when  you  have  a  lot  of  tree  material, 
 you  have  a  lot  of  fronds,  a  lot  of 
 leaves,  you're  going  to  get  dropage. 
 Now,  along  my  walkway  and  through  the 
 front  yard,  those  leaves  and  debris  that 
 fall  from  birds  and  whatnot  and 
 clippings,  those  are  all  visible  and  all 
 scene.  So,  I'm  either  blowing  them  out, 
 pulling  them  up,  or  picking  out  the  the 
 weeds  from  in  between  because  there's 
 nothing  there  to  catch  that.  There's 
 nothing  there  to  disguise  that.  So 
 having  something  like  these  guys  or 
 aglionas  or  like  the  burl  marks  that  I 
 have  down  below,  having  a  collection  of 
 plant  groupings  doesn't  allow  for 
 anything  else  to  get  in  there.  It  really 
 gives  you  that  dense  kind  of  bit  of  a 
 blanket.  And  that's  kind  of  what  my 
 whole  garden  goes  from.  It  goes  from 
 these  guys  here.  The  only  maintenance 
 that  I  have  is  separating  the  species. 
 So  I  just  have  a  little  break  between 
 each  plant  species.  I'll  just  take  one 
 little  clipping  off  and  then  make  sure 
 that  they're  not  touching.  And  that's 
 all  you  have  to  do  is  just  make  sure 
 that  one  is  not  intruding  on  the  other. 
 I  mean,  too  much  because  I  do  like  a 
 little  bit  of  of  cuddling.  You  want  that 
 kind  of  mesh.  You  want  that  garden  floor 
 because  in  nature,  that's  exactly  how 
 things  grow.  You'll  see  in  those 
 beautiful  forests  how  the  ferns  cover 
 all  of  that  ground.  Now,  that  prevents 
 new  growth  from  popping  up  and  it 
 prevents  weeds  and  whatnot  from  taking 
 over  and  filling  up  that  area  because 
 you  don't  have  any  sun  exposure  that 
 blocks  out  anything  like  that.  And  then 
 these  are  heavily  rooted  plants.  Things 
 like  croins,  things  like  burlarks, 
 cesia,  agonymas,  their  root  system  is  so 
 good  that  they  really  knit  together 
 underneath  and  knit  together  above  which 
 does  a  great  job  of  preventing  anything 
 from  down  below  to  sprout  up.  That 
 allows  for  that  tropical  feel  to  that 
 garden.  But  you  can't  have  that  unless 
 you  have  the  cover  that  protects  those 
 particular  plants.  And  that's  why  more 
 of  a  filtered  light  or  a  shade  garden  is 
 going  to  be  a  lot  less  maintenance. 
 Right  over  here  on  this  side,  I  have  my 
 centerpiece  tree,  which  is  my  triple 
 bottle  palm.  You  guys  know  how  I  feel 
 about  my  bottle  palms.  They're  just  so 
 fun.  Down  below,  I  have  the  dwarf 
 Taiwanese  exora.  These  guys  bloom  10 
 months  out  of  the  year,  give  you  great 
 color,  but  are  such  a  slow  growing 
 little  leafed  plant  that  require  very 
 little  care  because  of  how  slow  they 
 grow.  I  mean,  I  literally  trim  them 
 about  three  times  a  year.  And  then  I 
 balance  them  out  with  these  icon  croins. 
 And  croins  in  general  are  going  to  be  on 
 your  slower  growing  maintenance  plan. 
 So,  if  you  guys  like  the  look  of  croins, 
 then  you  are  in  for  a  lowmaintenance 
 landscaping  because  this  painted  leaf 
 offers  very,  very  little  care.  Song  of 
 India  droenas  down  below.  Again,  a 
 perfect  lanus  plant.  You  only  trim  what 
 you  don't  want.  A  couple  times  a  year,  I 
 will  just  nip  off.  One  that  gets  a 
 little  bit  too  tall.  So  that  way,  these 
 connect  fully  and  become  a  nice  little 
 3-FFT  ground  cover.  I  do  this  because 
 these  guys  as  they  get  a  little  bit 
 taller  are  going  to  have  a  little  bit  of 
 a  legggininess  to  the  bottom,  and  this 
 is  going  to  cover  that.  This  is  going  to 
 be  my  skirt  grouping.  And  then  of 
 course,  look  at  this  leaf  color 
 together.  It's  just  so  stunning.  The 
 light  and  the  dark  combinations  are  just 
 gorgeous  together.  So,  let's  move  on 
 over  here  to  a  tad  bit  higher 
 maintenance.  And  why?  So,  anything 
 blooming  is  going  to  be  on  your  higher 
 maintenance  side.  I  had  softened  this 
 little  area.  So,  I  have  a  tree  jasmine. 
 This  gets  great  great  sun,  gets  the  heat 
 off  the  deck,  so  it  gets  tons  and  tons 
 and  tons  of  blaring  sun  and  it's  happy. 
 It  is  blooming  like  crazy,  but  it 
 constantly  drops  old  blooms  everywhere. 
 So  that  is  one  of the  higher  maintenance 
 plants  that  I  have  in  my  gardens  because 
 I  have  no  protection.  If  I  put  something 
 over  top  of  this,  I'd  have  this 
 beautiful  green  foliage  but  very,  very 
 little  blooming  on  that  and  that  would 
 minimize  the  maintenance.  The  next  thing 
 that  I  have  that  gets  such  great  sun  is 
 that  Madagascar  palm  right  there. 
 And  you  can  see  when  it's  in  full  bloom, 
 oh  my  gosh,  is  just  a  stunner.  I  mean, 
 it  is  so  such  a  focal  point  that  I've 
 kind  of  made  it  the  centerpiece  of  my 
 rock  garden  right  here.  But  because  of 
 those  blooms,  it's  constantly  holding 
 brown  blooms  above  and  then  it  causes 
 this  area  to  be  a  little  bit  higher 
 maintenance  because  of  all  of  that 
 droppage,  the  droppage  on  the  deck  and 
 whatnot.  Keep  that  in  mind  on  what  trees 
 that  you're  going  to  plant.  If  you're 
 going  to  have  a  heavy  blooming  garden, 
 whether  it's  a  butterfly  garden  or  it's 
 a  cod  style  garden  and  you  still  want  to 
 do  that  mass  plant  grouping,  you  can 
 absolutely  get  a  big  benefit  and  big 
 beautiful  impact  from  that  kind  of 
 gardening,  but  it's  going  to  be  on  the 
 higher  end  of  maintenance.  So,  if  you 
 can  do  more  painted  leaves,  more 
 variegated  leaves,  which  are  usually 
 things  that  that  do  require  a  little  bit 
 of  protection,  do  require  some  shade. 
 Hence  why  this  section  of  my  garden, 
 even  though  it  has  way  more  plants  than 
 probably  the  rest  of  the  yard,  it  is  a 
 lot  less  care  because  of  that  reason, 
 because  of  all  of  this  ground  foliage 
 that  we  have.  I  mean,  just  look  at  how 
 many  different  species  we  have  right  in 
 this  area.  This  penanga,  which  is  a  slow 
 grower  palm,  this  penanga  coronada, 
 absolutely  stunner  multi-  trunk  little 
 palm  tree.  I  wouldn't  been  able  to 
 incorporate  this  palm  tree  had  I  not  had 
 the  triangle  and  the  coconut  palms  and 
 the  ora  palms  around  it  because  it  would 
 have  been  far  too  much  sun  and  I'd  be 
 constantly  helping  this  tree  survive  by 
 adding  tons  of  water  to  it,  tons  of 
 micronutrients  to  it  to  kind  of  get  it 
 to  be  happy  and  healthy.  Now  with  the 
 protection  and  it  being  the  undergrowth 
 to  those  trees,  it  is  thriving.  It  is 
 beautiful.  It's  doing  super  super  well 
 in  its  first  year  in  the  garden.  It's 
 probably  grown  probably  more  than  more 
 than  they  said  that  it  should  grow.  So, 
 but  it  is  absolutely  stunner.  And  then 
 just  down  below,  look  at  the  dense 
 foliage  of  all  of  this  agonas.  I  mean,  I 
 just  trim  them  so  very  little  and  they 
 do  exactly  what  I  want  them  to  do.  I 
 would  put  them  everywhere  if  I  could. 
 They  are  a  bit  pricey,  but  they  are  the 
 perfect  jungle  floor  to  a  shady 
 environment  because  they  really  do  a 
 great  job  of  multiplying  and  densing, 
 becoming  a  dense  plant  without  being  too 
 crazy  where  you're  constantly  having  to 
 keep  them  up.  They  grow  slow  enough  to 
 make  that  happen.  And  then  we  have  some 
 ground  orchids  right  in  through  here. 
 Look  how  you  just  don't  see  the  floor  of 
 the  garden  and  that  is  kind  of  the 
 reason  for  it.  I've  been  able  to  put  in 
 some  more  exotic  tropical  trees  in  here 
 because  of  the  shade  included  in  this 
 backyard  space.  So,  that  is  a  key  to 
 creating  this  type  of  look.  The  more  sun 
 you  get,  the  more  care  is  involved,  the 
 more  trimming,  the  more  shaping,  even 
 the  more  fertilizing.  Because  most  of 
 the  time  when  you  have  sun,  a  lot  of  the 
 plants  and  choices  and  tree  choices  that 
 you're  going  to  have  to  work  with  are 
 going  to  be  bloomers,  which  is  great  for 
 some  people.  But  just  know  that  that  is 
 going  to  be  that's  going  to  create  quite 
 a  bit  more  work  than  this  particular 
 space  right  here.  So  when  it  comes  to  a 
 creating  a  space  very  similar  to  this, 
 get  your  roof  line  in  first.  So  get  your 
 trees  that  are  going  to  create  that 
 canopy  coverage.  Then  start  with  your 
 walls.  So  it  could  be  something  like 
 fishtail  palms  as  your  walls.  It  could 
 be  something  like  a  palms,  kucia  hedge, 
 whatever  that  might  be.  So  you  have  your 
 wall  and  you  have  your  roof  line  in. 
 Now,  the  only  sun  that  that  area  is  now 
 getting  is  from  the  side,  which  is  the 
 perfect  condition  for  plant  groupings 
 like  this.  And  you're  not  constantly 
 fighting  with  having  to  add  tons  and 
 tons  of  water  to  it  and  tons  of 
 fertilizer  to  it  to  keep  that  tree 
 healthy  because  it's  in  an  environment 
 that  it's  always  battling.  It's  almost 
 like  it's  got  the  flu.  You  got  to  keep 
 the  immune  system  up  on  those  varieties 
 of  trees  if  they're  not  in  the  perfect 
 conditions.  If  you're  worried  about 
 weeds,  because  I  get  this  question  all 
 the  time,  how  do  you  battle  the  weeds?  I 
 do  not.  I  do  not  battle  any  weeds  in 
 this  part  of  my  garden.  I  have  tons  of 
 ground  cover  that  creates  a  such  a 
 knitting  effect  that  doesn't  allow  any 
 sunlight.  Pretty  much  gives  me  that 
 beautiful  layer  of  foliage  and  it  gives 
 you  that  kind  of  pop  of  color  without 
 without  having  to  worry  about  weeds.  So, 
 it's  just  such  an  ideal  thing  to  work 
 with.  So,  whatever  you  choose  for  your 
 upper  tree  canopy,  whatever  you  choose 
 for  your  roof  line  is  going  to  allow  you 
 to  choose  quite  a  bit  more.  It's  going 
 to  open  you  up  to  more  of  a  tropical 
 scape  for  down  below.  Now,  one  of  the 
 other  things  that  I  want  to  mention  as 
 far  as  maintenance  goes  in  a  backyard 
 space.  Now,  this  isn't  for  everybody, 
 but  I  love  the  use  of  stone.  Whether 
 it's  stone  just  bordering  the  edge  of  a 
 planting  bed,  I'll  do  that  commonly  in 
 gardens  where  we  have  foliage  like  this 
 where  it's  layered  and  it's  thick  and 
 it's  tropical,  but  then  we  want  to  kind 
 of  give  it  a  nice  clean  finish  line, 
 like  a  pristine  little  border.  Then  I'll 
 take  and  do  a  twoft  curved  border  of 
 stone  edged  with  like  either  a  natural 
 edging  like  you  see  here  or  we'll  use 
 something  like  the  buta  edging  like  you 
 see  here 
 or  I'll  use  the  aluminum  alloy  edging. 
 Whatever  it  calls  for  for  that 
 particular  spot.  That's  kind  of  what 
 I'll  use  because  I  kind  of  want  a  garden 
 where  it  is  like  I  always  say  the  crazy 
 is  in  the  back,  the  party  is  in  the  back 
 and  then  have  something  really 
 controlled  to  the  front.  What  I  love 
 about  that  kind  of  feel  is  it  gives  you 
 more  of  a  pristine  kind  of  more  of  that 
 resort-like  feel  when  you  have  a  nice 
 border  of  stone  or  can  incorporate  a 
 lush  border  because  you  go  from  all  this 
 heavy  crazy  wild  to  very  very  clean 
 lines  that  kind  of  keeps  all  of  that 
 paired  back.  So,  if  that's  a  look  that 
 you  like,  kind  of  keep  that  in  mind 
 because  when  you  have  a  stone  area  and 
 you  don't  have  a  bunch  of  plants  in  that 
 stone  bed,  it's  a  lot  easier  maintenance 
 than  you  think  because  we  have  a  good 
 amount  of  weed  barrier  pin  down  below 
 and  then  it's  edged  along  the  side.  So, 
 this  becomes  almost  like  a  ground  floor. 
 This  becomes  very  compact,  very,  very 
 dense  and  I  don't  have  to  worry  about  it 
 if  I  get  a  weed  here  and  there.  Very 
 easy  to  pull  because  it's  just  a  top 
 layered  weed.  It's  not  something  that's 
 coming  from  the  ground  up  and  then  I 
 don't  have  plants  in  there  that  are 
 causing  a  network  of  roots.  So,  and 
 that's  what  makes  it  low  maintenance.  If 
 there  are  plants  in  there,  it  would  make 
 it  a  higher  maintenance  planting  bed. 
 That's  a  great  way  to  take  a  jungle  vibe 
 and  then  polish  it  a  little  bit  with 
 stone.  I  love  using  Mexican  beach 
 pebbles  as  that  border.  You  can  use 
 other  decorative  kind  of  rock  as  that 
 border,  but  whatever  that  might  be  that 
 kind  of  gives  you  that,  you  know,  it 
 kind  of  gives  you  that  flare,  that 
 little  tropical  vibe  there.  And  another 
 way  to  make  your  garden  interesting  with 
 little  care  would  be  incorporate  pots  in 
 there.  Not  baby  pots,  not  little  pots, 
 but  definitely  some  bigger  pots.  So,  I 
 have  a  pot  in  my  garden.  I  have  several 
 pots  in  the  front  yard  garden.  It  is  a 
 way  to  keep  a  plant  that  you  might  like 
 that  maybe  is  is  a  difficult  plant. 
 Maybe  it's  a  plant  that  likes  to  run  or 
 likes  to  take  off  in  the  garden,  but  you 
 definitely  love  the  idea  of  having  that 
 front  or  that  look  in  the  garden  space 
 and  you  want  to  keep  it  controlled.  A 
 pot  is  a  great  way  to  do  that. 
 incorporate  it  right  into  the  garden. 
 Now,  this  is  a  tree  stump  that  I  had  to 
 take  out.  So,  there's  a  flat  stump 
 underneath  there.  So,  I  wanted  something 
 with  some  impact  coming  from  that  spot, 
 but  I  couldn't  plant  anything  there, 
 hence  the  pot.  So,  this  was  another 
 alternate  option  because  I  wanted  a  dune 
 palm  to  stand  and  crown  over  top  of 
 these  croins.  As  these  croins  really 
 grow  into  this  space,  the  natural  clay 
 pots  do  a  great  job  of  releasing  water. 
 They  don't  tend  to  clog  nearly  as  much 
 as  the  other  pots.  Do  it  correctly,  of 
 course.  We  always  use  cheesecloth  at  the 
 bottom,  some  stone  next  layer,  and  then 
 cheesecloth  again,  and  then  our  soil. 
 So,  it's  like  a  lasagna,  you  guys.  Just 
 kind  of  function  it  that  way.  And  I 
 think  that  always  had  great  success  with 
 our  pots  in  that  type  of  way.  But 
 incorporate  them  into  the  garden.  God 
 forbid  we  get  one  of  those  freezes  once 
 or  twice  a  year.  You  pull  that  bad  boy 
 out,  put  it  in  the  garage  for  the  night, 
 and  then  the  rest  of  the  year  she's 
 golden  in  the  ground.  So,  that  is  an 
 ideal  thing.  But  if  you  have  those  plant 
 stands  that  have  holes  in  them  and  you 
 have  landscape  lighting,  put  the  plant 
 stand  over  top  of  the  landscape 
 lighting,  it'll  shine  that  whole  pot.  It 
 is  just  such  a  stunner.  I've  done  that 
 in  different  projects  where  I've  had 
 that  opportunity  to  do  that.  All  my 
 clients  think  that's  brilliant  and  it 
 really  does  shine.  I'll  kind  of  get 
 Bryce  to  pop  up  an  example  of  what  that 
 looks  like  and  you  can  incorporate  that 
 all  the  way  through  your  garden.  It  just 
 kind  of  gives  you  a  little bit  of  gleam 
 and  also  gives  you  a  little  bit  of 
 different  interest  because  you  know  all 
 those  plant  stands  are  so  different  from 
 each  other.  So,  you  know,  just  as  kind 
 of  like  a  recap  on  what  we  talked  about 
 today,  you  guys.  Just  because  you  want  a 
 jungle  inspired  garden  does  not  mean  you 
 have  to  be  out  in  the  garden  every 
 single  weekend  or  even  every  single 
 month.  I  am  in  my  garden  about  three 
 times  a  year  on  average.  You  do  some 
 trimming,  you  do  some  light  foliage.  I 
 would  say  if  you  can  do  like  a  an  80% 
 count  when  it  comes  to  your  trees.  So, 
 your  your  tall  trees,  your  accent  trees, 
 your  wall,  whatever  that  is.  If  it's 
 more  palms,  that's  going  to  give  you 
 less  work  or  less  care  in  the  garden 
 because  those  things  need  to  be  trimmed 
 more  like  a  like  a  bianually  type  of 
 thing  versus  or  shrubs  or  plants  need  to 
 be  trimmed  more  often.  So,  that's  kind 
 of  how  my  garden  is  structured.  I  have 
 my  roof  line  of  my  canopy  trees.  I  have 
 my  wall  as  my  kucia  and  other  types  of 
 slow  growing  palm  trees.  And  then  I've 
 got  my  tropicals  underneath  those 
 because  they've  allowed  for  them  to  live 
 happily  underneath  that  environment, 
 underneath  the  roof  line  of  all  those 
 big  canopy  trees.  And  then  I  come  in 
 with  my  foliage.  Now,  it  looks  like  I 
 have  tons  of  foliage  in  my  garden,  but  I 
 really  don't.  I  really  just  have  a  nice 
 jam-packed  collection  of  groups.  And 
 that's  the  way  I  like  to  do  it.  You  guys 
 know  I  like  to  plant  in  drift.  So,  I'll 
 do  a  a  drift  of  Sanchezia  and  then  it 
 stops  and  breaks  and  then  a  drift  of 
 burl  marks  and  then  a  drift  of  croins. 
 had  that  go  through  the  garden  and  in 
 any  of  the  open  areas,  any  areas  that 
 you  see  in  your  garden,  as  long  as  you 
 have  some  protection,  some  good  cover, 
 fill  that  bad  boy  up  with  something  like 
 bird's  nest  fern  or  crowned  orchid  or 
 ageneemas,  anything  that's  kind  of  your 
 taste,  that's  your  style.  Make  that  your 
 ground  floor  because  that  ground  cover, 
 not  only  suppresses  weeds,  not  only  just 
 is  it  a  gorgeous  view  from  the  base  up, 
 it  gives  your  garden  that  finishing 
 touch  it  needs  where  you  don't  see  any 
 type  of  ground.  And  it  makes  the  garden 
 feel  more  expansful.  Makes  it  feel  more 
 full  because  you  have  a  carpet  as  a 
 base.  Then  you've  got  your  accents  in 
 the  middle.  Then  you've  got  cool 
 tropical  foliage  coming  out  everywhere 
 else.  And  then  you've  got  your  structure 
 trees  that  kind  of  keep  everything 
 nestled  in  together.  And  that's  the  way 
 to  create  that  jungle  vibe,  that  jungle 
 experience.  It  doesn't  need  to  be  as 
 vast  or  as  long  as  my  particular  space. 
 It  might  be  your  sideyard.  I'll  put  a 
 link  down  in  the  description  down  below 
 of  a  sideyard  jungle  inspired  walking 
 path  that  I  did.  And  it's  the  same  type 
 of  feel.  It's  it's  maybe  like  12  foot 
 wide  and  very  very  short  in  length,  but 
 it's  a  very  narrow  sideyard  that  really 
 created  that  same  kind  of  feel  where  we 
 had  shade.  We  had  pockets  of  coverage 
 where  we  could  incorporate  some  really 
 cool  foliage  because  of  what  that 
 offered.  So,  you  know,  kind  of  keep  that 
 in  mind.  And  when  it  comes  to 
 lowmaintenance,  there's  not  anything 
 lower  maintenance  than  incorporating 
 some  natural  material  in,  you  know, 
 adding  some  boulder  here  and  there,  a 
 little  bit  of  a  statue,  some  flag  stone, 
 anything  like  this.  Like  I  love  this 
 little  combination  of  ending  point  here 
 with  these  boulders  on  this  side  of  the 
 edge  ending  this  kind  of  backyard  space 
 coming  up  to  these  boulders  that  are 
 covering  up  a  stump  over  here.  I  just  I 
 like  the  way  that  that  little  inset, 
 that  little  insert  into  the  garden,  a 
 little  touch  of  a  boulder  here  and  a 
 boulder  there.  These  boulders  that  are 
 incorporated  into  the  garden,  these  are 
 things  that  are  you  can  pick  up  with 
 your  hands.  You  can  kind  of  transport 
 from  one  space  to  another.  I  love 
 bringing  them.  We  go  to  Tennessee  often. 
 That's  where  my  husband  loves  to  go  to 
 hunt.  We  go  to  Tennessee  pretty  often. 
 So,  I'm  always  coming  back  with  a 
 truckload  of  of  little  handheld  boulders 
 to  incorporate  into  my  garden  and  other 
 people's  gardens  because  I  like  that 
 look  in  the  garden.  There's  no 
 maintenance  to  it.  It  adds  just  another 
 different  element.  Just  like  I  would 
 change  a  contrast  of  a  frond  to  a  leaf 
 or  to  a  different  type  of  soft  foliage 
 to  more  dynamic  foliage.  A  boulder  does 
 the  same  kind  of  look  but  offers,  you 
 know,  no  care,  which  so  is  I  kind  of 
 kind  of  a  no-brainer,  right?  But  you  can 
 also  do  that  with  a  non-natural  material 
 in  the  garden.  Like  I  love  my  little 
 mushrooms  over  here  in  the  garden.  I 
 love  little  statues  and  whatnot.  Little 
 things  that  kind  of  just  add  a  little 
 bit  of  personality,  a  little  interest. 
 Those  are  things  that  kind  of  soften 
 that  jungle  vibe,  that  forest  vibe,  and 
 kind  of  help  you  create  more  of  that, 
 you  know,  that  that  enjoyable  walkable 
 space,  that  little  bit  of  personality  in 
 the  garden.  The  next  thing  that  we  did 
 when  we  took  out  the  grass,  creating 
 this  rock  pathway,  if  you  guys  love 
 pathways  in  your  garden,  once  the  stone 
 is  down  and  once  it's  done  properly,  it 
 is  no  fuss,  no  mus.  This  is  the  easiest 
 thing  we've  done.  We  don't  have  to  water 
 the  grass.  We  don't  have  to  cut  the 
 grass.  We  don't  have  to  worry  about  this 
 in  my  backyard.  This  walkway  has  become 
 my  backyard  swale,  my  backyard  space. 
 And  what's  great  about  it  is  it's  so 
 easy  to  maintain  and  trim  from  both 
 sides  of  my  pathway  area  here.  I  can  nip 
 and  tuck  as  I  walk  safely  through  my 
 garden  and  technically  bare  feet  if  I 
 wanted  to  and  just  nip  things  as  I  need 
 to  as  I  walk  through.  I  can  do  that  on 
 my  left  side  and  on  my  right  side.  And 
 this  is  where  all  of  my  heavy  foliage  is 
 within  just  a  few  feet  within  just  a 
 hand  reach.  the  back  side  of  my  garden. 
 You  that's  an  area  where  I'll  collect 
 old  fronds  before  my  maintenance  guy 
 picks  them  up.  This  is  an  easy  way  to 
 maintain  that.  Keep  it  an  area  to  where 
 you  can  maintain  from  the  backside  and 
 from  the  front  side.  And  then  that  way 
 that  little  bit  of  time  in  your  garden, 
 it's  easy  to  transport  with  a  little 
 wheelbarrow  and  and  do  your  trimmings 
 and  clippings  and  kind  of  keeping  it  on 
 the  lower  maintenance  end.  All right, 
 you  guys.  So,  I  know  that  was  a  lot  of 
 information  to  probably  digest.  I'm 
 hoping  that  you  got  enough  information 
 and  and  tips  through  this  video  that  it 
 might  help  you  kind  of  create  something 
 similar  into  your  own  space.  You  guys 
 have  always  been  so  kind  on  the  comments 
 on  how  much  you  love  my  outdoor  space. 
 So,  I  thought  that  let's  share  this 
 video  today  and  let  you  in  behind  the 
 scenes  on  the  lack  of  maintenance  that's 
 involved  with  a  space  like  this.  If  you 
 enjoyed  today's  video,  then  please  click 
 on  last  week's  video.  It  was  how  we 
 created  a  private  backyard  in  your 
 typical  backyard  suburban  space.  Thank 
 you  so  much.  Take  care.  to  see  you  next 
 weekend.

 [Music] 
 Well,  hello  true  gardeners.  Today  we  are 
 in  Vero  Beach,  Florida,  zone  10A,  and  we 
 are  all  about  privacy.  We  are  in  a 
 backyard  that  we  just  finished  last  week 
 and  pretty  much  created  instant  privacy 
 for  our  clients.  Many  of  you  guys 
 probably  have  a  very  similar  situation 
 where  you  love  your  home.  You  love  your 
 space.  However,  it  is  pretty  nice  and 
 close  and  tucked  tucked  along  your 
 neighbors.  In  this  particular  backyard, 
 what  we  really  want  to  create  is  side 
 privacy  on  both  sides.  However,  because 
 they  were  backed  up  to  the  water  line, 
 they  still  wanted  to  see  a  little  bit  of 
 a  water  view.  So,  I'm  going to  get  Bryce 
 to  slide  in  all  three  angles.  the  one 
 from  the  closest  neighbor  side  here,  the 
 one  looking  from  inside  out  so  you  can 
 still  see  a  little  bit  of  that  water 
 line  so  that  wasn't  taken  up.  It  really 
 helped  soften  some  of  the  outside  houses 
 and  roof  lines  that  are  across  the  lake. 
 And  I  know  a  lot  of  my  clients  and 
 customers  had  that  issue.  So,  I'm  sure 
 that  you  guys  are  kind  of  battling  some 
 of  the  same  things.  I  think  this  is 
 going  to  do  a  great  job  pretty 
 instantaneously.  And  then  as  everything 
 grows  in  and  fills  out  even  more.  And 
 then  the  opposite  side,  as  that  grows  in 
 and  fills  out,  that  is  really  going  to 
 create  that  privacy.  All  three  sections 
 are  a  little  bit  different.  So  I'm  going 
 to  break  it  down.  This  way  you  guys 
 really  have  a  really  good  idea  of  what 
 we  used,  um,  the  reasons  why  we  used  it, 
 the  general  growth  rate  of  how  quickly 
 things  are  going  to  go  to  get  grow 
 together,  and  then  the  overall 
 combination  of  plants  that  I  chose  for 
 this  area.  And  why?  Because  I  love  them. 
 No,  I'm  just  joking.  because  they  work 
 together.  Plants  that  work  together  that 
 live  together  and  grow  together  are  so 
 much  easier  to  maintain  because  of  the 
 perfect  collection.  So,  this  grouping  is 
 going  to  grow  together  so  beautifully, 
 give  them  that  tropical  look,  but  be  on 
 the  easier  maintenance  side  and  still 
 offer  them  a  pretty  controlled  privacy. 
 All right,  you  guys.  So,  let's  jump 
 right  in,  get  started  on  the  heavy  side. 
 All right,  you  guys.  So,  we  are  going  to 
 start  on  the  beefy  side.  So,  this  is 
 what  I  would  consider  the  widest  part  of 
 the  backyard.  We  have  a  good  amount  of 
 girth  here.  The  pool  is  over  here,  but 
 what  is  on  the  other  side  of  these 
 fishtail  palms  of  this  nice  green  wall 
 here  would  be  the  neighbors  and  their 
 more  than  likely  pool  that  they're  going 
 to  put  in.  And  you  can  kind  of  see  how 
 they're  exactly  adjacent  from  each 
 other.  And  that's  kind  of  what  my 
 clients  are  really  concerned  about  as 
 construction  goes  on.  That's  part  of  it. 
 Neighbors  are  a  part  of  it.  but  having 
 your  own  bit  of  privacy,  having  this 
 space  to  yourself,  the  space  that  you're 
 going  to  live  in,  you're  going  to  enjoy. 
 I  think  that  was  really,  really 
 important  to  John  and  Patty.  So,  that's 
 what  we  tackled  first.  And  I  can't  think 
 of  a  better  tree  that  offers  impact  and 
 density  like  the  fishtail  palm.  And 
 that's  exactly  what  we  chose  to  use 
 here.  So,  we  have  a  nice  wall  of 
 fishtail  palms.  These  are  30  gallon 
 size.  This  is  about  what  you  get  for  a 
 30-  gallallon  size.  They're  about  seven, 
 seven  and  1/2t  tall.  great  thickness  to 
 them.  These  are  planted  six  foot  on 
 center.  So  from  the  center  of  the  tree 
 over  to  the  next  center  is  6  foot. 
 That's  kind  of  how  I  like  to  place  them. 
 You  can  spread  them  a  little  further 
 apart  if  you  like  because  they  do  chunk 
 out  nice  and  wide,  but  it  just  really 
 takes  them  time.  They  tend  to  grow 
 taller  first  before  they  grow  out  wide. 
 And  then  don't  be  afraid  that  this  is 
 too  close  together  because  they  will 
 join  nice  and  tight  together,  support 
 each  other,  and  then  all  shoot  together 
 simultaneously.  All  of  a  sudden,  they 
 get  that  high  five.  Okay,  we're  here. 
 We're  connected.  Now,  let's  go  up.  Cuz 
 they're  really  just  looking  for  that 
 support  on  either  side,  that  strength. 
 So,  you  can  really  plant  these  very 
 close  together  for  quick  coverage,  and 
 that's  the  way  I  like  to  use  them 
 because  they  do  just  that.  We  are  in 
 June.  By  the  end  of  summer,  these  will 
 be  connected.  These  will  be  solid.  This 
 will  be  the  wall  they're  looking  for. 
 And  then  by  next  end  of  summer,  they're 
 going  to  be  three  foot  taller  and  start 
 to  open  up  and  kind  of  give  you  that 
 fishtail  look.  That's  when  they  really 
 take  on  their  beauty.  They're  cool  now. 
 You  kind  of  see  what  they're  going  to 
 do,  but  nothing  like  they're  going  to  be 
 a  year,  two,  three,  four  years  down  the 
 road.  That's  when  their  real  beauty 
 comes  in.  And  having  a  nice  tall  wall 
 here  of  that  will  allow  my  clients  if 
 they  want  to  take  some  of  this  grass  up 
 and  curve  another  bed  to  the  front.  They 
 can  now  bring  in  some  shade  material, 
 some  different  options  cuz  they  can 
 change  the  microclimate  because  these 
 guys  are  going  to  get  so  nice  and  tall 
 that  there's  plenty  of  room  for  some 
 added  impact  here.  Fishtail  palms  make  a 
 fabulous  wall.  And  just  in  case  you  know 
 fishtails  aren't  doing  it  for  you,  maybe 
 you  look  them  up  and  they're  just  maybe 
 a  little  bit  too  big  for  what  you  want 
 or  maybe  you  like  more  of  that  palm 
 frron  kind  of  feel.  You  can  always  do 
 the  exact  same  kind  of  vertical  wall 
 planting  with  a  palms.  Of  course,  they 
 do  get  tall.  They'll  get  all  the  way 
 into  that  30  foot  range  like  the 
 fishtails.  They'll  get  27  to  30  over 
 time.  Great  part  about  both  of  those 
 pumps  is  you  can  cut  trunks  that  you 
 don't  want.  So,  you  can  really  kind  of 
 maintain  what  you  want  of  the  tree.  But 
 I  love  the  vertical  wall  they  offer 
 without  getting  too  far  into  the  yard. 
 They  really  can  be  nice  and  tall  and 
 lean.  If  you're  in  the  shade,  you  can 
 use  something  like  cat  palms.  Those  max 
 out  around  the  10  to  11  foot  range  and 
 they  will  offer  you  a  fabulous  10  to  11 
 foot  wall.  And  then  you  guys  know  how  I 
 feel  about  the  pygmy  8  palms.  You  can 
 actually  stagger  pygmy  8  palms.  They're 
 going  to  take  more  room,  but  if  you 
 stagger  them  kind  of  overlapping  each 
 other,  they're  going  to  create  a 
 fabulous  wall  that's  going  to  end  up 
 being  around  10  to  12t,  leaving  you  room 
 at  the  bottom  to  plant.  Kucia  is  also 
 another  nice  wall  that  you  can  create 
 and,  you  know,  give  you  that 
 instantaneous  privacy.  Got  to  give  those 
 things  time  to  grow.  And  I  love  what 
 fishtails  and  ora  palms  offer  because 
 they  give  you  density  and  they  give  you 
 height  right  off  the  bat.  So  that's  kind 
 of  why  it's  my  go-to  coverage  tree.  You 
 can  see  how  narrow  this  bed  is.  There's 
 no  need  for  this  bed  to  extend  any 
 further  out.  These  guys  will  grow  in 
 this  pattern  here.  So  nice  and  vertical, 
 nice  and  tight  to  the  fence,  nice  and 
 easy  maintenance.  Just  cut  off  whatever 
 trunk  you  don't  want.  They  will  not  hold 
 it  against  you.  So  they're  a  great  tree 
 to  work  with.  As  we  got  to  this  corner, 
 I  really  wanted  to  start  opening  the  bed 
 up  a  little  bit.  This  is  kind  of  a 
 direct  view  line  for  all  the  inside 
 seating.  So,  when  you're  indoors,  when 
 you're  in  the  pool,  when  I'm  creating 
 these  designs,  I'm  sitting  at  all  those 
 places.  I'm  looking  at  the  main 
 highlight  areas.  What  are  the  sections 
 that  I  kind  of  want  to  draw  your 
 attention?  This  is  beautiful,  but  it's 
 functional.  This  here,  obviously,  we 
 want  it  functional,  but  we  want  those 
 layers  to  start  popping  in.  We  want  it 
 to  be  beautiful.  So,  we  inherited  these 
 two  Christmas  palms.  They  were  part  of 
 the  builder's  package.  These  two  were 
 kind  of  in  the  middle  of  the  yard  and 
 that  was  it.  There  was  nothing  else  to 
 it.  So,  we  took  them  out  and 
 incorporated  them  into  our  beds.  We 
 chose  a  really  good  back  fill  of  a  soil 
 mixture.  And  we  use  Palm  Saver  in  these 
 guys  to  get  them  to  pop  out  with  good 
 root  growth  and  kind  of  get  them  out  of 
 some  of  that  old  soil  and  old 
 conditioning  they  have.  You  can  see  that 
 they're  not  super  happy,  but  they're 
 going  to  get  that  way  in  no  time.  So,  we 
 use  those  two  as  our  anchor  trees  here 
 on  the  side.  And  then  we  used  a  triple 
 bottle  palm.  It's  squatted.  It's  short. 
 These  two  trees  are  going  to  almost  over 
 canopy  where  the  bottle  palm  is,  which 
 is  going  to  give  it  that  great  roof 
 line.  I  just  love  the  way  that  that's 
 going  to  come  out  and  do  that  because 
 these  guys  are  going  to  open  up  all  the 
 way  to  12  ft.  So  these  two  will  connect 
 up  here  while  this  becomes  squatted.  So 
 these  get  to  16  to  18t  overall  height. 
 This  stays  around  the  12  to  14  foot 
 depending  on  the  location  and  really 
 just  widens  out  while  these  guys  go 
 vertical  and  tall  and  a  little  bit 
 thinner.  So,  I  think  that's  going  to  be 
 a  nice  little  cove  of  planting  in  this 
 area.  Now,  this  corner  area,  there's 
 going  to  be  construction  back  there.  I 
 know  it's  kind  of  hard  to  see  cuz  we  got 
 a  lot  going  on  right  here.  And  they  knew 
 that  they  really  wanted  that  corner  to 
 be  concealed,  but  not  completely  a  whole 
 wall  of  fishtails.  I  wanted  to  break  it 
 up.  That  corner  is  an  area  that  you  can 
 really  take  and  just  kind  of  add  a 
 bouquet  of  something  interesting. 
 Brazilian  red  cloaks  are  my  go-to  for  a 
 corner  planting.  They  will  get  8  to  10t 
 tall.  Fill  in  all  underneath  that  double 
 foxtail  palm  back  there.  So,  they're 
 going  to  be  absolutely  stunning  as  a 
 backdrop  and  understood. 
 And  we  don't  have  many  of  them.  We  have 
 four  15  gallons  back  here,  but  they  are 
 going  to  absolutely  engulf  this  whole 
 corner  at  8  to  10t  tall  underneath  the 
 canopy  of  this  tree  and  fill  in  all 
 under  here.  Give  you  this  gorgeous.  Look 
 at  this,  you  guys.  Look  at  this  leaf  at 
 such  a  young  plant.  And  this  leaf  is 
 just  so  stunning.  They're  going  to  give 
 you  that  8  to  10  foot  coverage  of  this 
 dense  leaf  and  then  pop  out  big  cone- 
 shaped  dark  pink  blooms.  And  that's 
 what's  really  going  to  give  this  back  a 
 showstopper  kind  of  feel.  It's  going  to 
 be  flanked  with  fishtail  palms  on  both 
 sides.  And  through  the  middle  is  going 
 to  be  this  double  foxtail  palm  coming 
 out  of  the  middle  with  this  cool  foxtail 
 frond  leaf.  I  just  love  the  way  that's 
 going  to  come  out  of  all  of  this  cluster 
 foliage  in  here.  It's  just  really  going 
 to  be  dense,  really  going  to  be  pink, 
 and  really  going  to  be  just  very,  very, 
 very  private,  but  tropical,  and  that's 
 the  goal.  So  now  I'm  sure  you  can 
 imagine  that  with  these  trees  kind  of 
 all  coming  in  this  coming  up  those 
 coming  this  way  the  canopy  of  this  tree 
 really  giving  us  coverage  this  area  is 
 going  to  get  a  bit  dark  and  that's  going 
 to  happen  in  no  time.  So  what  I  wanted 
 to  bring  in  was  a  few  brighter  tones  and 
 colors.  So  what  you  do  see  when  you're 
 looking  from  the  the  seating  section  you 
 see  the  bright  tones.  So,  we've  got  the 
 a  little  clustering  of  the  curly  dwarf 
 jaba  white  copper  leaves  and  then  one  of 
 my  favorite  plants  ever,  which  is  this 
 song  of  India.  Oh  my  gosh,  you  guys,  it 
 is  just  so  gorgeous.  The  darker  the 
 location  that  it's  in,  the  more  white 
 and  green  it  gets.  And  I  think  that  just 
 a  little  surrounding  the  base  of  this 
 tree  is  going  to  like  scream,  "Hey, 
 little  spotlight  in  the  garden."  It's 
 going  to  give  you  that  little  bit  of 
 impact  of  brightness.  And  I  think  that's 
 going  to  actually  be  a  stunner  as  this 
 garden  opens  up  down  below.  It's  time  to 
 get  nice  and  neat.  We  don't  want 
 anything  too  crazy.  We  got  the  crazy  in 
 the  back.  Now  it's  time  to  kind  of 
 outline  everything  with  some  controlled 
 detailed  planting.  And  you  guys  know 
 that  I  love  the  gold  mound  for  that.  I 
 love  what  Gold  Mound  offer.  They  give  us 
 just  a  little  bit  of  a  paired  back 
 controlled  almost  like  a  little  tropical 
 leafed  hedge.  And  then  if  I  have  gold 
 mound,  I  tend  to  really  love  to  bring  in 
 little  rubies.  These  rubies  will  offer 
 that  dark  tones  at  different  times  of 
 the  year.  They  get  a  little  bit  green 
 during  the  early  summer  and  they  get  a 
 little  bit  red  and  dark  purple  during 
 the  winter  and  fall  seasons.  So,  if  gold 
 mound  and  the  little  rubies  are  not  kind 
 of  your  speed,  if  you  kind  of  want 
 something  that's  kind  of  tapered  back, 
 maybe  you  have  enough  color  back  there, 
 I  love  the  Carissa  boxwood  emerald 
 blankets.  They  make  a  nice  controlled 
 planting.  So  do  dwarf  exoras.  They  make 
 a  nice  controlled  planting.  You  do  need 
 a  little  bit  more  sun  for  those,  but  I'm 
 telling  you,  it's  worth  it  because  they 
 just  really  give  you  that  pop  of  color. 
 That  tiny  leaf  makes  everything  look 
 super  super  tight  and  controlled.  So, 
 whatever  you  put  to  the  back  can  be 
 crazy,  can  be  wild,  but  that  front 
 couple  tiers,  if  you  can  make  that  nice 
 and  tiered  and  controlled,  it  really 
 does  a  nice  job  of  helping  it  come 
 together.  And  this  isn't  a  big  bed,  you 
 guys.  If  I'm  looking  from  this  corner  to 
 all  the  way  back  in  that  far  corner,  and 
 it's  very  v-shaped,  so  it  goes  back 
 very,  very  far  through  that  back,  we're 
 only  looking  at  10  feet.  So,  we  didn't 
 come  out  very  far  into  this  landscaping. 
 My  clients  had  dogs,  so  they  wanted  to 
 make  sure  to  keep  as  much  open  grass  as 
 they  could  and  then  still  enjoy  the 
 privacy  and  the  landscaping.  So,  this  is 
 one  way  that  we  chose  to  do  it.  We  chose 
 to  keep  everything  right  at  the 
 perimeter  of  the  fence  line.  And  I  think 
 it  did  a  nice  job  of  giving  them  the 
 coverage  without  taking  away  all  of 
 their  grass.  There's  not  much  grass  we 
 have  here  in  Vero  Beach,  so  we've  got  to 
 keep  what  we've  got.  So,  lastly  in  this 
 bed  are  going  to  be  the  anmaries.  And  I 
 feel  like  I  mean,  they  deserve  a  mention 
 because  they're  here  and  they're  very 
 young  and  they're  really  not  popping  out 
 yet,  but  I'm  still  going  to  mention 
 them.  I'll  get  Bryce  to  pop  up  a  picture 
 of  what  anaries  look  like  in  the  garden 
 as  they  really  flush  out  with  color. 
 These  are  going  to  be  stunners  when  they 
 do  that.  They're  just  not  quite  there. 
 We  have  a  little  clustering  and  they 
 offer  you  like  a  red  and  yellow  and  even 
 a  tad  bit  of  pink  coloration  in  the 
 blooms.  So  they're  going  to  be  a  perfect 
 little  ground  cover.  And  those  of  you 
 guys  who  have  rabbit  traffic,  anmarie 
 lantana  are  usually  not  on  the  menu  for 
 rabbits.  So  they're  kind  of  a  nice 
 option  and  alternate  to  something  like 
 blue  my  mind.  I'll  use  anie  lantana 
 society  garlic.  Those  kind  of  things  to 
 try  to  avoid  rabbit  traffic.  These  guys 
 will  do  a  nice  job  of  being  condensed. 
 get  a  little  bit  taller  in  the  center 
 with  some  of  that  blooming  color  and 
 then  taper  down  on  the  corners  with  the 
 gold  mound.  So,  I  think  that's  going  to 
 be  a  lovely  combination.  We  do  have  four 
 splitly  filidendrian  in  this  bed  here. 
 So,  I've  got  them  just  popping  out.  You 
 guys  who  know  splitly  filidendrian,  they 
 get  large,  they  get  big,  but  they  do 
 offer  you  a  great  pop  of  leaf  coverage. 
 We  had  a  couple  spots  that  I  thought 
 that  would  be  awesome.  So,  that's  what 
 these  guys  are  here.  They're  going  to 
 come  up.  you  know,  they  get  a  little  bit 
 leggy  to  them,  but  this  big  leaf 
 quadruples  in  size,  and  it's  going  to 
 kind  of  come  up  and  just  soften  the 
 corners  of  both  of  these  beds.  And 
 that's  kind  of  their  goal.  They're  going 
 to  pop  up  and  over  top  of  the  plant 
 material,  offering  a  little  bit  of 
 coverage,  a  little  bit  of  shade  to  the 
 plants,  but  also  give  us  that  leaf  kind 
 of  look  to  the  garden,  that  big  leaf 
 kind  of  look.  We  couldn't  do  10  of  them 
 back  here,  but  do  pop  it  in  a  couple, 
 you  know,  don't  sleep  on  the  split  leaf 
 filidendry.  Sometimes  people  think  you 
 need  a  big  mass  collection  of  them  to 
 really  do  something,  but  you  honestly 
 only  need  a  big  leaf  to  pop  out  here  and 
 there.  And  it  kind  of  gives  them  more  of 
 like  a  like  a  monstera  vibe,  you  know, 
 but  this  area  is  going  to  get  too  much 
 midday  sun.  And  that's  the  reason  why  I 
 chose  the  split  leaf  filidendran  for 
 that  because  they  can  handle  more  of  the 
 sun  than  the  monstera  can.  All right,  so 
 now  let's  move  on  to  the  next  section  of 
 the  yard.  So  this  is  directly  behind  the 
 pool  screen.  This  is  exactly  what  you 
 see  when  you  first  enter  the  front  door 
 of  my  client's  home.  This  is  what  you 
 see  when  you're  sitting  on  the  patio. 
 This  is  a  main  focal  point  area.  So,  I 
 definitely  wanted  to  have  some  interest, 
 some  lower  and  some  taller.  So,  what  I 
 chose  first  just  because  this  is  dead 
 center  on  the  doorway.  Funny  enough,  it 
 is  not  dead  center  on  the  pull  screen, 
 but  on  the  doorway  itself,  that's  where 
 I  pull  my  center  for  the  most  part

 you  see  it.  So,  this  is  dead  center  of

 something  you  can  see  through,  but  it's 
 still  dynamic  enough  to  catch  your 
 attention.  And  then  you  kind  of  float 
 off  from  there.  Then  we  kept  it  real 
 low.  Just  a  handful  of  little  rubies  on 
 the  corner.  A  handful  of  blew  my  minds 
 right  along  the  front.  These  are  planted 
 nice  and  tight  and  close  together  about 
 8  in  to  a  foot  apart.  So  that  way  I  want

 And  then  just  a  staggered  little

 And  then  that's  it.  A  nice  ovalshaped

 creates  more  of  a  meandering  pathway  of
