 started  another  bed  on  the  opposite 
 side.  So  this  is  more  of  the  garden. 
 This  is  more  of  the  butterfly  garden.  I 
 think  this  is  going  to  be  a  lovely  pop 
 of  blooms.  This  is  the  sunniest  spot  of 
 the  whole  garden.  So,  this  is  the  place 
 that  we  really  did  get  to  splurge  and  do 
 a  little  bit  of  color  in.  So,  I  think 
 that's  going  to  be  gorgeous.  Starting 
 with  the  powder  puff,  the  pink 
 powderpuff  trees.  These  are  25gallon 
 powder  puffs.  I  have  them  anchored  on 
 both  sides.  Their  spread  is  going  to  get 
 enormous  back  here.  Those  of  you  guys 
 who  had  powderpuff  know  they  can  get  all 
 the  way  up  to  20  foot  wide.  But  one  of 
 the  benefits  to  them  is  you  can  keep 
 them  this  size  forever  if  you  wanted  to. 
 They're  not  like  a  a  heavy  hardwood  that 
 you  can't  trim  and  can't  keep  dense  and 
 full.  Either  way,  however  you  want  to  do 
 it,  they're  a  gorgeous  specimen  in  the 
 garden  because  they  really  widen  out, 
 almost  give  you  the  kind  of  that  Asian 
 feel  as  they  get  a  little  bit  larger. 
 Fill  out  more  mushroom  at  the  top,  widen 
 out  at  the  bottom,  really  become  a  cool 
 feature.  And  what  I'm  hoping  to  do  with 
 these,  what  I  was  trying  to  explain  to 
 John  in  his  pruning,  go  ahead  and  prune 
 the  tops  kind  of  off.  could  give  a 
 little  bit  of  a  mushroom  look  to  the  top 
 and  let  the  sides  continue  to  grow  out 
 and  almost  connect  with  each  other.  By 
 the  time  that  these  sides  connect  with 
 each  other,  now  hold  up.  I  know  you're 
 thinking  it's  going  to  block  this  double 
 King  Alexander,  but  let  me  finish.  Once 
 these  guys  connect  like  this,  this  King 
 Alexander  is  going  to  be  25t  tall, 
 pretty  much  all  trunk  at  the  base  here. 
 And  then  you're  going  to  have  these 
 gorgeous  15t  wide  fronds  at  the  top  of 
 this  canopy  of  trees.  So  you'll  have 
 like  a  hammock  that  comes  across  the 
 middle  which  will  serve  as  the  perfect 
 thing  of  coverage.  It'll  kind  of  become 
 that  colorful  wall  to  kind  of  help 
 disguise  all  of  those  houses,  all  of 
 those  backyards,  all  of  those  screen 
 rooms  back  there.  That  will  become  your 
 wall  of  pink  and  green.  Above  that,  so 
 it  just  doesn't  feel  like  a  solid  wall 
 will  be  the  King  Alexander  as  like  the 
 little  crown  on  top.  So  it'll  come  out 
 like  just  a  flaming  little  centerpiece 
 that  you  want  it  to  be.  I  just  love  the 
 way  that  these  palm  trees  kind  of  come 
 out  of  the  hammocks  of  trees.  I  think 
 that's  just  so  cool,  so  magical.  I 
 cannot  wait  to  see  that  happen.  This  bed 
 will  take  time.  I  tried  to  bring  them  in 
 at  30  gallon  size  because  these  powder 
 puffs  grow  a  little  bit  slower.  You  get 
 about  2  foot  this  year  at  the  top  and 
 hopefully  a  good  two  maybe  3T  of  width 
 at  the  edges.  But  it's  really  not 
 necessarily  how  far  they're  coming  out, 
 it's  how  thick  they're  going  to  get.  So 
 trimming  on  these  guys  is  really 
 important.  Anytime  you  have  something 
 that's  lacy  like  this,  trimming  these 
 little  edges,  just  the  little  tips,  you 
 don't  have  to  do  like  a  heavy  cut  back. 
 Just  a  little  trimming  on  the  edges 
 really  promotes  new  stem  off.  So, 
 that'll  get  fuller  and  fuller  through 
 this  area.  And  well  worth  that  little 
 bit  of  effort.  And  I  mean,  they're  so 
 delicate.  You  can  come  in  here  with  like 
 little  nippers  and  just  kind  of  cut  off 
 the  ends  kind  of  like  you  do  a  buganilia 
 tree.  That  way,  you  can  really  just 
 train  it  to  grow  the  way  you  want  to.  I 
 have  seen  these  guys  as  almost  like 
 mushroom  shaped  trees  that  kind  of  come 
 out  and  then  flat  at  the  bottom  and 
 they're  just  like  it's  almost  hard  to 
 tell  what  kind  of  tree  it  is.  It's  just 
 so  stunning.  So,  they'll  do  a  nice  job 
 of  being  the  final  anchor  here. 
 Underneath  here  is  going  to  be  our 
 colorful  garden.  We've  got  hot  pink 
 pentas  to  the  back  right  along  the  fence 
 line.  We've  got  lantana.  These  are 
 yellow  lantana  as  the  center  really 
 filling  up  this  bottom.  And  then  again 
 to  keep  it  nice  and  tight  along  the 
 front,  these  are  Cararissa  boxwood.  I 
 love  this  dark  green  leaf.  This  little 
 guy  will  connect  to  this  little  guy  and 
 it'll  just  kind  of  be  a  nice  little  half 
 circle  to  kind  of  hold  a  little  bit  of 
 the  the  cottagey  feel  of  the  garden 
 back.  So  taller  in  the  back,  shorter  in

 front,  but  very  clean  line,  very  very 
 crisp,  very  very  shiny  leaf.  So  it's 
 going  to  kind  of  give  us  that  tropical 
 feel  right  behind  the  palm  tree  just  to

 like  a  texture  change.  It's  like  it's 
 like  wardrobe  change.  So,  the  foxtail 
 ferns  do  a  great  job  of  that.  They're 
 going  to  give  you  that  almost  like  a 
 grassy  kind  of  feel,  a  little  bit  of 
 movement  in  the  garden.  Very,  very 
 vertical,  very,  very  upright.  And 
 they're  going  to  do  a  nice  job  of  kind 
 of  giving  us  that  soft  feathery  feel  to 
 the  back  as  an  underplanting  of  this 
 guy.  And  they're  not  going  to  get  four, 
 five,  six  foot  tall  that  covers  up  this 
 waterline.  When  this  area  matures,  the 
 only  thing  my  clients  are  going  to  lose 
 is  the  grass  line  behind  them.  They're 
 going  to  see  they're  going  to  go  right 
 from  plants  to  water.  And  that's  the 
 goal.  As  this  tree  gets  bigger  opening 
 those  trees  here,  we've  got  a  4ft 
 opening  underneath  here.  Once  they  have 
 a  5  to  6t  opening,  it's  all  water  and  no 
 houses,  which  is  is  kind  of  a  nice 
 thing.  So,  especially  when  you  want  to 
 keep  that  that  breeze,  keep  that  water 
 line,  but  not,  you  know,  not  everything 
 else.  We  have  another  boss  agave.  And  I 
 know  this  guy  looks  like  it  doesn't  have 
 exactly  a  purpose  here,  but  when  you're 
 looking  from  inside  out  this  way,  we 
 have  two  fals  agave  here,  one  dead 
 center  here.  So  it  looks  like  this  guy's 
 directly  in  the  middle.  So  we've  kind  of 
 given  it  a  triangle.  So  we  have  those 
 two  forward,  one  pulled  back.  We  have 
 these  two  trees  pulled  forward,  and  the 
 one  behind  me  pulled  back.  And  anytime 
 you  can  do  a  staggered  grouping  like 
 that,  where  you  have  a  triangle  to  the 
 front,  a  triangle  to  the  back,  it  I 
 don't  know,  it  just  comes  together.  It 
 looks  really,  really  well  done.  And  then 
 when  everything  grows  up  and  has  more 
 stature,  more  more  substance  in  the 
 garden,  then  it  really  turns  into  almost 
 like  I  said,  a  statue  in  the  garden.  It 
 kind  of  really  becomes  that 
 architectural  detail  where  they  all  kind 
 of  play  together.  So  I  I  hope  that 
 that's  coming  across  on  camera  for  you 
 guys.  So  if  you  guys  are  liking  this 
 look  or  kind  of  seeing  the  reason  behind 
 it,  but  you're  like,  you  know what,  I 
 just  never  been  a  fan  of  powder  puffs. 
 They're  not  my  thing.  That's  okay. 
 There's  other  trees.  Bottle  brush  trees. 
 Uh  the  standard  variety  is  my  favorite. 
 The  weeping  can  get  a  little  bit  crazy. 
 Can  get  a  little  broad  and  wide.  But  the 
 standard  is  more  lollipop  shape.  So  it 
 has  a  dense  rounded  head,  big  nice  solid 
 trunk.  You  can  put  two  standard  bottle 
 brush  and  they  will  get  10t  wide  and 
 really  give  you  whatever  size  you  want, 
 which  I  think  is  the  point  here.  As  long 
 as  you  can  have  about  5t  of  clear  trunk 
 and  then  that  dense  thick  canopy  at  the 
 top,  then  you're  kind  of  getting  exactly 
 what  you  want.  You  got  the  blockage  with 
 something  natural,  with  something  with 
 color.  Bottle  brush  will  do  a  great  job 
 with  that.  The  next  thing  that  you  can 
 use  is  a  hibiscus.  I  love  hibiscus.  Just 
 make  sure  it's  not  kind  of  like  this 
 where  it's  too  windy  of  a  spot  because 
 they  have  a  tendency  where  they  don't 
 root  quite  as  well.  So  stake  them  really 
 nice  and  tight  so  that  way  the  canopies 
 can  get  real  big  and  you're  not 
 constantly  cutting  it  back.  A  hibiscus 
 tree  will  do  the  same.  You  can  manage 
 the  size  and  you  have  a  nice  dense 
 canopy.  Crate  myrtles  are  ideal  if  you 
 guys  are  only  here  during  the  summer 
 months.  Crate  myrtle  is  an  ideal  tree  to 
 use  because  you  can  keep  it  whatever 
 size  you  want.  The  blooms  are 
 extraordinary.  Unfortunately,  it  is  only 
 during  the  summer  and  then  the  winter, 
 of  course,  they  fall  off.  Um,  a  little 
 dollop  gold  mound.  Now,  it's  rare  that  I 
 put  one  of  anything  in  the  bed,  but  I 
 have  one  on  one  side,  the  false  agave, 
 and  another  on  the  other  because  I 
 didn't  have  much  room,  but  I  still 
 needed  a  highlight  around  this  bad  boy. 
 I  kind  of  wanted  some  impact  from  the 
 inside.  So,  a  gold  mount  on  either  side 
 to  kind  of  give  us  some  paired  back  feel 
 from  the  foxtail  ferns  because  that's  my 
 motto,  tight  and  controlled  against  the 
 crazy.  And  that's  kind  of  what  they're 
 going  to  do.  Then  down  at  the  bottom,  we 
 have  just  a  nice  little  row  of  blew  my 
 minds  and  that's  going  to  offer  just  a 
 little  delicate  color  and  tie  in  with 
 the  delicate  color  in  that  bed.  Now, 
 what's  great  about  this  bed  is  there's 
 room  for  pop  out.  So,  right  now  they 
 wanted  to  keep  it,  you  know,  fairly 
 simple,  the  coverage  where  they  needed 
 it,  some  color  where  they  wanted,  but 
 ultimately  you  can  kind  of  see  how  this 
 can  pretty  much  be  a  thinner  pathway. 
 That  bed  can  loop  out  more  here  and 
 here.  You  can  kind  of  make  this  meander 
 more  this  way  and  tighten  this  whole 
 area  up.  Maybe  make  another  seating 
 section  over  there.  This  is  a  growing 
 landscape  because  this  phase  does  not 
 have  to  be  the  one  and  done.  And  I  try 
 to  encourage  my  clients  where  if  you  can 
 push  your  landscaping  out  to  the  extent 
 of  your  property,  if  that's  a  doable 
 thing  for  you,  start  there.  Because  once 
 you  get  that  bug,  it's  like,  okay,  I'm 
 really  liking  how  everything's  growing 
 in.  what  happens  if  I  just,  you  know, 
 pop  a  bed  out  here  or  pop  a  bed  out 
 there  and  add  to  it.  Kind  of  work  your 
 way  forward.  And  you  can  do  that  slowly 
 over  time,  a  phase  at  a  time.  And  that's 
 how  I  hope  these  videos  come  across.  I 
 hope  they  come  across  where  that's  kind 
 of  doable.  I  can  kind  of  see  the 
 direction  that  you're  going  in  here.  And 
 then  you  as  you  build  up  the  videos,  you 
 build  up  ideas  of  what  might  work  with 
 your  style,  what  you  like,  and  and 
 equally  what  you  don't  like  because 
 that's  just  as  important  when  you're 
 creating  a  space,  especially  when  you're 
 limited  like  we  are  here  in  Vero  Beach. 
 A  lot  of  the  Florida  homes  are  very 
 similar  to  this  where  you  have  very 
 little  space.  So  you  want  to  make  sure 
 that  what  you  put  in  there  is  something 
 that  you're  going  to  be  ideally  happy 
 with.  So  research,  research,  research  is 
 key  or  hire  a  company  like  ourselves,  a 
 landscape  design  company  or  wherever  you 
 are  and  investigate  that  a  little  bit 
 prior  to  actually  putting  the  first 
 planter  tree  in  the  ground.  That  way 
 you're  sure  to  really  like  the  direction 
 that  you're  going  in  and  you're  not 
 doing  things  backwards  or  not  doing 
 things  over.  There's  one  thing  about 
 investing  money  into  landscaping,  but 
 there's  a  whole  another  thing  in  wasting 
 it  in  landscaping.  And  I  know  that 
 happens  a  lot  more  times  than  it  should. 
 So  anyway,  so  kudos  to  you  guys  for 
 doing  your  research  today.  All right,  so 
 we're  now  in  the  opposite  corner.  And 
 although  I  love  balance,  I  think  it  was 
 very  important  to  have  something 
 different  going  on  here.  I  did  stick 
 with  the  foxtail  palm,  but  this  is  a 
 triple  compared  to  the  double  that  we 
 have  on  the  opposite  side.  So,  we  have  a 
 nice  triple  foxtail  palm  for  this 
 corner.  Flanking  on  either  side,  we  have 
 two  kinopsis  palms.  Oh  my  gosh,  you 
 guys.  I  love  this.  I  mean,  just  look  at 
 this  giant  leaf  compared  to  me.  I  mean, 
 this  is  a  huge  leaf.  This  is  very 
 vertical  tree,  very  upright,  grow  slow. 
 For  those  of  you  guys  in  the  northern 
 area,  Melbourne,  Cocoa  Beach,  Satellite 
 Beach,  maybe  even  into  Orlando,  these 
 guys  can  handle  it.  They  can  get  down 
 into  temps  of  24.  Fabulous  tree  to  work 
 with.  I  love  that  upright  look  that  they 
 have  to  their  fronds.  So,  they  have  a 
 nice  small  trunk.  They  will  of  course 
 grow  tall  like  most  palms  do,  but 
 they're  going to  do  it  at  a  slow  rate. 
 So,  they're  really  going  to  offer  this 
 kind  of  look.  But  once  they  do  grow 
 tall,  they're  not  going  to  compete  with 
 this  triple  foxtail  palm.  It  is  going  to 
 be  the  crown  on  the  top.  It's  going  to 
 be  the  one  that's  pushing  through.  These 
 will  be  the  understory  trees,  but  these 
 fronds  will  now  eventually  start  to  open 
 up  and  kind  of  come  across  me.  They 
 won't  quite  touch.  They're  not  quite 
 that  wide.  They're  still  more  vertical 
 than  they  are  wide,  but  they  will  come 
 pretty  darn  close  and  kind  of  become 
 almost  like  a  little  hammock  to  this 
 area,  like  a  little  cove  to  this  corner. 
 And  that  was  the  goal  on  both  of  these 
 corners  because  we  had  to  work  so 
 tightly  against  the  fence.  You  want  to 
 make  sure  that  you  push  it  back  as  far 
 as  you  can.  Make  sure  that  whatever's  in 
 that  rear  corner,  make  it  the  tallest 
 thing  in  the  garden.  Make  it  the  crown. 
 So  that  way  when  you  put  other  things  on 
 either  side  of  it,  you're  almost 
 creating  that  Vshape  above  your  ey  line. 
 And  then  all  of  this  lower  material, 
 this  is  just  fluff.  This  is  just  filler. 
 It  really  kind  of  creates  a  cove  of  its 
 own  without  you  having  to  do  any  of  that 
 work  because  palm  trees  are  way  less 
 maintenance  than  than  plants  themselves. 
 If  you  want  to  create  this  look,  but 
 maybe  these  palms  aren't  an  option  for 
 you.  Some  other  options,  if  you  can't  do 
 a  triple  foxtail  palm,  look  into 
 something  like  a  king  Alexander  or  a 
 regular  Alexander,  a  Montgomery  palm. 
 Those  are  all  palms  that  kind  of  really 
 give  you  that  big  nice  bow  to  the  trunk 
 and  gives  you  a  nice  dense  full  thick 
 canopy  because  what  you're  looking  for 
 is  a  big  umbrella  back  there.  That  big 
 thing  that  comes  up  and  out.  Another 
 thing  would  be  a  cold  coconut  if  you're 
 from  the  north.  A  regular  coconut  is 
 ideal  if  you're  down  south  because  it's 
 going  to  really  give  you  that  great 
 branching  and  it's  going  to  do  it  pretty 
 fast.  On  either  side,  you  guys  know  I 
 love  the  King  Alexander,  the  singles.  I 
 would  put  a  single  King  Alexander, 
 another  single  here.  And  that  really 
 does  a  great  job  of  kind  of  giving  you 
 that  vertical  feel  without  taking  up  too 
 much  space.  So  that  would  be  a  good 
 look.  To  the  back  we  have  the  Rojo  red 
 copper  leaves.  And  I  know  you  you  guys 
 know  you  see  me  use  them  all  the  time. 
 They're  going  to  get  six  to  seven  foot. 
 Fill  in  this  whole  back  corner.  This  is 
 going  to  be  a  dense  cluster  planting 
 that's  going  to  be  nice  and  full  because 
 what  my  clients  are  looking  at  are  five 
 or  six  different  pool  areas  and 
 different  screen  rooms  back  there.  So 
 having  this  corner  more  dense  is  ideal 
 for  that  privacy,  for  that  coverage,  and 
 this  is  going  to  do  a  great  job  of  that. 
 Right  through  the  bottom,  our  song  of 
 India.  So  we  have  a  bright  spot  on  both 
 rear  corners.  In  what's  going  to  be  a 
 dark  spot  as  it  grows  in  these  songs  of 
 India  will  become  a  nice  filtered  kind 
 of  like  just  a  bright  tone  as  you  come 
 in.  Can  easily  be  managed  at  3  foot.  You 
 guys,  Java  white  is  another  great  plant 
 to  use.  The  only  negative  with  Java 
 white  versus  the  Song  of  India  is  the 
 Java  white  not  only  gets  taller  but  it 
 does  need  some  room  for  expansion.  So  if 
 you've  got  that  room  ideal  if  you  don't 
 Song  of  India  is  perfect  for  that  kind 
 of  look.  Another  one  is  Sanchezia. 
 Sanchezia  is  a  great  kind  of  bright  tone 
 in  a  dark  spot.  So  sandwich  those  things 
 in  between  your  dark  colors.  Right  here 
 we  have  an  orange  flame  burmilad.  This 
 is  a  sunloving  burmilad.  It's  going  to 
 widen  out  and  fill  in  this  whole  spot. 
 become  such  a  a  nice  pop  of  bright 
 orange-ish  yellow  color  in  the  middle.  I 
 have  some  little  golden  sedum  at  the 
 base  here  and  at  the  base  here  and  then 
 right  along  this  tip  just  to  give  us  a 
 highlight  and  carry  this  theme  on  over 
 is  going  to  be  the  blew  my  minds  because 
 that  is  a  song  that  we're  singing 
 through  this  whole  bed.  Just  about  every 
 bed  back  here  has  a  little  touch  of  blew 
 my  minds.  We  did  not  go  crazy,  but  it 
 just  has  a  little  bit  of  that  blue 
 color.  I  wish  they  were  popping  open 
 right  now,  but  it  is  6  o'clock  in  the 
 evening  and  they've  closed  up  for  the 
 night,  so  you  don't  really  get  to  see 
 the  beauty  of  those.  I  know  you  true 
 gardeners  out  there,  I  know  you  guys  can 
 imagine  what  that  looks  like  cuz  you've 
 seen  them  on  so  many  of  my  videos. 
 Speaking  of  true  gardeners,  comment  true 
 gardener  if  you  guys  have  made  it  this 
 far  in  this  video  because  you  are  truly 
 true  gardeners.  I  really  enjoy  reading 
 and  flipping  through  your  comments  every 
 single  weekend  and  seeing  that  true 
 gardener  stamp  of  approval  there.  So, 
 thank  you,  True  Gardeners.  So  for  the 
 next  smallest  section,  but  definitely 
 not  the  least,  because  this  is  an 
 important  thing  to  do  if  you  have  one  of 
 those  narrow  areas  to  avoid  them  being  a 
 pain  in  the  butt  to  work  with.  This 
 little  section,  which  is  a  6  foot  wide 
 side  area  of  the  pool,  could  not  be 
 neglected,  but  it  was  very  hard  to 
 figure  out  what  to  do  here  other  than  a 
 nice  tight  pod  carpus  hedge.  Now,  I  love 
 podocarp  because  it  can  be  10t  tall  and 
 1T  wide.  I  mean,  there's  not  many  things 
 that  will  hold  up  nice  and  straight  like 
 that  and  really  become  nice  and  dense 
 and  full  and  solid.  So  much  so  that  when 
 this  guy  gets  full  and  thick  and  they 
 all  connect  and  become  that  10-ft  wall, 
 they're  going  to  be  almost  a  sound 
 barrier,  too,  because  of  all  these 
 individual  little  needles.  And  that's 
 what  you're  looking  for,  but  you  don't 
 have  the  room  for  something  like  a  Kucia 
 or  a  viburnum  or,  you  know,  anything 
 that's  going  to  come  over  here  and 
 encroach  into  this  space,  then  podarpus 
 is  a  great  go-to  option.  I  love  what  it 
 does.  it  will  be  this  tall  in  no  time 
 and  really  become  a  nice  sleek  clean 
 wall  and  really  really  work  in  this 
 space.  And  because  they're  going  to  do 
 that  and  they're  not  going  to  let  any 
 sun  come  in  from  this  side,  we  ended  up 
 doing  a  Tahesian  gray  granite  stone 
 pathway.  Look  how  nice  and  tight  this 
 pathway  is.  It's  only  been  in  for  just  a 
 few  days  and  you  can  really  see  I  am  not 
 sinking.  I  am  not  wobbling.  This  is  a 
 great  pathway  to  use  if  you  guys  have 
 Tahesian  gray  granite  or  even  regular 
 gray  granite.  This  pathway  here  is  an 
 inch  to  inch  and  a  half.  Most  rocky 
 yards  carry  it.  Probably  not  the  most 
 ideal  thing  if  you're  out  there  looking 
 at  rock  at  the  rocky  yard.  That's  the 
 reason  why  I  mention  it  so  much.  It's 
 one  that  gets  looked  past  so  often 
 because  it's  I  wouldn't  say  it's  your 
 prettiest  rock,  but  it  knits  together  so 
 well.  All  those  little  hard  edges 
 connect  and  knit  together  and  drop  down 
 unlike  a  rolling  rock  like  your  White 
 River  rock  or  some  of  your  prettier 
 rocks.  That  kind  of  rock  is  lovely  in  a 
 garden  bed,  but  if  you're  looking  to 
 make  it,  you  know,  useful  where  you're 
 needing  to  walk  or  it's  traffic  or,  you 
 know,  this  is  a  much  better  option.  So, 
 I  love  using  it  right  outside  the  pool 
 screen  here.  You  can  tell  that  this  is 
 an  area  that's  more  of  a  utilitarian 
 area.  And  we  all  kind  of  need  to  kind  of 
 make  allowance  for  that  for  storage  or 
 would  be  ideal  for  herb  planting 
 planters  along  this  area.  There's  still 
 enough  room  for  both  of  those  things 
 with  this  tight  fitting  hedge.  Now,  what 
 you  do  want  to  make  sure  and  do  if 
 you're  going  to  you  have  a  very  similar 
 fence  like  my  client  has,  if  you  have 
 that  and  you're  going to  put  rock  up 
 against  it,  definitely  continue  putting 
 an  edging  along  that  bottom.  Put  a  nice 
 little  footer.  We  have  the  aluminum 
 alloy  edging.  It  runs  all  along  this 
 little  front  section  here  and  then  feeds 
 all  the  way  through  the  side  and  goes 
 all  the  way  down  the  back.  It's  kind  of 
 a  bummer  because  you  don't  get  to  see 
 it,  but  it  does  a  great  job  of  keeping 
 this  compact  and  tight,  real  controlled. 
 So,  this  rock  isn't  going  anywhere.  We 
 have  hurricanes,  tornadoes,  we  have  so 
 much  bad  weather  in  our  Florida  area. 
 So,  keeping  this  in  a  permanent  sandwich 
 position  is  the  way  to  go.  All  right, 
 you  guys.  So,  that  pretty  much  does  it 
 for  today.  This  small  yard  is  now 
 becoming  private.  One  side  is  fully 
 private.  The  other  side  in  no  time  will 
 become  a  gorgeous  wall  and  kind  of 
 create  that  look.  And  I'm  hoping  that 
 helps  you  guys  with  maybe  some  ideas, 
 maybe  some  tips  and  tricks  of  what  you 
 can  do  in  your  space.  All  right,  you 
 guys.  Thank  you  so  much  for  joining  me 
 on  today's  video.  I  hope  you  enjoyed  it. 
 And  if  you  liked  this  one,  then  you'll 
 like  the  latest  garden  tour  video,  which 
 is  a  backyard  pool  tropical  resort  feel. 
 I  hope  you're  going  to  enjoy  that.  Take

---

 What  goes  into  making  these  projects 
 from  bare  dirt  renovated  to  a  resort 
 style  garden  like  we  like  to  do. 
 [Music] 
 Today  is  going  to  be  about  a  day  in  the 
 life  of  a  landscape  designer  or  at least 
 this  landscape  designer.  So  you  guys  get 
 to  see  that  it's  not  just  about  the 
 digging  the  hole,  the  watering  things  in 
 and  putting  the  trees  in,  but  just  kind 
 of  the  thoughts  that  go  on  behind  the 
 scenes.  Happy  Monday  morning  and  let's 
 get  started.  We  are  going  to  head  to  the 
 job  sites  where  I'm  going  to  go  meet  my 
 guys  and  kind  of  just  walk  through  the 
 project  and  kind  of  get  things  set  up 
 and  started.  Let's  get  going. 
 [Music] 
 All right,  you  guys.  So,  we  have  arrived 
 at  the  job  site.  We  are  here  in  Vero 
 Beach,  Florida,  zone  10A.  We  are  going 
 to  set  up  the  job  now.  One  of  the  most 
 important  parts  of  my  day.  So,  this  is 
 where  I'm  going  to  take  my  stakes.  I'm 
 going  to  take  the  paint.  I'm  going  to 
 kind  of  mark  out  the  entire  job  for  the 
 guys  to  start  with  the  prep  work,  start 
 with  the  removal.  Those  of  you  guys  who 
 are  loving  this  kind  of  content,  please 
 like,  subscribe,  hit  that  notification 
 bell.  I  have  noticed  that  so  many  of  you 
 guys  who  keep  revisiting  back  with  me 
 have  not  yet  subscribed.  So,  if  you  love 
 it,  subscribe. 
 [Music] 
 We  have  the  frame  trees  in.  Now  we're 
 going  to  go  see  what  it  looks  like  from 
 inside.  Then  I  can  set  the  rest  of  the 
 trees  off  of  the  frame  trees,  which  are 
 the  most  important  trees  in  the  whole 
 design.  This  is  a  real  important  part  of 
 the  process.  A  lot  of  times  you  can  set 
 up  from  outside  in  that  space,  but 
 really  the  true  final  like  look  of 
 everything  is  from  inside  because  it  is 
 amazing  how  different  it  can  look  from 
 when  you're  sitting  out  there. 
 everything  can  eye  up  and  it  can  line  up 
 perfectly.  But  then  you  get  inside  this 
 seating  area  and  you're  you're  looking 
 at  it  from  this  angle,  which  is  the  most 
 important  angle  and  it  looks  a  little 
 off.  And  I  always  kind  of  do  it  right 
 from  when  you  walk  out  to  the  garden.  So 
 center  of  the  doors,  if  you  guys  have 
 back  patio  doors,  the  center  area  of 
 that,  you  kind  of  want  to  see  what  those 
 angles  look  like.  So  over  here  in  this 
 corner,  we're  dead  center  in  the  middle. 
 And  I'm  really  really  happy  with  this 
 this  feel,  this  look.  But  then  now  you 
 come  over  here.  This  grouping  of  three 
 stakes.  But  you  can  see  how  off  that 
 middle  stake  when  I'm  looking  at  it 
 outdoors,  that  middle  stake  is  on  that 
 middle  post.  It's  way  off.  So  I  need  to 
 shift  that  whole  bed  to  the  right. 
 That's  why  you  always  want  to  come 
 inside  and  make  sure  that  you're  looking 
 at  the  island.  You're  looking  at  the 
 location  of  the  trees  from  the  most 
 important  part,  which  is  where  you're 
 at.  You  want  to  make  sure  the  most 
 important  seating  sections  are  accounted 
 for. 
 All 
 right,  on  the  inside 
 >> we  are  done.  Trees  are  set.  This  is  what 
 the  preliminary  looks  like.  All  of  these 
 posts  that  are  here  with  tags  on  them 
 represent  our  trees  to  be  installed.  So 
 we  can  make  sure  that  we  are  happy  with 
 placement  of  everything.  As  easy  as 
 picking  up  a  stake  and  moving  it  6  in  to 
 the  left  or  6  in  to  the  right.  This  is 
 the  corner  planting  grouping  here.  So 
 let's  envision  this.  So,  in  this 
 particular  bed,  right  directly  behind  me 
 in  this  corner  is  going  to  be  a  double 
 foxtail  palm.  It's  going  to  pop  up  nice 
 size  back  here.  Directly  to  the  front  is 
 going  to  be  a  triple  bottle  palm.  So, 
 this  is  going  to  be  tall  and  slender. 
 This  is  going  to  be  short  and  chunky. 
 And  then  right  on  either  side  here  and 
 here  is  going  to  be  the  triple  Christmas 
 palms  that  came  from  the  builder's 
 package.  So,  we're  going  to  utilize  them 
 back  into  this  bed.  And  then  envision 
 the  privacy  as  it  pops  in.  So  back  here, 
 these  poles  represent  fishtail  palms.  So 
 a  nice  backdrop  of  fishtail  palms  on 
 this  side  and  a  nice  backdrop  of 
 fishtail  palms  on  the  opposite  side 
 along  the  fenced  area  there.  That  means 
 bye-bye  neighbors.  That  means  it's 
 really  going  to  have  nice  and  a  peaceful 
 space,  especially  if  the  neighbor  next 
 door  is  going  to  have  a  pool  area.  This 
 is  the  design  process.  This  is  exactly 
 what  I  went  through  and  discussed  with 
 my  clients.  We  went  through  photos.  We 
 went  through  images.  We  talked  about 
 sight  lines.  We  did  all  of  this  in 
 preparation  for  today  for  this  week.  So 
 that  way  my  clients  can  get  a  good 
 visual  of  everything  that's  in  the 
 space.  I  will  pop  in  the  rendering  right 
 here  so  you  can  kind  of  see  exactly  what 
 we're  working  off  of,  what  the  new 
 landscape's  going  to  look  like. 
 All right,  you  guys.  So,  we  are  here. 
 We're  at  one  of  the  nurseries  that  we're 
 picking  material  up  for  the  job  that  we 
 are  on  today.  And  it's  one  of  my 
 favorite  parts  and  it's  probably  one 
 thing  that  I  would  say  that's  crucially 
 important.  If  you  guys  are  working  with 
 a  landscape  designer  or  a  landscape 
 contractor,  make  sure  that  they  are 
 actually  tagging  your  material.  They're 
 going  to  the  nursery  and  they're  picking 
 that  up.  They're  going to  make  sure  they 
 pick  the  prettiest  plant  in  a  batch,  the 
 prettiest  tree  in  a  batch.  You  know, 
 it's  just  like  going  Christmas  tree 
 shopping.  You're  looking  for  the  right 
 tree  for  the  right  place  and  and  making 
 sure  it's  turned.  It  looks  just  stunning 
 in  all  directions.  what  I  have  imagined. 
 You  know,  I  want  to  make  sure  that  I 
 have  real  thick  grouping  on  one  side  and 
 a  little  bit  more  of  an  angular  narrow 
 in  another  section.  So,  when  I'm  looking 
 for  plants  and  trees,  I'm  kind  of  trying 
 to  match  the  puzzle  pieces  to  go  into 
 the  spaces  that  I'm  looking  for.  My 
 clients  will  say  to  me,  "Oh  my  goodness, 
 I  had  no  idea  that  you  were  going  to  be 
 on  the  job  site.  I  had  no  idea  that 
 you're  going to  be  setting  the  poles.  I 
 had  no  idea  that  you're  going  to  be  out 
 there  marking  paint  for  the  guys  to  do 
 the  actual  install."  You  want  to  find  a 
 company  who's  going  to  either  be  on  site 
 to  make  sure  that  vision  comes  to  life 
 for  you.  You  want  to  make  sure  that  they 
 have  a  good  team  behind  them  so  that  the 
 job  goes  seamlessly.  And  then  you  want 
 to  make  sure  that  you  have  a  person 
 tagging  your  material,  making  sure  that 
 you're  getting  the  best  in  the  crop.  So 
 that  way  everything  pulls  together  and 
 you  get  not  just  what  you  pay  for,  but 
 you  get  that  dream  garden  that  you're 
 looking  for.  Those  are  just  some  tips 
 that  I  would  be  looking  for  if  I  were 
 looking  for  a  contractor  for  my  space. 
 All  right,  so  this  yes, 
 this 
 no.  All  right,  you  guys.  So,  we  are  back 
 in  our  office.  I  just  finished  up  a 
 virtual  consult.  It  was  fabulous.  I  got 
 to  speak  with  Chris,  kind  of  walk 
 through  his  front  yard  designs.  He  had 
 one  general  angle  that  he  was  very,  very 
 focused  on  wanting  to  create  something 
 with  some  impact  there.  He  had  a  tree 
 that  died,  so  he  wanted  to  replace  it 
 with  something  that  had  some  ump.  What 
 we  talked  about  was  creating  a  clean 
 line  landscape.  It  was  one  image  he 
 wanted  to  look  at,  one  actual  location. 
 And  so  I  was  actually  able  to  take  that, 
 superimpose  it  into  my  program  during 
 our  hour  meeting  and  overlay  the  plants 
 and  trees  and  the  landscape  into  that 
 space.  So  as  we  were  talking,  we  were  we 
 were  adding  it  in.  So  he  got  a  good 
 visual  of  what  that  looks  like.  This  is 
 the  area  in  question  here  that  he  has 
 some  concerns  over.  You  can  see  there  is 
 a  big  empty  hole  here  where  a  previous 
 Canary  Island  date  palm  had  died.  Got  a 
 nice  pygmy  palm  this  corner  and  a 
 foxtail  palm  over  here.  So,  what  was 
 missing  is  right  here  in  this  spot  to 
 have  some  impact.  Now,  we  couldn't  do  it 
 in  this  area  because  of  some  underground 
 pipes  and  a  propane  tank.  So,  we  brought 
 the  bed  forward  down  into  this  area.  And 
 that's  what  we're  going  to  look  at  now. 
 And  then  Chris  loved  the  idea  of 
 complenting  the  foxtail  to  the  back  with 
 three  additional  foxtails  to  the  front, 
 creating  a  nice  big  tropical  island. 
 Very  clean  line,  but  definitely  has  some 
 vertical  impact.  So,  we  have  the  foxtail 
 palms  here  that  are  going  to  get  a  great 
 size.  Three  pygmy  date  palms  underneath 
 that  are  going  to  give  him  the  coverage 
 he  kind  of  wants.  He  just  all  this  glass 
 and  windows  and  everything  that's  here 
 for  a  very  busy  street.  He  wanted  some 
 kind  of  a  little  bit  of  privacy,  a 
 little  bit  of  coverage  from  all  of  that. 
 So,  this  is  going  to  do  a  great  job  of 
 offering  a  kind  of  a  palm  frrawn  type  of 
 wall  and  kind  of  like  a  nice  floating 
 island  in  this  front  area.  We  brought  in 
 some  fals  agave  to  give  it  some  accents. 
 A  little  bit  of  fakahhatche  grass  on  the 
 corner  to  soften  it.  And  you  guys  can 
 see  the  mix  of  croins  and  exoras  and 
 very  nice  soft  clean  mix  at  the  bottom. 
 He  is  going  to  move  forward.  He's  going 
 to  pick  up  this  material  and  install  it 
 and  it's  going  to  be  a  nice  island  that 
 he's  able  to  take  away.  And  this  was  all 
 done  in  today's  virtual  console.  What  I 
 love  the  most  about  this  whole  thing  is 
 I  do  get  to  share  my  expertise  of  all  of 
 these  years  being  in  business,  you  know, 
 but  I  also  get  to  share  with  my 
 mistakes,  you  know,  it's  like  we've  all 
 been  there.  There's  always  an  issue  with 
 a  a  propane  tank  in  the  wrong  spot  or  a 
 septic  system  that  you're  dealing  with 
 or  whatever  it  might  be  that  just  really 
 might  be  troubling  you  about  your 
 particular  area  of  this  garden.  And  it 
 might  not  be  an  area  that  you  need  to 
 have  some  big  master  plan  or  have  an 
 architect  or  a  designer  come  and  take  a 
 look  at  this  space.  It  just  might  be 
 that  little  problem  child,  that  little 
 problem  corner  in  your  garden.  So,  it's 
 just  been  a  fun  thing  to  do  face  to 
 face.  We're  going  to  get  into  the  last 
 phase  of  our  day,  which  is  the  planning 
 section,  and  that  is  where  Bryce  comes 
 in.  We  have  made  it  to  the  end  of  our 
 day.  This  is  the  time  where  it  gets  down 
 to  the  brass  tax,  where  it  gets  really, 
 really  serious.  This  is  important  stuff 
 right  now.  This  is  where  the  plans  come 
 together.  Bryce  gathers  all  the 
 information  for  our  landscape  design. 
 So,  I  am  on  site  for  our  landscape 
 design  installation.  Bryce  handles  all 
 the  collection  of  the  information  for 
 our  designonly  service.  He  meets  with  a 
 client  in  person.  He  video  records  the 
 conversation,  all  of  the  questions  that 
 he  knows  to  ask  about  the  specific 
 space.  All  of  that's  being  recorded. 
 We'll  review  those  recordings.  We'll 
 review  the  discussion.  And  then  I 
 prepare  the  renderings  for  the  space.  I 
 lay  everything  out  after  gathering  all 
 that  information  and  then  pass  that  over 
 to  him.  and  he  does  the  detailed  stuff. 
 >> So,  just  like  mom  said,  this  is  her 
 doing,  this  is  mine.  I  always  say  that 
 this  is  the  visual  and  then  this  is  the 
 actually  scaled  up  version.  And  I  try  to 
 make  it  a  map  so  it's  just  pretty  much 
 easy  to  follow  as  possible.  And  what  I 
 have  is  the  common  name  with  the  amount 
 and  then  a  little  call  out  that  goes 
 right  to  it.  If  you  want  to  hand  this  to 
 your  installer  or  you  wanted  to  do  it 
 yourself,  it's  pretty  easy  to  follow. 
 And  I  also  have  a  little  legend  right 
 here  where  it  has  the  common  name,  the 
 quantity,  and  the  size  or  if  it's 
 already  existing  in  the  property.  When  I 
 first  met  with  Eugene,  he  was  really 
 wanting  a  tropical  vibe.  And  I  feel  like 
 we  accomplished  that  for  him.  She 
 literally  filled  up  everything  in  his 
 backyard.  It  was  clear  that  he  wanted  no 
 grass.  And  I  think  she  accomplished  that 
 pretty  well.  And  after  she's  done  with 
 both  of  these  renderings,  all  it  is  is 
 my  job  to  translate  this  onto  a  map.  So, 
 I  guess  you  guys  can  see  what  a  joint 
 effort  this  is.  We  fine-tune  what  we 
 need  to.  We  really,  really  play  really 
 well  off  of  each  other.  And  I  think 
 that's  probably  one  of  the  best  parts  of 
 my  job  is  that  I  get  to  work  with  my 
 family.  If  it's  not  Bryce,  it's 
 chitchatting  with  Marissa  about  this  or 
 that.  And  of  course,  my  husband  is  on 
 the  job  site,  so  we  have  plenty  of  that 
 unified  little  group  that  we  have 
 together.  And  I  hope  you  guys  enjoy  just 
 kind  of  seeing  what  we  go  through  in  a 
 day.  Now,  is  there  some  drama  sometimes? 
 Absolutely.  Sometimes  we'll  hit  a  pipe 
 or  sometimes  we'll  hit  a  cable  line  or 
 or  something  like  that  where  it's  like 
 ah  been  doing  this  so  long  that  we  kind 
 of  worked  the  kinks  out  and  then  now 
 sharing  it  with  a  new  generation  coming 
 in.  He's  fabulous  at  the  CADS  who  really 
 lays  it  out  and  I  love  how  he  goes 
 through  with  our  clients  and  just  shares 
 with  them  with  the  ruler  and  say,  "Okay, 
 this  is  exactly  how  to  set  this  up  and 
 line  this  up  just  like  if  they  were  a 
 landscaper  doing  it  for  20  years."  We 
 give  everybody  a  care  schedule.  So,  all 
 the  plants  and  trees  that  we  install,  we 
 leave  our  clients  with  a  complete  list 
 of  a  picture  of  the  plant  with  a 
 paragraph  or  two  of  how  to  take  care  of 
 it,  how  to  maintain  it,  when  to  trim  it, 
 when  to  fertilize  it.  And  that  goes  with 
 the  installations  and  with  our  design 
 service,  too,  because  I  think  that 
 that's  a  big  part  that  kind  of  gets 
 missed.  Everything  will  be  so  good  and 
 so  easy  the  first  year,  and  then  we  get 
 a  drought  or  then  we  get  too  much  rain 
 and  and  things  might  have  some  issues, 
 and  there's  some  questions  on,  okay, 
 what  do  I  do  in  this  situation  or  what 
 do  I  do  in  that?  So  giving  as  much 
 insight  as  possible  I  think  has  been 
 huge.  Bryce  has  added  in  even  more  of 
 that  with  the  cabs. 
 >> Try  to  be  as  helpful  as  possible. 
 >> Yeah.  Yeah.  Because  it  it  it  does  it's 
 all  about  getting  our  clients  from  point 
 A  to  point  B.  And  that  is  a  beautiful 
 garden.  And  so  whatever  way  that  we  can 
 do  that  with  as  much  information  as  we 
 can  gather  and  give.  I  hope  you  guys 
 enjoyed  watching  today's  video  and

 >> a  little  bit  of  creating  something  every

 I  have  been  talking  about  this  for 
 months  and  the  day  is  finally  here. 
 [Music] 
 We  are  putting  a  flag  stone  pathway  into 
 our  back  garden.  We're  going  to  walk  you 
 through  the  process.  We  have  our  handy 
 dandy  installation  team  here  to  help  us, 
 but  I'm  going  to  kind  of  share  with  you 
 everything  right  along  the  way  and  then 
 of  course  costs  involved  in  doing  this. 
 So,  if  you  guys  are  thinking  about  doing 
 this  for  yourself,  I'm  hoping  by  the  end 
 of  today's  video,  you  will  be  able  to 
 design  and  install  your  flagstone 
 pathway  to  perfection.  Please  be  sure  to 
 like  and  subscribe  if  this  is  the  kind 
 of  content  that  you  guys  like  to  see. 
 And  we  will  see  you  guys  every  single 
 weekend  as  we  post  a  video.  Just  like 
 everybody  else,  we  had  grass  in  our 
 backyard.  It  just  didn't  hold  up  well. 
 Between  the  filtered  light  that  we  had 
 to  work  with  here,  you  know,  the 
 constant  rains  that  we  have  here  in 
 Florida,  it  tended  to  be  more  mushy  than 
 anything  else.  We  just  knew  that  budgets 
 weren't  going  to  quite  allow  for  a  flag 
 stone  pathway  right  away.  So,  what  we 
 did  do  was  we  did  remove  the  sod.  That 
 was  our  first  phase.  Our  next  phase  was 
 bringing  in  some  edging.  So,  we  used 
 edging  on  both  sides  and  that  made  sure 
 to  secure  the  rock  in  place.  It  locked 
 our  pathway  in  place  for  now.  Filled 
 this  with  Tahesian  gray  granite.  You 
 guys  know  how  much  I  love  my  Tahesian 
 gray  granite.  Knowing  that  we're  going 
 to  get  to  the  point  of  doing  flag  stone. 
 So,  the  first  thing  that  you're  going  to 
 want  to  do  when  you're  deciding  on  where 
 to  lay  your  flag  stone  and  how  you  want 
 that  to  come  about  is  get  extension  cord 
 or  garden  hose  or  whatever  you  have  on 
 hand  and  outline  that  pathway  area.  So, 
 that's  exactly  where  we  started.  So,  I 
 know  I  didn't  want  a  straight  pathway. 
 Now,  you  can  absolutely  do  that  and  it 
 would  look  fine.  I  needed  some  areas  for 
 it  to  bow  out.  It  won't  make  sense  just 
 yet,  but  in  the  next  phase  it  will 
 because  I'm  going  to  create  little 
 pockets  of  groupings.  of  boulders  with 
 maybe  some  foxtail  agave  or  or  maybe 
 it's  a  bird  bath.  The  reasons  for  that 
 pathway  to  have  that  meandering  feel. 
 And  if  you  do  too  much  of  this  going  on 
 with  a  pathway  and  there's  no  reason 
 why,  then  you  tend  to  want  to  take  that 
 straight  and  narrow  path.  And  when 
 you're  looking  down  your  pathway,  you 
 see  the  pathway  kind  of  meander  through 
 here,  but  that  block  in  your  vision  does 
 such  a  good  eye  to  draw  you  further 
 down.  So  that's  why  I  love  curves.  I 
 love  what  they  do.  And  so  I'm  hoping 
 that  this  turns  out  just  like  that.  So, 
 in  breaking  down  the  costs  of  what 
 you're  going  to  kind  of  need  for  flag 
 stone,  you're  going  to  want  to  make  sure 
 that  you  have  obviously  enough  materials 
 where  it's  you're  not  hopping  from  step 
 to  step  to  step.  Now,  I  like  a  loose 
 fitting  flag  stone.  It  doesn't  need  to 
 be  fully  pieced  together.  I  like  it 
 where  it's  set  in  gravel.  So,  you  get  a 
 lot  of  flag  stone  for  the  money,  I 
 guess,  when  you  do  it  that  way.  Or  I 
 kind  of  want  almost  like  a  flag  stone 
 stepping  stone  pathway.  And  then  we're 
 going  to  take  the  rock  and  bunch  it 
 right  back  up  to  it.  And  that  way  it's 
 actually  set  in  that  stone.  So  you  kind 
 of  see  I  have  a  little  example  of  it 
 here.  This  is  a  very  small  path  that 
 leads  to  my  pond  here.  It's  just  nice 
 and  easy  to  step  on.  I  have  a  big  piece 
 here,  a  couple  small  pieces  here  for 
 individual  footing  where  it's  just  a 
 nice  easy  gradual  path.  If  I  create  the 
 curves  like  you  see  here  end  up  being  68 
 ft  that  I'm  working  with.  I  am  going  to 
 use  one  pallet  of  flag  stone.  You  want 
 to  make  sure  when  you're  shopping  for 
 flag  stone  pallets  or  pieces  that  you 
 have  multiple  sizes.  You  want  some  big 
 sizes.  You  want  some  small  sizes.  A  lot 
 of  times  when  you  get  a  pallet, 
 sometimes  it'll  have  all  big  pieces  or  a 
 bunch  of  little  small  pieces.  And  that 
 can  be  really  tricky  to  work  with.  You 
 want  some  good  footing,  some  things  that 
 you  can  work  on.  So  having  that 
 combination  is  going  to  be  ideal.  That 
 palette  is  going  to  run  around  $600.  So 
 it  can  be  a  bit  pricey.  We're  going  to 
 use  the  tan  stone.  It's  called  buff  and 
 color.  So  it  has  kind  of  some  tans,  a 
 little  bit  of  grays  in  there.  The 
 greystone  is  a  little  bit  more 
 expensive.  that  it's  about  $100  more  per 
 pallet,  but  I  wanted  some  variation 
 because  I  have  so  much  of  this 
 Greystone,  Tennessee  field  stone 
 throughout  the  rest  of  my  garden.  So,  I 
 thought,  let  me  bring  in  the  the  little 
 lesser  expensive  product  and  I  think 
 it's  going  to  blend  really  well.  And 
 then,  of  course,  we  already  have  the 
 gray  rock,  giving  me  a  little  bit  more 
 contrast  than  just  strictly  gray  on 
 gray.  And  the  next  thing  that  you're 
 going  to  need  is  you're  going  to  need 
 leveling  material.  Now,  some  people  do 
 it  with  sand.  And  you  can  absolutely 
 level  a  piece  of  flag  stone  with  sand  or 
 stepping  stones  with  sand,  but  I  really 
 love  the  cement  millings.  You'll  get  it 
 pretty  much  the  same  place  that  you  get 
 the  flag  stone  from.  It's  a  lot  cheaper 
 and  it  hardens  and  packs  down  after  a 
 few  rains.  So,  I  like  to  use  that 
 because  I  can  really  get  a  good  base  for 
 my  flag  stone.  Now,  once  you  do  that  and 
 you  connect  and  do  that  fully  through 
 the  whole  pathway,  then  after,  I  don't 
 know,  seven  or  eight  rains,  you're  going 
 to  notice  cement  starts  to  just  harden 
 all  the  way  around  the  stone.  It  will 
 not  turn  into  grout.  It  will  not  be  a 
 solid  surface,  but  it  does  a  great  job 
 of  packing  an  area,  not  making  the  flag 
 stone  itself  movable,  which  is  exactly 
 what  you  want  in  a  natural  flagstone 
 path.  A  half  a  yard,  which  is  what  we're 
 going  to  use  here,  cost  me  $48.  It's 
 definitely  worth  worth  the  cost 
 involved.  When  I  start  with  a  pathway 
 opening,  I  tend  to  really  like  to  make  a 
 nice  broad  wide  opening,  almost  like 
 just  a  grand  entrance  to  a  space. 
 Wherever  we  end,  I'll  end  it  with  that 
 same  wide  opening,  sometimes  even  wider, 
 just  to  kind  of  give  you  a  welcoming 
 feel  to  this  walkway  space.  Now,  this 
 particular  spot  right  here  is  almost 
 like  a  direct  focal  point  from  my  coffee 
 area,  my  seating  section  over  there.  So, 
 I  definitely  wanted  a  little  bit  of  room 
 to  make  this  interesting.  maybe  a  little 
 bird  bath  that  is  actually  a  bubbling 
 bird  bath  of  some  sort.  But  I  know  that 
 I  needed  space,  so  I  didn't  want  to 
 eliminate  by  creating  a  straight  pathway 
 leading  into  this  space  here.  Very 
 similar  to  how  they  do  the  botanical 
 gardens.  And  that's  kind  of  what  I  I 
 love  to  mimic  in  my  own  space.  When  you 
 go  to  resorts,  when  you  go  to  botanical 
 gardens  and  you're  walking  through  those 
 pathways,  there's  almost  something  for 
 you  to  visit.  Every  single  step  that  you 
 take,  like  you're  seeing  this,  and  this 
 is  kind  of  popping  out,  meander  to  the 
 left  a  little  bit  and  then  meander  to 
 the  right  a  little  bit.  want  to  get  a 
 good  visual  of  all  of  those  little 
 intricate  things  that  are  right  along 
 the  way.  So,  what  you  guys  were  watching 
 was  my  crew  dry  setting  the  flag  stone. 
 You  know,  you  know  the  direction,  you 
 know  the  angles  that  you're  going  to  go 
 in.  Go  ahead  and  start  laying  out  some 
 of  the  stones.  Start  piecing  it  together 
 like  your  little  puzzle  pieces.  Now,  I 
 like  to  do  this  more  of  a  casual  flag 
 stone  so  that  everything  is  not 
 intertwining.  There  are  no  cuts  that  are 
 made.  Do  you  want  it  a  little  bit  busier 
 pattern  with  some  smaller  pieces?  Do  you 
 have  some  bigger  chunks  that  you  know 
 that  you're  going  to  work  with?  whatever 
 that  might  be.  Kind  of  get  that  laid 
 out,  take  a  good  look,  step  back,  make 
 sure  you  like  the  pattern,  and  then 
 after  that,  walk  up  and  down  it  a  few 
 times.  I  want  to  be  able  to  walk  through 
 this  pathway  in  high  heels  if  I  have  to. 
 You  know,  I  want  to  be  able  to  make  sure 
 that  I  have  some  sure  footing  all  the 
 way  through.  If  I  feel  like  I'm  doing 
 like  a  stutter  step  because  one 
 flagstone  piece  is  too  small,  then  you 
 want  to  make  sure  to  adjust  that  at  that 
 point.  So  that  way  you're  not  regretting 
 that  single  step  halfway  through  every 
 single  time  you  walk  down  the  pathway. 
 Set  the  flag  stone  in  place.  Use  a 
 mallet  or  rubber  hammer.  Make  sure  it's 
 really  wedged  in  there  nice  and  tight 
 before  you  start  sealing  those  joints 
 back  with  rock.  You'll  notice  that  these 
 stones  are  different  sizes,  different 
 thicknesses.  And  that's  part  of  the 
 natural  beauty  of  flag  stone  is 
 nothing's  even  and  part  of  the 
 frustration.  So  he'll  level  this  out.  So 
 this  one  will  get  less  sand.  This  one 
 will  get  more  sand.  So  you're  doing  a 
 dry  set  on  that.  kind  of  keep  that  in 
 mind  so  you  kind  of  know  maybe  a  bigger 
 size  but  definitely  thinner.  So  you  want 
 to  make  sure  that  you  raise  it  on  the 
 kind  of  levels  and  that's  another  reason 
 why  they're  doing  this  in  segments.  By 
 doing  them  as  an  individual  grouping, 
 you're  really  saving  yourself  a  lot  of 
 time  and  you're  also  able  to  keep  that 
 pattern  nice  and  tight.  I'm  going  to 
 list  all  of  the  materials  here  for  you 
 guys.  So  screenshot  this  bad  boy  and 
 hopefully  it'll  help  you  with  your 
 shopping  list  of  gathering.  You're  going 
 to  need  a  rubber  mallet,  wheelbarrel,  a 
 tamper.  You're  going  to  need  all  of  that 
 just  to  start  this  project.  So  the  next 
 thing  you're  going  to  want  to  do  is 
 decide  on  the  type  of  edging  that  you're 
 going  to  use.  Whether  you're  going  to  do 
 the  aluminum  alloy  edging,  I  love  to  use 
 that  with  pathways.  You're  going  to  use 
 the  buta  edging.  You  can  use  something 
 really,  really  natural  like  I  have  the 
 stone  work  here.  So  whatever  that  might 
 be,  decide  on  that.  Gather  that  material 
 in  place.  Make  sure  you  have  a  good 
 linear  measurement  for  that  space.  So 
 that  way  you  can  really  kind  of  just 
 start  getting  that  in  place.  That's 
 going  to  hold  everything  together.  So  it 
 is  the  structure.  It  is  the  bones  of 
 getting  this  in.  Then  you're  going to 
 want  to  make  sure  that  you  have  your 
 weed  barrier  fabric  down  below.  Nicely 
 laid  on  solid  tamped  down  soil  depending 
 on  the  stage  that  you're  in.  I  picked  my 
 stone  next  because  that  was  where  my 
 budget  allowed  before  I  did  the  flag 
 stone.  I  have  Tahesian  gray  granite.  I 
 have  the  inch  and  a  half  here.  What's  a 
 little  bit  nicer  to  use  is  the  3/4  in  or 
 the  half  inch.  It's  a  little  bit  smaller 
 stone.  Knits  together  really  well.  Easy 
 to  walk  on  between  the  grooves  of  the 
 flag  stone.  So  it  can  allow  you  to  pull 
 the  flag  stone  a  little  bit  closer. 
 However,  in  my  situation,  this  area  gets 
 good  rain.  It's  a  drainage  easement.  So, 
 if  we  get  our  hurricanes,  we  get  water 
 in  this  little  alley  here.  So,  if  that 
 is  your  situation,  go  with  a  bigger 
 stone.  It  will  stay  put.  But  if  it's  the 
 beauty  and  you  have  a  nice  clean  area  to 
 work  with,  go  with  the  small  stone.  That 
 little  stone  joints  really  well 
 together.  Makes  for  a  perfect  walkway 
 space.  And  I  love  the  crunch  it  gives 
 when  you're  walking  through  an  area.  So, 
 next  on  the  materials  list  is  pick  your 
 flag  stone  pieces.  Big  pieces,  little 
 pieces.  Pick  a  nice  mixture  and  make 
 sure  that  you  get  a  nice  mix  into  your 
 palette.  Sometimes  the  pallets  are 
 already  prepalized  and  they  won't  let 
 you  separate  it  and  sometimes  they  will. 
 So  ask  that  question  because  if  you  can 
 get  a  nice  mix,  that's  really  what 
 you're  going to  need  so  you  don't  have 
 too  much  of  one  thing  and  it  looks  like 
 a  stepping  stone  pathway  with  just  using 
 flag  stone.  This  is  natural  material.  We 
 want  it  to  look  natural.  We  want  it  to 
 look  organic.  So  pick  something  that's 
 going  to  give  you  that  kind  of  feel, 
 that  kind  of  vibe.  So  obviously  one  of 
 the  most  important  things  is  what  the 
 flag  stone  is  going  to  sit  on  which  is 
 your  millings.  Whether  it  is  your 
 setting  sand  or  it  is  the  crushed 
 concrete  like  I  used  or  pa  millings 
 whatever  you  have  or  whatever  your  stone 
 yard  has  that  you're  going  to  work  with. 
 You  want  to  make  sure  that  that  is 
 something  that  you  have  in  your 
 wheelbarrow  with  a  shovel  right  at  your 
 fingertips  because  you're  going  to  set 
 that  as  you  work.  So  you're  going  to 
 pull  these  sections  out,  put  that 
 setting  stone  in  depending  on  the 
 heights  of  your  pavers.  Put  that  back  in 
 and  do  a  section  at  a  time.  So,  you're 
 going to  need  that  on  hand  all  the  time. 
 Now,  if  you  don't  have  a  wheelbarrow,  a 
 lot  of  times  the  stone  yards  will  have 
 that  exact  same  product  in  bags.  So,  you 
 can  put  them  in  an  individual  bags  and 
 just  line  the  bags  up  along  the  pathway. 
 So,  you  can  easily  cut  into  them  and 
 just  like  do  a  little  a  small  shovel  and 
 put  them  in  and  then  tamp  them  into 
 place.  So,  if  you're  doing  this  yourself 
 as  a  DIYer,  you  you  can  easily  work  with 
 each  piece  on  its  own.  So  you  can  pick 
 this  up,  move  this  around,  adjust  this 
 to  whatever  you  need  to  adjust  it  to  and 
 work  with  that  space.  You  might  need  an 
 extra  hand  with  some  of  those  little 
 bigger  pieces,  but  that's  the  best  part 
 about  Flag  Stone  is  that  you  can  do  it 
 yourself  as  a  nice  walking  pathway. 
 And  it  is  finished,  you  guys.  It  is 
 beautiful.  I  am  absolutely  in  love  with 
 this  space.  Please  let  me  know  what  you 
 guys  think.  I  think  it's  turned  out 
 really  well.  I  think  it's  a  great 
 combination  of  small  and  large  stones. 
 This  is  something  that  I  know  that  my 
 little  size  8  ft  could  fit  and  walk 
 down.  I  could  literally,  like  I  said, 
 walk  down  here  in  heels  because  I 
 totally  have  enough  footing  to  run 
 through  this  path.  And  I  that's  kind  of 
 what  I  wanted.  I  wanted  a  very  nice, 
 comfortable  path  to  just  stroll  down  as 
 I  walk  through  my  garden.  I'm  a  cup  of 
 coffee  drinker,  glass  of  wine  drinker.  I 
 like  feeling  like  I'm  walking  through 
 the  garden  and  enjoying  my  space  like  I 
 enjoy  botanical  garden  or  a  resort 
 garden  or  something  like  that  because 
 nothing  makes  you  feel  more  immersed  in 
 a  garden  setting  than  walking  directly 
 through  it.  You're  up  close  and 
 personal.  You're  checking  in  the  morning 
 who's  blooming,  who's  showing  off.  And 
 you  don't  get  that  unless  you're  down 
 here  down  here  in  the  walkway  enjoying 
 and  it's  right  in  your  face.  It's 
 something  that  you  get  to  really  be  a 
 part  of.  I  never  feel  more  in  the  moment 
 than  when  I'm  walking  through  my  garden 
 on  those  mornings  or  late  evenings. 
 That's  what  I  love  about  gardening 
 because  you  might  not  be  able  to  afford 
 it  all  at  once,  but  if  you  have  the 
 vision  and  you  have  the  patience,  you 
 really  can  create  these  perfect  spaces 
 that  are  just  for  you.  And  I  promise 
 you,  doing  that  makes  you  want  to  go  on 
 vacation  less,  makes  you  want  to  not  hop 
 that  plane,  makes  you  want  to  really 
 make  that  cocktail  and  sit  in  your 
 backyard  space  and  enjoy  your  own 
 environment.  And  I  know  that  it  does 
 that  for  my  clients.  And  speaking  of 
 design,  so  if  you  guys  are  looking  to

 If  you  guys  are  able  to  do  that,  that  is

 resort.  When  you  guys  are  traveling, 
 when  you're  having  those  tropical 
 vacations,  what  soothes  your  soul  the 
 most?  This  is  something  that  I'm  going 
 to  recreate  in  my  own  style,  in  my  own 
 space,  and  that's  ultimately  what  we  all 
 want.  So,  one  thing  that  resorts  and 
 those  kind  of  pricey  uh  restaurants  have

 they  really  know  how  to  sell  that 
 atmosphere  and  that  comes  at  a  premium 
 for  all  of  us.  Use  some  soft  silhouette

 much  you  enjoy  just  cooking  that  steak 
 out  in  your  backyard.  You  know,  bringing 
 that  ambiance  to  your  backyard  space  and 
 having  dinner  outside.  I'm  going  to 
 share  with  you  some  serious  lighting 
 options.  The  first  one  is  overhead 
 lighting.  Now,  I  know  not  all  of  us  can 
 have  chandeliers  and  big  lights.  Mix 
 your  twinkle  lights  in.  Mix  your  little 
 Christmas  lights  in.  I  have  been  through 
 several  different  lighting  options.  This 
 is  one  of  my  favorite  because  you  get  so 
 many  lights  on  one  GFI  outlet.  If  you 
 have  overhead  structures,  a  tiki  hut,  an 
 overhead  cabana,  even  if  it's  umbrella 
 lighting,  wrap  these  bad  boys  up.  Really 
 kind  of  give  you  that  twinkle  fairy 
 light  overhead  rooftop  kind  of  feel  that 
 the  restaurants  offer  you  when  you're 
 outdoor  dining.  Another  area  that  I  have 
 them  in  is  along  my  walkway.  I've  kind 
 of  just  kind  of  meandered  them  through 
 all  natural  along  the  walkway  to  really 
 offer  that  little  bit  of  twinkle  right 
 through  the  greenery  of  the  garden.  Now, 
 I've  also  mix  them  with  cafe  lights 
 because  if  you  have  little  lights  and 
 you  have  big  lights  and  you  have  a 
 combination  of  it,  it  just  offers  so 
 much  ambiance.  I  chose  the  brighten  for 
 a  reason.  I  like  that  they  offer 
 different  colors.  So,  for  fall,  for 
 spring,  for  Fourth  of  July,  for  all  of 
 the  holidays,  I  like  to  have  one  set  of 
 lighting  instead  of  having  to  do  a  bunch 
 of  different  decorations.  However,  I 
 know  that  a  lot  of  people  use  lighting 
 as  their  outdoor  kind  of  overhead 
 structures,  but  don't  sleep  on  putting 
 them  in  the  garden.  I  have  155  ft  of 
 cafe  lights  that  run  through  the  middle 
 of  my  burm.  It  looks  like  little 
 fireflies  light  up  that  backyard  space 
 so  that  way  it's  not  directly  overhead. 
 It's  cast  out  into  the  shadows  of  the 
 palm  frrons  and  the  different  leaf 
 structures.  And  those  of  you  guys  who 
 think  that  gosh,  is  that  going  to  break

 But  now  for  the  last  tip  for  today,  find 
 a  key  feature.  Now,  take  your  time  with 
 this  because  it  took  me  a  little  while 
 to  find  what  I  wanted  to  become  a  focal 
 point.  It  does  not  have  to  be  big.  It 
 can  be  small  like  a  ponytail  palm,  like 
 a  desert  rose.  It  does  not  have  to  be 
 anything  large,  but  something 
 interesting,  something  you  want  to 
 showcase  and  then  you  can  incorporate 
 small  things  after  that.  So,  I  know 
 necessarily  this  might  not  be  the 
 cheapest  thing  in  the  garden  center. 
 However,  if  you  get  it  young  in  a  small 
 pot,  then  you  know  it's  going  to  be 
 large  and  beautiful  and  interesting  as 
 it  gets  some  size  to  it.  Like  this  girl 
 behind  me.  This  Madagascar  palm  was  $120 
 when  I  got  her.  I  got  her  from  a  garden 
 center.  She  didn't  have  all  of  these 
 cool  sprawling  trunks,  but  I  knew  she 
 was  going  to  be  a  key  feature  in  my 
 garden.  So,  she  got  forefront  up  close 
 VIP  status  kind  of  feel  because  I  knew 
 that  I  love  the  look  of  this  tree.  All 
 the  pictures  I've  seen  of  them  are  just 
 awesome.  I  made  a  perfect  place  for  her. 
 I  put  her  in  a  rock  garden.  I  lifted  her 
 up  out  of  the  swale  so  she  has  more 
 drainage.  But  I  made  sure  that  she  was 
 going to  be  something  that  I  not  only 
 saw  from  my  seating  section,  my  favorite 
 seating  section,  but  I  saw  from  inside 
 my  kitchen  area.  I  saw  from  where  I  do 
 the  dishes.  I  saw  from  my  seating 
 section  inside.  I  made  sure  that  she  was 
 in  that  spot  that  drew  me  out  into  the 
 garden.  And  that's  what  these  key  things 
 are  about.  From  one  window  in  your  house 
 or  right  from  the  front  door  when  you 
 walk  in  and  put  that  thing  right  there 
 for  front  right  in  your  garden.  Make 
 that  the  focal  point  that  you  build 
 everything  around.  That's  exactly  what 
 this  gal  does  in  my  garden.  Thank  you 
 guys  for  watching.  If  you  enjoyed

 to  bring  indoors.  Thank  you  so  much. 
 Take  care.  I  will  see  you  guys  next

 subscribe.  Hit  that  little  notification 
 bell.  Bryce  and  I  post  every  single

 just  completed.  As  you  guys  know,  your

 share  with  you,  but  we  also  offer  design 
 services  only.  And  we  offer  virtual 
 consults.  If  you're  looking  to  have  some 
 work  done,  please  reach  out  to  us.  But 
 for  now,  let's  kind  of  just  jump  into 
 some  of  these  cool  features.  So,  when  I 
 get  to  most  homes,  I'm  usually  in  after
