 construction  is  done  and  I'm  just 
 dealing  with  what's  left  over.  In  this 
 particular  situation,  I  got  to  come  in  a 
 little  bit  earlier.  A  lot  of  the 
 planning  was  already  done  where  the 
 clients  have  decided  they  definitely 
 wanted  some  planters.  They  definitely 
 wanted  a  water  feature.  Now,  what  they 
 did  is  they  have  a  gorgeous  turf  along 
 this  linear  section,  which  in  most  cases 
 around  a  pool  is  kind  of  either  wasted 
 space  or  become  like  for  loungers.  Her 
 husband's  a  big  golfer,  so  encourages 
 them  to  come  out,  do  a  little  putt  putt 
 if  they  want.  This  is  just  kind  of  a 
 nice  linear  space  to  encourage,  you 
 know,  games  when  you're  out  here  in  the 
 pool  area,  in  the  pool  space,  and  you're 
 out  of  the  elements.  You're  out  of  the 
 bugs.  So,  it's  kind  of  a  nice  feel.  They 
 went  ahead  and  put  in  the  taller  pool 
 screen.  I  love  how  open  and  airy  this 
 feels.  I  don't  feel  like  they  lost  much, 
 if  any,  light.  It  just  feels  just  like  a 
 big  giant  room,  a  giant  outdoor  room  in 
 here.  And  then  they  left  me  with  some 
 planter  space  back  here.  They're  like, 
 "Okay,  this  whole  space  back  here  is 
 yours  to  do  what  you  want  to  do  with." 
 Which,  as  you  can  see,  it's  kind  of 
 right  up  my  alley.  So,  that's  exactly 
 what  we  did.  Now,  they  definitely  wanted 
 this  large  water  feature  here.  They  went 
 with  something  that  would  be  a  little 
 bit  of  a  softer  look.  They  went  with 
 Tennessee  Fieldstone  waterfall.  That 
 would  kind  of  give  this  area  a  little 
 bit  of  a  rustic  vibe,  which  I  think  is  a 
 cool  switch  because  most  of  my  water 
 features  around  pool  areas  usually 
 happen  to  be  the  wall  water  feature,  the 
 spouts  or  the  bowls  or  whatnot.  So,  I 
 think  this  is  kind  of  a  nice  touch  and 
 it  kind  of  really  does  add  a  little  bit 
 of  that  rustic  charm  to  a  very  serene 
 back  space.  So,  since  they  had  that 
 already  in  place,  I  went  ahead  and 
 incorporated  stone  beds  in  this  area.  We 
 chose  an  Indian  River  Creek  rock  that  I 
 think  ties  in  nice  with  the  pool 
 borders.  The  colors  complement  super 
 well.  And  then  I  tucked  in  some 
 Tennessee  field  stone  within  the 
 planters  just  to  kind  of,  you  know,  pay 
 homage  to  the  waterfall  itself.  And  I 
 think  that  that  really  tied  in  with  that 
 tropical  look.  And  I  think  that's  so 
 great  how  you  can  mix  that  kind  of 
 mountainous  kind  of  stone  feel  with  the 
 tropical  vibe  and  it  still  gives  you  a 
 very  jungle  jungle  vibe.  Directly  behind 
 me  here  is  a  nice  pathway.  I  believe 
 it's  18  in  that  goes  all  the  way  behind 
 connecting  the  two  spaces  so  you  can 
 maintain  from  the  back  side  of  this  pool 
 planter  as  well  as  from  the  front. 
 Probably  be  easier  from  the  back  side. 
 There's  definitely  a  good  maintenance 
 path  back  there.  And  I  love  that  you  can 
 pass  right  through  and  go  to  the  outdoor 
 kitchen  and  the  other  section  of  the 
 patio  over  there.  So  to  me,  this  is  just 
 such  a  really  well-laidout  backyard 
 space.  I  feel  like  it  has  everything 
 that  you  need.  playground  for  adults, 
 beautiful  gardens  to  feel  like  you're  in 
 a  tropical  resort,  a  maintenance  path  to 
 the  back,  entertaining  and  dining  to  the 
 right,  and  then  of  course  everything 
 from  the  inside  right  from  their  front 
 door  looks  out  to  this  back  space.  And 
 then  to  top  it  off,  they  brought  in 
 these  cool  lanterns.  Oh  my  gosh,  you 
 guys,  those  light  up  with  fire  and  go 
 straight  up.  And  then  voila,  this  is 
 just  entertainment  central.  We're  going 
 to  go  through  the  plants  and  trees  like 
 we  normally  do  on  a  garden  tour,  but 
 really  to  me  what  the  star  of  the  show 
 really  is  is  just  the  placement  of 
 everything  that's  here,  the  layout,  and 
 then  of  course,  you  know,  the  plants  and 
 the  trees  always  do  what  they  do,  which 
 is  offer  a  softness  to  a  space.  Really 
 take  this  big  space  from  being  open  and 
 empty  to  nestled  and  retreat  like.  For 
 our  anchor  feature,  I  chose  our  King 
 Alexander  and  I  had  it  just  kind  of  pull 
 forward.  As  you  guys  know,  I  love 
 curves.  So,  having  something  blunt  stop 
 here,  I  was  just  not  having  it.  So,  we 
 were  able  to  curve  this  into  this 
 section  of  the  garden  to  kind  of  wrap  it 
 around  this  gorgeous  curve  of  the  pool 
 area.  And  I  think  it  did  just  the  trick. 
 We've  got  Sanchezia  to  the  back  that  are 
 really  going  to  flush  out  and  be  a 
 gorgeous  four  or  5ft  tall  back  there. 
 Really  nice  and  lush.  And  then  ice  tone 
 croins  on  to  the  front.  Now,  right  now, 
 because  this  is  a  fairly  newly  planted 
 space,  the  Icetone  Croins  are  a  little 
 bit  bigger  than  the  Sanchezia  because 
 they  grow  so  much  slower.  So,  I  brought 
 these  in  at  a  10gon  size.  And  then  the 
 Sanchezia,  they're  super  growers. 
 There's  no  sense  in  spending  the  money 
 and  upping  the  pot  size.  So,  I  got  those 
 in  three  gallons.  So,  in  no  time,  those 
 will  kind  of  catch  up  and  become  a  nice 
 4ft  sea  of  bright  green  and  yellow  color 
 to  the  backdrop,  allowing  these  this 
 perfect  color  of  the  ice  teens  to  really 
 shine.  What  I  love  about  ice  te  croins 
 is  they  really  kind  of  mound  out.  Look 
 at  what  a  nice  kind  of  rounded  look  a 
 croin  can  give.  A  lot  of  them  have  a 
 tendency  to  go  sprawling  and  be  a  little 
 bit  crazy.  These  are  chunky,  tight,  and 
 compact.  This  is  the  perfect  environment 
 for  them.  They  love  the  protection  of 
 what  this  screen  is  offering.  So,  a 
 little  filtered  light  goes  a  long  way 
 with  these  girls.  They  can  be  drama 
 queens.  If  they're  out  in  the  full  sun, 
 they'll  just  be  like,  but  in  here  they 
 love  it.  So  ice  te  croins  from  morning 
 sun,  midday  sun,  but  not  evening  sun. 
 See  this  one  that's  out  in  the  sun  more. 
 Look  how  much  more  color  it  offers.  I 
 mean  that  brightness,  that  multicolored 
 tone  in  those  leaves.  Just  stunning.  And 
 then  this  one  that's  underneath  the  king 
 Alexander.  How  much  coverage  that  that's 
 giving  for  color.  And  look  at  how  dark 
 green  it  is  and  some  of  this  darker 
 foliage  down  below.  I  mean,  it's  just 
 crazy  how  light  changes  the  look  of  a 
 leaf  pattern.  We  used  an  aluminum  alloy 
 edging  to  give  us  a  nice  clean  defined 
 look.  And  I  think  that  it  pairs  just 
 beautifully  as  you  enter  from  clean  zone 
 to  the  jungle.  I  love  how  that  that 
 transition  is  just  so  dramatic.  I  think 
 it  turned  out  so  lovely.  Right  here  is 
 golden  sedum  right  at  the  base.  Then 
 right  over  here  are  my  favorite.  These 
 are  the  Marie  agimas.  These  are  a 
 perfect  little  ground  cover.  These  are 
 what  would  be  on  the  jungle  floor  of  any 
 jungle.  So  these  grow  very  very  slow, 
 stay  very  very  compact,  have  a  gorgeous 
 variegated  leaf  color.  Not  too  bright, 
 not  too  dark,  almost  give  you  more  of  a 
 green  backdrop.  And  so  that  way  you  can 
 pair  it  with  something  more  colorful 
 like  the  ice  tone  croins.  But  I  love  how 
 delicate,  how  small,  how  compact,  and 
 how  easy  care  because  they  grow  so  slow. 
 Trimming  is  pretty  non-existent.  You'll 
 maybe  trim  twice  a  year  on  these  guys.  I 
 wanted  something  very,  very  low 
 maintenance  in  this  particular  spot,  and 
 these  guys  will  do  that  trick.  Another 
 lowmaintenance  plant  is  the  emperialis 
 burmilad.  This  guy  is  more  of  the  green 
 tone.  You  can  see  the  one  that  I  have  at 
 my  house  has  more  purple  to  it.  The 
 green,  this  is  what  it  looks  like  in 
 more  of  a  shaded  environment.  So,  but 
 what  I  wanted  was  something  dynamic  that 
 wouldn't  spread  or  wouldn't  go  to  town 
 in  such  a  small  area.  And  of  course,  as 
 you  guys  know  what  I  love  about  the 
 Imperialis  is  wherever  you  put  them, 
 they  stay.  They'll  grow  3  and  1/2t  by  3 
 and  1/2  wide.  Ideal  for  a  little  spot 
 just  like  this.  So,  these  guys  are 
 framing  the  centerpiece  here,  which  is 
 the  triple  bottle  palm.  You  guys  know 
 how  I  feel  about  the  triple  bottle  palm. 
 This  guy  will  get  14,  15t  tall,  widen 
 out  as  it  branches  up.  Could  you  imagine 
 when  this  guy  gets  over  here  and  the 
 fronds  are  above  the  pool  water  line  and 
 just  going  to  be  stunners  in  this  space. 
 I  cannot  wait  to  see  that  as  that  kind 
 of  unfolds  and  these  trunks  widen  out 
 like  this.  This  one's  going  to  grow  a 
 heck  of  a  lot  slower,  I  guess, 
 unfortunately  because  it  isn't  a 
 planter,  so  there's  not  a  lot  of  room 
 for  roots  to  grow.  Speaking  of  roots, 
 these  trees  that  I  put  in  here  are  soft 
 tip  roots,  what  we  call  courtyard  palms, 
 things  that  are  not  going  to  be  invasive 
 into  the  pool  area.  They're  not  like  a 
 bismar  or  a  royal  palm  or  a  queen  palm, 
 even  a  Christmas  palm.  Those  are  things 
 that  the  roots  can  be  very,  very 
 aggressive.  So,  you  kind  of  want  to  stay 
 away  from  those  so  close  to  the  pool 
 wall  line.  So,  these  are  a  delicate 
 feature,  as  is  all  the  other  small 
 plantings  that  are  here.  So,  this  is 
 definitely  little  planter  approved.  So, 
 the  triple  bottle  palm  is  going  to  be 
 the  anchor  points  to  this  beautiful 
 water  feature.  And  as  you  can  see,  we 
 have  them  on  both  sides.  That  way,  in  no 
 way,  this  waterfall,  it's  the  accent 
 that  it  was  intended  to  be.  We  don't 
 want  it  to  master  the  whole  pool  area. 
 We  don't  want  it  to  be  the  total  focal 
 point  and  everything  else  around  it  to 
 be  so  small  that  it's  the  biggest  guy  in 
 the  room.  It's  supposed  to  be  nestled. 
 It's  supposed  to  be  intimate.  It's 
 supposed  to  be  wrapped  around.  And  I 
 think  that's  what  we  were  trying  to 
 create  here  was  really  to  soften  it.  Let 
 it  be  the  focal  point,  but  soften  it.  I 
 think  it  worked  out.  I  think  it  happens. 
 So,  so  yes,  keep  that  in  mind  if  you've 
 got  a  big  feature,  whatever  that  feature 
 might  be  in  your  own  space.  All right, 
 so  we're  going  to  make  our  way  to  the 
 pool  area.  Now,  what  I  love,  and  if  you 
 guys  can  manage  to  do  this,  give 
 yourself  at least  18  in  behind  your  pool 
 planters  on  the  inside.  I  mean,  look 
 between  the  inside  of  the  screen  and  the 
 pool  planter  here,  connecting  the  two 
 spaces  and  leaving  yourself  an  easy 
 maintenance  pathway  because  again,  it 
 would  be  tough  to  maintain  it  from  the 
 front.  So  that  really  allows  you  to  get 
 into  the  pool  planters  from  the  back 
 side.  So,  and  then  I  love  how  it 
 connects  the  two  spaces  instead  of 
 having  to  go  all  the  way  around  from  the 
 front  if  you're  in  the  back  section.  So 
 on  this  side,  it  is  more  of  a  rinse  and 
 repeat.  You  can  see  how  narrow  this 
 space  is.  I  think  we  had  4  foot  to  work 
 with.  We  have  burl  marks  here.  So  we 
 have  four  burl  marks.  Look  at  how  nice 
 and  open  and  rounded  these  guys  get. 
 Just  so  tropical.  Such  a  perfect  little 
 leafed  plant.  Perfect  for  a  clean  back 
 border  that  doesn't  look  like  a  hedge. 
 So  to  me  this  is  what  I  call  a  tropical 
 hedge.  They  will  create  a  nice  backdrop 
 of  green  to  show  off  color  to  the  front. 
 And  then  of  course  we  have  two 
 imperialis  burmilads  and  then  just 
 aglion  maras  for  the  base  here.  And  then 
 of  course  we  popped  in  some  boulders. 
 And  when  you  guys  pop  in  your  boulders 
 into  your  landscape,  set  them  in  at  an 
 angles.  Maybe  pop  prop  them  up.  Put  some 
 soil  around  them  so  they're  tilted  up. 
 Just  kind  of  give  them  a  little  bit  of 
 interest  to  really  fit  the  space  that 
 you're  going  to  work  in.  I  think  these 
 guys  look  so  good  in  the  landscape.  They 
 kind  of  complement  and  pay  homage  to  the 
 water  feature  in  the  middle  and  just 
 kind  of  really  tie  everything  together. 
 So  to  me,  field  stone  is  an  ideal  thing 
 to  incorporate.  Some  little  neo 
 burmilads  in  the  middle  just  to  give  us 
 a  little  bit  of  that  color.  And  then 
 right  along  the  waterfall,  I  know  we 
 didn't  touch  on  that,  but  those  are  some 
 trailing  ice  plants.  And  I  just  think 
 those  variegated  ice,  I've  used  them  in 
 pots  and  planters  and  hanging  baskets. 
 They  can  handle  drought.  They  can  handle 
 too  much  moisture.  They  can  handle  They 
 can  handle  pretty  much  anything.  You 
 have  to  trim  them  about  every  other 
 month  to  kind  of  keep  them  where  you 
 want  them,  but  they  do  grow  profusely, 
 which  is  a  nice  option  for  a  trailing 
 plant.  So,  we've  got  a  cardboard  palm  in 
 here.  Now,  those  of  you  guys  who  know 
 what  this  guy's  going  to  do,  I  know  I 
 can  see  the  comments  right  now.  Oh  my 
 god,  a  cardboard  palm.  It's  going  to  get 
 huge  cuz  they  will  get  up  to  6  feet.  I 
 know.  But  this  is  a  very  small  planter. 
 We  backfilled  it  with  rocks,  so  it's  got 
 very,  very  little  places  to  go.  But  I  do 
 want  around  this  waterfall  to  have  a 
 little  chaos,  to  have  a  little  crazy.  I 
 want  those  leaves  to  go  that  way  and 
 this  way  and  kind  of  really  fill  in  this 
 space  and  not  have  such  a  hard  edge.  I 
 will  slide  in  a  picture  of  what  this 
 waterfall  looked  like  before  and  it  was 
 a  complete  U.  It  was  too  perfect,  too 
 angled  and  I  wanted  this  to  feel  softer, 
 feel  more  natural  and  so  I  think  that 
 having  some  of  this  crazy  going  on  right 
 near  the  water  feature  soften  the  eye 
 when  it  came  to  that.  So  that's  exactly 
 what  I  was  going  for.  Flanking  either 
 side  into  the  bigger  planters  are  giant 
 aposle  iris.  Now,  these  are  fantastic 
 for  small  planters.  They  can  also 
 actually  live  right  in  the  waterline. 
 So,  if  my  clients  wanted  them  right  here 
 in  the  water,  they  could  absolutely  live 
 right  here  and  enjoy  and  root  in  and  be 
 very,  very  happy.  I  had  them  in  my  pond 
 and  I  absolutely  love  them  right  in  the 
 water.  They're  a  nice  flanking  point 
 here  to  again  soften  these  hard  corners 
 of  the  water  feature  from  this  big  U. 
 These  are  tiki  torches.  They're  lit  up 
 with  propane  down  below,  so  they're 
 pre-plumbed.  So,  if  you  guys  are  in  the 
 beginning  stages  again  and  you  like  the 
 look  of  fire  above,  this  is  such  a  cool 
 look.  These  light  up  and  go  straight  up 
 and  really  give  you  a  gorgeous  flame  at 
 night.  It  really  kind  of  just  brings  you 
 to  that  resort-like  feel.  It  really  just 
 kind  of  pulls  it  all  together.  I  love 
 how  this  area  has  turned  out  and  created 
 that  jungle  vibe.  Funny  enough,  the 
 planters  are  the  smallest  thing  in  this 
 whole  backyard  space,  and  I  feel  like 
 that's  what  you  see  first,  but  maybe 
 that's  just  what  I  see  first.  I  don't 
 know.  You  guys  will  have  to  let  me  know. 
 Well,  you  guys,  thank  you  so  much  for 
 joining  us  today.  It  was  a  pleasure  kind 
 of  sharing  this  garden  with  you.  I  hope 
 it  gave  you  some  great  ideas.  And  if  you 
 loved  today's  video,  then  please  check 
 out  our  most  recent  garden  tour.  This 
 way,  Bryce  says  he's  going  to  post  it 
 right  on  the  screen.  We  will  see  you 
 guys  next  weekend.  Take  care.

 [Music] 
 So,  not  everyone  has  a  huge  grand  front 
 yard  to  work  with,  and  that  is  exactly 
 what  happened  in  this  front  yard  space. 
 This  is  a  beautiful  community  in  Port 
 St.  Lucy,  Florida.  However,  the  front 
 yards,  they  have  a  lot  to  be  desired. 
 You  know,  they're  they're  kind  of 
 compact,  kind  of  small.  The  contractor 
 developer  only  lets  you  have  so  much 
 space  to  work  with.  So,  we  really  had  a 
 very  constricted  front  yard  space  to 
 work  with.  And  I  know  a  lot  of  you  guys 
 are  in  the  same  boat,  whether  it's  a 
 front  yard,  courtyard  area,  a  little 
 corner,  sideyard,  kind  of  like  my 
 sideyard  where  those  are  just  tough 
 spots  to  really  kind  of  create  some 
 magic  in.  So,  I  thought  today  I'd  bring 
 you  guys  along  and  share  with  you  what 
 we  did  for  this  particular  space.  That 
 way,  if  you  guys  have  one  of  those  areas 
 and  you're  like,  what  do  I  do  to  have 
 impact  but  not,  you  know,  have  your 
 typical  Florida  garden  where  it  looks 
 good  initially  and  then  w  at  maturity  it 
 turns  into  10  times  the  size.  and 
 outgrows  that  small  area.  So,  in  this 
 garden,  we  definitely  thought  about 
 that.  Planting  is  key  for  small  spaces 
 in  Florida  because  they  really  outgrow 
 an  environment  very,  very  quickly  if  you 
 do  not  plan  for  that.  So,  we're  going  to 
 go  over  some  combination  plant  groupings 
 that  I  think  that  you  can  just  kind  of 
 take  away  into  your  own  space  and 
 recreate  the  same  type  of  vibe,  the  same 
 type  of  look  if  that's  what  you're 
 looking  for.  I  designed  this  garden  and 
 my  installation  team  put  it  in  a  couple 
 weeks  ago  and  that's  really  why  I  want 
 to  bring  you  guys  along  and  I'm  hoping 
 that  my  clients  will  invite  us  back  in  a 
 few  months  and  you  guys  will  really  get 
 to  see  it  in  8  months  to  a  year  as  it 
 matures  and  flushes  out  and  check  out  in 
 the  description  all  the  services  that  we 
 offer.  But  right  now,  I  really  want  to 
 jump  into  this  front  yard  garden  and  get 
 started.  So,  let's  do  that.  These  homes 
 are  so  beautiful.  The  interior  is  set  up 
 so  well.  The  exterior  gorgeous  setting 
 in  this  community.  But  to  start  with, 
 right  on  the  left  side,  we  have  the 
 large  driveway  that  goes  into  the  garage 
 and  then  almost  like  a  secondary 
 walkway/d  driveway  for  the  uh  golf  cart 
 that  goes  into  the  golf  cart  garage  and 
 then  a  small  front  yard  and  a  small 
 little  median  section  dead  center.  So, 
 it  could  be  a  bit  challenging  to  figure 
 out  what  you  want  to  do  in  this  space. 
 Several  people  have  left  this  pretty 
 blank  and  just  let  this  be  a  grass 
 patch.  But,  I  really  do  like  the  way 
 this  looks.  That  way  we  framed  both 
 sides  and  the  front  entryway  with 
 landscaping.  So  to  start  with,  we  have 
 two  beautiful  foxtail  palms.  Really 
 given  a  lot  of  ump  right  as  soon  as  you 
 walk  in.  You  guys  know  how  I  feel  about 
 walking  underneath  a  canopy  of  fronds.  I 
 just  think  that  that's  just  so  charming. 
 Gives  so  much  instant  impact  right  away. 
 So  anytime  you  can  do  a  street  planting 
 that  offers  you  a  big  canopy  entrance, 
 to  me,  it's  almost  like  having  a  gate 
 right  at  the  front  entrance.  So  that 
 really  gives  you  that  big  impact  coming 
 right  up  the  front.  We  lead  over  to  this 
 little  section  of  the  garden.  Now,  this 
 is  about  six  foot  deep.  So,  it's  a  very, 
 very  small  width  section  to  work  with. 
 So,  there's  not  many  trees  that  you  can 
 incorporate  into  this  space.  Since  we 
 had  big  palms  right  at  the  front,  I 
 wanted  something  squattier,  something 
 chunkier  right  in  this  middle  to  really 
 offer  like  an  a  lot  of  impact,  a  lot  of 
 sculptural  impact  for  a  small  space.  And 
 that's  what  this  triple  bottle  palm  is 
 going  to  do,  you  guys.  It's  still  a  baby 
 about  5  and  1/2  just  under  6'  tall.  It's 
 a  25gallon  size.  So  it's  a  great  size  to 
 start  with  if  your  budget  allows  and  you 
 can  get  a  65gallon  that  is  going  to  get 
 the  canopy  fronds  a  little  bit  over  the 
 headline  of  people  as  they  walk  through. 
 My  clients  know  that  these  fronds  are 
 going to  breach  over  into  into  the 
 pavers  a  little  bit,  but  they're  kind  of 
 like  me  where  they  don't  mind  a  little 
 bit  of  uh  obscurity  from  the  pavers.  So 
 I  think  that's  going  to  work  just  fine. 
 Now  this  tree  will  mature  out  to  14 
 foot.  So  that's  ideal  for  this  size.  So 
 it's  going  to  go  straight  up.  Those 
 fronds  will  come  over  and  across  and 
 kind  of  breach  over  into  this  way  and 
 breach  over  into  that  way  and  be  the 
 perfect  anchor  for  such  a  small  space. 
 And  because  this  is  such  a  slow  growing 
 palm,  giving  you  about  a  foot  a  year,  it 
 really  does  stay  put  for  a  long  period 
 of  time.  So  it's  always  in  the  eye  of 
 the  landscape.  It's  kind  of  always  in 
 your  eyesight  line,  unlike  a  lot  of  our 
 tall  palms.  Even  our  foxtail  palms  can 
 get  above  our  view  line  in  in  time.  But 
 this  tree  will  always  stay  within  that 
 line.  So  every  time  when  these  foxtail 
 palms  get  27  to  30  foot  tall,  they're 
 still  going  to  be  gorgeous.  But  this 
 will  be  a  nice  14  foot  backdrop  to  this 
 trunk  of  this  foxtail.  Kind  of  a 
 waterfall  effect  as  as  you  get  to  the 
 back.  So  I  think  it's  absolutely  just  a 
 stunning  little  collection  of  plants. 
 Now  to  either  side  of  it,  I  have  two 
 mango  croins.  These  are  7gallon  mango 
 croins.  What  I  love  about  these,  you 
 guys,  is  they  stay  short  and  chunky.  So 
 you  can  keep  these  guys  3  foot  by  3T.  So 
 they're  never  going  to  outgrow  this 
 spot.  So  they're  going  to  widen  into 
 this  area  here  and  widen  to  just  below 
 the  trunk  line  here.  So  it's  going  to 
 have  kind  of a  nice  chunky  overall  look. 
 I  love  the  variation  in  color.  During 
 the  winter  time,  they  tend  to  get  a 
 little  bit  darker  in  tone,  a  little  bit 
 of  that  reddish  tone  with  the  greens  and 
 the  tips  of  the  yellow.  During  the 
 summer,  they  have  more  of  the  yellow 
 tones.  And  you  can  kind  of  see  that 
 variation  from  the  winter  growth  to  the 
 summer  growth.  And  I  just  absolutely 
 love  that  they  offer  you  two  different 
 variations  in  color  throughout  the  year. 
 And  of  course,  they're  so  easy  to 
 maintain.  You  just  clip  what  you  don't 
 want  off.  You  just  take  that  top  trunk 
 off  of  the  tallest  one  to  kind  of  keep 
 them  more  mushroomed,  more  more 
 manageable  and  compact.  And  because 
 they're  such  slow  growers,  you  can  do 
 that  very  little.  So,  I  do  that  about 
 every  every  90  days.  And  you  could 
 pretty  much  probably  just  do  that  twice 
 a  year  if  you  if  you  really  kind  of  want 
 to  leave  it  more  soft  and  more  natural. 
 Now,  another  alternate  option  if  you 
 cannot  find  mango  croins  in  your  nursery 
 are  pie  crust  croins,  magnificent  croins 
 or  congo  croins.  Those  are  all  varieties 
 that  can  stay  chunky  and  kind  of  broaden 
 and  wide  out  like  that.  All  have  a  nice 
 big  leaf  to  them.  So,  they  really  do 
 give  you  that  nice  tropical  look  and  you 
 can  keep  them  3T  tall  without  too  much 
 care.  And  because  they  grow  so  slow, 
 that's  where  the  low  maintenance  comes 
 in.  However,  I  do  want  to  mention  when 
 it  comes  to  those  bigger  leafed  croins, 
 you  want  to  put  them  in  areas  similar  to 
 this  where  they're  getting  a  little  bit 
 overhead  protection.  Whether  it's 
 protection  from  the  house  or  protection 
 from  fronds  like  this  bottle  palm,  you 
 see  how  tucked  up  I  have  them  underneath 
 these  big  fronds  of  these  bottle  palms. 
 They're  offering  them  quite  a  bit  of 
 shade  and  filtered  light  under  here.  And 
 as  this  tree  matures,  it's  going  to  do 
 that  even  more.  So,  they  do  their  very 
 best  when  they're  not  in  full  sun.  Full 
 sun  will  bleach  them  out  and  put  them 
 under  stress.  So  filtered  light,  morning 
 sun,  midday  sun,  but  once  we  get  past 
 early  afternoon,  that  late  afternoon  sun 
 can  really,  really  do  harm  to  a  big  leaf 
 croen.  To  the  backside,  I  needed 
 something  really  tough  that  can  handle 
 the  heat  of  the  day.  So,  we've  got  the 
 laopy  as  a  backdrop.  I  wanted  them  to  be 
 able  to  bounce  off  the  heat  from  this 
 paper  deck  and  the  rock,  as  well  as  kind 
 of  give  us  a  real  clean,  defined  border. 
 And  I  I  want  that  border  to  comes  to 
 have  like  a  little  grassy  pad  to  the 
 back.  And  they're  going  to  grow  in  and 
 do  that.  so  nicely  and  be  so  so 
 contained.  And  there's  something  about 
 laria  mixed  with  croins  that  I  love  that 
 contrast  and  look.  You  guys  know  how  I 
 feel  about  foxtail  ferns  and  rock.  Every 
 time  I  have  rock  or  a  little  bit  of 
 boulders,  I'll  pop  in  just  a  handful  of 
 foxtail  ferns.  Now,  you  can  see  we  do 
 not  have  a  huge  amount  of  plant  material 
 collected  in  this  grouping.  Three 
 foxtail  ferns  is  what  we  have  on  either 
 side  of  our  focal  point.  So,  in  a 
 triangle  formation,  I  think  they  work 
 the  best  that  way.  I  have  them  framed 
 around  a  boulder  on  both  sides.  So  that 
 way  as  these  guys  grow  up  with  that  cool 
 texture  that  they  offer,  they  highlight 
 this  boulder  as  like  a  little  bit  of  a 
 frame.  Now  you  can  do  this  with  an 
 inexpensive  small  boulder  just  like  you 
 have  here.  I  know  we  see  landscapes  with 
 giant  big  cap  rocks  and  those  are 
 awesome,  but  they're  also  hundreds  and 
 hundreds  of  dollars  for  those  rocks.  So 
 having  a  little  touch  of  a  a  basketball 
 size,  something  just,  you  know,  tad  bit 
 bigger  than  a  football  size  here.  You 
 tell  we're  a  sports  family  just  to  give 
 you  a  change  in  element.  So,  we  have  the 
 stone,  the  white  Alabama  river  rock 
 here.  And  then  we  have  some  field  stone, 
 some  Tennessee  field  stone  that  we've 
 put  in  here  in  a  small  size.  And  that 
 just  adds  a  little  bit  of  interest,  just 
 one  more  element  to  the  garden.  The 
 stone  does  a  nice  job  of  highlighting 
 against  the  grass  area.  And  I  think  that 
 this  since  it's  a  small  bed,  it's  an 
 ideal  thing  to  do.  And  anytime  that  you 
 have  a  bed  that's  sandwiched  between  two 
 hardscape  areas  and  you  don't  want  mulch 
 to  run  off  into  those  areas,  having 
 stone,  it  just  does  such  a  great  job  of 
 keeping  it  just  tidy  and  neat  and  not 
 having  to  worry  about  any  kind  of 
 runoff.  So,  this  is  the  Imperialis 
 burmilad.  Yes,  very  nice.  I  love  love 
 love  this  plant.  It  can  handle  full  sun 
 to  full  shade  pretty  much.  It  does  look 
 different  in  both  of  those  environments. 
 from  full  sun,  it  can  be  a  little  pale 
 or  a  little  greener.  When  it's  in 
 partial  light,  like  filtered  light,  it 
 will  have  more  of  a  burgundy  tone  to  it. 
 Now,  this  one  here  was  grown  more  in  the 
 full  sun,  so  it's  going  to  adapt  to  its 
 location.  It  might  have  more  of  a  purple 
 tinge  to  it  as  it  matures.  So,  you'll 
 get  to  see  that  change  according  to  the 
 location.  And  then,  as  this  tree 
 matures,  it'll  change  again  because  this 
 canopy  will  be  up  over  it.  So,  but 
 regardless,  that's  why  I  picked  a  plant 
 that  can  handle  both  conditions  because 
 we're  going  to  have  both  conditions  in 
 this  particular  spot  from  now  to,  you 
 know,  10  years  from  now.  It'll  widen  out 
 to  about  3  and  1/2  ft  and  kind  of  give 
 us  a  spherical  kind  of  roundness  to  this 
 top.  So,  it  is  not  one  of  those 
 vermilads  that  will  throw  a  limb  this 
 way  or  throw  a  a  leaf  that  way  or  throw 
 pups  every  which  way.  This  one  is  a 
 solitary  plant  until  it  dies.  is  it  will 
 offer  a  pup  when  it  dies,  which  is  I 
 mean  pretty  ideal  as  bmilads  go,  but  it 
 will  not  produce  tons  and  tons  of  pups. 
 So,  it  is  a  very  lowmaintenance  plant. 
 Only  trim  it  as  needed.  I  trim  mine  once 
 twice  a  year.  If  you  get  too  much 
 collection  of  water  as  it  holds  water  in 
 this  area,  you  can  flush  it  out  with  a 
 hose.  So,  you  bring  your  hose  out  here 
 and  just  kind  of  flush  it  out  in  the 
 middle  of  the  cups  and  that'll  wash  any 
 of  that  old  water  away  because  that  is 
 where  it  stores  its  water  for  its  plant. 
 Now,  this  particular  burmilad,  unlike 
 many  others,  can  handle  more  water  than 
 others.  So  it  can  be  absolutely  be 
 incorporated  into  a  tropical  landscape 
 without  any  kind  of  issues.  So  I  love 
 love love  using  this  plant  for  that 
 reason.  This  versatility,  shade  versus 
 sun,  handling  more  water,  and  just  easy 
 low  care  overall  trimming  as  needed. 
 That's  why  we've  made  this  to  focal 
 point.  And  I  think  it  turned  out 
 beautifully  as  it  is.  So  we  made  it  the 
 centerpiece.  Flanked  it  with  some 
 foxtail  ferns  on  the  side.  A  little 
 touch  of  pentas  here  on  the  corner  to 
 pop  in  some  color  and  then  highlighted 
 the  front  area  with  some  golden  dew. 
 These  are  the  dwarf  variety  of  the  red 
 pentas.  What's  great  about  those  is  that 
 you  can  keep  them  at  2  foot.  So  they 
 will  continue  to  grow,  but  every  other 
 month  just  do  a  nice  cut  back  on  these 
 guys.  So  you  just  trim  them  about  every 
 other  month  and  they  flush  out  and  chunk 
 out  with  new  growth.  Even  if  they're  in 
 full  bloom,  do  not  be  afraid  to  trim 
 them  back.  Really  kind  of  staying  nice 
 and  chunky  and  blooming,  trimming  after 
 trimming  after  trimming.  So,  you  do  have 
 to  do  a  little  work  to  these  guys,  but 
 it's  a  beautiful  carpet  flower  of  two 
 foot.  I  think  they're  definitely  worth 
 having.  And  you  can  see  how  this  little 
 bed  was  done  with  very  few  plants,  but  a 
 lot  of  impact.  Um,  we  used  the  aluminum 
 alloy  edging  to  edge  and  keep  the  rocks 
 separated  from  the  sod  here.  And  it's 
 just  kind  of  a  nice  crisp,  clean  look 
 all  the  way  around.  This  little  bed  is 
 so  small  that  it  only  needed  two 
 irrigation  heads.  These  are  typical 
 sprinkler  irrigation  heads.  One  sprays 
 out  this  way  covering  this  bed  and  this

 corner.  They  overlap  each  other.  This  is 
 going  to  need  to  be  irrigated  about 
 three  to  four  times  a  week  and  it's 
 ideal  for  that.  So  now  for  the  second 
 section  and  last  section  of  this  small 
 front  yard  garden.  Took  away  what  was 
 currently  here,  cleared  out  this  bed  and 
 incorporated  a  triple  foxtail  palm 
 that's  really  going  to  pair  beautifully 
 with  the  two  foxtail  palms  in  the  front. 
 all  this  clearance  so  that  way  it  didn't 
 block  any  light  from  the  window  coming 
 in  and  it  just  really  gives  kind  of a 
 crown  effect  to  the  top  of  the  roof 
 line.  Now,  the  reason  why  I  chose  to  put 
 something  so  heavy  on  this  side  is 
 because  over  on  this  side,  we  have  the 
 driveway,  we  have  the  garage,  we  have 
 the  doorway.  So,  having  some  heavier 
 impact,  having  some  more  interest  on 
 this  side  was  really  important  for 
 balance.  So,  that's  kind  of  what  I'm 
 always  looking  at  when  I'm  creating  a 
 space  or  creating  a  design.  And  so  this 
 triple  foxtail,  I  think,  is  anchoring 
 this  space  beautifully.  And  it's  still 
 very,  very  new.  Once  it  really  matures 
 and  opens  up,  it's  going  to  be  even  more 
 gorgeous.  I  believe  it  was  14t  at 
 planting,  so  that's  from  the  top  of  the 
 the  ground  all  the  way  up  to  the  tallest 
 frond.  And  it  has  a  good  7t  of  clear 
 trunk  at  the  bottom.  We  like  to  plant 
 about  5  to  six  foot  off  of  the  house 
 line.  So  even  when  it's  up  and  over  the 
 house  line,  we  like  to  have  a  little  bit 
 of  girth.  This  tree  will  grow  slowly  to 
 about  a  foot  to  two  foot  per  year.  This 
 is  a  very  claybank  soil,  so  it's  going 
 to  grow  into  that  slow  range.  When 
 you're  in  sandy  soil,  it's  going  to  grow 
 much  faster.  On  either  side  on  these 
 blank  walls  that  we  have,  we  chose  a 
 clumping  rafus  palm.  Now,  these  are 
 awesome,  awesome  trees  to  light  at 
 night.  I  love  this  leaf.  These  are  great 
 for  planters  or  indoor  voses.  Just  such 
 a  cool  cool  tree  and  they  really  have 
 that  dynamic  kind  of  hand  frrawn  to 
 them.  I  love  putting  them  either  on 
 blank  walls  or  if  there's  a  blank  spot 
 right  behind  an  opening  of  this  tree,  I 
 love  to  put  them  in  the  center  of  that 
 area  as  well  because  they  really  do 
 offer  a  big  ump  as  a  backdrop.  They  do 
 grow  slowly  and  they  do  grow  nice  and 
 compact.  The  negative  to  these  guys  is 
 they  will  travel,  so  they'll  throw  a 
 little  chute  to  the  left  and  to  the 
 right  of  itself.  So,  you  want  to  make 
 sure  that  you  pull  that  out.  So,  when 
 you  do  your  trimming,  you  just  take  any 
 of  them  out  that  you  don't  want. 
 However,  if  you  guys  get  nervous  about 
 those  running  shoots,  then  absolutely  do 
 not  sleep  on  these  guys.  is  go  ahead  and 
 put  them  in  a  planter.  Put  them  in  a  pot 
 and  put  them  into  the  garden.  They  work 
 so  so  well  and  can  live  in  a  pot  for 
 years  and  years  and  years.  That's  how  I 
 have  mine  in  my  garden.  These  are  about 
 4t  tall  and  these  were  in  a  25gallon 
 size.  Um  I  usually  get  them  in  a  15  or 
 25  gallon  just  depending  on  what  you 
 know  budgets  allow.  I  love  the  25gallon 
 size  because  they've  clustered  nice  and 
 tight  in  the  bottom  and  they've  rounded 
 out.  15  gallon  is  a  little  bit  thinner 
 and  seven  gallon  and  three  gallon  is 
 just  a  little  bit  too  hard  and  it  takes 
 too  long  for  them  to  really  clump. 
 They'll  want  to  spread  before  they 
 really  clump.  So  I  would  stick  with 
 trying  to  get  a  15  gallon  or  25gallon 
 size  right  off  the  bat.  Just  spend  the 
 extra  money  to  do  that  on  these 
 particular  plants.  It's  worth  it.  I 
 commonly  will  put  blueberry  trees  into  a

 really  softening  those  corners.  So 
 because  this  tree  has  such  long  legs,

 So  we  have  a  nice  dual  view  from  both

 the  dwarf  exoras.  It's  just  a  little

 filidendrian  leaves.  They're  still  going

 crazy.  So  these  dwarf  exoras  and  this 
 gold  mound  down  below  do  a  nice  job  of 
 having  two  tiers  of  keeping  it 
 controlled  and  very  clean  lines.  So  you 
 guys  know  my  style  is  crazy  in  the  back 
 paired  back  in  the  front.  And  that's 
 exactly  what  this  will  do.  It'll  make  it 
 feel  like  it's  a  purposeful  landscape. 
 So  anytime  you're  like,  did  I  get  a 
 little  bit  too  crazy  with  that 
 landscaping?  Now  it's  time  to  divide  it 
 and  create  something  really  fine-tuned. 
 Dwarf  exoras  are  my  go-to  for  that.  So 
 are  gold  mound,  dwarf  kucia,  variegated 
 arbicola.  Those  are  things  that  kind  of 
 you  can  really  keep  and  draw  with,  kind 
 of  curve  with.  So  anything  Carissa 
 boxwood  blew  my  mind.  That's  what  you 
 want  to  use.  So  and  then  of  course  we 
 just  tapered  it  off  and  finished  it  to 
 the  corner.  This  is  not  the  same  shape 
 or  size  as  the  bed  adjacent  to  it.  But 
 trying  to  find  some  balance  and  kind  of 
 make  them  two  mirror  each  other  is 
 always  an  important  thing.  You  don't 
 want  to  have  one  style  way  over  there, 
 another  bed  right  across  from  it,  a 
 completely  different  style.  Like  that 
 was  almost  like  an  afterthought.  Do 
 little  pop  outs  of  stone  in  this  bed  to 
 tie  these  two  areas  together.  Have  some 
 of  that  Tennessee  field  stone  framing 
 some  of  the  key  features  in  this  garden 
 by  having  them  over  there.  So  that  way 
 it  feels  like  gosh,  this  is  a  bed  that's 
 almost  just  like  it's  interrupted  by  the 
 walkway.  Like  this  is  one  continuous 
 space.  Then  the  walkway  comes  through 
 the  middle  of  it  and  interrupts  that 
 space,  but  then  it  continues  right  on  to 
 the  next  planter.  That  makes  one  little 
 space  look  bigger  by  having  a 
 continuation.  So  keep  those  long  arching 
 beds  as  long  and  as  big  as  you  can 
 possibly  make  them.  And  then  here  we  had 
 the  budget  to  do  a  nice  little  final 
 planting  with  this  yucka  restrada.  I 
 love  this  plant.  It  is  like  a  little 
 firework  in  the  garden.  It  is  just  so 
 stunning  with  its  bright  blue  colors.  It 
 has  gorgeous,  gorgeous  leaves  to  it. 
 It's  just  a  such  a  beautiful  look.  When 
 this  guy  gets  big,  they  get  very,  very 
 expensive  as  they  grow  taller.  It  does 
 have  a  nice  trunk  to  it  and  then  it  does 
 have  a  nice  big  round  head.  It'll  be  a 
 stunner  as  a  front  focal  point.  It'll  be 
 like  a  sculpture  in  the  garden.  Brought 
 in  at  15gallon  size.  It's  a  great  size. 
 Still  affordable.  They  are  pricey  little 
 accents,  but  gosh,  they  are  so  worth  it. 
 They  live  a  long  time  and  they  grow 
 super  slow.  So,  if  you're  going  to  put 
 them  in  a  pot  on  a  pool  deck,  they  don't 
 drop  a  bunch  of  stuff.  It's  almost  like 
 a  look  at  me  plant.  That  kind  of  fan 
 look  to  them.  So,  having  three  of  those 
 on  your  back  pool  deck,  I  think  is 
 ideal.  And  then  dappled  in  some  ground 
 cover.  So  these  are  little  onegon  boom 
 my  minds  that  are  going  to  kind  of  fill 
 in  this  spot.  To  the  back  we  have  some 
 gold  mound  holding  back  the  crazy  of 
 those  burl  marks  and  mango  croins  there. 
 So  these  guys  are  going  to  be  6'  tall. 
 Those  guys  are  going  to  be  around  four 
 or  fivet  tall.  These  drop  down  to  3t 
 tall,  3ft  tall,  2  foot  to  the  bottom.  A 
 focal  point  coming  out  of  the  middle  and 
 about  a  foot  and  a  half  to  two  foot  at 
 the  bottom  with  the  blew  my  mind.  So  you 
 can  really  see  that  layering  effect 
 happen.  Look  at  all  that  darkness  on 
 either  side.  Doesn't  it  call  for  a  pop 
 of  interest  with  these  leaves?  I  mean,  I 
 just  love  this  leaf  color.  It's  so 
 stunning.  A  lot  of  people  let  them  get 
 giant  and  tall  and  kind  of  go  crazy.  You 
 can  keep  them  this  size  forever.  You  can 
 keep  them  3T  4T  tall  forever  by  just 
 trimming  whatever  you  do  not  want.  Just 
 this  one  trunk  that  you  would  trim  off 
 and  it'll  start  to  fill  out.  So,  they're 
 looking  for  neighboring  plants  to 
 connect  to.  These  will  group  as  one 
 solid  bush  and  become  a  clustering  of 
 that  bright  color.  And  when  that 
 happens,  they're  just  golden.  They're 
 just  a  stunner  in  the  garden.  If  you  can 
 have  that  much  bright  and  dark,  bright 
 and  dark  in  a  garden,  doesn't  matter  how 
 small  it  is,  it  just  pops.  But  that  will 
 be  all  for  today's  video.  Thank  you  so 
 much  for  joining  us.  We  put  a  video  on 
 the  screen  for  last  week's  garden  tour. 
 Thank  you  guys  so  much.  See  you 
 tomorrow.  Take  care.

---

 Well,  hello  gardeners.  Welcome  back.  We 
 are  in  my  backyard  today,  Vero  Beach, 
 Florida,  zone  10A.  And  today  is  all 
 about  cutting  flowers.  Today  is  all 
 about  bringing  the  outdoors  inside.  So, 
 I  know  up  north  a  lot  of  my  clients  have 
 mentioned  to  me  how  they've  made 
 beautiful  cutting  gardens  and  they  have 
 all  of  those  florals.  They  bring  them 
 inside  and  they  have  them  for  weeks  on 
 end  and  they  don't  have  to  buy  any 
 bouquets  from  the  flower  shops.  However, 
 here  in  Florida,  that  seems  to  be  a 
 mystery  to  us.  I've  not  been  able  to 
 really  recreate  that  kind  of  feeling  in 
 my  own  garden.  However,  what  I  do  do  is 
 there  are  so  many  different  variations 
 of  color,  beautiful  variegated  plants 
 that  I  absolutely  do  that  constantly.  I 
 have  so  much  greenery  inside  that  comes 
 from  the  outside  and  I  I  don't  miss  a 
 time  of  trimming.  And  as  you  guys  can 
 see,  we've  recently  done  a  big  heavy 
 trim  back.  So,  I  thought  today's  video 
 would  be  an  ideal  time  to  take  those 
 plants,  those  clippings  that  we  did  and 
 show  you  guys  what  we  brought  inside  to 
 create  beautiful  little  cutting  voses, 
 things  that  last  weeks  and  months  in  my 
 house.  I  pretty  much  just  take  from  the 
 outside  and  bring  it  in.  And  anytime  I 
 have  a  gathering  or  friends  come  over 
 for  the  evening,  I  will  come  out  and 
 clip  and  nip  and  do  just  a  little  bit  of 
 a  light  trimming  and  put  them  in  voses 
 inside  and  put  them  in  the  bathrooms, 
 the  guest  bathrooms,  put  them,  you  know, 
 just  everywhere  that  I  feel  like  I  want 
 a  touch  of  just  a  little  bit  of  softness 
 to  kind  of  share  with  my  company  that 
 comes  here.  So,  I  thought  today  I  would 
 do  a  video  on  my  favorite  plants  to  cut 
 things  that  that  last  a  while  because  I 
 am  a  busy  lady.  So,  I  really  need  it  to 
 be  a  kind  of  a  one  and  done  trim,  put  it 
 inside,  maybe  every  couple  weeks  just 
 change  the  water  out,  but  it  does  super 
 super  well  longterm.  And  I  thought  that 
 I  would  share  those  particular  plants 
 and  trees  as  well  as  maybe  some  that 
 I've  done  in  the  past  that  were 
 nightmares,  maybe  just  leafed  all  over 
 the  counter  and  was  just  not  a  thing  to 
 do.  So,  let's  get  started  with  my  first 
 and  one  of  my  favorites.  So,  you've  seen 
 my  antilooines,  you've  seen  my  red 
 sisters,  you've  seen  my  exotic.  But  I 
 have  a  few  different  varieties  of  portal 
 lines  mainly  because  I  love  that 
 spotlight  of  color  in  a  in  a  relatively 
 dark  space.  They  really  offer  that  kind 
 of  pop  of  color.  But  another  thing  that 
 I  love  about  them  is  they  become  one  of 
 my  focal  points  on  the  inside  of  my 
 house.  They  sit  on  my  little  table  that 
 my  husband  and  I  eat  at  usually  late  in 
 the  evenings.  It's  near  the  TV.  It's 
 kind  of  it's  not  our  dining  room  area, 
 but  it's  kind  of  our  little  seating 
 section  that  we'll  have  we'll  have 
 dinner  at.  and  it's  the  plant  that  I 
 love  to  put  there  because  it's  very 
 vertical,  doesn't  take  up  much  space, 
 and  it  offers  a  pop  of  color.  This  is  my 
 Marie  variety,  and  I  am  a  big  fan  of 
 this  plant.  I  know  I  don't  use  it  very 
 often  in  other  landscapes  because 
 honestly,  it  is  a  hybrid  variety  that's 
 been  out  for  five  or  six  years,  but  I've 
 had  a  lovehate  relationship  with  it. 
 I've  had  some  great  success  with  it,  and 
 I've  had  some  areas  that  where  it  just 
 didn't  do  well.  So,  I'm  still  learning  a 
 little  bit  more  about  it.  However,  this 
 particular  grouping  has  always  done  well 
 protected  from  the  wind  and  with  this 
 wall,  but  it  is  a  gorgeous  variation  in

 dark  tones  are  just  absolutely  stunning.

 I'm  so  grateful  to  share  it  with  you

 bouncy  to  the  kitchen  table  kind  of  just

 in  the  garden.  So  I  leave  them  empty  and 
 then  I  will  incorporate  my  favorite 
 plants  and  I  kind  of  each  vase  has  its 
 own  kind  of  plant  species  that  I  tend  to 
 work  with.  So,  as  you  can  see,  I  have 
 these  beautiful  voses  that  I  got  for 
 Bryce's  wedding.  I  have  two  that  I  kept 
 for  myself.  These  are  absolutely  just  a 
 fun  fun  vase  to  have  indoors.  I  use  my 
 palms.  You  guys  know  I  have  tons  of 
 palms.  So,  I  totally  love  to  use  these 
 in  this  particular  space.  These  palms 
 will  last  in  this  vase  for  2  months  and 
 they  will  do  fine.  Now,  I  don't  put 
 water  in  right  away.  I  cut  them.  I  let 
 them  sit  for  about  2  days,  harden  off  a 
 little  bit,  then  add  water.  I  know  that 
 seems  crazy  because  you  think,  gosh, 
 wouldn't  they  dry  out,  but  they  just 
 seem  to  hold  so  much  better  like  that. 
 So,  I  will  fill  half  of  this  with  water 
 and  then  about  every  two  to  3  weeks, 
 I'll  switch  out  this  water.  I  would  like 
 to  say  I'm  more  diligent  than  than  that, 
 but  I'm  I'm  really  not.  So,  um  my  small 
 voses  I  definitely  do  about  every  2 
 weeks  until  they're  ready  to  be  kind  of 
 popped  out.  And  you'll  know  that  they'll 
 start  to  kind  of  give  you  a  little bit 
 of  yellow  tone  and  they're  like, "Okay, 
 I'm  kind  of  done  visiting.  I'm  kind  of 
 over.  Put  me  out  of  my  misery."  And  then 
 I  move  on  to  do  more  clipping.  So,  the 
 very  first  thing  is  going  to  be  my  small 
 vase.  I  got  this  for  Mother's  Day,  God, 
 forever  ago.  And  it  is  just  such  a  fun 
 little  vase.  It's  absolutely  short,  big, 
 wide  mouth.  I  love  the  gold  trim.  Goes 
 perfectly  on  a  little  table  that  I  have 
 right  in  my  TV  room.  Now,  because  this 
 is  so  short,  you  want  to  make  sure  that 
 you  use  a  small  or  narrow  stem.  This  is 
 exactly  why  I  use  the  raphus  palm.  And 
 you  notice  I  didn't  cut  the  whole  trunk 
 on  the  rais  palm.  I  just  cut  the 
 individual  stems.  But  they  add  such  a 
 bit  of  architectural  detail  to  this 
 little  vase  here.  And  they're  not  tall, 
 so  they're  not  going  to  obstruct  the  TV 
 because  I  have  men  in  my  house  and  they 
 have  a  hard  time  seeing  through  fronds. 
 Go  figure.  But  they  do.  So  this  is  the 
 perfect  little  piece  for  me.  So  I  add  a 
 little  bit  of  water.  And  I  usually  don't 
 do  any  more  than  this.  Now  I  know  this 
 doesn't  offer  color,  but  I  do  think  it 
 offers  fun.  It  offers  texture.  I  set  it 
 right  on  one  of  my  design  books  and  it's 
 just  perfect  for  that.  Let  me  add  some 
 water  and  then  I'll  show  you  guys  where 
 it  goes.  And  voila,  we  are  done. 
 All right,  you  guys.  So,  what's  next  is 
 one  of  my  favorite  voses  throughout  my 
 whole  house.  I  usually  will  put 
 something  that's  really  wide  in  here. 
 So,  that's  kind  of  why  I  use  my 
 collection  of  croins  in  here.  Sometimes 
 I'll  put  some  ice  plants  kind  of 
 dripping  or  some  ferns  dripping  to  it.  I 
 love  ferns  and  a  vase.  The  only  thing  I 
 do  not  like  is  how  much  they  drop 
 leaves.  So  those  little  kind  of  pin 
 needle  leaves,  they  can  be  kind  of 
 crazy.  The  only  fern  that  I  tend  to 
 really  love  to  work  with  are  the  foxtail 
 ferns.  I  have  it  on  my  window  sill.  It's 
 been  there  for  almost  2  months.  They 
 will  get  a  little  dried,  so  when  you  go 
 to  change  out  the  water,  you  will  have 
 little  fern  needles  everywhere.  Easy  to 
 clean  up,  but  such  a  vertical  aspect  in 
 the  garden,  and  you've  got  to  trim  those 
 anyway.  So  I  just  take  the  trimmings  and 
 I  put  them  in  a  vase,  and  I  utilize  them 
 that  way.  So  I'll  start  with  the  whitest 
 one  first.  And  you  guys  probably  know 
 this  as  you  guys  work  with  your  plants. 
 But  you'll  see  kind  of  how  that's  big 
 and  broad  there.  And  then  I'll  kind  of 
 do  all  of  my  little  fluff.  So  these  are 
 nice  and  vertical.  Angle  this  one  out 
 just  to  balance  out  with  the  angle  that 
 we  have  here.  And  voila.  Add  a  little 
 filtered  water  to  that  guy.  And  you're 
 kind  of  good  to  go.  And  I  place  him  in 
 the  same  spot  all  the  time  in  the 
 kitchen  area.  So  this  is  my  little  tea 
 set.  I  just  pretty  much  put  them  in 
 here.  My  family  and  friends  will  know 
 this,  but  I  find  little  tea  or  coffee 
 pots.  I  know  this  is  off  topic,  but  I 
 find  them  all  the  time  at  like  Goodwill 
 or  little  thrift  stores  that,  you  know, 
 maybe  have  a  broken  little  lid  or 
 whatnot  and  they're  like  a  dollar.  So 
 many  cute  ones  that  I  found  that  you  can 
 put  little  little  plants  in  there  that 
 have  just  started  to  root.  Some  of  my 
 alicacas,  some  of  my  poo,  really  unique 
 things  that  you  can  put  in  here  and  then 
 give  as  a  gift  to  someone  visiting.  I 
 just  think  that  is  such  a  cool  thing  to 
 do.  So,  there  are  so  many  out  there.  I 
 literally  get  them  for  like  a  dollar,  $2 
 and  then  they  just  kind  of  make  little 
 little  treats.  A  lot  of  times  I'll  put 
 them  in  the  bathroom  with  a  little  plant 
 in  there  and  it's  it's  just  perfect.  I 
 don't  have  a  lot  of  small  voses  around 
 the  house.  So  I  usually  use  this  as  like 
 a  lower  tier  in  the  plant  grouping.  So 
 it  kind  of  goes  like  this  or  at  the 
 bottom  with  something  vertical  popping 
 out  of  it.  So  this  is  the  song  of  India. 
 I  use  it  for  everything.  I've  put  it  in 
 water,  put  it  on  my  wall.  It's  just  such 
 a  fabulous  plant  to  work  with.  You  take 
 off  these  lower  leaves.  You  don't  have 
 to  be  super  delicate  with  this  plant. 
 does  not  mind  it.  It  will  pop  out  roots. 
 And  you  guys,  I  don't  like  tons  of 
 frills.  I  don't  like  too  much  mess.  I'm 
 like,  I'm  not  going to  cut  all  these 
 little  individual  browns  that  are  on 
 there.  That  is  just  part  of  nature.  It 
 comes  in  just  that  way.  The  only  thing  I 
 will  check  it  for  is  if  we  have  any 
 pests  or  bugs  or  anything  along  those 
 lines.  It's  usually  as  good  as  a  rinse 
 and  you're  good  to  go.  I  just  think  that 
 what  a  great  display  that  makes  right 
 there.  So,  I  just  love  the  way  that 
 little  touch  of  dark  and  bright  looks  in 
 the  garden. 
 All  right,  you  guys.  So,  the  last  vase 
 that  I  have  is  this  big  boy.  So,  I  tend 
 to  use  the  Eureka  palm  frrons.  I  cut

 bit  of  just  kind  of  a  lacy  look  to  them

 is  the  only  vertical  space  that  I  have 
 for  those  guys.  And  as  you  can  tell 
 there,  there's  not  a  lot  of  vertical 
 space  there  either.  Trim  these  guys 
 almost  in  half  just  before  you  get  to 
 the  bend  of  it.  And  then  just  take  off 
 some  of  these  lower  fronds.  We're  not 
 propagating  these  guys.  These  are  just 
 sitting  in  water.  So  you  don't  have  to

 pretty  much  just  to  kind  of  give  us  a

 as  my  felos.  Now  this  does  right  here. 
 Now  you  can  put  this  right  into  the 
 ground  right  next  to  where  I  took  this 
 plant.  It  will  rroot  and  offer  you  a 
 whole  new  plant.  So  don't  toss  any  of 
 your  cutings  when  it  comes  to  your 
 quarter  lines  because  they  are  worth 
 their  weight  and  gold  as  offering  you 
 brand  new  plants.  Now  this  particular 
 planter  I  only  keep  this  in  this  planter 
 for  about  no  more  than  a  month  because 
 you  see  how  tight  this  nozzle  is.  It  is 
 not  an  ideal  planter  for  plants  that  you 
 want  to  rroot.  These  plants  will  root  in 
 about  a  month  and  you'll  start  to  see 
 them  kind  of  spiral  down.  And  when  that 
 happens,  you  don't  want  to  tug  on  those 
 tender  roots  by  getting  them  out.  So,  I 
 will  keep  it  in  for  a  few  weeks  and  then 
 take  it  out  so  I  can  go  ahead  and  put  it 
 back  in  the  garden.  It's  just  too  pretty 
 just  to  kind  of  toss.  So,  I  do  my  best 
 to  remember  to  do  that.  But  gosh,  what  a 
 beautiful,  beautiful  display  it  makes  as 
 a  gorgeous  centerpiece.  And  you  kind  of 
 see  what  I  mean.  If  you  have  them  in  a 
 real  vertical  planting  like  this,  gosh,

 you  know,  layer  up  on  this  palm.  This  is

 giant  frond,  you  guys.  I  mean,  I  just

 overall  you  can  see  it's  just  like  a  big 
 old  giant  giant  fan  underneath.  And  the

 zone  10A.  They  do  fabulous  all  the  way 
 down  south  from  the  Keys  all  the  way  up 
 in  kind  of  that  Palm  Bay  area.  That's 
 kind  of  where  our  break  is  because  when 
 you  hit  temperatures  like  32,  which  I 
 know  that  few  times  a  year  it  gets  down 
 to  that  over  in  the  Melbourne  area,  they 
 can  burn.  Now,  I  will  show  you  this  one 
 leaf  over  here.  This  is  an  old  growth 
 leaf.  This  is  from  this  past  season's 
 burn.  So,  you  can  kind  of  see  this  is 
 what  happens.  They'll  kind  of  speckle 
 like  this  when  they're  not  happy  with 
 the  cold  temperatures.  I  didn't  cover 
 this  tree,  but  I  had  so  much  foliage 
 down  below.  So,  I  really  felt  like  it 
 was  covered  enough,  but  boy  was  I  wrong. 
 And  we  did  not  get  into  super  freezing 
 temps.  I  mean,  I  think  we  got  down  to  32 
 twice  and  it  was  for  just  a  few  hours. 
 So,  anything  north  of  us,  this  is 
 probably  not  the  palm  for  you,  unless 
 you  plan  to  pot  it  and  cover  it  or  bring 
 it  in  during  the  season.  And  totally 
 worth  that,  you  guys,  cuz  it  grows  so 
 slow.  It  holds  this  kind  of  frrawn 
 canopy  for  years  and  years  and  years. 
 So,  this  tree  is  probably  close  to  9  to 
 10  years  old,  and  you  can  tell  that  it 
 is  not  grown  much.  You  need  something 
 that's  going  to  offer  like  a  powerful 
 punch  in  a  garden  and  kind  of  give  you 
 that  exotic  look.  This  is  a  fabulous  one

 heavier  frrawn  leaves  and  wow  what  a 
 contrast  those  two  make.  So  it's 
 definitely  worth  using  in  your  garden. 
 So  this  guy  grows  about  6  in  to  max  a 
 foot  a  year.  It  really  is  a  slow  slow 
 grower.  You  can  get  it  in  a  threegon  pot 
 size.  So  do  not  feel  like  you've  got  to 
 start  super  big  on  these  guys.  I  started

 ponytail  palm  base.  Just  the  way  it  gets 
 chunky  and  fat.  I  had  three  of  them  in 
 my  garden.  These  two  guys  in  my  garden, 
 I  started,  they  were  around  the  10ft

 they  grow  super  super  slow.  However,

 particular  tree.  But  if  you've  got  a

 especially  I  hope  it  comes  across  this

 You  can  definitely  find  it  here  in  Palm

 Ant.  It  is  a  fantastic  resource  to  find 
 some  of  these  exotic  palm  trees.  You  can

 area  to  incorporate  a  tree,  this  is  one 
 to  incorporate.  So,  I  hope  you  guys  like 
 it.  And  it  can  handle  some  light 
 temperatures.  It  really  doesn't  like 
 freeze  temperatures.  So,  anything  from 
 32  and  warmer  ideal.  Um,  growth  habits 
 super  super  slow.  Trimming  is 
 self-cleaning.  So,  however,  it's  not  a 
 heavy  canopy  frond  base.  So,  I  normally 
 just  actually  trim  them  myself  when  they 
 kind  of  start  to  get  brown  a  little  bit

 that  just  stand  on  their  own.  So,  let's 
 go  to  the  next  one.  All right,  you  guys. 
 So,  my  next  rare  find  is  the  penanga 
 coronada.  This  is  a  small  palm,  very, 
 very  vertical.  It  has  multi-  trunks  to 
 it.  Sometimes  called  the  ivory  cane 
 palm,  which  because  they  have  those 
 beautiful  white  canes  as  they  start  to 
 get  some  size  to  it,  but  grow  very  very 
 vertical  and  very  compact.  And  the  leaf 
 is  kind  of  like  on  top  of  one  another. 
 So  it's  one  leaf  and  then  you  see 
 another  leaf  and  it's  just  really  really 
 vertical  and  really  small.  Unlike  a  palm 
 that  somebody  might  consider  similar  to 
 it  and  looks  like  the  Eureka  palm  or  cat 
 palm  or  something  like  that,  but  those 
 palms  have  a  tendency  to  really  widen 
 out,  really  open  up.  This  is  more  of  a 
 vertical  palm.  So,  it  is  actually 
 related  to  the  lipstick  palm.  It  has  a 
 very  similar  look.  However,  it  doesn't 
 have  those  beautiful  red  crown  shafts 
 like  the  lipstick  palm.  I  would 
 obviously  totally  have  that  palm  in  my 
 garden,  but  I  just  cannot  commit  to  a 
 palm  that  pricey  that  really  can't 
 handle  any  kind  of  cold  temps  because  we 
 do  get  them.  As  a  good  gardening  parent 
 that  I  am,  I  can't  say  that  I'm  out  here 
 covering  things  all  the  time.  I  mean,  we 
 might  have  some  hot  spots  where  I'm 
 willing  to  cover,  but  I  definitely  can't 
 do  that  with  a  lot  of  my  exotics.  So,  I 
 have  to  make  sure  that  the  palms  that  I 
 do  choose  can  handle  our  temperatures 
 really  well  and  that  are  also  going  to 
 work  for  our  space  long  term.  So,  this 
 is  kind  of  a  lookalike  version  of  that 
 without  the  red  cane.  But  what  I  do  like 
 about  this  palm,  if  you  guys  have  a 
 courtyard  space  or  a  nice  little  nook 
 space  or  an  area  along  a  wall  or  maybe 
 near  a  screen  room  that  you  kind  of  want 
 to  do  some  cool  impacts,  this  is  a  great 
 palm  that  stays  kind  of  narrow  and 
 really  kind  of  crowns  on  itself.  So 
 you'll  have  a  leaf  on  leaf  and  it  really 
 can  be  nice  and  vertical  and  you  can 
 keep  it  that  way.  You  can  fit  like  a  lot 
 of  palm  in  a  little  space  because  it's 
 not  going  to  widen  out  or  outrow  that 
 space.  So  very  very  narrow.  Trimming  on 
 it  is  super  super  easy.  You  can  see  that 
 it'll  have  a  yellow  leaf  or  a  brown 
 leaf.  And  when  that  happens,  all  you  do 
 is  you  take  your  loppers  or  your  nippers 
 and  then  you  just  clip  as  close  to  the 
 palm  base  as  possible.  So,  right  here 
 along  this  edge  is  kind  of  where  you 
 want  to  clip.  Hopefully,  you  can  get  a  a 
 decent  idea  to  see  what  one  clump  looks 
 like.  As  they  grow  together,  they  still 
 stay  real  real  vertical  and  work  in  a 
 space.  The  growth  habit  on  this  guy  is 
 super  slow  because  I've  got  a  lot  of 
 large  variety  palms  behind  me.  You  guys 
 who  especially  those  of  you  guys  who  are 
 new  to  Florida,  you'll  figure  out  in  the 
 palm  world,  in  the  plant  world,  one  of 
 the  first  questions  that  you  ask  all  the 
 garden  centers  is  how  big  does  it  get 
 and  how  fast  does  it  get  there?  Cuz  you 
 know,  you  can  like  go  to  bed  one  night 
 and  you  put  a  traveler's  palm  in,  it's 
 only  this  high  and  you  wake  up  the  next 
 morning  and  it's  this  high.  That's  how  a 
 lot  of  our  palms  are  in  Florida.  They  go 
 from  mini  monsters  to  big  monsters 
 pretty  pretty  fast.  So  when  you  can  find 
 a  tree  that  is  a  cool  looking  tree  in  a 
 small  size  and  it  stays  that  way  for  a 
 long  length  of  time  to  me  that  is  a 
 winter  winter  chicken  dinner  in  my  palm 
 garden  variety  book  any  single  day.  So 
 Penangga  Coronada  is  totally  one  of 
 those  perfect  palms  to  do.  It  loves  the 
 8212  palm  gain  fertilizer.  Hit  it  every 
 single  quarter.  I  hit  it  in  March,  June, 
 September,  and  then  December  if  it's 
 nice  and  warm  still  in  December,  which 
 it  usually  is  in  our  area.  hit  it  that 
 way  and  it  you  won't  have  problems  with 
 pests  or  bugs  or  the  cold  temps.  It'll 
 just  be  a  strong  strong  tree.  That's 
 what  I  do  with  all  my  tropicals  and  it 
 just  takes  the  cake,  you  guys.  So,  yeah. 
 So,  this  is  one  of  my  favorites.  So, 
 let's  hop  into  the  next  one.  All right, 
 you  guys.  So,  now  for  Bryce's  favorite 
 palm  in  our  whole  yard,  which  is  the 
 Capernicia  fencis.  This  palm  is 
 obviously  one  of  those  big  giant  fanlike 
 beautiful  species.  Very,  very  vertical, 
 very  upright.  Some  people  will  confuse 
 it  with  a  Bismar  palm,  which  is  also 
 beautiful.  However,  this  one  is  more 
 compact.  So,  at  the  trunk,  it  stays  nice 
 and  compact  at  the  center.  And  instead 
 of  it  widening  out  at  the  canopy  from 
 the  trunk,  it  actually  stays  real 
 vertical  to  the  trunk  itself.  So,  it 
 stays  compact  and  upright.  And  the  fans 
 almost  interlock  with  each  other  as  it 
 starts  to  open  up  and  bloom.  And  that 
 doesn't  change  even  when  it  gets  large. 
 Now,  this  tree  will  get  large.  It  does 
 take  a  long  time  unlike  the  bismar  palm. 
 But  you  can  kind  of  see  kind  of  the 
 pattern  that  we're  going  with.  Some  of 
 these  exotic,  some  of  these  rare  palm 
 trees  grow  exceptionally  slow,  which  I 
 think  is  part  of  what  makes  them  rare 
 because  they're  harder  to  find  in  the 
 nurseries  because  of  that  reason.  But 
 they  are  well  worth  it  because  if  you 
 got  tons  of  varieties  of  beautiful  fast 
 growing  palms  and  you  have  key  areas 
 that  you  kind  of  want  small  palms  with  a 
 dynamic  look  and  you  want  them  to  stay 
 that  way  for  a  long  period  of  time, 
 check  out  some  of  these  palms  in  this 
 video  because  these  are  things  that  are 
 have  been  in  my  garden  for  years  and 
 years  and  years.  And  then  you  can  kind 
 of  see  the  things  around  them  have 
 really  grown  up  while  these  guys  have 
 stayed  nice  and  compact  and  small.  Now 
 the  trimming  on  this  guy  is  about  the 
 same  as  it  would  be  a  Bismar.  You  know, 
 you  take  those  old  fronds.  It  is  not 
 self-cleaning.  You  lop  them  off  and  they 
 can  get  kind  of  large  in  size.  So,  as 
 they  get  bigger,  you're  going  to  have  to 
 have  a  maintenance  company  come  through 
 and  probably  trim  those  as  the  tree  gets 
 taller.  This  tree  will  grow  all  the  way 
 up  into  the  30ft  range.  So,  it  will  get 
 some  size,  but  I'll  be  long  and  gone  by 
 the  time  this  guy  gets  that  way  because 
 they  grow  so  darn  slow.  He's  been  in  the 
 ground  for  about  four  years  and  probably 
 has  put  maybe  a  foot  and  a  half  on.  You 
 can  really  see  how  long  it  takes  for 
 them  to  get  some  decent  size  to  them. 
 But  there  is  one  thing  I  wanted  to  add 
 on  this  particular  palm.  Because  those 
 fans  are  so  compact  and  tight,  they  can 
 act  as  kind  of  like  wind  sails  in  the 
 garden.  So  if  we're  getting  a  hurricane 
 or  if  we're  getting  some  heavy  storms  or 
 a  rainy  season,  then  you  want  to  make 
 sure  that  you  do  strap  that  tree  up  nice 
 and  tight.  So  this  tree  has  been  in  the 
 ground  a  very  long  time  like  I  said,  but 
 I  still  have  straps  on  it  to  help 
 support  it  because  that  canopy  is  almost 
 taller  than  the  trunk  itself.  So,  it's  a 
 little  topheavy,  which  makes  it  kind  of 
 a  unique  look  to  a  palm  because  it's 
 normally  the  opposite,  more  trunk  than 
 canopy.  But  because  this  one  is  situated 
 that  way,  it  can  actually  blow  over  or 
 lay  crooked  very,  very  easy.  So, 
 definitely  when  you  put  this  guy  in 
 young,  stake  him  nice  and  tight  with 
 four  stakes  with  some  rebar  in  the 
 ground  and  then  he'll  be  good  to  go. 
 Palm  fertilizer  is  super  important  with 
 this  guy  because,  of  course,  we  want 
 that  trunk.  We  want  him  to  be  a  solid 
 base,  a  solid  tree,  and  they're  rather 
 expensive.  So  you  want  to  make  sure  that 
 you  know  you  give  it  everything  it  needs 
 to  really  become  a  dense  and  heavily 
 rooted  tree  in  a  garden.  This  is  a 
 perfect  perfect  palm  for  a  centerpiece 
 kind  of  like  how  I  have  it  shown  here. 
 All right  you  guys.  So  for  the  next  rare 
 find  is  the  pendo  palm  or  also  known  as 
 the  jelly  palm.  Now  I  know  what  you're 
 thinking.  You're  thinking,  "Well,  that's 
 not  really  a  rare  palm  species."  And 
 it's  technically  not.  But  what  does  make 
 this  one  a  little  bit  more  unique  is 
 it's  multi-  trunk  to  it.  This  is  a 
 triple  version.  They  come  in  triple, 
 double,  and  of  course  they  come  in 
 singles.  And  I've  seen  them  in  quads. 
 I've  just  not  had  a  chance  to  plant  a 
 quad  yet.  So,  but  this  triple  variety  is 
 just  so  fabulous,  so  unique.  I  think 
 that  it's  the  perfect  tree  for  the 
 corner  of  my  property.  This  is  coming 
 right  to  the  sideyard  entrance  of  my 
 garden.  So,  it  really  does  a  great  job 
 of  kind  of  anchoring  the  edge  of  my 
 property  line.  This  is  a  tree  that  you 
 see  when  you  first  pull  right  into  my 
 driveway.  So,  I  think  it's  just  fabulous 
 for  that  little,  you  know,  that  anchor 
 spot  in  the  garden.  I'm  going  to  kind  of 
 go  into  the  middle  here  to  show  you, 
 give  you  a  good  point  of  reference  about 
 how  big  this  tree  is.  So,  this  is  the 
 center  of  this  tree  that  I'm  standing 
 into.  This  is  the  mounding  area.  These 
 trunks  themselves  kind  of  compete  with 
 each  other.  So,  it  causes  the  tree 
 canopy  to  be  a  little  bit  more  vertical, 
 a  little  bit  more  straight,  and  then  a 
 little  curl  at  the  edges  of  the  palm 
 frrons  where  if  it's  a  single,  you'll 
 notice  that  they'll  be  a  little  bit  more 
 wider,  a  little  bit  more  open,  more  like 
 a  bouquet  style  where  it's  tight  in  the 
 middle  and  then  really  fans  out.  But 
 because  of  this  particular  variety, 
 they're  more  vertical  and  more  linear 
 this  way,  which  I  think  to  me  makes  it 
 have  a  whole  another  look.  They  have  a 
 silverish  tone  to  the  leaf,  which  I 
 think  is  really  cool,  especially  when 
 you  have  a  lot  of  greenery  in  your 
 garden.  That  bright  silver  tone  really 
 shows  off  in  a  palm  tree.  I  think  kind 
 of  like  the  copperia  fences  that  we  just 
 looked  at.  This  is  also  not  a 
 self-cleaning  tree.  It  is  one  you  will 
 have  to  cut.  So,  you  will  have  to  cut 
 this  tree.  some  of  the  brown  or  older 
 limbs.  I've  got  a  few  of  those  in  here 
 that  I  have  to  actually  get  in  here  and 
 do.  You  can  trim  it  with,  you  know,  your 
 loppers  or  you  can  use  a  saw  and  kind  of 
 cut  it  at  an  angle  here  to  kind  of  give 
 it  more  of  an  interesting  trunk  base. 
 Kind  of  cutting  those  boots  at  an  angle, 
 giving  you  kind  of  more  of  that  diamond 
 cut  type  of  look.  But  they  grow  so  so 
 slow  that  you  really  only  have  to  do 
 that  at  the  most.  I  mean,  you  could  do 
 it  once  a  year.  You  could  probably  do  it 
 once  every  two  years  because  it's  just 
 such  a  slow  growing  tree.  So,  I  rarely 
 have  to  get  in  here  and  cut  on  this 
 tree.  I  almost  forget  about  it.  Just 
 like  you  see  here,  I've  got  one  or  two 
 brown  fronds  that  probably  need  to  go 
 because  I  always  forget  to  cut  it.  So, 
 but  yeah,  this  is  a  great  great  focal 
 point  tree.  It  grows  about  a  foot  a  year 
 if  you're  lucky  in  really  really  good 
 condition.  So,  super  super  slow  growing, 
 stays  where  you  put  it,  nice  anchor 
 point,  and  definitely  a  tree  worth 
 having.  This  guy  can  handle  freezing 
 temperatures.  I  have  seen  them  planted 
 all  the  way  into  Georgia  into  the  South 
 Carolina  area.  So,  for  you  guys  who  are 
 in  those  tough  zones,  pendop  palms  are 
 ideal  for  that.  and  so  are  the  next  two 
 palms  that  we're  going to  talk  about. 
 But  now  for  the  next  two  trees  in 
 today's  video.  I  do  not  have  them  yet  in 
 my  garden.  I'm  sure  I'm  going  to  find  a 
 spot  for  them  somewhere,  but  I  don't 
 have  them  yet.  But  I've  definitely 
 thought  they  were  worth  mentioning  and

 we're  going  to  hop  on  over  there  and 
 share  those  with  you  guys.  So,  let's  go. 
 All right,  you  guys.  So,  we  are  here  at 
 the  nursery  and  this  is  one  of  my 
 favorites  amongst  many  of  my  other 
 favorites.  This  is  the  Kentopsis  palm. 
 It  is  a  gorgeous  palm  tree.  Now,  I  tend 
 to  get  them  in  this  kind  of  size.  Um, 
 they're  commonly  found  this  size  whether 
 they're  30  gallon,  45  gallon  or  in  the 
 ground  just  like  you  see  here. 
 Technically  a  self-cleaning  palm,  but  I 
 will  tell  you  most  of  the  time  you  will 
 have  to  trim  that  frrawn.  It  will  be 
 self-cleaning  after  a  long  period  of 
 time  after  the  weight  on  that  limbs 
 tends  to  put  pressure  to  release,  but 
 that  tends  to  take  a  long  time.  So  I 
 would  say  most  of the  time  I  tell  my 
 clients  to  just  go  ahead  and  cut  that 
 limb  when  it  turns  brown.  But  overall  I 
 think  this  is  a  very  very  cool  tree.  It 
 has  a  beautiful  upright  canopy  to  it. 
 When  it  gets  some  size  that  canopy 
 really  opens  up.  Also  keeps  the 
 stiffness  to  those  fronds.  So  it's  not  a 
 real  heavily  wavy  or  soft  lacy  kind  of 
 tree  like  the  next  tree  we're  going  to 
 talk  about.  This  one  is  more  vertical, 
 more  dynamic,  more  upright.  So  I  think 
 that  that's  what  makes  it  look  so  exotic 
 because  everybody's  like  that's  not  an 
 Alexander,  is  it?  or  what  is  that?  The 
 leaf  itself  on  this  tree  is  just  so 
 magnanimous.  It's  so  big  and  so  broad 
 for  such  a  small  frame  tree.  I  think  it 
 makes  it  look  so  cool  in  a  garden.  Now, 
 you  can  plant  these  like  you  would  plant 
 a  foxtail  palm  and  stagger  them  in  and 
 just  kind  of  like  rows  in  the  garden  and 
 they  can  kind  of  really  really  give  you 
 that  palm  row  kind  of  feel  because  of 
 just  what  kind  of  stature  they  bring  to 
 the  garden.  What's  nice  about  this 
 particular  tree  for  such  an  exotic  palm, 
 it  is  very  cold  tolerant.  So  this  can 
 get  into  the  20s  which  is  ideal  for  any 
 of  us  flidians.  You  know  if  you  want  to 
 incorporate  some  palms  of  a  little  bit 
 north  of  us  then  this  is  an  ideal  palm 
 to  do.  Now  it  doesn't  like  it  for  any 
 length  of  time.  So  it  can't  be  like  in 
 Georgia  or  the  Carolinas  but  your  kind 
 of  your  cut  off  point  I  would  say  would 
 be  you  know  just  northn  north  Florida. 
 So  this  is  great  palm  to  have  if  you 
 don't  want  something  growing  too  too 
 fast.  This  palm  is  about  a  foot  and  a 
 half  to  two  foot  a  year.  So  a  little 
 faster  than  the  last  few  palms  that  we 
 talked  about  but  overall  it  is  a  um  slow 
 grower.  It  loves  palm  gain.  So,  I  use 
 8212  palm  gain  fertilizer  on  this  guy 
 four  times  a  year  and  help  keep  these 
 leaves  nice  and  dark  green.  You  can  tell 
 in  this  particular  setting  that  it's  in 
 the  ground  and  it  needs  a  shot  of 
 fertilizer.  Has  a  little  bit  of 
 potassium  deficiency.  So,  hitting  it 
 with  some  granular  this  time  of  year  is 
 going  to  be  ideal  for  the  grower.  If  you 
 guys  find  it  in  a  potted  location  or  at 
 a  nursery  in  a  pot  35  or  45gallon,  don't 
 hesitate  to  get  it  cuz  they're  usually 
 gorgeous  and  dark  green  in  a  pot  because 
 it's  really  contained  and  I  know  that 
 they  do  their  great  job  of  fertilizing 
 them.  But  this  is  a  fabulous  tree  to 
 incorporate.  It  is  middle  of  the  row 
 when  it  comes  to  growth  and  it  will  get 
 nice  and  tall.  So  definitely  leave  some 
 room  for  that.  But  it's  got  a  gorgeous 
 canopy  to  it.  Nice  upright  strong  fronds 
 that  really  hold  their  own.  But  now 
 let's  pop  over  right  across  the  hall 
 from  here  and  uh  look  at  the  next  tree 
 in  the  grouping.  This  is  the  mule  palm. 
 This  tree  itself  is  absolutely  just  a 
 fun  tree  to  work  with.  It  is  a  cross 
 between  the  pendo  palm  and  the  queen 
 palm.  Now,  the  queen  palm  has  had  its 
 share  of  troubles  with  it's  had  fungus 
 issues.  It's  had  problems  over  the  last 
 few  years.  So,  it's  definitely  not  a 
 palm  that  I  incorporate  anymore  into 
 gardens.  However,  this  cross  species  has 
 really,  really  taken  to  its  own.  It 
 makes  a  fabulous  intermediate  tree.  So, 
 if  you're  looking  for  long-term 
 coverage,  a  big  frond  canopy  with  a 
 short  trunk,  this  is  a  great  tree  to  do 
 that.  What  it  carries  over  from  one  of 
 its  parents,  which  is  the  pendo  palm,  is 
 that  short  base  and  that  bigger  frond 
 canopy.  So  you  can  kind  of  see  that's 
 exactly  what  this  guy  does.  It  has  a 
 short  bulbous  base  on  the  bottom  and 
 then  most  of  the  tree  itself  is  frrawn. 
 Now  that  is  going  to  carry  over  through 
 most  of  its  life.  So  it  will  continue  to 
 get  bigger  as  most  palm  trees  do.  But  it 
 also  have  the  ratio  would  be  more  frunk 
 which  is  ideal  for  a  lot  of  areas 
 especially  those  of  you  guys  who  have 
 few  lines  of  water  and  you  kind  of  want 
 to  keep  that  understory  a  little  bit 
 clean  but  you  need  something  really 
 dense  and  full  above  to  kind  of  block 
 out  those  roof  lines.  I  get  a  lot  of 
 those  questions  in  the  comments.  So, 
 this  is  an  ideal  tree  to  do  that  with. 
 You  know,  get  one  that  has  about  4  foot 
 of  clearance  if  you  can  and  then  you 
 have  that  canopy  and  it  stays  that  way 
 for  a  long  period  of  time.  This  tree 
 grows  6  foot  to  max  1  foot  per  year.  So, 
 very  very  slow  growing  tree  in  general. 
 It  can  be  a  tree  that  gets  easily 
 deficient  if  your  soil  is  not  very  good. 
 So,  you  definitely  want  to  use  some  good 
 compost  with  it  and  then  keep  it 
 fertilized  regularly  with  that  8212  and 
 it's  going  to  be  fabulous.  It  has  a  very 
 very  dark  green  coloring  to  the  leaf  and 
 very  cold  tolerant.  So  this  is  like  its 
 parent  which  is  the  queen  palm  and  the 
 pendo  palm.  Both  of  them  cold  tolerant 
 palm.  So  it  really  allows  you  to  plant 
 this  these  guys  all  the  way  up  into  the 
 Georgia  area.  I  mean  they  these  can 
 handle  into  the  20s  and  take  it  like  a 
 champ.  And  they're  a  great  intermediate 
 tree  to  incorporate  with  some  of  your 
 taller  palm  trees.  So  they  can  handle 
 our  heat  as  far  south  as  the  Keys  all 
 the  way  up  north  to  North  Florida  and 
 beyond.  So  definitely  a  good  palm  to 
 work  with.  It  is  technically  hitting  my 
 rare  palm  species  because  they  are  hard 
 to  find.  Even  for  instance  where  we  are 
 here  in  Bureau  Beach,  we've  got  one  row 
 of  these  that  are  remaining.  And  this  is 
 a  huge  palm  nursery  with  thousands  of 
 foxtails  and  queens  and  other  varieties 
 of  species  of  trees.  But  the  Kentopsis 
 and  the  meal  palms,  we  actually  only 
 have  one  row  left  and  there's  barely  any 
 left  that  are  available  in  this  two 
 particular  rows.  So,  you're  going  to  see 
 that  across  nurseries  that  you  look  for. 
 And  I  think  the  common  denominator  is 
 the  slow  growth  of  these  rare  trees. 
 Obviously,  the  dynamic  fronds  that  they 
 offer,  their  ability  to  handle  some  of 
 the  colder  temps,  the  dwarfism  on  many 
 of  them  where  they  just  kind  of  over 
 time  just  kind  of  stay  more  compact  and 
 low  to  the  ground.  Those  are  all  really, 
 really  big  bonuses  in  our  palm  world. 
 So,  that  makes  them  a  little  bit  more 
 exotic,  a  little  harder  to  find  because 
 takes  them  a  little  bit  more  time  to  get 
 established.  whether  it's  a  grower  or  a 
 nursery  that  you're  picking  them  up. 
 Take  some  time  to  cultivate  them  and  get 
 to  them  to  where  they're  up  for  sale  and 
 ready  and  looking  their  best.  So,  I 
 think  that's  kind  of  what  classifies 
 these  last  two  as  more  of  your  rare 
 finds.  So,  you  guys  will  have  to  let  me
