 log  in,  put  in  your  zip  code,  put  in  the 
 plant  of  choice,  and  find  out  what 
 nursery  nearby  might  have  it.  So,  you 
 can  incorporate  some  of  these  beauties 
 and  not  have  to  hit  the  road  and  spend 
 your  gas  finding  them  the  hard  way.  So, 
 hopefully  that  does  help.  If  you  guys 
 enjoyed  today's  video,  please  hit  that 
 like  button.  And  of  course,  if  you 
 haven't  subscribed,  I  don't  know  where 
 you've  been.  Please  subscribe  because 
 you  will  see  us  every  single  weekend  in 
 your  feed.  We  post  every  single  weekend 
 with  content  just  like  this.  And  we  will 
 pop  in  a  video  over  here  of  our  last 
 garden  tour,  which  was  a  beautiful 
 butterfly  garden.  So,  if  you  like  those 
 happily  winged  friends,  you  might  really 
 enjoy  this  video.  Take  care.

---

 Well,  hello  gardeners.  Welcome  back. 
 Today  we  are  in  my  backyard  yet  again, 
 but  with  really,  really  good  reason. 
 Today  I  want  to  share  with  you  guys  some 
 things  that  gosh,  I  wish  I  would  have 
 done  in  my  backyard  space  right  away  in 
 the  part  of  my  planning  of  what  we  were 
 going  to  create  in  this  space.  This 
 might  be  really,  really  helpful  to  you 
 guys  to  either  incorporate  right  off  the 
 bat,  you  know,  put  it  in  your  planning 
 stages  to  save  you  some  time,  money,  and 
 having  to  redo  some  things  in  the 
 future.  These  are  four  things  that  I 
 just  kind  of  wish  I  would  have  realized 
 earlier  on  in  the  stages.  And  I  thought 
 as  a  landscape  designer,  if  I  had  made 
 these  mistakes,  then  might  be  something 
 that  that  you  may  have  overlooked,  too. 
 So,  those  of  you  guys  who  are  new  to 
 gardening,  I  hope  this  really  helps  you 
 guys  out.  You  guys  know  if  you  watch  my 
 channel,  you  know  I  am  a  landscape 
 designer  of  over  25  years.  So,  if  you 
 are  looking  to  have  some  landscaping 
 work  done,  you're  in  the  Treasure  or 
 Space  Coast  area,  please  reach  out  to 
 us.  Those  of  you  guys  who  are  outside 
 that  area,  we  do  also  have  a  designonly 
 service  as  well  as  a  virtual  service.  I 
 will  be  sure  to  put  all  of  that  on  the 
 screen  so  you  guys  can  screenshot  that 
 bad  boy.  But  for  now,  let's  move  right 
 into  the  first  tip.  Those  of  you  guys 
 who  have  seen  my  backyard  tour  know  that 
 it  is  jampacked  full  of  palms  and  trees 
 and  offers  not  only  just  that  beauty 
 that  I  want  to  see  every  time  I  walk  out 
 my  backd  door  space,  but  it  offers  me 
 privacy.  tons  and  tons  and  tons  of 
 privacy,  which  is  what  I  look  for  in  my 
 typical  suburban  front  yard,  backyard 
 situation  that  I  have.  But  at  the  same 
 time,  since  I've  utilized,  as  my  husband 
 says,  every  square  inch  of  my  yard  for 
 plants  and  trees,  there  is  very,  very 
 little  space  for  concealing  the  fallen 
 tree  debris,  any  kind  of  clippings  or 
 cutings  or  anything  like  that.  We  don't 
 have  a  big  storage  area.  We're  not 
 allowed  to  have  sheds  here.  So,  as  far 
 as  garbage  cans  go,  we  don't  have,  you 
 know,  tons  of  them  along  our  sideyard  to 
 house  all  that  material.  So,  what  I  wish 
 I  would  have  done  from  the  very 
 beginning  was  create  a  space  that  could 
 house  that  material.  Since  then,  I've 
 cleared  out  a  spot.  So,  I  thought  if  I 
 shared  that  with  you  guys,  then  in  your 
 planning  stages  of  your  buffer  planting, 
 you  might  take  a  part  of  that  buffer. 
 So,  if  it's  very  similar  to  my  backyard 
 space,  which  is  a  pretty  much  a  buffer 
 from  one  corner  of  the  backyard  to  the 
 other  corner  of  the  backyard,  you  might 
 move  one  corner  up  and  then  create  just 
 a  little  nook,  just  a  little  spot  just 
 behind  there  that  when  you're  walking 
 through  your  garden  and  you've  got  some 
 fallen  tree  debris  and  some  brown  fronds 
 that  you're  going  to  absolutely  see  in 
 your  garden,  and  you  grab  those  guys, 
 you  walk  them  around  that  spot,  pile 
 them  in  that  section.  And  I  have  a 
 lovely  lawn  maintenance  guy  who  I  pay  an 
 extra  $20  a  month  to,  and  every  single 
 week  when  he's  here  doing  my  natural 
 clippings,  he  will  grab  that  debris, 
 take  it  with  him,  so  I  don't  have  to 
 worry  about  hauling  that  and  cutting  it 
 up,  putting  it  into  the  trash,  whatnot. 
 It's  just  a  common  thing  for  them  to  do. 
 I  encourage  all  my  clients  to  do  it,  and 
 they're  usually  like,  "Oh  my  gosh, 
 that's  absolutely  great  because  I  didn't 
 know what  I  was  going to  do  with  all  of 
 this  debris."  Because  we  also  live  in  a 
 community  just  like  you  guys.  So,  let  me 
 share  with  you  guys  where  my  little 
 secret  spot  is.  So,  we  are  going  to  walk 
 right  through  my  little  arbor.  This  is 
 brand  new,  by  the  way.  Oh  my  goodness, 
 you  guys.  I  cannot  wait  for  this 
 Confederate  jasmine  to  take  off.  But 
 this  is  the  end  of  my  property  line.  You 
 can  see  I  have  a  little  seating  section 
 here  that's  going  to  be  perfect  for  for 
 when  this  goes  into  full  bloom.  New 
 little  mushrooms.  I  just  think  they're 
 the  cutest  thing  ever.  You  guys,  I  will

 plugging,  you  know,  local  companies 
 where  you  can  because,  you  know,  got  to 
 support  our  locals,  right?  All right. 
 So,  this  is  my  spot  right  back  here. 
 This  is  going  to  be  in  the  future,  I 
 think,  going  to  be  another  secret  garden 
 now  that  things  have  really  grown  up. 
 This  is  our  property  line  here.  So,  we 
 put  up  a  Kucia  hedge  right  on  the 
 property  line.  And  then  this  spot  right 
 where  I'm  standing  is  was  plantings.  And 
 then  I  found  out  that  I  gosh,  where  am  I 
 going to  put  all  these  clippings?  So,  I 
 was  constantly  fighting  with  them  in  the

 back  of  the  truck,  whatnot.  They're 
 always  in  the  way.  So,  we  cleared  out  a 
 section  back  here  and  kept  it  nice  and 
 clean.  This  has  always  been  a  little  bit 
 of  an  alleyway  for  trimming  the  backside 
 of  my  burm,  but  now  it  really  just 
 serves  as  a  perfect  spot  for  all  of  that 
 debris.  We  leave  it  all  here,  piled  up 
 weekly.  They  come  pick  it  up  and  voila, 
 no  one's  the  wiser.  You  can  see  that  I 
 have  a  little  collection  over  there  of 
 some  debris  that  fell  from  the  front 
 section.  Now  that  things  have  really 
 grown  up,  we've  cleared  some  things  out 
 from  back  here.  I  totally  see  this  as  my 
 little  secret  jungle  walkway.  I'm  really 
 thinking  about  incorporating  a  little 
 bit  of  stone,  maybe  some  stepping 
 stones,  maybe  a  little  bit  of  lower 
 plant  material  to  the  left  side  of  the 
 walkway  and  creating  just  a  little  bit 
 of  a  secret  garden  between  the  two 
 spaces.  So,  this  is  the  back  side  of  my 
 buffer.  It  has  now  gotten  to  the  point 
 where  things  have  grown  up  enough  to  see 
 that  happening,  to  see  that  actually 
 come  to  fruition.  So,  I  do  think  that 
 it's  time  to  plant  phase  30.  So,  then 
 this  will  be  a  brand  new  planting  as  a 
 cool  meandering  secret  little  walkway 
 path  kind  of  coming  through  this  space. 
 So,  I  think  that's  going  to  be  cool. 
 But,  but  that'll  be  in  an  upcoming 
 video.  However,  that  being  said,  I'll 
 also  make  sure  to  keep  a  little  spot  for 
 my  debris.  So,  I  always  have  that  little 
 hidden  away,  keeping  everything  nice  and 
 tucked  and  tidy  and  clean  spot  for  all 
 of  my  tree  debris.  So,  for  the  second 
 thing  that  I  would  say  that  I  regret  in 
 my  garden  is  not  doing  this  sooner.  So, 
 you  guys  know  from  earlier  videos  from 
 the  past  years  that  I  had  pretty  much 
 grass  in  this  backyard  space.  Obviously, 
 we  always  had  the  big  buffer  and  we've 
 added  to  it  over  the  years.  The  grass 
 was  one  of  those  things  that  as  a 
 landscaper  I  could  not  get  to  grow.  It 
 would  have  its  good  days.  It  would  have 
 its  bad  days,  but  a  lot  of  the  times  it 
 just  had  so  much  issues  with  kind  of 
 staying  mucky  and  muddy  and  turning  into 
 weeds  and  battling  fungus.  You  know,  we 
 have  some  filtered  light  here  and  we  get 
 some  rainfall.  And  of  course,  it  is  a 
 lower  section  of  my  garden.  Water  did 
 flow  to  this  area.  So  now  when  I  see 
 clients  who  have  a  very  similar 
 situation  and  their  plan  is  for  the 
 future  to  have  their  backyard  pretty 
 much  a  garden,  I  ask  them,  "Do  you  think 
 that  you  might  utilize  using  stone 
 versus  grass  as  your  main  base,  your 
 main  walkway?"  And  fortunately,  a  lot  of 
 them  are  like,  "Yeah,  I  kind  of  like 
 that  idea."  I  did  not  initially.  I  was 
 not  sure  if  I  was  comfortable  with 
 having  no  grass  at  all  in  the  backyard. 
 I  waited  and  tried  sawing  here  multiple 
 times  before  that  was  the  case.  If  I 
 were  to  go  back  in  time,  it  would  be 
 totally  to  take  out  the  grass  day  one 
 and  create  a  nice  pathway.  This  rock 
 backyard  along  this  swale  area  has  been 
 clean,  has  been  easy  to  maintain,  has 
 been  a  just  a  no  fuss,  no  mus  kind  of 
 situation.  It  has  been  ideal.  I  wish  I 
 would  have  done  that  from  the  very 
 beginning  instead  of  wasting  thousands 
 on  resolding  year  after  year  several 
 several  times  because  this  has  been 
 ideal.  also  kind  of  adds  a  little  bit  of 
 whimsy  to  the  garden.  I  love  the  fact 
 that  I  have  a  nice  little  meandering 
 pathway.  In  the  future,  as  my  budget 
 allows,  I  think  I'm  going  to  create  some 
 maybe  flag  stone  leading  through  the 
 middle  of  it  to  really  kind  of  create 
 that  and  incorporate  maybe  some  boulders 
 a  little  further  out  to  maybe  narrow 
 that  pathway  to  kind  of  make  it,  you 
 know,  a  little  bit  more  intimate.  But 
 that's  going  to  come  over  time.  And 
 that's  what's  great  about  landscaping  is 
 these  things  grow.  Now,  if  you  guys  are 
 in  a  situation  where  I  was  years  ago  and 
 you're  starting  off,  consider  doing  a 
 nice  gravel  pathway,  letting  your 
 landscaping  encroach  right  into  that 
 space,  and  then  just  having  to  not  worry 
 about  any  kind  of  fuss.  On  average,  you 
 get  about  100  square  ft  per  yard  when  it 
 comes  to  gravel  or  stone.  And  so,  if  you 
 price  that  out,  you  kind  of  have  a 
 better  idea  of  how  much  that's  going  to 
 cost  and  how  much  of  that  will  be  a 
 savings  or  not  a  savings  for  you  long 
 term  with  your  maintenance  company.  But 
 for  me,  it  has  definitely  been  a  savings 
 because  I've  again  resolded  this  yard 
 countless  times  trying  to  make  it  a  nice 
 healthy  green  grass  backyard,  whatever 
 that  is  in  Florida.  So,  that  would  be 
 something  that  was  definitely  a  fail  on 
 my  part.  I've  come  to  realize  I  wish  I 
 would  have  done  a  lot  sooner. 
 All right,  you  guys.  So,  for  the  next 
 thing  that  that  I  think  I  regret,  this 
 one's  kind  of  a  tricky  one.  So,  I  have 
 always  wanted  privacy  in  my  yard,  as  you 
 guys  can  tell  from  the  backyard. 
 However,  the  front  yard  came  years 
 later.  I  enjoy  sitting  by  my  fish  pond. 
 I  enjoy  having  my  coffee  in  the  morning. 
 Enjoy  walking  through  my  garden  and 
 feeling  like  a  resort  or  feeling  like 
 it's  a  botanical  garden.  I  walk  through. 
 That's  why  I  have  all  these  pathways 
 that  lead  me  throughout  the  whole  space 
 because  that's  what  I  want  to  feel  like 
 when  I'm  in  my  own  space.  I  don't  want 
 to  always  have  to  take  a  vacation  to 
 feel  like  I'm  on  vacation.  I  enjoy  my 
 neighbors,  but  I  kind  of  wanted  a  little 
 setback,  a  little  bit  of  privacy  in  my 
 own  space.  And  I  had  concerns  about 
 doing  that  because  I  am  not  in  some  big 
 mansion  on  an  estate  somewhere.  This  is 
 typically  a  very  suburban  yard.  My 
 neighbors  have  your  typical  front  floor 
 yard,  backyard.  It's  just  your  typical 
 neighborhood.  And  so  creating  a  bordered 
 fence  of  any  kind  was  kind  of  a  not 
 really  approved  thing  for  my  HOA.  You 
 know,  having  a  big  walled  fence  was  not, 
 you  know,  I  can  see  why  that  wouldn't  be 
 appealing.  When  I  mentioned  to  them  I 
 was  thinking  about  doing  a  Kousia  wall, 
 kind  of  encompassing  my  front  yard  space 
 to  make  it  more  private,  adding  a  couple 
 gates  and  then  kind  of  softening  it  with 
 a  hedge,  they  were  like,  "Okay,  we're 
 going  to  work  with  you."  Cuz  you 
 apparently  know  landscape.  I  was  a 
 little  bit  concerned  about  doing  that. 
 So,  I  was  very  hesitant.  So,  I  did  not 
 do  that  for  years,  even  though  I  wanted 
 to  do  it  right  away.  Now  that  we've  done 
 it,  it  has  been  such  a  blessing.  It  is 
 probably  my  favorite  thing  in  my  whole 
 yard.  We  have  entertained  in  this  space. 
 We've  pitched  to  tents  out  here.  We  have 
 had  dinner  parties  out  here  on  this 
 front  little  slice  of  our  grass  area.  We 
 have  had  fire  pits  with  family  and  just 
 kind  of  enjoy.  This  has  been  such  a 
 great  spot  because  I  feel  like  it's  so 
 private.  The  hedge  has  solar  lights  that 
 run  through  it  at  night.  So,  it  feels 
 just  so  whimsical.  It  really  does  bring 
 together  what  the  backyard  does.  Now, 
 the  front  yard  does  that,  too.  And  I 
 really  feel  like  that  gave  me  the 
 privacy  that  I  needed.  and  I  was  a 
 little  bit  concerned  about  being  able  to 
 do  that  in  what's  typically  a  pretty 
 small  ordinary  house.  So,  those  of  you 
 guys  who  are  thinking  about  doing  that, 
 but  you're,  you  know,  you're  not  in  a 
 big  estate  or  you're  not  in  a  mansion, 
 hopefully  this  serves  as  a  okay  to  you 
 guys.  This  is  something  that  I've  done 
 and  I  love.  Do  not  regret  it  for  one 
 second.  And  not  only  that,  I  encourage 
 it  to  my  clients.  I'm  like,  if  you  guys 
 you're  garden  people,  you're  my  people. 
 You  want  to  be  surrounded  by  your 
 tropical  landscape  and  you  want  to  use 
 every  bit  of  square  footage  of  your 
 yard.  Do  that  because  this  becomes  a 
 wall  for  you  to  enjoy.  Then  you  can 
 landscape  in  front  of  it  and  landscape 
 behind  it  for  your  neighbors  and  to  the 
 inside  of  it  for  yourself.  And  it  serves 
 such  dual  duty.  It's  just  such  an  ideal 
 thing  to  do.  We  have  limitations.  Right 
 where  I'm  standing  is  my  septic  tank.  So 
 there  was  no  planting  of  any  kind  that 
 can  be  done  here.  So  you'll  notice  that 
 I  put  my  favorite  trees  which  are 
 buganveillia  trees.  I  had  to  put  them  in 
 pots  mainly  because  of  the  septic  tank. 
 And  then  secondly,  I  really  don't  like 
 putting  bugilia  trees  in  the  ground 
 because  they  can  be  crazy  as  a  lot  of 
 you  flidians  know  it.  They  can,  you 
 know,  just  kind  of  go  to  town.  But  in  a 
 pot,  they're  controlled,  they're 
 condensed,  and  they  bloom  so  much  more 
 like  this.  I  hate  that  I'm  sharing  this 
 video  today  with  you  guys.  We  literally 
 just  trimmed  the  Kucia  hedge  and  the 
 buganillas  yesterday.  But  I  know  you 
 guys  as  gardeners  can  see  right  through 
 that.  You  know  that  June  is  the  time 
 period  where  everything  gets  that  really 
 heavy,  ugly  cut  back  and  then  it's 
 beautiful  for  the  rest  of  the  summer.  So 
 definitely  if  you're  thinking  about 
 creating  a  walled  privacy  buffer  for 
 yourself  and  you  can  only  use  something 
 like  a  hedge,  you  might  not  be  able  to 
 use  tons  and  tons  of  layers  to  create 
 that  because  of  the  space  that  you're 
 working  with.  Maybe  you  too  have  a 
 septic  tank.  Maybe  your  neighborhood 
 doesn't  allow  a  bunch  of  palms  and  trees 
 to  the  front  of  the  house.  Maybe  you 
 want  more  of  a  clean  line  landscape  like 
 you  see  here.  Those  are  great  reasons  to 
 incorporate  a  walled  hedge  like  this. 
 Kucia  is  my  favorite.  My  second  favorite 
 is  pod  carpus.  It's  what  I  have  between 
 my  two  gates  because  it  can  stay  super 
 super  narrow.  Um  it  takes  a  little  while 
 for  them  to  get  established  unlike  the 
 Kousia.  But  once  they  become 
 established,  they  turn  into  that  green 
 dark  dark  green  wall.  And  I've  done  two 
 gates  on  either  side  of  that  to  really 
 kind  of  help  create  that,  you  know,  very 
 estatelike  feel  to  what  is  technically  a 
 small  entrance  way  to  my  home. 
 So,  we're  going  to  walk  out  quickly. 
 So,  we're  now  outside  on  my  driveway 
 area.  This  is  what  my  neighbors  see. 
 It's  also  Bryce.  I'm  sure  my  neighbors 
 wouldn't  mind  if  you  got  kind  of  got  a 
 pan  of  what  the  typical  homes  look  like 
 in  my  little  suburban  single  street 
 community.  We  are  a  modest  home  in 
 Bureau  Beach  and  this  is  the  front  of 
 that  space.  I  kept  it  clean.  I  kept  it 
 tidy.  I  kept  it  neat.  Of  course,  it's  a 
 little  neater  than  normal  because  again, 
 yesterday  everything  got  a  severe 
 haircut,  but  you  can  see  how  this  wall 
 kind  of  curves  in  and  out.  So,  it's  not 
 exactly  straight.  I  tried  to  work  with 
 what  I  had  to  work  with  to  make  it  look 
 attractive  from  the  inside.  There's  some 
 curvature  leaning  in  and  leaning  out. 
 And  I  did  little  pop  outs  of  key 
 features.  This  is  my  son's  favorite 
 plant,  which  is  the  blue  agave.  I  love 
 this  triple  Christmas  palm.  It's  just 
 been  so  such  a  stature  palm  in  the 
 garden.  And  so  it's  the  centerpiece  to 
 the  wall  and  just  kind  of  offers  a 
 little  bit  of  division  with  some  small 
 plantings  underneath.  And  of  course, 
 privacy  above  all.  It's  exactly  when 
 we're  inside  there,  you  do  not  see  a  car 
 unless  it  is  UPS  or  FedEx.  You  do  not 
 see  anything  beyond  that  point,  which  is 
 so  nice  because  I  can  go  outside  in  my 
 pajamas,  you  know,  a  cup  of  coffee  and 
 not  have  to  worry  about  waving  to  every 
 single  neighbor  that  comes  through 
 walking  their  dog.  I  swear  that  sounds 
 terrible,  but  I  I  don't  know.  I  just 
 enjoy  my  Saturdays  until  I'm  ready  to 
 engage.  A  lot  of  people  are  that  way,  so 
 I'm  hoping  you  guys  are  that  way,  too. 
 No  judgment.  All  right,  you  guys.  So, 
 we're  going  to  jump  into  the  last  tip. 
 So,  you  guys,  last  but  definitely  not 
 least,  is  irrigation.  So,  I  know  that 
 irrigation  is  obviously  an  important 
 part  to  a  Florida  landscape.  We 
 definitely  need  the  water.  It  keeps  the 
 plants  lush  and  thick  and  shiny,  and 
 it's  an  ideal  thing  to  incorporate  into 
 every  garden.  So,  I  ask  my  clients  to 
 make  sure  that's  a  priority  when  we're 
 doing  our  planting  and  planning  phases 
 that  we  are  incorporating  irrigation  to 
 make  that  happen.  However,  in  my  own 
 garden  years  and  years  and  years  ago,  I 
 did  an  initial  irrigation  system  like, 
 you  know,  traditional.  It's  going to  be 
 a  back  buffer.  So  I  did  some  heads  that 
 shot  out  towards  the  buffer  and  I 
 thought  voila  that  was  going  to  be  good. 
 Considering  that  I  had  a  couple  phases 
 in  mind.  The  original  plan  was  about 
 three  phases  and  we  were  done  and  that 
 was  I  don't know  15  16  years  ago.  We  are 
 now  probably  at  phase  if  I  were  to  count 
 10  12  somewhere  along  that  where  we've 
 added  incorporated  and  I  don't  even  see 
 that  changing  even  in  the  future.  So  if 
 you  guys  kind  of  have  a  general  plan  in 
 mind,  if  you  see  my  backyard  garden  and 
 it  kind  of  just  appeals  to  you,  you 
 think,  you  know,  over  time  I  would  like 
 to  create  that.  I  would  like  to  have 
 layers  and  layers  leaning  all  the  way 
 from  maybe,  you  know,  a  few  foot  from  my 
 foundation  out  to  the  rear  side  of  my 
 property.  Then  allocate  for  that  now.  It 
 is  an  ideal  time  to  do  that  before  all 
 of  this  vegetation  is  in  place.  And  if 
 you're  going  to  do  that,  definitely  do 
 that  on  stand  pipe.  A  lot  of  typical 
 irrigation  is  set  with  like  little  small 
 heads.  They  go  all  the  way  from  the  4  in 
 to  the  6  in  to  the  12in  heads.  Usually 
 the  highest  of  them  all,  and  that's 
 originally  what  I  had.  However,  if  you 
 know  that  you're  going  to  do  a  layered 
 jungle  kind  of  garden,  go  ahead  and  get 
 the  large  fixed  stand  pipes  like  I  have 
 here.  So,  as  you  can  see,  I  have  6ft 
 stand  pipes.  They're  adjustable  pipes. 
 They're  pretty  much  PVC.  We  painted  them 
 green  when  we  put  them  in  and  then  put 
 standard  um  pop-up  nozzles  on  there.  So, 
 those  are  your  normal  typical  nozzles  on 
 those  particular  standup  pipes.  And  then 
 I  have  a  different  variety  in  two  other 
 places  that  coordinate  really,  really 
 well  and  complement  the  type  of 
 irrigation  that  I  need  for  my  backyard 
 space.  Having  the  standup  pipes  do  such 
 a  great  job.  Having  them  in  the  middle 
 of  the  bed  where  we  had  to  trench  after 
 the  fact  would  have  been  ideal  if  I  had 
 put  them  in  the  appropriate  spots  when  I 
 originally  planned  the  landscaping. 
 However,  I  wasn't  quite  sure  I  was  going 
 to  go  as  heavy  as  I  did.  So,  even  after 
 the  thought,  it  still  served  as  ideal. 
 It  would  have  saved  me  some  serious 
 money  if  I  done  it  right  from  the 
 beginning.  And  so,  that's  what  I  try  to 
 do  for  my  clients  now.  I  try  to  say, 
 "Okay,  if  this  is  phase  one,  what  does 
 phase  five  look  like?  Let's  plan  for 
 this  or  at least  lay  the  pipeline  for 
 it."  and  then  maybe  put  some  pop-up 
 heads  or  work  towards  that  as  we  go  so 
 we're  not  doing  things  twice.  Big  part 
 of  the  reason  why  I  do  that  is  because  I 
 have  done  that  myself  in  my  own  garden. 
 So  to  try  to  avoid  expense  for  my 
 clients,  we  make  sure  to  incorporate 
 that  when  we're  doing  our  plans.  The 
 next  set  of  piping  that  I  use  is  what's 
 here  in  the  landscape  beds.  And  I'm 
 going  to  turn  those  on  so  you  guys  can 
 kind  of  see  them  and  I'll  point  out  what 
 type  of  heads  they  are  so  that  way  you 
 guys  can  maybe  recommend  them  to  your 
 irrigation  guy.  So  these  here,  I  hope 
 you  can  see  that  in  the  picture.  These 
 are  the  12in  pop-up  spray.  So  they  go 
 flush  all  the  way  to  the  ground.  Spray 
 out,  come  up  12  in,  really  give  a  nice 
 fan.  Now,  this  guy  right  here  will  cover 
 about  a  12t  approximal  half  moon  shape 
 here.  So  it'll  go  from  this  corner  to 
 this  corner.  Spray  out  a  good  12t.  And  I 
 bet  if  I  were  to  measure  it  exactly,  it 
 looks  to  me  more  like  15.  but  really 
 does  get  a  nice  big  bit  of  coverage  in 
 this  whole  area  where  it  shoots  along 
 here  and  up  and  over.  I  love  this 
 irrigation  head,  but  not  as  much  as  the 
 one  I'm  going  to  show  you  next. 
 All right,  you  guys.  So,  this  mama  jama 
 right  here  is  an  MP  rotor.  It  is  a  water 
 saver  head.  Now,  it  does  it  sounds  like 
 a  water  saver  head,  but  it  does  take 
 some  pressure  to  do  it.  That's  why  I 
 only  have  a  few  of  these  in  the  garden. 
 But  if  you've  got  a  spot  where  you  need 
 mass  coverage,  pull  this  guy  back  and 
 really  let  him  fan  out.  I  mean,  look  how 
 far  he  sprays  into  the  bed.  Really 
 pushes  out  water,  really  puts  out  big 
 thick  jets  along  here.  And  it's  called 
 an  MP  rotor  head.  And  it  just 
 continuously  does  this  all  the  way 
 through.  The  adjustment  will  determine 
 how  far  it  goes  one  way  or  the  other. 
 It's  golden  when  it  comes  to  really 
 getting  a  lot  of  coverage  in  my  heads. 
 And  I  have  this  here  and  I  have  it  on 
 several  of  my  stand  pipes  that  I  need  to 
 really  push  out  some  significant  water. 
 But  MP  rotor  heads,  if  your  irrigation 
 guy  says  you  have  enough  pressure  to  use 
 that  in  your  garden,  go  that  route. 
 There  are  just  game  changers.  I  wish  I 
 could  use  them  for  my  entire 
 landscaping,  but  I  have  an  old  well  and 
 old  system,  so  I'm  working  with  what  I 
 got  to  work  with.  But  ideal.  I  love  the 
 water  they  push  out.  I  would  have  to 
 water  a  little  bit  less  if  I  had  these 
 all  through  my  garden.  And  so  I  put  them 
 in  the  most  appropriate  places.  Just 
 quick  tip  on  that.  If  you've  got  an  area 
 that  really  like  you  have a  lot  of 
 Sanchez  or  Java  whites  or  blaze  copper 
 leaf  things  that  really  like  a  little 
 bit  more  water  than  others,  put  these 
 kind  of  heads  in  that  particular  spot 
 because  the  other  section  of  the  garden 
 like  buganilas  and  things  that  oleanders 
 things  that  don't  need  that  much  water, 
 you  can  put  regular  heads  on  those  these 
 bigger  heads  on  the  the  water  loving 
 plants  and  voila,  you've  got  a  system 
 that's  really  going  to  operate  perfectly 
 because  20  minutes  equally  on  something 
 like  this  versus  something  like  your 
 traditional  heads  is  going  to  be  a 
 really  really  good  balance  on  drought 
 tolerant  versus  tropical  plant 
 groupings.  I  hope  that  makes  sense.  So 
 that's  definitely  something  I  wish  we 
 would  have  started  right  from  the 
 get-go.  Would  have  saved  us  a  lot  of 
 effort,  a  lot  of  time,  and  a  lot  of 
 digging  had  we  just  done  that  right  off 
 the  bat.  But  we  did  it  a  few  years 
 later.  Still  serves  as  a  beautiful 
 garden.  But,  you  know,  hopefully  you 
 guys  who  are  in  the  beginning  stages  of 
 things,  this  is  really  something  that's 
 going  to  help  you  right  off  the  bat. 
 So,  I  hope  this  video  does  what  it's 
 supposed  to  do,  which  is  save  you  guys 
 just  a  little  bit  of  time  and  money  and 
 long-term  effort  in  your  garden  and,  you 
 know,  you  don't  make  some  of  the 
 mistakes  that  I've  made  over  the  years. 
 I  try  to  tell  all  of  my  clients  that, 
 but  I  love  this  channel  because  I'm 
 really  able  to  send  that  to  the  masses, 
 those  of  you  guys  who  are  diying  it  and 
 making  a  lot  of  the  same  mistakes  that 
 I'm  making  through  that  I  have  made  in 
 the  past  that  you  might  be  making  or 
 future  making  into  your  garden.  So,  I 
 hope  this  video  becomes  useful  and  it's 
 something  that  you  can  look  back  on  and 
 say,  "Hey,  I'm  going  to  make,  you  know, 
 address  this  situation  now."  So,  if  you 
 guys  enjoyed  today's  video,  then  please 
 check  out  last  week's  video.  It  was 
 about  a  updated  garden  tour  on  a 
 beautiful,  originally  blank  slated 
 backyard  that  is  now  a  tropical  paradise 
 of  its  own.  It  is  full  of  fun  plants  and 
 trees  that  are  tried  and  true  and  tough 
 to  Florida  landscape.  So,  see  you  guys 
 in  the  very  next  garden  tour.  Take  care.

 Well,  hello  gardeners.  Welcome  back. 
 Today  we  are  in  Fort  Pierce,  Florida, 
 zone  10A.  And  I  cannot  wait  to  share 
 this  beautiful  garden  of  tried  and 
 trueue  Florida  plants  and  trees  that  are 
 just  not  only  stunning,  but  are  tough 
 and  can  handle  our  environment.  So, 
 we're  going  to  talk  about  the  individual 
 plants  and  trees.  We're  going  to  talk 
 about  the  combination  of  how  things  come 
 together.  And  that  way,  if  you  guys  are 
 looking  to  create  something  like  this 
 into  your  own  space,  you're  going  to 
 have  a  great  shopping  list  of  really, 
 really,  really  nice  plant  material  to 
 really  work  with  in  your  own  particular 
 space.  We  were  here  about  8,  nine  months 
 ago,  few  months  after  the  original 
 planting  and  now  we're  about  a  year  in 
 from  planting.  So,  you  guys  get  to  see 
 what  this  has  transformed  into  a  year 
 later.  Now,  we've  had  some  storm  damage. 
 Those  of  you  guys  who  are  from  our  area 
 know  that  we  had  those  two  hurricanes 
 that  came  through  and  all  that  that 
 happened  right  after  installation 
 unfortunately.  So,  there's  some  tree 
 damage  that  got  hit,  but  overall  things 
 have  come  out  beautifully  and  are  in 
 full  recovery.  So,  yeah,  let's  kind  of 
 jump  right  into  this  garden  and  I  cannot 
 wait  to  share  these  things  with  you. 
 Just  before  we  get  started,  you  guys,  if 
 this  is  your  kind  of  vibe,  if  this  is

 We  post  every  single  weekend  and  we  will 
 show  up  in  your  feed  if  you  do  that.  For 
 those  of  you  guys  who  are  new  to  my 
 channel,  I  am  a  landscape  designer  of 
 over  25  years.  These  are  the  kind  of 
 projects  that  we  do.  We  create,  you 
 know,  backyard  resorts  for  clients.  We, 
 you  know,  redefine  the  front  yard 
 gardening.  We  really,  really  enjoy  being

 All right,  you  guys.  So,  just  giving  you 
 a  point  of  reference.  As  my  clients  are 
 entering  their  backyard  space,  we 
 redefined  this  section  with  a  nice  brand 
 new  walkway.  So,  this  is  a  lovely 
 walkway  leading  into  the  garden  area, 
 which  I  just  takes  my  breath  away  every 
 time  I  see  it.  I  absolutely  just  love 
 coming  around  this  corner  as  I  check 
 into  Kirby  and  Cathy's  garden.  About 
 eight  or  nine  months  ago,  it  was  pretty 
 well  established  by  that  point,  but  now 
 a  year  in,  you  can  really  see  the  layers 
 really  come  together,  how  everything  is 
 just  kind  of  giving  you  that  bright  pop 
 of  color,  the  brights  and  the  darks 
 mixed  in.  So,  for  those  of  you  guys  who 
 have  shade  plant  or  shade  areas,  this  is 
 a  nice  collection  of  shade  plant 
 groupings.  So,  as  you  can  see,  they  had 
 an  existing  bottle  brush  tree.  This  is  a 
 weeping  bottle  brush.  These  guys  get 
 nice  and  broad  and  big.  They've  lost  a 
 couple  trunks  over  the  years,  but 
 overall  it  offers  a  good  bit  of 
 protection  on  this  side  of  the  property. 
 And  the  plant  groupings  allowed  us  to 
 get  completely  different  than  the  mids, 
 mid  central  area  of  the  garden.  So,  I 
 love  these.  We  have  flanked  the  two 
 corner  sections  with  ground  orchids.  I 
 just  love  the  way  they  look.  They  bloom 
 in  the  winter.  They  bloom  in  the  summer. 
 Nobody  tells  them  when  to  bloom.  They 
 just  bloom  when  they  want  to.  So,  I 
 think  they're  absolutely  stunning  in 
 this  little  pocket  here.  And  then  right 
 to  the  rear  section  here,  we  have  the 
 dwarf  alicacious.  And  they're  almost,  I 
 would  say,  full  grown  at  this  point.  And 
 really  just  kind  of  offering  that  big 
 pop  of  just  that  big  giant  leaf.  So, 
 they're  going  to  be  a  gorgeous  4ft 
 specimen  as  the  midpoint  here.  And  then 
 right  to  the  back  are  our  java  whites. 
 Now,  look  at  the  leaf,  Bryce.  Look  at 
 the  leaf,  you  guys,  on  these  here.  I 
 just  love  how  every  leaf  is  a  little  bit 
 different.  It  is  just  so  fun.  It's  the 
 size  of  my  hand  or  bigger.  Actually, 
 bigger.  Just  so  gorgeous.  Some  people 
 nickname  these  guys  a  spotlight  plant 
 because  in  a  dark  area  cuz  they  can 
 handle  set  shady  conditions,  they  are 
 like  a  bright  white  spotlight  in  a 
 space.  Those  of  you  guys  who  are  looking 
 for  some  moon  garden  plants,  I  know  when 
 they're  newly  planted,  you  don't  kind  of 
 pick  up  on  how  bright  this  leaf  is 
 because  it  takes  time  for  it  to  really 
 flush  out  and  grow  in.  Approximately  a 
 year,  as  you  can  see,  but  it  is  the 
 perfect  brightness  in  a  dark  spot.  So, 
 don't  be  afraid  to  use  it.  There  is  a 
 little  bit  of  a  yellow  tone,  but 
 definitely  some  white  tones  in  it,  too. 
 There  is  a  neighboring  house  here.  So, 
 we're  going  to  let  these  guys  get  about 
 5,  six  foot  tall  over  top  of  this  wall. 
 So,  this  will  be  a  big  backdrop.  Then  it 
 tears  down  to  the  forefoot  of  the  dwarf 
 alicacius.  And  then  down  to  the  foot  and 
 a  half  of  the  ground  orchids.  And  then 
 we  popped  right  in  the  middle  because 
 this  is  facing  their  seeding  section  a 
 little  clustering  of  Rojo  Congos.  Some 
 people  are  scared  to  put  this  big  leaf 
 against  this  big  leaf.  But  you  guys, 
 because  the  contrast  in  leaf  color,  I 
 think  it's  a  gorgeous  look.  And  they're 
 never  going  to  compete  with  the  height 
 of  these  guys.  These  guys  are  always 
 going  to  stay  in  that  middle  range  of  3 
 foot.  These  guys  will  get  four  4  and 
 1/2t  to  the  middle  and  then  about  5  to 
 6t  to  the  back.  So  you  can  see  that 
 natural  layering  and  then  of  course  the 
 lower  ground  cover  of  the  ground  orchids 
 here.  Now  right  to  the  front  we  have 
 just  a  little  dollop,  just  a  little 
 swath  of  the  burl  marks  because  you  know 
 I  love  how  they  just  mound  over  into  a 
 bed.  To  me  they're  a  tropical  hedge. 
 They  really  do  a  good  job  of  keeping  a 
 nice  divided  line.  They  grow  into  about 
 two  and  a  half  foot.  That's  their  ideal 
 size.  You  can  keep  them  shorter  if  you 
 like,  but  that's  a  perfect  size  to  keep 
 them.  And  they  kind  of  make  a  nice 
 tropical  hedge  with  these  guys.  They 
 kind  of  hold  all  the  crazy  to  the  back. 
 And  they're  a  little  crazy  themselves, 
 so  they're  not  too  formal  fitting,  but 
 they  can  handle  sun.  They  can  handle  uh 
 shade.  They  do  need  protection  from  the 
 late  afternoon  sun.  That's  the  only  time 
 that  it  can  get  a  little  bit  burnt.  But 
 overall,  they  can  handle  quite  a  bit  of 
 sun  cover.  So,  they're  always  going  to 
 be  something  you  want  to  put  towards  the 
 edge  of  the  bed  because  most  of  the  time 
 that's  where  the  sun  hits  the  most.  So, 
 um,  so  they're  a  perfect  little  lower 
 ground  cover  for  that.  All right.  So, 
 you  guys  can  see  how  we  finished  off.  We 
 kind  of  started  wrapping  the  bed  around. 
 You'll  notice  from  a  lot  of  my  landscape 
 designs,  if  at  all  possible,  I  try  to 
 take  and  go  to  the  extent  of  the 
 property  line  and  work  my  way  forward 
 from  there,  leaving  as  much  grass  space 
 as  we  can  between  that  and  the  next 
 plant  grouping,  just  because  it  makes 
 the  yard  feel  bigger.  The  last  thing  I 
 want  to  do  is  kind  of  create,  you  know, 
 a  wall  structure  around  your  space 
 that's  just  too  heavy.  I  didn't  want 
 them  to  lose  the  size  of  this  backyard. 
 I  wanted  it  to  always  be  grand.  But 
 believe  it  or  not,  kind  of  bringing  in 
 some  soft  walls  on  the  outside  where 
 it's  just  more  of  a  soft  plant  grouping 
 does  a  great  job  of  still  feeling  like 
 everything  is  just  nice  and  big.  You  can 
 see  we  took  out  about  eight  or  nine  foot 
 of  bed  space,  but  we  didn't  come  into 
 all  of  this  open  grass  space.  They 
 really  have  plenty  of  yard  to  work  with 
 here.  And  it's  kind  of  that  way  all  the 
 way  around.  And  then  we  decided  to  do  a 
 humdinger  and  bring  out  a  middle  section 
 right  out  of  their  main  doorway  area  so 
 they  can  see  the  gorgeous  garden  right 
 from  the  inside  of  their  house  and  kind 
 of  put  a  divider  right  in  the  middle 
 with  some  beautiful  plant  islands  just 
 around  that  new  pergola  just  to  kind  of 
 create  an  outdoor  seating  section.  So 
 that's  what  I  love  about  this  garden.  I 
 love  that  we  were  able  to  do  that.  And  I 
 know  not  all  of  us  have  the  benefit  of 
 having  a  goodsized  backyard  space.  But 
 when  I  get  that  creative  juices  start 
 get  going  because  I'm  like,  "Okay,  we 
 could  do  this  and  we  could  do  that  and 
 still  leave  enough  room  for  for  yard  and 
 grass."  And  that's  that  was  kind  of  the 
 goal  here.  So  you  guys  will  have  to  let 
 me  know  if  you  you  think  that  we  made 
 that  happen.  On  this  side  again,  we  had 
 the  job  of  whites,  the  big  leaf  color 
 here.  Now,  what  I  find  so  fascinating 
 about  this  plant  is  its  versatility.  We 
 are  now  in  full  sun  over  here  where  on 
 the  other  side  where  those  copper  leaves 
 were  was  pretty  much  shade  with  a  little 
 filtered  light  coming  through.  This  is  a 
 heavier  sunbase.  Now,  this  plant  is 
 doing  just  fine  in  that  same  particular 
 spot.  Maybe  has  a  little  bit  more 
 brightness  to  the  leaf.  More  of  the 
 yellow  tones  you're  going  to  see  when  it 
 has  full  sun  versus  the  shady  areas 
 where  you  get  more  shade.  And  then  as  a 
 backdrop,  we  chose  the  Louisiana  red 
 copper  leaves  because  when  you've  got 
 sun,  you  guys,  and  you  love  variegated 
 leaf,  these  Louisiana  reds  do  a 
 beautiful  job  of  offering  you  a  hot  pink 
 burgundy  kind  of  variegation  in  a  big 
 giant  leaf.  I  mean,  look  at  those  that 
 leaf  grouping  right  there  where  that  sun 
 hits  Bryce.  You  just  see  it's  just  a 
 super  happy  plant. 
 Now,  the  negative  to  those  plants  would 
 be  that  the  bottom  two  foot  are  usually 
 pretty  bare.  all  of  their  energy,  the 
 front  and  the  back  and  the  top  of  the 
 planting.  So  the  top  four  feet  or  five 
 feet  of  this  plant  is  absolutely 
 stunning,  but  you  do  need  a  skirt 
 planting  to  kind  of  cover  up  that  lower 
 section  that  you  know  may  not  be  so 
 appealing.  So  these  guys  are  going  to  do 
 a  great  job  of  that  at  5T.  This  is  a 
 particular  spot  they  did  want  to  have 
 some  privacy  since  the  neighbors  patio 
 section  is  over  in  that  area.  So  having 
 a  nice  colorful  wall  here  of  these  about 
 8  or  9  ft  is  going  to  be  gorgeous.  So 
 they're  doing  just  that  job  right  there. 
 So  you  guys  will  have  to  let  me  know 
 what  your  thoughts  are  on  it.  Over  here, 
 this  was  an  existing  landscape  right 
 here.  This  was  one  thing  that  was  here. 
 This  is  a  watermelon  pink  crepe  myrtle. 
 They  had  some  lovely  plumbago  here.  So 
 we  kept  it.  It  looked  great.  We  worked 
 with  it  within  the  garden.  All  we  did 
 was  take  the  two  side  sections  and 
 incorporate  it  into  this  island.  So  we 
 have  a  full  wraparound  island  along  the 
 wall  here.  In  this  little  section  here, 
 we  have  a  king  sego.  This  is  kind  of  our 
 anchor  point.  This  is  kind  of  where  we 
 want  the  bed  to  start  now  to  drop  down 
 before  it  goes  back  up.  When  you're 
 looking  at  your  space,  pay  attention  to 
 that  because  I  think  that's  what  makes 
 the  landscaping  look  really  interesting. 
 If  you  can  have  a  lot  of  layered 
 heights,  then  it  drops  down  into 
 something  very  easy  to  work  with,  more 
 of  a  hedge  planting.  Then  now  you  get 
 into  some  more  dynamic  things  like  false 
 agave,  king  seos,  things  that  are  more 
 structurally  vertical.  And  then  it  gets 
 into  a  more  of  a  jungle  vibe  again  over 
 here.  It's  almost  like  a  rinse  and 
 repeat  of  what  we  have  over  on  one  side. 
 That's  what  makes  it  look  like  it  has 
 rhythm  in  the  garden.  We  kind  of  created 
 a  little bit  of  a  break  here  with  some 
 lower  material.  Then  you  come  back  in  to 
 a  similar  pallet  as  we  had  over  there. 
 We've  got  the  Java  whites.  We've  got  the 
 red  Louisiana  red  copper  leaf  to  the 
 back.  And  that's  really  kind  of  giving 
 us  more  of  that  wild  fun  look  to  the 
 front.  Now,  unfortunately,  this  and  the 
 other  Christmas  palm  were  damaged  in  the

 Antilus  are  starting  to  catch  up.  We're

 taller  and  fill  in  this  whole  back

 All  right,  you  guys.  So,  now  this  is 
 where  the  bed  changed.  So,  we  could  have

 And  it  was  yes,  yes,  and  yes.  So,  I'm 
 like,  okay,  so  let's  do  it  all.  So,  we 
 created  a  new  um  PA  walkway  leading  out 
 into  the  middle  of  the  garden.  So,  their

 backyard  section  and  then  opens  up  to 
 the  center  walkway.  And  flow  is  so 
 important,  you  guys,  being  able  to  to 
 have  a  continuous  flow  of  pavers  or  a 
 walkway  path  or  whatever  leading  to  that 
 area.  So,  it  looks  like  it  has  real 
 purpose.  Then,  we  found  a  finishing 
 point.  So,  we  needed  something  if  we're 
 going  to  have  something  in  the  middle  of 
 the  yard  to  have  something  with  some 
 anchoring.  It  doesn't  have  to  be  a 
 pergola,  you  guys.  if  that's  not  in  your 
 budget.  But  it  could  be  a  water  feature. 
 It  could  be  a  shade  sail.  Those  are 
 relatively  inexpensive  and  offer  a  big 
 area  to  really  gather  underneath.  Could 
 be  anything  that  kind  of  makes  you  want 
 to  go  out  there  and  sit  in.  It  could  be 
 a  big  shade  tree  with  a  bench  and  a 
 little  bubbling  water  feature.  Just 
 something  that's  going  to  draw  you  out 
 into  the  garden  that  you  might  want  to 
 take  a  phone  call,  walk  outside,  sit  in 
 that  spot  for  a  few  minutes  or  when 
 you're  doing  your  gardening,  sit  there 
 after  you're  done  pulling  weeds  and 
 trimming  and  whatnot.  just  a  little  spot 
 in  your  space  that  kind  of  takes  you 
 into  the  garden.  And  that's  exactly  what 
 this  area  has  become  for  Kathy  and 
 Kirby.  What  I  chose  to  do  in  this  area 
 was  find  an  entry  point.  Because  we  have 
 grass  on  this  side  and  we  have  grass  on 
 that  side,  we  needed  an  area  for  the 
 mower  to  run  straight  across  the  PA 
 patio.  So,  I  could  not  do  like  a  little 
 collection  here  and  a  little  collection 
 here  like  I  like  to  do  on  either  side  of 
 the  walkway.  So,  if  you  have  that  same 
 situation,  you  need  to  have  access 
 leading  from  one  spot  to  the  other,  just 
 take  that  same  planting  bed  and  stagger 
 it.  So,  take  it  instead  of  it  being 
 right  across  from  each  other  at  your 
 entrance  way,  stagger  it  forward.  One 
 pushed  back,  one  pulled  forward.  And 
 that's  exactly  what  we  have  here.  And  it 
 kind  of  really  gives  it  an  interesting 
 look.  And  if  you're  not  a  matchy  matchy 
 person,  that  really  fits  in  with  your 
 style.  So,  it  definitely  does  here.  So, 
 we  have  two  king  seos.  And  anytime  I 
 have  king  seos,  I  want  a  small  plant 
 grouping  next  to  it.  You  almost  want 
 like  a  swath  of  one  low  ground  cover 
 mixed  with  another  low  ground  cover. 
 Now,  this  is  golden  dew  or  gold  mound. 
 This  is  a  nice  collection  of  those  just 
 kind  of  wrapping  the  front  of  it.  And 
 when  I  use  gold  mound,  I  love  the  idea 
 of  using  little  rubies.  I  think  little 
 rubies  do  a  great  job,  a  great 
 collection  of  really  contrasting  in 
 color.  And  that  goes  for  any  of  your 
 ground  covers  that  you  guys  choose.  do  a 
 light  and  a  dark  and  then  have  something 
 kind  of  a  thriller  coming  out  of  the 
 middle  of  those  things.  And  you  guys 
 will  notice  in  this  particular  bed,  we 
 just  we  didn't  need  much.  So  when  I  say 
 a  swath,  you  kind  of  you  only  need  a 
 little  collection.  So  we've  got  four 
 gold  mound  in  this  area.  You  guys  know 
 how  I  love  to  stagger  my  gold  mound  or 
 stagger  anything  that  I  put  in.  So  one's 
 pulled  forward,  one's  pulled  back,  one's 
 pulled  at  an  angle,  and  one's  in  the 
 middle.  So  we  kind  of  have  a  a  nice 
 curvature  of  gold  mound  across  this 
 front.  And  the  same  thing  with  the 
 little  rubies.  I  never  put  them  in  a 
 straight  pattern.  Look  at  this 
 collection  of  thickness  right  here.  This 
 is  from  that  staggered  pattern.  They 
 grow  together  and  connect  really,  really 
 well.  If  you  stagger  a  zigzag  pattern, 
 takes  you  from  a  narrow  swath  to  a  nice 
 wide  swath,  a  nice  wide  area  for  them  to 
 collect.  It  makes  them  stronger,  makes 
 them  grow  in  faster.  Braid  at  the  top 
 and  braid  at  the  bottom,  and  that  really 
 helps  with  weed  prevention.  So,  don't  be 
 afraid  to  do  a  nice  thick  staggering  of 
 these  guys  in  place.  The  same  thing  with 
 this.  You'll  see  that  we  continued  on 
 with  the  swath  of  the  gold  mound  to  the 
 front  of  that  king  sego  there.  And  we've 
 got  1  2  3  4  5  6  7  it  looks  like  in  that 
 area.  And  again,  it's  just  a  staggered 
 formation  around  the  king  sego  just  to 
 continue  that  type  of  look.  I  wanted 
 everything  from  when  you're  seeing  from 
 the  seating  section  low  low  big  big.  So 
 everything  kind  of  goes  low  low.  Then

 of  hedge,  for  instance,  you  know,  with  a

 even.  I  mean,  look  at  these  guys.  I  love 
 this  texture.  I  mean,  this  is  a  low 
 plant  with  a  lot  of  ump,  you  know?  So,  I 
 know  a  lot  of  people  do  mass  plantings 
 of  these.  I  tend  to  like  them  like  this 
 where  I  have  just  like  a  collection  of 
 four  of  them  in  a  staggered  grouping  at 
 just  an  entry  point  or  an  ending  point

 a  nice  job  of  kind  of  really  changing

 landscaping  because  those  leaves  are  so 
 different  than  almost  any  other  leaf 
 that  you  can  have  in  the  garden.  And 
 they're  so  low  maintenance.  So,  I  mean, 
 you  just  kind  of  trim  anything  unwanted. 
 You  pretty  much  just  hold  this  guy  up. 
 Anything  at  the  bottom  here,  you  just 
 nip  and  trim.  So,  super  super  easy  to 
 do.  And  because  they  don't  grow  too 
 tall,  they  really  stay  a  nice  kind  of 
 controlled  planting  right  by  an  entrance 
 space  without  getting  out  of,  you  know, 
 out  of  control. 
 Use  everything  that  is  yours,  everything 
 that  is  within  your  space.  If  you  can 
 make  your  whole  surroundings  beautiful 
 like  a  resort  does,  they  make  sure  that

 nook  and  that  little  nook  and  this

 plants  every  time  you  trim  and  they're 
 perfect  for  cutting.  So  those  of  you

 coloring  coming  through  finally  on  those 
 guys.  There  is  a  lot  of  love  hate  with 
 variegated  arvoca.  Now  I  do  know  this 
 plant  is  common.  It  is  used  in  biller's 
 packages.  There's  no  secret  about  this 
 plant.  It  gets  used  pretty  often.  And 
 it's  also  one  of  those  plants  that  are 
 easily  neglected  because  everybody 
 thinks  you  don't  have  to  do  anything  to 
 it.  It's  one  of  those  plants  that  so 
 hardy  it  can  withstand  any  kind  of 
 conditions.  Not  the  case.  The  little 
 love,  little  care,  it  is  a  great  ideal 
 lowmaintenance  plant.  Even  with  a  little 
 care,  it's  still  a  very  low 
 lowmaintenance  plant.  So  if  you  have  a 
 spot  in  your  garden  and  you  don't 
 absolutely  hate  this  light  and  green 
 leaf,  you're  going  to  have  enough 
 interesting  characters  in  the  garden 
 that  this  is  almost  like  a  supporting 
 cast  member,  the  one  that's  like,  I 
 don't  have  to  fuss  with  you  a  whole  lot. 
 So,  I'm  going  to  put  you  in  like  a 
 little  swath  of  that  in  because  I  need  a 
 light  coloration  and  I've  already  done  a 
 lot  of  other  of  those  plants  that  are 
 light  coloration.  So,  this  gives  you  a 
 nice  variegated  pop  of  brightness  with  a 
 very  little  amount  of  effort.  I  don't 
 use  a  ton  of  them.  I  try  not  to  use 
 giant  swats  of  them,  but  I  do  try  to  use 
 them  in  key  areas  and  they  work  really 
 well  for  that.  So,  don't  sleep  on  these 
 guys  because  they  are  tough.  They  can 
 handle  high  pH,  low  pH,  draining  soil, 
 non-  draining  soil.  So,  if  you've  got  a 
 pocket  of  an  area  that  is  a  really  tough 
 tough  place  to  find  plant  material  to 
 really  thrive  in  and  do  well  in, 
 variegated  or  cola  should  be  on  the 
 list.  So,  and  I  needed  a  real  controlled 
 plant.  You'll  notice  that  along  the 
 patio  and  walkway  sections,  I  always  use 
 controlled  plants.  Nothing  that's  going 
 to  get  too  hairy  carry.  There  are  no  job 
 whites  here.  You  notice,  you  know, 
 nothing  that's  going  to  get  too  bold, 
 too  big.  In  this  particular  spot,  it  is 
 going  from  the  ground  cover  to  the 
 vertical  plants  of  the  foxtail  ferns  to 
 mammy  croins  to  dwarf  exoras  to 
 variegated  arbicola  and  then  the 
 craziness  is  in  the  back.  You  guys, 
 that's  how  it  works.  Make  sure  that 
 everything  around  your  area  is  pristine, 
 clean.  Then  bring  your  texture,  your 
 funness,  your  craziness,  and  work  it 
 into  the  outside  of  those  areas.  You're 
 never  competing  and  you're  never 
 fighting  through  the  jungle  as  you're 
 getting  through  as  you're  trying  to  walk 
 through  your  walkways.  that  seems  to 
 really  work  for  me  in  my  designs.  But, 
 you  know,  to  each  his  own.  That's  just 
 my  style.  We  have  an  anchored  Christmas 
 palm  here.  And  then,  of  course,  like  I 
 mentioned  before,  some  very  controlled 
 plants  like  the  mammy  croins  around  the 
 base  of  the  Christmas  palm.  But  to  give 
 this  area  a  little  ump  because  we  have 
 the  water  feature  on  the  opposite  side 
 of  them,  I  wanted  something  with  some 
 weight  over  here.  So,  we  have  a  trio  of 
 false  agave.  You  guys,  false  agave  are 
 my  go-to  plant.  I  love  the  architecture 
 they  create  in  a  garden.  They're  like 
 the  sculpture  in  the  garden.  I  just  love 
 what  they  offer  in  a  space  and  it's  like 
 a  little  pow  feature  in  a  garden, 
 especially  when  you  have  low  material 
 all  the  way  around  them.  I  think  they  do 
 a  fabulous  job  of  that.  Whatever  you 
 have,  if  you  have  a  bird  feeder  in  your 
 house,  if  or  in  your  backyard  area,  if 
 you  have  anything  with  any  weight,  a 
 bird  bath,  a  fountain,  a  swing  in  one 
 area,  whatever  it  is,  you  want  to  make 
 sure  that  you  balance  that  on  the 
 opposite  side  with  something  equally 
 heavy.  So,  on  this  side,  we  have  this 
 gorgeous  bubbling  water  feature.  I  love 
 the  basalt  columns  bubbling  feature.  You 
 guys  might  remember  that  from  my  own 
 yard.  I  just  love  the  way  it  looks.  It 
 offers  light  at  night.  It  offers  just  a 
 really  cool  little  rustic  charm  in  the 
 garden.  And  it's  not  like  I'm  a  dramatic 
 traditional  fountain,  but  it  fits  into 
 me  with  a  tropical  landscape  really 
 well.  I  love  the  verticalness  to  it.  And 
 I  think  it's  just  a  fantastic  feature. 
 It  bubbles  up,  disappears  into  the 
 rocks.  There's  a  big  basin  down  below 
 that's  about  a  50-gallon  basin.  Holds 
 that  water  down  below  so  you're  not 
 fighting  the  algae.  every  time  the 
 irrigation  comes  on,  it  adds  tops  off  a 
 little  bit  of  water  because  there's  so 
 much  wind  and  and  you  know,  obviously 
 heat  some  absorption  that  happens.  That 
 way  they  don't  have  to  come  out  here  and 
 constantly  add  water  every  single  week. 
 You  know,  just  easy  care  type  of 
 fountain  work.  But  you  guys,  that's  what 
 I  love  about  these  particular  kind  of 
 fountains.  I  just  think  that  they're 
 lowmaintenance.  They're  easy  to  install 
 and  incorporate  into  a  garden  bed.  But 
 you  definitely  if  you're  going  to  bring 
 something  like  that  into  your  garden, 
 balance  out  the  opposite  side  with 
 something  like  the  blue  agave,  the  false 
 agave,  the  king  seos,  whatever  else  that 
 you  need  on  that  opposite  side  to  give 
 you  some  balance  there.  So  let's  move  on 
 to  the  rest  of  the  garden. 
 All right,  guys.  So  when  you  can  see 
 that  we're  now  on  the  opposite  side  of 
 the  pergola  here,  and  now  you  can  see  a

 with  these  cool  fall  agave.  We've  teared 
 down  with  the  blew  my  minds  just  at  the 
 bottom  there.  And  you  can  see  I've  just 
 staggered  them  there.  You  do  not  need  a 
 ton  of  plants  here.  There's  three  blue 
 my  minds  here  and  there's  just  a 
 staggered  grouping  of  blue  my  minds 
 here.  You  know,  you're  just  working  with 
 the  bed  that  you  have  to  work  with.  You 
 know,  I  plant  my  blue  my  minds  no  closer 
 than  two  2  and  1/2t  on  center.  Really 
 give  them  some  space  to  fill  out  and 
 become  their  gorgeous  selves.  And  the 
 same  way  with  plants  in  general,  if  it's 
 an  upright  plant  like  this  dwarf  exora, 
 I'm  going  to  plant  this  a  little  bit 
 closer  because  its  natural  way  to  grow 
 is  like  this.  So  it'll  take  forever  for 
 them  to  connect.  So  I  do  kind  of  stagger 
 them  in  close  together.  And  I  believe 
 we've  got  like  seven  of  them  in  this 
 grouping.  And  that's  kind  of  how  I  like 
 to  do it.  So  we've  got  seven  here  and 
 seven  over  on  that  side.  And  then  I've 
 just  got  a  nice  little  staggered 
 grouping  till  we  start  to  get  into  the 
 bigger  material  back  here.  It's  the  same 
 rinse  and  repeat  as  I  mentioned  over 
 into  that  side.  You  know  where  we  have  a 
 little  bit  of  crazy,  a  little  bit  of 
 controlled,  and  then  now  we're  going  to 
 get  back  into  the  little  crazy  again. 
 So,  we've  got  the  backdrop  of  these 
 pygmy  8  palms  again  to  help,  you  know, 
 soften  the  the  wall  line  that  are  here. 
 You  can  see  we've  got  them  staggered. 
 So,  we've  got  the  one  pulled  forward  and 
 then  one  pushed  back  by  the  wall.  One 
 pushed  back  by  the  wall  here,  one  pulled 
 forward.  We've  got  them  one  pushed  back 
 further  back  here.  And  then  over  on  that 
 side,  we  have  it  pushed  back  by  the 
 wall.  So,  you  can  kind  of  see  the 
 forward  and  backward  motion.  Now,  if  you 
 guys  have  the  room  to  stagger  the 
 pygmies  like  that,  they  grow  in 
 beautifully  together  like  that  because 
 it's  more  organic.  that's  more  natural. 
 If  you  don't  and  you  have  to  do  a 
 straight  line,  don't  fuss.  Just  make  the 
 plant  material  to  the  front  of  those 
 more  interesting  and  more  staggered. 
 Make  sure  you  put  little  clusters  of 
 different  varieties  of  plant  material  in 
 front  of  them  to  make  that  happen.  We 
 just  happen  to  have  the  room  here.  So, 
 we  did  that,  you  know.  So,  you  can  see 
 when  you're  looking  at  this  garden, 
 there's  a  lot  of  this  going  on.  High, 
 high,  low,  high,  low,  the  whole  thing. 
 And  that's  how  it's  going  to  grow.  And 
 if  you  can  do  that  right  off  the  bat, 
 your  maintenance  is  way  less  than  trying 
 to  kind  of  keep  plants  individual  and 
 separate  them.  and  you  know  work  that 
 way.  But  if  you  can  do  a  big  clustering 
 of  something  big  and  then  bring  it  back 
 down  with  something  like  this  that's 
 never  going  to  compete  ever  with 
 something  like  this,  it's  always  going 
 to  be  very  controlled.  Then  now  you 
 don't  even  have  to  worry  about  that 
 break.  That  break  is  just  there.  So  you 
 have  that  lowline  grouping  here  to  offer 
 that  break.  Then  you  come  in  with  a  sea 
 of  some  crazy  like  the  blaze  copper 
 leaf.  I  love  this  variegation  pop  of 
 color.  It's  some  probably  one  of  the 
 first  things  that  you  see  when  you  come 
 around  the  corner  of  this  backyard. 
 Then  it's  backed  by  the  sea  of  Java 
 white  copper  leaf.  Now  we've  got  nine  10 
 of  the  blaze  copper  leaf  in  here  in  this 
 grouping  and  I  have  a  good  12  in  the 
 back  of  with  these  Java  whites  and  it 
 might  be  closer  to  14.  You  can  see  how 
 this  is  just  a  sea  of  these  to  the  back 
 and  that's  kind  of  what  I  wanted.  I 
 wanted  this  whole  area  underneath  this 
 very  old  pointiana  tree  to  really  have 
 kind  of  a  big  like  a  finish  point.  This 
 is  a  big  final  in  the  garden.  So  I  want 
 this  height  to  really  really  happen. 
 We're  not  getting  the  full  view  of  what 
 this  is  going  to  be  in  this  garden 
 because  the  Brazilian  red  cloaks  to  the 
 back  are  a  little  slower  grower  than  the 
 other  copper  leaves.  Copper  leaves  are 
 going to  be  on  the  faster  point,  but 
 they  were  worth  it.  And  I  told  my 
 clients  it's  going  to  be  a  little  bit 
 lopsided  for  a  little  while  because  I 
 could  not  find  Brazilian  red  cloaks  any 
 bigger  when  we  planted  them.  So,  she 
 knew  she  had  to  keep  these  a  little  bit 
 more  contained  until  those  catch  up.  So, 
 we  have  a  clustering  of  six  Brazilian 
 red  cloaks  in  that  rear  corner  back 
 there.  Again,  they  are  staggered,  so 
 they  will  grow  together.  They're  just 
 starting  to  connect,  but  once  they  do, 
 they  will  consume  that  whole  wall.  I'll 
 get  Bryce  to  pop  up  a  picture  of  what 
 they  look  like  as  a  backdrop.  So,  we  are 
 going  to  have  hot  pink  back  there.  We're 
 going  to  have  the  light  tone  and 
 coloration  of  the  Java  whites  here. 
 Then,  we're  going  to  have  the  darker 
 coloration  of  the  pink  and  the 
 burgundies  down  below.  And  so,  this 
 backyard's  combination  is  yellow,  pink, 
 burgundy,  orange,  purple  with  the  purple 
 crepe  myrtles  coming  in.  watermelon  pink 
 from  the  pink  crepe  myrtles  and  then  the 
 red  tones  and  the  orange  tones  um  of  the 
 other  copper  leaf  and  the  orange  from 
 these  awesome  beautiful  pagotas.  Oh  my 
 goodness,  they  are  just  starting  to  come 
 in.  And  look  how  gorgeous  they  are.  I 
 don't  know  what  offers  such  a  tropical 
 bloom  like  the  pagotas.  Now  those  come 
 with  a  warning  you  guys.  Those  will 
 multiply.  They  will  create  more  pagotas. 
 So  you  have  to  definitely  put  them  in  an 
 area  where  you  can  keep  them  controlled. 
 So  you  see  how  the  back  is  cleared  out 
 in  this  bed.  There  is  just  mulch. 
 There's  open  areas.  That  way  my  clients 
 can  make  sure  to  manage  the  pagotas 
 where  they  want  them.  And  I  would  not 
 put  them  in  like  a  sea  of  java  white 
 copper  leaves.  I  can  put  them  in  a 
 controlled  pattern  next  to  things  like 
 this  variegated  arbicola.  Hence  why  I  do 
 love  this  plant.  This  plant,  this  is  our 
 serene  look.  This  is  the  opposite  of  the 
 java  whites.  This  is  more  controlled. 
 This  gives  us  great  contrast  to  this 
 coloration.  This  is  a  a  perfect  plant 
 for  that.  And  then  we  can  keep  this  more 
 hedge  formal  fitting,  allowing  us  to 
 have  something  wild  and  crazy  to  the 
 back  because  you  don't  want  to  mix  too 
 much  of  those  two,  especially  when  you 
 have  a  plant  that  likes  to  propagate 
 itself  like  the  pigota  plant  does.  So, 
 these  are  going  to  fill  in  this  area, 
 but  to  a  point.  And  then  there's  another 
 clean  species  of  a  tree  as  a  centerpiece 
 with  this  purple  um  crate  myrn. 
 Unfortunately,  it's  not  in  bloom  yet. 
 probably  another  month,  but  it's  going 
 to  be  stunning  as  this  purple,  orange, 
 yellow,  and  green  comes  together  on  this 
 side  of  the  garden.  All  right,  you  guys. 
 So,  I  know  we  talked  about  plant 
 groupings,  plant  combinations,  um  things 
 to  definitely  are  going  to  just  work  in 
 your  garden  in  Florida  long  term,  but 
 there  is  one  thing  that  I  did  want  to 
 touch  on  if  you  can  just  to  add  a  little 
 bit  of  a  difference  in  the  garden.  There 
 are  things  that  you  can  incorporate  like 
 the  fountain  we  mentioned,  like  a  bird 
 bath,  but  things  like  boulders.  I  love 
 the  look  of  a  little  boulder  in  the 
 garden.  It  doesn't  have  to  be  anything 
 big.  can  be  something  like  basketball 
 size.  But  I  love  just  little  touches  of 
 a  different  element  in  the  garden.  If 
 you  can  incorporate  that  and  you  can 
 incorporate  them  and  some  stone,  that 
 different  element  in  a  garden  makes  such 
 a  interesting  place  for  your  eye  to 
 rest.  It's  like,  oh,  there's  more  going 
 on  out  there  than  I  thought.  I  really  do 
 like  the  look  of  that.  But  I  love  the 
 way  this  is  inset  kind  of  at  an  angle. 
 And  you  can  play  with  that.  Stick  some 
 dirt  underneath  of  it  to  kind  of  make  it 
 fit  your  space.  But  you  can  incorporate 
 them  throughout  the  garden  in  key  areas. 
 So  if  you've  got  false  agave,  if  you've 
 got  king  seos,  if  you've  got  anything 
 vertical  like  that,  stick  a  couple  of 
 small  boulders  like  this,  add  pack  some 
 dirt  in  behind  them  so  they're  tilted  up 
 a  little  bit,  making  them  look  a  little 
 bit  bigger  than  what  they  are.  Play  with 
 it  a  little  bit.  Find  out  if  you  want  it 
 on  an  incline.  Find  out  I  kind  of  want 
 it  sitting  more  straight  forward.  So 
 just  a  different  element  in  the  garden 
 that  really  kind  of  plays  with  the  space 
 and  gives  a  little  bit  more  personality. 
 Just  for  reference,  this  is  Tennessee 
 field  stone  and  you  can  get  them  in  a 
 giant  pallet  and  you  can  really  kind  of 
 play  with  them  throughout  your  garden. 
 They  go  a  long  way  when  you  get  them 
 that  way.  This  is  a  triple  basalt  column 
 from  Aquacapes.  And  then  this  Alabama 
 white  river  rock.  I  like  the  way  that 
 this  bright  against  a  dark  mulch.  I 
 think  that  really  makes  a  nice  contrast. 
 This  is  the  inch  and  a  half  variety. 
 This  is  what  I  use  in  landscape  beds  for 
 the  most  part  or  around  water  features. 
 I  do  not  use  them  in  walkways  because  of 
 the  round  rock  and  as  we  know  round  rock 
 rolls.  So  I  use  more  of  the  gray 
 granates  and  the  Tahesian  gray  granates 
 for  walkway  pathways.  But  this  is  a 
 great  landscape  rock  for  beds  themselves 
 because  it  does  offer  a  nice  bit  of 
 highlight  in  the  garden.  And  then  we 
 just  kind  of  did  a  nice  aluminum  alloy 
 edging  border  around  it  to  kind  of  keep 
 it  nice  and  controlled.  You  know,  a  year 
 later  and  you  can  see  we're  not  bleeding 
 to  the  mulch  bed.  It's  kind  of  staying 
 nice  and  compact.  Edging  is  about  4  and 
 12  in  tall.  It  does  a  great  job  of 
 keeping  everything  neat  but  not,  you 
 know,  overly  visible.  So,  if  you  want 
 something  more  of  an  invisible  edge 
 line,  the  aluminum  alloy  edging  is  a 
 good  edging  to  work  with  in  that 
 particular  situation.  All right,  you 
 guys.  So,  I  just  want  to  pop  in  here 
 real  quick  and  let  you  know  that  we  are

 Well,  hello  gardeners.  Welcome  back.  We 
 are  back  in  my  backyard  here,  Vero 
 Beach,  Florida,  zone  10A,  and  we  are 
 going  to  talk  about  color,  color,  color, 
 but  color  without  blooms.  So,  some  nice 
 leaf  color  that  can  handle  great  shady 
 spots,  filtered  light  spot,  just  these 
 perfect  little  plant  groupings  that  you 
 can  incorporate  into  that  spot  in  your 
 garden.  So,  let's  jump  right  in.  Oh, 
 before  we  do,  please  like  and  subscribe. 
 Hit  that  little  notification  bell.  We 
 post  every  single  weekend.  So,  if 
 gardening  along  Florida  is  your  jam, 
 then  definitely  hit  that  notification 
 bell  so  you  will  see  us  in  your  feed 
 every  single  Saturday  and  Sunday.  But 
 now,  let's  get  started.  One  of  my 
 favorites,  if  you  guys  have  been  around 
 for  this  on  this  channel  for  a  while, 
 you  know  it.  It  is  the  Sanchezia.  I 
 absolutely  love  the  variegation  leaf 
 color  of  this  particular  plant.  It  can 
 handle  filtered  light.  It  can  handle 
 full  shade.  It  can  handle  morning  sun  to 
 early  afternoon  sun,  the  heat  of  the  day 
 sun,  the  late  afternoon  sun.  And  that's 
 where  you  need  to  make  sure  that  it  has 
 some  filtration,  some  filtered  coverage 
 like  you  see  this  bottle  palm  is  doing 
 for  this  particular  plant  here.  It's  one 
 of  those  plants  that  really  bright  spot 
 in  the  garden.  So  if  you  kind  of  need 
 some  impacts  of  bright  color 
 combinations,  mix  these  guys  with 
 something  like  the  antiloo  or  a  solid 
 color  backdrop  and  they  will  really 
 really  shine.  Easy  to  keep  up  with. 
 They're  a  cluster  planting.  So  if  you 
 need  to  kind  of  put  a  nice  big  pop  of 
 them  together,  they  can  overlap  each 
 other  and  really  grow  in  so  so  lovely. 
 So  this  is  one  of  my  favorite  plants  to 
 work  with  when  I  have  like  pops  in  the 
 garden  that  I  really  want  to  highlight 
 an  area.  So  for  instance,  in  this 
 particular  spot  right  here,  this  is  more 
 of  a  straight  path.  Normally  I  like  to 
 curve  with  them,  but  in  this  particular 
 space,  there  are  four  plants  and  I  plant 
 them  about  2  foot  on  center.  So  that  way 
 there's  room  for  them  to  grow  together. 
 Now,  normally  when  I'm  not  working  with 
 a  direct  straight  narrow  path  like  I 
 have  here,  I  like  to  plant  them  in  a 
 staggered  grouping.  So,  I'll  put  one 
 here,  here,  here,  and  here.  And  then  let 
 them  connect  and  fold  together.  And  they 
 become  such  a  nice  thick  clustering. 
 They  do  need  trimming.  So,  every  March, 
 June,  September,  and  December  time 
 frame,  that's  usually  my  months  that  I'm 
 out  here  doing  some  trimming,  I'll  do 
 some  light  clipping  of  these  guys.  Make 
 for  beautiful  cutings.  So,  if  you  like 
 to  put  voses  in  your  house  and  do  some 
 lovely  cutings,  this  is  one  of  my 
 favorites  to  use.  You  can  use  these,  mix 
 them  with  antiloos,  and  voila,  you  have 
 a  nice  little  centerpiece  grouping  for 
 the  the  kitchen  table.  But  I  love  this 
 variety  of  plant  and  it's  pretty  common, 
 pretty  easy  to  find.  So  I  think  it  is  a 
 winner  winner  chicken  dinner  in  my 
 garden.  But  you  guys  will  have  to  let  me 
 know  what  you  think.  Neighboring  plant 
 right  next  to  this  guy  is  the 
 magnificent  Croin.  Now  you  guys  have 
 seen  these  in  my  videos.  I  use  them 
 often  for  my  clients  in  designs  because 
 I  just  love  this  big  giant  leaf  that 
 they  offer.  This  little  speckled 
 coloring.  It's  just  so  dynamic  and 
 really  offers  a  nice  big  punch.  This  is

 rarely  gets  any  sun.  Maybe  just  a  little

 guys  are  pushing  out.  I  rarely  ever 
 trim.  Maybe  once  a  year.  An  ideal  plant

 trees  like  palms,  you  want  a  little  bit 
 of  depth  in  the  garden,  incorporate 
 these  in  a  rear  corner.  Let  them  pop  up 
 and  fill  out  and  then  plant  something 
 darker,  a  variegation  color  down  below, 
 and  you're  going  to  have  such  a  lovely 
 combination  with  these  sloppy  pan 
 croins.  No  blooms,  but  tons  and  tons  of 
 leaf  color  on  these  guys.  I've  got  them 
 another  couple  places  in  the  garden. 
 I'll  get  Bryce  to  pop  it  on  the  screen 
 for  you  guys  so  you  can  kind  of  see  it 
 in  different 
 situations.  All right,  you  guys.  So,  we 
 popped  over  into  my  front  yard  and  the 
 next  grouping  is  going  to  be  the 
 antiloo.  I  am  in  love  with  this  plant 
 because  it  is  so  versatile.  It  can 
 handle  shade.  It  can  handle  filter 
 light.  It  can  handle  sun.  It  can  handle 
 it  can  handle  anything.  It's  just  so 
 fabulous.  So,  you'll  notice  that  this 
 grouping  back  behind  us  is  more  of  a 
 solid  leaf  in  color.  And  that  is  rare  to 
 find  when  you're  looking  for  a  colorful 
 plant  that  can  handle  a  darker

 think  that  this  just  does  it  so 
 fabulously.  You  can  keep  them  at  more  of

 tall.  Um  cuz  I'm  a  little  This

 beautiful  yellow  leaf  to  it.  It  stays 
 more  compact.  So  it's  never  going  to

 like  the  quarter  lines.  And  that  yellow

 like  painting  with  colors  you  guys.  It's

 definitely  a  must  in  the  garden.  So, 
 let's  go  check  out  the  next  and  the  last 
 one  for  us.  It  is  one  of  my 
 favorites.  So,  my  next  plant,  my  next 
 feature  plant  is  definitely  one  of  my 
 favorites.  This  Imperialis  burmilad  is

 the  entrance  of  my  garden.  Um,  it  is

 absolutely  love  them.  Um,  I  have  had 
 this  question  where  people  are  concerned 
 about  holding  mosquitoes  in  the  cups 
 because  of  course  they  do  hold  water  in 
 these  particular  areas.  And  all  I  do  is 
 about  once  a  month,  I'm  not  super 
 diligent  about  it,  but  all  I  do  is  run 
 the  hose  in  this  center  and  it  flushes 
 all  of  that  old  water  out.  So,  it  will 
 hold  water  for  a  period  of  time  before 
 it  starts  to  drain  or  evaporate.  Now, 
 the  more  sun  that  it's  in,  the  less  you 
 have  to  worry  about  that  because  I 
 hardly  ever  have  to  do  it  with  that  one.

 protection  in  those  that  are  by  my 
 waterfall,  they  get  more  protection  and 
 not  enough  sun  to  dry  out.  I  will  have

 Well,  hello  gardeners.  Welcome  back  to 
 the  True  Gardening  channel.  And  today's 
 video  is  all  about  the  exotics.  Well, 
 sort  of.  It's  about  the  exotics  of 
 Florida.  These  are  tropical,  I  don't 
 know,  exclamation  marks,  big  punches  of 
 things  that  you  can  add  into  your 
 garden.  That  explosion  of  like  a 
 tropical  flare  that  can  incorporate  into 
 your  garden  that  really  kind  of  sets  it 
 from,  you  know,  luxury  and  beautiful  to, 
 wow,  what  is  that?  Got  to  know  that.  And 
 these  are  some  things  that  you  may  have 
 seen  in  a  garden  center  that  you're 
 like,  oh,  I  like  the  look  of  that,  but  I 
 kind  of  don't  know if  it's  going  to  work 
 with  what  I  have  to  work  with,  you  know, 
 and  so  it  could  be  a  bit  intimidating. 
 So,  these  are  six  of  the  things  that 
 I've  incorporated  into  many  other 
 gardens  as  a  landscape  designer  as  well 
 as  my  very  own  garden.  So,  it's  well 
 worth  the  trouble,  well  worth  trying  to 
 find  and  locate  them  and  put  them  in  key 
 areas  into  your  space  because  they 
 really  do  set  up  a  garden  like  none 
 other.  So,  the  very  first  one  is  this 
 gal  behind  me.  This  is  the  Madagascar 
 palm.  You  guys  may  have  seen  her  in  many 
 previous  videos.  Right  now,  she  is 
 flushing  out  with  beautiful  white  blooms 
 and  this  gorgeous,  gorgeous  leaflet 
 topper  to  all  of  her  very  dramatic  spiky 
 trunks.  She's  dangerous  and  yet 
 beautiful.  So,  I  have  her  an  ideal  spot. 
 I  think  I  was  lucky  enough  to  score  her 
 in  a  garden  center  and  I've  yet  recently 
 gotten  another  one  put  into  a  pot, 
 waiting  for  it  to  kind  of  get  some  size 
 to  it  to  incorporate  into  another 
 section  of  my  garden.  Now,  these  guys 
 come  in  singles,  they  come  in  doubles, 
 they  come  in  multi-  trunks.  Sometimes 
 they'll  have  one  trunk  like  this  that 
 will  sprout  into  multiple  ones.  I  know 
 they  can  be  a  bit  intimidating  into  a 
 garden,  but  if  you  have  just  that  right 
 spot  for  it,  go  ahead  and  put  it  into 
 that  spot  and  let  it  kind  of  be  the 
 feature.  Let  it  be  the  architectural 
 detail  into  a  garden.  Let  it  really  set 
 off  a  space  because  it  really  does.  Now, 
 it's  called  a  Madagascar  palm,  but  it  is 
 not  really  a  palm.  It  is  just  absolutely 
 a  stunning,  stunning,  stunning  tree.  and 
 it  likes  drought  tolerant  conditions. 
 So,  if  you  got  a  spot  in  your  garden 
 that  doesn't  get  a  whole  lot  of  water, 
 ideal.  If  you're  in  an  area  like  my 
 particular  garden  where  everything  in 
 this  space  gets  a  lot  of  water  because  I 
 have  a  lot  of  tropicals  with  it,  just 
 raise  it  a  bit  in  the  garden.  Kind  of 
 give  it  put  it  in  a  little  bit  of  an 
 incline.  What  I've  done  is  I've  brought 
 it  up  about  5  to  6  in  so  it  drains 
 downward  and  really  kind  of  helps  keep 
 this  root  ball  dry  and  it  couldn't  be 
 happier.  Loves  full  sun.  I've  seen  these 
 in  gardens  all  along  from  Key  West  all 
 the  way  to  North  Florida.  So,  you  really 
 can  really  incorporate  these  all  the  way 
 into  that  Merit  Island,  Cocoa  Beach  kind 
 of  area.  So,  anything  north  of  that,  I 
 would  double  check  because  I  think  the 
 freezing  temp  on  these  guys  are  29,  30, 
 but  anything  below  that,  anything  that 
 you  only  get  a  freeze  here  and  there, 
 it's  definitely  worth  having.  Super  slow 
 growers,  so  kind  of  be  patient  with  it. 
 But  gosh,  what  a  stunner  it  makes  in  a 
 garden.  It's  kind  of  unique.  And  then 
 when  it  throws  up  those  individual 
 trunks  like  that  and  that's  all  hairy 
 carry.  It's  almost  like  I  don't  know. 
 It's  my  cousin  into  the  garden.  It's 
 just  kind  of  a  really  cool  feature.  As 
 soon  as  you  walk  out,  it's  the  first 
 thing  that  you  see  amongst  everything 
 else  that  I  have  in  the  garden.  So  I 
 think  it's  definitely  on  my  top  list  of

 foliage,  tropical  jungle.  Just  make  sure 
 you  put  in  a  few  allowances  for  that 
 particular  tree.  All right,  you  guys.  So 
 for  the  next  plant  that  I  love  to  use

 garden  because  of  that  reason  is  the 
 imperialis  burmilad.  Now  I  know 
 burmilads  they  can  get  a  bad  wrap. 
 There's  some  that  run  too  much  and  then 
 die  out  too  often.  This  particular 
 burmilad  I  believe  offers  a  bit  of 
 impact  without  multiplying  into  10,000 
 little  burmilads.  This  is  a  singular 
 trunk.  though  it  is  one  that  lasts  and 
 lives  a  long  time  but  stays  as  a  center 
 its  own  burmilad.  It  doesn't  produce 
 pups  or  whatnot.  The  imperialis  burmilad 
 grow  to  about  4t  tall  by  about  3  to  4 
 foot  wide.  So  you  can  use  it  as  a 
 singular  or  kind  of  like  how  I  have  it 
 here  as  an  entrance  to  my  um  seating 
 section.  This  guy  has  been  here  for 
 about  4  years.  Absolutely  love  it.  I 
 love  them  in  gardens.  They  can  handle 
 full  sun.  And  now  if  you  Google  it,  it 
 says  full  sun,  but  really  this  one  gets 
 direct  full  afternoon  sun.  You  can  see 
 it's  a  little  bit  smaller  and  a  little 
 bit  paler.  So  if  you  guys  have  morning 
 sun  to  midday  sun  with  a  little  bit  of 
 protection,  this  one  gets  a  little  bit 
 of  canopy  coverage,  just  a  tiny  bit  from 
 the  corner  of  my  roof.  And  you  can  see 
 that  this  coloration  is  way  nicer.  Now, 
 it  can  also  handle  full  shade.  So  if  you 
 got  a  full  shade  environment,  this  plant 
 does  fabulous  for  that.  Love  the  purple 
 detail.  I  love  the  kind  of  cylinder  kind

 you  a  whole  sphere  kind  of  look,  but 
 still  upright  and  vertical.  So,  it 
 doesn't  take  up  a  lot  of  space.  So,  any 
 place  near  entrance  way  to  a  walkway  or 
 pathway  or  an  entrance  way  to  a  pool  or 
 fabulous  in  pots.  If  you  guys  want  to

 cylinder  pots  up  and  then  have  them  kind 
 of  crown  out  to  the  front  of  those,  they 
 make  fabulous  features  for  that.  So, 
 I've  commonly  put  them  in  as  more  of 
 accent  features  around  palm  trees.  So 
 you  can  have  a  palm  tree  in  the  middle 
 and  then  have  three  of  these  guys  around

 dynamic  base  looking  like  it's  almost 
 like  part  of the  palm  tree  but  it's  not. 
 A  lot  of  different  ways  that  you  can  use 
 these  as  almost  like  a  little  bit  of  an 
 exclamation  garden.  So  they're  awesome 
 features.  They're  not  like  the 
 Madagascar  palm  that  I  mentioned  earlier
