 standalone  feature,  but  they're 
 definitely  almost  a,  like  I  said,  an 
 exclamation  mark  in  the  garden.  Kind  of 
 add  a  little  bit  of  explosion  here,  a 
 little  bit  impact  there.  They're  perfect 
 for  that.  And  then  I  love  that  they 
 offer  you  color  and  their  versatility  to 
 work  in  a  shade  environment  versus  a  sun 
 environment  and  still  perform 
 beautifully  in  both  areas.  So  definitely 
 worth  having.  Um,  they  can  handle  more 
 water  than  a  typical  burmilad,  which  is 
 ideal.  They  will  hold  the  water  in  the 
 cups.  So,  what  I  tell  my  clients  when  we 
 plant  these  is  to  once  a  week  or  every 
 other  week,  just  flush  out  the  water  in 
 the  cups.  So,  if  you  bring  a  hose  out 
 and  you  kind  of  wet  the  inside  of  it, 
 it'll  overflow  and  flow  out  of  the  cups 
 so  you  don't  have  any  kind  of  standing 
 or  sitting  water  in  that  spot.  So,  they 
 work  really,  really  well  with  this. 
 Overall,  maintenance  is  trimming  about 
 three  times  a  year,  four  times  a  year  at 
 best  if  you're  really  a  manicured 
 trimmer.  Obviously,  you  guys  know  I'm 
 not.  So,  this  is  more  of  a  natural  look 
 for  these  guys.  Um,  trimming  just  every

 to  work  with.  So,  Imperialis  burmilads 
 are  definitely  a  go-to  mediumsiz  accent

 third  favorite,  and  this  is  I  can't  even 
 say  it's  my  third  favorite  because  I 
 think  it's  like  up  there  with  my  very 
 first  favorite.  I  have  several  of  these 
 in  my  very  own  garden.  Um,  I  always

 can  pop  them  in  because  they're  a  little 
 bit  not  tolerant  to  some  of  the  colder 
 temps.  So,  if  you're  anything  above  us 
 into  the  North  Melbourne,  Merit  Island, 
 Cocoa  Beach  area,  temperatures  drop  just 
 a  little  bit  too  low.  Anything  below  32 
 will  unfortunately  kill  this  particular 
 plant.  However,  it  is  so  worth  having  it 
 in  a  pot.  They  do  fabulous  in  a  pot. 
 They'll  live  there  for  years  and  years 
 and  years.  But  if  you  put  it  in  a  pot, 
 put  it  on  a  little  stand,  incorporate  it 
 into  your  garden,  you  will  not  be  sorry 
 because  that  rounded  leaf,  that  big  fan 
 of  a  leaf  for  that  kind  of  like  small 
 compact  of  a  tree  sets  off  a  space  so 
 nicely.  Even  when  I  look  out  from  my 
 seating  section,  I  look  out  to  my  whole 
 garden.  My  eye  always  rests  on  this 
 particular  spot  because  the  leaves 
 branch  out.  Everything  is  so  rounded.  It 
 is  so  Alice  and  Wonderland.  I  just 
 absolutely  love  those  big  giant  fans  on 
 such  a  small  tree.  I  feel  like  it  always 
 deserves  this  big  ump  or  this  big  hello, 
 this  big  exclamation  mark  in  a  garden. 
 So,  where  I  can  incorporate  it  as  a 
 landscape  designer,  I  do.  And  of  course, 
 I've  done  the  same  for  my  own  space 
 because  they're  tough.  They're  hearty. 
 The  only  thing  they  don't  like  is  the 
 cold.  So,  without  further  ado,  that  is 
 the  Laquala  palm.  I  feel  so  bad  sharing 
 her  with  you  guys  in  this  kind  of 
 condition.  We've  had  such  severe  winds 
 and  storms  recently  and  you  can  see  a 
 lot  of  the  torn  fronds  because  of  that. 
 They  do  love  a  more  protected 
 environment.  I  have  kind  of  created  a 
 cove  of  palm  trees  around  her  to  protect 
 her.  But  we  have  had  some  doozies 
 lately.  I  mean  you  guys  have  probably 
 seen  the  tornadoes  that  happened  about 
 two  months  almost  three  months  ago  now 
 and  things  are  starting  to  pop  back.  You 
 can  see  all  this  new  growth  is 
 absolutely  stunning  but  the  older  growth 
 is  not  there  yet.  So,  this  is  a  dwarf 
 tree.  So,  if  you  are  going  to  put  it  in 
 a  pot,  okay,  to  start  with  the  3  gallon 
 size,  but  put  it  in  a  pedestal  so  that 
 way  you  can  kind  of  see  it  amongst  your 
 garden  and  then  bring  that  bad  boy  in 
 when  we  get,  you  know,  high  temps.  So, 
 they  create  new  fronds.  You  get  about  10 
 new  fronds  a  year.  So,  it  really  can  be 
 a  nice  dynamic  clustering  of  these  big 
 giant  leaves.  And  no  matter  what  kind  of 
 landscape  you  have  in  the  garden, 
 there's  something  about  this  leaf  style. 
 It  always  attracts  the  eye  because  all 
 these  other  fronds  are  just  so 
 different.  They're  wispy  and  they're 
 maybe  a  darker  color  or  maybe  they're 
 more  vertical,  whatever  the  case  may  be. 
 Not  many  fronds  have  this  kind  of  look 
 to  it.  So,  it  stands  alone  in  a  garden. 
 And  anything  in  Florida  in  a  palm  family 
 that  stands  alone  in  the  garden  is 
 always  worth  having.  A  little  bit  of  a 
 diva.  I  get  it.  you  got  to  take  it  in, 
 you  know,  during  the  cold  temps,  but 
 well  worth  it  because  it  is  a  unique 
 species  in  the  garden.  So,  finding  some 
 key  areas  to  have  them,  easy  access  to 
 get  them  in  and  out  if  you  need  to  move 
 them  around,  but  well  worth  it.  Grows 
 very,  very  slow,  but  we'll  get  all  the 
 way  up  into  the  14  15t  range.  So,  you'll 
 really  get  to  see  they're  absolutely 
 stunners  in  a  nice  long  buffer.  So, 
 don't  be  afraid  to  incorporate  them.  If 
 you  see  them  in  the  nurseries, 
 definitely  pick  one  of  those  guys  up 
 because  they're  worth  it.  All right,  you 
 guys.  So,  this  summer  bloomer  probably 
 doesn't  need  much  introduction,  but  I 
 absolutely  love  to  incorporate  it  into  a 
 garden  setting.  Whether  it  is  on  a 
 pedestal  amongst  the  garden  if  you  got 
 some  great  sun  or  it's  like  here  on  its 
 own  in  a  pot,  handles  the  drought  like 
 nobody's  business.  So,  if  you've  got  a 
 pool  deck  that  you're  like,  "Hey,  I'm 
 not  a  hand  waterer  by  any  means."  This 
 might  be  your  grow.  Just  tons  of 
 foliage.  You  couldn't  put  one  more  bloom 
 on  them  during  the  summer.  Now,  during 
 the  winter,  they're  pretty  much  bald. 
 There's  nothing  to  love  about  them  in 
 the  winter  other  than  this  cool  trunk 
 line  that  they  have.  They  all  have  like 
 a  really  cool  bonsai  looking  kind  of 
 trunk  line  to  them.  They  can  live  in  a 
 pot  for  years  and  years  and  years  and 
 years,  unlike  a  lot  of  potted  plants. 
 The  desert  rose  is  an  ideal  potted  plant 
 to  incorporate  into  your  garden.  Now, 
 I've  seen  them  many  places  where  they're 
 planted  into  the  ground  of  really  good 
 drainage,  but  in  my  opinion,  I  prefer 
 them  in  a  pot.  They're  really  well 
 controlled  in  a  pot.  They  can  handle  the 
 cold  temps.  They  can  handle  the  hot 
 temps.  they  can  handle  no  water.  They  do 
 not  like  too  much  water.  So,  when  you  do 
 water  them,  you  water  them  kind  of  like 
 a  bugan  villia.  You  put  water  into 
 around  the  the  base  of  the  pot.  You  let 
 it  flow  out  of  the  pot  and  voila.  You  do 
 that  no  more  than  once  a  week.  Um,  you 
 want  to  make  sure  that  it  does  not  get 
 too  much  water  and  it  will  bloom  like 
 crazy.  If  you  fertilize  it,  it  loves  the 
 BGI  buganvilla  fertilizer.  That's  a 
 perfect  blend  for  it.  So  go  ahead  and 
 hit  it  with  some  granular  along  the  base 
 or  some  osmmaote.  Either  one  of  those, 
 they  love  a  little  bit  of  extra  feeding. 
 And  that  way  all  summer  long  it  goes 
 from  one  blooming  cycle  into  the  next 
 and  to  the  next  into  the  next  and  then 
 you  just  can't  I  mean  like  right  now 
 it's  like  I  can't  I  can't  bloom  anymore. 
 It's  just  like  incredibly  beautiful  with 
 its  pops  of  color  and  pops  of  blooms. 
 And  you  can  put  it  in  the  toughest  of 
 places  in  the  garden.  I  have  one  right 
 by  my  driveway  that's  a  little  small  one 
 that's  getting  started.  I  have  one  over 
 here  at  the  edge  of  the  patio  that  gets 
 no  love  at  all.  And  then  I  have  this  one 
 right  here  on  this  wall  where  I'm  trying 
 to  kind  of  soften  my  pool  wall  a  little 
 bit  and  it  does  a  great  job  here.  I  had 
 one  in  the  ground  years  ago  that  had  a 
 beautiful  trunk  and  had  a  nice  long 
 branching.  I  swear  it  had  such  an  Asian 
 bonsai  kind  of  look  that  I  thought  it 
 was  the  most  magnificent  thing  ever.  I 
 put  it  in  the  ground  at  the  top  of  a 
 waterfall  feature  and  it  just  got  too 
 much  water  over  time  and  it  just  didn't 
 do  well.  So,  I  lost  it  over  time.  That's 
 the  reason  why  I  say  kind  of  keep  them 
 in  pots.  That  way,  you  can  control  the 
 drainage  and  control  the  amount  of 
 water.  But,  they  will  last  in  pots  for 
 so  many  years  that  you  can  kind  of  pass 
 it  on  to  your  kids  if  you  want  if  you 
 grow  them  in  your  garden  because  I  just 
 think  they're  just  such  stunners.  So, 
 the  desert  rose  plant  in  the  multitude 
 of  colors  that  it  comes  in.  I'm  just  a 
 pink  girl,  so  I  love  the  pinks.  But  it 
 comes  in  so  many  varieties  of  colors. 
 And  if  you  incorporate  it  into  a  sunny 
 spot  into  your  garden  on  like  a  column, 
 like  I  do  the  buganilla.  I  have  a  bug 
 and  villia  out  front  that  I  have  on  a 
 column  and  it's  a  little  pop  that's 
 there.  It's  just  that  little  pop  along  a 
 walkway  that  adds  some  interest.  Do  the 
 same  thing  with  these  guys.  Just  along  a 
 walkway,  put  them  on  a  pedestal  and  they 
 just  kind  of  show  up  and  say,  "Well, 
 hello  summer."  They're  perfect  for  that. 
 So,  do  not  sleep  on  the  desert  roses. 
 you  see  a  beautiful  one  in  your  garden 
 center  this  summer,  they're  definitely 
 worth 
 having.  So,  the  fifth  species  in  today's 
 video  is  the  Capernicia  fencis  palm. 
 Now,  this  is  in  my  front  yard.  It  is  a 
 stunner.  Everybody  always  thinks  it's  a 
 Bismaria  palm.  Um,  which  is  absolutely 
 gorgeous  in  its  own  right.  This  one  has 
 some  different  characteristics,  and  I'll 
 explain  why,  but  is  it  not  just 
 fantastic?  I  mean,  look  at  this  frrawn. 
 I'm  going  sit  on  this  boulder  right  here 
 so  you  guys  can  see,  but  look  at  this 
 frrawn  and  the  size  of  this  frrawn.  The 
 dynamic  kind  of  crown  shaft  that  it 
 offers  and  the  fact  that  it's  all  nice 
 and  compact.  I  don't  have  to  trim  it 
 this  way.  It  grows  this  way.  Real 
 vertical,  real  compact.  And  those  fronds 
 are  so  close  together.  They're  almost 
 overlapping  themselves,  which  gives  you 
 even  a  more  of  that  dynamic  kind  of 
 look.  So,  I  love  love  love  this  tree.  It 
 has  a  silver  tone  to  it.  The  older  it 
 gets,  the  more  silver  it  becomes.  Grows 
 exceptionally  slow.  So,  it's  definitely 
 going  to  be  a  feature  palm.  Wrap  other 
 palms  around  it.  Let  it  be  the 
 centerpiece  kind  of  like  I  did  here.  I 
 put  some  curved  foxtail  palms  around  the 
 side  of  it  to  kind  of  almost  like  kind 
 of  create  a  frame  around  it.  It  is  a  bit 
 of  a  pricey  palm,  a  little  hard  palm  to 
 find,  but  they're  definitely  out  there 
 along  the  Treasure  and  Space  Coast. 
 Definitely  worth  picking  it  up.  You 
 don't  need  a  ton  of  them  to  make  an 
 impact.  One  will  do  the  job.  So,  I  think 
 it's  well  worth  it  because  there's  very 
 few  palms  in  Florida  where  one  will  do 
 the  job  of  making  the  impact  that  we're 
 looking  for  and  this  one  will  absolutely 
 do  that.  So,  it's  compernicia  fencis. 
 It's  from  Cuba.  It's  a  rare  palm,  but 
 it's  definitely  really  top  top  choice 
 when  I'm  looking  for  something  like  a 
 standout  feature  for  somebody's  front 
 yard  or  a  corner  backyard  garden.  It's 
 ideal  for  that.  Grows  about  a  foot  to  a 
 foot  and  a  half  a  year.  So,  really  slow 
 when  it  comes  to  palm  growth.  The  one 
 thing  I  will  say  is  that  the  crown 
 itself  of  the  palm  is  heavier  than  the 
 actual  smallness  of  the  trunk.  When  we 
 planted  it,  we  staked  it  with  some  rebar 
 and  really  kind  of  holding  it  in  and 
 we've  gotten  some  really  really  bad 
 storms  over  the  winter  months.  So,  it's 
 moved  more  than  I'd  like.  So,  if  you 
 plant  it,  make  sure  that  you  kind  of 
 secure  it  in  really  well  because  of  how 
 heavy  that  canopy  is  and  you  can't  trim 
 back  all  those  fronds  to  make  sure  that 
 you  keep  the  palm  healthy.  Definitely 
 make  sure  that  it's  nice  and  tucked  and 
 secured  in  right  off  the  bat  and  then 
 you'll  have  no  problems  with  this  tree. 
 So  the  capernicia  felencis  is  an  ideal 
 palm  to  work  with.  Give  it  some  room  to 
 grow  because  this  bad  boy  will  get  some 
 size.  It  may  be  for  your  children  or 
 your  grandchildren  when  it  finally  gets 
 there,  but  it  will  get  some  size  to  it. 
 But  even  at  a  small  height  of  when  I 
 brought  it  in,  which  was  around  6'  7t 
 tall,  it  was  a  stunner  right  off  the 
 bat.  So  no matter  how  small  it  is,  put 
 it  in  the  ground,  let  it  take  off.  It 
 will  take  some  time,  but  it  will  always 
 be  a  stunner.  Whether  it's  three  foot  or 
 whether  it's  20  foot,  it's  just 
 absolutely  gorgeous.  So,  definitely  one 
 of  my  palms  to  go  to  as  a  landscape

 So,  but  for  now,  let's  talk  about  the 
 last  palm  in  the  garden.  All  right,  you 
 guys.  So,  the  last  but  not  least  species

 right  here.  They  grow  super  slow,  super 
 When  I  say  super  slow,  they  grow  super

 out  maybe  a  neighbor,  this  kind  of  my

 So  you  can  see  it's  just  barely  outgrown

 things.  Normally  you  go  to  bed  one  night

 the  exact  size  that  you  need  it  to  stay 
 for  a  lot  of  the  spots  in  in  gardens.  So 
 this  guy's  solving  problems.  I  love 
 plants  or  trees  that  solve  problems  in  a 
 garden.  So,  if  you  need  something  to

 This  has  a  really  cool  trunk  base  at  the 
 bottom,  kind  of  like  a  bottle  base,  and 
 then  the  canopy  opens  up  and  really 
 branches  out  nice  and  wide.  So,  it's  not 
 related  to  the  coconut.  It's  called  the 
 coconut  because  of  the  fronds.  The 
 fronds  have  a  similar  look  as  our 
 typical  coconut  palms.  The  benefit  to 
 this  bad  boy  is  its  versatility.  Can 
 grow  in  the  shade,  can  grow  in  the  sun, 
 can  grow  in  the  cold,  can  grow  in  the 
 heat.  I  don't  know  where  it  can  grow, 
 but  yeah,  all  the  way  into  freezing 
 temperatures  into  the  20s  and  not  blink 
 of  an  eye,  it  can  handle  those  kind  of 
 temps.  So,  those  of  you  guys  who  are  up

 Well,  hello  true  gardeners.  Welcome 
 back.  Today  we  are  in  my  backyard,  Vero 
 Beach,  Florida,  zone  10A.  And  summer  is 
 here.  If  you  haven't  felt  it  already, 
 you're  feeling  it  now.  Summer  is  here. 
 And  I  want to  talk  to  you  about  my 
 favorite  five  blooming  perennials  that  I 
 use  in  my  garden  and  so  many  others.  As 
 a  landscape  designer,  these  are  kind  of 
 my  go-to  flowering  power  punch  of 
 bloomers  that  I'll  incorporate  into  a 
 lot  of  my  landscapes  along  the  Treasure 
 and  Space  Coast.  So,  these  are  plants 
 and  trees  that  are  going  to  do  well  as 
 far  south  as  Key  West  all  the  way  up  to 
 the  Merit  Island,  Cocoa  Beach,  kind  of 
 in  that  environment  kind  of  area.  So, 
 all  up  the  coast,  they're  going  to  do 
 fabulous.  And  so  I  thought  I  would  point 
 out  my  favorites  and  why.  So  the  very 
 first  one,  if  you  hadn't  noticed,  is  the 
 lion's  tail.  This  is  a  fabulous  bloomer. 
 Love,  love,  love  it.  You  can  plant  it  in 
 a  nice  little  cluster  like  I  have  here 
 by  a  walkway.  It  really  produces  a  power 
 punch  of  that  orange  kind  of  bloom.  And 
 I  just  absolutely  love  it  in  the  garden. 
 I've  only  had  this  one  species.  I 
 planted  as  one  sevengallon  plant.  Clumps 
 beautifully.  produces  these  vibrant 
 blooms.  I  trim  it  about  three  times  a 
 year.  So,  really,  really  easy  to  keep  it 
 manageable.  And  that  says  a  lot 
 considering  where  it's  at.  It's  along 
 this  little  pathway.  So,  super  hard  to 
 keep  something  here  that  isn't  going  to 
 take  over.  Like  a  fire  spike  might 
 encroach  too  much  in  this  area.  So,  this 
 lion's  tail,  I  think,  is  just  such  a 
 fantastic  little  specimen  for  the 
 garden.  This  is  kind  of  what  the 
 standard  summer  bloom  is.  But  you  guys, 
 if  you're  in  full  sun,  this  beauty  would 
 be  covered  in  orange  tiger  tail  kind  of 
 blooms.  But  what  I  do  love  about  it, 
 even  when  it's  not  blooming,  you  got 
 these  gorgeous  green  leaves  on  it.  It's 
 absolutely  a  stunner.  Now,  anything  with 
 big  leaves,  the  bugs  can  find  a  home  for 
 so  they  can  live  underneath.  So, 
 definitely  it's  one  of  those  that  you 
 want  to  keep  an  eye  on  it.  You  know,  add 
 a  drench  to  it  if  you  need  it.  That  way, 
 it's  it's  kind  of  protected  over  time. 
 Fertilize  it  so  it's  nice  and  a  strong 
 plant.  But  overall,  it  is  an  easy  to 
 care  for  tropical.  Trim  it  very,  very 
 little.  Let  it  flush  out.  Let  it  bloom. 
 It  will  bloom  all  season  long.  Loves, 
 loves,  loves  a  blooming  fertilizer  twice 
 to  three  times  a  year.  And  you  guys  know 
 I  love  fertilizing  in  March,  June, 
 September  time  frame.  That  really, 
 really  does  a  good  job  of  really  kind  of 
 keeping  everything  lush  and  tropical. 
 So,  do  not  sleep  on  the  lion's  tail 
 plant.  I  absolutely  love  it.  You  know,  I 
 like  to  keep  mine  pretty  mounded.  So, 
 think  about  like  a  mushroom  top.  So  you 
 kind  of  want  to  allow  it  to  be  taller  at 
 the  top.  Find  out  where  you  want  it  to 
 be.  This  guy  will  grow  all  the  way  up  to 
 eight  foot  if  you  let  it.  But  this  is  a 
 perfect  height  for  me.  I  kind  of  just 
 wanted  it  to  cover  the  hose  reel  for 
 when  you're  walking  around  the  corner. 
 Keep  it  a  little  high  at  the  top.  And 
 then  along  the  corners,  you'll  start 
 trimming  along  these  edges.  So  you'll 
 make  sure  you  trim  and  keep  these  side 
 areas  nice  and  tight  and  tucked.  So  you 
 trim  shorter  here,  a  little  longer  here, 
 a  little  longer  here,  a  little  longer 
 here,  and  the  longest  here.  And  think 
 about  a  mushroom.  That's  kind  of  the 
 look  that  you  want.  The  more  you  trim 
 these,  the  more  they'll  bloom.  They're 
 absolutely  love  to  be  touched  up  and 
 trimmed.  So,  I  trim  mine  about  every  3 
 months,  sometimes  four  months,  but  if  I 
 trim  them  more  often,  they'd  be  happier. 
 So,  it's  up  to  you  guys  on  how  you  like 
 to  maintain  them.  Because  they're  near  a 
 walkway,  I  do  trim  them  as  needed  based 
 on  my  walkway.  Fabulous,  fabulous 
 growers.  Keep  them  around  four,  five, 
 six  foot  tall.  Ideal  size.  They  do  love 
 it.  So,  now  let's  go  check  out  the  next 
 one.

 from  your  girl,  True  Gardener.  and  I'll

 you  guys  have  put  in.  That's  such  great 
 great  comments  and  things  that  I've  run

 this  is  your  vibe,  then  stick  around

 talking  about  jungle  inspired  gardens.

 bell.  But  now,  let's  get  into  the 
 blooming 
 plants.  Can  you  guys  see  that  bloom  up 
 there? 
 All  right.  So,  it's  probably  no  wonder 
 why  the  Brazilian  red  cloaks  are  one  of 
 my  top  top top  choices  when  it  comes  to 
 blooming  plants.  Now,  I  do  know  this  is 
 not  technically  your  small  layered 
 blooming  plant.  This  is  a  grouped 
 blooming,  perfect  for  buffer  plantings, 
 perfect  for  big  clusters.  It  does  not 
 need  to  be  this  big.  This  is  just  kind 
 of  what  I  needed  for  this  particular 
 spot  in  my  garden.  But  there's  many  of 
 places  that  I've  created  this  in 
 clusters  where  I  needed  something  five 
 foot  by  5  foot  and  it's  an  ideal  plant 
 grouping  to  work  with.  So  don't  let  this 
 intimidate  you  to  the  back.  They  bloom 
 whether  they're  here  or  whether  they're 
 there.  They're  absolutely  fantastic 
 bloomers.  This  one  just  went  through  a 
 series  of  a  heavy  bloom  season  during 
 the  spring  and  now  it's  kind  of  coming 
 back  and  it's  getting  ready  to  pop  out 
 with  new  color  again.  They'll  go  through 
 that  cycle.  So  I  hate  that  we  missed  But 
 I'll  get  Bryce  to  pop  up  some  pictures 
 of  what  that  looks  like  when  they're  in 
 full  gorgeous  bloom.  They're  going  to  go 
 through  bloom.  Those  blooms  last  several 
 months.  So,  it'll  have  tons  and  tons  of 
 color  for  several  months.  Then  you'll 
 have  about  a  month,  maybe  6  weeks  before 
 it  starts  to  really  flush  out.  But  this 
 is  the  in  between  period.  And  you  can 
 still  see  we  have  top  layer  blooms  up 
 there  that  are  remaining.  So,  if  you're 
 looking  for  something  that's  going  to 
 give  you  great  color  in  your  garden,  and 
 maybe  a  bonus,  if  you  need  something 
 that's  going  to  kind  of  create  a  little 
 bit  of  buffering  from  you  or  your 
 neighbor  or  that  perfect  spot  outside 
 your  kitchen  window  where  you  might  be 
 facing  one  of  your  neighbors  kitchen 
 window,  this  is  an  ideal  plant  to  use. 
 It  has  gorgeous,  gorgeous  green  foliage 
 when  it's  not  in  bloom.  So  you're  not 
 you're  kind  of  not  missing  out  on 
 anything  because  this  color  and  this 
 this  big  giant  leaf  is  like  double  size 
 of  my  hand.  Gives  you  that  tropical 
 feel.  You  can  propagate  this  plant.  You 
 can  just  cut  off  one  of  these  limbs  that 
 you  see  here.  You  can  cut  off  one  of 
 these  limbs  here  right  between  the 
 nodes.  Cut  that  guy  off.  Peel  off  the 
 bottom  three  leaves.  Put  them  right  into 
 the  ground.  A  little  extra  water.  Six 
 weeks  later  you  have  a  brand  new  plant. 
 So  it  is  or  a  gift.  That's  right,  Bryce. 
 It's  an  ideal  thing  to  have  in  your 
 garden.  let  it  cluster  and  then 
 propagate  it  throughout  the  rest  of  your 
 garden.  So,  to  me,  this  is  not  just  a 
 awesome  bloomer,  but  it's  definitely  a 
 moneysaver  when  it  comes  to  being  able 
 to  use  it  in  several  areas  of  your 
 garden  or  give  away  to  family  and 
 friends.  So,  Brazilian  red  cloaks.  Now, 
 they  can  handle  temperatures  all  the  way 
 into  the  low30s,  just  around  that 
 freezing  level,  and  they  start  kind  of 
 getting  really  yucky.  So,  you  might  get 
 some  burn  back  on  them,  but  overall, 
 they  can  handle  it.  When  they  become 
 thicker  clusters,  they  can  handle  windy 
 areas  like  nobody's  business.  Initially, 
 they're  going  to  struggle.  They're  going 
 to  get  a  little bit  windburnt,  but  let 
 them  become  thick  little  groupings  like 
 I  have  here  because  this  particular  spot 
 is  a  very  windy  spot.  If  you  have 
 courtyards  or  maybe  a  wall  planting 
 around  your  pool  area,  have  them  pop  up 
 over  top  of  a  wall.  I'll  get  Bryce  to 
 incorporate  a  picture  of  what  that  looks 
 like.  And  they  just  kind  of  give  you 
 that  next  tier  of  coverage  right  above 
 that  or  above  a  fence  ideal  to  kind  of 
 really  soften  those  hard  edges  of  any 
 kind  of  hard  structure  like  that.  But 
 Brazilian  red  cloaks  are  definitely  one 
 of  my  go-tos  when  I'm  incorporating  them 
 into  my  landscape  designs  through  all 
 along  projects  that  I  do  through  the 
 Treasure  and  Space  Coast.  Go-to  if 
 you're  looking  to  create  some 
 brightness,  more  of  a  green  and  white 
 pattern.  I'm  getting  a  lot  of  clients 
 who  are  asking  me  for  that,  which  I  love 
 that  kind  of  look  where  it's  green, 
 different  shades  of  green,  and  then  pops 
 of  white  with  the  blooms.  Those  last  two 
 are  going  to  be  white  bloomers,  and  I 
 think  they're  just  going  to  be  stunning 
 in  any  garden.  All right,  you  guys.  So 
 the  next  one  is  the  dwarf  fire  bush.  I 
 absolutely  love  this  guy.  I  think  that 
 it  is  a  fantastic  plant  grouping.  This 
 one  really  blooms  this  gorgeous  red  and 
 orange  tone.  So  this  is  the  dwarf 
 variety,  believe  it  or  not,  of  the  fire 
 bush.  So  this  is  not  the  native  variety, 
 but  you  cannot  tell  that  to  the 
 butterflies  and  the  birds  because  they 
 absolutely  adore  this  plant.  They're 
 literally  covered.  I'm  sure  we've  scared 
 them  off  as  you  know  running  through 
 here,  but  they  bloom  10  to  12  months  out 
 of  the  year.  Yeah,  you  heard  it  right. 
 Even  in  the  winter,  they'll  pop  off  with 
 blooms.  But  this  time  of  the  year  is 
 when  they  really  get  going  with  tons  and 
 tons  of  blooms.  I'll  list  the  pros  and 
 the  cons  of  this  kind  of  plant.  So, 
 first  to  tell  you  a  little  bit  about  it. 
 It  is  a 
 dwarf.  I  know  why  it's  called  dwarf  uh 
 fire  bush  is  because  it  can  be 
 maintained  as  little  as  3  foot  tall.  So 
 right  now  it's  five  foot  plus  because 
 I'm  5  foot  six  and  it's  really  reaching 
 that  kind  of  height  in  the  middle.  You 
 can  maintain  this  easily  at  three  foot 
 tall.  It  can  be  kept  dense  from  the  top 
 all  the  way  to  the  bottom.  Now  if  you 
 try  to  maintain  something  that's  not  a 
 dwarf  plant  at  3t  tall,  you'll  have 
 nothing  but  wood  stocks  to  it  and  maybe 
 a  little  bit  of  coverage  at  the  top.  If 
 we  cut  this  all  the  way  down  to  3t,  it 
 would  flush  out  from  the  bottom  all  the 
 way  to  the  top.  So  it  allows  you  to  keep 
 it  the  way  you  want  to  keep  it.  But  it 
 doesn't  mean  that  it  won't  outgrow  a 
 dwarf  size.  So  it'll  grow  all  the  way  to 
 10  or  12t  tall.  I've  actually  done 
 plantings  where  I've  created  a  backyard 
 all  the  way  around  fence  buffer  with 
 these  guys  because  because  the  clients 
 wanted  butterflies  and  wanted  birds  and 
 and  this  is  a  great  bit  of  foliage  for 
 that.  So  we  did  a  nice  looped  kind  of 
 all  the  way  around  the  property 
 perimeter  buffer  with  these  and  popped 
 palms  big  palms  out  of  them  and  it  was 
 absolutely  stunning  because  they  had 
 constant  constant  color.  So,  these  are 
 actually  one  of  my  favorite  plants  for 
 that  particular  reason  because  they  can 
 stay  dense,  they  can  stay  full,  and  they 
 can  handle  filtered  light  and  full  sun. 
 They  do  bloom  far  better  in  full  sun 
 environments.  They  can  handle  a  good 
 amount  of  moisture.  So,  if  the  rest  of 
 your  landscaping  needs  3  to  4  days  of 
 irrigation  of  water  every  single  day, 
 these  guys  will  be  okay  in  that  kind  of 
 environment.  Or  if  you're  in  an 
 environment  where  they  only  gets  2  days 
 a  week  of  water,  again,  they're  going  to 
 do  just  fine.  So  they  can  handle  quite  a 
 bit  of  um  different  environments  and  and 
 still  bloom  and  be  their  beautiful 
 cells.  So  dwarf  fire  bush  are  on  my  list 
 of  gorgeous  bloomers  and  of  course  such 
 a  beautiful  butterfly 
 attractant.  So  for  my  next  favorite 
 blooming  plant  is  the  pin  wheel  jasmine. 
 You  know  it  really  doesn't  need  much 
 introduction.  I  love  love love  this 
 plant.  It  is  mainly  the  only  jasmine 
 that  I  do  use.  I'm  not  a  very  big  fan  of 
 some  of  the  other  ones  that  kind  of  go 
 sprawling  a  little  bit  crazy.  I  love  the 
 clumping  variety  and  these  do  a  fabulous 
 job  for  kind  of  pulling  together  a 
 cluster  of  one  bright  pop  of  color  in  a 
 garden.  What  I  love  most  about  these 
 particular  plants  are  their  versatility. 
 This  can  handle  full  sun  like  where 
 we're  at  right  now  or  it  can  handle 
 filtered  light  and  still  bloom.  So,  if 
 you're  looking  for  something  to  kind  of 
 create  a  bright  spot  into  the  garden, 
 they're  fabulous  for  that.  They  give  you 
 this  pin  wheelel  kind  of  bloom.  It's 
 just  so  gorgeous.  and  it  floods  the 
 plant  with  it.  Now,  it  does  only  bloom 
 in  the  spring  and  the  summer.  You  will 
 get  no  blooms  in  the  winter  on  this  guy. 
 Um,  and  then  also  it  does  thin  out  too 
 during  the  winter  months  where  I've  had 
 a  lot  of  clients  say,  "Well,  you  know, 
 I'm  okay  with  it  kind  of  becoming  a

 have  other  things  that  they  can 
 appreciate  in  the  garden."  So, 
 definitely  keep  that  in  mind  because 
 they're  not  their  best  during  that  time 
 of  the  year.  But  the  rest  of  the  year, 
 showstoppers.  This  bloom  is  so  bright 
 white  that  I  can  see  this  at  night.  It's 
 amazing  how  bright  this  little  area  is 
 lit  up  along  this  Kucia  hedge.  So,  don't 
 sleep  on  the  pin  wheelel  jasmine  because 
 they're  absolutely  stunners.  And  you  can

 bloomers.  They're  fabulous  clusters  and

 corner  of  my  garden.  So,  but  these  dwarf 
 tree  das  are  fabulous.  You  can  clean  the 
 bottoms  up  and  make  them  cool  little 
 trees.  I  have  one  in  the  front  that  I've 
 made  an  actual  tree,  so  it's  one  stock 
 and  it  has  a  tree.  Or  if  you  have  the 
 bushes  and  they're  multiple  stocks,  you 
 can  clean  those  stocks  off.  It  creates  a 
 beautiful  tree  clustering.  So,  I've 
 loved  working  with  them.  They're  tough. 
 They're  durable.  They  can  handle  the 
 wind.  They  can  handle  drought  tolerant 
 conditions.  They  can  handle  a  little bit 
 more  moisture  than  a  lot  of  plants  like. 
 So,  they're  kind  of  a  really  good 
 balance.  They'll  live  well  in  the  shade, 
 but  they  do  need  that  sun  to  provide 
 that  big  clusters  of  bloom.  So,  think 
 about,  you  know,  kind  of  where  you're 
 placing  them,  but  they're  an  ideal  deal 
 plant  if  you're  looking  to  create  kind 
 of  like  a  moon  garden  in  certain  spots, 
 especially  if  you're  looking  to  create 
 something  with  a  little  bit  of  height. 
 Now,  this  is  not  a  plant  that  you  can 
 keep  two  foot.  If  you  try  to  keep  it  two 
 foot,  it's  really  just  gonna  kind  of 
 stunt  out  and  not  do  its  best.  It's 
 something  that  needs  to  be  four  foot  and 
 above.  So,  kind  of  keep  that  in  mind.  I 
 put  them  commonly  on  like  blank  walls 
 along  a  house.  So,  if  I  have  some 
 centerpiece  that  I  need  to  kind  of  have 
 bushed  out  in  the  middle  between  two 
 windows  of  a  house,  it's  an  ideal 
 centerpiece  backdrop  to  something  like 
 this,  like  a  false  agave.  You  can  put  it 
 to  the  front,  put  that  in  the  back,  have 
 the  two  windows  and  do  something 
 dramatic  on  the  other  side  of  the  two 
 windows  and  you  have  a  a  beautiful 
 landscape  combination.  So,  they're  great 
 to  work  with  and  you  know,  it's  just 
 hard  to  find  things  with  fragrance.  I 
 love  the  gardinas,  but  I  have  a  lovehate 
 relationship  with  them  because  of  pH 
 levels  get  off  and  they  can  be  a  bit 
 temperamental.  So,  um  I  need  some  things 
 that  are  easy  and  that's  why  I  have 
 several  of  these  in  my  garden  and  only 
 one  gardinia  in  my  gardens.  So  that  is 
 my  last  five  I  would  say  non-negotiable 
 tropical  blooming  plants  that  I  use  to 
 create  beautiful  tropical  gardens  along 
 the  treasure  and  space  coast  just

 you  guys  have  really  good  luck  with  them

---

 Well,  hello  gardeners.  Welcome  back.  We 
 are  in  Merit  Island,  Florida  today  and 
 we  are  in  a  beautiful  butterfly  garden 
 that  we  just  created  for  a  client.  This 
 garden  has  10  different  varieties  of 
 butterfly  plants.  And  I  don't  know  if 
 you  guys  can  see  them  around  me,  but  we 
 are  literally  being  invaded  by  those 
 beautiful  creatures.  So,  today  I  want  to 
 take  a  tour  through  some  of  the  most 
 common  butterfly  plants  that  I  like  to 
 use.  Now,  what  I  do  love  about  butterfly 
 plants  is  the  obvious.  They  bring  those 
 beauties  in.  The  one  negative  is  it's 
 kind  of  hard  to  create  a  butterfly 
 garden  without  it  kind  of  creating  a 
 crazy  kind  of  look.  It's  a  more  cottagey 
 vibe.  And  as  you  guys  know,  that's  kind 
 of  not  necessarily  the  way  that  I  like 
 to  design.  So,  this  is  kind  of  like 
 marrying  my  style  with  a  butterfly 
 garden  style.  There's  going  to  be 
 obviously  a  little  bit  more  layered 
 effects,  more  softness  of  plants  leaning 
 on  plants,  but  overall,  it's  still  going 
 to  be  a  clean,  defined  line.  So,  I  still 
 planted  in  the  same  kind  of  drift 
 patterns,  the  same  kind  of  levels.  So, 
 if  this  is  a  combination  that  you  like 
 and  you  are  a  butterfly  lover,  then 
 stick  around  because  I'm  going  to  list 
 all  of  these  plants  that  we  chose,  the 
 kind  of  the  locations  we  chose  them  in. 
 Most  of  them  are  sun  varieties.  So,  for 
 those  of  you  guys  who  are  new  to  our 
 channel,  my  name  is  Jennifer  Bevans.  I 
 am  a  landscape  designer  of  over  25  years 
 now,  and  I  specialize  in  creating  these 
 kind  of  landscapes  for  my  clients.  Every 
 single  week,  we  do  projects  just  like 
 this.  We  also  have  a  designonly  service 
 for  those  of  you  guys  that  are  outside 
 our  area.  And  we  have  a  virtual  consult 
 option  also.  So,  if  that's  something 
 that  you're  looking  for,  I'll  put  all  of 
 our  contact  information  down  below. 
 Check  us  out,  see  if  we're  going  to  be  a 
 good  fit  for  what  you're  looking  for. 
 But  for  right  now,  let's  get  started  and 
 tour  this  beautiful  garden.  So,  you 
 guys,  before  we  start  pointing  out  the 
 plants  individually,  I'm  going  to  ask 
 Bryce  to  kind  of  just  do  a  a  span 
 throughout  the  whole  front  yard  space. 
 So  that  way  you  guys  kind  of  get  an 
 overall  chance  to  see  what  the  whole 
 garden  looks  like  as  a  combination,  as  a 
 as  a  whole  look.  Um,  this  is  a  very  long 
 front  yard  and  with  a  big  septic  tank  in 
 the  middle.  So  we  really  kind  of  just 
 landscaped  around  the  corners  of  the 
 septic  tank  to  make  sure  that  we  um,  you 
 know,  we  didn't  infringe  on  this  whole 
 front  section.  We  hit  as  many  hot  points 
 as  we  could  to  really  create  some 
 interest  around  this  house  without  of 
 course  getting  into  any  of  the  danger 
 zones  that  we  are  trying  to  avoid.  So 
 you  guys,  we're  right  here  at  the  right 
 corner  of  the  house.  So,  of  course,  our 
 big  anchor  tree  is  going  to  be  the 
 triple  foxtail  palm,  but  that  triple 
 foxtail  palm  needed  a  backing.  Needed 
 some  some  height,  some  impact  to  the 
 rear.  So,  what  we  chose  to  do  is  bring 
 in  some  red  hibiscus.  This  is  our  first 
 butterfly  plant.  We  have  got  a 
 clustering  of  eight  red  hibiscus  that 
 are  going  to  kind  of  come  from  this 
 point  here  and  curve  around  the  back 
 side  of  it,  filling  up  this  whole  corner 
 to  about  5t  tall.  Now,  these  are  planted 
 about  a  foot  and  a  half  to  two  foot  on 
 center.  So  I  plant  them  in  kind  of  a 
 staggered  effect.  So  you  can  see  like 
 there's  a  trio  here  of  a  triangle 
 formation  and  then  a  staggered  grouping 
 here.  This  will  allow  them  to  connect 
 fast  and  that  way  they  don't  get  that 
 wonky  shape  to  them.  That  way  they 
 really  become  a  nice  grouped  planting 
 and  will  create  a  fabulous  wall  of  red 
 hibiscus.  Now  I  often  see  hibiscus  kept 
 at  like  a  3ft  and  under  size,  you  know, 
 where  they're  cut  back  and  cut  back  and 
 cut  back.  And  although  they  will  live, 
 they  will  have  a  tendency  to  become 
 woody  and  you  will  not  get  nearly  as 
 many  blooms  as  you  will  if  you  let  them 
 get  four  foot  and  above.  So  four  to  six 
 foot  is  kind  of the  sweet  spot  for  um 
 hibiscus.  And  since  blooms  are  a  big 
 part  of  what  they're  doing  here  to 
 attract  all  kinds  of  beautiful  things, 
 you  know,  I  asked  my  clients  to  go 
 around  four  to  six  foot  and  keeping  them 
 the  rear  wall  here.  So  they're  they're 
 going  to  be  kind  of  that  colorful  bright 
 red  and  green  wall  directly  behind  this

 against  this  green.  So  that's  part  of  my 
 design  style  that  it,  you  know,  kind  of 
 mixed  in  with  her  butterfly  style.  So 
 these  Sanchez  are  going  to  cluster  here 
 at  a  nice  3-foot  height  on  both  sides.

 going  to  really  become  just  a  nice  bit 
 of  dark  green  foliage.  And  then  another 
 favorite  butterfly  plant,  our  second

 some  railroad  vine  for  the  butterflies 
 to  really  just  enjoy  a  little  touch  on 
 either  side  of  the  dwarfed  pentis.  Of 
 course,  when  I  have  boulders,  I  put 
 foxtail  ferns  in  here.  I  know  you  guys 
 from  up  north  probably  are  laughing  when 
 I  call  these  boulders,  but  in  Florida, 
 they're  boulders.  soon.  They're  small 
 boulders,  but  we  just  kind  of  have  them 
 to  give  them  just  a  change  in  the  garden 
 because  this  is  not  a  big  bed,  and  it's 
 hard  to  fill  up  a  big  bed  like  this  with 
 plants.  So,  changing  the  elements  is  a 
 great  way  of  doing  just  that.  I  have  a 
 little  bit  of  golden  sedum  right  at  the 
 touch  because  the  heat  off  of  this 
 sidewalk  is  intense.  So,  you  really  have 
 to  work  with  some  plants  that  are  really 
 going  to  be  able  to  handle  that  long 
 term.  And  these  guys,  all  of  these  guys 
 can  battle  that  battle.  So,  it's  going 
 to  just  be  a  nice  little  punch  in  an 
 area  that  we  could  put  it.  So,  all 
 right,  gardeners,  that's  pretty  much  the 
 end  of  our  front  yard  tour.  I'm  going  to 
 list  the  plants  again  that  were 
 butterfly  plants  amongst  this  garden, 
 which  the  first  one  was  the  red 
 hibiscus.  The  second  blew  my  minds  cuz 
 they're  just  blew  my  minds.  And  then  the 
 third  is  the  uh  dwarfed  pink  pentas.  The 
 fourth  is  the  yellow  African  iris.  The 
 fifth  is  the  sapphire  durant  tree.  Oh  my 
 goodness.  The  sixth  is  the  anmarie 
 lantana.  The  seventh  is  the  dwarf 
 firebush.  The  eighth  is  the  yellow 
 lantana  tree.  Nine  is  the  mimosa  tree 
 which  is  not  yet  in  bloom.  So,  and  then 
 10  is  the  milkweed.  Now,  if  you  count 
 the  trees  and  of  course  everything 
 winged  loves  trees.  So,  if  you  count  the 
 orchid  tree  and  the  bottle  brush  tree 
 and  the  vines,  I  mean,  all  of  that  can 
 also  be  included.  But  overall, 
 plant-wise,  if  those  are  things  that  you 
 want  to  incorporate  into  your  garden  to 
 bring  some  winged  friends  in,  and  then 
 those  are  a  great  grouping  that  I  would 
 include  in  landscapes  that  I  create  for 
 others  as  well  as  my  own  garden.  All 
 right,  you  guys.  Thank  you  so  much  for 
 joining  us.  Please  like  and  subscribe.

 So  today  we  are  talking  about  having  a 
 strategy  and  why  it  matters  in  creating 
 a  backyard  tropical  environment.  Hey 
 gardeners,  today  we  are  in  Port  St. 
 Lucy,  Florida  and  we  are  going  to  talk 
 about  how  we  created  this  tropical  oasis 
 or  maybe  a  start  of  a  tropical  oasis  and 
 that's  exactly  what  we  did  for  our 
 client.  My  client  is  an  avid  gardener 
 from  up  north  and  he  knows  that 
 gardening  in  Florida  has  its  has  its, 
 you  know,  struggles.  So,  what  he  wanted 
 to  do  was  not  do  things  twice.  He 
 contacted  us  to  create  a  private  area 
 for  his  very  small  backyard  space.  Those

 Lucy  recently  know  they  have  beautiful 
 communities,  but  the  lot  lines  are  a  lot 
 to  be  desired  of.  You  kind  of  share  your 
 lot  line  with  your  neighboring  house  on 
 both  sides.  So,  he  wanted  something  that 
 was  his,  that  would  become  his  private 
 sanctuary,  his  private  garden,  a  place

 the  heavy  lifting,  create  a  design  that 
 for  things  that  are  going  to  work.  And

 and  trees  in  this  video,  why  we  place

 the  soil  prep,  bringing  in  the  big 
 trees,  he  is  going  to  doll  it  up  with

 for  the  spaces,  what  they're  going  to  do 
 in  the  future,  overall  heights  of  what 
 they're  going  to  be,  and  and  the  reasons 
 why  we  put  them  in  this  particular  spot. 
 Just  to  kind  of  give  you  a  point  of 
 reference,  this  whole  backyard  space  is 
 about  25  foot  deepway  and  about  40  foot 
 deep  or  45  foot  wide  uh  lengthwise.  So, 
 we're  really  talking  about  a  fairly 
 small  space.  And  I  will  pop  have  Bryce 
 pop  in  a  before  picture  of  what  it 
 looked  like.  One  of  the  things  that  you 
 want  to  avoid  in  a  small  space  is  you 
 don't  want  to  take  it  in  and  bring  all 
 the  plants  and  all  the  trees  and  all  the 
 walls  of  the  garden  and  bring  them  in  so 
 tight  that  you  feel  gosh  like  you've 
 done  the  opposite  of  what  you  want  to 
 do.  You  made  it  smaller.  You  made  it 
 more  congested.  That's  why  it's  really 
 important  to  pick  the  perfect  column 
 trees  to  go  into  that  space  because  it 
 raises  the  roof  line.  It's  like  all  of  a 
 sudden  now  it  opens  your  view  line, 
 opens  your  eyes  up  all  the  way  to  14, 
 15,  16  foot  where  before  you  just  kind 
 of  saw  a  flat,  you  know,  area  of  grass 
 that  was  that  was  kind  of  what  you  were 
 looking  at.  But  because  now  we  have 
 multi-layers  that  are  already  getting 
 started,  it  makes  it  opens  up  the  space 
 almost  like  umbrellas  at  a  resort. 
 That's  what  I  love  about  it.  So,  that's 
 what  I  wanted  to  kind  of  share  with  you 
 guys.  So,  if  you  could  you  can  get  them 
 started.  And  those  of  you  guys  who  are 
 not  able  to  have  a  landscape  company 
 come  in  and  put  in  this  big  material 
 with  their  machines  and  and  do  all  this, 
 don't  let  that  deter  you  because  start 
 small.  Florida  palm  trees  grow  super 
 fast.  You  may  have  a  gap  of  time  before 
 you're  able  to  put  in  your  smaller  plant 
 material  because  everything  is  still 
 young  and  small,  but  you  can  follow  this 
 same  plan.  Just  make  sure  that 
 everything  is  still  staggered.  So  if 
 you're  starting  with  bottle  palm  for 
 instance,  you  know,  and  and  you  may  not 
 be  able  to  go  with  a  30-  gallallon 
 bottle  palm  if  you  only  have  a  30- 
 gallallon  foxtail,  go  ahead  and  start 
 with  a  30-  gallon  or  15  gallon  foxtail 
 and  maybe  start  with  a  three  gallon  or 
 7gallon  bottle  palm.  You  know,  just  make 
 sure  you're  staggering  the  material  so 
 that  way  everything  grows  in  unison  like 
 this.  Really  going  to  do  the  same  thing. 
 You  just  need  a  little  bit  more  time  for 
 it  to  mature.  I  always  forget  to  say 
 this.  If  you  guys  have  not  already, 
 please  subscribe,  hit  that  little 
 notification  bell,  and  we  will  pop  up  in 
 your  feed  every  single  weekend  when  we 
 post  a  new  video.  So,  I  feel  like 
 fishtail  palms  are  are  underused  um  for 
 whatever  reason.  I  think  they're  a 
 fabulous  tree  to  work  with.  I  know  a  lot 
 of  people  go  right  to  a  palms  or  right 
 to  Kucia  or  right  to,  you  know,  some 
 other  kind  of  buffering  trees  and  plants 
 that  can  even  be  a  lot  higher 
 maintenance  than  that.  So,  I  um  I  I  lean 
 towards  using  the  fishtails  when  I  can. 
 But  if  you  guys  have  a  a  favorite,  you 
 know,  something  that  gosh,  you  put  in 
 and  it  just  did  so  well  and  you  want  to 
 share  it  with  the  community,  please  do

 how  well  you  like  it  and  why  you  like  it 
 because  that  is  just  so  helpful  to  new 
 gardeners  from  Florida.  And  that's 
 mainly  who  watch  this  channel  are  a  lot 
 of  new  gardeners  or  a  lot  of  us

 after,  you  know,  fails  and  triumphs  and 
 fails  and  triumphs.  So  save  somebody 
 some  work  and  be  sure  to  post  that  name 
 of  that  plant  or  that  tree  that  you 
 absolutely  loved  and  did  the  job  for 
 you.  But  now  let's  go  into  the  next  the 
 understory  palms.  The  palms  that  are 
 kind  of  right  in  that  sighteline.  The 
 palms  that  I  to  me  are  some  of  the  show 
 pieces  that  are  going  to  be  around  for 
 the  long  haul.  Some  of  these  bigger 
 trees  are  going  to  continue  to  do  what 
 they're  going  to  do,  which  is  really 
 give  you  that  gravitas,  that  raising  of 
 the  canopy  of  the  trees.  The  rest  of 
 these  little  palms,  they're  little  now, 
 but  they're  really  going  to  become  that 
 long-term  solution.  And  one  of  those  is 
 going  to  be  the  Kentopsis.  I  don't  get 
 to  use  this  tree  very  often.  I 
 absolutely  love  love love  this  tree.  It 
 can  handle  temperatures  and  drops  down 
 into  the  low30s,  which  is  unusual  for  a 
 lot  of  tropical  uh  Florida  palms.  I  love 
 this.  I  mean,  I  don't  know  if  you  guys 
 can  tell  or  if  it  comes  across  on 
 camera,  but  I  love  this  big  frond  and 
 the  verticalness  of  it.  I  love  I  just 
 love  the  way  it  just  has  a  completely 
 different  look  than  a  foxtail,  than  a 
 pygmy,  than  a  fish  tail.  You  know,  it's 
 the  whole  idea  is  when  you  look  back 
 here,  you  just  have  a  mesh  of  different 
 kind  of  textures  and  different  kind  of 
 fronds.  They're  all  green,  but  they're 
 all  different.  And  that's  kind  of  to  me 
 what  creates  that  tropical  vibe.  And 
 these  are  going  to  not  outgrow  the 
 foxtail  palm.  They  will  continue  to  get 
 big  like  a  lot  of  Florida  palms,  but 
 it's  never  going  to  compete  with  that 
 over  time  because  this  is  going  to 
 obviously  started  out  as  a  much  much 
 smaller  accent  tree.  So,  these  are  great 
 trees  to  work  with.  They  can  handle 
 sandy  soils.  They  can  handle  a  little 
 bit  of  moisture.  They  can  handle  full 
 sun.  And  they  can  handle  filtered  light. 
 So,  and  they  can  handle  those  occasional 
 drops  that  we  get.  And  they're  cool.  I 
 mean,  I  just  think  they're  super  cool. 
 So,  nice  compact  tree  that  you  can  fit 
 into  a  tight  space.  So,  the  next  tree, 
 and  I  know  I  use  these  all  the  time,  and 
 there  is  a  lovehate  relationship  with 
 these  trees  so  very  often,  but  you  guys 
 know  they  are  on  my  list  of  fan 
 favorites  because  they  are  tough,  and  I 
 love  this  wispy  frond  to  them.  Now,  we 
 had  three  pygmy  palms  around  the 
 centerpiece  tree.  This  is  a  direct  view 
 line  from  Pat's  windows  or  his  doors 
 right  from  the  front  and  right  from  the 
 front  door  of  his  house.  This  is  what  he 
 sees.  And  I  know  he  wanted  to  keep  the 
 water  line  pretty  close.  Unfortunately, 
 I  could  not  find  pygmies  any  taller.  And 
 so  I  told  him,  I  said, "I  can  bring 
 these  in.  They're  going  to  be  a  bit 
 short  for  right  now,  but  in  time,  they 
 really  are  going  to  create  that  perfect 
 level  of  privacy  that  he's  looking  for. 
 Once  these  guys  hit  their  maturity  at 
 right  around  12t  tall,  they'll  have  four 
 four  and  1/2t  of  trunk.  The  rest  of  it 
 will  be  canopy.  And  that  is  going  to  do, 
 I  guess  you  guys  can  guess  what  it's 
 going  to  do.  It's  going  to  completely 
 block  out  those  house  lines  from  his 
 viewpoint  right  outside  his  front  door, 
 right  outside  his  back  doors  that  open 
 up  to  his  screen  room.  This  is  going  to 
 become  a  wall  kind  of  like  the  fishtail 
 palms  do,  but  instead  of  being  solid  all 
 the  way  to  the  top,  they're  going  to  be 
 nice  and  open  at  the  trunk  and  create 
 kind  of  like  a  palm  hedge  along  the 
 backside  to  really  give  him  the  wall, 
 not  see  the  roof  lines,  not  see  the 
 house  lines,  but  still  see  the  water 
 lines.  So,  um,  so  if  you  guys  can  bring 
 them  in  a  little  bit  larger,  if  you  find 
 them  at  nurseries  where  they  have  more 
 leg  and  then  the  canopy  is  is  higher  and 
 they're  around  9  or  10  foot,  ideal.  They 
 are  hard  to  find  at  that  size  because 
 they  grow  kind  of  slow,  but  they  do  when 
 once  they're  planted,  once  they're 
 installed,  once  they're  full  grown,  they 
 stay  there  for  a  very  long  time.  So, 
 this  becomes  a  long-term  fix.  The  next 
 intermediate  tree  is  going  to  be  the 
 bottle  palm.  And  you  guys  know  I  love  my 
 bottle  palms.  I  just  love  what  they  do 
 in  the  garden.  I  think  they're 
 absolutely  just  an  interesting  kind  of 
 architectural  detail  in  the  garden  with 
 those  big  trunks  and  how  they  bow  out. 
 This  guy  is  still  very  young.  He  was  a 
 25  gallon  when  we  put  him  in  about  5  and 
 1/2t  tall  and  um  but  max  out  at  14t  and 
 when  they're  when  this  is  14t  it  is 
 going  to  offer  shade  all  in  this  area 
 right  here.  So  you  can  put  farfu,  you 
 can  put  rojo  congos,  you  can  put  just 
 tons  of  stuff  because  even  at  14  foot, 
 these  canopies  will  have  quadrupled  in 
 size  and  really  branch  out  and  fill  and 
 create  like  an  umbrella  around  here.  Now 
 a  foxtail  will  only  offer  so  much  shade 
 because  it  is  so  tall  at  its  full  grown 
 height  of  20some  height  where  this  tree 
 itself  here  will  stay  kind  of  squatted 
 and  small  and  really  offer  a  nice  bit  of 
 shade  underneath  of  it.  So,  it  is  the 
 perfect  tree  to  kind  of  create  a  little 
 shade  garden,  a  little  pocket  of  shade 
 garden.  Now,  they  do  like  a  little 
 filtered  protection  when  you  plant  them. 
 So,  go  ahead  if  you  plant  a  bottle  palm, 
 plant  a  couple  trees  around  them,  like  a 
 foxtail,  like  a  queen,  like  a  royal 
 palm,  anything  that's  going  to  kind  of 
 give  you  a  little  bit  of  coverage 
 because  they're  the  perfect  under  canopy 
 tree.  They're  always  meant  to  be  kind  of 
 a  a  second  story  tree  or  secondary  tree 
 to  a  bigger  canopy  tree  and  it's  really 
 going  to  give  you  that  multi-layer  look. 
 So  these  guys,  pygmy  date  palms, 
 pentopsis,  those  are  trees  that  are 
 going  to  offer  you  a  great  deal  of  shade 
 underneath  that  underneath  their 
 canopies  because  they're  going  to  stay 
 more  squatted,  more  more  canopy  than 
 they  are  going  to  be  trunk.  And  then  of 
 course  your  trees  above  them  are  going 
 to  offer  those  trees  the  protection.  And 
 then  you  have  a  heavy  tropical  garden 
 that  is  kind  of,  you  know,  helping  each 
 other  with  changing  the  microclimates 
 around  it.  taking  it  away  from  a  full 
 sun  bright  bright  spot  to  more  of  a 
 filtered  light  environment  to  give  you  a 
 lot  of  opportunity  for  so  many  different 
 plants  and  accents  for  underneath  those 
 groupings.  So  you  guys,  it's  just  that 
 easy.  If  this  is  kind  of  what  you're

 So,  congratulations  gardeners.  You  have 
 gotten  the  plants.  You've  gotten  your 
 trees.  You've  dug  the  holes.  You  put 
 them  all  into  the  ground.  You've  mulched 
 them.  You're  completely  satisfied  with 
 the  work  that  you've  done  or  had  done. 
 And  you're  like,  "Now  what?  What  next? 
 How  do  I  keep  this  landscaping  gorgeous 
 and  thriving?  And  what  do  I  do  next?" 
 So,  I  do  virtual  consults  where  clients 
 can  ask  me  questions  on  what  to  do  with 
 this  or  what  to  do  with  that,  like  small 
 areas  that  they  might  be  struggling 
 with.  And  I  was  so  surprised  how  often  I 
 got  this  question  like,  "Okay,  so  you 
 talk  about,  you  know,  combination 
 plants.  You  talk  about,  you  know,  what 
 to  do  over  time  when  what,  you  know,  but 
 what  do  we  do  after  that  landscaping's 
 in?  What  do  we  do  to  create  that  that 
 just  that  lush  tropical  foliage  to 
 really  take  off  and  grow?"  And  so  I'm 
 going  to  tell  you  guys  exactly  what  I 
 tell  all  of  my  clients  right  after  the 
 planting.  It's  as  simple  as  four  steps 
 to  keeping  your  garden  from  going 
 downhill  and  keeping  it  really  thriving. 
 So  the  very  first  thing  is  water.  So  I 
 know  we  always  say  water,  water,  water, 
 but  the  exact  what  I  tell  my  clients  to 
 do  is  water.  If  you  have  sandy  soil  like 
 my  client  does  here,  we're  getting  ready 
 to  do  this  tour.  If  you  have  sandy  soil 
 like  that,  then  you're  going  to  water 
 want  to  water  every  single  day  for  about 
 30  minutes  a  day.  And  that  I  know  that 
 seems  excessive,  but  I  promise  you 
 that's  really  going  to  help  those  roots 
 kind  of  start  to  spread  and  pull  out. 
 You're  going  to  dial  back  that  water 
 after  30  days.  you  can  do  every  other 
 day  after  30  days  for  the  same  amount  of 
 time.  And  then  you're  going  to  move 
 yourself  into  a  90-day  cycle  where 
 you're  watering  three  days  a  week.  And 
 that's  kind  of the  goal.  Three  days  a 
 week  is  an  awesome  amount  of  time  to 
 water  for  approximately  30  to  45  minutes 
 just  depending  on  what  you're  what  you 
 know  what's  allotted  for  your  area.  But 
 those  are  great  basic  lines  to  follow. 
 Now,  if  you  have  clay  soil  where  the 
 water  kind  of  runs  off  and  it  doesn't 
 stay  very  long,  you  may,  believe  it  or 
 not,  have  to  water  that  first  month  a 
 couple  times  a  day  for  10-minute 
 intervals.  So,  you  might  have  to  water 
 late  in  the  evening  or  early  early  in 
 the  morning  for  about  10  minutes.  Let 
 that  water,  it'll  sit  on  the  top.  Some 
 of  it  will  percolate  down,  the  rest  of 
 it  will,  you  know,  unfortunately  you'll 
 lose  it.  But,  you're  going  to  want  to 
 kind  of  get  those  plants  ready  and 
 established.  And  what  you're  trying  to 
 do  is  you're  trying  to  get  your  plants 
 to  realize  that  gosh,  you're  not  in 
 survival  mode.  You're  not  starving 
 yourself.  You're  going  to  actually  push 
 them  to  say,  "Okay,  there's  moisture  out 
 there.  Let's  go  out  and  find  it."  So, 
 that  is  the  goal  to  get  them 
 established.  And  then  you're  going  to 
 dial  that  water  way  back  because 
 tropicals  don't  need  tons  and  tons  of 
 water.  So,  before  we  get  into  the  next 
 tip,  you  guys  be  sure  to  like  and 
 subscribe.  Bryce  and  I  put  these  videos 
 out  every  single  weekend.  And  if  this  is 
 the  kind  of  content  that  you  like  to 
 watch,  a  little  bit  of  learning  about 
 plants  and  trees,  a  little  bit  about 
 showing  plant  and  tree  material  off, 
 what  does  well  in  our  area,  then 
 definitely  hit  that  like  and  subscribe 
 button  as  long  as  that  as  well  as  that 
 little  notification  bell.  Okay,  you 
 guys.  So,  for  tip  two,  tip  two  is  more 
 like  an  advanced  warning.  You  know,  this 
 is  probably  going  to  happen  when  it 
 comes  to  your  palm  trees  especially.  So, 
 if  you  had  gone  to  the  garden  center  and 
 you  put  that  bad  boy  in  the  back  of  your 
 truck  and  the  garden  guys  wrapped  up 
 that  canopy  with  some  rope,  that  way  you 
 can  corral  it  into  your  backyard  and 
 install  it  um  into  your  garden.  Then 
 it's  you  untie  that  canopy  and 
 beautiful,  beautiful  green.  But  then 
 about  two  weeks  later,  you  see  tons  of 
 brown  foliage  on  there  and  you're  like, 
 what  is  happening?  What  is  going  wrong? 
 This  is  something  I  tell  my  clients 
 right  from  the  beginning.  It  is  common 
 for  transplanted  trees  from  one  location 
 to  the  other.  When  you  tie  those 
 canopies  up  on  those  palms,  they  get 
 rope  burn.  They  do  not  like  it.  They  do 
 not  love  us  for  it.  Now,  they  will 
 reproduce  very  quickly,  but  that  is  just 
 a  normal  process.  You  know,  we  try  to  do 
 it  for  such  a  minimal  amount  of  time. 
 You  know,  if  it's  done  for  a  few  hours, 
 less  of  the  fronds  are  going to  get 
 damaged.  They  get  a  little  bit  more 
 water.  Less  of  the  fronds  will  show 
 attitude.  So,  those  are  two  things  that 
 you  can  help  to  combat  it.  like  don't 
 leave  those  that  canopy  tied  up  too 
 long.  Go  ahead  and  untie  that  guy  and 
 put  him  in  the  ground  and  then  know  that 
 a  couple  of  those  fronds,  you  know,  up 
 to  five  or  six  frrawns  will  go  brown  and 
 will  drop.  It's  nothing  you're  doing 
 wrong.  That  is  just  part  of  the  process 
 when  canopies  are  tied  up.  And  it  is 
 actually  better  to  tie  up  those  canopies 
 because  you're  really  protecting  the 
 crown  of  the  tree  when  you  do  that.  So 
 instead  of  you  doing  this  and  all  that 
 shaking  and  movement  that  goes  on  when 
 you're  trying  to  install  that  tree, 
 those  limbs  around  that  are  protecting 
 that  crown  from  breaking  or  getting 
 knocked  off.  So  it's  it's  a  good  thing 
 to  do,  but  you  you  know  the  consequence 
 is  is  that  you  will  get  some  brown 
 limbs.  But  the  ultimate  takeaway  is  that 
 it's  not  your  fault.  It's  just  the 
 normal  part  of  process  at  give  it  a 
 little  extra  water  and  it'll  be  fine. 
 It'll  bounce  back  and  give  you  tons  of 
 new  foliage  and  new  fronds  before  you 
 know  it.  So  tip  three  to  me  really  pays 
 off.  Now  as  a  landscape  contractor,  it's 
 part  of  our  process.  Once  the 
 landscaping  is  in,  once  the  good  soil  is 
 in,  we'll  top  coat  everything  with  a 
 root  starter  fertilizer.  Now,  I  know  um 
 I  know  what  people  are  going to  say,  you 
 shouldn't  fertilize  brand  new  plants.  It 
 could  burn  the  roots,  and  that's 
 absolutely  true.  But  you  can  go  in  with 
 a  gentle  fertilizer.  Now,  we  buy  it  big 
 bulk,  but  you  guys,  one  of  my  favorite 
 fertilizers  is  the  Osmicote  Plus.  I 
 mean,  it  is  it's  not  going  to  burn  any 
 roots.  You  can  put  it  in  just  after  the 
 planting.  So  once  the  planting's  in, 
 once  the  mulch  is  in,  take  that  bag  of 
 osmmaote  and  just  spread  it  along  the 
 mulch.  Just  kind  of  chicken  feed  it 
 along  the  mulched  area.  There  is  a  slow 
 release  on  there.  It's  kind  of  like  a 
 resin  that'll  break  down  over  time.  Can 
 last  around  3  to  6  months.  I  do  tend  to 
 do  that  the  first  three  months  and  then 
 the  second  three  months.  And  then  after 
 that,  you  can  go  to  your  regular 
 fertilizer  and  your  plants  are  just 
 going  to  really  take  off.  It's  just 
 really  going  to  get  those  roots  in  and 
 established  and  fast  growth  really, 
 really  fast.  Okay,  so  tip  four,  I  know 
 can  be  very  controversial,  so  I'm  going 
 to  going  to  take  a  load  off  for  this 
 one.  So  tip  four  is  weeds.  We  have  weeds 
 in  Florida.  We  cannot  want  to  talk  about 
 weeds  all  day  long,  but  we  have  them  and 
 we  have  them  in  the  garden.  And 
 especially  when  you  do  a  new 
 landscaping,  one  of  the  things  that  you 
 do  is  we  take  out  quite  a  bit  of  that 
 old  soil,  but  we  bring  in  new  mix  into 
 the  existing  remaining  soil.  Mix  it  all 
 together.  So  that  way  those  plants  and 
 trees  really  get  a  good  dose  of  both. 
 You  know,  they  get  the  old  so  they  can 
 establish  to  that  new  environment  very 
 well  and  they  get  the  new  for  the  boost 
 that  they're  going  to  need  to,  you  know, 
 get  them  strong  and  healthy.  However, 
 when  you  do  all  that  mixing  and  you  do 
 all  that  fertilizing  and  then  you  do  all 
 that  watering,  the  one  thing  that's 
 going  to  grow  is  any  seedling  that  is  in 
 that  ground  or  was  underneath  is  now  on 
 top  and  now  busting  out  to  get  into  the 
 garden.  So,  it  is  very  happy  and  is  very 
 healthy  because  you've  done  all  those 
 great  things  for  it.  So,  weeding  is 
 going  to  be  a  big  part.  The  first  six 
 months  of  a  brand  new  garden  is  the  most 
 crucial.  If  you  can  every  15  days  check 
 for  weeds  through  that  garden.  Whether 
 you're  taking  and  and  hand  pulling  them 
 out  and  getting  the  roots  and  everything 
 with  it,  then  ideal.  If  you  are  there's 
 a  claw  that  you  can  get,  I  think  it's 
 called  grandpa  claw.  I  I'll  get  it.  I'll 
 link  it  down  below.  And  you  put  it  in 
 there  and  you  twist  and  it  pulls  the 
 whole  root  out.  You  can  do  that  as  well. 
 Or  you  can  spray.  Now,  I  know  a  lot  of 
 people  don't  like  the  idea  of  spraying, 
 but  spraying  does  get  into  the  green 
 down  into  the  root  system.  so  that  one 
 weed  is  not  producing  seeds  for  multiple 
 weeds  creating  neighbors  of  weeds  all 
 the  way  around.  The  reason  why  I  say  the 
 first  six  months  is  so  crucial  is 
 because  all  of  those  new  weeds  are  going 
 to  start  to  really  kind  of  come  up  after 
 the  landscaping  starts  to  get 
 established.  So  the  first  six  months  is 
 all  of  those  weeds  that  are  that  were  in 
 the  ground  that  you  couldn't  get  out 
 during  um  during  demo  and  removal.  If 
 you  allow  those  weeds  to  become 
 full-blown  weeds,  now  those  weeds  will 
 produce  new  weeds.  And  you  kind  of  see 
 the  invasion  of  weeds  and  how  that 
 works.  But  if  you  stay  on  it,  takes 
 about  a  weed  about  15  days  to  go  from  a 
 seed  to  an  actual  weed.  If  you  hit  it 
 every  15  days,  like  on  your  calendar, 
 then  I'm  telling  you,  you're  really 
 going  to  eradicate  weeds  from  your 
 garden.  It  is  the  best  way  to  get  rid  of 
 them.  Go  through  and  either  spray  or 
 pull  or  whatever  your  method  is.  Hit 
 those  bad  boys  right  from  the  beginning. 
 and  that  way  they're  not  replicating  and 
 creating  a  a  havoc  of  weeds  throughout 
 your  whole  garden.  And  if  you  guys  run 
 across  anything  that  you've  done  in  your 
 garden  that  has  just  been  a  gamecher, 
 then  please  stick  in  the  comments  down 
 below.  Those  of  you  guys  who  are  looking 
 for  alternative  options,  read  those 
 comments  down  below  because  we  have  a 
 fantastic  community  of  gardeners  out 
 there.  You  guys  are  fabulous  and  you've 
 always  put  putting  really  good  details 
 into  the  comments  kind  of  sharing  your 
 advice  and  your  experience  and  and  some 
 of  your  failures  which  I  just  I  I  just 
 love  that  which  really  helps  a  lot  of 
 that  a  lot  of  folks  that  are  new  to 
 Florida  or  new  gardeners  in  general.  It 
 really  helps  them  kind  of  skip  those 
 some  of  those  bad  steps  that  you  know

 So,  I  know  today's  video  is  a  little  bit
