 Well,  hello  gardeners.  Welcome  back. 
 Today  I  want  to  talk  with  you  about  how 
 to  maximize  those  small  spaces  that  you 
 might  be  working  with  in  your  own  house 
 like  I'm  working  with  in  mine.  So,  about 
 a  year  and  a  half  ago,  I  did  a  living 
 wall  and  my  sideyard  section.  And  I 
 wanted  to  share  with  you  some  pros  and 
 cons  that  I've  dealt  with  along  the  way. 
 I've  absolutely  really  enjoyed  having 
 it.  I  feel  like  it's  flushed  out  and  it 
 really  does  the  job  of  making  big 
 impacts  for  what  is  a  generally  small 
 space.  This  area  is  about  5  foot  deep. 
 So  from  the  foundation  of  my  house  to 
 the  edge  of  this  patio  here  is  about  5 
 foot  wide  and  then  it  is  pretty  much 
 flat  along  the  side  north  side  of  my 
 house.  And  it  kind  of  covers  up  a 
 bathroom  window  that  was  fully  exposed 
 as  you  walk  along  this  walkway.  Now, 
 this  area  along  the  walkway  is  where  a 
 lot  of  my  guests  come  from  the  front 
 door  leading  to  my  backyard  patio 
 section.  So,  this  is  the  main  used  area 
 for  that  pathway.  So,  I  kind  of  wanted  I 
 wanted  it  to  carry  over.  I  wanted  it  to 
 have  that  same  kind  of  tropical  jungle 
 vibe  that  you  know  as  you're  coming 
 around  to  the  front  yard  or  from  the 
 front  yard  to  the  backyard  that  you're 
 really  starting  to  get  that  impact  as 
 you  come  around  this  corner.  So,  when 
 you  hit  this  gate,  it  kind  of  turns  into 
 more  of  a  secluded  garden  gate.  And  what 
 better  way  to  do  that  when  you  don't 
 have  a  lot  of  space  to  work  with  than  go 
 up.  So  I  I  guess  to  say  as  a  tropical 
 gardener,  I  wasn't  satisfied  with  how 
 much  I  could  do  with  the  width  of  this 
 space.  Instead,  we  ended  up  going 
 vertical.  So  we're  a  little  over  8  foot 
 tall. 
 Olive.  I  don't  know if  you  guys  saw 
 Olive  in  the  previous  video,  but  when  I 
 first  did  this  video,  she  was  a  brand 
 new  puppy,  and  this  is  her  now,  a  year 
 later,  and  she  is  nothing  but  trouble. 
 But  she  likes  to  make  her  cameos.  So, 
 before  we  were  so  interrupted  with  Olive 
 here,  um  I  wanted  to  share  with  you 
 guys,  um  kind  of  some  pros  and  cons  of 
 the  the  wall  structure  is.  And  later  in 
 the  video,  I  want  to  share  with  you, 
 Bryce  is  going  to  pop  up  kind  of  the 
 overall  supply  list  of  what  we  needed  to 
 create  this  space.  So,  for  you  DIYers 
 out  there,  I  wanted  you  to  have  kind  of 
 a  shopping  list  of  what  you  could  do  to 
 recreate  this  in  a  pinch  on  your  own. 
 And  because  I  just  think  that  it's 
 something  that  I  don't know,  everybody 
 should  try  and  hopefully  some  of  my  dos 
 will  help  and  some  of  my  don'ts  will 
 help  as  well  with  not  having  to  recreate 
 some  of  my  mistakes  in  the  garden.  For 
 the  first  pro,  I  would  say  is  just  look 
 at  the  impact  this  makes  in  the  space. 
 We've  got  nearly  40  plants  on  this  list 
 or  on  this  panel  here.  And  what  kind  of 
 impact  can  this  small  narrow  space  make 
 with  40  plants  if  it's  not  going 
 vertical?  I  really  do  feel  like  it  just 
 kind  of  comes  out  and  gets  you.  It  just 
 it  has  all  these  layers,  all  these 
 different  textures,  all  of  this 
 interest.  And  to  me,  that  is  such  a 
 significant  pro  because  it's  very  hard, 
 especially  in  our  Florida  gardens,  to 
 find  room  for  some  of  that  impact.  In 
 doing  so,  I  think  that  it  does  a  great 
 job  as  I  pair  it  with  my  water  feature 
 next  to  it.  I  think  that  that's  a  a 
 perfect  way  to  take  a  narrow  space  and 
 kind  of  create  something  really 
 interesting  with  it.  The  places  I 
 learned  that  the  most  are  some  of  those 
 resorts  that  I  got  to  travel  through  um 
 through  the  years.  You  know,  they  do 
 such  a  good  job  of  finding  little  key 
 little  corners  or  nooks  in  the  garden, 
 maybe  courtyard  spaces,  and  they've 
 popped  in  some  fountains  and  some  water 
 features  and  maybe  some  hanging  plants 
 or  some  hanging  pots  or  or  a  living 
 wall.  I  have  seen  some  living  wall 
 displays  that  are  absolutely  will  take 
 your  breath  away.  I'll  ask  Bryce  to  pop 
 in  a  picture  of  one  that  I  saw  on  Worth 
 Avenue  and  West  Palm  Beach.  And  you  guys 
 may  have  seen  it  if  you're  from  down 
 south  in  that  area.  And  I  just  think  it 
 is  every  time  I  see  it  takes  my  breath 
 away.  I  think  it  is  super  stunning.  And 
 so,  you  know,  to  me,  having  a  vertical 
 aspect  of  just  kind  of  something  right 
 in  your  face  where  you  see  those  layers 
 kind  of  pile  on  on  top  of  each  other  is 
 just  so  fabulous.  So,  I  hope  you  guys 
 agree.  But  the  second  pro  I  would  say  is 
 maintenance.  So,  I  I  I  know  people  have 
 said  a  living  wall  is  little  to  no 
 maintenance,  and  that  is  not  true.  There 
 is  maintenance  to  any  plants,  especially 
 in  Florida.  But  the  maintenance  is  about 
 this  much.  So,  if  you  had  40  plants  in 
 the  garden  that  was  taking  over  and 
 being  real  lush  and  real  tropical,  then 
 you  would  be  in  there  weeding.  You'd  be 
 in  there  trimming.  You'd  be  in  there 
 separating.  Not  the  case  with  these 
 guys.  So,  your  minimal  maintenance  comes 
 from  just  clipping  any  kind  of  brown 
 that  you  see  in  the  garden  and  just  kind 
 of  removing  that  from  the  wall  itself.  I 
 mean,  it's  really  it's  really  such  a 
 small  thing.  I  do  it  every  once  in  a 
 while.  Overall,  I  I've  picked  out  little 
 to  no  weeds  in  this  space  because  this 
 is  not  getting  a  whole  lot  of  debris 
 that's  sitting  in  those  areas.  It's  nice 
 and  full  and  nice  and  compact.  And  best 
 thing  of  all  is  I  am  not  bent  over 
 weeding  or  clipping  as  I'm  trimming. 
 This  is  a  trimming  like  this.  You  know, 
 pretty  much  overall,  unless  you're 
 scared  of  heights,  you  guys,  because  I 
 do  have  to  get  on  the  ladder  and  trim 
 the  upper  areas.  And  this  probably  why 
 you  notice  that  those  areas  need  more 
 trimming  than  the  rest  of  it  because  I 
 do  that  a  lot  less  time.  But  I  would  say 
 during  the  year,  a  little  over  a  year 
 that  I've  had  this  living  wall,  I  have 
 trimmed  it  twice  and  you  could  have  used 
 it  more.  But,  you  know,  I  like  a  natural 
 jungle  vibe.  So,  I'm  not  worried  with 
 some  brown  leaves  here  and  there. 
 Overall,  I  think  the  maintenance  on  a 
 living  wall  is  about  this  much  compared 
 to  the  maintenance  overall  in  a  plant 
 grouping.  Now,  when  I  fertilize,  I  do 
 something  very  simple.  I  use  the  Miracle 
 Grow  hose  fertilizer,  the  attachment, 
 and  I  just  kind  of  go  through  this  and 
 it  makes  everything  just  lush  and 
 tropical  and  just  absolutely  blooming. 
 It  takes  me  like  2  minutes  to  do  it.  I 
 just  kind  of  give  everything  a  good 
 dose,  but  it  that's  all  it  is.  And  as 
 far  as  watering,  because  of  the  way  the 
 system  set  up,  and  as  I  mentioned,  we'll 
 get  into  that  a  little  bit  later  in  the 
 video,  it  is  there's  no  watering 
 involved.  It's  it's  set  up  to  water 
 itself.  So  I  I  think  overall  the  time 
 that  I  spend  on  this  wall  versus  the 
 rest  of  the  garden  is  just  a  minuscule 
 amount.  It's  just  so  so  small.  So  I 
 think  that  if  you  have  a  small  space, 
 need  a  big  impact,  there's  not  much  more 
 that  you  can  get  with  like  working  with 
 kind  of a  structure  like  this  with  the 
 amount  of  maintenance  that's  involved. 
 And  a  quick  shout  out  to  one  of  my 
 subscribers,  Kimberly.  Hello,  Kimberly. 
 This  is  part  of the  reason  why  we  wanted 
 to  do  this  video.  You  know,  Bryce  had 
 mentioned  that  you  were  thinking  about 
 doing  a  living  wall  and  you  needed  some 
 advice  on  it.  So,  I  thought,  you  know 
 what?  This  is  a  time  for  an  update.  And 
 I'm  so  sorry,  you  guys.  I've  been 
 meaning  to  do  an  update  on  this  wall 
 forever.  And  it  wasn't  until  we  got 
 Kimberly's  message  that  I  was  like,  go  a 
 yes,  we  need  to  do  an  update  on  the 
 living  wall.  And  so,  shout  out  to  you.  I 
 cannot  wait  to  see  pictures.  I  hope  it 
 turns  out  absolutely  beautifully.  And  I 
 hope  this  video  helps  you  once  Bryce 
 puts  in  the  kind  of  details  on  how  to 
 construct  it  for  yourself. 
 So,  let's  start  with  the  plants  that  I 
 would  not  use  again.  Now,  the  sword 
 ferns  I  know  are  a  golden  plant  when  it 
 comes  to  potted  plants.  I  mean,  they're 
 great  for  your  front  entrance  way.  They 
 really  fold  over.  They  get  lush  and  they 
 get  full.  And  I  thought  they  would  do 
 that  as  a  topper  to  this  area  because  I 
 kind  of  wanted  something  that  was  going 
 to  kind  of  come  up  and  kind  of  fold  over 
 and  top  over  this  this  top  of  this 
 feature  so  it  didn't  feel  so  flattened 
 off.  And  I  encourage  you  guys  to  do 
 that.  I  totally  think  if  you're  if  you 
 have  the  protection  of  maybe  from  the 
 sun,  use  bird's  nest  ferns  or  use 
 something  that's  going  to  kind  of  come 
 up  and  come  over  and  fold  over  that  top 
 just  to  soften  that  so  you  lose  some  of 
 that  hardness  at  the  top  of  the  wall  so 
 it  doesn't  look  so  man-made.  Now,  my 
 problem  with  the  bird's  nest  fern  is 
 that  it  there  was  just  more  trimming 
 involved  than  what  I  wanted,  especially 
 for  a  top  tier  plant.  And  then  it  throws 
 out  those  aerial  roots  that  are 
 constantly  and  I'll  get  Bryce  to  slide 
 in  a  picture  of  what  it  looks  like  from 
 behind,  but  they're  constantly  throwing 
 out  those  roots  from  the  back  and  from 
 the  front.  The  front  I  keep  trimmed,  but 
 I  just  think  it  wasn't  appropriate  for 
 what  I  was  looking  for.  It  didn't  do 
 what  I  wanted  it  to  do.  I  would  totally 
 go  back  with  something  softer.  I 
 absolutely  love  what  these  burmilads  are 
 doing.  They're  really  grown  in  lovely, 
 kind  of  multiplied,  and  now  they're 
 starting  to  crawl,  which  is  exactly  what 
 they  would  do  in  nature.  And  that's  what 
 we're  trying  to  replicate  that.  Unlike 
 the  sword  ferns  which  have  kind  of  come 
 in  and  now  I  have  to  um  kind  of  the  ones 
 that  I've  taken  out  I've  had  to  cut  out 
 of  the  pots  just  because  the  roots  are 
 so  aggressive.  And  I  should  know  this  as 
 a  landscaper,  you  know,  working  with 
 them  in  gardens.  But  honestly,  I  don't 
 work  with  them  a  lot  in  the  garden  just 
 because  of  their  aggressiveness  anyway. 
 I  thought  they'd  be  great  in  a  pot  as 
 far  as  a  hanging  wall  because  of  that 
 feathery  kind  of  soft  frrawn  leaf,  but 
 in  my  case,  they  just  didn't  work  out 
 for  what  I  wanted  them  to  work  out  for. 
 So,  that  is  definitely  one  of  my  cons 
 when  it  comes  to  this  garden.  So,  the 
 next  thing  I  would  change  if  I  were  to 
 do  this  again  is  something  that  I'm 
 already  in  the  process  of  doing.  So, 
 when  I  first  started  this  living  wall,  I 
 used  regular  soil.  I  used  my  normal  mix. 
 So,  I  used  a  little  bit  of  Pete  Moss,  a 
 little  bit  of  really  good  black  cow,  and 
 thinking  that  would  really  kind  of  help 
 give  everything  the  nutrients  that  it 
 needed  to  get  started.  However,  these 
 pots  are  so  small,  and  that  did  it 
 retained  more  water  than  I  wanted.  So, 
 with  my  new  plantings  that  are  doing  so 
 much  better,  I've  popped  out  plants  that 
 have,  you  know,  not  done  well  and 
 incorporated  plants  that  are  now  doing 
 well.  With  that,  I've  used  the  cocoa 
 core.  Let  me  show  you  guys  what  my 
 secret  is.  So,  the  cocoa  core  is  it 
 comes  in  like  a  brick  form.  That's  my 
 favorite  kind  and  I  love  it  from  this 
 company.  This  is  not  a  sponsored  video. 
 This  is  just  something  that  I  absolutely 
 love  working  with.  You  just  cut  off  a 
 piece  of  this  brick.  You  put  it  into 
 water.  You  add  a  little  bit  of  perlite 
 with  it.  Now,  I  know  I've  said  in  the 
 past  that  I  use  hardwood  mulch  instead 
 of  perlite,  but  for  these  little  baskets 
 like  this,  perlite  is  ideal.  So,  a 
 mixture  of  this  with  perlite  does  a 
 fabulous  job.  This  will  expand  like  this 
 will  like  fill  nine  pots.  I  mean,  it's 
 amazing  how  this  little  brick  will  work. 
 That's  why  I  love  keeping  them  just  like 
 this  because  I  can  stick  them  on  my 
 shelf,  use  them  when  I  want  to.  Put  a 
 brick  in  some  water,  it  expands.  I  can 
 add  it  to  my  plant  potting  mix  when  I'm 
 ready.  So,  you  do  50%  this,  50%  perlite, 
 put  it  in  those  little  pots,  and  then  it 
 does  a  fantastic  job.  And  what  it  does 
 is  once  it  expands,  it  will  it  will  kind 
 of  create  more  of  a  compost  mix  in  your 
 planting  area.  The  roots  love  to  grab  a 
 hold  of  it.  When  it  gets  too  wet,  it  the 
 water  will  just  drain  out.  Unlike  with 
 soil,  it  really  stays  saturated  and 
 really  can  hold  water  there  way  longer. 
 But  the  two  combination  of  these  two 
 things,  I've  not  had  to  worry  about  any 
 kind  of  root  rot  or  any  kind  of  issue. 
 Whatever  they  don't  need  water-wise,  it 
 drains  out.  So,  it's  been  an  ideal 
 product  to  use.  So,  if  I  were  to  start 
 this  all  over  again,  that  would  be  the 
 mix  that  I  would  go  to.  So,  the  next 
 thing  I  would  do  as  far  as  uh  a  mistake 
 I  guess  I'd  made  is  I  just  looked  at  the 
 space  and  in  all  the  years  of  living 
 here,  this  is  the  north  side  of  my 
 property.  I  thought,  well,  this  is  such 
 a  shady  area  that  I  can  really  go  in 
 with  all  shade  plants  for  this  whole 
 living  wall.  What  I  didn't  consider  is 
 because  I'm  used  to  planting  ground 
 side,  you  know,  I'm  used  to  planting 
 along  the  ground  that  I  didn't  think 
 about  the  upper  area  and  how  that  is 
 going  to  penetrate  from  the  front  of  my 
 house.  how  the  sun  hits  it.  So,  this 
 whole  upper  section  burnt  for  the 
 longest  time.  I  mean,  the  very  first 
 summer  that  I  had  here,  it  pretty  much 
 just  torched  the  whole  top  section  of  my 
 living  wall.  This  whole  bottom  section 
 of  shade  plants  did  superior  did  very, 
 very  well  because,  you  know,  it  did,  you 
 know,  it  worked  for  what,  you  know,  what 
 it  was  meant  for  because  this  is  a  nice 
 shady  spot.  But  I  didn't  anticipate  kind 
 of  how  the  rays  of  the  sun  would  come 
 in.  And  I  feel  like  as  a  gardener  that 
 that's  something  that  that  I  do  in 
 different  environments  and  you  know  in 
 landscapes,  but  I  just  it  it  it  just 
 didn't  dawn  on  me  during  the 
 installation  of  my  living  wall.  So  that 
 top  layer  should  have  been  something 
 sunloving.  So  as  time's  gone  on,  I 
 popped  out  plants  and  put  in  other 
 plants  that  that  are  doing  much  much 
 better.  So  I've  got  some  porchaka  or  if 
 you  guys  call  them  plane  here.  They're 
 still  asleep  for  the  morning  because 
 we're  in  the  in  the  the  early  early  part 
 of  the  day  right  now.  But,  um,  when  they 
 open  up,  you  guys,  that  bright  orange 
 and  yellow  is  just  so  stunning.  And  that 
 is  right  on  that  corner  where  the  sun 
 just  kind  of  hits  because  it  goes  in 
 between  the  two  trees  that  I  have  on 
 this  corner.  Really,  really  filters 
 through  and  hits  just  the  corner  of  the 
 house  with  that  nice  bright  ray  of  sun. 
 And  that's  exactly  what  they  needed.  So 
 all  day  long  they  are  opened  up  and 
 gorgeous  when  the  sun  starts  to  come  out 
 and  hits  those  areas  and  I  just  think 
 it's  stunning.  So  I'm  going  to  go  across 
 the  top  of  the  rest  of  the  living  wall 
 with  some  draping  plants  that  can  really 
 handle  that  kind  of  sun.  So  kind  of  pay 
 attention  to  your  area.  If  you're 
 thinking  about  putting  a  living  wall, 
 don't  just  look  at  the  side  of  the  house 
 like  I  did.  You  know,  look  and  see  gosh, 
 you  know  that  it's  kind  of  hitting  the 
 top  of  my  window.  I  can  see  the  sunlight 
 hit  the  roof  line  of  my  house.  So,  um, 
 know  that  your  living  wall  is  now  going 
 to  be,  you  know,  6  to  7  foot  to  8  foot 
 tall  depending  on,  you  know,  your 
 location  and  then  determine  your  kind  of 
 plant  groupings  from  there.  So,  one  of 
 the  last  things  I  want  to  mention  before 
 we  get  into  the  breakdown  of  the 
 structure  is  that  you  guys,  if  you're 
 building  a  living  wall,  don't  just  look 
 at  the  frame  and  work  with  just  what's 
 in  front  of  you  here.  Kind  of  make  sure 
 that  you've  like  built  the  environment 
 around  it  because  that's  exactly,  you 
 know,  that's  exactly  what  designers 
 dream  up.  So,  if  that's  kind  of  your 
 goal  and  you're  diying  it  yourself, 
 then,  you  know,  think  about  like  the 
 surrounding  area.  So,  we  do  have  the 
 living  wall  structure  here.  I 
 incorporated  some  driftwood  along  the 
 front  so  that  way  I  have  some  impact, 
 some  long  braces,  some  long  um  hangers 
 that  are  here  to  kind  of  give  us  a 
 little  bit  of  impact  so  that  the  living 
 wall  comes  out  at  you.  But  what  I  love 
 the  most  is  that  um  this  little  this 
 little  rock  section  here.  I  I  love  the 
 mixture  of  stones,  adding  the  flag  stone 
 here,  having  a  light  shine  up  on  the 
 wall.  So  when  you're  walking  through 
 this  area,  you  just  kind  of  see  a  glow 
 through  this  whole  this  whole  living 
 wall.  So  it's  almost  like  setting  the 
 scene,  you  guys.  If  you  got  a  place  to 
 incorporate  a  small  fountain, 
 incorporate  it.  No matter  how  small  it 
 is,  but  it  adds  a  little  bit  of  texture, 
 different  shape  in  the  garden.  If  you 
 can  incorporate  some  different  kinds  of 
 stones  and  edge  them  with  different 
 rocks  or  even  bring  in  some  edging  in 
 there,  just  kind  of  separate  that  look. 
 do  that  because  you  know  when  you're 
 working  with  small  spaces,  those  are 
 often  the  hardest  areas  to  work  in.  When 
 we  have  big  areas  to  work  in  as 
 landscape  designers,  we  love  it  because 
 we  can  do  drifts  of  this  and  drifts  of 
 that  and  kind  of  intertwine  and  kind  of 
 create  color  and  interest  with  those 
 ways.  But  when  you  have  a  very  small 
 area  to  work  with,  then  you're  hitting 
 like  a  powerhouse  of  something  and  then 
 an  impact  of  something  else  and  you  kind 
 of  need  to  kind  of  frame  all  the  way 
 around  it  and  it's  a  tiny  area  to  work 
 in.  So  kudos  to  you  guys  who  are  out 
 there  trying  to  make  that  small  space 
 pretty  amazing  because  it  it's  not  an 
 easy  thing.  That's  why  I  really  hope 
 this  video  becomes  helpful  to  you  guys 
 and  and  you  can  kind  of  take  this  as  a  a 
 bit  of  inspiration  saying,  "Oh,  I  kind 
 of  see  where  she  was  going  with  that." 
 And  then  incorporate  it  and  make  it  your 
 own.  So  now  for  the  fun  stuff.  Now  for 
 the  real  stuff.  If  you  guys  are  waiting 
 for  just  the  kind  of  overall 
 construction  of  this  particular  wall, 
 then  screenshot  this  bad  boy  because 
 we're  going  to  lay  it  all  out  for  you. 
 So  to  start  with,  you  want  to  start  with 
 a  freestanding  wall.  You  know,  just 
 being  able  to  get  all  the  way  around  the 
 wall.  Whether  even  if  it's  like  me  where 
 you  only  have  a  couple  foot  to  walk 
 behind  it,  it  is  well  worth  getting  it 
 off  the  house.  So  this  wall  sits  about 
 two  and  a  half  foot  off  of  my  house.  And 
 I've  got  two  4x4  post  flanking  each 
 side.  Those  are  our  support  posts.  And 
 then  I've  got  four  1x4  panels.  The  one 
 that  runs  along  the  top  through  the 
 middle  and  down  two  down  below  on  the 
 bottom.  Those  are  the  things  that 
 support  the  panels  that  we  put  up  on  top 
 of  those.  We  have  three  2  by  six  panels 
 and  we've  attached  those  to  those  those 
 boards,  those  linear  boards  that  are 
 going  across  here.  So,  those  panels, 
 those  wire  panels  are  what's  holding  up 
 our  pots.  So,  we  instantly  create  with 
 that  space  a  nice  solid  structural  wall. 
 Now,  I  did  I  don't  know  if  I  mentioned 
 this,  but  I  did  put  dry  set  concrete,  a 
 bag  of  in  each  under  those  4x4  columns 
 just  to  give  us,  of  course,  that  strong 
 support  structure  because  this  can  get 
 heavy,  you  know,  with  the  plants  and 
 over  time.  Definitely  want  to  make  sure 
 that  your  structure  is  freestanding  and 
 strong.  Then  we  incorporated  40  baskets. 
 Why  40  baskets?  Cuz  that's  what  fit.  If 
 I  could  have  fit  50,  I  would  have  put  50 
 on  there.  But,  you  know,  so  to  each  his 
 own.  And  if  you're  going  to  do  more  free 
 flowing  vines  and  bigger  material,  maybe 
 longer  filidendrans,  things  like  that, 
 you  might  need  less  plants  to  fill  up 
 that  kind  of  space.  But  I  had  a  mixture. 
 I've  got  some  poo  in  here  that  are  big 
 fillers,  but  then  I've  got  things  like 
 bird's  nest  ferns  that  are  kind  of 
 compact  at  the  base  and  then  fan  out,  so 
 they  don't  take  up  a  lot  of  room  and 
 burmilads  and  so  on.  So  I  didn't  want  a 
 bunch  of  gaps  in  my  walls.  If  you  want 
 bigger  plants  that  are  bushier,  then 
 obviously  you  need  less  pots.  But 
 that's,  you  know,  that's  make  it  your 
 own  your  own  style  for  your  own  space. 
 So,  40  plants  in  general  here,  which  I 
 know  feels  like  it's  probably  a  lot. 
 There's  no  way  I  could  have  put  that  in 
 the  ground  and  had  that  many  plants  kind 
 of  really  fill  in  these  gaps.  I'm  going 
 to  do  my  best  to  kind  of  just  point  to 
 the  plant  and  and  hit  the  names  of  those 
 plants.  I  have  a  lot  of  replicated 
 plants  in  here,  so  I  won't  there  won't 
 be  40  individual  varieties.  But,  as  I 
 mentioned  before,  that  top  section  there 
 are  the  sword  ferns.  They're  probably 
 coming  out  shortly.  I've  got  a  mix  of  a 
 little  bit  of  macho  ferns  in  there  that 
 might  be  still  tucked  in,  but  I've 
 removed  most  of  those  because  again,  too 
 much  sunlight.  They  just  kind  of  burnt 
 up  on  me.  And  then  I  have  the  Athereum 
 pearly  whites  here.  I  just  think  they're 
 doing  so  well.  Just  really  filling  in 
 this  spot,  kind  of  giving  us  a  fern-like 
 look.  They  are  getting  a  little  bit  of 
 sun  from  that  corner,  but  overall 
 they're  a  perfect  shade  plant,  but 
 they're  very,  very  tough.  And  then  I've 
 got  a  mix  of  this  right  here  is  just  a 
 dwarf  alicia.  These  are  from  pups  from 
 my  garden.  Anytime  I  get  a  pup,  I'll 
 just  take  that  off  and  then  pop  it  right 
 into  these  little  planters.  Even  if  I've 
 got  a  plant  growing  out  of  it,  I'll  just 
 kind  of  put  them  on  the  side  and,  you 
 know,  just  to  add  a  little  bit  of  extra 
 flare  because  I  like  to  soften  these 
 edges.  Like  I  like  to  soften  the  top.  So 
 having  something  protrude  over  to  the 
 side  and  come  up  over  the  top 
 naturalizes  that  flat  wall  space.  This 
 is  just  a  little  little  bit  of  alicacia 
 that  you  can  kind  of  use  throughout  your 
 garden.  And  I  love  how  I  can  source 
 those  everywhere.  But  it  has  grown  in, 
 taken  off,  and  done  super  super  well. 
 I've  got  a  lemon  lime  poo  vine  here.  I 
 know  poo  are  one  of  those  things  that 
 people  love  and  hate  because  they  can 
 really  take  over  a  space.  I  personally 
 love  them  for  this  kind  of  environment. 
 They're  off  of  my  wall.  I  can  allow  them 
 to  drape  drape  until  they  get  almost  to 
 the  ground  and  then  I  clip  that  bad  boy. 
 I'll  take  those  clippings  and  put  it 
 into  another  pot  and  start  over  again. 
 So,  as  long  as  you  know  a  couple  times  a 
 year  you  go  out  and  you  just  kind  of 
 clip  what  you  don't  want,  they're  an 
 ideal  plant  to  work  with.  Do  not  let 
 them  get  into  the  ground,  though, 
 because  they  can  take  over  and  fill  in  a 
 spotlight.  Nobody's  business.  So, 
 perfect  for  a  hanging  wall,  though.  So

 If  you're  looking  for  a  tough  tough 
 spot,  they  can  dry  out.  They  can  get  a

 Well,  hello  gardeners.  Welcome  back.  So, 
 I  hope  you  are  ready  for  another  garden 
 tour.  We  are  in  Port  St.  Lucy,  Florida 
 today  and  we're  going  to  walk  through 
 this  lovely  yet  small,  very  compact 
 backyard  tropical  oasis.  And  I'm  going 
 to  say  oasis  because  that's  exactly  what 
 it  is.  Is  it  a  teenytiny  footprint  of 
 about  15  foot  deep?  Yes.  But  I  really  do 
 think  that  these  clients  maximized  every 
 bit  of  space.  I  mean,  that  was  the  whole 
 conversation  when  we  met.  It  was  like, 
 we  don't  want  grass.  We  just  want  to  sit 
 out  here  on  our  backyard  patio  and  enjoy 
 the  backyard  space  and  enjoy  that 
 tropical  environment  and  not  look  at  all 
 the  houses  across  the  street.  So,  if 
 that  is  you  guys,  if  you  guys  are  in  a 
 community  and  you're  looking  to  maybe 
 take  out  most  of  the  grass  or  all  of  the 
 grass  and  create  a  tropical  garden  to 
 kind  of  infold  that  back  patio,  then 
 stick  around  because  this  video  is  going 
 to  be  just  for  you.  And  towards  the  end 
 of  this  video,  we're  going  to  do  that 
 thing  that  you  guys  absolutely  commented 
 about.  Thank  you  so  much  for  all  your 
 comments.  that  overhead  view  line  of 
 what  this  uh  particular  garden  looks 
 like  so  you  guys  can  see  it  in  full

 going  to  try  to  do  that  as  often  as  we 
 can.  But  so  let's  jump  right  into  this.

 in  the  neighboring  backyards.  All right,

 us.  Um,  this  is  a  big  panoramic  screen

 and  these  doors  all  join  that  front  door

 door,  you  see  kind  of  all  of  this  space.

 had  a  um  a  quick  story.  I  had  a  somebody 
 come  over  to  buy  something  from

 the  best  compliment  ever.  We  were

 like  infolded  with  like  a  lot  more."  So,

 gardener  because  that's  exactly  what  I 
 wanted  back  there.  I  know  that  we  all

 close  by  and  that's  just  part  of  the  joy 
 of  living  in  Florida.  But  when  you  can 
 take  and  and  have  that  all  those 
 benefits  without  the  negative  of  having 
 to  be,  you  know,  so  on  top  of  each 
 other,  then  I  think  that  was  just  a 
 true,  you  know,  true  compliment  of 
 success.  And  so  I  want  to  share  that 
 with  you  guys  because  I  bet  as  you're 
 gardening,  you  kind  of  run  across  things 
 like  that.  And  I,  you  know,  it  hit  home 
 with  me.  I  thought  it  might  hit  home 
 with  you,  too.  That  is  pretty  much  the 
 end  of  the  plant  and  tree  material.  It 
 was  pretty  much  gives  you  the  name  and 
 the  callouts  for  everything  that's  here. 
 The  only  thing  I  didn't  address  was  the 
 the  irrigation  systems.  You  can  see  that 
 they  the  homeowner  has  an  irrigation 
 system  through  the  community,  but 
 because  they  wanted  to  make  sure  that 
 they  didn't  just  have  to  stick  to  the 
 reclaimed  water  that's  available  to  the 
 community,  he  went  ahead  and  put  in 
 these  small  little  irrigation  um  heads, 
 these  misters  that  he  can  control  right 
 off  his  spot  that  can  get  these  plants 
 and  trees  established  from  the  get-go. 
 So,  I  think  that's  ideal.  That  way,  he 
 does  not  have  to  hand  water  it.  He  can 
 see  the  irrigation  coming  on.  All  this 
 is  is  a  tube  that  runs  like  an  entire 
 oval  around  the  bed.  The  tube  goes  from 
 the  front,  curves  around  the  backside, 
 and  the  tube  itself  is  solid.  So,  all  he 
 had  to  do  was  pop  in  these  those  little 
 heads  that  you're  seeing  there  um  into 
 that  tube  just  where  he  needs  it.  And 
 that  was  done  after  the  plants  were  in. 
 It  was  so  easy  to  be  able  to  make  sure 
 that  coverage  got  put  where  it  need  to 
 get  put  and  then  not  where  it  didn't 
 need  it.  So,  I  I'm  an  advocate  for  that. 
 I  love  that  idea  because  a  lot  of  us 
 have  to  handwater  until  things  get 
 established  when  you're  with  a  community 
 and  you're  only  on  their  time  clock.  So, 
 I  will  make  sure  to  put  that  link  in  the 
 description  down  below.  So,  if  you  guys 
 are  thinking  about  landscaping  or 
 getting  ready  to  have  a  landscaper  come 
 out  and  do  your  work,  get  that  put  in 
 because  it  is  something  that  a  homeowner 
 can  easily  do  without  any  experience. 
 It's  just  running  a  line  to  the  back, 
 popping  a  hole  in,  and  then  I  guess  the 
 most  the  most  difficult  part  of  the 
 whole  thing  is  the  little  timer  that 
 goes  on.  But  it's  just  a  battery 
 operated  timer  that  you  set  to  come  on 
 every  single  day,  so  you  don't  have  to 
 press  that  start  button  yourself.  But 
 other  than  that,  it  is  just  so  super 
 easy.  Okay,  so  we  talked  about  the 
 plants,  we  talked  about  the  irrigation. 
 Now,  let's  get  to  the  good  stuff.  Let's 
 break  this  down  so  you  guys  can  see  an 
 overhead  view.  Bryce  is  going  to  do  his 
 magic  for  you  guys  and  kind  of  share 
 with  you  what  we're  looking  at  treewise 
 in  this  bed.  All right,  you  guys.  So,  we 
 have  got  Kucia,  largely  Kucias.  We've 
 got  a  nice  row  of  those  planted  three 
 foot  on  center.  We've  got  four  of  those 
 that  are  going  to  cover  that  entire 
 space,  give  them  the  perfect  green  wall. 
 That's  where  we  started  in  this  bed. 
 Then  on  each  corner,  we  have  foxtail 
 palms.  So,  we  have  a  foxtail  palm  triple 
 here,  and  we  have  a  double  foxtail  palm 
 on  that  side  over  there.  Now,  for  our 
 backing  material,  the  things  that's 
 going  to  create  that  wall  for  us,  that 
 long-term  version  of  the  wall,  we  have 
 two  fishtail  palms.  We  kind  of  have  them 
 in  two  key  areas,  um,  they're  not 
 symmetrical,  but  the  goal  for  those  were 
 to  kind  of  camouflage  some  some  houses

 get  tall  tall  tall tall  as  they  really

 back  section.  Then  we  have  two  pygmy 
 eight  palms  to  the  back  here  that  once 
 this  tree  gets  big,  they're  going  to 
 come  come  together  and  create  a  wall  for 
 themselves.  This  is  a  triangle  fan  palm 
 which  is  our  centerpiece  tree.  That's 
 the  tree  that  you  kind  of  want  it.  You 
 want  it  to  be  different  than  any  other 
 tree  if  at  all  possible  because  it's 
 supposed  to  draw  your  eye  to  the  middle 
 even  if  it's  not  going  to  be  in  the 
 middle.  Because  in  this  particular  spot, 
 it  wasn't  in  the  middle.  This  is  offset 
 because  of  the  the  viewpoint  I  was  going 
 for  was  the  clients,  not  centered  on  the 
 house.  So,  whatever  your  your 
 centerpiece  is,  it  should  be  different. 
 Even  if  it's  not  your  centerpiece,  it's 
 it's  your  focal  point.  I  hope  that  makes 
 sense.  Um,  so  this  is  your  centerpiece 
 tree.  And  then  flanking  the  centerpiece 
 tree  just  so  we  frame  it  itself  are  two 
 single  alexanders.  There  are  the  frame 
 for  this  tree  there  to  give  us  a 
 different  row  of  layers  for  your  palms. 
 Your  foxtails  are  going  to  be  taller 
 than  your  than  your  alexanders.  Your 
 centerpiece  tree  will  eventually  get 
 tall  in  the  middle  but  not  as  tall  as 
 your  as  your  um  king  Alexanders.  And 
 your  pygmies  will  never  get  that  tall. 
 They'll  never  compete  with  that.  So 
 they'll  be  your  wall.  Now  for  the  fun 
 stuff,  the  smaller  plant  material.  To 
 the  back,  we  have  the  Jacob's  coat 
 copper  leaf  as  a  group.  That's  going  to 
 get  nice  and  six  foot  tall  in  that 
 backdrop.  We  have  blaze  copper  leaf  on 
 this  side  and  the  opposite  side.  So, 
 we've  got  five  here  and  I  think  we've 
 got  four  or  five  over  there  on  that 
 corner  there.  So,  we've  got  blaze  copper 
 leaf  on  each  end.  Then  through  the 
 middle  kind  of  in  a  nice  curved  fashion, 
 um  we  have  the  dwarf  alicacas.  They're 
 going to  be  a  nice  clustering  together 
 around  the  centerpiece  tree  to  kind  of 
 soften  that  look.  Each  corner  got  a 
 little  dash  of  golden  dew.  So,  we've  got 
 three  golden  dues  here  and  we've  got 
 four  golden  dues  in  this  area  because  it 
 has  a  little  bit  more  room.  So,  just  a 
 little  bit  of  brightness  because  the 
 centerpiece  plant  grouping  is  a  dark 
 grouping.  It  is  the  ruby  reds.  So,

 to  really  balance  out  that  yellow  on  the 
 corners.  And  then  to  the  backside  is 
 just  a  little  dollop  of  the  blue  my 
 minds  just  to  give  us  a  little  touch  of

 where  my  client  sits.  So  you  guys  can 
 really  see  those  low  plantings  right

 It's  really  nice  and  nice  and  tidy.  It's 
 not  20  or  40  or  50  plants.  It  is  like  a 
 a  swath  or  a  drift  of  these  and  a  drift 
 of  those  and  a  drift  of  these.  So,  it 
 doesn't  have  to  be  a  huge  amount  of 
 plants  that  you're  taking  from  the 
 nursery.  It  just  has  to  be  the  right 
 plant.  And  oh,  I  almost  forgot.  I've  got

 size,  and  then  those  are  going  to  fill 
 in  underneath  of  the  pigment  eight  palms 
 and  kind  of  camouflage  the  neighbor's 
 fence  and  whatnot.  Oh,  so  I'm  popping  in 
 here  real  quick.  I  guess  I  forgot.  We  do

---

 Well,  hello  gardeners.  Welcome  back.  So, 
 today's  video  is  all  about  mistakes. 
 These  are  five  mistakes  that  I  will 
 never  make  again  in  my  garden.  So,  I 
 want  to  share  them  with  you  guys  so  it 
 cuts  to  the  chase.  You  guys  will  not 
 make  these  mistakes  or  if  you're  making 
 them,  maybe  it'll  help  you  kind  of  go  a 
 different  direction  and  save  you  a  bit 
 of  time  and  money.  Let's  jump  right  in. 
 All right,  guys.  So,  the  first  mistake  I 
 want  to  talk  about  today  is  luck  in 
 transplanting.  Whether  it's 
 transplanting  from  a  plant  or  tree  that 
 you  bought  from  the  nursery,  from  a 
 nursery  pot  to  in  the  ground,  or 
 something  like  what  I  have  here,  where 
 it's  a  plant  that's  going  to  go  from  a 
 pot  into  into  the  ground  because  it's 
 maybe  gotten  too  big  for  the  area.  The 
 very  first  thing  that  you  want  to  do  is 
 make  sure  that  you  loosen  that  pot.  So, 
 you  don't  want  to  kind  of  tug  or  or  pull 
 on  the  plant  or,  you  know,  put  any  kind 
 of  pressure  on  the  stem  at  all.  What  you 
 want  to  do  is  I  usually  take  my  Horyhori 
 knife  and  that's  my  garden  knife  for 
 those  of  you  who  are  curious  and  I'll 
 kind  of  just  slice  all  the  way  around 
 the  sides.  Now,  my  guys  will  use  the 
 machete  and  I'm  using  a  machete  on  the 
 edge  of  a  um  of  a  pot  and  kind  of 
 pulling  that  plant  out  of  to  free  it  up. 
 So,  you  want  to  put  as  minimal  amount  of 
 stress  on  that  trunk  instead  of  pulling 
 and  tugging.  You  kind  of  want  to  try  to 
 completely  if  you  can  prevent  that 
 pressure  on  that  trunk.  When  I  started 
 in  the  landscape  business  a  hundred 
 years  ago,  um  it  was  common  to  do 
 transplants  like  this.  You  know,  we  dug 
 the  hole  tad  bit  bigger  than  what  the 
 hole  or  the  root  ball  was.  We  planted  it 
 a  little  bit  of  top  soil  kind  of  mixed 
 in,  covered  it  back  up,  it  was  nice  and 
 level  with  the  ground,  and  added  mulch, 
 and  voila,  we  were  done.  And  that's  just 
 not  the  way  to  do  it.  You  know,  the  way 
 to  do  it  for  real  success  is  when  you're 
 when  you're  getting  ready  to  install 
 your  plant  or  your  tree,  then  you  want 
 to  make  sure  that  you  dig  that  hole,  but 
 dig  it  shallow  the  like  but  maybe  just 
 about  the  height  of  the  pot,  barely  the 
 height  of  the  pot,  but  three  times 
 wider.  So,  more  shallow,  but  wider.  So, 
 you  want  to  make  sure  that  you're  really 
 giving  those  roots  places  to  spread  this 
 way  because  that's  where  the  roots  are 
 going  to  go  first  before  they  go  deep. 
 So,  dig  that  that  hole  nice  and  wide, 
 three  times  wider  than  the  pot.  And  then 
 you  want  to  take  that  root  ball  and  uh 
 you  want  to  kind  of  we  call  it 
 butterflying.  So  you  kind  of  want  to 
 take  that  root  ball  and  you  want  to  pull 
 those  roots  apart.  That  way  they're  not 
 constantly  going  around  in  circles  where 
 with  that  pot  size  frame  because  that's 
 exactly  what  they'll  do.  Especially  if 
 you  guys  end  up  purchasing  something 
 that's  more  rootbound.  Now  if  you're 
 like  me  and  you  see  a  bigger  tree  at  the 
 nursery  than  the  rest  of  the  trees  and 
 that  grouping,  you  know  that  plant  or 
 tree  has  more  than  likely  been 
 rootbound.  and  it's  been  in  that  pot  a 
 long  time.  It's  ate  up  all  the 
 nutrients.  It's  big  and  it's  broad  and 
 it's  beautiful.  But  then  you  try  to  take 
 out  of  that  pot  and  it's  like,  you  know, 
 and  then  you  open  it  up  and  the  roots 
 are  like  a  defined  circle  like  this. 
 That  will  not  change  even  when  you  put 
 it  into  that  beautiful  big  ground  filled 
 with  good  soil.  You  have  to  force  it 
 open.  And  that  is  something  that  I 
 didn't  know  years  and  years  ago.  So  I'm 
 hoping  that  helps  some  of  you  guys,  you 
 know,  make  that  change  when  you're  doing 
 your  planting.  So,  if  it's  a  bigger 
 tree,  if  it's  like  a  25  gallon  or  even  a 
 15  gallon  tree  and  it's  really  compact 
 and  you  can't  break  it  apart  with  your 
 hand,  you  want  to  take  your  knife  or 
 machete.  I'll  take  my  Hy  blade  and  I'll 
 just  kind  of  pry  at  it  to  get  it  loose 
 to  get  it  open.  You  kind  of  want  to  open 
 that  up  because  you're  going  to  force 
 those  roots  out  and  go  sideways.  And  you 
 almost  want  to  plant  it  where  where  it's 
 more  of  a  a  flat  bottom  like  like  a 
 soggy  diaper.  You  kind  of  want  it  to  be 
 flat  at  the  bottom.  And  then  put  that 
 guy  right  in  the  ground  there.  And  then 
 you're  going  to  want  him  to  stick  up 
 that  root  ball,  that  top  of  that  root 
 ball  to  stick  up  three  to  four  inches 
 because  it  is  common  for  a  lot  of  people 
 just  to  make,  you  know,  maybe  an  inch  up 
 or,  you  know,  just  enough  for  mulch  to 
 go  over  top  of  it.  But  you  kind  of  want 
 to  raise  there  because  what  you're  going 
 to  back  fill  with  will  kind  of  compress 
 over  time.  And  if  you  guys  have  watched 
 my  channel,  you  know  that  I  like  to  back 
 fill  with  50%  black  cow,  25%  pine  bark 
 nuggets,  and  25%  Pete  moss.  You  know, 
 that  is  my  golden  mix.  That  is  a  mix 
 that  everything  seems  to  do  super  well 
 with.  So  once  you  dig  that  hole,  once 
 you  have  a  fresh  and  open  hole,  you  want 
 to  set  that  tree  or  set  that  plant  right 
 into  that  space  and  then  back  fill  all 
 the  way  around  it.  Now,  there  is  one 
 caveat  to  that.  There's  been  times  where 
 we've  been  on  a  project  and  my  guys  have 
 dug  a  hole  and  there's  water  in  that 
 bottom  of  that  hole.  And  if  there's 
 water,  sitting  water  in  there,  and  that 
 water  looks  like  maybe  it's  been  there  a 
 little  while  and  maybe  even  has  an  odor 
 or  a  smell  to  it,  then  you  know  that 
 area  doesn't  drain  well.  So,  you  got  to 
 do  something  about  that  before  you  put  a 
 brand  new  plant  or  a  brand  new  tree  in 
 that  space.  And  I  mention  this  because 
 this  happens  maybe  three  out  of  five 
 times  when  we  dig  a  hole  because  a  lot 
 of  these  new  developments,  they're 
 beautiful  developments,  but  a  lot  of 
 them  have  used  soil  to  back  fill  their 
 yards  with  that  come  from  lake  banks, 
 you  know,  come  from  the  the  the  big 
 lakes  that  they  dug  out  and  they  use 
 that  soil  there.  So,  what  does  that  soil 
 do?  It  doesn't  drain,  you  know,  so  it's 
 not  good  for  plants.  So,  you've  got  to 
 modify  that  a  little  bit.  And  the 
 cheapest  and  easiest  and  quickest  way  to 
 do  that  is  to  use  gypsum.  I  use  that.  I 
 have  it  in  the  back  of  my  truck.  My  guys 
 have  it  in  the  back  of  their  truck.  It's 
 like  an  emergency,  you  know,  grab 
 solution  if  you  see  water  sitting  in  a 
 hole.  So,  the  best  thing  to  do  is  grab 
 several  handfuls  of  it.  You're  not  going 
 to  hurt  your  new  plant  or  you're  not 
 your  new  tree.  You're  not  going  to  burn 
 roots.  You're  not  going  to  do  anything 
 to  it.  But  there's  a  chemical  reaction 
 with  gypsum  and  clay  or  compact  soil. 
 Once  it  hits  that,  it  breaks  it  up.  So 
 you  almost  go  into  almost  immediate 
 draining  after  that.  So  we  constantly 
 have  that  on  hand  and  we  use  that  as  we 
 go.  And  then  I'll  let  my  clients  know, 
 hey,  we  ran  across  this  problem.  You're 
 going  to  want  to  buy  a  bag  of  this, 
 stick  it  in  your  garage,  and  every  so 
 often  throw  that  out  there.  And  that  way 
 it  kind  of  helps  it  helps  um  break  up 
 the  soil  along  the  top  because  you  need 
 air.  You  need  movement  in  that  soil  for 
 good,  healthy  plants.  So  if  you  see  that 
 happen,  throw  that  in  there.  There  is 
 one  other  thing  that  I  want  to  mention. 
 When  you're  in  that  process,  the  hole  is 
 still  open.  and  you've  added  a  little 
 bit  of  soil  to  it.  If  it's  a  palm  tree 
 or  a  tropical,  use  palm  tone.  This  is  my 
 perfect  time.  I  I  wish  I  had  a  bag.  I 
 just  actually  just  used  a  bag,  finished 
 a  bag  off,  so  I  don't  have  one  with  me, 
 but  use  palm  tone.  It  is  a  perfect  time 
 to  use  it.  Sprinkle  that  at  the  bottom 
 of  the  hole.  Put  the  plant  or  the  tree 
 into  that  spot.  It  is  organic,  so  it's 
 not  going  to  burn  your  uh  roots,  but 
 it's  going  to  give  it  kind  of  a  big  jump 
 start.  It's  going  to  give  it  that  impact 
 that  you  want  for  your  new  plant  or  your 
 tree  to  really  just  thrive  and  and  throw 
 out  good  roots.  So,  so  go  ahead  and  use 
 it  that  time  and  then  back  fill  with 
 that  three-part  moss  mix  that  I  like  to 
 use,  the  pine  bark,  the  black  cow,  and 
 the  Pete  moss.  And  then  back  fill. 
 You're  going  to  have  a  little  bit  of 
 height  that's  going  to  be  there.  Do  not 
 worry  about  that  height.  It  will  settle 
 over  time.  What  you  want  to  happen  is 
 you're  allowing  for  that  area  to  settle 
 because  if  you  plant  it  level,  it  will 
 settle  and  create  a,  you  know,  a  little 
 divot  there.  And  what  that  will  happen 
 every  time  it  rains,  that  area  will  hold 
 water  and  your  tree  or  your  plant  will 
 start  to  get  root  rot  over  time.  And 
 it's  a  slow  and  ugly  death.  And  you're 
 constantly  wondering  what's  wrong  with 
 your  plant  or  your  tree.  So  avoid  that 
 by  putting  a  little  high  from  the  very 
 beginning  and  then  you're  then  you're 
 goldens.  So  I  hope  that  helps.  We've  had 
 great  success  with  transplanting  that 
 way.  We  did  a  video  of  that  a  couple 
 weeks  ago.  I'll  get  Bryce  to  post  it 
 here  and  put  it  in  the  description  down 
 below  if  you  guys  would  like  to  see  it. 
 And  we  used  so  much  I  would  say  over  a 
 hundred  plants  of  material  that  was 
 already  on  site  and  we  did  not  lose  one 
 plant.  And  so  I  am  it's  that's  a  success 
 story  to  me  when  we  can  transplant  that 
 many  plants  in  a  garden,  take  it  because 
 they  were  decent  plants  and  then  rework 
 it  into  the  landscape  kind  of  like 
 musical  chairs  when  it  comes  to  planting 
 and  then  create  a  new  design  with  it.  So 
 you  guys,  just  give  it  a  little  extra 
 care,  a  little  bit  of  extra  time,  and 
 then  you're  going  to  have  a  successful 
 garden  that  way.  I  hope  that  helps.  All 
 right,  you  guys.  So  the  next  mistake  is 
 a  mistake  I  made  years  and  years  and 
 years  ago,  but  I  do  see  it  happening 
 when  I  go  to  clients  houses,  so  I 
 thought  I  would  share  it  with  you  guys. 
 So  planting  in  one  or  twos,  that  means 
 like  if  you  went  to  the  garden  center 
 and  you  see  this  perfect  little  plant  or 
 a  perfect  little  accent  and  you're  like, 
 "Okay,  I'm  just  going  to  put  one  in  the 
 garden  or  I'm  going  to  put  two  in  the 
 garden  and  then  go  find  something  else 
 and  put  one  or  two  and  then  one  or  two 
 and  one  or  two."  And  then  you  have  this, 
 you  know,  this  concoction  of  a  bunch  of 
 different  plants  kind  of  just,  you  know, 
 trying  to  fight  each  other  off  in  the 
 gardens.  I  know  that  that's  tempting, 
 especially  when  you're  only  shopping 
 every  so  often  and  you're  adding  as  you 
 go.  But  if  you  can  pick  put  together  a 
 plan  of  plant  groupings  that  you  like 
 and  work  with  them  in  your  garden, 
 you're  going  to  love  that  so  much  more. 
 So,  I  plant  in  drifts.  Even  as  a 
 tropical  landscaper,  I  plant  in  drifts. 
 So,  it  might  not  feel  like  that  when  you 
 look  at  my  garden.  It  feels  like  there's 
 a  lot  going  on.  There's  a  lot  of 
 different  layers,  but  I  promise  you 
 there's  a  rhythm  um  to  the  madness  here. 
 So,  for  example,  you  know,  I  have  I  have 
 my  magnificent  croins  right  through 
 here.  And  you  can  see  that  I  have  a  nice 
 drift  or  a  collection  or  a  swath, 
 whatever  you  want  to  call  it,  of 
 magnificent  croins  in  this  one 
 particular  spot.  Now,  I  have  this 
 grouping  here  because  it's  not  going  to 
 ever  compete  with  my  Laquala  palm  that's 
 behind  it.  They're  going  to  stay  very, 
 very  low.  And  when  they  start  to  grow, 
 they're  slow  such  slow  growers  that  I 
 can  easily  maintain  them  by  trimming 
 them  ever  so  often.  So  I  you  I'll  plant 
 that  grouping  just  like  that.  And  then 
 I'll  do  little  touches  like  you  have  a 
 little  grouping  of  five  of  these  burl 
 marks.  And  you  guys  bear  with  us  because 
 we  just  did  our  spring  trimming.  So 
 things  are  not  as  gorgeous  as  they 
 normally  are.  But  normally  they're 
 feeding  right  over.  They're  thick  and 
 they're  dense.  But  I  did  thin  them  out 
 to  allow  some  air  to  get  in  there.  But 
 you  can  kind  of  see  what  I  mean.  Now 
 when  you  plant  in  drifts,  if  you  could 
 do  your  best  to  find  different  levels  of 
 how  those  plants  grow.  Like  these  are 
 never  going  to  compete  with  the  size  of 
 these.  These  are  going  to  stay  at  that  2 
 and  a  half,  three  foot  range  and  then 
 you're  golden.  That's  just  going  to 
 thicken  right  up  and  become  that 
 gorgeous  little  swath  of  dark  shiny 
 green.  And  then  you  got  this  great  bit 
 of  color  that's  going  to  be  around  4  and 
 1/2t  tall  to  give  you  that  bright 
 coloration.  And  then  it's  going  to  stop. 
 And  I  do  the  same  thing  with  all  of  my 
 plants  and  trees.  And  Bryce,  if  you 
 shoot  over  here,  you'll  see  that  I  have 
 a  collection  of  icon  croins  doing  the 
 same  thing  up  here  and  then  some  dwarf 
 exoras  coming  along  through  here.  Not 
 only  does  the  variety  of  plants  change, 
 but  the  height  and  the  levels  change. 
 So,  plant  in  swast,  it  gives  you  that 
 more  of  a  of  a  professional  look.  And 
 also,  it's  just  easy  on  the  eyes.  See, 
 when  you  plant  in  groups  like  this, 
 you're  going  to  notice  that,  you  know, 
 you're  going  to  have  one  solid 
 collection.  And  I  try  to  zigzag  the 
 pattern.  So,  when  I  do  it  in  a  grouping 
 of  four,  you'll  notice  I'll  have  kind  of 
 like  a  zigzag  pattern  going  on  because  I 
 want  them  to  connect  together.  I  want 
 them  to  become  a  bish  big  almost  like  a 
 one  bush  type  of  planting,  like  a  real 
 big  cluster.  And  then  when  I  go  around  a 
 focal  point  like  you  see  here,  I  tend  to 
 more  wrap  it  around  the  focal  point. 
 Kind  of  give  it  a  little  bit  of 
 curvature.  But  we're  sticking  with  a 
 collection  of  plants,  but  we're  not 
 we're  not  meshing  them  all  together.  So 
 if  you  can  instead  of  doing  one  of  these 
 and  another  one  of  these  and  then  one  of 
 these  and  another  one  of  these,  which 
 kind  of  can  confuse  the  eye  or  or  just 
 kind  of  be  a  little  bit  too  chaotic, 
 just  do  one  drift  then  stop  like  a  break 
 and  then  do  another  drift.  And  if  you 
 can  pay  attention  to  the  height  growth 
 on  those  things  and  make  sure  one  drift 
 is  higher  than  the  other  drift.  So 
 naturally  the  garden  does  this  through 
 the  whole  space.  So  not  only  does  it 
 change  with  color,  lights  and  darknesses 
 or  texture  is  big  leaf,  little  leaf,  but 
 it  also  does  that  with  heights.  And  then 
 before  you  know  it,  you'll  look  out 
 there  and  say,  "Okay,  I  know  this  is  a 
 jungle  and  I  know  it's  chaotic,  but  it 
 has  rhyme.  It  has  reason.  It  has,  you 
 know,  it  it's  it's  soothing."  And  that's 
 kind  of  what  when  you  go  to  resorts  and 
 what  whatnot,  the  architects  have 
 figured  that  out  and  that's  kind  of  what 
 they  created.  It  looks  like  a  little  bit 
 of  chaos,  but  in  all  rights,  it's  really 
 just  a  garden  really  well  thought  out. 
 So,  I  learned  that  early  early  on  in  my 
 career  because  I  thought  tropical  meant 
 just  throw  things  in  and  be  really  crazy 
 and  have  a  leaf  on  leaf  kind  of  vibe  and 
 that's  not  the  case.  So,  so  I  I  hope 
 that  tip  helped.  That  embarrassing  tip 
 that  I  could  share  with  you  helped.  All 
 right,  you  guys.  for  the  next  mistake  is 
 one  I  shamefully  made  in  my  own  garden 
 years  ago  when  I  planted  my  Laquala. 
 Right  plant,  right  place  or  suffer  the 
 consequences.  Now,  I  absolutely  love 
 this  plant.  I  do  not  want  to  take  it  out 
 because  I  I'm  almost  like  hoping  she 
 will  withstand  the  conditions.  So,  when 
 I  say  right  plant  for  the  right  place, 
 it  it  covers  a  little  bit  more  than 
 that.  So,  Bryce,  show  show  everyone  this 
 area  really  quickly  so  you  guys  get  a 
 good  vibe,  get  a  good  understanding  of 
 what  we're  dealing  with  in  this 
 particular  location.  So,  you  would  not 
 think  this  area  gets  as  much  wind  as  it 
 gets,  but  it,  as  you  can  see,  it  does. 
 It's  a  a  great  backyard.  going  to  get 
 great  breezes.  And  I  thought  that  I  had 
 done  my  due  diligence  and  kind  of 
 creating  a  wall  around  this  particular 
 tree  to  kind  of  help  prepare  it  to  be  in 
 this  location  and  withstand  this  area, 
 but  we  just  have  a  little  bit  too  much 
 wind  for  it  to  be  super  super  happy.  You 
 can  see  the  tear  in  the  leaves.  And  that 
 goes  for  a  lot  of  us.  You  know,  we  find 
 a  plant  or  we  find  a  tree  that  we're 
 like,  you  know  what,  I  have  Pinterested 
 this  for  like  five  years.  I  want  this 
 tree  in  my  garden  or  I  want  this  plant 
 in  my  garden.  but  it's  a  a  a  shade  plant 
 that  loves  to  be  in  a  hammock  planting 
 and  then  you  want  to  put  it  in  full  sun 
 and  it's  just  it's  just  not  going  to  be 
 happy.  And  so  you're  going  to  fight  that 
 battle  over  and  over  again  and  by  kind 
 of  really  having  to  treat  it  really 
 really  well  to  do  well.  So  when  Bryce 
 and  I  go  to  our  consults,  we  deal  with 
 our  clients.  The  first  thing  that  we 
 talk  to  them  about  is  show  me  your 
 vision.  Talk  to  me  about  what  your 
 Pinterest  board  says  of  what  you  want  to 
 create  in  your  backyard.  And  that  way  we 
 can  determine  from  what  we  see  in  our 
 knowledge  of  how  much  sun,  how  much 
 exposure,  how  much  wind,  how  much  salt, 
 how  much  if  it's  a  soggy  area,  whatever 
 those  situations  are,  we're  kind  of 
 pairing  that  to  my  our  client  style.  And 
 you  know,  if  I  get  a  client  who  says,  "I 
 love  your  backyard.  I'm  really  into  that 
 jungle  vibe,  that  tropical  vibe,  but  I 
 don't  need  the  trees.  I  just  kind  of 
 want  the  plants.  I  want  the  color."  And 
 then  I  look  at  their  backyard  and  it's 
 full  sun.  And  then  I  have  to  break  it  to 
 them  and  say,  "You  you  guys,  we  got  to 
 find  some  ways  to  protect  it.  But  we  got 
 to  change  your  microclimate  in  your 
 backyard  in  order  for  that  plant  or  that 
 tree  or  that  grouping  that  you  want  to 
 create  to  really  flourish  and  do  well. 
 Other  than  that,  you're  just  going  to  be 
 disappointed  and  have  put  a  lot  of 
 expense  into  a  garden  that's  just  not 
 sustainable  for  the  area.  You  can't  you 
 got  to  work  with  mother  nature.  It  is 
 like  the  perfect  handshake  with  mother 
 nature  by  saying,  "Okay,  I  want  to  do 
 this  and  you  know  this  environment  will 
 call  for  that.  So,  we're  going  to  have  a 
 nice  marriage  here."  So  that's  what  if 
 you're  not  working  with  a  landscape 
 designer,  you  have  to  do  a  little  bit  of 
 research  on  reading  those  labels, 
 understanding  your  location.  And  so  I'll 
 tell  my  clients  or  consults  if  I'm  not 
 working  with  them.  I'll  tell  them,  you 
 know,  go  outside  on  a  a  Sunday  when 
 you're  home  all  day.  Go  out  every  couple 
 hours,  do  your  front  yard,  your 
 sideyard,  your  backyard,  whatever  area 
 that  you're  going  to  do  your 
 landscaping,  and  just  put  from  morning 
 to  evening  hours  how  much  sun  you're 
 getting.  Are  you  getting  full  sun?  Just 
 put  sun,  sun,  sun,  shade,  shade,  shade. 
 That  way  you  know  if  you're  getting  six 
 to  eight  hours  of  sun,  which  is  what  a 
 sunloving  plant  wants.  If  you're  getting 
 less  than  that,  then  voila,  you're  in 
 the  shade  garden  family  and  you  can 
 incorporate  those  into  your  garden 
 without  any  kind  of  fuss  or  any  kind  of 
 worry.  Now,  keep  in  mind  if  you're  in  a 
 windy  location  than  this,  you  might  have 
 to  put  in  some  tree  bras  to  make  that 
 happen.  I  recently  spoke  with  another 
 designer  who  had  to  redesign  a  project 
 because  a  previous  architect,  a 
 well-known  architect,  had  designed  15 
 Laqualas.  My  gosh,  you  guys.  I'm  not 
 calling  the  wind.  This  is  completely 
 circumstantial,  but  it  it's  pretty  bad 
 back  here.  But  had  put  in  so  many 
 Laqualas  in  this  riverfront  area  where 
 the  wind  just  gusted  through  and  you 
 would  not  know.  It  did  not  have  one  leaf 
 on  them.  I  mean,  they  were  just  I  mean, 
 these  are  expensive  little  trees  and  for 
 that  whole  area  to  completely  be 
 shattered  with  just  not  just  I  mean, 
 they  look  more  like  ribbon  palms  with 
 their  poor  little  little  itty  bitty 
 stringy  fronds  to  them.  So,  you  know, 
 just  pay  attention  to  your  environment 
 and  you  can  do  that  by  just  reading  a 
 little  bit  about  the  plant  or  the  tree. 
 Um,  but  that's  a  mistake  I've  even  made 
 in  the  past  years  ago  and  I  I  am  adamant 
 not  to  make  again.  So,  I  hope  sharing 
 that  with  you  guys,  you  guys  will  not 
 make  that  same  mistake.  So,  the  next 
 mistake  I  wanted  to  touch  on  is  you  do 
 not  need  to  fertilize  your  palms,  your 
 trees,  your  plants  in  Florida.  The 
 tropical  plants  and  trees  can  withstand 
 and  live  so  well  in  our  tropical 
 climate.  And  part  of  that  is  true.  They 
 live  fantastic  here.  But  the  other  part, 
 not  so  much.  You  guys,  we  you  need  to 
 fertilize  your  plants  and  trees  for  one 
 big  reason.  It  fights  off  the  pest.  It's 
 like  the  best  immunity  shot  that  you  can 
 give  your  plants  or  your  trees.  So  there 
 was  a  study  done  in  the  University  of 
 Michigan  where  they  had  a  healthy  and 
 unhealthy  milkweed  and  they  saw  which 
 one  attacked  more  and  obviously  as  we 
 know  the  unhealthy  one  attacked  quite  a 
 bit  more  but  it  was  astonishing  to  like 
 the  percentage  it  was  like  99%  attacked 
 the  unhealthy  where  1%  attacked  the 
 other  and  it  was  short-lived.  I  mean 
 like  they  really  could  not  digest  the 
 healthy  milkweed  so  they  moved  on.  And 
 not  that  we  want  to  move,  you  know,  we 
 don't  want  our  pests  to  move  on  to  our 
 neighbors  gardens,  but  we  don't  want 
 them  in  ours.  So  if  those  of  you  guys 
 who  hate  using  synthetic  fertilizers  in 
 your  garden,  then  you  know,  just  know 
 that  if  you  do  that  or  you  treat  your 
 gardens  and  you  really  fertilize  and 
 take  good  good  care  of  them,  then  you  do 
 not  have  to  worry  about  doing  that  those 
 drenches  so  frequently  or  so  often.  I 
 have  a  very  extensive  garden  as  you  guys 
 can  see.  I  mean,  it's  it's  pretty  full. 
 Everything  is  really  collected.  I  mean, 
 it  is  a  bug  magnet,  but  it's  not.  I  have 
 to  drench  or  treat  very  very  rarely.  And 
 I  know  that  it's  because  everything  is 
 happy  and  strong  and  had  its  immunity 
 shot.  And  so,  you  guys  definitely 
 definitely  take  it  to  heart.  You  know, 
 treat  your  plants  and  trees  with  those, 
 you  know,  four  times  a  year.  Hit  it  with 
 that  granular  fertilizer.  You  will  not 
 be  disappointed  with  how  well  they  hold 
 up  during  not  just  pest  and  bugs,  but 
 during  storms,  during  cold  weather.  I 
 mean,  it's  a  way  to  keep  your  garden 
 just  strong  and  lush.  So,  do  not  sleep 
 on  treating  your  garden  with  some  good 
 fertilizer  four  times  a  year.  It's  worth 
 it.  But  real  quick,  this  is  what  I  use. 
 And  I  know  if  you  guys  have  watched  this 
 channel,  you  know  that  I  pull  this  guy 
 out  all  the  time.  I  use  Palm  Gain  8212. 
 I  use  it  for  all  of  my  tropicals,  which 
 is  pretty  much  101%  of  my  garden.  So  you 
 can  use  this  granular  mix,  throw  it  into 
 the  ground,  kind  of  chicken  feed  it  into 
 the  open  areas  of  the  mulch  and  voila, 
 you  are  done  and  it  really  really  limits 
 any  kind  of  other  kind  of  u  pest  control 
 that  you  have  to  do  to  the  rest  of  your 
 garden.  So  for  the  next  mistake  is  one 
 that  you  know  a  lot  of  us  have  made  and 
 so  I  if  you're  starting  with  a  new 
 garden  then  you  guys  listen  up  because 
 the  next  one  is  really  paying  attention 
 to  the  growth  rates  that  you  see  on  the 
 tags  at  the  nursery.  Listen  to  your 
 nursery  people  when  they  tell  you  that 
 this  plant  is  going  to  get  this  size  or 
 this  plant's  going  to  need  this  much 
 room  for  growth  rate.  So,  when  I'm 
 designing  a  landscape,  that  is  I  would 
 say  that's  one  of  the  most  important 
 things  that  I  do  in  a  landscape  design 
 because  if  you  design  a  plant  or  tree 
 grouping  backwards,  you'll  know  it.  You 
 don't  have  to  be  professional  to  see 
 that  happen.  So,  the  thing  that  you  want 
 to  pay  attention  to  is  when  you're 
 looking  or  you're  deciding  on  a  plant 
 grouping,  just  because  it  says  dwarf  on 
 it  does  not  mean  it's  going  to  be  dwarf. 
 It  just  means  that  it  can  be  maintained 
 as  a  smaller  plant,  but  it  does  not  mean 
 that  it  will  stay  that  height  and  never 
 grow.  I  hear  that  all  the  time  from  my 
 clients  who  were  gold  mound  had  been 
 planted  10  years  ago  and  now  it's  5  foot 
 tall  and  they're  like,  "No,  they  said 
 this  plant  was  going  to  be  two  foot  tall 
 and  stop."  And  what  they  mean  is  that 
 plant  can  be  cut  and  maintained  at  2 
 foot  tall  very  easily.  So  dwarf  plants 
 show  two  types  of  characteristics. 
 either  they  grow  very  slow  so  you  can 
 easily  maintain  them  at  that  size  with 
 very  very  little  maintenance  or  they'll 
 grow  fast  like  a  dwarf  fire  bush  and  um 
 become  a  a  gorgeous  wall  of  color.  But 
 if  you  want  to  keep  them  at  3  foot  and 
 never  allow  them  to  get  any  bigger,  then 
 you  can  trim  and  they  will  still  flush 
 out  and  be  bushy  and  gorgeous  at  3t  tall 
 forever.  Unlike  something  like  a 
 hibiscus  or  a  gardinia,  if  you  try  to 
 trim  that  and  keep  that  three  foot  tall, 
 then  you'll  have  nothing  but  sticks.  It 
 won't  reproduce  nice  blooms  or  or  color 
 on  it.  It'll  just  kind  of  stay,  you 
 know,  pretty  unhealthy.  So,  when  it's 
 dwarf,  you  can  be  you  can  keep  things  at 
 a  slower  rate.  So,  that  is  the  goal  of 
 planting  dwarf  plants  with  your  taller 
 plant  groupings.  The  next  thing  is  kind 
 of  pay  attention  to  how  generally  things 
 grow.  So,  when  I'm  working  with  a 
 design,  for  instance,  in  my  backyard 
 here,  you  see  I  put  the  tallest  thing 
 first.  So,  the  tallest  thing  that  you 
 see  in  my  garden  back  here  is  that 
 traveler's  palm.  Now,  I  planted  that 
 traveler's  palm  the  same  time  I  planted 
 most  of  the  things  in  this  garden,  in 
 this  like  section  of  the  garden.  But 
 because  it  grows  five  times  faster,  I 
 knew  that  there  was  nothing  in  front  of 
 it  that  was  going  to  compete  with  it. 
 But  if  I  put  that  traveler's  palm  in 
 front  of  this  palm  here  or  in  front  of 
 these  guys  here,  then  it's  gonna 
 completely  block  the  the  beauty  of  those 
 those  plants.  Sorry,  this  wind  is 
 kicking  our  butt  today,  you  guys.  But  so 
 you  can  plant  those  guys,  but  I  wouldn't 
 put  these  Brazilian  red  cloaks  in  front 
 of  these  gold  dust  croins.  These  gold 
 dust  croins  do  a  nice  job  of  staying 
 compact  and  small.  I  trim  these  very, 
 very  little  because  I  don't  have  to 
 worry  about  them  competing  with  height 
 like  this  to  get  above  these  Brazilian 
 red  cloaks.  So,  when  you're  looking  at 
 the  plant  tags,  pay  attention  to  where 
 it  says  sun,  of  course,  shade,  of 
 course,  windy  conditions,  moist 
 conditions,  that  kind  of  stuff  or  it's 
 all  of  those  things  are  important,  but 
 height  is  just  as  important  because  you 
 want  to  layer  in  here.  We've  got  my 
 annuals  at  the  bottom  for  ground  cover. 
 We've  got  the  gold  dust  croins  that  have 
 been  here  for  years  as  our  secondary 
 tier.  And  then  we've  got  the  Brazilian 
 red  cloaks  that  are  filling  out  this 
 area.  Lovely.  And  then  we've  got  the  the 
 traveler's  palm  right  here  to  the  back 
 as  our  backdrop.  And  then  just  to  give 
 these  Brazilian  red  cloaks  when  they  do 
 pop  with  color,  we  have  those  kucas  at 
 our  as  our  wall  as  our  final  backdrop 
 there.  So  that  blocks  out  the  screen  the 
 pool  screen  behind  us  and  it  kind  of 
 gives  us  a  green  screen  to  all  of  the 
 fun  and  color  in  the  front.  So  it  does  a 
 good  job  of  really  helping  us  visualize 
 those  layers  as  we  tear  down.  Just  think 
 of  it  as  a  waterfall.  Just  start  from 
 the  top  and  you  just  kind  of  want  to  see 
 your  defined  layers  kind  of  all  the  way 
 down  to  the  ground  cover.  And  that's 
 what  gives  you  that  lush  garden  feel. 
 And  this  area  maintenance  is  so  minimal, 
 you  guys.  It's  just  it  it's  fabulous  how 
 easy  care  this  area  is.  So  understanding 
 your  layers  from  the  beginning,  it  can 
 be  so  important.  So  before  you  start, 
 you  know,  plopping  plants  or  trees  into 
 the  ground,  really  figure  out  what  your 
 foundation  trees  are  going  to  be  and 
 then  work  your  way  down.  Just  again, 
 think  of  a  waterfall  effect.  You  know, 
 start  from  the  top  and  work  your  way 
 down.  And  then  you're  going  to  really, 
 really  be  happy  with  how  that  flows 
 through  the  garden,  how  those  defined 
 lines  do  that.  And  then  you'll  be 
 wondering  what  to  do  with  your  weekends 
 because  you  won't  be  out  here  working  in 
 the  garden.  You'll  be  just  enjoying  it. 
 All  right,  you  guys.  So,  I  know  that  we 
 threw  a  lot  at  you  in  this  video.  I  hope 
 these  these  tips  on  not  making  some  of 
 the  mistakes  that  I've  made  help  you 
 through  your  gardening  process,  cuz
