 So,  happy  spring  gardeners.  Today's 
 video  is  all  about  what  to  do  in  your 
 garden  during  the  springtime.  So,  as  you 
 guys  know,  I'm  an  extensive  gardener.  I 
 do  gardens  not  just  for  myself,  but  for, 
 you  know,  so  many  others  as  a  landscape 
 designer.  There's  just  things  that  I 
 stick  to  this  time  of  the  year  that 
 become  habit  and  then  become  tradition. 
 So,  I  thought  today  I  would  share  both 
 of  those  with  you  guys  and  and  I  hope 
 you  enjoy  it.  I  hope  you  enjoy  these 
 tidbits.  But  for  those  of  you  guys  who 
 do  not  know  me,  my  name  is  Jennifer 
 Bevans  or  your  true  gardener  and  I  am  a 
 landscape  designer  for  now  over  25  years 
 and  I  specialize  in  creating  outdoor 
 spaces  kind  of  like  the  outdoor  spaces 
 that  you  see  here.  So  this  channel  is 
 all  about  sharing  those  projects  that  we 
 do  with  our  clients  so  that  way  you  guys 
 have  some  really  good  insight  on  what  we 
 create  as  far  as  gardens  throughout  the 
 treasure  and  space  coast.  We  do  have  a 
 service  that  we  do  installation  and 
 design  and  we  have  a  service  that  we  do 
 design  for  outside  our  installation 
 field  and  then  we  do  have  a  virtual 
 service  for  you  guys  who  are  looking  for 
 consultations,  virtual  consultations  for 
 just,  you  know,  some  tidbit  points  and 
 whatnot.  So,  send  us  an  email  with  your 
 phone  number.  Marissa  is  my 
 daughter-in-law.  We  are  a  family-owned 
 business  and  she  will  gather  all  that 
 information  and  see  if  we're  just  going 
 to  be  a  good  fit  for  you  guys.  But 
 that's  enough  of  that.  So  like  and 
 subscribe  if  this  is  the  kind  of  vibe 
 that  you  like  to  watch  every  single 
 weekend.  We  talk  about  plants,  trees, 
 gardens,  how  to  do  this,  how  to  do  that, 
 anything  outdoors  in  Florida 
 landscaping.  This  might  be  the  channel 
 for  you.  All right,  you  guys.  So  for  tip 
 number  one,  it  is  trimming.  So  we  are  in 
 the  perfect  climate  for  getting  a  good 
 trim  on  things.  So  normally  when  I  do  my 
 trimming  cycle,  it  is  the  last  week  of 
 March,  maybe  the  first  week  of  April.  We 
 trimmed  a  little  bit  early  this  year 
 because  of  Bryce  and  Rissa's  wedding. 
 But  normally  I  like  to  hold  off  to  make 
 sure  that  all  of  the  winter  chill  is 
 gone  and  we're  like  really  really  coming 
 into  spring.  But  I  wanted  to  show  you 
 this  area  in  particular  because  it  it's 
 really  I  know  it's  looking  bold.  I  know 
 those  of  you  guys  who  are  true  gardeners 
 and  watch  this  channel  religiously  know 
 what  these  Sancheesio  look  like.  They're 
 usually  engulfed  in  this  space  even 
 falling  over  into  the  rock  way  and 
 that's  how  I  keep  them  most  of  the  year. 
 But  spring,  spring  is  when  they  know 
 they're  getting  the  ugly  bang  haircut. 
 They're  getting  cut  back.  They're 
 getting  separated.  They're  really, 
 really  getting  that  area  that  they  need 
 to  really  flush  out  and  kind  of  create 
 that  whole  new  year's  worth  of  growth. 
 What  I  normally  do  is  I  take  a  couple 
 foot  off  the  top  of  my  sanchesia  and 
 then  I  separate  the  plant  groupings 
 themselves  because  they  naturally  want 
 to  group  together.  And  that  happens  with 
 90%  of  our  tropicals,  our  our  Sanchezia, 
 our  copper  leaves,  our  croins,  whatnot, 
 they  all  kind  of  want  to  interconnect 
 and  that's  what  makes  them  super  strong. 
 But  in  order  to  kind  of  keep  them 
 pestfree  and  kind  of  come  in  with  that 
 beautiful  new  growth  that  they  happen 
 that  happens  every  year,  this  is  an 
 ideal  time  to  do  it.  It's  not  It's  early 
 enough  where  they're  not  getting  the 
 heat  of  the  season,  but  it's  that  time 
 frame  where  they're  getting  ready  to  get 
 a  lot  of  good  rain  and  a  lot  of  good 
 heat.  So,  they're  going  to  grow  in  in  no 
 time.  So,  I'm  going  to  lose  very,  very 
 little  time  of  them  being  their 
 beautiful  cells.  The  next  thing  that  I 
 do  in  this  area  now  that  we  have  a  good 
 cutback,  I  make  sure  to  kind  of  peel 
 back  some  of  the  top  coating  of  the 
 mulch.  You  know,  just  the  top  layer.  So, 
 I'll  rake  that  out  and  kind  of  get  that 
 cleaned  off  so  that  way  I'm  not  piling 
 mulch  on  top  of  mulch.  I  know  mulch 
 decomposes,  but  sometimes  you'll  still 
 have  that  residue  from  last  year's  mulch 
 and  you'll  kind  of  get  that  off  the 
 plant  grouping  and  then  just  kind  of 
 leave  yourself  a  really  really  good 
 clean  slate.  And  this  is  the  perfect 
 time  to  do  that  because  there's  all 
 these  openings.  There's  all  this  exposed 
 space  that  you  do  not  have  the  remainder 
 of  the  year.  This  is  the  only  time  of 
 the  year  that  you  really  get  that  open 
 sense  to  things  that  it  is  truly  helpful 
 for  the  plants  because  it  really 
 protects  them  against  pest  and  allows 
 air  to  get  to  the  inside  and  sun  to  get 
 to  the  inside  of  this  plant  like  it 
 wouldn't  if  you  had  it  full.  So,  my  next 
 tip  would  be  fertilizing.  You  guys  know 
 I  love  8212  palm  gain.  I  use  it  through 
 my  whole  garden.  I  fill  it  into  this  mop 
 bucket  that  I  have  here  and  just  kind  of 
 chicken  feed  it  through  my  yard.  So,  now 
 that  I  have  all  these  open  spaces  that 
 I've  made  when  I've  done  my  trimming, 
 all  I  do  is  take  in  those  open  spaces 
 and  just  flood  it  with  some  fertilizer 
 through  my  yard.  Now,  I  notice  after 
 fertilizing  that  the  springtime  plants 
 are  really  wanting  to  flush  out.  Their 
 blooms  are  coming  out,  that  growth  is 
 coming  out.  I'm  seeing  tons  of  new  green 
 foliage  everywhere.  And  so,  I  know  that 
 this  is  the  perfect  time  of  year  to  give 
 them  a  bit  of  assist.  you  know,  give 
 them  that  kind  of  vitamin  C  boost  that 
 we  all  kind  of  need.  They  really  love 
 that  in  the  springtime  because  as  soon 
 as  I  fertilize,  it's  almost  like  I  want 
 to  walk  out,  you  know,  every  morning 
 afterwards  and  just  see  who's  doing 
 what,  who's  showing  off,  who's  blooming, 
 who's  got  new  growth.  And  that's  exactly 
 what  happens  after  trimming  is  done, 
 after  fertilizing  done,  after  irrigating 
 more  often,  all  of  that.  Once  that  all 
 starts  to  happen,  it's  like  the  like  the 
 garden  starts  to  wake  up  and  just  kind 
 of  explode  with  new  growth  and  new 
 blooms.  So  to  me,  it's  such  a  rewarding 
 thing  to  do  when  I'm  fertilizing  that 
 spring  weekend  knowing  that  I'm  just 
 going  to  get  tons  and  tons  of  benefit 
 from  it.  So  our  next  spring  tip  is 
 mulching.  Now  that  everything  has  been 
 cleared  out,  there's  open  spaces  in 
 place  and  there's  fertilizer  that's 
 down.  This  is  a  perfect  time  to  do  a  top 
 coating  of  mulch  for  your  entire  garden. 
 Now,  one  of  the  main  reasons  that  I  love 
 mulching  during  this  time  of  the  year  is 
 because  we're  getting  ready  to  get  into 
 the  heat  of  the  season.  So,  you  guys 
 know  Florida,  it  gets  hot.  It  gets 
 crazy.  So,  protecting  your  plants  for 
 that  upcoming  heat  is  so  important.  So, 
 if  you  can  add  a  nice  layer  of  mulch, 
 some  of  it  will  break  down,  help  the 
 soil  conditioning  over  time,  but  the 
 majority  of  it  will  do  its  job,  which  is 
 hold  moisture.  So  instead  of  having  to 
 weigh  up  your  water  for  that  intense 
 heat,  you  can  add  a  nice  layer  of  mulch 
 and  it'll  help  keep  that  moisture  around 
 your  new  plantings,  keeping  them  thick, 
 lush,  and  hydrated.  So  mulching,  this  is 
 a  perfect  time  of  the  year  to  kind  of 
 get  in  there  in  between  those  plants  and 
 top  everything  off.  So,  for  the  next 
 tip,  now  that  you've  gotten  those  areas 
 cleaned  out,  you've  gotten  mulch,  you've 
 gotten  fertilizer,  you've  done  your  due 
 diligence  of  getting  things  kind  of 
 prepped  and  ready  in  the  garden,  now 
 it's  time  to  take  a  look  around,  kind  of 
 see  what  maybe  didn't  handle  the  winter 
 months  really  well  or  kind  of  what  what 
 bare  spots  you  have  in  the  garden.  Those 
 are  my  favorite  times  because  I  look 
 around  and  I'm  like,  you  know what,  I 
 could  use  a  little bit  more  of  this  or  a 
 little  bit  more  of  that  in  the  garden. 
 But  we're  early  enough  in  the  season  to 
 introduce  some  new  plants  before  it  gets 
 too  darn  hot  to  stress  them  out  like 
 crazy.  So,  this  is  the  time  of  the  year 
 that  I  do  these  lovely  ladies.  I  love  to 
 incorporate  my  epipites,  my  my  plants 
 that  love  to  grow  on  trees,  whether  it's 
 burmilads,  it's  orchids  like  you  see 
 here,  it's  bird's  nest  ferns,  it's 
 whatever  that  might  kind  of  add  some 
 interest  or  some  different  elements  into 
 the  garden.  My  potted  plants,  all  of 
 those  kind  of  things.  That's  what  I 
 incorporate  this  time  of  the  year.  And  I 
 love  these  orchids.  I  brought  in  nine 
 new  nine  I  know  I  I  go  a  little  crazy.  I 
 have  a  habit  issue  with  my  plants.  But  I 
 brought  in  nine  new  orchids  to  my 
 existing  orchids.  I  see  my  old  orchids 
 that  have  already  attached  to  the  tree. 
 Really  flushing  out  with  new  growth, 
 telling  me  like,  "Hello,  spring.  We  are 
 here."  And  so  bringing  in  a  few  extra  is 
 my  favorite  thing  to  do  this  time  of  the 
 year.  So  find  little  area,  little 
 sections  in  your  garden  that  you  know, 
 maybe  you  got  them  some  thin  spots, 
 maybe  you  got  some  quarter  lines  that 
 maybe  didn't  all  take  from  the 
 propagation,  maybe  just  kind  of  little 
 fill  in  little  areas.  Now  that  you  kind 
 of  have  everything  cleaned  up  and  it's 
 easily  accessible,  this  is  a  great  time 
 to  incorporate  a  cluster  planting. 
 you're  going  to  have  from  now  in  April 
 um  all  the  way  into  the  season  for  those 
 to  establish  and  get  healthy  and  get 
 strong  before  we  get  to  the  heat  of  the 
 season  in  July,  September,  that  time 
 frame  where  it  can  be  tough.  And  then 
 you've  got  a  whole  season  before  winter 
 hits  again  for  them  to  get  really 
 established  and  get  strong.  So  go  ahead, 
 this  is  the  perfect  time  of  year  to 
 introduce  your  new  plants  without  any 
 kind  of  worry  during  those  other  times 
 of  the  year.  The  next  tip  is  run  and 
 check  your  irrigation  system.  So,  I 
 literally  set  my  calendar  to  this  time 
 of  the  year.  This  is  the  best  time  of 
 the  year  to  run  through  your  irrigation 
 system.  Whether  you  have  sprinklers  like 
 you  have  I  you  see  here  behind  me  or  you 
 have  the  6  to  8  to  10  in  or  12  in  popups 
 or  you  have  a  drip  line  system.  Those 
 are  all  perfect  times  just  to  make  sure 
 that  nothing  is  clogged.  Make  sure  that 
 everything  is  getting  good  adequate 
 water.  So,  even  in  my  drip  line  systems 
 that  I  have,  you  can  take  and  and  cut 
 off  that  one  section  and  plug  it  and  run 
 a  new  line  through  it  and  make  sure  that 
 you  just  flush  that  whole  line.  So, 
 whatever  might  be  in  there,  whatever 
 sediment  might  have  collected  throughout 
 the  year,  this  is  a  great  time  to  flush 
 that  system  out,  flush  that  whole  line 
 out  and  that  way  you're  good  to  go  for 
 the  year.  And  at least  you  know  that  you 
 don't  have  plants  and  trees  suffering, 
 especially  with  drip  lines.  Drip  lines 
 can  be  a  bit  challenging  because  you 
 kind  of  don't  know  something's  wrong 
 until  things  start  dying.  So  I  have  it 
 on  my  calendar.  April  when  I  do  my 
 trimming,  when  I  do  my  cleanup,  when  I 
 do  my  mulching,  when  I  do  my 
 fertilizing,  that  is  the  time  of  the 
 year  that  I  go  out  and  run  through  all 
 my  zones.  Make  sure  that  I  am  good  to 
 go.  Everything  is  getting  adequate 
 coverage.  So  I  am  not  waiting  until  I 
 see  distress  before  I  react.  So  all 
 right,  y'all.  For  today's  final  tip,  it 
 is  to  add  those  key  features  in  your 
 garden.  So  every  single  year,  every 
 single  spring,  I  don't  know  what  it  is. 
 It's  more  tradition  than  anything,  but  I 
 find  a  new  feature  or  two  or  three  to 
 incorporate  into  the  garden.  And  it's  I 
 don't  know if  I  do  it  beginning  of 
 spring  because  I  love  to  be  out  this 
 time  of  the  year  and  then  I  get  to  enjoy 
 it  all  year  long.  But  it  is  the  time  to 
 incorporate  something.  It  could  be 
 something  simple  like  we  have  this 
 little  trellis  at  the  end  of  our  garden. 
 I  am  going  to  put  some  bleeding  hearts 
 on  there  because  my  daughter-in-law 
 loves  bleeding  hearts.  So,  I  think  that 
 this  will  be  a  nice  finale  to  our  back 
 walkway  as  you  lead  into  this  area.  So, 
 we're  gonna  have  the  purple  and  red 
 bleeding  hearts  here.  And  then  I'm  gonna 
 incorporate  my  little  bird  houses.  I 
 just  think  they're  cute.  They're 
 charming.  They  were  inexpensive.  They're 
 a  nice  touch  and  just  a  little  kind  of 
 little  welcoming  spot.  Now,  every  single 
 year  I  bring  in  bird  houses  or  little 
 like  hummingbird  little  nests  like  this. 
 I  just  love  the  idea.  I  feel  like  I'm 
 just  making  little  Airbnbs  everywhere. 
 I've  got  them  popped  in  throughout  my 
 whole  garden.  I  will  continue  to  add 
 them.  I  imagine  when  I'm  80  years  old. 
 I'm  going  to  have  like  town  houses  of 
 birdhouses  throughout  my  whole  garden. 
 But  what  a  great  place  to  be  because  I 
 when  I  hear  them  in  the  mornings,  I 
 wonder  did  they  roost  there?  Did  they 
 stay  there?  Do  they  I  just  I  don't  know. 
 They  call  me  weird,  but  I  think  that's 
 charming.  This  year,  I  got  these.  I  got 
 the  trellis  and  I  got  a  really  cool 
 little  mermaid  bird  bath.  I'll  get  Bryce 
 to  pop  in  a  picture  here.  I  don't  know 
 where  I'm  going  to  put  her,  but  when  I 
 saw  her,  I  just  thought,  got  to  have 
 her.  Got  to  got  to  find  a  spot  for  her. 
 So,  and  I've  already  got  she's  not  even 
 in  her  proper  place,  and  I've  already 
 got  birds  bathing  in  her.  I  just  cannot 
 wait  to  get  a  clip  for  you  guys.  But  it 
 is  so  exciting.  So,  you  know,  adding 
 those  features  into  a  garden.  As  you 
 guys  know  that  I  work  with  clients  every 
 single  day  incorporating  my  my  design 
 style  into  their  spaces,  but  I  always 
 encourage  them  when  we're  done.  You 
 know,  I  know  we've  married  my  design 
 style,  their  design  style,  and  then 
 worked  with  things  and  plants  and  trees 
 that  work.  You  know,  that's  the  best 
 part  of  my  job,  but  I  always  tell  them, 
 and  I  know  Bryce  does  the  same  thing. 
 Now,  it's  time,  now  that  this  is  done, 
 now  it's  time  to  really  incorporate 
 those  perfect  features.  Whether  it's  a 
 handme-down  bench  that  you  want  to  you 
 you  want  to  incorporate  into  your  garden 
 or  that  cool  statue  or  something  you 
 found  off  marketplace,  what  whatever  it 
 might  be  that  has  your  personality,  that 
 has  that  touch  that  just  screams  to  you 
 or  makes  you  want  to  walk  out  into  the 
 garden,  incorporate  it  because  that's 
 exactly  what  it  does.  It  encourages  us 
 to  walk  out  into  our  gardens  and  see  if 
 there's  anything  nesting  in  that 
 birdhouse  or  see  if  there's,  you  know, 
 anything,  you  know,  you  taking  sips  out 
 of  that  bird  bath  or  bathing  in  it  or  or 
 whatever  the  thing  might  be.  But  it  just 
 draws  you  out  into  the  garden  and  that's 
 what  brings  a  garden  to  life.  It's  just 
 not  about  the  plants  and  the  trees  and 
 the  waterfalls  and  all  of  that.  It's 
 about  it's  it's  so  interactive.  So,  if 
 you  can  grab  what  you  like,  you  know, 
 find  things  that  really  speak  to  you, 
 incorporate  them  in  your  garden,  they 
 become  a  part  of  your  space.  They  become 
 something  that  you  talk  with  somebody  as 
 you're  walking  through  it.  And  I  just  I 
 don't  know.  I  just  think  that's 
 charming.  Call  me  a  romantic,  but  I  just 
 think  that  is  super  charming  to  add  into 
 your  garden.  So,  every  single  year  I  do 
 that.  I  will  tell  you,  just  as  a  side 
 note,  one  thing  I  am  going  to 
 incorporate  back  here  that  I  have  seen 
 other  gardeners  do  that  I  love.  I'm 
 going  to  find  a  cool  tropical  mailbox  on 
 Marketplace.  I've  been  looking.  I 
 haven't  found  just  the  right  one  just 
 yet,  but  I'm  going  to  find  one  and  pop 
 it  into  the  garden  somewhere  over  here 
 because  I  love  the  idea  of  being  able  to 
 put  my  tools  in  there.  As  I  walk  through 
 this,  I'm  usually  holding  a  cup  of 
 coffee  or  a  glass  of  wine.  No  judgment. 
 But  I'm  walking  through  here  and  um 
 there's  commonly,  as  gardeners  know,  a 
 brown  limb  or  this  or  that  needs  to  be 
 clipped  or  trimmed.  So,  last  thing  I 
 want  to  do  is  go  back  into  the  garage, 
 grab  it,  and  then  come  out  here  and  and 
 trim  that  off.  So  having  something 
 tucked  maybe  one  or  two  or  three 
 mailboxes  throughout  my  back  buffer 
 would  be  a  really  cool  thing  to  just  set 
 on  a  post  and  put  my  little  tools  in 
 there  and  just  adds  a  little  bit  of  um 
 interest  and  it  also  adds  functionality. 
 So  both  of  those  married  are  just 
 phenomenal  in  your  garden.  So  that 
 pretty  much  does  it  for  today's  video.  I 
 hope  those  tips  and  tricks  and  and  fun 
 little  thoughts  really  help  you  guys.

 um  four  times  a  year  is  so  that's  March

 on  your  feed  but  for  right  now  we  are 
 going  to  jump  into  the  five  most  common 
 myths  that  I've  run  across  in  the  garden 
 so  the  first  one  being  watering  or  maybe 
 I  should  say  overwatering  so  I  I  get 
 this  question  all  the  time  my  plants  are 
 not  looking  great  and  I  water  like 
 clockwork  every  single  day  like  they  say 
 to  do  in  Florida  I  I  hit  that  irrigation 
 or  I  add  plant  add  water  to  my  garden 
 and  and  it's  just  not  doing  the  trick 
 for  it  so  it  is  it's  common  to  say  to 
 water  every  day  is  ideal  for  maybe  10  or 
 15  minutes  that  gives  the  plants  a 
 little  bit  of  drink  throughout  their  hot 
 hot  season  of  our  floor  to  heat  but 
 overwatering  every  day  is  actually  more 
 harm  than  good  you  want  to  make  sure  to 
 water 
 2  to  3  days  a  week  in  the  Florida  sun 
 and  then  do  a  deeper  watering  so  you 
 want  that  kind  of  water  to  be  on  for 
 more  like  like  35  minutes  to  an  hour  two 
 to  three  days  a  week  is  going  to  allow 
 the  roots  to  grow  deep  and  go  down  to  to 
 grab  that  water  that  soaks  in  now  of 
 course  if  you  don't  have  well  draining 
 soil  that  might  be  a  little  bit 
 different  you  might  have  to  do  more 
 shallow  watering  but  for  most  of  us  in 
 our  coastal  areas  you  want  to  definitely 
 you  know  water  a  deeper  a  longer  time 
 frame  because  you  want  deep  not  shallow 
 roots  and  that  really  makes  a  big 
 difference  during  our  hurricane  season 
 our  crazy  winds  during  the  winter  months 
 as  you  can  probably  see  a  little  bit  of 
 that  today  in  today's  video  and  then  of 
 course  our  cold  snaps  so  the  deeper  The 
 Roots  the  more  insulated  they  are  into 
 the  heat  of  that  Florida  Sun  my  average 
 Garden  here  and  I  tell  my  clients  after 
 the  plans  have  established  to  water 
 about  every  2  to  three  days  for  35 
 minutes  to  up  to  an  hour  depending  on 
 the  location  if  it's  more  in  the  Sun  or 
 not  so  that's  going  to  be  just  a  a 
 longterm  turn  better  fit  for  stronger 
 plants  that  can  withstand  Sun  winds  and 
 of  course  cold  temps  but  here's  a  little 
 tip  on  how  to  know  if  you're 
 overwatering  so  when  you're  noticing 
 that  your  plants  have  a  little  bit  of  uh 
 Browning  edges  or  a  yellow  tone  to  the 
 leaf  a  lot  of  time  it  is  just  getting  so 
 washed  out  with  so  much  water  it  it's 
 tough  because  when  you're  underwatering 
 they  kind  of  droop  and  they  kind  of  have 
 a  a  Browning  tinge  to  them  so  it  it  it 
 can  be  a  bit  challenging  but  if  you  see 
 kind  of  a  yellow  happy  kind  of  looking 
 plant  definitely  one  that  is  pretty  weak 
 in  stem  then  you'll  know  that  that's 
 just  it's  just  getting  way  too  much 
 water  or  the  fact  that  your  plants  and 
 trees  are  growing  just  way  too  fast  then 
 they're  kind  of  shooting  straight  up 
 because  they  have  such  a  shallow  root 
 system  all  of  their  energy  is  going 
 straight  up  so  you  want  to  make  sure 
 that  they're  kind  of  pushing  doing  the 
 work  to  get  down  below  and  that's  where 
 they're  they're  throwing  that  energy  for 
 for 
 growth  no  no  no  over  pruning  is  a  thing 
 you  guys  so  this  is  myth  number  two  to 
 pruning  makes  everything  Lush  beautiful 
 and  keeps  it  so  so  controlled  in  your 
 tropical  garden  however  overp  pruning 
 can  do  more  harm  than  good  so  there  are 
 certain  months  out  of  the  year  that  I 
 prune  my  entire  landscape  and  I  stick  to 
 this  unless  I  see  something  you  know  a 
 brown  Lim  or  here  and  there  but  overall 
 pruning  I  stick  to  the  months  of  March 
 June  September  and  December  those  are 
 the  time  frames  where  it  gives  the  plant 
 enough  time  to  flush  out  but  once  you 
 start  pruning  that  plant  back  in  those 
 months  it  lets  new  air  come  in  it  really 
 helps  with  um  just  kind  of  keeping  any 
 kind  of  fungus  or  any  kind  of  problems 
 from  really  encroaching  into  that  area 
 but  think  of  this  every  time  that  you 
 prune  you  allow  kind  of  an  open  sore  for 
 disease  or  pest  or  bugs  to  come  in  so 
 over  pruning  if  you're  out  there  and 
 you're  uh  like  some  of  my  clients  who 
 are  are  fabulous  you  know  they're  like 
 new  parents  after  a  new  Landscaping  goes

 same  thing  definitely  pruning  is 
 important  to  keep  shape  and  create

 times  is  what  where  really  really 
 matters  so  you  definitely  want  to  hit 
 those  months  of  March  June  September  and 
 December  that's  the  kind  of  the  range

 averages  out  to  every  70  to  90  days  is

 off  the  list  for  keeping  your  plants

 our  yard  especially  if  you're  like  me

 lay  their  little  babies  and  uh  create  a

 garden  is  awesome  but  just  make  sure

 that  you  have  running  water  now  my 
 fountains  that  I  have  are  what  we  call 
 disappearing  water  fountains  so  there  is 
 a  Basin  down  below  underneath  the  ground 
 that's  where  it  holds  the  water  below 
 ground  it  circulates  or  a  pump  pushes  it

 down  below  so  just  kind  of  keep  in  mind

 ground  if  it's  you  know  one  that  you

 Falls  versus  a  big  lake  out  there  so  you 
 want  to  make  sure  it's  not  one  of  those 
 big  bowls  where  it's  a  kind  of  just  a 
 little  trickle  water  syst  sits  and  then 
 eventually  flows  over  you  want  to  put  in 
 a  decent  Siz  pump  to  push  that  water

 number  four  you  guys  is  weed  fabric  will 
 prevent  weeds  from  coming  into  my  garden 
 so  definitely  put  your  weed  fabric  down

 time  and  a  place  for  weed  barrier  weed 
 fabric  I  use  it  for  places  kind  of  like 
 you  just  see  right  here  for  places  that 
 are  going  to  be  a  walkway  area  where  I'm 
 going  to  put  stone  or  even  in  stone  beds 
 because  it  has  it  has  a  it  it  serves  as 
 a  really  really  good  purpose  for  those 
 things  if  you're  going  to  use  weed 
 fabric  in  this  particular  situation  you 
 want  to  make  sure  that  you  really  do  a 
 good  job  of  grading  that  area  out  the 
 worst  thing  that  you  can  do  is  put  weed 
 fabric  over  kind  of  a  lumpy  or  bumpy 
 area  because  the  first  thing  that  it'll 
 do  is  those  little  lumps  and  bumps 
 they'll  Pock  it  with  soil  or  they'll 
 pocket  with  water  either  one  or  worse  it 
 clogs  the  area  up  and  then  it  creates 
 just  a  magn  for  weeds  in  those 
 particular  spots  you  want  it  to  look 
 like  a  Marine's  bed  you  want  it  to  be 
 kind  of  nice  and  and  tight  and  then  that 
 way  it's  all  fully  pinned  and  then  then 
 your  material  goes  on  top  of  that  and  it 
 kind  of  becomes  a  nice  level  playing 
 Ground  even  if  there's  a  grade  shift  you 
 just  want  to  make  sure  that  grade  shift 
 is  nice  and  smooth  and  there's  no  lumps 
 and  bumps  in  there  that  is  90%  of  the 
 time  how  I  use  my  weed  fabric  now  if  you 
 are  going  to  do  a  landscaping  bed  and 
 rock  is  included  and  it  is  more  of  the 
 tough  Tropicals  that  we're  working  with 
 and  you  can  absolutely  use  weed  fabric 
 there  because  you  need  the  fabric  there 
 to  for  the  The  Rock  to  sit  on  top  of  so 
 again  you  want  to  make  sure  that  is 
 grated  but  that  that  does  a  really  good 
 job  of  keeping  your  rock  in  place  Bryce 
 if  you'll  pan  over  here  to  the  side  then 
 you'll  be  able  to  see  kind  of  what  I'm 
 talking  about  kind  of  where  we  did  our 
 our  Rock  beds  so  things  that  are  tough 
 like  you  see  my  little  plant  groupings  I 
 allowed  them  to  be  in  the  Rock  bed  where 
 there  is  weed  matting  but  all  of 
 everything  else  else  in  my  garden  that 
 is  mulch  based  that  is  grouped  planting 
 that  is  a  nice  thick  group  layer  I 
 wanted  it  to  have  the  healthiest 
 environment  ever  and  that  is  a  mulch  bed 
 mulch  holds  moisture  mulch  breaks  down 
 and  it  goes  into  the  soil  and  really 
 helps  the  soil  nutrients  over  time  as  it 
 breaks  down  now  if  you  put  mulch  over 
 top  of  weed  barrier  it  does  the  exact 
 same  thing  it  breaks  down  but  then  it 
 becomes  a  pretty  much  weed  bed  for  new 
 seedlings  so  all  the  seedlings  that  drop 
 or  get  blown  in  lay  on  top  of  that  mulch 
 Bed  above  your  weed  matting  and  before 
 you  know  it  you  just  got  little  seed 
 Pockets  everywhere  so  save  your  money

 Landscaping  like  you  see  here  busting 
 myth  number  five  palm  trees  in  Florida 
 do  not  need  fertilizer  okay  so  I  can 
 understand  where  that  comes  from  we  do 
 live  in  a  beautiful  place  for  palm  trees 
 the  perfect  place  I  think  but  pal  trees 
 do  need  pottassium  and  magnesium  for  for 
 their  natural  deficiencies  they  have  a 
 tendency  to  go  a  little  bit  yellow  on 
 you  especially  in  our  soil  conditions  so 
 modifying  that  for  them  really  makes  the 
 most  beautiful  fronds  it  really  kind  of 
 helps  them  from  getting  that  yellow  tone 
 or  tint  to  them  that  you  see  in  a  lot  of 
 Florida  gardens  so  it's  absolutely 
 important  I  use  8212  as  a  it's  called 
 8212  Palm  gain  I  use  that  throughout  my 
 whole  garden  not  just  my  palm  trees  I 
 feel  like  that's  a  great  mixture  to  give 
 all  of  my  Tropicals  they  eat  it  up  they 
 love  it  I  really  really  get  good  color 
 from  everything  with  that  mix  however  I 
 have  heard  from  clients  um  in  the  past 
 who  swear  by  Epsom  salts  you  know 
 they'll  go  out  and  they'll  just  sprinkle 
 epson  salts  around  their  palm  trees  and 
 their  Tropicals  and  they've  had  just 
 great  luck  with  that  now  I  do  I  do 
 believe  that  if  your  soil  is  deficient 
 in  magnesium  and  adding  some  magnesium 
 sulfate  to  that  would  definitely  benefit 
 that  but  I  do  want  to  kind  of  say  that 
 with  the  Clause  because  if  your  soil 
 isn't  that  way  and  you  add  it  to  it  and 
 you  add  it  to  it  over  time  then  you 
 actually  deplete  the  soil  of  a  lot  of 
 the  nutrients  that  it  needs  as  it  breaks 
 that  down  so  you  want  to  make  sure  that 
 you  don't  add  it  unless  it's  absolutely 
 necessary  if  if  you  do  you're  causing 
 yourself  much  larger  problems  in  the 
 future  because  modifying  and  and  and 
 bringing  your  soil  up  to  certain  pH 
 levels  is  so  much  harder  than  just 
 maintaining  a  good  level  it  can  take  up 
 to  years  to  do  that  versus  just  adding 
 your  natural  granular  fertilizer  you 
 know  three  to  four  times  a  year  and 
 that's  kind  of  how  I  do  it  during  my 
 trimming  Cycles  which  is  March  June 
 September  and  December  I'll  hit 
 everything  with  fertilizer  in  one  one 
 weekend  in  those  months  and  then  that 
 way  I  just  know  everything  has  got  what 
 it  needs  it's  just  got  its  flu  shot  it's 
 immune  shot  whatever  you  want  to  call  it 
 everything  does  super  super  well  during 
 that  time  of  the  during  that  time  of  the 
 year  it's  my  go-to  time  frame  and  I 
 absolutely  stand  behind  you  know 
 fertilizing  your  garden  it  just  makes 
 such  a  difference  with  your  long-term 
 term  benefits  and  keeping  that  soil  just 
 at  the  right  levels  that  you  need  to 
 keep  it  it's  just  like  our  bodies  we  all 
 need  certain  things  to  flourish  our 
 Gardens  du  too  all  right  you  guys  so 
 that  does  it  for  today's  video  please

 so  tip  number  one  is  starting  from  the 
 ground  up  so  as  we  know  our  soil 
 especially  here  in  Florida  is  not  the 
 best  so  amending  your  soil  is  huge 
 especially  if  it's  you  have  a  blank 
 slate  to  work  with  kind  of  get  some  of 
 that  soil  out  bring  in  some  new 
 nutrients  my  favorite  soil  mixture  that 
 I  use  on  a  large  scale  for  all  of  our 
 projects  is  is  50%  Black  Cow  25%  Pete 
 Moss  and  about  25%  pine  bark  nuggets  so 
 now  if  you  guys  are  in  your  development 
 sometimes  that  soil  does  not  drain  you 
 might  want  to  up  that  pine  bark  mulch  um 
 so  that  way  you  get  excessive  draining 
 you  really  really  get  that  soil  moving 
 and  and  really  helps  with  that  breakdown 
 and  that  micronutrients  in  the  soil  so

 your  G  off  to  its  biggest  success  so  tip

 so  hello  gardeners  welcome  back  my  name 
 is  Jennifer  bevans  or  as  you  guys  might 
 know  me  as  true  Gardener  uh  we  are  back 
 at  my  home  today  and  I  want  to  share 
 some  tips  on  how  to  create  a  garden  on  a 
 budget  these  are  just  a  few  quick  tips 
 that  I've  had  to  overcome  over  the  last 
 25  years  so  I  thought  gosh  let  me  share 
 them  with  you  guys  and  hope  that  I  can 
 save  you  guys  a  bit  of  the  stress  and 
 angst  that  I've  been  through  in  my 
 beginning  years  of  gardening  but  do  stay 
 to  the  end  because  that  um  that  last 
 couple  tips  they  are  humdingers  they're 
 ones  that  I  definitely  want  you  guys  to 
 be  around  for  so  the  first  tip  I  would 
 say  would  be  splitting  your  plants  if 
 you  guys  aren't  new  to  gardening  or  you 
 know  just  starting  to  kind  of  create  a 
 pallet  for  your  backyard  get  some 
 clumping  plants  plants  that  provide  pups 
 plants  that  provide  extra  plants  for  the 
 rest  of  your  garden  especially  if  you're 
 doing  this  in  phases  because  it  it  will 
 pay  for  itself  um  plants  like  the  dwarf 
 alas  I  know  I've  mentioned  this  in 
 previous  videos  because  this  plant 
 actually  I  have  propagated  it  and  pulled 
 it  pulled  pups  off  of  it  and  it's  been 
 in  so  many  different  areas  of  my  garden 
 and  it's  a  fantastic  plant  to  use  you 
 can  put  it  in  the  ground  for  about  6 
 months  to  a  year  it  starts  to  like 
 recreate  little  pups  along  the  edges  of 
 it  you  can  easily  chop  off  those  pups 
 put  them  right  into  water  if  you  want  or 
 put  them  right  into  the  ground  in  other 
 areas  and  I'll  get  Bryce  to  post  a  few 
 pictures  of  of  them  in  different  areas 
 of  my  garden  but  you  can  do  that  with  so 
 many  Florida  plants  that  it  it's  almost 
 like  there's  just  a  huge  selection  of 
 them  so  like  look  up  clumping  plants  for 
 your  area  that  way  you  can  determine  you 
 know  what's  going  to  work  for  your 
 particular  space  and  and  then  maybe  you 
 can  just  kind  of  get  free  plants  that 
 can  you  know  like  you  can  reuse  amongst 
 different  areas  of  your  garden  like  the 
 dwarf  alices  like  the  agonas  like  the 
 Eureka  Pals  or  the  cat  Pals  or  your  Rus 
 Palms  things  along  those  lines  this  is 
 one  of  my  favorite  budget  friendly 
 things  to  do  in  a  young  Garden  so  those 
 of  you  guys  who  know  that  you're  going 
 to  be  working  in  phases  it's  ideal  get 
 some  started  in  certain  areas  of  your 
 garden  knowing  that  you're  going  to  take 
 the  babies  and  you're  going  to  just  make 
 families  all  over  the  place  so  it  is  a 
 fantastic  way  to  do  it  because  plants 
 are  expensive  so  if  you  spend  $20  or  $25 
 on  one  plant  three  gallon  plant  grouping

 so  hey  gardeners  welcome  back  so  today 
 we  are  in  my  backyard  again  and  today's 
 video  is  all  about  privacy  for  those  of 
 you  who  are  new  my  name  is  Jennifer 
 bevans  I  am  a  landscape  designer  here  in 
 virau  beach  and  we  are  going  to  talk 
 about  some  solutions  that  I've  created 
 for  my  own  personal  privacy  and  things 
 that  I've  done  for  so  many  people  um 
 just  throughout  the  treasure  and  Space 
 Coast  so  um  there  are  so  many  different 
 ways  that  you  can  do  privacy  and  I 
 thought  that  I'm  going  to  list  kind  of 
 some  things  that  are  super  budget 
 friendly  things  that  grow  very  very  fast 
 and  things  that  you  know  if  you  want  to 
 create  and  kind  of  get  your  hands  into 
 um  into  a  little  bit  of  Woodwork  in  here 
 there's  some  things  that  you  can  do 
 there  but  we'll  get  into  that  later  in 
 the  video  I  would  say  70%  maybe  75%  of 
 my  clients  who  call  and  email  me  they're 
 looking  for  privacy  they're  looking  for 
 how  to  create  that  Oasis  or  maybe  even 
 just  block  something  out  that  maybe 
 maybe  their  neighbor  is  doing  over  there 
 whatever  it  might  be  they're  looking  to 
 kind  of  create  their  own  space  we're  all 
 busy  individuals  and  we're  you  know 
 we're  looking  to  make  our  space  our  own 
 so  privacy  is  a  big  thing  for  us  and  I 
 thought  let  me  do  a  video  on  sharing 
 some  of  my  top  things  that  I  love  to 
 incorporate  into  those  particular  homes 
 and  hopefully  this  might  help  you  guys 
 to  to  do  the  same  on  your  own  so  please 
 if  this  is  kind  of  your  thing  then 
 subscribe  hit  that  little  notification 
 Bell  we  put  out  a  video  every  single 
 week  so  let's  get  started  so  there  are 
 typically  about  three  ways  to  create 
 privacy  in  a  yard  you  can  do  a  fence 
 which  is  what  we  have  right  here  uh  you 
 can  do  a  typical  iCal  hedge  it's  a 
 common  thing  to  do  create  a  hedge  and 
 you  have  instantaneous  privacy  right 
 well  there's  that  and  then  there's  a 
 palm  tree  grouping  that  you  can  do  and 
 I'm  going  to  share  with  you  guys  all 
 three  because  I  have  all  three  in  my

 so  hey  gardeners  welcome  back  so  we  are 
 in  my  front  yard  today  and  today's  video 
 is  all  about  propagation  so  if  you  guys 
 are  looking  to  create  a  garden  and  then 
 take  that  garden  and  have  it  you  know 
 transfer  into  other  parts  of  your  yard 
 and  just  kind  of  you  know  let  it  all 
 flow  and  have  beautiful  beautiful 
 specimens  then  stay  into  this  video 
 because  I'm  going  to  share  with  you  my 
 favorite  plants  within  my  whole  garden 
 that  I  have  taken  and  propagated  and  put 
 little  clusters  of  the  throughout  the 
 whole  area  and  how  I've  done  it  so  we're 
 going  to  start  with  one  of  my  favorites 
 which  is  the  Brazilian  Red  Cloak  and  I 
 don't  know  if  I  even  have  to  tell  you 
 why  this  is  one  of  my  favorites  I  mean 
 it  is  just  a  stunner  grow  strong  just 
 resilient  to  pest  just  just  overall 
 tough  the  only  thing  that  about  this 
 particular  plant  is  it  does  need  a 
 little  bit  of  water  a  little  extra 
 watering  than  some  of  your  other 
 Tropicals  but  goodness  does  anything 
 scream  more  tropical  than  these  big 
 giant  leaves  I  mean  I  just  feel  like  I'm 
 just  in  developed  in  a  rainforest  when  I 
 have  them  so  obviously  I  wanted  to  have 
 them  in  many  other  places  in  my  garden 
 I'm  going  to  share  with  you  guys  where  I 
 took  some  of  these  cuting  from  and 
 propagated  them  so  when  you  want  a  big 
 clustering  like  you  see  here  then  you're 
 going  to  want  to  make  sure  to  trim  it 
 pretty  heavily  now  we've  had  some  really 
 cold  snaps  that  have  come  through  so  you 
 can  kind  of  see  some  Leaf  burn  on  on 
 some  of  these  beautiful  blooms  oh  my 
 goodness  but  overall  it  has  handled  the 
 cold  temps  like  like  a  champ  so  I'm  not 
 going  to  do  a  heavy  cutting  right  now 
 and  you  can  kind  of  see  where  it's  gappy 
 and  it  really  needs  a  good  trim  but  I  am 
 going  to  show  you  guys  exactly  what  I 
 would  do  and  where  I  would  cut  to  make 
 myself  a  brand  new  plant  let  me  find  one 
 that's  not  in  bloom  or  not  popping  New 
 Growth  like  you  see  here  but  has  a  good 
 stem  to  it  so  here  we  are  so  we've  got  a 
 young  one  here  so  you  want  to  go  in 
 between  the  nodes  that  you  see  here 
 which  is  pretty  much  just  the  L  lines 
 themselves  on  the  plant  so  we  got  a  line 
 here  and  a  line  here  and  I  just  want  to 
 go  just  above  this  line  cut  this  guy 
 right  through  here  now  you  can  do  two 
 things  you  can  take  this  guy  and  you  can 
 let  him  just  dry  out  a  little  bit  for 
 the  day  or  you  can  put  him  right  in  the 
 ground  now  I've  seen  people  do  both  and 
 honestly  I  can't  tell  much  of  a 
 difference  but  what  I  can  tell  when  that 
 makes  a  big  difference  is  cutting  these 
 leaves  in  half  that  way  the  plant  itself 
 when  I  go  to  plant  it  only  has  has  to 
 worry  about  pushing  out  new  stem  growth 
 these  leaves  are  very  big  so  cutting 
 them  down  really  pushes  all  of  that 
 energy  towards  the  root  system  so  I'll 
 leave  some  of  these  especially  these 
 younger  leaves  that  are  kind  of  just 
 really  doing  super  well  but  some  of 
 these  older  leaves  I  will  cut  them  right 
 at  the  corner  and  cut  them  in  half  and 
 we're  going  to  walk  over  to  my  backyard 
 that's  a  little  bit  shadier  spot  and 
 we're  going  to  stick  this  guy  right  in 
 the  ground  now  you  can  of  course  let  it 
 dry  out  if  that's  your  thing  it's  done 
 well  in  both  ways  so  but  I  do  like  to 
 you  know  I'm  busy  so  on  a  Saturday  I

 Pest  Control  sounds  like  such  a  hard 
 thing  to  do  especially  for  those  of  you 
 guys  who  are  new  gardeners  but  it's 
 something  as  simple  as  mixing  an  ounce 
 of  the  product  in  with  a  jug  of  water 
 shaking  it  and  pouring  it  on  the  root 
 system  it  draws  up  from  the  root  system 
 it  feeds  your  plants  and  it  also 
 protects  them  so  it  it's  one  of  those 
 things  that  is  worth  its  weight  and  gold 
 do  it  for  them  during  cold  snaps  because 
 they're  weak  do  it  for  during  you  know 
 during  the  hurricane  season  or  um  Heavy 
 Rain  season  because  they're  weaker 
 because  they're  taking  on  that  extra 
 bout  think  of  it  as  like  a  flu  shot 
 anytime  that  you  think  that  you  would 
 need  a  flu  shot  because  of  your 
 circumstances  hit  them  with  a  pest 
 control  product  because  it  really  does

 so  hey  you  guys  hear  that  that  is  the 
 sound  of  a  finished  waterfall  I  wanted 
 to  share  with  you  guys  some  tips  that  I 
 have  learned  along  the  way  as  being  a 
 waterfall  Builder  um  something  that  I 
 think  would  have  been  super  helpful  for 
 me  years  ago  when  I  started  this  trade 
 so  hopefully  I  can  demystify  some  things 
 if  you're  looking  to  create  a 
 naturalistic  waterfall  something  that 
 really  is  just  um  you  know  just  sets  off 
 your  backyard  or  maybe  a  little 
 Courtyard  front  entrance  way  um  that  you 
 want  to  make  it  look  like  it  you  know 
 not  like  it  just  popped  up  out  of 
 nowhere  but  make  it  look  like  it's  part 
 of  the  garden  that  I'm  hoping  these  tips 
 are  going  to  help  you  guys  now  I  know 
 this  feature  right  here  that  we  just 
 finished  is  a  much  bigger  feature  than 
 you  might  be  working  with  in  your  own 
 house  but  the  fundamentals  are  the  same 
 my  waterfall  in  my  backyard  which  is 
 much  smaller  all  of  the  top  sections 
 were  done  by  hand  with  smaller  Boulders 
 so  it's  the  same  concept  but  I  we're 
 here  today  so  I  thought  I  would  just  go 
 through  these  tips  for  you  guys  and 
 hopes  that  that  kind  of  it  helps  you 
 create  that  look  for  your  s  so  tip 
 number  one  which  sounds  simple  but  super 
 important  so  when  you're  um  building 
 your  waterfall  feature  you're  going  to 
 dig  out  your  Basin  that's  where  you're 
 going  to  start  you're  going  to  dig  out 
 the  hole  or  the  Basin  area  for  where  the 
 water  is  going  to  collect  whatever 
 company  that  you  work  with  we're 
 aquascapes  contractors  so  we  use 
 aquascapes  products  but  there's  so  many 
 different  varieties  of  products 
 depending  on  your  your  budget  so  you're 
 going  to  dig  this  area  out  quite  nice 
 and  large  you're  going  to  take  all  of 
 that  soil  and  you're  going  to  use  it  to 
 build  your  waterfall  90%  of  the  time  no 
 matter  how  small  your  waterfall  that  is 
 not  enough  soil  for  you  to  use  um  you 
 need  to  bring  in  enough  dirt  where  your 
 waterfall  area  doesn't  not  look  like  a 
 teepee  does  not  look  more  like  this  kind 
 of  structure  you  kind  of  want  it  to  look 
 like  an  oversized  mound  of  uh  like  an 
 antill  um  more  like  Florida  anthills  you 
 know  like  they're  just  gravitas  you  know 
 triple  story  an  Hills  you  want  to  make 
 sure  that  you  have  enough  where  you  can 
 really  Mound  it  out  on  the  sides  and 
 feather  it  out  and  go  into  a  natural 
 grade  so  kind  of  like  um  you  know  just 
 just  a  rounded  State  and  then  you  want 
 to  take  wherever  that  waterfall  wherever 
 the  Viewpoint  is  where  whatever  the 
 middle  of  that  area  is  you  want  to  carve 
 the  middle  of  that  area  out  just  like  we 
 did  here  so  this  is  our  big  giant  antill 
 here  and  um  all  we  did  was  you  know 
 feather  it  down  on  both  sides  and  then 
 we  took  the  middle  of  that  the  area  that 
 we  wanted  to  focus  on  and  we  built  a 
 channel  in  the  middle  so  we  started 
 carving  that  middle  section  out  and 
 insetting  our  Boulders  you  wherever 
 you're  starting  from  the  top  there  that 
 you  have  enough  kind  of  framework  around 
 to  kind  of  create  an  inset  Boulders  just 
 to  frame  where  that  water  is  going  to  go 
 that  way  this  has  a  nice  deep  line  now 
 you  see  that  the  boulders  that  we  used 
 at  the  top  they're  only  you  know  they're 
 handheld  Boulders  they're  Boulders  that 
 you  can  pick  up  and  and  move  those  right 
 there  are  holding  water  in  so  so  we  have 
 the  liner  wrapped  inside  those  those 
 Boulders  into  the  outside  of  those 
 Boulders  kind  of  pinned  there  with  um 
 with  mulch  so  they're  kind  of  tucking  in 
 creating  a  wall  for  that  water  to  go  in 
 but  you  see  where  the  water  line  is  it's 
 it's  you  know  not  even  halfway  up  those 
 Boulder  lines  before  it  falls  what  you 
 want  to  make  sure  when  you're  creating 
 that  wall  you  naturally  want  to  do  a 
 straight  wall  of  course  but  for  a  pitch 
 for  for  water  to  move  you  definitely 
 want  that  first  tier  especially  the 
 first  tier  to  have  a  nice  angled  pitch 
 you  don't  want  it  to  be  like  this 
 because  the  last  thing  you  want  to  do  is 
 you  want  you  don't  want  your  water  to 
 come  from  here  and  then  back  flow  into 
 these  Corners  you  want  it  naturally  to 
 tilt  forward  so  water  comes  here  and 
 wants  to  go  this  direction  cuz  water 
 will  move  fast  and  then  it  it  won't  have 
 time  by  the  time  it  starts  collecting 
 it'll  kind  of  go  into  different  areas  so 
 we  didn't  want  it  to  go  back  into  those 
 Corners  we  wanted  it  to  flow  first  and 
 the  same  thing  happens  with  every  single 
 tier  so  as  we  get  in  here  that's  there's 
 a  higher  level  there  and  then  it's  a 
 smaller  or  lower  level  here  and 
 everything  is  pitched  forward  down  to 
 this  gigantic  final  tier  this  Boulder 
 tips  forward  to  create  that  same  kind  of 
 look  now  in  this  particular  house  or 
 this  particular  water  feature  my  client 
 wanted  a  heavy  amount  of  sound  so  we 
 have  pools  of  water  sitting  here 
 normally  this  would  flow  into  just  Stone 
 there'd  be  a  tad  bit  of  water  in  the 
 stone  but  not  much  not  like  a  pooling 
 area  but  she  wanted  to  you  know  bring  in 
 birds  and  really  have  some  serious 
 sounds  so  we  have  a  thick  layer  of  water 
 everywhere  but  you  can  do  the  exact 
 opposite  you  can  do  a  very  sheet  style 
 waterfall  where  it  moves  so  fast  that  it 
 doesn't  have  time  to  pull  you  don't  have 
 to  have  these  Pockets  I  personally  like 
 the  look  of  them  but  to  each  his  own 
 it's  really  up  to  you  you  can  do  it  both 
 ways  the  next  thing  that  I  would  suggest 
 um  is  to  mix  your  Stones  mix  your 
 Boulders  um  many  times  I'll  see  where 
 people  will  do  all  the  same  size  Stone 
 you  know  even  if  it's  handheld  Stone 
 like  this  I'll  see  them  just  do  that  all 
 with  one  one  size  stone  that  looks  very 
 very  man-made  if  you  can  pocket  some 
 bigger  stones  in  there  great  if  you  can 
 pocket  um  only  certain  sides  like  if 
 it's  only  something  that  you're  kind  of 
 carrying  in  from  from  your  front  yard  or 
 your  backyard  by  yourself  then  make  sure 
 you  bring  in  smaller  Stones  than  that  to 
 make  sure  that  you  know  you  have  some 
 mix  and  match  it  it  matters  so  much  you 
 can  see  the  variation  of  different 
 Stones  so  here  we  have  the  river  Jacks 
 here  and  then  we  mixed  in  with  a  little 
 bigger  um  Tennessee  Field  Stone  and  then 
 we  have  you  know  look  at  the  the 
 difference  between  I  mean  this  giant 
 boulder  that  we're  sitting  on  this  is 
 our  frame  rock  this  is  our  what  we  call 
 the  destination  rock  this  is  the  rock 
 that  we  sit  and  relax  on  um  we  do  this 
 often  and  we'll  do  this  usually  more  so 
 at  the  bottom  to  kind  of  create  kind  of 
 a  standing  point  when  you're  enjoying 
 the  water  feature  or  a  sitting  point  and 
 if  you  can  do  that  and  mix  and  match 
 your  Stones  it  just  makes  for  a  natural 
 waterfall  no  matter  you  know  what  sizes 
 you're  working  with  just  mix  and  match 
 when  I  started  doing  this  I  you  know  I 
 always  like  the  look  of  stone  wrapping 
 around  a  water  feature  because  I  think 
 it  kind  of  gives  you  a  nice  clean  Edge 
 all  the  way  around  so  I  would  wrap  it 
 with  um  like  a  white  river  rock  or  brown 
 river  rock  all  the  way  around  the  water 
 feature  making  it  look  like  I  put  a 
 String  of  Pearls  around  you  know 
 Boulders  and  and  the  waterfall  and  it 
 just  it  just  did  not  just  didn't  work  so 
 if  you  can  mix  and  match  the  elements 
 there  so  right  at  the  bottom  here  we 
 have  a  smaller  white  Alabama  River  Rock 
 and  then  it  goes  into  a  bigger  white 
 Alabama  River  Rock  in  the  Basin  where  I 
 needed  to  make  sure  that  I  that  water 
 didn't  move  the  Rock  in  any  kind  of  way 
 and  then  you  guys  will  see  the  river 
 Jacks  dispersed  in  key  areas  that  are 
 right  through  here  I  mean  that  just  just 
 that  little  bit  of  touch  now  that  was 
 done  on  purpose  just  to  hold  water  from 
 from  um  moving  the  dirt  down  below  so 
 just  retaining  that  soil  there  and  um 
 and  then  I'll  use  mulch  and  plants  to  do 
 the  rest  of  it  like  I  love  these  golden 
 Sedum  now  these  guys  are  going  to 
 encroach  right  into  these  corners  and 
 flow  right  in  to  touch  that  water  and 
 it's  going  to  really  soften  those  edges 
 so  I've  done  that  with  poos  Vines  I've 
 done  that  with  these  guys  I've  done  that 
 with  um  creeping  Fus  um  on  um  running  on 
 Boulders  and  that's  just  a  great  way  to 
 naturalize  the  look  so  um  if  you  can 
 kind  of  just  tuck  in  your  your  plants 
 and  your  trees  to  kind  of  overgrow  into

 golden  Dew  or  gold  Mound  and  I've  gotten

 confuse  people  golden  Dew  and  gold  Mound

 Nursery  have  evolved  and  they  now  call 
 them  gold  Mound  and  then  now  some 
 nurseries  still  call  them  golden  Dew  so 
 I  go  back  and  forth  but  they  are  the 
 same  plant  gold  Mound  golden  Dew  are 
 just  a  nice  beautiful  consistent  low 
 ground  cover  so  um  I  use  them  for  just 
 that  so  this  is  going  to  be  about  2T

 with  dark  beautiful  reddish  orange 
 flowers  so  that  contrast  of  red  orange 
 green  yellow  yellow  green  and  blue  are 
 gorgeous  but  what  these  these  three 
 plants  all  have  in  common  here  is  that 
 they're  not  um

 um  do  mulch  within  the  planting  beds  but 
 right  along  the  border  of  the  walkway 
 right  by  the  front  entrance  of  the  house

 it  keeps  everything  so  nice  and  clean

 rock  kind  of  borders  everything  and  then

 we're  going  to  look  at  here  but  I'll 
 break  down  the  steps  into  four  easy 
 steps  and  we'll  kind  of  just  walk  right 
 through  those  so  let's  do  it  so  step  one 
 would  be  um  clearing  out  the  area  so 
 whatever  the  area  is  that  you're  going

 fully  cleaned  out  so  if  it's  grass  if 
 it's  just  landscape  debris  if  it's  weeds

 the  whole  root  ball  of  that  weed  out 
 just  so  you're  starting  with  a  nice 
 clean  base  and  then  take  a  moment  and 
 just  kind  of  rake  that  area  out  level  it 
 out  the  best  that  you  can  it  does  not 
 need  to  be  laser  level  but  it  does  need 
 to  be  kind  of  where  it's  not  got  lumps 
 and  bumps  all  in  it  because  the  last 
 thing  you  want  is  when  we  do  have  rain 
 you  have  like  a  little  collection  of  of 
 puddles  in  the  Rock  so  you  kind  of  want 
 that  rock  to  be  on  a  nice  flat  surface

 what  this  video  is  about  so  in  this 
 particular  situ  ation  we  have  different 
 types  of  Lights  this  is  what  is  called  a 
 wall  light  so  most  people  that  this  is  a 
 full  bronze  light  it  can  handle  the  salt 
 conditions  is  a  nice  nice  standard  um 
 commercial  product  that  is  just  really 
 really  good  the  bulb  itself  has  a  5-year 
 warranty  5year  replacement  warranty  so 
 if  it  goes  out  within  5  years  they 
 replace  it  for  free  which  I  absolutely 
 love  um  but  this  is  a  wall  light  now  you 
 can  get  a  wall  light  in  any  any  of  your 
 lighting  packages  and  most  people  want 
 to  put  that  directly  on  a  wall  but  I 
 love  it  on  things  like  the  Agave  because 
 what  happens  when  you  put  a  spotlight 
 right  on  a  Agave  you  get  that  little 
 round  circular  direct  um  like  looks  like 
 a  just  a  bright  shining  little  circular 
 uh  light  right  on  this  Agave  now  the 
 wall  light  has  like  a  screen  diffuser  in 
 it  so  it  has  a  a  widening  effect  so  you 
 can  already  see  it's  not  built  directly 
 like  a  spotlight  where  it  has  that  real 
 real  rounded  scope  it  has  more  of  a 
 broad  uh  space  to  the  front  of  of  it  or 
 face  to  the  front  of  it  and  then  it  has 
 a  diffuser  in  it  that  softens  the  light 
 and  widens  the  light  out  so  you  kind  of 
 get  that  whole  Shadow  effect  and  as  this 
 tree  gets  bigger  that  light  gets  even 
 cooler  because  it  really  winds  it  out  to 
 fill  the  whole  plant  versus  that  just 
 that  little  circular  hot  spot  on  it  so 
 anytime  you  pick  up  any  even  the  Malibu 
 lights  or  the  home  deeper  or  Lowe's 
 lights  get  the  wall  light  for  that 
 particular  these  particular  lower  plants

 ideal  for  even  those  anti-l  that  you 
 guys  we  just  looked  at  over  there  in  the 
 video

 a  natural  potassium  deficiency  so  I 
 might  come  in  and  add  a  bit  more  of  that 
 just  to  just  to  know  that  I'm  covered 
 especially  if  I  start  seeing  any  kind  of 
 variation  in  leaf  coverage  if  my  if  my 
 leaves  start  having  some  flaking  in  here 
 I  know  that  I'm  having  a  little  bit  of  a 
 deficiency  but  as  you  can  see  my  leaves 
 are  fully  green  fully  happy  and  very 
 very  strong  and  that  goes  for  most  of  my 
 palm  trees  and  I  know  that's  because  of 
 this  8212  mixture  it's  a  very  very  easy 
 mixture  to  apply  now  I  do  this  every 
 single  March  June  and  September  I'll  hit 
 it  again  in  December  if  it's  going  to  be 
 if  it  looks  like  it's  going  to  be  a  warm 
 winter  I'll  hit  it  a  fourth  time  but 
 overall  it's  about  every  every  90  days 
 you  can  hit  it  with  this  granular  the 
 only  thing  about  this  particular  product 
 not  everything  is  a  slow  release  on  this 
 product  the  nitrogen  is  a  slow  release 
 but  if  you  notice  that  you  might  be 
 needing  a  little  bit  more  in  between 
 those  times  you  can  use  something  like 
 um  like  this  drench  that  is  obviously 
 heavily  used  in  my  garden  I  can  use  this 
 in  between  times  it  does  a  fantastic  job 
 of  giving  my  trees  a  um  just  a  nice  bit 
 of  dose  of  nutrients  and  then  they  have 
 micronutrients  in  them  and  it's  just  a 
 fantastic  product  what  I  do  is  I  take 
 that  um  the  8212  fertilizer  I  put  it  in 
 this  little  mop  bucket  and  then  I  take 
 several  handfuls  of  this  and  I  work  my 
 way  around  the  tree  and  I  like  to  call 
 it  kind  of  like  I'm  chicken  feeding  it  a 
 bit  so  all  I  really  do  is  I  get  around 
 the  root  base  and  I  you  know  start  from 
 the  back  and  work  my  way  all  the  way 
 around  the 
 tree  and  there  is  a  label  on  the  back 
 based  on  how  big  the  caliber  of  your 
 trunks  are  but  I've  been  doing  this  so 
 long  that  I  um  I  kind  of  just  feel  it

 so  hey  gardeners  welcome  back  so  today's 
 video  is  all  about  what  to  do  prior  to  a 
 hurricane  if  you  have  an  extensive 
 Garden  if  you  guys  followed  my  channel 
 you  know  that  I  have  a  very  extensive 
 Garden  so  prepping  for  these  storms  is 
 just  part  of  living  in  Florida  and  so  I 
 want  to  share  a  few  tips  that  I  do  in 
 help  to  help  kind  of  keep  um  keep  the 
 damage  pretty  minimal  so  um  the  very 
 first  thing  that  I  do  is  I  walk  through 
 this  Garden  several  times  um  prior  to 
 the  storms  it's  nice  and  quiet  now  right 
 before  all  the  weather  starts  to  hit  so 
 a  great  time  to  just  kind  of  walk 
 through  your  garden  see  if  there's  any 
 any  kind  of  loose  material  any  brown 
 limbs  anything  that  might  become  a 
 projectile  um  you  know  throughout  the 
 storm  it's  also  a  great  idea  to  get  kind 
 of  release  some  of  those  limbs  off  of 
 the  trees  because  as  I  say  that  here 
 comes  the  rain  but  to  release  those 
 limbs  off  of  the  trees  because  um  you 
 want  you  want  air  flow  to  really  hit 
 those  trees  now  when  I  have  um  more 
 compact  trees  like  um  gardinas  bottle 
 brush  trees  hibis  SP  and  Vilas  things 
 that  have  more  of  a  thicker  denser 
 canopy  head  and  have  more  of  a  Slender 
 trunk  that  I  give  those  guys  a  severe 
 haircut  prior  to  a  storm  because  and 
 sometimes  I'll  even  cut  a  little  gaps  in 
 them  so  this  is  the  time  to  give  your  to 
 really  experiment  with  your  cutting  you 
 can  give  them  as  ugly  bangs  as  they  need 
 just  because  it's  going  to  help  get  them 
 through  the  storm  they  will  flush  back 
 out  they  will  be  beautiful  but  the  last 
 thing  that  you  want  is  that  that  canopy 
 to  be  so  dense  and  so  thick  that  um  it 
 snaps  that  trunk  so  so  it  it  turns  into 
 a  sail  if  it  doesn't  have  if  it  can't 
 allow  air  to  pass  through  it  so  the  goal 
 is  is  to  really  open  that  tree  up  the 
 best  that  you  can  um  you  know  even  if 
 it's  green  and  I  and  I  know  normally  I 
 say  that  with  palm  trees  don't  cut  it  if 
 it's  still  green  but  in  this  case  even 
 some  of  those  lower  limbs  that  are 
 hanging  go  ahead  and  trim  those  off  and 
 I'll  give  you  some  some  insight  of  what 
 I  do  um  just  before  the  storm  hits 
 that's  going  to  help  protect  it  and  just 
 after  the  storm  hits  to  to  help  them 
 rebound  from  that  kind  of  stress  um  the 
 next  thing  I  do  um  and  this  is  not 
 necessarily  in  the  garden  but  I  think 
 it's  very  very  important  to  mention  is 
 um  I  I  clean  out  my  gutters  so  this  past 
 weekend  I  went  through  and  cleaned  out 
 my  gutters  and  um  really  kind  of  got  any 
 kind  of  leaf  debris  anything  out  of 
 there  and  really  made  sure  that  I  had  a 
 lot  of  um  you  know  I  had  had  good 
 drainage  going  on  you  know  my  house  is 
 pretty  level  I'm  just  on  a  slight 
 incline  for  those  of  you  guys  who  have  a 
 nice  nice  raise  then  you  might  not  have 
 to  worry  about  it  so  much  but  you  want 
 to  make  sure  that  all  of  that  water  that 
 um  Milton  is  going  to  bring  really  exits 
 um  along  the  foundation  of  the  house 
 line  so  you  kind  of  want  to  push  that 
 water  out  so  you  want  to  have  it  nice 
 and  clean  so  I  ran  a  hose  down  my  gutter 
 make  sure  everything  was  nice  and 
 flushed  and  clean  and  then  while  I  was 
 up  there  I  I  cleaned  my  gutters  didn't 
 realize  how  stained  they  were  when  I  was 
 there  but  anyway  so  so  that's  an 
 optional  thing  to  do  while  you're  while 
 you're  cleaning  your  gutters  for  the 
 storms  um  the  um  the  next  thing  I  do  is 
 all  of  my  big  trees  anything  that's  you 
 know  that  it  might  needs  extra  securing 
 anything  that  might  be  real  close  to  the 
 house  maybe  it  was  newly  planted  I've 
 done  this  for  my  clients  in  the  past 
 I'll  make  sure  that  Bryce  puts  up  a  um  a 
 video  clip  of  that  going  up  but  we  stake 
 them  with  wood  so  any  new  trees  that  you 
 have  or  any  trees  that  are  close  to  your 
 pool  screen  or  your  house  that  that  are 
 maybe  tall  and  kind  of  you  know  a  little 
 shaky  go  ahead  and  stake  them  um  better 
 to  be  safe  than  sorry  so  what  we  use  is 
 2x4s  to  to  brace  along  them  so  we  kind 
 of  just  dig  out  the  edges  a  little  bit 
 brace  three  to  four  2  by  2x4s  depending 
 on  the  size  of  the  tree  go  all  the  way 
 around  the  tree  we  take  and  cut  off 
 about  10  in  of  that  2x4  and  place  it 
 around  the  base  of  the  tree  around  the 
 trunk  of  the  tree  to  kind  of  help 
 protect  the  tree  itself  and  that  allows 
 us  to  be  able  to  screw  in  the  angled 
 2x4s  that  we  put  up  against  it  so  you 
 can  just  use  wood  screws  to  to  kind  of 
 angle  that  in  and  protect  the  tree  and 
 then  finally  we'll  we'll  do  two  rat 
 ratchet  straps  on  each  tree  um  just 
 because  there's  so  much  vibration  during 
 those  storms  especially  if  we  get  hurt 
 or  tornadoes  come  through  um  you  want  to 
 make  sure  those  ratchet  straps  are  going 
 to  just  going  to  seal  the  deal  of  making 
 sure  that  those  those  braces  stay  into 
 place  so  I  I'll  get  Bryce  to  kind  of  you 
 know  put  what  that  looks  like  um  maybe 
 even  a  clip  of  the  guys  um  installing 
 those  for  us  but  um  it's  really  it's 
 that's  an  ideal  thing  to  do  now  if  your 
 trees  are  12T  and  smaller  then  you  can 
 usually  use  just  the  strapping  material 
 and  some  rebar  it's  the  same  kind  of 
 concept  it's  just  more  of  the  pressure 
 kind  of  pulls  it  to  the  side  angle  in 
 those  rebar  pieces  and  then  um  strap  it 
 to  the  center  of  the  tree  and  you  can 
 just  kind  of  wrap  it  around  and  kind  of 
 tie  tie  a  knot  to  it  again  I  I'll  post  a 
 picture  of  what  that  looks  like  um  but 
 that  really  allows  that  tree  to  um  kind 
 of  give  it  some  extra  support  in  the 
 trunk  and  that's  kind  of  what  we're 
 trying  to  do  is  protect  the  trunk  of  the 
 tree  um  on  those  trees  the  reason  why  we 
 don't  use  the  wood  staks  on  those  is 
 because  the  last  thing  that  we  want  to 
 do  is  the  tree  to  stay  upright  but  the 
 tree  was  so  weak  because  it's  still 
 young  that  the  tree  breaks  in  half  so 
 you  it's  better  for  the  tree  to  actually 
 go  over  if  it's  a  young  tree  versus  um

 other  steak  are  going  to  be  just  enough 
 support  to  kind  of  help  it  through  some 
 of  the  some  of  those  winds  but  not  so 
 much  if  the  wind  really  comes  through 
 and  pushes  it  over  then  you  know  it  it's 
 better  that  way  than  to  snap  the  tree 
 itself  the  Big  Trees  however  those  those

 heavy  trunk  so  that's  why  we  use  the 
 2x4s  I  hope  that  makes  sense  so  um  so 
 definitely  go  ahead  and  stake  those 
 trees  this  is  the  time  to  do  it  as  we 
 know  that  the  storm  is  approaching  so

 this  house  these  trees  were  transplanted

 roots  have  been  cut  they  weren't  quite 
 ready  to  um  to  withstand  the  kind  of 
 storms  that  we've  had  they've  only  been 
 in  the  ground  newly  in  the  ground  again 
 for  2  weeks  so  what  we  did  is  we  put 
 plywood  on  those  and  then  we  put 
 strapping  on  these  but  first  we'll  talk 
 about  the  plywood  so  what  we  did  is  we 
 cut  these  2x4s  um  placed  them  um  the 
 ends  on  the  tree  itself  to  kind  of 
 protect  from  digging  into  the  tree  and 
 then  cut  the  angles  on  these  other 
 remain  on  the  other  remaining  2x4s  and 
 then  attach  them  to  the  boards  here  so 
 um  you  we  did  that  in  the  main  location 
 so  what  you  want  to  make  sure  is  that 
 you  get  all  the  way  around  the  tree 
 because  this  tree  um  over  over  during 
 those  wind  storms  it's  going  to  vibrate 
 so  you  want  to  make  sure  that  you  have 
 some  some  you  want  to  make  sure  that 
 it's  fastened  pretty  tightly  with  the 
 2x4s  and  then  ratchet  strapped  around  it 
 cuz  as  that  vibration  happens 
 these  guys  will  literally  come  off  the 
 edge  of  the  tree  so  this  ratet  strap  is 
 one  of  the  most  important  things  to  use 
 on  it  it  holds  it  secure  holds  it  tight 
 and  vibrates  with  the  tree  so  that  way 
 you  get  complete  coverage  now  on  a 
 larger  tree  this  one's  kind  of  narrow  so 
 three  is  just  fine  but  on  a  larger  a 
 thicker  tree  then  you're  going  to  want 
 to  use  four  that  way  you  get  all  the  way 
 around  the  tree  nice  and  easy  but  that 
 is  a  very  easy  and  simplistic  way  to  do 
 it  I  know  it  doesn't  look  like  it  but  a 
 few  snaps  um  these  ratchet  straps  make 
 it  very  very  easy  I  think  they're  like 
 N9  or  $10  so  it's  just  it's  definitely 
 worth  having  on  hand  and  then  just  cut 
 these  guys  that  way  you're  protecting 
 the  base  of  the  tree  and  then  angle 
 those  guys  in  right  into  the  ground 
 there  and  these  don't  have  to  be  dug 
 into  the  ground  you  see  they're  just 
 kind  of  just  kind  of  angled  into  the 
 ground  that  that  keeps  continuous 
 pressure  on  the  tree  now  we're  going  to 
 leave  these  on  here  for  the  rest  rest  of 
 the  season  so  since  we're  almost  through 
 it  um  but  you  can  leave  these  on  for  as

 not  beautiful  so  if  you  want  to  take

 answering  a  similar  question  over  and 
 over  again  in  um  within  the  comments  so 
 um  so  today's  question  is  weed  barrier 
 or  no  weed  barrier  and  the  answer  is  is 
 is  yes  and  no  and  I'll  explain  why  um 
 but  for  those  of  you  who  are  very  new  to 
 gardening  and  new  to  Florida  and  don't 
 um  use  weed  barrier  or  don't  know  what 
 weed  barrier  is  it's  pretty  much  the  um 
 the  black  mesh  barrier  that  is  used  on 
 top  of  the  ground  before  you  put 
 whatever  ground  cover  that  you  use  it's 
 what's  supposed  to  prevent  the  weeds 
 from  coming  up  and  through  it  um  now 
 we're  in  Florida  so  that's  you  know  it 
 it  it  helps  but  it's  not  perfect  the 
 projects  that  I  do  use  it  on  is  for 
 projects  that  we  install  stone  for 
 because  it's  very  very  important 
 important  to  have  a  barrier  base 
 underneath  of  your  stone  and  um  I'll  get 
 Bryce  to  show  you  an  example  of  what 
 that  uh  looks  like  in  um  actually  in  the 
 job  that  we  just  finished  that  you  just 
 saw  the  video  of  um  we  have  a  little 
 Stone  SWAT  there  so  in  that  stone  swath 
 we  use  that  barrier  as  a  base  before  we 
 put  our  Stone  on  top  of  and  so  that's 
 partially  to  help  you  with  the  weeds 
 that  are  going  to  come  up  through  those 
 rocks  CU  rocks  are  very  porous  there's 
 all  those  cracks  in  between  so  weeds 
 have  a  tendency  to  come  through  and  it 
 it's  it's  kind  of  hard  to  really  kind  of 
 pull  those  weeds  out  and  get  the  root 
 system  because  you  do  have  um  those 
 heavy  rocks  on  top  of  it  however  um  it's 
 kind  of  a  misconception  that  it  does  the 
 same  thing  for  mulch  it  it  it  really 
 doesn't  if  you  put  mulch  in  that  same 
 area  for  instance  in  that  same  um 
 project  that  you're  looking  at  um  we 
 haven't  uh  the  rest  of  it  is  Mulch  and 
 there  is  absolutely  no  weed  barrier 
 within  that  because  mulch  breaks  down 
 over  time  and  um  so  it  pretty  much  just 
 just  sandwiches  soil  above  and  soil 
 below  and  the  weeds  just  grow  um  along 
 the  top  of  that  with  mulch  so  mulch 
 really  doesn't  um  it  doesn't  promote 
 weeds  and  then  it  also  the  purpose  of 
 mulch  is  really  to  hold  that  moisture 
 around  the  roots  and  around  the  base  of 
 each  and  every  single  plant  and  with  the 
 weed  barrier  weed  berryer  has  a  tendency 
 to  really  restrict  um  the  water  from 
 getting  into  those  areas  so  I  don't  like 
 to  use  weed  barrier  and  mulch  it  kind  of 
 just  it  kind  of  doesn't  really  it  it 
 really  has  no  purpose  in  my  in  my 
 situation  so  I  don't  ever  put  it  within 
 the  plants  now  you'll  notice  that  I  use 
 plant  groupings  that  are  braided  plants 
 so  they  braid  at  the  bottom  which  means 
 the  roots  connect  at  the  bottom  and  the 
 C  the  the  upper  part  of  the  plant  the 
 stems  um  all  connect  at  the  top  so 
 you'll  notice  in  my  plant  groupings  I'll 
 have  like  a  swath  of  this  that's  fully 
 connected  and  then  the  only  Gap  is 
 within  the  next  um  plant  grouping  and 
 then  there's  a  swath  of  that  and  that 
 does  a  really  good  job  of  helping 
 helping  prevent  weeds  so  it's  more  of  a 
 a  clustering  plant  grouping  that  does  a 
 nice  job  of  preventing  weeds  but  um  so 
 yes  so  I  I'll  get  Bryce  to  kind  of  um 
 slide  some  of  those  uh  videos  in  from 
 that  video  you  just  watched  and  show  you 
 the  areas  with  stone  we  always  use  weed 
 barrier  it  helps  keep  the  stone  in  place 
 it  kind  of  helps  make  sure  that  it 
 doesn't  sink  or  you  don't  lose  Stone 
 over  time  and  then  of  course  it  does 
 help  with  the  weeds  and  that  kind  of 
 conditioning  now  keep  in  mind  and  I  know 
 this  isn't  part  of  that  question  but 
 when  you  use  plants  within  your  stone 
 garden  like  that  swath  we  have  in  that 
 particular  video  um  that  those  plants 
 you  want  to  make  sure  those  are  tough 
 hearty  plants  that  can  handle  the  bounce 
 back  from  that  stone  so  there's 
 definitely  um  rock  heats  up  so  you  know 
 the  things  like  the  blue  my  Minds  that 
 you  see  in  that  in  that  picture  and  the 
 yellow  thalis  super  super  they  love  it

 stone  wrapped  around  them  for  the  midday 
 heat  um  that's  what  you  want  to  keep  but 
 some  of  the  softer  plants  you  definitely 
 want  to  make  sure  they're  within  a  mulch 
 bed  because  they  need  that  little  cush 
 that  little  added  bit  of  moisture  so  um 
 so  I  I  hope  that  helps  you  guys 
 determine  whether  you  know  you're  you're 
 planning  on  using  weed  barrier  or  not 
 weed  barrier  so  my  entire  Garden  that 
 you  see  out  here  there  is  absolutely  no 
 weed  barrier  but  everywhere  you  see 
 Stone  there  is  weed  barrier  so  all  right

 helps  and  and  I  hope  um  I  I  i  i  as  you

 but  overall  um  your  garden  service  in

 getting  into  your  garden  about  every 
 quarter  that's  that's  the  average  amount 
 of  Maintenance  that's  what  I  do  in  my 
 own  space  because  it's  just  cuz  we're 
 busy  people  so  I  want  to  share  with  you

 shaped  but  it  is  an  aggressive  cut  back 
 because  that  is  what  we  need  we  need  to 
 let  air  into  those  plants  and  trees  to 
 really  flush  out  really  become  thick 
 from  the  bottom  out  so  so  let's  walk

 how  much  comes  off  one  plant  when  you

 you  almost  take  it  back  down  to  its 
 original  size  um  now  in  this  particular

 planting  but  you  can  let  them  become 
 individual  if  this  is  a  look  that  you 
 like  but  this  is  a  harsh  cutback  so  it's 
 been  almost  four  months  since  this  house 
 has  been  trimmed  and  you  can  really  see 
 that  it  now  looks  like  a  brand  new 
 landscape  again  the  hand  trimming  really

 everything  is  clipped  and  rounded  versus 
 um  when  you  come  up  through  with  a  hedge

 leaves  all  those  brown  edges  and  tips

 [Music] 
 so  the  one  thing  I  love  about  Florida 
 plants  is  that  overall  you  know  if  you 
 if  you  give  it  a  bad  haircut  it's  going 
 to  flush  back  out  it's  going  to  grow  so 
 why  not  practice  why  not  get  in  there 
 and  figure  out  exactly  the  shape  that 
 you're  hoping  to  achieve  with  a  planting 
 you  see  like  what  bernabi  is  doing  here 
 he's  really  making  sure  he's  kind  of 
 following  a  curved  path  and  all  he's 
 doing  is  trimming  the  things  that  are  on 
 the  outside  of  that  curved  path  and  you 
 you  also  want  to  see  there's  a  big  gap 
 app  in  here  and  this  is  just  the  way  the 
 tree  grows  so  the  goal  is  is  to  get  that 
 and  open  that  up  and  I  know  that  sounds 
 like  it's  counterproductive  but  if  you 
 can  open  that  up  and  allow  sun  to  get  in 
 there  once  it's  fertilized  it's  going  to 
 push  energy  back  out  into  that  hole 
 because  plants  naturally  do  want  to  fill 
 in  those  spaces  they  kind  of  want  to 
 become  full  and  become  solid  and  create 
 a  canopy  so  that's  exactly  what's  going 
 to  happen  with  that  tree  now  I  know 
 hibiscus  trees  are  especially  the  these 
 lollipop  shapes  are  very  controversial 
 some  people  love  them  real  full  real 
 natural  looking  some  people  want  them 
 like  a  nice  rounded  ball  so  it  really 
 just  depends  on  um  it  really  depends  on 
 your  space  your  house  what  you're 
 looking  for  how  much  coverage  you  want 
 out  of  it  but  don't  be  afraid  to  cut  it 
 way  back  a  couple  times  a  year  I  mean 
 I'm  talking  like  make  it  a  nice  lollipop 
 shape  and  then  allow  it  to  flush  out  in 
 all  those  spots  that  it  might  be  missing 
 maybe  a  bird  nested  in  a  certain  spot  so

 is  Loria  monsteras  are  going  to  get  that
