 Well,  hey  you  guys.  Happy  Saturday.  So, 
 today's  video  is  going  to  be  quick  and 
 succinct.  It's  going  to  be  based  pretty 
 much  on  how  to  care  for  your  buganilla 
 trees.  So,  this  video  is  inspired  by 
 Deborah.  Deborah,  hello,  if  you're 
 watching.  Um  Deborah  hired  me  to  do  her 
 uh  her  new  landscaping,  and  she  asked  me 
 to  incorporate  some  Buggania  plants 
 within  her  um  within  her  new  design.  And 
 then  she  quickly  backed  right  off  of 
 that  and  said,  "Yeah,  yeah,  yeah,  no, 
 no."  I  get  sucked  in  every  single  time 
 um  at  the  stores,  at  the  big  box  stores, 
 the  nurseries  on  bugganas.  Um  and  then  I 
 bring  them  home  and  then  a  month  later 
 they  look  like  a  bucket  of  sticks.  It's 
 where  buganas  come  to  die,  my  house.  And 
 so  she's  like,  I'm  not  going  to  do  it 
 again.  So  this  that's  happened  to  a  lot 
 of  us  and  I'm  sure  I'm  sure  and  it's 
 even  happened  to  me.  So  I  completely 
 understand.  And  so  I  want  to  do  a  quick 
 video  on  four  quick  tips  on  what  you 
 guys  can  do  to  keep  your  bugan  villas, 
 you  know,  pretty  much  just,  you  know, 
 nursery  worthy.  I  mean,  just  really 
 busting  with  blooms  because  they  bloom 
 all  year  long.  I  think  there's  very  very 
 few  plants  and  trees  that  give  you  the 
 impact  that  buganas  offer.  So  um  they're 
 definitely  worth  it.  They're  definitely 
 worth  a  little  extra  care  in  the  garden. 
 Um  and  and  you  know,  I  just  think 
 there's  a  little  misconception  about  um 
 how  to  care  for  them.  So  tip  number  one, 
 first  things  first,  they  definitely  need 
 sun.  So  they  need  a  minimum  of  five 
 hours  of  sun  every  single  day.  So  you 
 want  to  make  sure  that  they're  planted 
 in  the  proper  location  within  your 
 garden.  Now  my  boogan,  let  me  share  mine 
 with  you.  So  this  is  my  girl  here  and 
 then  I've  got  one  there 
 and  one 
 right  there.  Now  mine  are  in  pots 
 because  my  um  my  landscaping  is  very 
 tropical.  So  my  landscaping  has  um  you 
 know  my  irrigation  comes  on  three  times 
 a  week  and  that's  just  far  too  much  for 
 bugan  villas.  I  could  not  resist  not 
 having  a  couple  standard  trees  in  my 
 landscape.  So,  I  put  them  in  pots  um  and 
 knowing  that  I  kind  of  followed  those 
 guidelines  uh  that  that  I  could  keep 
 them  blooming.  Now,  these  guys  have  been 
 in  the  in  these  pots  for  a  couple  years 
 and  they're  doing  super  super  well.  I 
 kind  of  keep  them  at  the  prop  the 
 perfect  size  for  myself,  but  um  you 
 know,  I  just  kind  of  want  them  tipping 
 out  just  over  top  of  my  Kousia  hedge 
 there  so  I  can  see  them  as  I'm  coming  up 
 the  road.  Um,  but  they  get  um  they  get 
 all  morning  sun  up  until  about  six 
 o'clock  in  the  evening.  So,  they  really 
 get  a  good  dose  of  sun.  Now,  I've  got 
 one  more  bug  and  in  a  pot  over  there  by 
 my  um  my  seeding  section  and  it's  orange 
 um  and  pink  and  it's  absolutely 
 stunning,  but  it  does  not  bloom  nearly 
 as  much.  So,  I've  got,  you  know,  some 
 blooms  along  the  tips,  but  nowhere 
 nowhere  like  these  guys  are.  So,  um  the 
 first  things  first,  don't  overwater  your 
 Bugenville.  Make  sure  they're  in  the 
 sun.  Um,  if  they're  if  you  have  too  much 
 water  going  on  within  your  landscaping, 
 possibly  put  them  in  pots  like  I  have 
 them  here,  cuz  that  way  you  get  the 
 benefit  of  them  without  oversaturating 
 them.  If  they  are  going  to  be  in  the 
 garden,  make  sure  that  they're  in  an 
 area  where  your  sprinkler  system  is  not 
 hitting.  So  maybe  put  them  in  one 
 specific  cluster  within  the  landscape 
 and  then  have  your  irrigation  um  heads 
 kind  of  go  the  different  direction  that 
 you  need  them  to  go  and  kind  of  you  know 
 miss  or  or  just  do  a  soft  cast  over  top 
 of  those  irrigate  or  those  plants.  So 
 when  I  do  water  my  buganvillia  it's 
 about  every  two  weeks  um  10  days  to  two 
 weeks  if  it  hasn't  rained  I'll  come  out 
 and  I'll  give  them  a  just  a  deluge  of 
 water.  So,  I  will  take  the  hose  and  I 
 will  let  it  run  for  a  few  minutes  in 
 each  pot  and  let  that  water  just  kind  of 
 really  go  through  the  root  system  all 
 the  way  down.  I  have  good  I  have  a  big 
 drainage  hole  at  the  bottom  and  it 
 wasn't  quite  enough  for  the  amount  of 
 rain  that  we  get  here  in  Vero  Beach.  Um, 
 so  I  incorporated  or  incorporated  I 
 words  what  are  they?  So,  I  put  in  two 
 drainage  holes  in  the  backside  of  my 
 pots  as  well.  So,  that  way  I  know  that 
 my  plants  are  not  going to  get  root  rot. 
 They're  going  to  become  really  nice 
 strong  standard  trees.  So,  um,  drainage 
 is  a  big  one.  So,  and  the  the  the  next 
 tip  is  pretty  much  um  it's  a 
 misconception  about  bugan  villas  to  kind 
 of  forget  about  them.  That  makes  the 
 best  buganillaa.  Not  the  case.  So, 
 bugenville  really  really really  love  to 
 be  trimmed.  They  love  a  little  bit  of 
 haircut,  a  little  bit  of  pruning.  So, 
 um,  you  want  to  kind  of  take  right  on 
 these  edges  like  you  see  here,  you  just 
 kind  of  want  to  take  those  tips  off  and 
 you  kind  of  want  to  do  that  all  the  way 
 around  the  bug  and  villia  tree.  Just 
 kind  of  nip  all  of  the  outside  tips. 
 maybe  three  or  four  inches  of  those  tips 
 um  all  the  way  around  it.  And  it  does 
 two  things.  It  keeps  the  buganvea  nice 
 and  compact  and  dense  and  thick  and  and 
 solid  and  allows  the  blooms  to  kind  of 
 be  all  the  way  all  the  way  through.  I 
 mean,  look  how  compact  she  is.  And  you 
 know,  she  looks  like  she's  wearing  some 
 Spanx.  I  mean,  she  looks  fantastic, 
 doesn't  she?  So,  um  it  keeps  them  nice 
 and  thick  and  dense  and  blooming  all  the 
 way  around.  And  then  it  also  everywhere 
 that  you  bloom  everywhere  that  you  cut 
 um  you're  going  to  get  two  stems  off  of 
 that  cutting.  Since  bugenville  only 
 bloom  on  new  growth,  you're  really 
 doubling  your  money  because  those  two 
 stems  are  now  going  to  provide  you  two 
 two  blooms.  So  for  those  of  you  who  are 
 like  don't  want  to  turn  my  big  blooming 
 because  it's  absolutely  so  stunning. 
 You're  gonna  you're  going  to  double  your 
 money  with  it  because  you're  gonna 
 you're  gonna  you're  going  to  come  out 
 and  they're  going  to  be  like,  you  know,

 then  you're  gonna,  you  know,  everybody

 trimmed.  I  look  fabulous."  So,  um, 
 they're  they're  definitely  worth.  So, 
 when  you  come  out,  do  that  about  every 
 two  months  in  the  summer.  Just  kind  of 
 nip  just  those  outside  edges  and  they  it 
 they'll  they'll  reward  you  for  it.  And 
 so,  at  the  same  time  that  I  do  that,  my 
 final  tip  is  hit  it  with  some 
 fertilizer.  So,  I  um  because  they're  in 
 pots  and  I  have  a  tendency  to  overfeed

 so  I  do  that  every  two  months.  So,  my 
 pattern  is  um  every  couple  months  I  put
